title: Cellphone in New Role: Loyalty Card
description: Loyalty cards  those little paper cards that promise a free sandwich or coffee after 10 purchases, but instead get lost or forgotten  are going mobile. And merchants are looking for ways to marry the concept to games that customers can play to earn more free items and, it is hoped, spend more money.

title: Three Men and a Video Camera, Out to Reveal Urban Truths

title: Paterson Now Focuses on Layoffs to Cut Budget

title: Iraqs Psyche, Through a Green Zone Prism
description: BAGHDAD  The term was coined by the American military. But unlike some others  say, entry control points  the name managed to stick in the popular imagination. Green Zone always seemed to say so much, here and abroad. It was the imperial outpost of an occupation, or the citadel of a government never quite sovereign  bulwark or bubble, refuge or unreality.

title: Airline Reward Programs Pay Off Less Frequently
description: FOR participants in frequent-flier programs, more miles are chasing fewer seats, and the problem is likely to get worse.

title: Throwing a Lifeline to a Teenager in Need
description: Alexander Carno passes too much time staring out the window of the tidy bedroom he shares with his grandfather, relying on binoculars to take him down 19 flights to the Harlem street below. Sometimes, being a 17-year-old boy, he notices a girl, or watches his old friends, hanging out and laughing. Sometimes, he stares at the corner where he was shot last December, remembering the moment when he realized, as bullet met bone, that his legs no longer did as they were told. I tried to run, he said recently. But nothings faster than a bullet.

title: Who Should Be Called Soldier, and Who Shouldnt
description: On yet another Memorial Day, hundreds of people made their way Monday to the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, the colonnaded memorial built more than a century ago at Riverside Drive and 89th Street to honor New Yorks Civil War dead.

title: Obama Improvises After Speech Rainout

title: Make Kendras Law Permanent

At the time lawmakers were searching for a useful response to the tragic death of 32-year-old Kendra Webdale, who was pushed in front of a subway train in Manhattan by a stranger who had untreated schizophrenia.

With the 2010 count under way, people were paying attention. And the bill, which grants the Census Bureau director more independence, is a smart response to the chronic problems that have plagued census planning: fragmented leadership, political interference and not enough financing.

title: Its Up to You, Mr. Holder

Sadly, a recent ruling by a federal appeals court on the American military prison at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan was not one of those times.

A similar attempt failed three weeks ago, but officials said they had resolved some of the technical problems that forced them to abort last time.

title: China: Earthquake Death Toll Increased
description: Quake Officials have raised the death toll from the earthquake that devastated the city of Jiegu in Qinghai Province last month, the state media said Monday. The provincial government now says that 2,698 bodies have been recovered and that 270 people are missing. In the previous estimate, issued in late April, officials said 2,220 had died and 70 were missing. More than 12,000 people were injured. Officials attributed the rise to newly discovered bodies and a failure to report the deaths of family members. The 6.9-magnitude earthquake, which struck on April 14, affected a predominantly Tibetan area and prompted a massive rescue and relief operation by the Chinese government. Xinhua, the official news service, also said on Monday that Chinese individuals and groups had donated almost $1 billion in goods and money to relief efforts.

title: Iran Moves to Thwart Protests Ahead of Election Anniversary
description: Moving to thwart any protests on the anniversary of a disputed election, the authorities in Iran have ordered at least two million paramilitary members into Tehran, re-arrested dissident activists furloughed from prison and aggressively enforced public bans on mingling of the sexes and un-Islamic womens clothing.

title: In Review, Europe Accuses China of Protectionism
description: China is failing to carry out its pledges to liberalize its economy and open its markets to foreign companies, according to the European Union, which accused the nation of protectionism to prop up its domestic industry. Even though China reiterates its firm commitment to continued opening-up and reform, this does not duly characterize the current situation in China, John Clarke, head of the European Unions delegation to the World Trade Organization, said on Monday during Chinas trade policy review in Geneva. In fact, our companies have reported a worsening of the business climate. Mr. Clarke said China used a weak currency, export incentives and subsidies to bolster its economy. Trade in goods between the bloc and China was worth 296 billion euros ($364 billion) last year.

title: Inquiry Faults Ex-Canadian Leader on Cash From Lobbyist

title: Canada: Passenger on Flight Identified

The United States did not allow the flight, from Paris to Mexico City, to enter its airspace after it learned that Mr. Gaal was on board. He was arrested on an outstanding warrant, but the United States Transportation Security Administration and the Canada Border Services Agency declined to say who issued the warrant or what charges Mr. Gaal faced. The Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada declined to identify Mr. Gaals nationality or say where he lived. An immigration hearing is set for Wednesday.

Telus did not disclose financial terms of the deal.

title: Banksy Work Is Moved After Threats
description: A mural painted by the pseudonymous British artist Banksy has been taken off display at a nonprofit gallery in Detroit after the gallery said the work had been threatened with defacement or destruction, The Detroit Free Press reported. The mural, above, which depicts a boy holding a can of paint and standing next to the message I remember when all this was trees, was discovered at the citys abandoned Packard Plant in May. A few days later the 7-by-8-foot, 1,500-pound cinder block wall bearing the work was taken by artists from the 555 Nonprofit Gallery and Studios, who said they were given permission by a crew removing scrap metal from the plant. Carl W. Goines, the executive director and co-founder of the gallery, told The Free Press, There was a lot of anxiety with the threats, so our board of directors requested that we move it until it can be displayed safely. The gallery artists said they were not seeking to sell the Banksy work and were trying to preserve and protect it.

title: After Theft, Paris Museum Is to Reopen
description: A Paris museum that last month was the site of a burglary of five paintings will reopen on June 10, Agence France-Presse reported. A lone thief broke into that citys Museum of Modern Art, near the Eiffel Tower, before it opened for the day on May 20, shearing off a gate padlock and breaking a window. The stolen pieces included Picassos 1912 Cubist painting Dove With Green Peas and Matisses 1905 Pastoral, as well as works by Georges Braque, Amedeo Modigliani and Fernand Lger, and are believed to be valued at about $120 million. The thief was able to take advantage of a flaw in the museums alarm system, which had been malfunctioning for several weeks, leading to speculation that the thief may have had inside assistance. The museum said it would reopen with an exhibition spotlighting young French artists.

title: Fans Say Farewell to Dio
description: As befits a man who sang about tigers, demons, wizards, evil and hell, the heavy-metal vocalist Ronnie James Dio, below, was treated to a raucous memorial service on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Dio, who sang in the band that bore his name, as well as in groups like Rainbow, Black Sabbath and Heaven and Hell, was 67 when he died of stomach cancer on May 16. More than 1,200 fans gathered at a service inside the Hall of Liberty at Forest Lawn Memorial-Park in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles, while hundreds more watched on monitors outside. Among the musicians who performed at the service were the keyboardist Scott Warren, who played a piano arrangement of Dios This Is Your Life; John Payne of Asia, who sang Black Sabbaths Heaven and Hell; and Joey Belladonna of Anthrax, who sang Rainbows Man on the Silver Mountain. Willie Fyfe, Mr. Dios personal assistant, said: Once he had a crowd in his hands, thats where they stayed until it was time to go, then hed give them back, and walk off and do his thing. Bless him. Hes still doing that now, and the guy is in a coffin.

Between classes, you eat on the street, said Mr. Wong, who is 46 and Malaysian Chinese. Street hawkers would sell the students piping-hot stir-fried glass noodles with seafood, served on a banana leaf, for 10 cents.

None other than Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas and a global-warming skeptic, upbraided BP managers for their seeming indifference to safety and environmental issues.

Mr. Scott finds much here to admire, saying that Mira Nair draws together an unruly tangle of plots and subplots, and handles them with clarity and grace. Have you seen Monsoon Wedding? description: Our show begins with a series of images revealing the fierce reaction to Israels attack on a flotilla of ships bound for Gaza (Slides 1 through 6). The fallout widened on Tuesday amid growing criticism of the raid, which left nine activists dead. Egypt reopened its border with Gaza to allow aid to pass through, and activists said they had sent another ship toward the area.

title: The Morning Line: Pletcher Ends Another Hex
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Putting Queens on the Tourism Map
description: Queens is the first and last place many tourists see when they arrive in New York, but one they rarely visit. Home to John F. Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, it has long been seen as a place to pass through on the way to or from Manhattan.

title: More on Cortney Munnas Student Loan Tale
description: This weekends Your Money column profiled Cortney Munna, a 26-year-old San Francisco resident who ended up with nearly $100,000 in student loan debt after finishing her undergraduate degree at New York University. Here, she responds to some of the nearly 600 comments on the story.

title: Queens Students Sickened, Probably by Contaminated Water
description: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | About 80 children at Public School 20, an elementary school in Flushing, Queens, became ill Tuesday afternoon, apparently after drinking from water fountains that were contaminated by an air-conditioning chemical, the Department of Education said.

title: Not Exactly Preaching to the Choir
description: A basement theater in Long Island City is an unlikely place to see a miracle. But the Lord  and Off Off Broadway  works in mysterious ways.

title: Some iPads Cant Take the Heat
description: What lovely New York weather we had this weekend: sunny, high 80s and a light breeze. Perfect for lying around outside and reading a good book. That is, if the book you are hoping to read is not on an iPad.

title: Case Study | Vintage Cocktails
description: Everyone knows that aging a spirit transforms it from fiery youthfulness to softly purring maturity, with the requisite increase in prestige and price to match. The mixologist Tony Conigliaro, who owns 69 Colebrooke Row in Londons Islington district, has been taking the process a step further, aging fully prepared cocktails.

title: Mere Silence Doesnt Invoke Miranda, Justices Say
description: WASHINGTON  Criminal suspects seeking to protect their right to remain silent must speak up to invoke it, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, refining the courts landmark 1966 ruling in Miranda v. Arizona.

title: Perfectionist Parents
description: I do not claim to have ever been a perfectionist. A peek into my closets will confirm that. But whatever orderly tendencies I once had were challenged  and conquered  by the early days of parenting. Think of flawlessness as the rock and infancy is the hard place. Do those caught in between ever fully recover?

title: Upscale Mexican Food in Philadelphia
description: Stephen Starr, who owns a string of high-profile restaurants in Philadelphia including Buddakan and Morimoto, has gone south-of-the-border opening El Rey, a moderately priced Mexican restaurant in the citys Center City neighborhood, last month.

title: Posada Is Closer to Returning
description: Jorge Posada, on the disabled list since May 17 with a hairline fracture in his right foot, arrived at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday expecting to be in the lineup. Instead, it looks as if he will have to wait another day.

title: Kirsten Dunst Forgoes Laughs in Return to the Witness Stand
description: Just over eight months after The New York Post declared her Kirsten Dunce, the actress Kirsten Dunst showed up in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday with a complete personality makeover.

title: How Soderling Knocked Off Federer
description: Robin Soderling stunned the defending French Open champion, Roger Federer, in four bone-crushing sets, avenging last years straight-sets thrashing by Federer and ending Federers streak of 23 appearances in a Grand Slam semifinal at 23. If revenge is a dish best served cold, then Soderlings huge serving and brutal ball striking kept Federer from finding any warmth on the cold, rainy day.

title: So Far, Revivals Eclipse Newer Pieces in City Ballets Season
description: So far this season, the main story at New York City Ballet has been not the new ballets but the old ones. I have watched two Robbins ballets (Opus 19: The Dreamer and Im Old Fashioned) with, amazingly, greater admiration than I felt with their original casts. In Balanchines Serenade the corps de ballet brought an intensity and a wealth of inflections that had been lacking in the ballets last appearances here, and at one performance Teresa Reichlen (in the Russian dance) and Sara Mearns (as the Dark Angel) were both incandescent.

title: Off the Menu: 1st Ave Steak Shoppe
description: Lesley Bernard has turned Permanent Brunch into a place with a different focus: steak. 1st Ave Steak Shoppe will serve four cuts, eight ounces, all grass-fed or natural, with pickles, and salad, $17 to $22. Other side dishes are available as are wines, beers and spirits, but no cocktails.

title: The TV Watch: An Oprah Visitation for the Royal She
description: She may be in disgrace, again, but Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, still hasnt lost her regal touch. Telling Oprah Winfrey on Tuesday about being caught on tape soliciting a 500,000 bribe from an undercover tabloid reporter posing as an Indian businessman, Ms. Ferguson kept referring to herself in the third person  the royal she.

title: Rachel Alexandra May Race on June 12
description: Despite two disappointing losses, Jess Jackson has not given up on Rachel Alexandra, and now is looking at three options to run the reigning Horse of the Year on June 12. He has circled races in Kentucky, New York and Delaware.

title: The Passage
description: Wolgast had been to the Compound only once, the previous summer, to meet with Colonel Sykes. Not a job interview, exactly; it had been made clear to Wolgast that the assignment was his if he wanted it. A pair of soldiers drove him in a van with blacked out windows, but Wolgast could tell they were taking him west from Denver, into the mountains. The drive took six hours, and by the time they pulled into the Compound, hed actually managed to fall asleep. He stepped from the van into the bright sunshine of a summer afternoon. He stretched and looked around. From the topography, hed have guessed he was somewhere around Telluride. It could have been further north. The air felt thin and clean in his lungs; he felt the dull throb of a high-altitude headache at the top of his skull.

title: The Justice Department Seeks Evidence of Crimes in the Gulf
description: More than 40 days after 11 men died in an inferno when that deep-sea oil well blew its top, President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder announced that criminal investigations were part of the broader inquiry into the petro-calamity in the Gulf of Mexico. The announcements came after several weeks in which Justice Department officials had publicly spoken only of civil cases.

title: Blumenthal Is on the Air in Connecticut
description: Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Connecticut, has gone up with his first television advertisements of the campaign, casting himself as a fighter willing to go to bat for his states residents.

title: Disney and Facebook Join Hands to Move Some Tickets
description: In what may be the first such initiative, Walt Disney Pictures has entered into an agreement with Facebook in which users of the social-networking site will be able to purchase tickets to Disneys upcoming Toy Story 3 as well as alert their friends to join them. Brooks Barnes has the full story.

title: Literary Novelist Turns to Vampires and Finds Pot of Gold
description: Justin Cronin is the author of an epic, multimillion-dollar, 766-page novel that stars bloodthirsty creatures that run in packs and savagely kill people at night. And hes planning to turn it into a trilogy.

title: Economist: Blame Government for the Crisis
description: As the search for causes of the financial crisis continues in Washington, one economist, Russell Roberts of George Mason University, says he believes that it was inept government policy, not Wall Street greed, that allowed the financial system to spin out of control.

title: Lexus Drives to the Jagged Edge
description: Drinking and driving do not mix. Is that why Lexus is shattering a Champagne glass in a new commercial?

title: The Pink Tea Cup Returns
description: The resurrection of the Pink Tea Cup in Greenwich Village, which closed in January, will soon open nearby and on a much grander scale than the venerable soul food restaurant. The new owner, Lawrence Page, has given it a polished setting with more than 100 seats, a full bar, a lounge, a cabaret and also a 600-seat catering hall. It came about fortuitously. Mr. Page, who owned the Actors Playhouse on Seventh Avenue South, had already rented the space to open a wine bar, but when the Pink Tea Cup closed he decided it had to be saved. So he moved it over to the space he already had and what had been the Actors Playhouse. The classic soul food menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner has also been expanded, with dishes like rack of lamb with lobster mashed potatoes, as well as some lighter dishes. Mr. Page has Glander Glover, who had been a chef at the original restaurant for 15 years, back in the kitchen, along with the executive chef, Angela Groover. I want an all-female kitchen, Mr. Page said. It opens June 7.

title: On Location in Transylvania
description: Ligia Valcus home in Brasov, Romania, an alpine village 100 miles north of Bucharest, is surrounded by cobblestone streets and quiet gardens.

title: Morgenthau Withdraws From Fire Dept. Case
description: Bowing to concerns over his appointment but fiercely defending his record, Robert M. Morgenthau stepped down on Tuesday from his role overseeing the citys efforts to increase the number of minority firefighters in response to a long running discrimination lawsuit.

title: In Romania, Creating a Bohemian Attic
description: BRASOV, ROMANIA  Surrounded by cobblestone streets and quiet gardens, Ligia Valcus home, here in this alpine city 100 miles north of Bucharest, miraculously escaped razing during the communist era, when many traditional buildings were torn down and replaced with drab apartment buildings.

title: Half a Dozen States Delay Tax Refunds
description: Procrastination is no longer just for the taxpayers who wait until the last moment to file their tax returns. Thanks to the economic downturn, at least a half-dozen cash-poor states are now delaying their tax refund checks.

title: Readers Take No Ifs, Ands or Cigarette Butts on the Sidewalk
description: The New York city sidewalk is a battleground. Residents take issue with tourists who walk too slowly. Singletons get annoyed when confronted withdouble strollers in their way. And non-dog-owners who must swerve to avoid a steaming pile may have the urge to curse Lassie, and her owner, who failed to stoopto scoop.

title: Strike Status at Honda in China Is Uncertain
description: SHANGHAI  A Honda spokesman in China said operations had resumed on Wednesday after a strike at the Japanese automakers transmission plant in southern China had shut down production.

title: Loans That Vanished in a Property Bust Reappear
description: The W Hotel in Union Square has had an eventful six months. The 270-room hotel changed hands in December after the private equity division of Dubai World defaulted on a $117 million mezzanine loan in the face of dwindling business. But the lender, LEM Mezzanine, could itself lose the hotel in coming months as a result of its filing for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.

title: The iPad Pulse Reader Scales the Charts
description: June 8 | Updated  Apple removed the Pulse News Reader from the App Store after the New York Times Company objected to it. It was later reinstated. See our post on the matter.

title: On The Things They Carry
description: Soldiers from the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., talked about the things they plan to take with them.

title: Another Los Angeles in Gardener
description: LOS ANGELES  Quiet on the set was no small order last week, as Chris Weitz, probably best known as the director of The Twilight Saga: New Moon, worked a grittier side of the street on this citys largely Hispanic East Side.

title: Showing the Benefits of Green Retrofits
description: The practice of retrofitting buildings with simple, environmentally friendly technology like more-efficient boilers and better-quality windows has been around for years, but there is little research on how much energy these changes actually save  and by extension, how much money they can save landlords and lenders.

title: Recasting the Cold War as the Hitchcock Years
description: In 1962, as he was shooting The Birds, Alfred Hitchcock had an encounter on the Universal Studios lot with an older version of himself, mysteriously arrived from 1980 with some sobering news about life, death and cinema. This meeting (inspired by a short prose piece called August 25, 1983, by Jorge Luis Borges) is one of the conceits of Double Take, Johan Grimonprezs intriguing new film. Mark Perry, sounding uncannily like the man himself, narrates the fictitious younger Hitchcocks account of this peculiar event, while two look-alikes, including Ron Burrage, a longtime and well-known Hitchcock impersonator, act it out.

title: House Hunting in France
description: A six-bedroom house with details like beamed ceilings, wood floors and marble staircases.

title: Husbands Expectation Meets Life, and Loses
description: Were it not for the election of the countrys first African-American president two years ago, we might all be a little bit more worked up about the regressive race comedies on basic cable television. We might be writing letters and protesting and demanding a remake of The Jeffersons.

title: House Hunting in ... France
description: A SIX-BEDROOM HOUSE IN PROVENCE

title: In Memoir, Christopher Hitchens Looks Back
description: Christopher Hitchens was in boarding school and barely out of short pants when he first learned that words could function as weapons. He was small, bad at sports and got picked on. He worried he was becoming a mere weed and weakling and kick-bag. So one day he turned on a tormenter. You, the young Mr. Hitchens declared, are a liar, a bully, a coward, and a thief. His stunned tormentor slunk away.

title: What You Get for $500,000
description: Properties for sale in Atlanta, Los Lunas, N.M., and Portland, Ore.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: ATLANTA

title: Home Cooks Take to the Street
description: The Greenpoint Food Market in Brooklyn provides an audience for amateur home cooks looking to enter the food world.

title: Gaza: Reaction in Iraq, Pakistan and Afghanistan
description: Israels deadly commando raid on a flotilla of pro-Palestinian activists heading for Gaza drew widespread media coverage across the Middle East, and farther afield in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Voters Make Choices in 3 Primaries
description: The primary election season advanced on Tuesday, with voters in Alabama, Mississippi and New Mexico selecting their partys nominees for the general election in dozens of federal and state races.

title: Activists Pledge to Send More Ships to Gaza
description: Updated | 10:05 p.m. After Israeli commandos killed nine pro-Palestinian activists  and detained about 600 more  while intercepting a flotilla of ships trying to break through a naval blockade to deliver 10,000 tons of aid to Gaza on Monday, Israels government and groups behind the protest continued to blame each other for the deaths.

title: Israeli Force, Adrift on the Sea
description: ARAD, Israel

title: Exotic Isle for Artists, Right in City
description: When New York City artists plan their workdays, they usually dont have to factor in a ferry boat.

title: Sculptors With a D.I.Y. Style
description: Three solo gallery shows in Chelsea present younger artists working primarily in sculpture: Johannes VanDerBeek, Josephine Meckseper and Siobhan Liddell.

title: Creative Debate Among Sculptors, Not Too Loud
description: Artistically speaking, West Chelsea  land of several hundred art galleries  is a tower of Babel spread on the horizontal. On any given day, scores of different visual languages are being spoken at once, often in raised voices. Arguments made by one show for one aesthetic position are immediately, sometimes violently, countered by the show next door. The effect can be cacophonous and confusing, although the other extreme is probably more disconcerting: when too many shows are talking alike.

title: At Spoleto, a Departing Director and a Premiere
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  News broke out on Monday here at the Spoleto Festival USA after a placid opening weekend. Emmanuel Villaume, the French conductor who has been the festivals music director for opera and orchestra since 2001, announced that he would leave at the end of the season.

title: Unemployed and O.K. With It, if Theyre Not Alone
description: People are less unhappy about being unemployed if their friends are also out of work, according to a new study from the World Bank based on British data.

title: A More Cheerful New York Subway Map
description: Sometime this month the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will release its redesign of the New York subway map, the first new version since 1998. Short of reducing the number of subway lines, there is probably little more that designers can do to make the citys subway map easier to decipher.

title: Rethinking the Gaza Blockade
description: Updated, June 2, 12:05 p.m. |  Rime Allaf, from Chatham House in London, says that the only solution is for the U.S. to rein in Israel.

title: Beiruts Updated Lebanese Cuisine
description: A few of the restaurants and dishes that are revitalizing Beiruts dining scene.

title: At Co-op City, Trash Piles Up as Workers Go on Strike
description: Mountains of trash bags sprouted across Co-op City on Tuesday as residents and office workers rushed to perform basic maintenance tasks left undone by more than 500 unionized janitors, groundskeepers and parking attendants who went on strike in a contract dispute.

title: A Chorus of Echoes, for Better and Worse
description: Fresh from his success conducting the complex score and loony characters of Ligetis Grand Macabre in the New York Philharmonics triumphant production last week, Alan Gilbert faced a very different challenge on Monday during the orchestras annual Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: Frustrated Posada Is Eager to Return
description: The first time reporters approached Jorge Posada on Tuesday, he said that he was finished answering questions about his status. A while later, after he had cooled off, he explained the source of his frustration.

title: ABC Kitchen
description: ANOTHER day, another restaurant from Jean-Georges Vongerichten. The latest is ABC Kitchen, a winsome sprawl on the ground floor of ABC Carpet & Home, luxe Manhattans best source for Ganesh statues and pillows marked with nautical signal flags. As has become custom for Mr. Vongerichten of late, it is very good.

title: Reviewing ABC Kitchen, in ABC Carpet and Home
Is There Still Hope for Syrah?
description: FORESTVILLE, Calif.

title: 10 Ideal Syrahs From California
description: I remember visiting the Santa Barbara wine country 10 years ago and feeling impressed by the syrah wines coming from the area, and by the prospects of California syrah in general. It was supposed to be the new merlot, a popular wine that even wine-lovers could embrace. By 2002, potential problems for California syrah were already becoming apparent.

title: Jobs Bill vs. Deficit, a Showdown in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON

title: Icahn Extends His Hostile Bid for Lions Gate
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn once again extended his hostile tender offer for Lions Gate Entertainment on Tuesday and the company responded by saying the offer has once again been rejected by shareholders, Reuters reports.

title: YouTube Dominates Online Video Views
description: Although Googles purchase of YouTube hasnt paid of financially, it has clearly made Google a giant in the world of online video, displaying more than 13 billion videos during the month of April.

title: Rossi a Surprise Omission From Italy
description: The American-born forward Giuseppe Rossi, who left his home in Clifton, N.J., at age 12 to pursue his dream of playing international soccer for Italy, was cut Tuesday from the final 23-man Italian World Cup roster.

title: Flavors of the Garden in Shortbread Cookies
description: Fragrant lavender, refreshing lemon thyme, earthy fennel pollen, rich cinnamon basil and spicy ginger are the flavors of these buttery little bites from Napa Valley. They are made with premium ingredients like Straus Family Creamery butter, and tread the line between sweet and savory.

title: A Blade That Makes Pizza Cutting Easier
description: If you have ever been frustrated using the often flimsy wheel-type pizza cutters, which sometimes make a ragged mess of the pie, heres the tool for you. Its a big, gently curved 14-inch stainless-steel blade with a hardwood handle that neatly cuts the pie straight across as you use a rocking motion. It works extremely well on other flatbreads, like focaccia, and is even sharp enough to make short work of a pile of herbs on a cutting board. A hole near one edge of the blade allows you to store it on a hook.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Kyochon and Bon Chon
description: THE crisp, tawny pleasures of Korean-style fried chicken arent new to New York. But this year, what had been a low-frequency contest between two chains based in South Korea, with a few local branches, intensified as each opened a flagship within a few months and a few Midtown blocks of each other.

title: For Would-Be Cooks in New York, a School With Small Classes
description: If you go back some 20 years, you will find dozens of small, hands-on cooking schools for home cooks all around New York. Then came the mega schools, with scores of courses for would-be chefs as well as amateurs, and those more intimate classes became more scarce. For the last eight years, Jennifer Clair (second from left), a former chef and food editor, has been teaching individuals and small groups in the Hudson Valley, and in peoples homes in Manhattan. This spring she opened a school in Chelsea and now has an expanded schedule of full participation sessions. There is a maximum of 10 students in each, and they include a meal at the end. Childrens classes and private classes are also available.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Dips and Grills 101

title: Young Food Entrepreneurs Make Their Future by Hand
description: THEY carry home-grown radishes and red-cooked pork. They transport dozens of empanadas, juggling sheet pans on the G train. They pack boxes of butterscotch cupcakes, Sichuan-spiced beef jerky and grapefruit marmalade. They haul boiled peanuts, ice-grinding machines, sandwich presses and at least one toaster oven painted hot pink.

title: Organic Gin Just Like Farmers Make (but Legal)
description: Gin, mixed in a martini, is the epitome of sophistication. There is nothing rustic about it. But in this age of everything artisanal and organic, you now have Farmers Gin. Its a small-batch production from the people who make Crop Harvest Earth organic vodkas, based on grains from organic farms in the upper Midwest and infused with classy herbs like elderflower, lemon grass and angelica, besides the required juniper.

title: Dried Limes, a Middle Eastern Secret for Flavoring Soups and Stews
description: FOR years I had been walking past dried limes in Middle Eastern markets. Dusky brown things slightly larger than Ping-Pong balls, ringed with faint, ghostly stripes, they always seemed vaguely sinister. Even one of their common names  black limes  conveyed an air of culinary menace.

title: Top Chefs and Restaurateurs Are Drawn to Beirut
description: Beirut

title: Sour Beer Is Risky Business, Starting With the Name
description: BREWERS of barrel-aged sour beer take risks and practice patience. They wait as long as three years to see whether the cloudy liquids resting in oak ripen into shades of gold or raspberry and develop the ideal tart, tangy flavors, or become undrinkable, ravaged by aggressive yeasts. Its an expensive gamble.

title: The Israeli Commandos and the Flotilla
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooking Up a Dream
description: In New York City, the recent economic downturn has thrown many good cooks  both professional and amateur  out of work. Dozens of them are now trying to start careers as food entrepreneurs, making cupcakes and kimchi, beef jerky and kombucha, and selling at the citys new weekend food markets. Youve probably seen some. Do you have any favorites?

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Europes Debt Crisis Starts to Weigh on Manufacturing
description: FRANKFURT  Signs emerged Tuesday that Europes sovereign debt crisis was feeding through into the euro area economy, as unemployment rose and a survey pointed to a slowdown in the recovery of manufacturing, with a sharp decline in Greece.

title: Ball Kids Wake Up the French Open
description: PARIS  The children line up outside Court No. 1 before the gates open to the public. There are 250 of them, les ramasseurs de balles, the gatherers of the balls. They are between 12 and 16 years old, and they dress in matching shirts and shorts.

title: Mayor Proposes Cutting School Nursing Positions
description: New York City workers may be facing layoffs. Libraries are bracing to lose financing, and caseworkers are girding for bigger loads. Now add to the list of victims of citywide budget cuts nursing positions at small schools, public and private.

title: After Flotilla Raid, U.S. Is Torn Between Allies
description: WASHINGTON  Struggling to navigate a bitter split between two important allies, the Obama administration on Tuesday tried to placate an outraged Turkish government while refusing to condemn Israel for its deadly raid on a flotilla of aid ships bound for Gaza.

title: The Gores Separate After 4 Decades
description: After 40 years of political defeats and policy triumphs, Al and Tipper Gore announced they would separate.

title: Two Dried Lime Recipes, One Traditional, One Anything But
description: Though they look kind of like lumpy little rocks, dried limes actually have all kinds of uses as a flavoring. They are excellent used whole in soups and stews as well as lentil and bean dishes; when ground up, theyre great rubbed directly onto steaks or chops, or combined with other spices and a bit of oil to make a paste for rubbing on seafood.

title: 3 Mayors Seek to Honor a Master of Campaigns
description: From the back porch of Gracie Mansion, John V. Lindsay looked into the camera and ate crow: I guessed wrong on the weather before the citys biggest snowstorm last winter. And that was a mistake. But I put 6,000 more cops on the street. And that was no mistake. The school strike went on too long, and we all made some mistakes. But I brought 225,000 more jobs to this town. And that was no mistake.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: U.S. Opens Criminal Inquiry

title: North Korea Trying for Unexpected in World Cup Again
description: JOHANNESBURG  North Koreas soccer team arrived Tuesday at the World Cup, where it will be supported by cheerleaders recruited from China, led by a forward born in Japan and prohibited at home from receiving free television coverage provided by fellow competitor and political rival South Korea.

title: Concussion Committee Breaks With Predecessor
description: WASHINGTON  They accused a fellow doctor of minimizing solid evidence of the dangers of football concussions. They concurred that data collected by the N.F.L.s former brain-injury leadership was infected, said that their committee should be assembled anew, and formally requested that the groups former chairman, Dr. Elliot Pellman, not speak at a conference Wednesday.

title: Entrepreneur or Unemployed?
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: For Rugby Fans, a First Trip to Soweto
description: SOWETO, South Africa  The wildly zealous fans of rugbys Blue Bulls are a decidedly white lot but for the blue paint they smear on their faces and the blue wigs they fit over their scalps. They customarily attend games at Pretorias Loftus Versfeld Stadium, where they are comfortably among their own kind and the language over the loudspeakers is Dutch-rooted Afrikaans.

title: New N.Y. Schools Face Extra Pain From Layoffs
description: Glancing down the hallway at the Brooklyn Brownstone School, Nakia Haskins, the principal, did a quick calculation.

title: Assumptions Go Asunder as Gores Split
description: WASHINGTON  In the baby-boomer psychodrama of the 1990s, Al and Tipper Gore supposedly had the enduring marriage while the union of the other half of their buddy movie  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton  seemed not so likely to last.

title: Investment in Rolen Is Paying Off for the Reds
description: ST. LOUIS  When Scott Rolen surveys the Cincinnati Reds clubhouse, he likes what he sees. It is not because the Reds are leading the National League in most important offensive categories, as they were through Monday. Lots of players can hit, Rolen said, but how many can really play? There is a difference.

title: Cuckoo!  Cuckoo!
description: A few weeks ago, I was walking through a wood in the English countryside when I heard the unmistakable call of the cuckoo. For some reason, it caused me to fall into a reverie, and as I walked, I began to meditate on that iconic bird and what it represents.

title: What to Watch: Serena Williams vs. Samantha Stosur
description: Samantha Stosur used her superb kick serve and heavy topspin forehand to keep Justine Henin off balance and well behind the baseline. Its a smart play against a one-handed backhand to get the ball up out of the strike zone, forcing the smaller Henin to hit a lot of balls at shoulder level or higher. This also pushed Henin well off the baseline, and Stosur pounced on anything short to score the huge upset.

title: Is Steve Jobs Big Brother?
description: Steve Jobs is in the running for two trophies: comeback of the decade and villain of the year.

title: Speaking Up to Stay Silent
description: The Miranda warnings remind suspects of their right to remain silent but were never particularly clear on what happens when a suspect actually stays silent. Can the police question the suspect? If so, can they do they so for just a few minutes or as long as they want?

title: The Continuing Pain of 9/11
description: Too many years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the House is ready to consider proper health care and compensation for thousands of emergency responders and residents of New York City who developed grave illnesses from the clouds of dust and toxins at ground zero.

title: Suffolk Meltdown
description: The problem of homeless sex offenders is causing a political meltdown on Long Island. In Suffolk County, like places all over the country, sex offenders are barred from living near schools, parks, pools or any other place children gather. Some communities  usually poor  have ended up with more offenders than others. Tensions have risen.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 1, 2010

title: Israel and the Blockade
description: The supporters of the Gaza-bound aid flotilla had more than humanitarian intentions. The Gaza Freedom March made its motives clear in a statement before Mondays deadly confrontation: A violent response from Israel will breathe new life into the Palestine solidarity movement, drawing attention to the blockade.

title: Coach Follows His Father While Leading His Way
description: I am my father.

title: Spain Struggles to Agree on a Path to Recovery
description: MADRID  Caught between a populace resistant to more austerity measures and investors demanding budget cuts and more flexible labor markets, the Spanish government is finding it increasingly difficult to keep a grip on power.

title: Hero to Conservatives Often Follows Centrist Path
description: WASHINGTON  After a pair of votes the other day on some fine points of a major financial regulatory bill, Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts ducked out of the Capitol and back to his office, where he traded his suit and tie for softball gear to lead his staff in an afternoon match-up against the office of Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.

title: Japans Premier Will Quit as Approval Plummets
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama of Japan, who swept into power last year with bold promises to revamp the country, then faltered over broken campaign pledges to remove an American base from Okinawa, announced Wednesday that he would step down.

title: When Friends Fall Out
description: As a friend of both Turkey and Israel, it has been agonizing to watch the disastrous clash between Israeli naval commandos and a flotilla of humanitarian activists seeking to break the Israeli blockade of Gaza. Personally, I think both Israel and Turkey have gotten out of balance lately, and it is Americas job to help both get back to the center  urgently.

title: San Diego Police Investigate the Death of a Mexican Man Resisting Deportation
description: LOS ANGELES  The San Diego police are investigating the death of a Mexican man who was struck with a baton and shocked with a stun gun by federal officers as he resisted being deported. The Mexican government and a human rights group condemned the death, which comes after Mexico has condemned Arizonas tough new immigration enforcement law.

title: Altria to Pay $971 Million to Resolve a Tax Dispute
description: The Altria Group, the nations largest tobacco company, announced on Tuesday that it would pay $971 million to resolve a tax dispute concerning leasing transactions in the years 2000 through 2003.

title: Blog That Found a Market for Sports News Is Purchased
description: The Big Lead, an independent blog that Jason McIntyre began as a hobby, is fixated on sports media, news and gossip. Along the way, it has built a devoted, if not huge, social media following.

title: Memorial Is Shaping Up Perfectly
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  It has been said that when it comes to grooming his Muirfield Village Golf Club course for the Memorial Tournament, Jack Nicklauss attention to detail is such that he could spot a fly dropping in a pepper mill. So when he announced Tuesday that he did not find a single thing wrong during two tours of the course over the weekend, veteran Nicklaus watchers were stunned.

title: Calcavecchia Heads to Seniors Tour, Grinning All the Way
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Mark Calcavecchia, who defied the stereotype of the typical PGA Tour player for almost three decades, will play in his 24th and final Memorial Tournament this week. Calcavecchia, 50, will be grinning all the way to the Champions Tour.

title: Turkish Funds Helped Group Test Blockade
description: ISTANBUL  Since 2007, a small group of hard-core activists has repeatedly tried to sail cargo-laden ships into Gaza in an effort to thwart Israels blockade. But when the Free Gaza Movement teamed up with a much wealthier Turkish organization to assemble a flotilla, it became more than a nuisance, supercharged by the groups money, manpower and symbolic resonance into what Israel sees as a serious and growing threat.

title: To Take Baby Pictures of the Universe, Click Here
description: Here was a model for the next great time machine, just over John Grunsfelds shoulder in a field in Battery Park: a giant telescope that will be launched in 2014 and sent one million miles from Earth. By looking deep into space, it will collect light and images that have been traveling since nearly the beginning of the universe, and send them back here.

title: Pennsylvania: Tax Revenue Falls Short
description: Tax revenue for the state was $125 million short of projections for May, leaving the state with a $1.2 billion shortfall for the budget year ending June 30, the State Department of Revenue said. Through 11 months of the fiscal year, Pennsylvania has collected $24.6 billion, or 4.8 percent less than expected for that period in Gov. Edward G. Rendells $27.8 billion budget. Mr. Rendell has identified about $700 million of cuts and additional revenue to make up part of the gap.

title: Skype on the iPhone Goes 3G  Finally
description: Skype, a leading provider of inexpensive phone calls over the Internet, has finally completed a long-awaited move to make its service available over AT&Ts 3G network.

title: Videos Carry On the Fight Over Sea Raid
description: When Israeli commandos attacked the so-called Freedom Flotilla, both sides were well armed  with video cameras  and both sides have released a blizzard of video clips as evidence that the other side was the aggressor in the conflict on Monday, which left nine activists dead.

title: Big Setback for A.I.G. in Repaying Taxpayers
description: The American International Group scuttled the deal to sell its huge Asian life insurance arm to Prudential of Britain for about $35 billion, in a major setback to repaying the government for its 2008 rescue.

title: Study Finds Blacks Blocked From Southern Juries
description: In late April in a courthouse in Madison County, Ala., a prosecutor was asked to explain why he had struck 11 of 14 black potential jurors in a capital murder case.

title: Photo Replay: June 1
description: A view of the day in sports, with the French Open in Paris and World Cup preparations in South Africa.

title: 20 in Black Caucus Ask for Curbs on Ethics Office
description: WASHINGTON  Twenty members of the Congressional Black Caucus, including its chairwoman, are asking the House to severely restrict the powers of an independent ethics office that has spent much of its first full year investigating accusations of wrongdoing among black caucus members.

title: Afghan Assembly Expected to Back Peace-Talk Plan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai opens his showcase event of the year on Wednesday, a national peace convention that is expected to endorse his plan to negotiate with the Taliban and other opposition groups fighting his government.

title: Telefnica Bid Is Rebuffed
description: Portugal Telecom said on Tuesday that Telefnica had raised its bid for a venture that controls Brazils largest wireless operator to about 6.5 billion euros ($7.99 billion).

title: A Million Miles From Earth
description: A new space observatory described as the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope is on display at the World Science Festival at Battery Park.

title: Tribesman of Kenya
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays fishing expedition had me pulling in a red herring on my first cast, as I entered in Light Brigade at 20 Across. After discovering the three other theme phrases ended in HOOK, LINE and REEL, I was puzzled as to how brigade fit in. Finishing off the NE corner of the puzzle set me straight.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Seek to Bar Wall St. Financier
description: As it investigates a suspected kickback scheme in New Yorks pension system, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been pushing to bar Steven L. Rattner, a prominent financier and former adviser to the Obama administration on the auto industry, from working in the securities industry for up to three years, according to three people told of the discussions.

title: Afghan Police Earn Poor Grade for Marja Mission
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Three months after arriving in the most dangerous area of Afghanistans Helmand Province, a contingent of specialized Afghan police officers has logged a mediocre performance while being almost wholly dependent on American supervision and support, Westerners who work with the officers said.

title: For Rugby Fans, a First Trip to Soweto
description: Thousands of white rugby fans descended on Soweto, South Africa's largest black township, for a match between the Pretoria Blue Bulls and the Soweto Stormers. For many, it was their first visit.

title: Deep Underwater, Oil Threatens Reefs
description: Last September, marine scientists studying deep-sea biology in the northern Gulf of Mexico lowered a submersible robot off the side of a government research vessel and piloted it 1,300 feet to the ocean floor.

title: Cleanup Costs and Lawsuits Rattle BPs Investors
description: BP shareholders are fleeing the companys stock amid growing uncertainty about the ultimate bill for cleanup costs, lawsuits, fines and damage to the oil giants reputation.

title: Morgenthau Withdraws as Monitor on Fire Jobs
description: Bowing to concerns over his appointment but fiercely defending his record, Robert M. Morgenthau stepped down on Tuesday from his role overseeing the citys efforts to increase the number of minority firefighters in response to a long-running discrimination lawsuit.

title: Guatemala Struggles to Recover After Storm
description: GRANADA, Nicaragua  Victims of the first tropical storm of the regions hurricane season began returning to their storm-battered homes in Guatemala on Tuesday because of a lack of emergency food and beds to house them, relief officials said.

title: A Storyteller Loses the Story Line
description: WASHINGTON

title: Foxconn Raises Worker Pay 30%
description: The Foxconn Technology Group, a giant contract electronics manufacturer that experienced a series of worker suicides, said it would raise salaries by at least 30 percent, more than previously indicated.

title: Hanes Banks on Strong Tie With Star
description: Michael Jordan, the longtime star of commercials for Hanes, has a new sidekick to sell the apparel companys undershirts. The twosome appear side by side as airplane seatmates. Mr. Jordan was previously paired with the actor Charlie Sheen, who was dropped from company advertising. He was arrested in the winter in a domestic violence dispute.

title: Vazquezs Performance at Stadium Is a Good Start
description: Javier Vazquez did not remember the last time he started a game at Yankee Stadium, and with good reason. The cacophony that tends to accompany his starts there  boos, hisses, jeers  never polluted the air Tuesday night because Vazquez did not let it.

title: Liberia Aids U.S. in Drug Fight
description: Over the past three years, United States authorities say, South American drug traffickers have worked to build a base in the West African nation of Liberia, where vast quantities of cocaine could be sent by boat or plane and then reshipped to markets in West Africa and Europe.

title: Mets Want Perez to Move Aside for Niese
description: SAN DIEGO  Four Mets left-handers pitched Monday, but the only one who performed well was in the minor leagues.

title: Fear Grips a Family
description: A look at the world's largest family suffering from Alzheimer's disease, and the hope that they may help scientists find answers for everyone else.

title: Watching as the Baton Is Passed
description: Flights from So Paulo to New York City take 10 hours. But what if I was asked to do the same trip, but taking my sweet time  say, three months  inching up the hemisphere by bus, Amazonian riverboat and, who knows, maybe even the occasional llama? That pretty much describes my dream trip. And on someone elses dime? You cant be serious.

title: Blackhawks Are on a Roll in Stanley Cup Finals
description: The Flyers have all kinds of reasons to be nervous going into Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Wednesday in Philadelphia, and all kinds of reasons to be confident.

title: In Era of LeBron, Kobe Isnt Stepping Aside
description: LOS ANGELES  At the time, it appeared that Jerry West needed his purple and gold checked. West, the keen talent evaluator and executive who orchestrated the trade that brought a teenaged Kobe Bryant to the Los Angeles Lakers, said during last seasons playoffs that LeBron James had better skills as a player than Bryant did.

title: The Vanishing Mind
description: By studying an extended family in Colombia where Alzheimers is seen in the early 40s, scientists hope to find a treatment for Alzheimers patients worldwide.

title: Black Congressman Loses Alabama Primary
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Artur Davis of Alabama, who sidestepped the states black political leadership in hopes of building a diverse coalition of voters in his campaign for governor, was rejected on Tuesday by Democratic primary voters, with the state agriculture commissioner, Ron Sparks, seizing a decisive victory.

title: Patient Voices: Alzheimer's Disease
description: A slow decline in memory, an inability to complete simple tasks, the concern about long-term care - eight men and women speak about living with and caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease.

title: Lidstrom Puts Off Retiring
description: Nicklas Lidstrom, the Red Wings 40-year-old defenseman, signed a one-year, $6.2 million contract to return to Detroit instead of retiring. He has spent all of his 18 N.H.L. seasons with Detroit.

title: Kazuo Ohno, a Founder of Japanese Butoh, Dies at 103
description: Kazuo Ohno, a founder of Butoh, the influential Japanese dance-theater form whose traditional look of darkness and decay evoked for many the horrors of the wartime bombings of Japan, died on Tuesday in Yokohama, Japan. He was 103 and had continued to perform beyond his 100th year.

title: Federers Loss Raises New Possibilities
description: It was supposed to be a dream final between a brawny Spaniard with legendary wheels and a Swiss legend with a powerful forehand, especially after the Madrid Open final, the first match between Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer in exactly a year. Billed as the ultimate test for the greatest player ever, attempting to defeat the greatest clay courter ever, the dream tantalized until Robin Soderlings blistering strokes crushed it like a piata.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Thursday about Sex and the City 2 misstated the title of a song Liza Minnelli performs in the movie. It is Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It), not All the Single Ladies, which is a line from the song.

title: Bailout Haunts Any A.I.G. Deal
description: The wrangling over the American International Groups Asian insurance unit clarifies what the board of Prudential of Britain should have known all along: A.I.G. is beholden to the American taxpayer. While accepting a lower price might have been a rational business decision, it also would have further opened A.I.G. to criticism that it was shortchanging its owners  in this case, to help a foreign insurer.

title: A Familys Torment as Relatives Slip Away
description: The anguish of Alzheimers in a sprawling extended family in Colombia may be hardest on those still lucid enough to know they have it, or those who know they could.

title: A Perplexing Case Puts a Doctor on the Trail of Madness
description: In 1982, Dr. Francisco Lopera, a Medelln neurologist, was puzzled. A 47-year-old patient was losing his memory, and so had his father, grandfather and seven other relatives.

title: Alzheimers Stalks a Colombian Family
description: YARUMAL, Colombia  Tucked away on a steep street in this rough-hewn mountain town, an old woman found herself diapering her middle-age children.

title: A Worldwide Whirlwind on Woodwinds
description: Steve Gorn, primarily a Bansuri flute player, told his story to Ozier Muhammad of The Times:

title: Phys Ed: Does Massage Help After Exercise?
description: Michael Tschakovsky, an associate professor in the School of Kinesiology and Health Studies at Queens University in Kingston, Ontario, enjoys a post-exercise massage as much as anyone. But unlike those of us who happily drowse through the massage therapists assurance that the pummeling and kneading is speeding blood flow to our muscles and draining them of built-up lactic acid, Mr. Tschakovsky took notes. His academic specialty is the study of blood flow to muscles, particularly in diseases like diabetes, and he decided to put the therapists words to the test.

title: Happy Feet or Kicking It New School
description: Imelda Marcos is unlikely to attend any matches of the 2010 World Cup, but she (and her prodigious collection of quality footwear) will find some kindred spirits gallivanting across the green soccer fields of South Africa in the latest high-fashion (and high-priced) kicks (or boots, or cleats). Few could rival the collection of the former first lady of the Philippines, but when it comes to soccer cleats players can never have too many shoes. In fact, they probably need more feet!

title: Steve Jobs Muses on All Things Apple
description: For Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, the timing of his public appearance at the D8 conference could not have been better. Last week, Apple surpassed Microsoft to become the worlds most valuable technology company. A little more than a decade ago, Apple was struggling for its life, and many tech pundits were predicting its demise.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Video View of Guatemala Sinkhole
description: Just in case anyone had doubts about the reality of the extraordinary sinkhole that formed in a crowded district of Guatemala City  following a similar incident in the city in 2007  this Associated Press video report closes the case. [Theres more on Guatemala Citys shaky underpinnings in the Daily Beast.]

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Be Seeking to Bar Rattner
description: As it investigates a suspected kickback scheme in New Yorks pension system, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been pushing to bar Steven L. Rattner, a prominent financier and former adviser to the Obama administration on the auto industry, from working in the securities industry for up to three years, according to three people told of the discussions, The New York Timess Michael Barbaro reports.

title: Alabama Voters Reject Coalition Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Artur Davis of Alabama, who sidestepped the states black political leadership in hopes of building a diverse coalition of voters in his campaign for governor, was rejected Tuesday by Democratic primary voters, with the state agriculture commissioner, Ron Sparks, seizing a decisive victory.

description: diligence \di-l-jn(t)s\ noun

description: 1:49 a.m. | Updated Prudential said Wednesday that it was negotiating an end to its talks with A.I.G.

title: E-Books by McMurty
description: E-BOOKS BY MCMURTRY

title: Zach Braff to Star Off Broadway in Trust
description: After eight seasons starring on the comedy Scrubs, Zach Braff, below, will return to a New York stage this summer in the Off Broadway production of the dark comedy Trust, a new play by Paul Weitz, the co-director of the films About a Boy and American Pie. Joining Mr. Braff in the ensemble cast at Second Stage Theater will be the Tony Award-winning actress Sutton Foster (Thoroughly Modern Millie), Bobby Cannavale (a Tony nominee for Mauritius) and Ari Graynor (The Little Dog Laughed). Mr. Braffs last major theater role in New York was as Sebastian in the Shakespeare in the Park production of Twelfth Night, in 2002. In Trust, Mr. Braff will play a wealthy married man who looks to find something real in the most unlikely of places, according to a statement from Second Stage. Directed by Peter DuBois (Becky Shaw), the production is scheduled to begin preview performances on July 23, open on Aug. 12, and run through Sept. 5. PATRICK HEALY

title: Seinfeld, the Director
description: If he can see a metaphor for racial harmony in a black-and-white cookie, and explain the similarities between breaking up and knocking over a soda machine, surely Jerry Seinfeld, left, understands how to communicate with actors. But he has rarely tried his hand at directing until now. Mr. Seinfeld, the comedian and sitcom star, will direct his friend and fellow stand-up comic Colin Quinn in Long Story Short, a one-man show that Mr. Quinn will perform at the Bleecker Street Theater, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. The play is Mr. Quinns attempt to cover 2,000 years of history in about 75 minutes. The show, produced by Columbus 81 Productions, is scheduled to run from June 19 to Aug. 15. Lets hope Crazy Joe Davola isnt in the audience on opening night.

title: Saudis on MTV May Face Charges
description: Three Saudi youths who appeared in a recent broadcast of the MTV documentary series True Life could be brought to court by the Saudi Arabian religious police, which are suing them for the crime of openly declaring sin, Reuters reported. The True Life episode called Resist the Power, Saudi Arabia, which was first shown on May 24, chronicled three young Saudis who tried to resist their homelands strict morality: Aziz, who is trying to meet a girlfriend on a date; Fatima, who makes cloaks in colors other than black; and Ahmad, who wants women to be able to hold elected office. A Jeddah court official confirmed to Reuters that a lawsuit had been filed against the three, who were identified by only their first names in the episode. The court, which follows Islamic law, said it would take at least a week to decide whether to proceed with a trial. Penalties for convictions on morality offenses can include corporal punishment and imprisonment. MTV did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: More Theater for Boston
description: The Boston theater landscape is set to expand significantly in September with the inaugural season of ArtsEmerson, a programming arm of Emerson College, with 17 professional stage productions through May 2011 including The Laramie Project and its sequel, The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later; two works by the director Peter Brook; and Elevator Repair Services adaptation of The Sun Also Rises. The season will begin on Sept. 23 with a one-week run of Frulein Maria, a re-imagining of The Sound of Music by the choreographer Doug Elkins. Other highlights include Petrushka, created by the puppeteer Basil Twist, set to Stravinskys classic score; two Irish imports, The Cripple of Inishmaan by Martin McDonagh, above, from the Druid Theater and Mark ORowes Terminus from the Abbey Theater; and a production of The Merchant of Venice by the Theater for a New Audience, starring F. Murray Abraham as Shylock. Emerson College established ArtsEmerson last year to oversee productions at the 1,186-seat Cutler Majestic Theater and the new Paramount Center in Boston. PATRICK HEALY

title: License to Shill
description: Calvin Trillin and Edward Koren on how old establishments are licensing brands to become hep.

title: Repeats Beat Reality
description: Week two of The Bachelorette was down sharply in the ratings on Monday night, bringing a low-rated end to the Memorial Day weekend. That ABC reality show drew an average of 7.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, down from the 9.1 million who tuned in a week ago for the shows sixth-season premiere. ABC ranked second in the ratings on the night behind CBS, which led with a lineup of repeats. A rerun of CSI: Miami (8 million) on CBS outdrew the second-season debut of ABCs True Beauty (5.4 million), a reality show in which beauty contestants are unsuspectingly judged on their moral qualities. NBC was third over all with its coverage of Game 2 of the National Hockey Leagues Stanley Cup Finals, averaging approximately 6 million viewers in prime time. Fox ranked fourth with repeats of Lie to Me (3.3 million) and The Good Guys (3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

title: Is Peter Jacksons Hat in the Hobbit Ring?
description: As the producers of The Hobbit seek a new director for the film adaptation of that J. R. R. Tolkien fantasy novel, they may have a replacement in their midst who already knows a thing or two about translating Tolkiens texts to the big screen: Peter Jackson, left, an executive producer and screenwriter on The Hobbit. In an interview with The Dominion Post of New Zealand, Mr. Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the Lord of the Rings trilogy, said that if necessary he would step in as director of The Hobbit, pending his commitments to other films. Over the weekend Guillermo del Toro said he was withdrawing as director of The Hobbit, citing the continued delays of its start of production. (The film is planned to be released in two parts in 2012 and 2013 by MGM, which put itself up for sale last year and is still seeking buyers.) Among his coming films, Mr. Jackson is producing The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn as well as an untitled sequel. But Mr. Jackson told The Dominion Post that his directing The Hobbit was not an impossibility. If thats what I have to do to protect Warner Brothers investment, then obviously thats one angle which Ill explore, he said, adding, The other studios may not let me out of the contracts.

title: Mets Pelfrey Wins Fourth Start in a Row
description: SAN DIEGO  One night after a cartoonish game in which the basepaths were constantly choked with Padres runners and two dozen total runs were scored, the Mets got a refreshingly well-pitched game from the man who is becoming their stopper, their workhorse, and surely an impending All-Star.

title: News Quiz | June 2, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: South Africa: Union Threatens to Quit Governing Alliance
description: In the most significant sign yet of cracks in South Africas governing alliance, Cosatu, the trade union federation with two million members, threatened Tuesday to quit if the African National Congress, the party in power, takes disciplinary action against Cosatus general secretary, Zwelinzima Vavi. Cosatu said it had learned that an influential A.N.C. committee had decided that Mr. Vavi should be sanctioned for saying publicly that the party was perceived as soft on corruption that is said to involve government ministers. A.N.C. officials would not comment.

title: Taliban Attacks Shake Afghan Peace Gathering
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzais peace council, called a jirga, came under fire from inside and out on its first day Wednesday.

title: Burundi: Candidates Accuse Government of Voter Fraud
description: Five presidential candidates, including a former president and former rebel leader, said Tuesday that they would boycott the June presidential election over allegations of voter fraud. They accused the government of rigging local elections last month in which candidates belonging to the ruling party of President Pierre Nkurunziza won by wide margins. The number of votes counted, the five said, had exceeded the number of registered voters.

title: Canada: Man Taken Off Plane Is Questioned by U.S. Officials
description: A man who was removed from a Mexican airliner in Montreal after it was denied entry to the United States airspace because of his presence was turned over to American officials on Tuesday, the Canada Border Services Agency said. The man, Abdirahman Ali Gaal, was taken in handcuffs from a flight from Paris to Mexico City on Sunday. A Homeland Security spokesman, Matthew Chandler, said American officials were questioning Mr. Gaal, who was born in Somalia and is a legal, permanent resident of the United States, but he would not say why Mr. Gaal was being held.

title: Dominican Republic: Suit Over Haitian Descendants
description: Civil rights lawyers filed a case before the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights on Tuesday challenging the Dominican Republics treatment of Dominican-born people of Haitian ancestry. Although Haitians have worked in the Dominican Republic for generations and their offspring had long been entitled to Dominican citizenship, in recent years the Dominican government has decided that the offspring of illegal immigrants are not Dominicans. The suit was filed on behalf of a Dominican-born man who has been denied a certified copy of his birth certificate.

title: Bailout Will Haunt Any A.I.G. Deal
description: The wrangling over the American International Groups Asian insurance unit clarifies what the board of Prudential of Britain should have known all along: A.I.G. is beholden to the American taxpayer, Reuters Breakingviews writes.

title: Loans That Vanished in a Property Bust Reappear
description: The W Hotel in Union Square has had an eventful six months. The 270-room hotel changed hands in December after the private equity division of Dubai World defaulted on a $117 million mezzanine loan in the face of dwindling business. But the lender, LEM Mezzanine, could itself lose the hotel in coming months as a result of its filing for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, Jotham Sederstrom reports in The New York Times.

title: Telefnicas New Bid Is Rebuffed by Portugal Telecom
description: Portugal Telecom said on Tuesday that Telefnica had raised its bid for a venture that controls Brazils largest wireless operator to about 6.5 billion euros ($7.99 billion), Bloomberg News reported.

title: American Apprentices at the Bolshoi Ballet
description: WHAT is the Bolshoi Ballet?

title: Citigroup Unit Being Revamped for Sale
description: Citigroup is closing 330 branches of its consumer finance business as part of an overhaul aimed at finding a buyer for the unit, the bank said Tuesday according to The Associated Press.

title: Neo-Frugalists
description: Thrifty young consumers.

title: In Bid to Quell Anger Over Raid, Israel Frees Detainees
description: JERUSALEM  Israel worked Wednesday to defuse rising international anger by agreeing to a rapid release of all detainees  including those suspected of attacking its soldiers  taken after the deadly nighttime raid of six ships seeking to break its blockade of the Gaza Strip.

title: Pru in Talks to End Deal; Costs at $662 Million
description: Prudential Plc, the British insurer, said Wednesday that it was in negotiations to cancel its planned takeover of the Asian life insurance unit of American International Group.

title: Oil Spill Inquiry Chills Traders at the Close
description: Stocks in the United States were dragged lower by the energy sector after the government announced on Tuesday that it was opening investigations into the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The New York Timess Christine Hauser reported.

title: Germany Balks at Opel Aid for G.M.
description: General Motors received a setback Tuesday in its effort to secure 1.1 billion euros in German aid for its money-losing Opel unit, after a government panel declined to endorse the request, Bloomberg News reported.

title: N.Y.S.E. Gets Starbucks as Part of Revamp
description: If you had told me 20 years ago that one day we would be sitting down and able to drink coffee on the floor, I would not have believed it, Neil Catania, chief executive of MND Partners, 29-year veteran of the New York Stock Exchange told The Financial Times.

title: Bad News Fridays
description: No one likes revealing bad news. But lately, Wall Street has taken to sneaking out some of its less palatable developments right before the weekend. Such timing may keep to the letter of transparency rules, but hardly the spirit, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Sports News Blog Is Sold
description: The Big Lead, an independent blog that Jason McIntyre began as a hobby, is fixated on sports media, news and gossip. Along the way, it has built a devoted, if not huge, social media following.

title: Biglari Extends Offer for Advance Auto Shares
description: Sardar Biglari, the activist investor who took over Steak n Shake after a widely publicized struggle in 2007 and renamed it Biglari Holdings, said Tuesday his company had extended an offer to buy up to 1.6 percent of the shares of Advance Auto Parts from Tuesday until Friday.

title: Do You Have a Summer Job?
description: Some wealthy parents want their teenaged children to work so that they can appreciate the value of what they want and have, but the job market for teens is shrinking. Do you have a job? Why or why not? Do you think it is important for teenagers to have jobs?

title: Buffett to Testify at Crisis Panel Wednesday
description: Warren E. Buffett and the chief executive of credit rating agency Moodys are scheduled to face questions Wednesday from a bipartisan panel probing the roots the financial crisis.

title: Massachusetts Pension Fund Loses Big in May
description: What the stock market giveth the Massachusetts pension fund, it also taketh away.

title: Paris Exhibition Questions Where Here Is
description: Ones destination is never a place but rather a new way of looking at things, the writer Henry Miller once said. Perspectives, a new exhibition opening June 4 at the Louis Vuitton Cultural Center, aspires to understand space, the world and the essence of travel through works by two French artists, Odile Decq and Camille Henrot.

title: As Governments Borrow, Many People Save
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Caterpillar Buys Locomotive Maker
description: Heavy equipment maker Caterpillar said its railroad service unit will spend $820 million to acquire locomotive maker Electro-Motive Diesel, The Associated Press reported.

title: Cadbury Deal Prompts Review of Takeover Rules
description: Reverberations from Krafts controversial $19 billion takeover of Cadbury continued in Britain this week as the countrys Takeover Panel said it planned to begin a review of its takeover rules, The Telegraph reported.

title: Investors May Shy Away From I.P.O.s This Week
description: Only two companies appear daring enough to try initial public offerings this week, as investors shy away from risky investments and buzz-worthy companies wait for the volatile market cloud to pass, The Associated Press writes.

title: Porter Aviation Grounds I.P.O.
description: Porter Airlines, a popular Canadian-based regional carrier that flies to New York City, Boston and Chicago, delayed its initial public offering Tuesday because of unfavorable market conditions caused by volatility in the equity markets, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Spare-Time Revolution
description: Todays idea: Our use of spare time is now less about passive viewing and more about engaging  from Flickr and Facebook to online political action  an author says. And new insights into human motivation help explain this historic shift, says another.

title: Cancer and Me
description: Regular readers of this blog and my Friday and Saturday columns no doubt have noticed that my productivity has plunged. I want to explain.

title: You Hired a Chef and Youve Never Tasted His Food?
description: I have worked with actors, athletes, composers, dancers, musicians and models. I am not saying that chefs are the highest strung or tightest wound group I have come across, but I would not hesitate to say they play second fiddle to no one. Holy smoke!

title: Ametek Acquires Medical Device Parts Maker
description: Ametek, which makes electric motors, battery chargers and products for aerospace, defense and other industries, said Tuesday it had acquired the privately held Technical Services for Electronics for an undisclosed amount, The Associated Press reported.

title: Prudential Faces Fallout From Failed Deal
description: After the collapse of the deal to sell the American International Groups huge Asian life insurance arm to the British insurer Prudential, the firm appears to be headed for some significant fallout.

title: Quarterfinal French Open Showdown: Jankovic vs. Shvedova
description: PARIS  The light was fading on an English summer afternoon last year at Wimbledon as the two unknowns battled into a third set. About 100 friends, family members and the curious gathered at the sides of the distant court.

title: China to Subsidize Electric Cars and Hybrids

title: How a Soccer Star Is Made
description: The youth academy of the famed dutch soccer club Ajax is grandiosely called De Toekomst  The Future. Set down beside a highway in an unprepossessing district of Amsterdam, it consists of eight well-kept playing fields and a two-story building that houses locker rooms, classrooms, workout facilities and offices for coaches and sports scientists. In an airy cafe and bar, players are served meals and visitors can have a glass of beer or a cappuccino while looking out over the training grounds. Everything about the academy, from the amenities to the pedigree of the coaches  several of them former players for the powerful Dutch national team  signifies quality. Ajax once fielded one of the top professional teams in Europe. With the increasing globalization of the sport, which has driven the best players to richer leagues in England, Germany, Italy and Spain, the club has become a different kind of enterprise  a talent factory. It manufactures players and then sells them, often for immense fees, on the world market. All modern ideas on how to develop youngsters begin with Ajax, Huw Jennings, an architect of the English youth-development system, told me. They are the founding fathers.

No, to the contrary. Thats exactly what would make us both throw up. Trust is not the same as faith. A friend is someone you trust. Putting faith in anyone is a mistake.
