title: Artifacts | Marina the Magnificent
description: It was no surprise that the audience present on Monday for the end of Marina Abramovics epic, 716-hour sit at the Museum of Modern Art gave her a tremendous ovation. The remarkable thing was the extent, and especially the sound, of it. The cheers lasted a good 15 minutes, filling the museums towering atrium with the sort of unbridled excitement that often greets (male) sports stars after a big win. Then again, when a woman of 63 has been sitting in the same chair almost daily for three long months, locking eyes with at least 1,545 individuals without moving or speaking, before 700,000 gawkers who came to watch, she deserves more than a pat on the back. A mental health exam might be in order, for instance. Or a long hot bath. But also a medal for heroism.

description: Richard Migliore, the jockey known affectionately in New York simply as The Mig, will never ride a racehorse again. It was not his choice to retire Wednesday morning: the doctor told him that he had sustained one broken neck too many and that he would be risking his life if he got on another horse.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: Randy Romeros Remarkable Ride
description: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

title: Panasonic FX75 Goes Wide and Bright
description: The new Panasonic Lumix DMC-FX75 is fronted by a very wide and bright lens  two features that should make it a versatile snap-shooter. This touch-screen camera is also eminently portable, housed in a chassis that measures a superslim 0.9 inch.

title: 2010: Honey-and-Ricotta Mousse With Strawberry-Rhubarb Broth
description: By Melissa Perello, chef and owner of Frances in San FranciscoFor the strawberry-rhubarb broth:

title: 1989: Rhubarb-Strawberry Mousse
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Olwen Woodier; it was adapted from Mallards Restaurant at Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y. 11/4 pounds rhubarb, finely diced

title: Recipe Redux: Rhubarb-Strawberry Mousse, 1989
description: Monolithic vintage desserts have their charms. A rhubarb-strawberry mousse that ran in The Times in 1989 is buoyant and absolute, with cream easing the tart sting of the fruits. A mousse can be any food that has a light and foamy texture. This sweet one, adapted from Mallards Restaurant at Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y., is created by folding whipped cream into a rhubarb-and-strawberry pure firmed up with gelatin. If you didnt whip the cream, youd end up with panna cotta. As is, or combined with whipped egg whites, you enter the land of chiffons and charlottes. Mousse is the neutral middleman: not very flashy, but dependably, well, moussey.

title: Florida G.O.P. Figure Indicted
description: Updated: MIAMI  Jim Greer, the big spender hand-picked by Gov. Charlie Crist to run the Republican Party of Florida, was charged on Wednesday morning with six felony counts tied to what the authorities described as a secret scheme to funnel political donations to a shell company Mr. Greer set up for personal enrichment.

title: Jane Lynch and Lara Embry
description: Jane Lynch and Lara Embry were married Monday at the Blue Heron Restaurant in Sunderland, Mass. Jeannie Elias, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: By the Numbers: A-Rods Grand Slams
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: A Trick to Earn More Interest
description: In response to my colleague Tara Siegel Bernards recent post on the best places to store down payment money for a home, a reader commented with a tip that we thought was worth sharing.

title: Greater New Yorkers | Tala Madani
description: The Moment homes in on five artists from Greater New York, an exhibition that runs through Oct. 18 at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

title: Ray Stevens Comes Streaking Back With Immigration Song
description: If theres an upside to the polarized debate over illegal immigration in the United States, its that it has put Ray Stevens back in the limelight. When we last heard from Mr. Stevens, the novelty country-music star who gave us Ahab the Arab and The Streak, it was probably via a Dr. Demento album we were loaned by a friend at summer camp or a stray reference to him on The Simpsons. (Admittedly, we missed his 2002 hit, Osama Yo Mama.)

title: TerraCycle
description: Tom Szaky, the founder and C.E.O. of TerraCycle, explains how he saved his company despite mounting manufacturing costs.

title: The Kno, a Tablet for the College Market
description: The success of the Kindle and iPad has sparked a slew of tablet-wannabes. Some are imitators, while others are trying to bring new ideas to the tablet and e-reader concepts.

title: Town House in Crane Collapse Is for Sale
description: THE collapse of a 22-story construction crane in March 2008 on the East Side of Manhattan killed seven people, crushed a building and rattled the city. It was the first of two fatal crane accidents that year.

title: Ex-Officer Is Convicted of Sexual Abuse
description: A former police officer was convicted on Wednesday of sexually abusing two women in Manhattan who had been lured by promises of applications for jobs and programs for their children.

title: Katrina and Climate: Case Dismissed?
description: Back in 2005, a group of landowners on the gulf coast filed a federal lawsuit against energy and chemical companies, arguing that they were directly responsible for greenhouse gas emissions that exacerbated the effects of Hurricane Katrina. It named more than 30 companies, including oil giants like Chevron, BP and Exxon Mobil.

title: How I Saved My Company: TerraCycle
description: TerraCycle has gotten a lot of media attention for its unusual business model: Basically, it takes waste and turns it into a wide range of products, from fertilizer to computer bags to kites. Co-founded by Tom Szaky, who dropped out of Princeton University to start the company, TerraCycle, which is based in Trenton, N.J., has been the subject of an Inc. magazine  cover story, a National Geographic reality show, and a recent profile in the Wall Street Journal.

title: No Hawk-Eye to Help Out Djokovic
description: PARIS  The French Open remains the only Grand Slam that has not implemented the multiple-camera tracking system called Hawk-Eye, which uses a sort of animated replay system to be the final arbiter of line calls at Wimbledon and the Australian and United States Opens.

title: The Morning Line: Singing a New Belmont Tune
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Mercury: A Brand Without a Cause
The Crew Behind a One-Woman Show
description: YOU were the child of glamorous but emotionally absent narcissists; your own credo is Never take advantage of anyone. You were drunk or high for much of the 1980s; you got sober when you realized that no matter what quantities of drugs and alcohol you consumed they no longer had an effect. You were an art-critical flop who spent decades in the professional wilderness; you were then so suddenly taken up by the establishment that collectors now stand in line for your work. Your pictures sell for $400,000; you insist that you will never give up teaching, so what if it pays two cents?

title: World Cup Chic | Kehinde Wileys Fancy Footwork
description: With the World Cup games in South Africa just days away, soccer balls arent the only things spinning out of control. The New York City artist Kehinde Wileys Africa Lifestyle sneakers and sports apparel for Puma are creating their own brand of hysteria. Puma has been supplying African soccer teams with uniforms since 1997, when it signed on with Cameroon. Wileys own partnership with the brand began two years ago with a commission to capture the spirit of the game through life-size paintings of Africana footballers like Samuel Etoo of Cameroon, John Mensah of Ghana and Emmanuel Ebou of Ivory Coast. The paintings have been touring the globe with pit stops in Paris, London, New York, Beijing, Tokyo, Milan and Johannesburg, where they will land just in time for next weeks kickoff.

title: Phantom Now Available to Students
description: 6:36 p.m. | Updated  All of those drama clubs with a spare chandelier, organ and motorized boat  not to mention enough playing space for a subterranean lair  are now in luck: The Phantom of the Opera is available, for the first time, for productions at high schools and colleges in the United States and Canada, the licensing executives for the musical are to announce on Thursday.

title: Laurent Manrique Is Taking Over Country in the Carlton Hotel
description: Laurent Manrique, who spent many years working in New York, including at Peacock Alley in the Waldorf-Astoria, then relocated to San Francisco, where he worked at Campton Place and then Aqua, will open a restaurant and lounge in what is now Country in the Carlton Hotel in Murray Hill.

title: Trunk Show
description: As extra-long board shorts recede in popularity, men are coming to appreciate the virtues of showing some leg.

title: Palin Backs Murkowski Rival in Alaska
description: Sarah Palin, who has not been shy of late about endorsing candidates around the country, made her presence felt back home in Alaska on Wednesday, backing a Republican primary opponent of Senator Lisa Murkowski.

title: A Lifeguard for Before You Get to the Beach
description: ATTENTION, reality-television producers: If youre desperately looking for a quick summer replacement show, here you go. Get Ronen Jehezkel to meet you at Parke & Ronen, the fashionable swimwear store that he and his partner, Parke Lutter, own on Ninth Avenue in Chelsea. Mike him up, plant the camera and wait.

title: 20 Young Writers Earn the Envy of Many Others
description: There are 10 women and 10 men, satirists and modernists, from Miami and Ethiopia and Peru and Chicago. And none of them were born before 1970.

title: Answers From a Train Operator
description: Following is the first set of responses from Dennis H. Boyd, who operates trains on the No. 4 Lexington Avenue subway line.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kabul and Elsewhere
description: In Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzais peace council, called a jirga, came under fire on its first day Wednesday. The Taliban responded before the president even finished speaking, as a rocket exploded within a few hundred yards of the jirga tent. Some are trying to fire rockets, he said, shrugging off the attack. Everyone is used to it; even my 3-year-old son is used to it.

title: Transit Maps in the Palm of Your Hand (No Refolding Required)
description: In some cities, pulling out a transit map is an open invite to solicitations from panhandlers, swindlers and car services. But you can avoid such nuisances if you own a smartphone.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Robot Surgery
description: In this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out about some fledgling alternatives to Facebook from Jenna Wortham, a Times technology reporter who covers digital culture and the Web. These social networking upstarts have emerged at a time of widespread concern over the privacy policies of Facebook, and Ms. Wortham says their creators see a potential opportunity, offering different ways of sharing information.

title: Buffett Warns of Possible Call for Muni Bailouts
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett warned Wednesday afternoon that many state and local governments would soon face a terrible problem in refinancing their debt loads, and that some could eventually need to be bailed out by the federal government.

title: Advising Graduates
description: You never know what moment a child will remember as transformative. When I think back on my memories of well-timed advice and wise counsel from my parents, most were happenstance and off the cuff.

title: The Beautiful Games Serious Blemish
description: While much of the (male) world rejoices with anticipation for the impending World Cup to commence in South Africa on June 11, most Irish (male and female) continue to be livid and feel slighted for being excluded from this event by dint of an egregious refereeing error in Irelands qualifying match against France. The referee awarded the French an all-decisive goal that had involved an obvious hand-play by the French superstar Thierry Henry thus catapulting the French into the tournament on the basis of a clear rule infraction.

title: Finding America, Searching for Identity
description: The case has been amply stated that Superman is the quintessential immigrant story. Born on an alien planet, he grows stronger on Earth but maintains a secret identity tied to a homeland that continues to exert a powerful hold on him even as his every contact with those origins does him harm.

title: In May, Lower Ratings for Larry King
description: In May Larry King Live scored its lowest monthly viewer total in nearly 20 years.

title: Products for Sensitive Skin
description: Some women with skin prone to allergic reactions seek out preservative-free skin care. Odacit, which makes a moisturizer, a night serum and a cleanser in the $40 to $120 range, does not add preservatives; its products are made to order, marked with a use-by date and mailed to the customer, so they never sit on store shelves.

title: New Korean Skin-Care Import
description: By the end of June, the Sulwhasoo skin-care line will open an island in Bergdorf Goodman, its first outpost in the United States. The 12 products sold there will include an $80 primer and a $220 ginseng cream.

title: Top Players Have Up-and-Down Day at French Open
description: PARIS  The day after the usually unflappable No. 1 mens player was overpowered by a rising, hard-hitting player at the French Open, the No. 1 womens player suffered the same end.

title: As Certain as Taxes: New Version of Office
description: Certain landmark events come around every few years, giving some reassuring structure to our lives. You know: Presidential elections. Summer Olympics. Remakes of A Christmas Carol.

title: Turning Heads, and Topping Them, Too
description: THE German hat designer Rike Feurstein has the sort of discovery story that most fledgling designers can only dream about. One winter day in 2007, almost a year after opening a little atelier in Berlin, Ms. Feurstein was in Manhattan and spontaneously popped into Barneys New York. She was wearing her classic Faye hat, a jaunty outsize caboose-style cap crocheted from almost rope-size wool yarn. The hat caught the eye of a floor manager, who enthusiastically flipped through the look book Ms. Feurstein had with her; within 48 hours an order was placed.

title: Push for Europewide Oversight of Credit Raters
description: The European Commission on Wednesday urged centralized oversight of credit rating agencies and stricter rules on bank directors to help prevent financial crises, James Kanter of The New York Times reports from Brussels.

title: Table for 5, Rookies Need Not Apply
description: THEY have had probably 1,000 lunches over the last 25 years, starting in a Mexican fast-food restaurant and moving upscale around New York, and now they lunch at the best table at Michaels, the popular Midtown media mecca.

title: Thrifty Wi-Fi That Travels With You
description: Wi-Fi is everywhere.

title: The Woman Behind Jean-Georgess Juices
description: ABC Kitchen With Jean-Georges has a very healthy scene  especially in the front bar  not to mention good food with an emphasis on local and organic ingredients. But the healthiest aspect of Jean-Georges Vongerichtens latest venture is just out the back door. At the cozy Elixir Bar, Brandi Kowalski, one of the restaurants managers, is taking juicing to the next (sustainable) level.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Al and Tipper Gore call it quits. The Weed Eater he gave her for her birthday should have been a tip-off that their love was too hot not to cool down.

title: Throwing Stones at Builders Crass Houses
description: Theres a long tradition in theater of skewering journalists, lawyers and politicians, but architects, by comparison, have gotten off easy. In this age of the starchitect, that is bound to change, as demonstrated by two new dramas that present  and then undercut  the persona of the uncompromising visionary who dreams up buildings.

title: The New Yorkers 20 Under 40
description: For the first time in more than a decade, The New Yorker will publish a 20 Under 40 list of fiction writers in its next issue, coming out Monday. Such lists, of course, tend to be controversial, or at least vulnerable to second-guessing and criticism. The editors in the fiction department at The New Yorker are certainly on guard for it.

title: Make Bikes in the U.S., or Go Abroad to Cut Costs?
description: A SMALL bicycle company for big riders, Super Sized Cycles, manufactures and adapts bicycles for overweight riders who are too big for conventional bikes. The five-year-old business, which is based in Vermont, had sales last year of $104,000.

title: Carly Fiorina Means Business
description: On a cloudless spring afternoon, Carly Fiorina strode onto an outdoor stage in Pleasanton, Calif., with the happy, hungry expression of someone not just confident of an enthusiastic reception but counting on one. She surveyed a riot of signs artful and artless  Give us liberty, not debt, Pelosis gavel is the new health care colonoscopy  and beamed. For the stemwinder on bloated government that she was about to deliver, there was probably no better audience than these thousands of angry rebels, spread across acres of fairgrounds near San Jose for a special Tea Party rally. And there was definitely no better date than this one: April 15. Tax day.

title: This Year, Mens Semifinals Should Be Televised Live
description: Both French Open mens semifinal matches should be carried live on Friday, not on tape delay as they were last year, dismaying fans watching on NBC and the Tennis Channel.

title: Pacific Crossing: Brahms by Way of Seoul
description: Western classical music has long flourished in Korea: where Western missionaries go, music tends to follow. In recent decades South Korean musicians like the Chung siblings  the violinist Kyung-Wha Chung, the cellist Myung-Wha Chung and the pianist and conductor Myung-Whun Chung  and more recently Hahn-Bin, a violinist, have led prominent international careers. And South Korea is a flourishing market for Western visitors, as the New York Philharmonic discovered in its Seoul concerts in 2008 and last year.

title: Would You Build Bikes in the U.S. or the Far East?
description: We have just published a case study of Super Sized Cycles, a company based in Vermont that manufactures and adapts bicycles for overweight riders who are too big for conventional bikes.

title: Egalitarian Virtues Trump Fireworks
description: Steve Cardenas is an earthbound jazz guitarist, more at home with the stir of a rhythm section than the whoosh of solo heroics. This makes him a pervasive but subtle presence on the scene: a consummate accompanist, not particularly known as a bandleader. But the balance may be shifting a bit. Last week he released a strong album, West of Middle (Sunnyside), his first for an American label. It features a clutch of unostentatious, intelligent originals, most of which he played at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night.

title: Around the Grill | Share Your Barbecue
description: With Memorial Day comes the unofficial beginning of barbecue season, a time to gather around the grill for food and fun. Around the Grill, a summer series from The New York Times, will feature articles, video and reader-submitted material. Many of you have already begun submitting barbecue photos, recipes and stories.

title: Italy Focuses on a Princeton Curator in an Antiquities Investigation
description: It has been five years since a former curator of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles went on trial in Rome for conspiring to traffic in stolen antiquities. The case has become a cornerstone of Italys aggressive campaign to recover ancient treasures from around the United States and has led major American museums to make their peace with the Italian government. As the museums have relinquished dozens of artworks that Italy claims were looted, receiving loans of other objects in exchange, officials on both sides have talked about a new era of collaboration.

title: Award to Aid Playwright and the Play
description: A new annual playwriting award, providing $50,000 to an emerging writer and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipients play, has been established by the foundation of Arthur Laurents, the Tony Award-winning Broadway director, playwright and librettist, and Tom Hatcher, his partner, according to organizers of the award.

title: Colorado Prosecutor Says a Deal Is Reached in Charlie Sheen Case
description: A Colorado prosecutor said on Tuesday night that an agreement had been reached with Charlie Sheen, below right, the Two and a Half Men star, in a case involving a domestic dispute between him and his wife, The Associated Press reported. Arnold Mordkin, the chief deputy district attorney of Pitkin County, confirmed the agreement to The A.P. but declined to provide details. Mr. Sheen was arrested in Aspen on Christmas Day after his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, called 911 after an argument. Mr. Sheen was charged with second-degree assault, menacing and criminal mischief, and he originally pleaded not guilty to those charges in March. Yale Galanter, a lawyer for Ms. Sheen, told The A.P. that a plea agreement had been reached, adding that the terms could not be revealed because a deal is not a deal until the judge approves it. Mr. Sheens trial was scheduled for July 21, but he is now scheduled to be in court on Monday for a hearing. Last month he announced that he had reached an agreement to return to Two and a Half Men for two more seasons.

title: Glee Soundtrack Stays On Top
description: Oldies topped the Billboard album chart this week, barely, with a sluggish showdown between Glee and the reunited Stone Temple Pilots. Glee: The Music, Volume 3  Showstoppers (Columbia), the fourth soundtrack to the popular Fox show  a fifth will be released on Tuesday  is No. 1 for a second week, with sales of 63,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Stone Temple Pilots (Atlantic), the bands first new release in nine years, was close behind, with slightly fewer than 62,000. Album sales were relatively healthy in the first few months of 2010, with most No. 1s selling more than 100,000 copies, but lately theyve been dismal. Also on this weeks chart, Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) is No. 3, with 50,000; Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 46,000; and Ushers Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive) is No. 5, with 35,000.

title: Sit. Stay. Appreciate: Music For Dogs
description: Woof woof, woof woof woof! Arf, arf! Bark! If the preceding composition made no sense to you, then youre probably not in the target audience for a new work by Laurie Anderson, above with her husband, Lou Reed, that is written for dogs. On Sunday the Sydney Opera House will host the debut of Ms. Andersons 20-minute piece composed of high-frequency noises that dogs can hear but that are inaudible to human ears, Agence France-Presse reported. (For the owners of the recitals intended listeners, there will also be spoken word and string music elements.) The recital, called Music for Dogs, is being presented as part of Vivid Live arts festival in Sydney, whose curators are Ms. Anderson and Mr. Reed. Announcing the dog-friendly composition at a news conference, Ms. Anderson explained that at a previous event, she thought: Wouldnt it be great, if you were playing a concert, and you look out and you see all dogs? And so I said, If I ever get the chance to do something like that I would do it. (A concert listing advises that all dogs in attendance must be on leashes, and all humans must be attached to those leashes.)

title: Christies Alters Gallery Management
description: In 2007 Christies announced with great fanfare that it had bought Haunch of Venison, a gallery with locations in New York, Berlin and London. At the time many in the art world questioned the potential conflicts that an auction house could have in owning a private gallery, especially when it comes to issues like sharing clients or buying and selling at auction. Now the Haunch of Venison founders, Harry Blain and Graham Southern, are leaving the gallery on Aug. 31. While nobody wants to talk publicly about what caused the split, some contemporary-art dealers say Mr. Blain and Mr. Southern tried to buy back the gallery from Christies but were unsuccessful. We decided we wanted to change direction, Edward Dolman, Christies chief executive, said in a telephone interview. We want to invest in the business and grow it, finding new spaces and building a bigger team. Harry and Graham felt more comfortable with a smaller operation. Mr. Dolman added that Christies would continue to own the gallery and that it would be run with the co-directors Emilio Steinberger and Barrett White in New York and Matthew Carey-Williams in London. Mr. Blain said he and Mr. Southern planned to continue working together.

title: Topping Fish With a Classic Onion Sauce
description: Although they have been available at farmers markets for a month or more, juicy spring onions are still a nice treat. So is the locally fished wild bass in our neighborhood Greenmarket. Hey  that sounds like the start of dinner, doesnt it?

title: Media Companies Support Filmmaker in Chevron Case
description: A group of 13 media companies has filed a friend-of-the-court brief on behalf of Joe Berlinger, below left, the documentary filmmaker who is appealing a federal district judges ruling that the oil company Chevron may subpoena the outtakes from his film Crude. The brief, filed on Tuesday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, by a group including NBC Universal, the Directors Guild of America, HBO and The New York Times Company, says the work of these companies will be seriously jeopardized by the judges decision and its effect on journalists privilege. Last month Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that Mr. Berlinger would have to turn over more than 600 hours of footage from Crude, his documentary about the Ecuadorians who sued Texaco (now owned by Chevron), accusing it of contaminating their water. Chevron said Mr. Berlingers footage could be helpful to the company as it seeks to have the suit dismissed and pursues an international treaty arbitration related to the litigation. The appellate court has ordered a hearing on Tuesday to consider the subpoena and stayed the subpoena until that hearing.

title: Life Along the Gowanus
description: Although so polluted it was placed on the federal Superfund list, the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is popular with many who live nearby.

title: Celebration at the Edge of Decay
description: IN the claustrophobic confines of New York City, nothing marks the beginning of summer like an open-air dance party. And in South Brooklyn on the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, summer commenced at an event space known as the Bklyn Yard.

title: Still Dancing, Her Way, From the Soul
description: Alicia Alonso, the longtime director of the National Ballet of Cuba, no longer dances with her feet, which, on Monday afternoon at a hotel near Lincoln Center, were daintily crossed at the ankle in a pair of ladylike slingbacks. She is also virtually blind. But when she talks about ballet, her hands, coppery and weathered, flutter near her face as slender fingers, flashing rings and pale pink nails spin and leap through delicate choreographic feats.

title: Packing the Computer for a Move
description: Q. Whats the best way to pack up my computer for a cross-country move?

title: Private Collection Becomes Very Public
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Superfun Site
description: The Bklyn Yard is open Fridays to Sundays all summer. On Fridays the space hosts a beer garden that opens at 6 p.m. (no cover). Saturdays are generally centered on food, such as a lobster bake cooked up by the Red Hook Lobster Pound (cover varies). And the Sunday Best dance party is $8 advance, $12 at the door. The Yard is at 388-400 Carroll Street, on the canal. Visit bklynyard.com for more details.

title: Which Minor to Ruff? Declarer Puzzles It Out
description: The oldest bridge event still being contested is the Goldman Pairs. It was first played in New York City in 1929, when it was won by Oswald Jacoby and George Reith. (Remember, it was only in 1925 that Harold Vanderbilt had invented contract bridge.)

title: Theater Talkback: Summer Reading List
description: Summer is not, for most people, peak theater-going season. Yes, there are charming festivals in bucolic settings (that includes Al Pacino doing Shakespeare in Central Park this year). But for most folks, the period between Memorial Day and Labor Day is a time to get out of Dodge, to exchange urban industry for pursuits that involve dressing down and chilling out, not dressing up and going out.

title: Jersey Shore, Without the Sun
description: PAULA BEGOUN, a beauty writer who calls herself the Cosmetics Cop, thought she had heard every silly claim about sunless tanners: that new flower extracts can extend the life of a tan by up to two weeks (they cant); that spray tans no longer smell funky or turn you a funny orange (they do, mostly); that you no longer need to worry about the color rubbing off on your sheets (you do).

title: Brazils Best Player: A Goalkeeper?
description: Musa Okwonga is a writer of Ugandan descent. In 2008, his first book on soccer, A Cultured Left Foot, was nominated for the William Hill Sports Book of the Year Award, and was named the best sports book of 2008 by Britains Independent newspaper.

title: Eyebrow Shaping, Pain Included
description: Usually taking tweezers into your own hands is the only way to get a free eyebrow shaping in Manhattan. Not on June 17, when the Ramy brow bars in three Duane Reade stores will offer free shaping from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.

title: Classic Ads: Mercury
description: With Fords announcement on Wednesday that it would discontinue its Mercury brand, a Merc-sponsored cruise down memory lane seemed in order.

title: Looking for Missing Culprit in Credit Ratings Mess
description: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission on Wednesday seemed to get its fill of the problems and conflicts at the credit rating agencies, hearing from three panels, including one featuring the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

title: Two Different Pictures of Hospitals
description: The Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care mines Medicare data to identify variations in hospital spending around the country. Dartmouth researchers sometimes argue that the highest-spending regions  those in the darkest color  tend to have the worst health care.

title: Jamaican Forces Accused of Killing Unarmed Men
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  As the battle for Tivoli Gardens raged, soldiers knocked on a door at Building 27. Inside, 16 or 17 people were huddled for safety, including a 22-year-old barber named Errol Spence. His family said a soldier searched him and did not find any evidence that he was one of the gunmen shooting at security forces. Still, one police officer asked Mr. Spences sister a question that at first confused her.

title: When Poets Rocked Russias Stadiums
description: Since the collapse of the Soviet empire in 1991, Russian poetry has begun to resemble American poetry in ways that are both fascinating and sad. Whats fascinating is how talented, and how different from one another, Russias young poets are. Whats sad is how little they are read, and how little they matter. Whatever reach contemporary poetry had in Russian society has vanished like wood smoke.

title: WeRewards Pays You to Check In
description: It sounds like one of those improbable come-ons that is an invitation to a scam: Get paid to Tweet.

title: High Talent at Low Prices
description: THE jewelry designer Monique Pan, one of three designers to win the 2009 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund prizes for up-and-coming talent (the others were Patrik Ervell and Sophie Thallet), makes pieces that often cost upward of $5,000.

title: Critics Question Study Cited in Health Debate
description: In selling the health care overhaul to Congress, the Obama administration cited a once obscure research group at Dartmouth College to claim that it could not only cut billions in wasteful health care spending but make people healthier by doing so.

title: Made for Prowling
description: IS there such a thing as a tasteful animal print? This ladylike simple sheath dress from Ann Taylor easily goes from office to cocktail party to a nightclub ($158).

title: Fitting More Into That Bag
description: LONGCHAMPS gut renovation of what the store calls La Maison Madison boutique plays homage to Le Pliage, its ubiquitous nylon and leather bag; the company estimates it has sold more than 16 million since its introduction in 1993. An accordionlike wall, an architectural reference to the bags folding design, displays each model and color, creating a rainbow from lilac to citrine ($90 to $270). The new Kate Moss for Longchamp line is available, including the Glastonbury, with a shoulder strap that can go across the chest, messenger style ($780). Longchamp Madison Avenue, 713 Madison Avenue (63rd Street); (212) 223-1500, longchamp.com.

title: The Art and Craft of Terrariums
description: Long a fixture of classrooms, a new breed of modern, elegant and highly detailed terrariums is gaining favor with young design enthusiasts.

title: Pop Up, Jump Under
description: VICTOR HSU, above, who calls himself the chief propagandist for the sneaker brand Jump, is getting the word out with a pop-up store in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn; it is called Jumbo, an acronym for Jump Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. Jumbo will have its opening party Thursday from 6:30 to 10 p.m.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,392 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,074 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: When Boomers Get Dementia
description: Updated, June 3, 1:05 p.m. | Marc E. Agronin, a geriatric psychiatrist, joins the discussion, pointing out the significant challenges to treating dementia patients.

title: The H-SLM Chair by Javier Cristiani
description: In designing the H-SLM chair, Javier Cristiani, the founder of Hemisferios, an architecture firm in El Salvador, set himself a challenge: I wanted to create a three-dimensional shape out of a flat material, he said, without any additional structure. To accomplish his goal, he took a single piece of metal, had a welder bend it by hand and then bolted it to a stainless-steel base so that it would read as two very different elements. H-SLM comes in two versions: a metal chair built by hand ($250), which has slight variations, and a fiberglass model ($280), above, that is lighter and more uniform because it is made in a mold. Mr. Cristiani, who is colorblind, made the prototype in a vibrant orange, a color he can see well; the chair also comes in yellow, green, black and white (the fiberglass version can be ordered in a combination of two colors as well). Information: (011-503) 2237-9565 or hemisferios.com.sv.

title: A Brief Box Office Move
description: Lincoln Centers Calder sculpture, Le Guichet (The Box Office), will take up temporary residence at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a move to be announced on Thursday. Lincoln Center presented the sculpture as a temporary gift to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at its spring gala last month, offering to let him place the artwork anywhere in the city for 90 days. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, has sat on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts since 1965. The sculpture will leave the Lincoln Center campus on Thursday and be installed at the garden on Friday. The Osborne Garden will frame Le Guichet in an entirely new and evocative way, said Scot Medbury, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: What to Watch: Schiavone vs. Dementieva

Today she faces Elena Dementieva, a rival since their days in the juniors, and she will stride onto Court Philippe Chatrier as the first Italian woman to reach a Grand Slam semifinal. After a first-round, first-set hiccup, Schiavone has motored through the draw without dropping another set.

The Haggards said they planned to open the church in the coming weeks, but had not found a specific location. Mr. Haggard said the church would be open to everyone, but especially those going through difficult times. Because of what weve been through, I may be qualified to help other people in need, he said.

Inside, they discovered 147 new AK-47 rifles, still in their boxes; 263 high-capacity magazines; 53 bayonets; and 10,000 rounds of ammunition  enough for a small army. title: Thailand: From Protest to Sales Pitch
description: Struggling to its feet again two weeks after a military crackdown that cleared Bangkok streets of protesters, the Rajaprasong commercial district is offering residents what one newspaper calls shopping therapy. In place of the propaganda slogans of the protests , the big department stores shout their wares with promotions like Bliss is Back@Gaysorn, Salon de Style, We Love Rajaprasong and Welcome Back, Shoppers, promising huge discounts of up to 80 percent on goods that survived the shutdowns and the fires.

title: China: Tank Cartoon Censored on Eve of Anniversary of Tiananmen Square
description: Days before the anniversary of Chinas 1989 assault on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square, Chinese censors have forced one of the nations more outspoken newspapers to excise a cartoon that appears to refer to the crackdown. In a series of cartoons commemorating International Childrens Day, the newspaper, Southern Metropolis Daily, based in Guangdong Province, depicted a child drawing a line of tanks, a man standing before them. The cartoon seemed to evoke the most famous photograph of the Tiananmen protests, in which an unarmed man brought a column of Chinese tanks to a standstill by refusing to move from their path. Friday is the 21st anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

title: Canada: Quebec Partys New Effort to Limit English in Quebec Schools
description: The separatist Parti Qubcois tied up Quebecs legislature with procedural maneuvers on Wednesday after the Liberal government introduced new restrictions on English language schooling. The opposition party thinks that the new legislation, introduced after the province lost a case at the Supreme Court of Canada, does not sufficiently limit access to English language education. The court dismissed an earlier law that had limited access to the English-speaking public school system.

title: Oil Could Reach Atlantic Coasts

Now a suite of simulations, run by an international team of ocean and climate scientists, shows this is a likely outcome should the flow remain unabated this summer. The researchers stress there are caveats and uncertainties, most notably related to the state of the gulfs highly variable loop current in coming weeks. (The Department of Energy put out its own fact sheet stressing that the simulations are highly uncertain.)

Collier West is filled with all sorts of stylish bric-a-brac from crystal chandeliers to John Derian decoupage to necklaces made from reclaimed bits and baubs. Suzi likes all things French and anything made by hand, says one staffer. You wont find anything produced in China. title: For Next to Normal, a Real-Life Couple
description: The real-life married couple Marin Mazzie (Kiss Me, Kate) and Jason Danieley (Curtains) will take over the roles of Diana Goodman and her husband, Dan, in the Broadway musical Next to Normal on July 19, the production said on Thursday. The roles mark the first time that the couple has appeared together in a Broadway musical; they last worked together on a major New York production in 1996 in the Off Broadway play The Trojan Women: A Love Story, and were married a year later. Ms. Mazzie, a three-time Tony Award nominee who most recently appeared on Broadway this spring in Enron, will succeed Alice Ripley, who won the Tony for best actress in a musical in 2009 for her portrayal of Diana, a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. Ms. Ripley is departing the show to prepare to play Diana in the North American tour, scheduled to begin in November. Mr. Danieley will replace Brian dArcy James (Shrek), who took over the role of Dan last month from J. Robert Spencer; Mr. dArcy James will rejoin the cast of the play Time Stands Still when it returns to Broadway in the fall. Ms. Ripley and Mr. dArcy James are to give their final performances on July 18.

title: The Last Stand

But for those who actually participated in the events of that past, the West was dynamic, unpredictable, and startlingly new. Native horse culture was only a few generations old by the time Lewis and Clark ventured west in 1804, and ever-building pressure from the East meant that the tribes territories and alliances remained in near-constant flux throughout the nineteenth century.

In more recent years Custers story has also been told with more detail and dispassion: in Jeffry Werts 1996 account of his military maneuvers (Custer: The Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer), and in Evan S. Connells novelistic classic, Son of the Morning Star: Custer and the Little Bighorn (1984).

title: Remembering Iraq

For nearly a year, my men and I patrolled areas fewer than ten miles from where Iraqi emergency personnel sifted through the smoldering remains.

(Perfection apparently requires the umpires to reach that same standard.) Yet there is still a way to get Galarraga into the record book, and one man has all the power.

title: Prakash Jhas Godfather, Bhopal Version
description: Prakash Jhas new Hindi film, Raajneeti, takes a dim view of the Indian political scene. Extortion, intimidation and murder (with car bombs, wooden bats and, less creatively, guns) engage the movies politicians far more than any platform or position.

title: Sculpture Is a Trip for Twins and Met
description: Summer on the Metropolitan Museums roof has typically meant circling a pedestal or two before moving on to cocktails and the view. But with Big Bamb, a walk-in/walk-on, site-specific, thoroughly exhilarating sculpture by the twin brothers Doug and Mike Starn, the museum has raised the bar.

title: Dell Chief Has Considered Taking Company Private
description: Dells chief executive, Michael S. Dell, said Thursday afternoon that he had considered taking the company he founded private and that the transformation of the computer maker was still incomplete, Reuters reports.

title: Masa Takayamas New House Has Lots of Room for Dinner Guests
description: NEW YORKERS are serious about lots of things, like food, art and  of course  real estate.

title: Devis Chef Is Leaving to Open a New Indian Restaurant
description: Hemant Mathur, the chef and founding partner at Devi, will leave in a couple weeks to open his own place, Tulsi, at 211 East 46th Street. The name of the restaurant, which he and his partners expect to open in September, means holy basil in Hindi.

title: The Week Ahead: June 6  12
description: Art

title: City Hall, 3:26 P.M.
description: A hole outside City Hall is the site of an archaeological dig this week. Workers have been testing to determine the age of an underground wall unearthed during the construction of a subbasement utility vault. The Landmarks Preservation Commission says that the wall appears to date from the 18th or early 19th century and may have been associated with the First Almshouse, a poorhouse that stood on the site from 1736 to 1797.

title: Glories of Nature, Tamed by Man
description: One of the greatest landscapes of the Romantic era can be found right in the middle of Manhattan. It isnt a Turner, a Friedrich, a Delacroix  or anything in a museum, for that matter. Its the 843-acre Greensward plan designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux in the mid-19th century  or, as we know it, Central Park.

title: On the Road to Rock, Fueled by Excess
description: Hes one of the last remaining rock stars! says Aaron Green, referring to Aldous Snow, the him in the new film Get Him to the Greek. The Greek is a famous concert hall in Los Angeles, and the guy to whom the films imperative title is addressed is Aaron himself.

title: The Politics of Espionage and Redemption
description: Thursday night marks the return of Burn Notice for its fourth season. A hit spy series on USA, Burn Notice chronicles the adventures of a former government spy (Michael Westen, played by Jeffrey Donovan) who washes up in Miami where he tries to right the wrongs of various underdogs with the help of his sidekicks Fiona (or just Fi, Gabrielle Anwar) and Sam (Bruce Campbell). The creator of the series, Matt Nix (whose latest show, The Good Guys, recently made its debut on Fox), answered some of our questions via e-mail. Hed like to hear from readers as well, so fire away. Send along your inquiries and well post Mr. Nixs responses here.

title: For Residents of Homeless Shelter, a Night to Shine
description: Yvette Alston pulled a strapless dress with a gold waistband out of her locker at the homeless shelter on West 41st street where she lives.

title: iPads Take to the Air
description: Travelers may not have to actually buy an iPad to use one on the road. The device has already gained a foothold in various hotels, and the latest to adopt the iPad is Jetstar Airways, a subsidiary of the Australian airline Qantas, which recently announced plans to roll out iPads as part of its in-flight entertainment options.

title: Painting Thin Air, Sometimes in Bright Blue
description: WASHINGTON  By now, hero worship of the French artist Yves Klein (1928-62) should be a thing of the past. Sure, he was charismatic, movie-star handsome and a black belt in judo, and he had a gift for provocative gestures. At the age of 19, on the beach with two friends, a poet and an artist, Klein signed the sky as his first work of art. In the mid-1950s he developed a smoldering ultramarine pigment that in a stroke of branding genius, he patented and named International Klein Blue.

title: House Tour: Ticonderoga, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house.

title: Cleopatras Underwater Kingdom
description: PHILADELPHIA  It may be best to dispel any illusions immediately. The only certain images we seem to have of the last queen of Egypt, Cleopatra VII, have no discernible resemblance to the painted faces of Elizabeth Taylor or Claudette Colbert or Sarah Bernhardt. Those visages can be contemplated with far more sensuous contentment than the Egyptian queens bulbous, knotty and eroded features stamped on gold coins from the first century B.C.

title: I Call Your Name
description: My husband and I are expecting. But every time we discuss a baby name with family and friends, someone claims it, saying theyve always wanted to use it. This has happened four times already. Their responses range from surprise that wed steal their baby name to threats of never speaking to us again. Some of these people are still single! Dont we have the right to name our child anything we like?

title: Oil, the Loop Current and the Atlantic
description: Many have fretted that oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico could spread to the Florida Keys and then northward up the Atlantic. Now, the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. has come up with some computer modeling suggesting that the spill could extend along thousands of miles up the Atlantic coast as early as this summer.

title: Theater Listings: June 4  10
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Yves Klein at the Hirshhorn
description: Images from a new exhibition in Washington.

title: Queen of the Nile
description: Images from an exhibition about Cleopatra at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

title: Feeding the Comedy Beast Without Serving Leftovers
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Revenue Picture, State by State
description: State revenues rose in the first quarter of this year, largely because two states raised a lot of money through tax hikes, according to the Rockefeller Institute of Government.

title: 2010 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport
description: The Grand Sport borrows just enough of the looks and performance of its upmarket brethren.

title: Sampling the Scene
description: Parties mentioned in this article:

title: Obama Will Tout Medicare Rebates
description: With the government preparing to put the proverbial checks in the mail, President Obama is planning a televised town hall meeting on Tuesday with senior citizens to trumpet one of the most popular provisions of his landmark health care bill: a $250 rebate to help Medicare beneficiaries pay for prescription drugs.

title: Social Disrobing and Other Party Fare
description: IT was Friday night, and the face paint was optional, but few people abstained. Why? Because here was a woman in pasties and a giant pink beehive talking to a guy in a unitard with a balloon for a head, who called himself the Eye of Disorient. There was a woman in a nude body stocking, with artfully applied glitter, go-go dancing on a platform. A daughter of a Factory star was nearby, alongside some art school kids, television writers and other nightlife denizens. And everywhere there were tchotchkes and doodads, glowing in the black light.

title: Bronx Zoos New Lion Cubs Are Impossibly Cute
description: I SUFFER from cat envy.

title: Treating the Worlds Sorrow and Pain
description: At one point in Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders, Mark Hopkinss new documentary about that Paris-based humanitarian group, an Australian doctor stationed in Congo, his tongue loosened by a lot of local beer, unloads his scorn for Unicef and other, similar organizations. They approach mass suffering, he says, by way of theories, meetings and high-minded statements of principle, whereas he and other Doctors Without Borders physicians meet the consequences of war, epidemic and natural disaster one patient at a time.

title: Senate Leader Urges Action on Energy Bills
description: In another sign that Democrats plan to harness outrage over the BP oil spill to help pass a comprehensive energy and climate change bill, Senator Harry Reid wrote to six committee chairmen on Thursday calling for new proposals to respond to the current and future disasters, for inclusion in the broader package the Senate will debate this summer.

title: A Duos Switch in Roles Is Made in Harmony
description: When Dave Rawlings and Gillian Welch sing country music together, they dont stay within the safety zone of harmonizing in thirds. Sometimes its a wider interval; often its narrower; and sometimes, but only for a few notes at a time, they sing in unison. This is true whether she sings lead and theyre performing under her name  which is usually the case  or vice versa, which was the case for Wednesday nights show at the Bowery Ballroom by the Dave Rawlings Machine.

title: Prime Meats No Longer Cash Only
description: It still does not take reservations, but Prime Meats, the popular, relatively expensive, 19th-Century-ish German-style restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, has at least added one 21st- Century luxury. It has started to accept payment by American Express card.

title: Finding Other America in Slums and on Farms
Lehman Plans Auction of Its Modern Artworks
Lincoln Center Closes Roof Lawn
description: Even on the Upper West Side, it seems, this is the season of lawn-care problems. Just two weeks after opening its new sloping roof lawn, Lincoln Center on Tuesday had to close it.

title: Urban Camping, Bargemusic, Museum Mile Festival
description: New Yorkers who feel the need to escape the concrete jungle and return to the wild can take advantage of the Urban Park Rangers free family camping trips. The outings are held on select weekends through September, in parks throughout the five boroughs. All you need is a sleeping bag and a flashlight; the rangers provide the rest, along with the chance to hike at night and observe nocturnal creatures. Or simply lie back, eat some smores and do a little stargazing. Families can sign up for trips on specified registration dates but space is limited. (Details are at nycgovparks.org; search for family camping.)

title: A Musical Exploration of Insomnia and Oblivion
description: Music inspired by night and sleep and the discontinuity between the two formed the backbone of Illuminating Darkness, a program by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Its Official: Murphy Is Out for the Season
description: Daniel Murphy came to spring training in February as the starting first baseman for the Mets, although he knew that Ike Davis was lurking in the minor leagues.

title: Cuomo in Rift With Working Families Party
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo is pressuring the embattled Working Families Party to install placeholder candidates for governor and attorney general at the partys convention on Saturday, according to three people who were briefed on Mr. Cuomos actions.

title: Coalition Seeks Boycott of Comedy Central Series
description: A coalition of organizations that seek to promote what they see as religious values and family-friendly programming said on Thursday that they were calling on prospective sponsors to boycott a planned Comedy Central animated series that would satirize Jesus Christ. The group, Citizens Against Religious Bigotry, which includes leaders from the Media Research Center, the Catholic League and the Parents Television Council, said that the series represented a double standard in light of the networks decision to censor an episode of South Park that mocked the Prophet Muhammad, the founder of Islam. In April, Comedy Central bleeped the audio of a South Park show that said a character was the Prophet Muhammad disguised in a bear costume. The move came after the shows creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, were named in ominous messages posted on revolutionmuslim.com, the Web site of the Islamic group Revolution Muslim. Comedy Central said last month that it was developing a show called JC, in which Jesus tries to lead a normal existence in New York. The series has not yet been added to the networks schedule or shown to the public. The coalition said it had written to some 250 advertisers urging them not to support the series. Tony Fox, a press representative for Comedy Central, said: JC is an idea and an idea only. Perhaps the Citizens Against Religious Bigotry should save their energy for the moment if and when this series ever makes air.

title: Solti Award For Music Director of New York Youth Symphony
description: The Solti Foundation U.S. has given Ryan McAdams, the music director of the New York Youth Symphony, a $10,000 prize for emerging conductors, the foundation said on Thursday. Mr. McAdams, 28, has been advancing quickly in the orchestra world, making recent appearances with the New York City Opera, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, among others. He is a former protg of Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic. The foundation also gave two career assistance awards: $5,000 to Kazem Abdullah, 30, a former assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera who made his debut there last year, and $3,500 to Robert Trevino, 26, who made his New York conducting debut at the New York City Operas VOX: American Opera series. The foundation, which supports young conductors, was established by the family of Georg Solti, the longtime music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, after his death in 1997.

title: Police Station Chemistry: Shes New, and Hes a Flirt
description: Judging by its silly title, not to mention the feathered hair and police station banter, Buddy Cop 2 seems as if it could be a joke-filled love letter to Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. But dont be fooled. Set in the 1980s, this downtown gem, full of minor-key revelations and offhand epiphanies, roots its quirky charm in an earnest and surprising realism.

title: Talent Is Tops but NBC Isnt
description: The second night of the NBC reality competition Americas Got Talent topped the ratings on Wednesday, but the network placed third for the night over all. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in for the second installment of Americas Got Talent auditions, in Dallas. Fox averaged the most viewers on the night, attracting 7.3 million for So You Think You Can Dance from 8 to 10, while CBS was a close second with sitcom repeats followed by reruns of Criminal Minds (8.1 million) and CSI: NY (8.6 million). ABC finished in fourth place with comedy repeats and a new episode of Happy Town (2.8 million).

title: Tennis Meets Obstacle Course
description: CARDIO tennis is like recess with a racket. A trademarked exercise class taught around the world and gaining ground in New York, it promotes movement on a court while keeping instruction and angst at a minimum. Think of it as playing at tennis.

title: For Next to Normal, a Real-Life Couple
description: The real-life married couple Marin Mazzie (Kiss Me, Kate), top right, and Jason Danieley (Curtains), below right, will take over the roles of Diana Goodman and her husband, Dan, in the Broadway musical Next to Normal on July 19, the production said on Thursday. The roles mark the first time that the couple have appeared together in a Broadway musical; they last worked together on a major New York production in 1996 in the Off Broadway play The Trojan Women: A Love Story and were married a year later. Ms. Mazzie, a three-time Tony Award nominee who most recently appeared on Broadway this spring in Enron, will succeed Alice Ripley, who won the Tony for best actress in a musical in 2009 for her portrayal of Diana, a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. Ms. Ripley is departing the show to prepare to play Diana in the North American tour, scheduled to begin in November. Mr. Danieley will replace Brian dArcy James (Shrek), who took over the role of Dan last month from J. Robert Spencer; Mr. dArcy James will rejoin the cast of the play Time Stands Still when it returns to Broadway in the fall. Ms. Ripley and Mr. dArcy James will give their final performances on July 18.

title: The Morning Line: Belmont Shares Spotlight
description: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Flowers That Bloom Between Abysses
description: Referring to the Beethoven piano sonata universally known by the evocative nickname  Moonlight  (Op. 27, No. 2), Liszt deemed the bright Allegretto between its moodier outer movements a flower between two abysses. Thomas Sauer, a pianist and the director of the Mannes Beethoven Institute, said Liszts observation provided a structure for the opening concert of this years series, presented on Wednesday evening.

title: HBP to Film Carrie Fishers Show
description: If you missed Carrie Fishers very public peacemaking with her Hollywood upbringing and her perpetual status as the heroine of a certain beloved outer-space epic, youll soon be able to catch it on a television not far, far away. On Thursday, HBO said that it would broadcast a feature-length documentary based on Wishful Drinking, the one-woman show by Ms. Fisher, right, that was presented by Roundabout Theater Company at Studio 54 earlier this year. The show, in which Ms. Fisher shares stories of her childhood with her parents, Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, and re-coils her hair in the coif she sported as Princess Leia in Star Wars, was called a brut-dry, deeply funny memoir of a show in a review by Ben Brantley in The New York Times, yet somehow escaped the attention of the Tony Award nominating committee. HBO said that its documentary will be directed by Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey (Monica in Black and White, The Eyes of Tammy Faye), and will combine footage of the show, to be taped on June 25 at the South Orange Performing Arts Center in South Orange, N.J., with archival footage and other interviews. A premiere date for the documentary was not announced.

title: Fresh Adventures With Balanchine, and Jazzy Footwork With Rodgers
description: The four ballets that entered New York City Ballet repertory on Wednesday night didnt add up as a rich program. They will return in combination with other works, perhaps to better effect, during this month. But they did open up different aspects of ballet both in fulfillment and, just as often, in potential.

title: 520 Days Inside a Simulated Spacecraft
description: As The Lede explained last year, Russian preparations for travel to Mars revolve around experiments in a hanger in Moscow, where teams of researchers have been spending increasingly long periods locked inside a simulated spacecraft.

title: Ask the Dancers: Young Americans in Russia Respond
description: Earlier this week Clifford J. Levy wrote about Julian MacKay and Joy Womack. The two budding ballet dancers are among a small group of Americans who have ever trained at the prestigious and competitive Bolshoi academy in Moscow. We asked readers to submit questions to the two dancers. Here is the first round of responses.

title: What to Watch: Soderling vs. Berdych
description: While the tennis world is abuzz after Robin Soderlings upset of Roger Federer, dont count out his semifinal opponent, Tomas Berdych, who has quietly demolished opponents on his way to the final four at Roland Garros. In his five matches, he has not lost a set; in fact, hes only lost 43 games. He easily handled Andy Murray in the Round of 16, then followed that up by overpowering Mikhail Youzhny.

title: Dancing Their Way to a Tony Nomination
description: The pleasures of dance and choreography come from strange sources. It is not without embarrassment that I report my recent delight in a male pole-dancing Pierrot in Cirque du Soleils Banana Shpeel. And I am somewhat shamefaced in mentioning my pleasure in the caged-birds number performed by the transvestite chorus in the current production of La Cage aux Folles.

title: Rereading The Man Who Loved Children
description: There are any number of reasons you shouldnt read The Man Who Loved Children this summer. Its a novel, for one thing; and havent we all secretly sort of come to an agreement, in the last year or two or three, that novels belonged to the age of newspapers and are going the way of newspapers, only faster? As an old English professor friend of mine likes to say, novels are a curious moral case, in that we feel guilty about not reading more of them but also guilty about doing something as frivolous as reading them; and wouldnt we all be better off with one less thing in the world to feel guilty about?

title: Up Front: Jonathan Franzen
description: In his essay for this issue, Jonathan Franzen, the author of The Corrections, makes a strong case for Christina Steads novel The Man Who Loved Children, which he feels deserves a much wider readership than it has so far achieved.

title: Action on the Stage Imprinted on the Eye
description: All kinds of things can happen at a contemporary dance performance besides actual dancing. (And I mean all kinds of things.) But Dusan Tynek, a Czech choreographer who has lived in New York since 1992, makes traditional kinds of dance: pieces with recognizable steps, set to music, possessed of beginnings, middles and ends.

title: Hasan di Tiro, Who Led Indonesia Rebels, Dies at 84
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Hasan di Tiro, the founder of the Indonesian rebel group the Free Aceh Movement, which fought Jakarta in a three-decade war of independence before disbanding under a peace accord in 2005, died Thursday in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. He was 84 and had returned from exile in 2008.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Man Meets Mermaid (Theres a Catch)
description: Tucked inside Ondine, the latest from Neil Jordan, is a wisp of a tale about a mythical sea creature and the sailing man who crosses paths with this being. As admirers of Mr. Jordan know, this director of The Crying Game and The Butcher Boy and, more recently, the macabre revenge story The Brave One, has a fondness for fantasy worlds. While the genre coordinates of his fictions change from film to film  they sometimes skew toward comedy, other times toward horror and occasionally someplace in between  the line between fantasy and reality in both his stories and in his characters heads often remains blurred.

title: C.A.A. Talks to Buyout Firms Over Potential Alliance
description: LOS ANGELES  The Creative Artists Agency, the entertainment and sports powerhouse, has been in discussions with private equity firms like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG about a potential alliance or joint venture to build up its sports business, people briefed on the talks told DealBook.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Report Warned Wal-Mart of Risks Before Bias Suit
description: More than six years before the biggest sex discrimination lawsuit in history was filed against Wal-Mart Stores, the company hired a prominent law firm to examine its vulnerability to just such a suit.

title: Salute of the Stars, Cosmic and Otherwise
description: As the host of the opening-night gala performance of the World Science Festival at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, Alan Alda promised a trip through the cosmos at the speed of art. And on this occasion, at least, art stepped lively.

title: Which Team Has the Right Stuff to Win the Title?
description: Carlton J. Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.

title: Careful, That Test Tube Might Be Incubating a Bouncing Baby Monster
description: The two recognizable stars of Splice, a pleasurably shivery, sometimes delightfully icky horror movie about love and monsters in the age of genetic engineering, are Adrien Brody and Sarah Polley, a well-matched pair of earthbound oddities. Given their respective performative idiosyncrasies and, as important, their singularly nontraditional beauty, the pairs casting immediately signals that the director Vincenzo Natali is after something different. With Ms. Polley and Mr. Brody on board, theres a chance that despite the big-studio brands on the movie, youre not headed into genre purgatory with the usual disposable plastic people who often populate (and perish in) mainstream horror. When these two bleed, you might actually care.

title: Out of Toothpaste or Toilet Paper? Buy It Online
description: The founders of Diapers.com managed to start a company selling a commonplace product and turn it into a darling of the tech world. Now its founders are trying to do it again, with Soap.com.

description: ART

title: Instant Replay and Blown Calls
description: Should instant replay be used in baseball to help prevent blown calls, like the one that cost Detroit's Armando Galarraga a perfect game on Wednesday night? Watch and vote.

description: TIGERS THE EXHIBITION

title: Case of the Kidnappings and the Scared Island
description: Like the child-killing clown in Stephen Kings It, the bogyman known as Cropsey was, to the children of Staten Island, a morphing symbol of evil. Hook-handed or ax-wielding, he was said to haunt the grounds of the abandoned Willowbrook State School for the mentally disabled, pouncing on the unwary and unprotected.

title: Plan for Relief Wells Spurs Hope Amid Caution
description: As engineers made headway Thursday in containing the oil leak at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico, crews on two floating rigs flanking the spot where the Deepwater Horizon exploded and sank were doing what rig crews normally do: drilling wells.

description: CLASSICAL

title: Photo Replay: June 3
description: A view of the day in sports, with clouds, fog, snow-capped mountains and a sun-splashed Stadium.

title: Casting Disclosed for Angels in America
description: Initial casting for the September revival of Tony Kushners Pulitzer Prize-winning Angels in America includes Zachary Quinto and Billy Porter, according to two theater executives involved with the Signature Theater Company production.

description: DANCE

title: Almost-Forgotten Leino Plays Memorable Role in Playoffs for the Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Few things seem to delight a hockey player more than the promise of extra ice time. Peter Laviolette, the Philadelphia Flyers coach, made such a guarantee this week to Ville Leino, who was not even dressing for games when the playoffs began in April.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Standing in a Tunnels Path, and Forced to Leave
description: Christine A. Moore, a hat designer on 34th Street in Midtown Manhattan, is one of the unlucky 100. Like other businesses and landlords in the area, she has been warned that a giant tunnel-boring machine is coming to her neighborhood and that she will have to move as her building is marked for demolition.

title: To Save an Afghan Boy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Cartoon Dog Tries the O.C.
description: The 200-pound Great Dane who lumbers through Marmaduke just cant help himself. When his owners, Phil and Debbie Winslow (Lee Pace and Judy Greer), are snuggling in bed, that darned dog (voiced by Owen Wilson) has a habit of noisily releasing gas that is noxious enough to erase any immediate prospects of romance.

title: Solar Power Keeps Cart Fleet in Motion
description: About a year ago, the Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y., retrofitted its golf carts with solar cell roof panels. Sebonack said it was the first American golf course with a solar-powered cart fleet. The roof panels convert daylight into power and charge the cart as it is being driven.

title: Day 44: The Latest on the Oil Spill
description: Containment Effort Progresses

title: Yelp and OpenTable Join Forces
description: On Thursday evening, Yelp.com, the user-generated review Web site, and OpenTable.com, the restaurant reservations site, announced an integration that will allow Yelp users to make a restaurant reservation directly from a Yelp.com review page.

title: Investors Demanding Social Justice
description: As instances of business malefaction pile up  Enron, Madoff, Goldman Sachs, A.I.G., Toyota, BP, and were just clearing our throats with that lineup  the concept of corporate responsibility has acquired the sour air of an oxymoron for many people. Laura Berry is not one of them.

title: BPs Natural Gas Joint Venture in Russia Is in Bankruptcy
description: MOSCOW  The British oil giant BP conceded another setback Thursday in its struggle to recover hundreds of millions of dollars in investments from a venture to sell Russian natural gas to China.

title: Housing for Sex Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Filmmaking Stripped Bare
description: Julie Daviss trifling romantic comedy, Finding Bliss, is a goofy ode to the liberating benefits of pornography. Its heroine, the strait-laced Jody Balaban (Leelee Sobieski), is an aspiring director with a degree from New York Universitys film school who goes to Hollywood to break into the movie business. When the only job to be found is editing pornographic films for Grind Productions, she grits her teeth, averts her eyes and settles down to work, determined to bring a softer feminine perspective to the companys hard-core products.

title: Eating Together: The Bonds We Formed at Our Table
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Cluttered Minds
description: Socrates started what may have been the first technology scare. In the Phaedrus, he lamented the invention of books, which create forgetfulness in the soul. Instead of remembering for themselves, Socrates warned, new readers were blindly trusting in external written characters. The library was ruining the mind.

title: Smart Students Go After Intels Science Prize
description: Three enterprising high schoolers blaze a path to the holy grail of science contests in Whiz Kids, an unabashed celebration of geekitude, idealism and the will to win.

title: New York G.O.P. Selects Candidate for U.S. Senate
description: Closing out a raucous and at times contentious state convention on Thursday, New York Republicans designated Bruce A. Blakeman, a lawyer and former Nassau County legislator, their preferred candidate to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand this fall.

title: Keeping Score: Act of Perfection Remains Random
description: There have already been two perfect games this season, and thats not counting Armando Galarragas near-miss on Wednesday night.

title: In Supreme Court Work, Early Views of Kagan
description: WASHINGTON  As a young law clerk working for Justice Thurgood Marshall at the Supreme Court in September 1987, Elena Kagan wrote an angry memorandum urging her boss to try to overturn a conservative appeals court ruling that had questioned the constitutionality of a rent-control ordinance.

title: City to Pay $9.9 Million Over Mans Imprisonment
description: New York City agreed on Thursday to pay $9.9 million, the largest personal settlement in its history, to a man who served almost two decades in prison but was released after evidence surfaced that he had been framed for murder by a corrupt detective.

title: Woods Is Tied for 50th After a First-Round 72
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Geoff Ogilvy and Tiger Woods finished at the same time Thursday evening, but not the same place. The two were separated by about 100 yards on the 9th and the 18th greens, by seven strokes on their scorecards and by nearly 50 places on the leader board after their first rounds at the Memorial Tournament.

title: Thousands in Turkey Mourn Victims of Israeli Raid
description: ISTANBUL  It was a day of mourning for Turkey on Thursday, as a crowd of several thousand people streamed down a central boulevard here, bearing eight coffins draped in Turkish and Palestinian flags, one of them carrying an American citizen.

title: Accused of War Crimes, and Living With Perks
description: THE HAGUE  Since the days after World War II when people accused as Nazi criminals awaited their fates in the grimness of Nuremberg Prison, reformers have dramatically reshaped the standards under which suspects accused of the vilest war crimes are being held.

title: Off Broadway Vampires
description: Jordan Gallands Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Undead has one great idea (and its not the title). An Off Broadway production, the film tells us, might actually be a vampire play  written and produced by bloodsuckers to gather an unsuspecting audience of potential victims. Now we know why sitting in a downtown theater can feel like living death.

title: Daniel K. Tarullo, a Star Regulator at the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  As finishing touches are put on the most comprehensive rewriting of financial rules since the Depression, a 57-year-old former law professor is emerging as one of the most influential financial regulators in the United States.

title: Google to Give Governments Street View Data
description: Google is bowing to the demands of three European governments and says it will begin surrendering the data it improperly collected over unsecured wireless networks.

title: Pentagon Told to Save Billions for Use in War
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has ordered the military and the Pentagons civilian bureaucracy to find tens of billions of dollars in annual savings to pay for war-fighting operations, senior officials said Thursday.

Mr. Awlaki sent him from Yemen a copy of his tract 44 Ways of Supporting Jihad, prosecutors said. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, after learning of the e-mail messages, sent an informer posing as a member of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula to contact Mr. Bujol, an American. From the informer, Mr. Bujol obtained equipment for the group, including global positioning system devices, telephone calling cards and a military compass. The main evidence was a headless torso found in the village well. In April, after Mr. Zhao had served 10 years of a 29-year sentence, the man he was supposed to have killed showed up alive. He was released, and officials admitted that he had been tortured to confess to a crime that did not exist. The body in the well, the police now say, belongs to Gao Zongzhi, The Beijing News reported. The police confirmed Wednesday that they had detained three men in his killing.

title: Revert
description: Lynne Geyser writes: "My son and I are in disagreement concerning the use of the word revert. The only usage I find acceptable is 'to return to a previous state.' He uses it (and claims that his Bahamian/English friends use it) to mean 'to get back to someone.' That is, instead of saying, 'I will get back to you with that information or with respect to that issue,' they say, 'I will revert to you.' Can you shed some light on this?"  Revert, as the major American and British dictionaries have it, does indeed primarily refer to a return to a former condition, belief or practice. For instance, George Vecsey, a sports columnist for The New York Times, recently wrote of the woeful New Jersey Nets, "Jason Kidd, Kenyon Martin and Richard Jefferson reached the finals in 2002 and 2003, but the Nets have since reverted to their haunted roots."  Secondary senses of the verb include the legal one, denoting the return of something to its previous owner, as in the contractual boilerplate, "All rights revert to the author after publishing." In evolutionary biology, it can signal an atavistic throwback to an ancestral type. To someone familiar with only these traditional meanings of the word, "I will revert to you" might sound like a bizarrely personal take on either property law or genetics.
