Until last month, the Milroy (5 Hamilton Place, W1J) was no exception. But now the hand-carved staircase, the newly restored tapestries and the Venetian chandeliers leading to its restaurants luxurious and extravagant dining rooms can be seen by the public  at least at lunchtime.

title: Catalonia Asks Bank to Reconsider Merger Plans
description: The Generalitat de Catalunya has asked La Caixa Laietana, the last Catalan savings bank yet to be merged under Spains broad efforts at financial consolidation, to reconsider its plans to enter a cold merger with a group of savings banks led by Caja Madrid, a person at the regional governments department of economics said Friday.

title: Joe Drapes Belmont Picks
description: The field for Saturdays 142nd running of the $1 million Belmont Stakes. The New York Racing Association oddsmaker, Eric Donovan, set the morning-line odds. Joe Drape made the selections in order of preference.

title: Infogroup Urges Shareholders to Support Sale
description: Infogroup is urging shareholders to ignore the objections of two of its biggest investors and approve the database providers proposed $460 million sale to private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors later this month, The Associated Press reported.

title: Rothschild Appoints Chief for North America
description: The Rothschild Group said on Thursday that it has named Jim Lawrence as its chief executive for North America, as the global firm seeks to bolster its practice here.

title: Laos Set For Capitalist Leap Into Stock Market
description: Isolated for decades behind Asias bamboo curtain, communist Laos will soon take a great leap into the global capitalist marketplace with the debut of a stock exchange to fuel a quiet mining and hydropower boom, Reuters reports.

title: Ulta Salon Investors Announce Share Offering
description: Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance said Thursday that its chief executive, Lyn Kirby, and entities and individuals associated with Global Retail Partners are publicly offering just under 9.8 million shares of Ulta common stock, The Associated Press reported.

title: Wells Fargo Jury Decides Against Punitive Damages
description: A jury decided not to impose punitive damages against Wells Fargo on Thursday, a day after those jurors awarded $29.9 million to four nonprofits after finding the bank had breached its fiduciary duty and engaged in fraud.

title: Hedge Fund Investors Pull $3.5 Billion in April
description: Investors withdrew $3.5 billion from hedge funds in April, according to TrimTabs Investment Research and BarclayHedge estimates, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Swiss Upper House Backs UBS Deal With U.S.
description: A Swiss-U.S. deal to end a tax dispute that nearly crippled UBS and undermined Swiss bank secrecy inched closer to approval in the full Parliament as the upper house gave it its backing Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: $8.4 Million for Lansdowne in Bet Against Pru
description: The collapse of Prudentials deal to buy the American International Groups Asian life insurance arm has cost investment banks lucrative fees, put the British insurers top brass under fire and deprived the American taxpayer of a big payback.

title: AgBank Signs Agreement With Dutch Rabobank
description: Rabobank said Friday that it had signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate with Agricultural Bank of China, the state-run lender poised to go public in what it hopes will be a $30 billion I.P.O.

title: Targeting New Business
description: Much has been written about the power of positive thinking, creating your own reality, putting your intentions out into the universe in the hope that thoughts and feelings will become tangible things. Our agency recently tested the theory with a new business development effort.

title: Stray Questions for: Nicholas Carr
description: Nicholas Carrs new book, The Shallows: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains, is reviewed in this Sundays book review.

title: HSBC in Talks to Sell 5 P.E. Units
description: HSBC Holdings said Friday that it is in talks to sell its private equity fund management businesses in five separate management buyouts.

title: Soderling Reaches French Open Final
description: PARIS  Robin Soderling of Sweden wore down Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic, 6-3, 3-6, 5-7, 6-3, 6-3, to gain the final round of the French Open for the second year.

title: Now, New York Is His Oyster
description: The first time Fabien Cousteau went scuba diving, he was only 4 years old. Now 42, he has followed in the footsteps of his famous grandfather, Jacques, and his father, Jean-Michel, traveling the world as a deep-sea explorer and documentary filmmaker.

title: Motorcycle News Roundup
description: After a long winters nap, the roundup is back, with two-wheeled motoring news from around the Web

description: Here are some highlights from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: Booz and AT Kearney Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: Booz & Company and AT Kearney, two management consulting firms, are in merger talks that could result in the creation of the worlds third-largest consultancy, The Financial Times reported.

title: McDonalds to Recall Glasses, Citing Cadmium
description: Could cadmium be the new lead? Some parents and consumer advocates think so.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Its the spill that keeps on spilling. BP has shown us the limits of human endeavor trying to cap its pipe in the gulf, but The Times says the oil giant has another leak to deal with: its chief executives diatribes. If Tony Hayward goes, so does all the fun! Meanwhile, the AgBank initial public offering is looming on the horizon; Spains bank consolidation is afoot; and global banking rules are said to be advancing.

title: Place Your Betson Madoff Settlements
description: Though the amount Bernard L. Madoffs investors are likely to recover from losses is still unclear, a number of companies are prepared to bet that the compensation will be worth the wait, The Wall Street Journal reported.

description: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: U.S. Indexes Fall Sharply on Jobs Data
description: Stocks tumbled Friday in one of their sharpest declines this year, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly below 10,000, as a disappointing jobs report cast a pall over the nations economic recovery.

title: The Early Word: Return to the Spill
description: President Obama returns to the site of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico today, his third visit to the region in just over a month. And, as officials reported some progress in containing the spill late Thursday night, he canceled his trip to Australia, Indonesia and Guam for the second time.

title: U.S. Withdrawal on Schedule, General Says
description: BAGHDAD Gen. Ray Odierno met President Obama this week, delivering what a White House spokesman described as a positive assessment of the situation in Iraq and the prospects for American withdrawal. On Thursday, General Odierno seemed to make it official, releasing a letter to United States troops here that set Sept. 1 as a milestone.

title: Barring Disaster, United States Will Proceed With Confidence
description: IRENE, South Africa  United States forward Jozy Altidore skipped practice Friday with a sprained right ankle while his teammates continue their preparations for the World Cup. Hes listed as day to day.

title: Talking Belmont With Alex Brown
description: Join The Rails Alex Brown for his weekly radio show as he talks about the Belmont Stakes with two other exercise riders, Andy Durnin and Bob Hatfield. Brown, Durnin and Hatfield worked together at Fair Hill Training Center in the early 1990s.

title: Job Data Casts Pall Over Economic Recovery
description: A shadow fell across Americas economic recovery on Friday, as the Labor Departments monthly report showed that job growth was weak in the private sector, provoking a precipitous sell-off in the stock market.

You may submit your question to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your inquiries to general legal issues; Mr. Reaves cant offer personal legal advice.

title: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: For Five Days of Oil
Tip of the Week: A Google Delivery
description: If you dont want to spend all your time trawling the Web for updates on your favorite topics, have Google deliver the latest articles directly to your e-mailbox. Just create a Google Alert, which is a message full of links to current news articles, video clips and other sources concerning your subject. Visit Googles alert page, and in the search box, type in the topic youre interested in, say, New Orleans Saints. Pick the types of sources you want to draw from, as well as the frequency and number of results youd like to see. Fill in your e-mail address and click the Create Alert button to stop chasing the latest information and have it come to you.

title: Getting Our Heads Around the Spill
description: Like many people, I have been reading the news about the oil spill and have an overwhelming desire to understand the entirety of the problem in the gulf. Stories like these are overwhelmingly complex, and it takes countless contributions from lone individuals and groups to begin to get a feel for what is happening.

title: Q.&A. With S.&P.s President on the State of Ratings
description: The credit rating agencies have been under continuing assault for the triple-A ratings they gave to billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities that turned out to be virtually worthless when the housing market collapsed, propelling the financial crisis.

title: Nocturnalist | Perspiring for a Good Cause
A Good Report, With Two Dark Linings
description: Updated at 10:05 a.m.

title: BP Bosss Gaffes Collected on YouTube
description: As my colleagues Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss report, in addition to capping the flow of oil from its damaged well into the Gulf of Mexico, BP is also hard at work trying to contain the damage done to its public image by the steady flow of unfortunate words from Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive.

title: Wuz You Robbed?
description: No one disagrees that Armando Galarraga, the Detroit Tigers pitcher, was robbed of a perfect game the other night  not even the umpire who robbed him of it with a very bad call. Mr. Galarraga has shown considerable class in dealing with what has to have been among the most disappointing moments in his life. He even shook the umps hand.

title: Deng Is Said to Have Backed Tiananmen Violence
description: BEIJING  The former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping ordered the military to try to limit injuries when it moved against Tiananmen Square protesters 21 years ago, but told it to be ready to shed some blood if necessary, according to an unpublished diary said to document internal decisions that led to the violent crackdown.

title: Cyprus Leaders Criticize Turkey During Pope Visit
description: PAPHOS, Cyprus  In the presence of Pope Benedict XVI, Cypriot religious and political leaders unleashed a furious broadside on Friday against Turkey, whose troops have occupied northern Cyprus since 1974.

title: Room for Debate: Should a Bad Call Change Baseball?
description: Should there be greater use of video replays in baseball to prevent such errors? How would that change the game, for better or worse? A panel of experts, including Buzz Bissinger, Jim Bouton, Jason Turbow and Keith Olbermann discuss over at our Room for Debate blog. Some excerpts:

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: The Sopranos Meets the Reservation
description: Welcome to the world of Scalped. Setting: South Dakotas fictional Prairie Rose Indian Reservation. Volume 6 of this series, published by Vertigo and written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by R.M. Guera, enters the softcover list at No. 5 this week. Scalped, with all its betrayal, violence and sex, has been aptly described as The Sopranos on an Indian reservation.

title: The Morning Skate: Prongers Roadbocks Concern Blackhawks
description: These Stanley Cup playoffs have had a few underwhelming and novel controversies, like Sand-gate (the Canadiens alleged ploy to ruin the Flyers skates during the conference championship) and Puck-gate (Chris Prongers puck thievery after the first two games of the final). But an old reliable issue  the changing standards of officiating in the postseason  could be a feature of Game 4 of the Blackhawks-Flyers series on Friday night in Philadelphia.

title: Chinese Military Impedes Ties to Pentagon, Gates Says
description: SINGAPORE  While Chinas relations with the United States are improving in many areas, particularly on political and economic issues, Chinas military is blocking efforts to strengthen ties with the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told reporters on Friday.

title: Friday Reading: More Unemployed People Start Looking For Work
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Inside the List
description: THE GIRL WITH THE STRUNK AND WHITE TATTOO: Stieg Larssons Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest, the third installment in his world-conquering Millennium trilogy, grabs the No. 1 spot on the hardcover fiction list. In the press run-up to the release, a few commentators noted an odd trans-Atlantic drift in the books title, which was rendered The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest in Britain. As it turns out, this probably isnt an instance of Larssons publisher nodding. According to Carol Fisher Saller, editor of the Q & A page at The Chicago Manual of Style Online and the author of The Subversive Copy Editor, a cheeky how-to book for comma jockeys published last year, hornets nest is the spelling in the 11th edition of Merriam-Websters Collegiate Dictionary (preferred by Chicago), while the Oxford English Dictionary lists hornets nest. Evidently the change for the U.S. edition follows convention, Saller said in an e-mail message.

title: The Return of Manufacturing?
description: One possibly bright spot in the May jobs report, which was released today, was in manufacturing.

title: Complaint Box | Assumptions
description: Maneuvering through New York City as a person with cerebral palsy can be a constant irritation. Just making my way down subway stairs at rush hour, with people breathing down my neck, is holy terror. But it is not the physical strain of steps and crowds that is my main source of anxiety. It is the nave, inappropriate and sometimes downright mean comments that people make.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNETS NEST,  by Stieg Larsson (Knopf, $27.95.) In the third installment of the pulse-racing trilogy featuring Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander, the pair are threatened by an adversary from deep within the very government that should be protecting them.

title: Paperback Row
description: STRENGTH IN WHAT REMAINS,  by Tracy Kidder (Random House, $16.) Kidders hero is a young medical student from Burundi who barely survives the civil war and genocide and manages to flee to New York City. Starting out with $200 in his pocket and sleeping in Central Park, the young man is eventually befriended by people who give him a place to live and help him make his way to university and medical school. This is a story about survival, Dwight Garner said in The Times. It is just as notably about profound human kindness.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Wages Up, and the Education Gap Grows
description: We covered the basics of the jobs report in earlier posts. Here are some details  on the rise in wages, the drop in part-time workers who want to work full-time, the increase in the workweek and the growing gap between unemployment for college graduates and everyone else:

title: The Forces of Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice League
description: Two new childrens books from the brand-name writers Rick Riordan and John Grisham present special challenges for the adult reader  not that their publishers or target audiences care. But you, dear reader, are presumably not 11, so I offer this age-appropriate report.

title: Summer, Interrupted
description: From the Odyssey through On the Road and beyond, journeys have always featured prominently in the literary tradition. The disrupted journey  the aim that goes wildly off course  is a type of story with a particular wayward appeal, and its one that happens to perfectly suit the storytelling talents of the artist and novelist Lynne Rae Perkins.

title: Bound by Friendship
description: Remember passing a secret note to a friend in class, folding it as small as possible and handing it off beneath the desk to avoid detection? Or, on the receiving end, quietly unfolding the tiny missive and finding the message inside? Even if it only said Hi! or Can I borrow a pencil? the silent exchange, meant for your eyes only, felt vaguely thrilling. Your friends handwriting might be brisk or slouchy, but it was interesting to look at and added to the feeling of getting to know him or her.

title: Beauty Among Beasts
description: For mystery readers, every book is a beach book and every day is a beach day. But even genre novels present a variety of escapist choices.

title: 20 More Cookbooks
description: A COOK'S JOURNEY TO JAPAN: Fish Tales and Rice Paddies, 100 Homestyle Recipes From Japanese Kitchens. By Sarah Marx Feldner. (Tuttle, $27.95.) A charming, accessible introduction to Japanese home cooking.

title: Gardening Books
description: Looks like were back to minding our peas and kumquats. This season, gardening books will tug us into the vegetable patch, and its but a slip of the muck boot into the chicken coop and pigpen. Where we go from there is anyones guess, but as I recall, last time around the rural life left us hungry for . . . Big Macs and TV dinners. Perhaps, though, while weve been spinning through this great cycle of dharma, weve ratcheted ourselves up to a higher level. Well see.

title: Travel Books
description: It might be just a coincidence. Or another sign of publishings adaptation to the age of austerity. In any case, this seasons most interesting travel books have gone into staycation mode. Their authors arent any less curious about the wider world, but they tend to be nest builders, not vagabonds. Some, of course, have built nests in pretty remote places. Others are getting views of the open road without packing a suitcase. And one manages to have it both ways: pulling up stakes whenever the mood strikes, bringing her home right along with her.

title: Cookbooks
description: It turns out America didnt plunge into the Greater-Than-Great Depression that clouded last summer, but the jams and pickles we were spooked into putting up (and giving as budget-conscious gifts) seem to have reawakened the countrys can-do spirit. When a fashion-magazine writer I used to know started a home-canning blog called Saving the Season, I knew homesteader chic had come out of the larder.

title: Carnivores Travels
description: Riding the wave of beef chic, the Canadian food writer Mark Schatzker travels to seven notably carnivorous countries on four continents and consumes 100 pounds of cow flesh in search not only of the perfect steak but also of the science behind its flavor. On a journey that starts in Texas and winds through France, Scotland, Italy, Japan and Argentina, he visits local farms, dines at meat meccas and traces the lineage of cattle. Throughout this blur of travelogue and food criticism, he sprinkles references to religion, history, anthropology, biochemistry and philosophy. (Who knew Roland Barthes was so interested in steak tartare?) Yet without fail, the conversation comes back to one question: What makes steak so tasty? Is it the breed or the feed? Marbling or aging? Preparation, cut or something else entirely?

title: Updated: iPad 3G Shortage Wont Bar Getting Unlimited Data Plan, AT&T Says
description: 1:04 p.m. | Updated to reflect decision by AT&T to allow customers who order a 3G iPad by June 7 to purchase an unlimited monthly data plan.

title: The Message Is the Message
description: By the late 1940s, the art gods (gallery impresarios) had decreed that commercial artists be banished from galleries and museums unless they hid their tainted pasts. Of course, this changed when Andy Warhol, who started his career as a fairly successful editorial and advertising illustrator-designer, turned the art world on its soup can. Since then, the list of crossover artists has increased to the point where, arguably, it is difficult to be a contemporary artist without having an applied or commercial art pedigree  or at least without once having designed a T-shirt. Yet one of todays most celebrated artists, Barbara Kruger, who began as a graphic designer for Cond Nast and helped pioneer (along with Lawrence Weiner, Ed Ruscha and Jenny Holzer, among others) a genre that liberally employs typography and advertising techniques, met with initial resistance not from myopic art pundits but from shortsighted fellow designers.

title: Sex, Lies and Narrow Escapes
description: Megan Kelso is best known for elegant, small-scale comics (like Watergate Sue, serialized in The New York Times Magazine) with a historical or memoiristic bent. So its surprising and wonderful that ARTICHOKE TALES (Fantagraphics, $22.99), her first novel-length work, is the sort of world-building fantasy story that comes with a family tree and a map on its endpapers. Its also the sort of fantasy whose characters have artichoke leaves for hair, which means it doesnt have to pass an anthropological stress test.

title: South Africa Scores!
description: As hundreds of thousands of soccer fans pour into South Africa to watch the World Cup, we asked residents from five of the nine host cities what shouldn't be missed. While sharing their favorite things to eat, see and do, they all agreed on a few larger truths: some streets could be safer, the beaches are beautiful, the cities electric and the wildlife unparalleled. This week, with the eyes of the world upon them, they are ready to show it all off.

title: Outside South Africas Stadiums
description: Residents of World Cup cities recommend places to eat, shop and sightsee after kickoff.

title: Robin Domeniconi New Brand Officer at Elle
description: Robin Domeniconi has been named the new chief brand officer for Elle magazine, overseeing its content, advertising and marketing.

title: Hello to All That
description: When I arrived in New York in 1980, Ann Beattie was, for many young aspiring fictionists, one of the two most influential writers in the country, the other one being Raymond Carver. Beatties influence, and her rumored proximity, seemed pervasive, a part of the cultural landscape. Her stories were appearing regularly in The New Yorker. Beatties feckless middle-class postgraduates, still mourning the demise of the 60s, seemed like older versions of me and my friends, albeit with better taste. As clueless as her characters sometimes seemed, they were terribly clued-in, worldly and semiotically correct. Just as an earlier generation used to read Hemingway in part to learn what to drink and where to travel, we read Beattie in part to learn what to listen to and read and what to wear. It seems to me that it was a Beattie story that first alerted me to the existence of Billie Holiday.

title: Ask the Dancers: Part 2
description: Earlier this week Clifford J. Levy wrote about Julian MacKay and Joy Womack. The two budding ballet dancers are among a small group of Americans who have ever trained at the prestigious and competitive Bolshoi academy in Moscow. We asked readers to submit questions to the two dancers. Here is the second round of responses. Read the first round here.

title: The Normandie Breathes Again
description: For a few short moments, a breath of life pushed through the lungs of a steam whistle that once gave a loud presence to the Normandie, the French luxury liner that was known as the fastest, most fashionable way to get to Europe in the 1930s.

title: Nadal Cruises Past Melzer in Semifinal
description: PARIS - Rafael Nadal of Spain made his way back into the French Open mens finals with a straight-set victory over Jurgen Melzer of Austria 6-2, 6-3, 7-6 (6).

title: The Inner Air Guitarist Unleashed
description: Air guitarists can take one small step toward reality with PaperJamz, a set of musical instruments that look as if theyve been run over by a steamroller.

title: Car of Intrigue for a Man of Mysteries
description: ON a recent afternoon, Timothy Sheard, a 62-year-old mystery novelist, was leaning against his cherry red car, which was drawing attention from passers-by on an otherwise quiet Brooklyn street.

title: Broadcaster Helps Man Struggling in River
description: Ron MacLean, one of the most recognizable sportscasters on Canadian Broadcasting Corp.s Hockey Night in Canada, is known for his unflappable manner.

title: Jay, Daisy, Nick and Cassie
description: ACouple of years ago, when the Australian filmmaker Baz Luhrmann bought the rights to The Great Gatsby, the move generated a fair amount of what Hollywood calls buzz. On the red carpet at the Academy Awards last year, the director, accosted by curious members of the press, called Gatsby a great, iconic story with remarkable contemporary resonance. If you reread it now, he declared, youll see how powerful and meaningful it is in this time. But last September Luhrmann retreated from the project, telling Newsweek, Ive not decided which thing I will commit to. Conceding, I own the rights to Gatsby,  he added, I own the rights to it and a whole lot of other books. Its dispiriting to think of one of the greatest of the Great American Novels jumbled among a pile of books, not top of the heap. But, as Nick Carraway reflects at the storys outset, a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out unequally at birth. In this case, however, humility may hide behind the mask of hubris: it takes audacity to wrap the gilded name of Gatsby around your own shoulders and hope to wear it with grace. The prospect is daunting  or ought to be.

title: A Solar Boom: Who Owns It?
description: Who has power in the high, sunny expanse of southern Colorados rural San Luis Valley?

title: Starting the Summer in Paris
description: Arriving in Paris the other morning on assignment, I did what most of the bleary-eyed do: I immediately checked my Blackberry to see what I had missed over the Atlantic. According to a press release, VIP guests at the Marina Abramovic dinnerthe subject of Eric Wilsons diverting dead snake threadwere dressed by Givenchy, the host, with the letters RTW or HC after each name to denote a ready to wear or haute couture wearer.

title: Corvette Plays Dress-Up: Now Isnt That Special?
description: TESTED: 2010 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport

title: Mozart: Keyboard Music, Vol. 1
Scaling Wagnerian Mountaintops
description: A SURPRISE highlight of the Metropolitan Opera season was the double triumph of the charismatic 41-year-old German tenor Jonas Kaufmann in touchstone roles of the Italian and French repertories. In April major cast changes came to two new productions that had been introduced in the fall: Luc Bondys Tosca, with Mr. Kaufmann taking over as an impassioned Cavaradossi, and Richard Eyres Carmen, with Mr. Kaufmann as a vocally elegant but wildly volatile Don Jos.

title: Indiana Revokes License of Kruse Auction House
description: KRUSE INTERNATIONAL, an auction company that has been a force in collectible-car sales for nearly 40 years, has had its license revoked by the Indiana Auctioneer Commission, which also fined Kruse $70,000. The commission suspended the companys owner and auctioneer, Dean Kruse, for two years.

title: A Reunion of Le Mans Corvettes as New Version Heads to France
description: Salinas, Calif.

title: Worlds of Trouble
description: To shape the everyday happenings of the world into a good story  isnt that what novelists are supposed to do best? Yet readers must often choose between literary fiction, understood to be works of well-written but meandering prose about the real world of human relationships, and commercial fiction, fast-paced novels in which plot is everything. The literary is assumed to be cerebral and artistic, the commercial mindless and entertaining. One suspects that nobody is completely happy with this divide. So it is a joy to discover, every once in a while, a writer whose prose and plotting take something from both camps. As Ted Mooney proves in his nuanced literary thriller  The Same River Twice,  it is perfectly possible to find a novel that has it all.

title: Loves Demons
description: William Beebe, an early deep-sea explorer, once described descending into the ocean in a diving helmet like this: The moment one is submerged, the reality of the absolute apartness of this place is apparent. Thats exactly what it feels like reading Charlie Smiths hallucinatory new novel, Three Delays. A few pages in, youll feel as if youre immersed in an absolutely separate world.

title: Companies Crack Down on Defining Dependents in Benefit Plans
description: To the list of letters that produce a groan when they arrive in your mailbox  a jury duty summons, past-due tax bills  add this one: a dependent audit.

title: Before Dying Quietly, Mercury Made Some Noise
description: The Ford Motor Company called a halt to Mercury production on Wednesday, ending the 71-year history of an automobile that never quite found its place in the Ford corporate lineup. And while the larger story of Mercury may be bland fare, the winged messenger spent some brief but exciting moments in the motorsports limelight.

title: Getting Audited by Your Health Insurer
description: In Fridays Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about getting audited. But its not a tax audit. This one comes from your health insurance plan.

title: Diapers in Kindergarten?
description: Noelle Howeys son is almost 4. He is not potty-trained. And on one hand, she has visions of him 10 years down the road still obsessed with Batman and sporting Toy Story 7-themed training pants in XXL.

title: Into Africa
description: Before the rise of the Internet, before the elimination of international bureaus at magazines and newspapers, the Africa beat in the 1990s epitomized both the dangers and the romance of the foreign correspondents life. As dictators fell, tribal animosities exploded and wide areas of the continent dissolved into anarchy, a pack of reporters and photographers shuttled from bush war to coup dtat, documenting the upheaval.

title: Nadal to Face Soderling in an Intriguing Final
description: PARIS  If not for Robin Soderling, Rafael Nadal might be going for his sixth consecutive French Open title on Sunday. Instead, he is one match away from his fifth over all  only to find Soderling, the rangy, hard-hitting Swede, in his way again.

title: Letter: Kindness of Strangers
description: To the Editor: Matt Grosss piece Frugal Europe, On Foot (May 23) charmed and inspired me. I, too, love the Carpathian Mountains, though I know them better from Romania. Standing on the hill overlooking the Danube, with Budapest sprawling across the opposite bank, counts as one of the grand visual experiences in Europe, right along with Florence seen across the Arno from the Forte di Belvedere.

title: Evidence of a Virtual Gathering in Tiananmen Square
description: On Friday, as the world marks the anniversary of Chinas brutal crackdown on demonstrators in Beijings Tiananmen Square in 1989, the blog TechCrunch notes that government censorship of the Web seems to have found a new target, the social network Foursquare:

title: The 'Innocent Prisoner's Dilemma'
description: Expected to show remorse, the wrongfully convicted in America's prisons face a moral dilemma.

title: Crucible of Pain
description: Marisa Silver is one of Californias most celebrated contemporary writers, but shes never done much for its glamorous, good-life image. Her debut in The New Yorker in 2000  gold rush days on the West Coast  was a grim story about a young Los Angeles limo driver discovering a near-suffocated baby in an abandoned suitcase. Her skillful, moving 2008 novel The God of War gave us an impoverished family in a desolate, sun-blasted trailer park near the Salton Sea.

title: South Korea Asks U.N. Council to Act Against North Korea
description: SINGAPORE  South Korea has asked the United Nations Security Council to take action against North Korea over the sinking of a South Korean warship, the South Korean president said Friday.

title: Back at Work and as Contentious as Ever
description: Its nice to see that everything is back to normal in Sheldon H. Solows real estate empire.

title: In the Ballpark
description: Everyone knows that baseball players lie and cheat. But in one department, at least, they deserve credit for their transparency. Ever since the days of Babe Ruth, many ballplayers have admitted with no sense of shame that they couldnt be bothered writing their own books. title: Breaking Down Soderlings Victory

Berdych led, two sets to one, with superb serving, great shotmaking and a sliding, underspin defense that at times flustered Soderling, but he could not summon the will and energy for a final surge to win the match. Soderling regained his composure in the fourth set, and played with focus and purpose to advance to the final for the second straight year.

title: Head to Head on Energy and Climate

He neednt worry. The 160-room property is probably the most memorable example of gingerbread cottage architecture since Hansel and Gretel. Its quirky faade consists of nearly 70 irregularly stacked wooden houses fastened onto a concrete cement frame.

title: Beyond Real Time Reporting, Forecasting Future Traffic Jams

title: Should I Help Out the Ex?
description: My ex-husband and I could not revise our child-support arrangement ourselves, so we took it to court. At the hearing, my lawyer, a specialist in family law, was better prepared than his, a generalist who made numerous mistakes in preparation and presentation. The hearing officers recommendation included several large calculation errors, most in my favor. Each side has 20 days in which to report such errors. Am I ethically obligated to do so? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

title: What We Miss
description: It is one of the most famous psychological demos ever. Subjects are shown a video, about a minute long, of two teams, one in white shirts, the other in black shirts, moving around and passing basketballs to one another. They are asked to count the number of aerial and bounce passes made by the team wearing white, a seemingly simple task. Halfway through the video, a woman wearing a full-body gorilla suit walks slowly to the middle of the screen, pounds her chest, and then walks out of the frame. If you are just watching the video, its the most obvious thing in the world. But when asked to count the passes, about half the people miss it.

title: The Freegan Establishment
description: I cruised through the West Side of Buffalo last summer with a young man named Kit who was looking to acquire a house. Kit was a 20-year-old Las Vegas native who had just arrived in Buffalo. He had the look of a mountain man fresh off the trail: his face was tanned, his brow was covered in sweat and his hair was pulled back haphazardly in a ponytail. He wore a bandanna around his neck, and his shorts and T-shirt looked as if they were his only set of clothes. He was also barefoot. Kit looked poor  destitute, even  but he was very excited about a grand, old house that he had his eye on.

title: Affirmation, Etched in Vinyl

I was only 6 when he died, and most of what I knew of him came from my mother, who considered him the embodiment of evil and tried at every opportunity to turn me against him. If I was going to be able to counter her poisonous tales, I needed empirical evidence of his humanity.

title: What We Misunderstand
description: Consider an experiment economists call the ultimatum game: The experimenter gives one player, the sender, $20 to distribute between himself and another player, the receiver. An egalitarian sender might propose a split of $10 each. A more selfish sender might propose to give the receiver only $1, keeping $19 for himself. If the receiver accepts the deal, the two players collect their shares. If the receiver rejects the deal, both walk away with nothing. Were humans perfectly rational, the receiver would accept whatever is offered: even a dollar is better than nothing, right? Instead, researchers find, receivers will reject an overly lopsided deal, gladly giving up their shares just to punish the stingy senders.

title: Letter: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
description: The article on Cass Sunstein and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (May 16) suggests that the government's estimates of the value of life draw on surveys - taken at malls, among other places - that asked passers-by how much more they would need to be paid to take on a job that carried, for instance, a 1-in-10,000 risk of death.'' The standard governmental practice for over a quarter century has been to rely instead on labor-market studies that analyze data from thousands of workers. My labor-market estimates of the value of life have been used by government agencies since 1982. The article also indicates that E.P.A. regulations costing a bit more than E.P.A.'s value-of-statistical-life estimate "would be scuttled." There are many E.P.A. regulations that involve a cost per expected life saved in excess of $100 million - far above any value-of-statistical-life estimate used for benefit-cost tests. The real challenge continues to be that of striking a meaningful balance between cost and risk so that we target our life-saving resources most effectively.W. Kip ViscusiUniversity Distinguished Professor of Law, Economics and ManagementVanderbilt UniversityNashville

title: How Green Was Their AstroTurf

Felicianos version of  The Star-Spangled Banner  was slow, melancholy and achingly personal, and contained maybe three notes from the original. At the height of the anti-Vietnam War movement and urban unrest, such an unexpected stylistic choice amid the sacrosanctity of the Series was viewed as melodic defiance. In an era when the Establishment and the counterculture clashed daily, this crossroads proved surreal (though no more surreal than the Tigers rallying from 3-1 down to defeat the mighty Cardinals in seven games).
