title: At French Open, Williams Sisters Win Another Doubles Title
description: PARIS  Venus and Serena Williams remember the first time they played doubles together, more than 20 years ago, when they were superyoung, Serena said. And when they thought about it Friday, they could not stop laughing.

title: Resort Report | Yves Saint Laurent, Short and Chic
description: The Yves Saint Laurent cruise show was an uptown affair at the French Consulate General on Fifth Avenue. In a beautiful chandeliered room and set to a live string quartet, Stefano Pilati showed a sophisticated collection that deftly alluded to the 70s hey day of YSL  via the 40s. There were butterfly prints, above the knee skirts, lots of shorts and multiple shades of pink. My favorite look was an abstract design that reminded me of a mushroom alien  with just enough print for when you dont feel like wearing a floral dress.

title: Convicted of Murder as Teenager and Paroled at 41
description: DIANA ORTIZ waited in a cagelike room at the Fishkill Correctional Facility that winter morning in 2005, going over it in her head again and again. She needed to find the right words, conjure the right emotions, strike the right balance between remorse for her role in the killing of an off-duty police officer and recognition of all that she had accomplished in the 22  years since.

title: A Belmont for the Horses, and the Horseplayers
description: Does anyone remember who won the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes? Anyone know where Super Saver and Lookin at Lucky are right now? Neither will be in the starting gate at 6:32 p.m. on Saturday for the 142nd running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Afghan Peace Talks End With Plea to Combatants
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans first national peace convention concluded Friday with a direct appeal to the Taliban and other insurgents to break with Al Qaeda, while urging a series of good-will gestures from foreign governments to end detentions and bombardments and to remove Taliban leaders from a wanted list.

title: Uncommon App
description: A guilty conscience needs no accuser. The narrator of  The Tell-Tale Heart  knows this, as does Raskolnikov. But unlike them, Addison Schacht, the conflicted hero of The November Criminals, is less interested in committing a crime than solving one. And though no one in the admissions office at the University of Chicago has asked Addison to discuss the murder of his high school classmate Kevin Broadus, he uses the applications essay assignment (What is your best quality? What is your worst quality?) as a chance to get some things off his chest. The result is no tidy, eager-to-please essay but a book-length spiel  concerning, among other things, Virgils Aeneid, Holocaust jokes, dope dealing, friends with benefits, classic cinema, adolescent ennui, Latin grammar and syntax, Jewish numerology, anti-Semitism, struggles with guilt, the hypocrisy of liberal politics, race relations in the United States, the philosophical downside of living in D.C. and, oh yeah, who killed Kevin Broadus. The list of topics sometimes makes this novel, Sam Munsons first, feel a bit shaggy. But, more often, The November Criminals is both a thoughtful coming-of-age story and an engaging teenage noir. Think of it as an existential murder mystery for the stoner pre-college set  Keanu Reevess  Rivers Edge,  as written by Camus.

title: The November Criminals
description: I. You've asked me to explain what my best and worst qualities are. So let me begin by saying that it's hard, ladies and gentlemen, for me to consider myself a bad person. I mean, I experience qualms, sometimes more serious and sometimes less. Everyone, evena real champion of immorality, sees himself as good. Or as working for the good, no matter if his actions  looked at one by one  are transparently self-serving, murderous, etc. Kind of a strong argument against the value of terms like good or bad. People feel this way even now, in 1999, when we're all supposed to be repenting and wailing and gnashing our teeth. But you can't go through life without making any distinctions. And selling small-to-medium amounts of weed to safe, calm rich kids (which I spent much of my spare time these past four years doing) is not a behavior worth agonizing over. That would make it seem too important, you know? I don't even need the money.

title: Kagan on Assisted Suicide
description: During her days in the Clinton White House, Elena Kagan rarely expressed her personal opinion in writing. But when administration officials contemplated asking Congress to make assisted suicide a federal crime, she proclaimed it a fairly terrible idea.

title: Tour New York City Like a Local
description: With its many riches (cultural, culinary, historical), New York is not the easiest city to navigate. So, of course, there are a number of iPhone apps to help travelers do just that  with a local attitude.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gulf Coast and Elsewhere
description: For the first time since April 20, the news agencies have started to transmit extensive close-ups of pelicans and other oil-slicked wildlife on the Gulf of Mexico. (Putting a Face on the Gulf Oil Leak.) Charlie Riedel of The Associated Press took a series on Thursday when he accompanied Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana to East Grand Terre Island. Thats also where Win McNamee of Getty Images shot on Friday (Slide 1).

title: Obama to Name Retired General to Top Spy Post
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has picked Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr. as director of national intelligence, tapping a retired officer with decades of experience to improve coordination of the nations sprawling spy apparatus amid increasing threats at home and escalating operations abroad.

title: In the Heart and Soul of Cuba
description: Adriana Teresa is the cofounder of FotoVisura and the publisher and creative director of Visura Magazine. She curated and produced the FotoVisura Latin American Pavilion at the recent New York Photo Festival, including the show Baobabs. Though she collaborated with Raul Caibano Ercilla on the show, she has never met him face to face. All their exchanges occurred by e-mail, over limited Internet access.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The morning mail brings squeaks of worry about where to eat near Lincoln Center and the theater district, and on the upper sides of Manhattan both east and west. The wholesome patterns include parents and anniversaries. We wont be addressing either the vegans or the vegetable-phobic today!

title: The Week in Pictures, June 4
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: A Marriage Falls Victim to a Childs Disorder
description: Researchers announced this month that having a child with autism does not increase the odds that parents will divorce. It was a refutation of the commonly held  but little documented  belief that the strain of caring for an ill or challenging child regularly tears couples apart.

title: My New York: Fall Favorites
description: Notable locals share what they like to do in the city.

title: Brooklyns New Hipster Outpost
description: Cocktail lounges, dancing dens and organic restaurants are drawing the young and hip to Prospect Heights.

title: A Weekend in New York City
description: Rooftop bars and three-star Italian restaurants make the list of the citys newest hot spots.

title: A Tour of New York Cemeteries
description: See intriguing monuments, beautiful grounds and the final resting places of the rich and famous.

title: The Frugal Traveler in New York
description: Matt Gross explores the citys more affordable (and enjoyable) corners.

title: New Hotels Brighten Downtown
description: The citys gritty neighborhood is now a glossy lifestyle magazine come to life.

title: Seth Kugels Weekend Finale
description: Radio City and the famed Peter Luger Steak House make the list of activities for the author's final weekend in New York.

title: New Yorks Hidden Parks
description: These green oases offer refuge from the citys frenetic pace.

title: Urban Fishing
description: Fishermen find scores of fish along New York Citys southern coastline.

title: A Weekend in New York City
description: The latest places to stroll, shop and dine.

title: Public Spectacles | Art in Plein Air
Obama, the Oil Spill and the Chaos Perception
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is that rare politician who is also a gifted writer, and he understands the power of a good metaphor. So you had to believe, on some level at least, that the president could appreciate the poetic significance of that cloud of oil, ubiquitous on cable television all last week, spewing endlessly from a 5,000-foot-deep puncture in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Obamas administration, too, had been breached, and the accumulating cloud threatened to obscure its considerable achievements  particularly the comprehensive reforms of health care and federal education spending  as the president heads toward the halfway point in his term.

title: Hamas: The Islamic Resistance Movement
description: Stephen Farrell, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times who manages the At War blog, and Professor Beverley Milton-Edwards, of Queen's University, Belfast, trace Hamas's early roots in the Muslim Brotherhood, its creation during the opening clashes of the first Palestinian Intifada in the late 1980s and its inexorable rise to emerge as a serious rival to the Palestine Liberation Organization led by its more secular nationalist opponent, Fatah.

title: Putting a Face on the Gulf Oil Leak
description: The oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico finally has a face.

title: When Soros Decided to Go for the Jugular
description: With the euro falling below $1.20 on Friday, it seems like a good time to recall the bear raid on the British pound that the billionaire hedge fund manager George Soros made in 1992.

title: Former Time Executive Buys Ziff Davis
description: Vivek Shah, a former Time Inc. executive, has bought Ziff Davis, the media company that operates nine technology sites, including PCMag.com.

title: Immigrant Convicted of Breaking Trade Sanctions on Iran
description: An Iranian immigrant who said he came to the United States to live the American dream was convicted on Friday of violating American trade sanctions on Iran by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move money between Iran and the United States. Hawala dates back hundreds of years and operates outside normal banking channels.

title: Shopaholic Confessions
description: In 1883, mile Zola warned that in the department store, then emerging as a hallmark of modern Paris, church doctrine had been replaced by the religion of the cash register. Even in todays challenging economic environment, a saunter through any luxury shopping emporium confirms the accuracy of this view. So too does Linda Grants Thoughtful Dresser, a zealous affirmation of the consumerist creed: Im entitled. Entitled to be walking along Bond Street and entitled to go inside Herms and inquire the length of the waiting list for a Birkin handbag. An English writer whose novel The Clothes on Their Backs was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize in 2008, Grant has no use for the spiritual counterargument: Better people than myself might sit under the great dome of St. Pauls and contemplate God and infinity. Good luck to them. For her money, shopping is the ultimate balm for the troubled soul, even when times are tough. Because in a recession the last thing I want to feel is depressed, and depressed I would feel if I was wearing dreary, cheap clothes. . . . You need to buy now the costumes you will need for the impoverished future.

title: Hamas, Israel and Gaza: No Way Out?
The Week in Culture Pictures, June 6
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: For Mickey Kaus, Winning Isnt the Point
description: Los Angeles

title: Ailing Ozawa Cancels Europe Tour
description: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who has been undergoing treatment for esophageal cancer, has canceled a weeklong tour in Europe with the Saito Kinen Orchestra to conserve his strength for performances in Carnegie Hall in December, a representative said on Friday. Mr. Ozawa was to have performed in Prague, Vienna, Berlin and Paris from Dec. 3 to Dec. 10 before opening Carnegies Japan NYC festival with the orchestra on Dec. 14. He said: Cancel Europe, Ive got to go to Carnegie,  Ronald Wilford, his manager, said on Friday. Thats a tough tour, Mr. Wilford added. Thats why he said no. Carnegie is absolutely right on. Mr. Ozawa is artistic director of the Carnegie festival. He is also principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Cape Town, Johannesburg, Port Elizabeth, Durban and Pretoria are among the nine host cities expecting hundreds of thousands of tourists for the World Cup in South Africa next week. Meet residents of these five cities, who offer their own personal mini-guides on where to shop, eat, and enjoy a night on the town.

title: Obama Allies Start Health Care Push
description: Close allies of the Obama administration, seeking to rally the public behind President Obamas landmark health care bill, are planning to spend $25 million over the next five years to promote the measure and beat back mischaracterizations of it that could harm Democratic candidates.

title: Actress Apologizes for Remark
description: Kristen Stewart, right, has apologized for comparing the swarm of paparazzi around her to a rape. In an interview in the British edition of Elle magazine, Ms. Stewart, the 20-year-old star of the Twilight movies, described her feelings about being pursued by photographers, saying, What you dont see are the cameras shoved in my face and the bizarre intrusive questions being asked, or the people falling over themselves, screaming and taunting to get a reaction. She added, The photos are so  I feel like Im looking at someone being raped. Her remarks drew wide criticism online since becoming public on Wednesday, and while in South Korea promoting her latest film, The Twilight Saga: Eclipse, she apologized for her word choice. I really made an enormous mistake  clearly and obviously, she said, in an interview published on People.com on Friday. And Im really sorry about my choice of words.

title: Basketball Helps ABC
description: Pro basketball and a special prime-time edition of Jimmy Kimmel Live lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday night. Although Nielsens final numbers for the game were not immediately available, early estimates for Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals were up 17 percent from the first night of the series last year, when 13 million viewers tuned in. Before the game, ABC began the night on a high note, earning 7.6 million viewers at 8 for a basketball-themed Jimmy Kimmel Live. Meanwhile, Fox averaged 8.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a two-hour So You Think You Can Dance. That reality competition easily outperformed repeats on CBS to make Fox runner-up for the night, behind ABC. NBC was in fourth place, with reruns of its comedy line-up struggling to top 3 million viewers.

title: Baitz Moves Play Off Broadway
description: Citing the current Broadway imperative of casting star actors, the playwright Jon Robin Baitz, below, said on Friday that he had decided to move his latest work, Other Desert Cities (formerly titled Love and Mercy), from Broadways lineup for the 2010-11 season and instead have the work produced at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Jeffrey Richards  who had been one of the producers for the play on Broadway  cited Mr. Baitzs comfort with that theater, which, at 299 seats, is about half the size of the smallest Broadway houses. The Newhouse was also home to productions of other Baitz plays. The Tony Award-winning director Joe Mantello (Take Me Out, Assassins) will direct Other Desert Cities, which is scheduled to begin preview performances on Dec. 16 and open on Jan. 13, a spokesman for Lincoln Center Theater said on Friday. In a telephone interview Mr. Baitz said he had decided that the familiar scale and trappings of the Newhouse were a better fit for both him and for the play. Im very comfortable there at Lincoln Center, Mr. Baitz said.

title: Male Swan to Return
description: Part cartoon, part spoof of the British royal family and part lyric poem is how Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times described Matthew Bournes Swan Lake in a 1998 review of Mr. Bournes reinterpretation of the ballet classic featuring a male corps. She added, It may not be as spectacular or profound as the 19th-century original, but it is a polished entertainment, clever in its choreography and uninhibited in its tender moments. Now the Tony Award-winning production will return to New York for a limited run from Oct. 13 to Nov. 7 at City Center. Tickets for the performances, produced by City Center, Sadlers Wells Theater of London and Back Row Productions, will go on sale on Monday.

title: Graphic Bullying
description: Beyond the fight for truth, justice and the American way, comic books have tackled issues far and wide: prejudice, drug abuse, world hunger and more. Dark Horse Books, a division of Dark Horse Comics, is adding school bullies to that roster. In October the company will publish Heart Transplant, by Andrew Vachss, about a teenager who is tormented in junior high school. Mr. Vachss, the author of a series of novels about Burke, an ex-con turned private eye, is also a lawyer with a focus on child abuse. Heart Transplant is illustrated by Frank Caruso and includes an essay by Zak Mucha, a social worker, who examines the bullying phenomenon and the effect on its victims.

title: Promoters Scramble as Bklyn Yard Loses Its Lease
description: The Bklyn Yard, above, an outdoor arts and performance space along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is shutting down. For four years it held concerts by big indie names, including Dan Deacon and Jos Gonzlez, and was a home for Sunday Best, a popular dance party. But in an announcement on Friday on the Yards Web site (bklynyard.com), MeanRed, the promoter behind the concerts, said it had lost its lease for the space. The Yard opened its season last weekend and had announced a full series of concerts and other events through Labor Day. In a telephone interview, Justin Carter, an independent promoter who organizes Sunday Best, said the news had caught him by surprise. This Sundays show, he said, would be moved to Littlefield, a club at 622 Degraw Street in Carroll Gardens that has served as its rain site, but after that plans werent clear.

title: Phantom Now Available for School Licensing
description: All of those drama clubs with a spare chandelier, organ and motorized boat  not to mention enough playing space for a subterranean lair  are now in luck: The Phantom of the Opera is available, for the first time, for productions at high schools and colleges in the United States and Canada, the licensing executives for the musical announced. Until now Phantom has not been available for performances by any groups or producers beyond the 24-year-old Andrew Lloyd Webber/Cameron Mackintosh production that has played in London, New York and Las Vegas and toured cities around the world. R & H Theatricals, the licensing arm of the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, which is handling Phantom, did authorize four American high schools and two colleges to mount pilot productions in 2007-8  essentially to test-drive the Broadway/London script at a school level. A spokesman for the licensing division said the pilot productions had been deemed successful. Applications for the show are being accepted for performances beginning Sept. 1.

title: Not Just Another Subdivision for Developable Estates
description: Old Westbury

title: In Low-Key Buffalo, a New-Music Milestone
description: BUFFALO  This city may not seem as glamorous a place for a summer new-music festival as Tanglewood in Massachusetts or Ojai in California, and puzzlingly, the University at Buffalo does relatively little to promote the annual June in Buffalo festival, which the composer Morton Feldman founded in 1975.

title: The Great Outdoors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Connoisseur of Cast-Offs
description: OF the many keepsakes in Roberto Garcias apartment in the Longwood section of the South Bronx, he is especially proud of the refinished oak dresser in his bedroom, a piece he grew up with.

title: Forest Hills Gardens, Queens
description: LIVING in Forest Hills Gardens, a tucked-away hamlet in central Queens, wasnt difficult for John Hazleton, who knew he wanted to move in when he first stepped into Station Square and saw a sea of red roofs and abundant greenery. Ernest Bristol, another resident, wanted to be near Manhattan but also the fresh air of Forest Park, while Ruby Ross Goodnow appreciated the chance to have a well-built house, nice neighbors, and her own garden and dogwood trees.

title: At the Ardsley, Art Deco the Way It Was
description: THE lobby of the Ardsley, a co-op on Central Park West at 92nd Street, is ready for its close-up. The designer Scott Salvator spent about two years restoring the buildings Art Deco interior  a series of spaces totaling about 4,000 square feet  before declaring the job complete. Though the work was largely finished over a year ago, Mr. Salvator wasnt happy until a mirrored wall constructed off-kilter was rebuilt and paint-splattered curtains were replaced.

title: How to Be a Brainy Renter
description: EVERYONE has heard a nightmare story of a newbie in Manhattans crazed rental market: the crooked brokers, the bait-and-switch online advertisements, the cajoling landlords, the thousands of dollars spent  and sometimes lost  in deposits.

title: An Apartment for Under $1,500, or Bust
description: WHEN Jen Rosenbaum told her colleagues that she was determined to find an apartment for just $1,200 to $1,500 a month, they laughed. Clearly, she was on a fools errand. My co-workers said it is not going to happen, you are insane, she said.

title: Richard Meier
description: Mr. Meier, 75, is the managing partner of Richard Meier & Partners Architects and a recipient of the Pritzker Architecture Prize.

title: In Westchester, the Sales Pace for High-End Houses Picks Up
description: IN Westchester, well known for its pricey homes and estates in sought-after locales like Bedford and Chappaqua, many buyers and sellers are wondering whether the high-end sector of the real estate market is rebounding  or still mired in the downturn that took hold two years ago and has been slow to let go.

title: Occupant Was Here
description: To the Editor:

title: The 20-Year Mortgage Alternative
description: MOST people who took out jumbo mortgages during the financial crisis got hit with high interest rates as lenders and investors recoiled from anything that seemed even remotely risky. Now that market conditions have improved, some of these borrowers are looking to refinance into lower-rate mortgages, but they may not want to start over with a 30-year loan.

title: A Rising Tide in Waterfront Values
description: ON the waterfront, at least, it appears the dense clouds covering real estate property values have dissipated.

title: Chic in Review | The Suri Cruise Effect
description: Bastian, MichaelWill soon add womens line to his collection with Gant. Yippee.

title: About That Coloring Book in the Kagan Files
description: Elena Kagan may well have learned to color inside the lines as a Clinton aide.

title: Spiriting Through in Many Languages
description: When the jazz singer Stacey Kent softens her sharp tangy voice to croon a ballad like Corcovado (the whispery Jobim standard known in English as Quiet Nights), a wonderful transformation takes place. Her metallic vocal edge melts, her phrasing relaxes, and her suppressed vibrato begins to quiver.

title: Block Parties, Bake Sales, Superspies and Assassins
description: Unless youre trapped on an airplane or enjoying movie night at the penitentiary, you have no excuse for watching Killers. A brain-deadening collision of high concept and low standards, this frenetic time waster from Robert Luketic requires Ashton Kutcher to play a superspy and Katherine Heigl to play  well, the same bubbly-sexy-anxious chick she always plays. Guess who succeeds.

title: Why Cameron Is Diving Deep on Gulf Oil
description: James Cameron, best known as one of the worlds most successful filmmakers, this week found himself slammed in some circles for pulling together a brain trust of underwater technology experts to provide advice to the Obama administration for next steps in the unfolding Gulf of Mexico petro-calamity.

title: Hewing to Tradition, Straining Against Limits
description: Sachal Vasandani seemed to want to take requests for his encore at Joes Pub on Wednesday night, but consensus proved elusive. So after some dithering, he left the choice to his pianist, Jeb Patton, who picked I Remember You. That standard had been faintly foreshadowed, to anyone paying attention: Mr. Vasandani interposed its melody during his set closer, briefly planting Johnny Mercers lyrics in unfamiliar soil.

title: Venerable British Museum Enlists in the Wikipedia Revolution
description: The British Museum has begun an unusual collaboration with Wikipedia, the online, volunteer-written encyclopedia, to help ensure that the museums expertise and notable artifacts are reflected in that digital references pages.

title: Inside-Out Lamb Persillade
description: Mark Bittman updates a classic lamb dish.

title: Leg of Lamb With Kick
description: I LIKE rack of lamb but think its overrated, one of those luxury (that is, expensive) meats that, like tenderloin of beef (whence filet mignon comes), is far less flavorful, indeed less enjoyable, than almost all the supposedly lesser cuts from the same animal. So I figured there had to be a better way to employ persillade  a combination of parsley and garlic  than to smear it on top of a rack.

title: Using Parsley and Garlic to Flavor Lamb
description: Persillade, the combination of (mostly) parsley and garlic, has many uses. My favorite: stuffing a boneless leg of lamb. I explain how in this weeks Minimalist column.

title: Sending an Old Dreamer Airborne
description: Dancing as Kitri in Don Quixote on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Natalia Osipova proved herself the most sensational ballerina now before the public. Kitri was the first major role for which Ms. Osipova  a Russian star of the Bolshoi Ballet, now in her second spring season as guest artist with American Ballet Theater earned international acclaim. Its clear why. She has a gamine quality; you can imagine this Kitri as the most riveting of street urchins. And shes a theater animal. The turn of her head, the flash of her smile, the immediacy of her response to the music, the intensity of her attention to her colleagues: these and other signs show she is never more alive than onstage.

title: The Same River Twice
description: Chapter 1

title: M.T.A. Broke Law With Layoffs, Judge Rules
description: In the latest back-and-forth over the legality of the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys layoffs of hundreds of subway station agents, a judge ruled Friday that the authority violated the law when it closed booths and laid off about 260 agents last month without holding public hearings.

title: Avery Likes an Underdog
description: The Rangers bad boy Sean Avery, who had 11 goals and 20 assists this season, took a crack at handicapping the Belmont Stakes on The Rail. He sided with the underdog, picking the 20-1 shot Stay Put to win. Stay Put won at Churchill Downs on Kentucky Derby day.

title: Student Debt and a Push for Fairness
description: If you run up big credit card bills buying a new home theater system and cant pay it off after a few years, bankruptcy judges can get rid of the debt. They may even erase loans from a casino.

title: From France, Works of Fanfare and Gentle Majesty
description: You might have expected the New York Philharmonic to sound at least a little weary when it took the Avery Fisher Hall stage on Thursday night. Last week many of these musicians were achieving audacious heights in Gyorgy Ligetis demanding operatic farce, Le Grand Macabre. On Monday evening, the orchestra presented its annual Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Thursdays program required rehearsals, one open to the public on Thursday morning.

title: Why Bankruptcy Wont Rid You of Student Loans
description: This weeks Your Money column is about the treatment of student loans in the federal bankruptcy code and whether this treatment ought to change. Currently, its nearly impossible for people to get rid of student loans in bankruptcy court, even though people in over their heads with credit card or gambling debts can often discharge those loans.

title: Motion Filed for Injunction Against LimeWire
description: The Recording Industry Association of America late Friday afternoon filed a motion for a permanent injunction against LimeWire, the file-sharing service found liable for copyright infringement in May.

title: Honey, Ive Got a Scene to Do. Be Right Back.
description: In the Broadway farce Lend Me a Tenor, Jan Maxwell as the jealous wife Maria Merelli, spends 30 minutes onstage during the two-and-a-half-hour show, throwing tantrums in heavily accented Italian. The rest of the time, Ms. Maxwell reverts to her soft-spoken though still pointed self backstage, as she keeps an eye on her 14-year-old son, Will Maxwell-Lunney, who spends most performances doing his homework in her dressing room.

title: AT&T Seems a Little Greedy
description: Thursday, I wrote about AT&Ts new Internet-service plans for iPhones and other smartphones. Instead of $30 for unlimited Internet use, new customers will be asked to choose between two limited-data plans: $15 for 200 megabytes a month, or $25 for 2 gigabytes. I noted that most people will save money with the new plans, sometimes lots of it. (Existing customers can keep the $30 unlimited plan if they like, even if they get new phones.)

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 6
description: More Photographs

title: Caesar Salad With True Flavor
description: IT must be my inner masochist that compels me to order Caesar salads over and over. No matter how many times Ive been disappointed by soggy croutons, bland mayonnaise dressing and a dearth of garlic and anchovies, I persist, hoping that one day Ill meet a salad that lives up to my expectations.

title: After Sleeping In, a Two-Wheel Tour
description: Kelly Cutrone, 44, is the founder of the public relations firm Peoples Revolution and, most recently, the star of the Bravo reality show Kell on Earth. The show chronicles her busy days at work, where she curses out bumbling interns in long bleep-filled rants, and at home in SoHo, where she is a single mother of an 8-year-old daughter, Ava. She visits the home she rents in Cold Spring, N.Y., as often as she can on the weekends, but Sundays in the city are not uncommon.

title: In Rome, Newsstands as Mini-Malls (and Unlikely Architectural Wonders)
description: ROME  Theyre not exactly Borrominis or Berninis. But some of the newsstands around here, in their crazy, Collyer Brothers fashion, have come to look almost as baroque.

title: Dancers Move on Foot; Audiences Travel by Bus
description: In longing two, a journey for the body and the mind, the choreographer Donna Uchizono finds the distance in closeness, and intimacy where it seems as if there were miles separating the viewer and the dancer.

title: So Sunny and Blonde and Young at Heart
description: With her sweet, soft voice that coos and dips in jazzy loops and spirals, blond hair that cascades about her face in ringlets and a wide-eyed Alice in Wonderland zest for adventure, Nellie McKay exudes the carefree spirit of a precocious child skipping through a meadow on a sunny afternoon. It is an ideal persona for conjuring the essence of Doris Day, to whom Ms. McKay pays delicious, heartfelt homage in Normal as Blueberry Pie: A Tribute to Doris Day, her debut at Feinsteins at Loews Regency.

title: A Little Quantum Science to Go Along With the Leotards and Point Shoes
description: Whats the more intractable problem, the conflict between quantum mechanics and the theory of general relativity, or the difficulty of finding an elegant meeting of ballet and modern dance?

title: The Week in Pictures for June 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a new United States citizen, a mothers grief and teachers night at the Apollo.

title: Two Endplays, Not One, Make a Contract
description: The Sunday Swiss Teams at the Eastern States Regional in New York City last week was won by Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; Greg McKellar (Archs nephew) from Kingston, Ontario; Michael Lipkin of New York City; and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.

title: Proposed Closings of City-Subsidized Facilities
description: Map of facilities that may be closed due to budget cuts.

title: Grilling and Grinning at the N.F.L. Party
description: Hey, welcome to our N.F.L. party. Glad you could make it. Before we check out the pool and patio, let me show you around. You thirsty? Rex Ryan is mixing drinks; practically everyone here has taken a shot from the guy. Ryans already declared himself to be the life of the party  the all-time life of the party, in fact.

title: G.M.s Gift of a Luxury Car Stuns a Few
description: DETROIT  A free sports car for a Detroit Tigers baseball player was not among the reasons the government saved General Motors from financial collapse. Nor was a years supply of diapers and other gifts for a Minnesota woman who gave birth behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Cobalt.

title: I Spied Your Red Heart (Tattoo Mine?)
description: Tattoos will get you noticed  often by members of the opposite sex. The following poems about tattoos were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: INDIESCREEN, an independent movie house on Kent Avenue, could probably devote itself full time to running the works of all those Williamsburg indie filmmakers. Marco Ursino, a co-owner, said the lineup would include a mix of revivals, new indies and selections of older ones that he has accumulated as the organizer of the Brooklyn International Film Festival. The 10-day festival began Friday at the Brooklyn Heights Cinema and had its first events at indieScreen on Saturday.

title: We Are LeBron
description: Cleveland personalities came together to sing an ode to the basketball player LeBron James in an effort to keep him in the city.

title: Tony Who?
description: Q. The Tony Awards will be held next Sunday. So who was Tony?

title: Kicking Off Summer on the Jersey Shore
description: Roommates pile into a Belmar, N.J., beach house over the Memorial Day weekend to begin a summer of sand, tans and beer pong.

title: With Drilling Stopped, Losses Could Multiply
description: Chett Chiasson, the executive director of Port Fourchon in Louisiana, has a message for President Obama  and any Americans who have applauded the administrations decision to halt deep-water drilling in the Gulf of Mexico: You just dont get it.

title: Summer Rituals | Down South With Family
description: Spending the summer with relatives gives a 10-year-old girl from Brooklyn a taste of rural life and a peek at her familys roots.

title: Where the Party Is Perpetual
description: Belmar, N.J.

title: A Gay Catholic Voice Against Same-Sex Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  I spent the summer before college reading Shakespeare and staring out the window and occasionally being a roadie for my friends band, says Eve Tushnet, the celibate, gay, conservative, Catholic writer. That was all good fun, she says upon meeting in Union Station, but she was ready for more, although she knew not what. I was hoping for something very different in college.

title: Research on Uncovering the Mystery of Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Ratings and Risk, as Seen by Standard & Poors
description: To the Editor:

title: Day 45: The Latest on the Oil Spill
description: Cap on Ruptured Well Captures Some Oil

title: Gay Marriage Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Two New Putters That Are Worth a Look
description: There is no piece of golf equipment more personal, more like a relationship, than the association of putter and golfer. Most people go through dozens of putters in a lifetime. Some pros go through hundreds. Some players are a little more faithful. My colleague Dave Anderson, who is a very good putter, has used the same flat stick for decades.

title: Plenty of Reasons to Leave the House
description: THE flip of the calendar to June is a sign that family outing season is right around the corner, with New Jersey public schools letting out later this month. Following are some ideas for day trips, or even half-day trips, with entertainment-starved, math-homework-weary children:

title: Bell Rings Again at Yankee Stadium
description: Fistiana, in all its raffish glory, is back in Yankee Stadium. It took almost 34 years from the chaos of the last boxing card to bring the tradition back to the Bronx night air, but late on Saturday the junior middleweight champion Yuri Foreman will defend his title against Miguel Cotto, a former welterweight champion.

title: When Bing Was King
description: AS a music-loving teenager from Massapequa, Ray Osnato haunted antiques shops and the offices of music publishers in Manhattan looking for original band arrangements from the era he loved most  the 1920s and 1930s, when the syncopated rhythms of jazz insinuated themselves into the previously staid sounds of society dance music.

title: A Festival That Caters to Body and Mind
description: YOU could hear Philip Glass play piano solos next Sunday night at Sprague Memorial Hall in New Haven. You could see Conor Lovett (of Gare St. Lazare Players Ireland) do Moby-Dick as a one-man show at the Long Wharf Theater the following week. You could, on various days, take a tour of artworks by Connecticuts own Sol LeWitt. And on June 19, on New Haven Green, you could see a free concert by the Blind Boys of Alabama.

title: Is the Embargo Good for the Jews?
description: Its been a good week to stay out of the water, and those who got too close paid the price  President Obamas situation in the Gulf of Mexico just getting stickier, former President George W. Bush got a little too casual about waterboarding, and the world discovered that Israels vaunted special forces cannot walk on water after all.

title: What New York Needs: More Water Taxis
description: From waters edge you can cross the Hudson River  or the East River, as you prefer  in less time than it often takes to wait for the subway. Even at the height of rush hour, youll get a seat, quite likely one near a window. From out on the water, the city you think you know will seem taller, more glamorous, more cinematic.

title: Parole for Police Officers Killer
description: A state parole board has voted to release a man who has served 35 years in state prison for the killing of a New York City police officer in 1973, the authorities said Friday.

title: Tag Sale Is Fake; Poster Is a Roz Chast Artwork
description: THERES something amiss with certain tag-sale posters tacked up in Fairfield County. For one thing, the address listed is nonexistent. For another, the image bears an uncanny resemblance to a New Yorker cartoon.

title: Pope Names Bishop
description: Pope Benedict XVI has named the Rev. David OConnell, who just stepped down after 12 years as president of the Catholic University of America, to be the next bishop of Trenton, a diocese with about 800,000 Roman Catholics. Father OConnell, a priest with the Vincentian religious order and a frequent commentator on Catholic issues, will succeed Bishop John M. Smith.

title: Political Survivor Inherits Japans List of Troubles
description: TOKYO

title: A Show in Which One Color Will Do
description: With their quiet simplicity, Robert Rymans paintings are a welcome contrast to the content overload of much contemporary art, although those who subscribe to the my grandchild could have done this school of art criticism might find it hard to appreciate the aesthetic merits of white paint smeared on a canvas. But there is another school of criticism, generally referred to as formalism, that says painting about painting is a valid avenue of artistic inquiry.

title: Qaeda Leaders in Iraq Neutralized, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Iraqi and American forces have killed or captured 34 of the top 42 leaders of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, cutting off the terrorist organization from its foreign sponsors and raising questions about whether it can reconstitute, the senior American commander in Iraq said.

title: Tying Memorial Record With Look of a Winner
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Until now, the temptation regarding the rookie Rickie Fowler has been to focus on the externals  the flat-billed skater hat pulled down over his flowing locks, the form-fitting clothes in an array of hues, the faster-than-a-thought swing, his 21-year-old swagger-with-a-smile demeanor.

title: Nearly Perfect in Detroit
description: Detroit

title: Blue Jays Trying to Keep Momentum
description: Even without Roy Halladay, its longtime ace, Toronto has managed to stay competitive this season in the American League East. As the Blue Jays prepared to meet the Yankees for the first time in 2010, they can feel proud of a surprising 31-24 record that has them tied with Boston for third place in the division, with New York within hailing distance in second.

title: Sneakers in the Trash Were Made for Recycling
description: I know perfectly well, Cynthia Magnus said, that garbage is not glamorous.

title: We Are LeBron
description: Comparing Cleveland's and New York's video campaigns to assess why each city would be a worthier place for LeBron James.

title: On the Street | Making Memories at Coney
description: A new era starts with the opening of Luna Park, as the landmark Cyclone and the boardwalk still provide plenty of thrills.

title: Batteries Power New Talk of Cheating in Cycling
description: Cyclings long history with doping means that any dramatic victory is as likely to create suspicion as admiration. But the whispers surrounding Fabian Cancellaras decisive wins in two of this springs most important races have a novel twist: they accuse him of using a tiny electric motor to help power his legs.

title: The Spill and Energy Bill
description: The nations political leaders have had a lot to say in recent years about Americas addiction to fossil fuels and the need to find cleaner, more climate-friendly alternatives. In recent weeks, they have had a lot to say about the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. On Wednesday, President Obama put them together.

title: Luring a Star: Big City Beckons; Cleveland Begs
description: In the front row, Ted Strickland, the governor of Ohio, croons into the microphone, shoulder to shoulder with Dick Goddard, the ageless Cleveland weatherman. Around them on a soundstage, a chorus chimes in plaintively: city clerks, radio personalities, blues musicians, the ponytailed Norton Furniture pitchman Marc Brown.

title: Turkeys Fury
description: Turkey is understandably furious about Israels disastrous attack on the Turkish-flagged aid ship that tried to run the Gaza blockade. Eight Turks and a Turkish-American died. Turkeys demands for the release of detained activists (all are now free) and for an international investigation (Israel is balking ) are reasonable.

title: Conferences Consider Expansion, Not Tradition
description: The Big Ten and Pac-10 Conferences have always clung to their traditional roots with white-knuckle fervor. They have gone to great lengths  at the expense of a college football playoff system  to make sure that their champions play in the Rose Bowl.

title: Justice Souters Counsel
description: Two recent moments have brought to mind Chief Justice John Robertss simplistic description of a Supreme Court justice as an umpire who confines himself to calling balls and strikes. The first was the reminder in Detroit on Wednesday night that umpires are highly fallible, and their calls subjective, even when something as important as Armando Galarragas nearly perfect game is at stake.

title: Bring On the Primaries
description: Here is the most basic rule about primaries: more choice is better for voters. Yet in New York State, such competition is pitifully rare. And in the last two weeks, New Yorkers have seen how antiquated election laws discourage primary candidates from healthy competition. Even when some party leaders decide they want a free for all  as Democrats and Republicans both attempted in the last two weeks  New Yorks convoluted election code conspires to make that almost impossible.

title: Tempting Area for Exaggeration Meets Tools of the YouTube Era
description: WASHINGTON  It happened again. Another candidate for office is struggling to reconcile misleading statements he made about his record in the military. This time, it is Representative Mark Kirk, a Republican from Illinois running for the Senate, apologizing for misleading statements he made about, among other things, serving in the first Iraq war and in Kosovo.

title: Immigrant Convicted of Violating Iran Embargo
description: An Iranian immigrant who said he came to the United States to live the American dream was convicted on Friday of violating the Iran trade embargo by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move millions of dollars between the United States and Iran.

title: Airlines Work to Catch Up to the Digital Age
description: Airlines have made great technological leaps in recent years, allowing passengers to check in from home or download boarding passes on their smartphones. But if youve ever been stranded at an airport during a raging thunderstorm, chances are you will end up standing in a long line watching a gate agent typing furiously on an outdated computer.

title: Day After Day, the Agony in the Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Plans for Ground-Floor Bar Make Residents Hit Roof
description: The Central Park West Caf, depending on whom you ask, would be either a serene wine bar with a Duke Ellington ambience or a rowdy, ear-splitting, velvet-roped nightclub.

title: Disaster in the Amazon
description: BPs calamitous behavior in the Gulf of Mexico is the big oil story of the moment. But for many years, indigenous people from a formerly pristine region of the Amazon rainforest in Ecuador have been trying to get relief from an American company, Texaco (which later merged with Chevron), for what has been described as the largest oil-related environmental catastrophe ever.

title: Pelicans, Back From Brink of Extinction, Face Oil Threat
description: FORT JACKSON, La.  For more than a decade, the hundreds of brown pelicans that nested among the mangrove shrubs on Queen Bess Island west of here were living proof that a species brought to the edge of extinction could come back and thrive.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 4, 2010

title: Elections Arent for Sissies
description: Loads of exciting primaries next week! Although itll be hard to top the one in South Carolina, where two Tea Party candidates are fighting about a lie detector test and a state senator has argued that racist comments he made over the radio dont really count since the interview occurred in a bar.

title: Rise in Suicides of Middle-Aged Is Continuing
description: For the second year in a row, middle-aged adults have registered the highest suicide rate in the country, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Days of Planning Led to Flotillas Hour of Chaos
description: ISTANBUL  It was just getting light when the Turkish boat, packed with 546 activists, descended into chaos, and Mahmut Coskun, a Turkish doctor on board, was in the middle of it.

title: Israel Faces Deepening Tensions With Turkey Over Raid, and Bond With U.S. Frays
description: WASHINGTON  Tensions deepened between Turkey and Israel on Friday, and a new fissure threatened to open between the United States and Israel, as the three countries continued to deal with the fallout from Israels deadly raid on a humanitarian aid flotilla off Gaza.

title: Bloggingheads: Israel, Pariah?
description: Robert Farley, left, of the University of Kentucky and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com discuss the international fallout from Israel's flotilla raid.

title: Indias Young and Poor Rally to Another Gandhi
description: AHRAURA, India  Rahul Gandhis helicopter descends out of the boiling afternoon sky and a restless, sweat-soaked crowd of 100,000 people suddenly surges to life. Men rush forward in the staggering heat. Teenage boys wave a white bedsheet bearing a faintly cheeky request: We Want to Meet the Prince of India.

title: African States Weigh 50 Years of Independence
description: DAKAR, Senegal  In a fancy resort on the French Riviera this week, limousines bearing African leaders gathered at the doorstep of Frances president for the France-Africa Summit, a time-honored ritual involving pledges of mutual love and, not surprisingly, some backbiting.

title: Budget Cuts Hit a Brooklyn Area Over and Over
description: Christina Nievess life revolves around a handful of blocks in Brooklyn: Drop off her 4-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son at the Strong Place day care center. Make sure her 75-year-old grandmother, who uses a wheelchair, makes it to lunch at the Gowanus Senior Center. Then, on too many occasions to count, take her son, who is asthmatic and prone to seizures, to the Wyckoff childrens clinic.

title: Cigarette Makers and Retailers Sue to Block Rule Requiring Antismoking Posters
description: The nations three big tobacco companies, and trade associations representing hundreds of New York City bodegas and convenience stores, are challenging the citys latest salvo in the antismoking wars: graphic images of diseased brains, lungs and teeth that are posted where cigarettes are sold.

title: In Hours Before Bouts, Another Test of Strength
description: Brad Jacobs is remarkably calm for someone in charge of the 200 workers feverishly setting up a boxing ring, a 60-foot-high canopy and 6,000 folding chairs on the field in Yankee Stadium. Never mind that the installation is about four hours behind schedule and a slate of fights, including a headline bout between Miguel Cotto and Yuri Foreman, is just a day away.

title: What Were Reading: Zuckerbergs Hoodie
description: Heres a selection of what the tech editors and reporters have been reading this week.Zuckerbergs Bizarre Facebook Insignia Revealed, And What It Means  blogs.sfweekly.comNick Bilton says: Mark Zuckebergs hoodie has a bizarre insignia inside; heres what it looks like.Official Google Blog: Hello from the Hiveplex  googleblog.blogspot.comNick Bilton says: Googlers decide search isnt enough. Now theyre making honey, too, installing Google beehives.

title: Irans Supreme Leader Assails Opposition
description: Days before the first anniversary of the antigovernment protests that rocked Iran, the nations supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, renewed his attack on opposition leaders on Friday, saying that they had betrayed the values of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

title: United Nations: More Police Officers for Haiti
Glimpses of Kagans Views in Clinton White House
description: WASHINGTON  A new cache of documents from Elena Kagans days as an adviser to President Bill Clinton shows that she frequently scribbled notes in the margins of memorandums yet rarely expressed forceful views. But on at least one question that came before the Clinton White House  whether to make assisted suicide a federal crime  Ms. Kagan was adamant.

title: France: Minister Guilty of Making Racist Comments
description: A French cabinet minister who is a close friend of President Nicolas Sarkozy faced fresh calls for his resignation on Friday after a Paris court found him guilty of making racist remarks. Interior Minister Brice Hortefeux was fined $900 and asked to pay an antiracism group $2,400 in damages for what the judge called private insults of a racial nature. Mr. Hortefeux was caught on video at an event in September making comments that were widely perceived as anti-Arab. He will appeal the ruling, said his lawyer, Nicolas Benoit.

title: Zambia: Editor Sentenced for Opinion Piece
description: Fred Mmembe, the editor of The Post, a newspaper highly critical of the government, was sentenced on Friday to four months of hard labor for contempt of court. The charge stems from his decision to publish a commentary by a Zambian lawyer, Muna Ndulo, who is based in the United States. The opinion piece concerned the prosecution of another Post editor, Chansa Kabwela, and appeared last December during her trial. Ms. Kabwela, who was charged with distributing pornography after publishing a photo of a woman in childbirth, was later found not guilty. In 1995, Mr. Mmembe received the International Press Freedom Award bestowed by The Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: China: Calligraphy Scroll Is Sold for $64 Million
description: A scroll of classical calligraphy dating back almost one millennium has been sold at an auction in Beijing for $64 million, which appears to be the largest amount ever paid at auction for a single piece of Chinese art, according to reports on Friday by several official Chinese news organizations. The calligraphy was done around 1095 by Huang Tingjian, a leading scholar and poet of the Song dynasty. The auction was held on Thursday by the Poly Group, which has a vast historic art collection and is one of the largest art auction houses in China. The buyer of the artwork remained anonymous. There was no independent confirmation of the record set during the auction. One report said the previous record amount paid at auction for a piece of Chinese art was $34 million, for a Yuan dynasty vase sold in 2005 at an auction in London.

title: Former Manager at Time Inc. Buys Ziff Davis
description: Vivek Shah, a former Time Inc. executive, has bought Ziff Davis, the media company that operates nine technology Web sites, including PCMag.com.

title: Czech Republic: Talks Toward a New Government
description: President Vaclav Klaus on Friday asked the leader of the center-right Civic Democrat party, Petr Necas, to lead talks on forming the next government, after three center-right parties cumulatively won the most votes in elections last weekend. The three parties won a combined 118 seats in the 200-member lower house. If they can form a government, the parties would have a strong mandate to enact changes they promised during the election campaign, including reducing the countrys deficit and fighting corruption. Mr. Necas, a former social affairs minister respected for his no-nonsense manner, is the most likely candidate to be the next prime minister.

title: Boston Skyscraper Nickname
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Heres a rarity  a themed Saturday puzzle. Its not a full-blown theme, but it does have 10 symmetrically placed entries that are tied together using the same clue: Triumphant shout. Half of these shouts are used in games (one in soccer, although it could be a bullfight) with the balance comprising cries of a more multipurpose nature.

title: Schiavone and Stosur Look for Each Others Flaws
description: The womens singles final between Francesca Schiavone and Samantha Stosur is as improbable as any Grand Slam final in recent memory. Just a year ago, the two met in the first round at Roland Garros, with Stosur winning in straight sets. While Stosur has captivated the tennis world with her back-to-back victories over Justine Henin and Serena Williams, followed by her lopsided one hour dismantling of Jelena Jankovic, Schiavone has quietly fought her way through a series of tough, seasoned opponents to become the first Italian woman to vie for a Grand Slam singles title. Both stories are compelling, and they point to an increasing depth in the womens game.

title: Having Seen Stats, Yanks Get First Look at How Blue Jays Stack Up
description: TORONTO  By now the Yankees know that the Rays and the Red Sox are formidable, and that the Orioles are not. But what about the Blue Jays, their other American League East rival? In an odd twist of scheduling, the Yankees and the Blue Jays, who meet 18 times, did not to play each other until Friday night, two months into the season.

title: Gay? Whatever, Dude
description: Last week, while many of us were distracted by the oil belching forth from the gulf floor and the presidents ham-handed attempts to demonstrate that he was sufficiently engaged and enraged, Gallup released a stunning, and little noticed, report on Americans evolving views of homosexuality. Allow me to enlighten:

title: Little Chains That Could... And Still Do
description: Although businesses like Starbucks that began elsewhere now seem to dominate New Yorks street corners, chains that got their start in the city are thriving.

title: With Niese Coming, Perez Is Still in Limbo
description: The Mets shuffled their roster Friday, but Oliver Perez remained a nebulous part of it. Perez, a former starting pitcher banished to the bullpen, has not accepted a demotion to the minor leagues.

title: Murray Stein, Crusader Against Water Pollution, Dies at 92
description: Murray Stein, who for more than 20 years led the federal governments fight against water pollution and did much to overcome the prevailing attitude that the nations waterways could serve as sewers, died May 24 at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 92.

title: Paul Garabedian, Mathematician at N.Y.U., Dies at 82
description: Paul R. Garabedian, a mathematician whose computer computations helped lead to fuel-efficient wings for modern jetliners, died May 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Iman: A Model's Journey
description: Iman's path from her birth in Somalia to fashion stardom in the 1980s and '90s has included modeling, and also family, business ventures and philanthropic work.

title: Between the Farm and the Table
description: DON LEWIS, the owner of Wild Hive Farm, rolled open a door to reveal his milling machinery and shoved a somewhat aggressive goat named Annabelle aside. Inside stood a modern Amish-style stone-burr mill, with 20-inch pink granite grinding stones. Its basically the same machine that was used 100 years ago, with a few more bells and whistles, he said.

title: Fear (and Shopping) When Big Stores Move In
description: Rhoda and Edward Green sat in the lobby of their building on 100th Street recently, engaged in a classic Upper West Side activity: collecting signatures on a petition.

title: Serving Up a (Very) Cold One
description: The Great Burnside Ice Company has been churning out ice in East Hartford since 1911  and remains one of only three firms producing block ice in New England. A decade ago, Bob McClellan, the owner, decided to branch out, establishing the Olde Burnside Brewing Company.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Iman: Not Just Another Pretty Face
description: THE supermodel Iman hasnt walked a runway in 21 years. Yet at almost 55 years old, with that famous Modigliani profile and copper-toned skin, shes as gorgeous as ever.

title: Corrections
description: A capsule summary on Friday about an article on buildings that will be demolished for a tunnel under the Hudson River referred incorrectly to letters being sent out about the project. The letters are going to 3,000 businesses, residents and others, not just to residents. It also misstated the contents of the letters. As the article correctly noted, they lay out the plans for the tunnel; they do not warn residents that they will be displaced. (While some businesses will be demolished, no residences are to be.)

title: City Drops Plan to Charge Rent to Shelter Residents
description: The Bloomberg administration has abandoned a controversial decision to charge rent to working homeless families living at city shelters, officials announced on Friday.

title: Two Styles of Pizza, Some Waiting
description: BLAME it on Mothers Day, I thought.

title: A Dubious Way to Prevent Fiscal Crisis
description: So where were we?

title: Personality Plus
description: While large-scale producers typically issue impersonal, programmatic wines, boutique wines tend to reflect the winemakers personalities. That seems especially true at Lenz, in Peconic, where Eric Fry has overseen the cellar for two decades.

title: Persian Delicacies, Made for Sharing
description: DELICIOUS food served in large portions at low prices has been a successful formula for Ravagh Persian Grill. The original Ravagh is on East 30th Street in Manhattan, with another on the Upper East Side. The Long Island branch opened in Roslyn Heights in 2001.

title: BP Funneling Some of Leak to the Surface
description: HOUSTON  BP and government officials said Friday that a cap installed over a gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico was funneling some oil and gas to the surface, but they cautioned that much was still leaking and that it would be days before they could declare this latest containment effort a success.

title: A Tour for the Taste Buds
description: Restaurant weeks  citywide dining-out promotions in which participating restaurants offer a special menu at a set price  have taken off in New Jersey. Montclair started one last year. So did Atlantic City. And New Brunswick had its first one in April.

title: John Wooden, Who Built Incomparable Dynasty at U.C.L.A., Dies at 99
description: John Wooden, a staid Midwesterner who migrated to U.C.L.A. and became college basketballs most successful coach, earning the nickname the Wizard of Westwood and an enduring place in sports history, died Friday at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he had been hospitalized since May 26. He was 99.

title: With Diplomas in Hand, but Without Legal Status
description: Stories of hardship are easy to find among community college students, and the class of 2010 at Queensborough, in Queens, is no different.

title: With Backdrop of Glamour, Wal-Mart Stresses Global Growth
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Wal-Marts past was as a humble five-and-dime store in nearby Bentonville, but at its shareholders meeting here Friday, the retailer said its future would be in distant lands.

title: Italian Specialties From Garden and Sea
description: THE server at Bcio seemed out of her element, nonplused by a near cross-examination from a diner at the next table about the origins of the seafood. Finally, the diner relented, admitting he was concerned about whether it had been tainted by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: Dickey Stays, Then Uses Bat and Knuckleball to Win Again
description: The Mets made several roster changes Friday before they defeated the Florida Marlins, 4-3, at Citi Field, but pitchers R. A. Dickey and Oliver Perez remained.

title: The Yankees Get Some Firsthand Knowledge of the Blue Jays Ability
description: TORONTO  Mucking through the American League East for the last two months presented the Yankees an unassailable truth: The Rays and the Red Sox are formidable, and the Orioles are not. But what about their other division rival, the Toronto Blue Jays?

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: John Woodens Career
description: John Wooden, a staid Midwesterner who migrated to U.C.L.A. and became college basketballs most successful coach, earning the nickname the Wizard of Westwood and an enduring place in sports history, died.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405..

title: Wooden as a Teacher: The First Lesson Was Shoelaces
description: Start at the bottom. Since that is the way John Wooden initiated his basketball players, it is also a good way to study the life of this early 20th-century man who died Friday at age 99.

title: General Manager Ferry Leaves the Cavaliers
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers and General Manager Danny Ferry mutually announced their parting Friday, less than two weeks after the organization fired Coach Mike Brown.

title: A Disaster Reaches Beyond the Gulf Coast
description: As BP continues to struggle to plug the leak at the bottom of the sea, the president tries to convince the country that he is on top of the crisis, and the first oil laps the coasts of previously untouched states, Americans far from the gulf are feeling touched by the disaster. A sampling:

title: Brand Officer Named at Elle Magazine
description: Robin Domeniconi has been named the new chief brand officer for Elle magazine, overseeing its content, advertising and marketing. Ms. Domeniconi most recently worked as a vice president at Microsoft, where she was in charge of sales and marketing for media properties. But she has a history in the magazine world, too, having run sales and marketing at Time Inc. and working as publisher and president of Real Simple. Carol Smith left the position at Elle in April to work at Cond Nast, overseeing the companys new epicurean group. Ms. Domeniconi starts full time in July, according to Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S., Elles publisher.

title: S.E.C. Delays Start of Exchange Trading Curbs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poors 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes, saying they will be implemented within two weeks. The announcement was made in an e-mail statement. NYSE Euronext said earlier Friday that it would not start its trial of the system on June 7 because it had not received S.E.C. authorization. The Nasdaq OMX Group is prepared to introduce circuit breakers on the S.& P. 500 companies it lists on June 14, pending S.E.C. approval, a spokesman, Robert Madden, said.

title: Agricultural Bank of China to Sell Shares
description: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nations biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the worlds largest initial public offering on record. The state-owned bank plans to sell 22.235 billion shares in Shanghai and 25.411 billion shares in Hong Kong, excluding an over-allotment option, according to a prospectus posted on the securities regulators Web site Friday. Agricultural Bank will compete for investors money with publicly traded rivals that plan to raise a combined $32 billion in stock and bond sales even with bank valuations near record low levels. Agricultural Bank will have 26.73 billion shares outstanding in Hong Kong after the offering, which includes 25.411 billion shares sold to the public and another 1.32 billion shares held by Chinas national pension fund. The prospectus did not give a price range for the share sale or an amount that the lender would seek to raise. Chinas securities regulator said it would review the plan on June 9.

title: Flyers Stay Steady at Home, Clawing Back Into Series

At this time of record deficits, however, the city is giving more than ever to After School Matters, the charity led by Mayor Daleys wife.

title: A New News Media Outlet Reflects Different, Though Still Familiar, Times
description: Twelve years ago, I was busy starting a weekly print magazine, The Industry Standard, which quickly became an icon of the dot-com era. On the way up  in less than three years we grew to more than 400 employees from an initial staff of about 40  we were the proverbial symbol of the Internet boom, with a smart, young staff putting out a smart, fat magazine, and marketers competing to underwrite both our press runs and our parties. On the way down  a brutal eight months in which our revenues declined by 75 percent while our investors played a game of financial chicken that ended in a bankruptcy filing  we were similarly a metaphor for the hubris and failed dreams of a most unusual time.

title: Schiavone Wins With Confidence

Schiavone outplayed Stosur, who seemed stunned by Schiavones daring play and fist-pumping displays of confidence. After beating Justine Henin, Serena Williams and Jelena Jankovic to reach the final, Stosur was considered the favorite to win. But it was Schiavone who played to win, outhitting and outserving the powerful Stosur. In many ways, she beat Stosur at her own game, serving big and setting up her groundstrokes to keep Stosur on the move and off-balance.

If it were to be followed this year, doctors would face a 21 percent cut in payments for the tests, procedures, office visits and other services they provide to elderly Americans.

title: Justice in the Jury Box
description: In 1986, when the Supreme Court reached a landmark decision forbidding prosecutors from routinely excluding blacks from juries without a good explanation, Justice Thurgood Marshall warned it would not end racial exclusions. Some prosecutors, he wrote in a concurring opinion, would simply invent phony reasons.

title: Walk the Talk
description: In its devastating decision to allow an uncontrolled flood of corporate money into federal elections, the Supreme Court tried to head off critics by endorsing full disclosure of fat-cat donors. It is not enough. But Congress can repair some of the damage by passing the Disclose campaign finance reform.

title: Prime Number
description: 50: The age at which people start feeling better about themselves after years and years of feeling steadily worse, according to a new study published online in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The study was based on the results of a 2008 Gallup poll of 340,000 people nationwide. People start out at age 18 feeling pretty good about themselves, the study found, but then feel worse and worse until they hit 50. At that point, there is a sharp reversal, and people keep getting happier. By the time they are 85, they are even more satisfied with themselves than they were at 18.

title: Early and Back Home
description: The birds begin. Ethel, the border terrier, stretches and yawns beside me. I listen for a while, then consult the time. It is so much earlier than Id thought  5:11 and nothing to do about it except listen for a little longer, then get up. I have the brief, puritanical thought that I should know all these birds by their songs. Perhaps theyre the same birds I hear at twilight, some of whose names I know.

title: Mozart for Microbes
description: Mozart's music is thought to stimulate the mind. But can it also stimulate microbes?A sewage treatment plant in the German town of Treuenbrietzen, about an hours drive from Berlin, is trying to find out, according to Spiegel Online. For the last two months, the plant has been treating its biomass-eating microbes to Mozart played on a special stereo system designed to replicate the vibrations and sounds of a performance in a concert hall. The thinking is that the sonic waves of Mozart, along with oxygen added in the treatment process, will spur the microbes to break down sewage more efficiently, saving money.

Appearing on Wednesday before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, he said that as the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, he has no negotiating power with Moodys and Standard & Poors, the two major agencies, because ratings were required in many cases by the rules.

title: Back Then: 1989
description: Last week, Chinese censors forced one of the nation's newspapersto excise a cartoon that appeared to evoke perhaps the most famous image of the June 1989 protests at Tiananmen Square. Heres how The Times described the confrontation at the time: It all started with a man in a white shirt who walked into the street and raised his right hand no higher than a New Yorker hailing a taxi. ... The man stood only half as tall as the lead tank. But his body language made it clear: He wanted the slow-moving column halted, and halt it did, the huge treads on the lead tank grinding to a stop just a few feet from his face. It was a close call  the tank came perhaps a second or two of killing him  and it seemed to encapsulate many of the confrontations in recent days between the citizens and the army: the touch-and-go maneuvering, with soldiers not sure when to press on and when to retreat; the determination of the demonstrators, brave and unyielding in ways that might have been unthinkable a few weeks ago.

Struggling hitters get more at-bats, often against the underbelly of a bullpen, and one clutch hit can erase a days worth of futility. The opposite can also be true, as demonstrated Saturday by the Yankees in their second consecutive loss to the Toronto Blue Jays. A single by Aaron Hill off Chad Gaudin scored Edwin Encarnacion in the bottom of the 14th inning and gave the Blue Jays a 3-2 victory, leaving the Yankees to wonder whether their offense ever cleared customs.

They use the conflict and the attention it generates to play out their own identity issues, passions and biases. My favorite in Beirut was a gentleman who showed up in August 1982 as the Palestinian guerrillas were sailing out of Beirut harbor. His name  I am not making this up  was Arthur Blessitt, the Sunset Boulevard Preacher. He had walked to West Beirut from Israel to pray for peace, dragging a 13-foot-long wooden cross with a little wheel on the bottom.

title: Should This Be the Last Generation?
description: Have you ever thought about whether to have a child? If so, what factors entered into your decision? Was it whether having children would be good for you, your partner and others close to the possible child, such as children you may already have, or perhaps your parents? For most people contemplating reproduction, those are the dominant questions. Some may also think about the desirability of adding to the strain that the nearly seven billion people already here are putting on our planets environment. But very few ask whether coming into existence is a good thing for the child itself. Most of those who consider that question probably do so because they have some reason to fear that the childs life would be especially difficult  for example, if they have a family history of a devastating illness, physical or mental, that cannot yet be detected prenatally.All this suggests that we think it is wrong to bring into the world a child whose prospects for a happy, healthy life are poor, but we dont usually think the fact that a child is likely to have a happy, healthy life is a reason for bringing the child into existence. This has come to be known among philosophers as the asymmetry and it is not easy to justify. But rather than go into the explanations usually proffered  and why they fail  I want to raise a related problem. How good does life have to be, to make it reasonable to bring a child into the world? Is the standard of life experienced by most people in developed nations today good enough to make this decision unproblematic, in the absence of specific knowledge that the child will have a severe genetic disease or other problem?
