title: His Heart Is in the Art of Sleuthing
description: There might be a few agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who could sit down at a piano and run through a Chopin Fantasie to calm their nerves, as Robert K. Wittman used to do. But there probably arent many who could also chat knowledgably about Czannes influence on Soutine. Or who have studied formalism at the Barnes Foundation art museum outside of Philadelphia. Or who have found themselves in Hollywood, Fla., eating lunch with  and probably being targeted by  two large French assassins nicknamed Vanilla and Chocolate, while tantalizingly close to recovering paintings from the biggest art heist in American history, the 1990 robbery of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston.

title: Mystery Hotel: They Check In, but They Dont Check Out
description: Persons Unknown was created by Christopher McQuarrie, who wrote the screenplay for the 1995 thriller The Usual Suspects, and that pedigree alone should seal the success of this new NBC series that begins on Monday.

title: New Portraits of Grief and Wanderlust
description: Chamber music concerts focusing on contemporary works often attract small audiences. But the organizers of the Tribeca New Music Festival needed to find a larger space this year after events sold out during the last two seasons at the Flea Theater downtown.

title: Vowels Ring in New Suite for Chorus
description: While introducing Kirke Mechems Suite for Chorus, which was given its New York premiere by the New Amsterdam Singers on Thursday evening at the Church of the Holy Trinity on the Upper East Side, the conductor Clara Longstreth pointed out that in the realm of vocal music most composers select the text, then write the score. For Mr. Mechem, on the other hand, words were secondary in this work, which treats the choir like a symphonic or chamber ensemble and uses consonants and vowels as strings might incorporate pizzicato and varied bowing strokes.

title: A Cuban Folk Song Pioneer
description: Outside Carnegie Hall on Friday night were knots of demonstrators, for and against the Cuban government. Inside was an uproar of adulation: repeated standing ovations, eagerly shouted requests, Cuban flags and banners unfurled, fervent singalongs, roses hurled onstage. The object of it all was a bespectacled, casually dressed man with a gentle voice and an acoustic guitar: Silvio Rodrguez, the 63-year-old Cuban songwriter who is making his first tour of the United States since 1980.

title: Welcome to the Dance, Bugsy Siegel. Care to Say a Few Words?
description: True or false: New York City Ballet is the home of neo-classical dance, the living tribute to the abstract, pared-down aesthetic with which George Balanchine revolutionized 20th-century ballet?

title: Callaway Sisters Have Serious Fun With 60s Songs
description: Ah, the 60s. The further that tumultuous decade, whose spirit extended well beyond it, recedes into the mist, the more its popular music becomes grist for lighthearted nostalgia with a tinge of camp. Preadolescents in those days, the singers Ann Hampton Callaway, now in her early 50s, and Liz, her slightly younger sister, were born a little too late to throw themselves headlong into the fray. But in their show, Boom! (as in boomer) on Friday evening at Town Hall, they remembered the music with deep affection.

title: The Subtlety of Gods and Goddesses
description: The sheer range of dance in New York is as great a marvel as any of the individual high points. Last week I caught DanceAfrica; a modern-dance world premiere; ballets by Balanchine, greatest of ballet choreographers; and the superlative dancing of the ballerina Natalia Osipova. Yet, strange as this may sound, the single performance that seemed the truest revelation of dance itself came in the Indian form of Odissi, opening Erasing Borders: Festival of Indian Dance at the Asia Society.

title: MLB Network Expands Coverage of Draft
description: A year ago, the MLB Network carried its first amateur draft, in which Stephen Strasburg was the No. 1 overall pick by the Washington Nationals. For its second go-round with the draft Monday, the network has made a few changes.

title: An Ailing Ozawa Wont Tour Europe
description: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who has been undergoing treatment for esophageal cancer, has canceled a weeklong tour in Europe with the Saito Kinen Orchestra to conserve his strength for performances at Carnegie Hall in December, a representative said on Friday. Mr. Ozawa, right, was to have performed in Prague, Vienna, Berlin and Paris from Dec. 3 to Dec. 10 before opening Carnegies Japan NYC festival with the orchestra on Dec. 14. He said: Cancel Europe, Ive got to go to Carnegie, said Ronald Wilford, his manager. Thats a tough tour, Mr. Wilford added. Thats why he said no. Carnegie is absolutely right on. Mr. Ozawa is artistic director of the Carnegie festival. He is also principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera.

title: And Now, Charlie Sheen, the Acting Teacher?
description: Charlie Sheen may teach acting as part of the community service he is most likely going to be sentenced to in a domestic violence case he is settling in Aspen, Colo., The Associated Press reported. Paige Price, artistic director of Theater Aspen, said that lawyers for Mr. Sheen, below, had approached her about the possibility of his volunteering with the company. I certainly think he has the career credentials, Ms. Price told The A.P., adding: He could possibly teach a class or do question-and-answer sessions. If this could benefit the Theater Aspens actors or students, I would certainly be amenable to it. Mr. Sheen was charged with criminal mischief and assault after a fight with his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, in a home they were renting in Aspen last Christmas. Arnold Mordkin, Pitkin County chief deputy district attorney, confirmed that an agreement had been reached and that there had been discussions about Mr. Sheen doing useful public service with the theater, but declined to confirm details until a judge approved the deal in court on Monday. Hes really not getting anything different than the average person under similar circumstances would receive, Mr. Mordkin said.

title: A Sharp Drop at the Box Office
description: Movie box-office receipts dropped by 24 percent from the comparable weekend last year, to an estimated $125 million from $165.3 million. Shrek Forever After, in its third week, held on to the No. 1 spot with an estimated $25.3 million in weekend ticket sales, taking in about $183 million in ticket sales to date. Two new comedies, Get Him to the Greek and Killers, posted tepid openings. Get Him to the Greek, from Universal Pictures, placed second with $17.4 million in domestic ticket sales for the weekend, while Killers, from Lionsgate, was third with $16.1 million. The two films together took in far less than the $45 million collected by The Hangover, a comedy that opened in the comparable weekend in 2009. The weekends decline follows soft openings last week by Sex and the City 2, from Warner Brothers, and Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time, from Walt Disney. Prince of Persia this week fell to the No. 4 spot, as ticket sales dropped 54 percent from last weekend, to $13.9 million, for a total of about $59.5 million since it opened. Sex and the City 2 placed fifth with $12.7 million in sales, down 59 percent, for a total of $73.4 million.

title: Screenings of the Cove in Japan Are Canceled
description: Movie theaters in Japan have canceled the opening screenings of The Cove, a documentary that shows the clandestine killing of dolphins in Taiji, Japan, Reuters reported. The film, directed by the photographer Louie Psihoyos and winner of this years Oscar for best documentary feature, has recently been protested by Japanese groups that defend the practice of dolphin and whale hunting as part of the countrys cultural tradition. Cinemart Theaters in Tokyo and Osaka have canceled screenings scheduled for this month out of fear for the safety of moviegoers, after receiving threatening phone calls and warnings of protests from groups that consider the film anti-Japan, said a spokeswoman for the films Japanese distributor, Unplugged. Other than a showing at the Tokyo International Film Festival last October, the Japanese public has not yet been given an opportunity to see the movie. Its not right that a small minority of extremists could take this right away from them, Ric OBarry, a former dolphin trainer featured in the film, said in a statement, adding, To do so is a clear threat to democracy.

title: Footnotes
description: Funeral plans for Gary Coleman were postponed this weekend after a Utah lawyer, Kent Alderman, produced a 1999 will that named an executor, The Associated Press reported. The discovery of the will could help end a fight for custody of Mr. Colemans body between his former wife, Shannon Price, and his estranged parents, Edmonia Sue and W. G. Coleman. Frederick Jackman, a lawyer for Mr. Colemans parents, said the executor named in the will is Dion Mial, a friend and former manager. ... The actress Cybill Shepherd, the director Lee Daniels and the pop singer Lady Gaga were among those honored at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamations Media Awards in San Francisco on Saturday night. Also among the recipients were the Public Broadcasting System, for its documentary Ask Not, about the Armys dont ask, dont tell policy, and the multimedia presentation The Stonewall Riots: 40 Years Later, a look at the present and future of the gay rights movement, by aarp.org.

title: Is Any Job Better Than No Job?

Though 431,000 jobs were created in May nationwide, the bulk of them were workers hired by the federal government to help with the Census  jobs that will disappear in a few months. Only 41,000 private jobs were created, far short of expectations of 150,000 to 180,000 jobs, and unemployment rates remained steady. Economists estimate that the U.S. needs to add more than 100,000 jobs a month just to keep pace with new workers  high school and college graduates  entering the market.

title: Fences Revival Recoups Investment
description: The Broadway revival of August Wilsons Fences, starring Viola Davis and Denzel Washington, below, has recouped its $2.8 million capitalization after only eight weeks of performances, the producers Carole Shorenstein Hays and Scott Rudin announced on Monday. The critically acclaimed production, which has received the most Tony Award nominations ever  10  for a play revival, began preview performances on April 14 and opened on April 26; the limited engagement is scheduled to end on July 11. Usually only one-quarter to one-third of Broadway shows recoup their original investment, and most require many months to do so; having popular stars in the cast has helped some recent plays, like God of Carnage and A Steady Rain, recoup more quickly. Like those productions Fences is one of the few hit plays in recent years that have grossed more than $1 million in a single week; the production has also twice set box office records at its home, the Cort Theater, most recently when it hit a figure of $1,024,316.50 last week. Among the plays nominations for Tony Awards, which will be presented on Sunday, are best revival of a play, leading actor (Mr. Washington), leading actress (Ms. Davis), featured actor in a play (Stephen McKinley Henderson) and direction of a play (Kenny Leon).

Ms. Peters said that Stephen Sondheim, who wrote the music and lyrics for the show, proposed the idea to her this spring and urged the producers to cast her. Ms. Stritch said that no one  including herself  was claiming credit for suggesting that she step into the role of Madame Armfeldt. No one is going to own up to it until they see how I do, said Ms. Stritch, who sang The Ladies Who Lunch in the original Broadway production of Mr. Sondheims Company. The change has led to a longer life for the revival, which had been set to close on June 20. A spokesman said that Ms. Zeta-Jones and Ms. Lansbury would play their final performances on that date, and that then the show would be dark until performances resumed on July 13 with Ms. Peters and Ms. Stritch.

title: Annie Revival Planned
description: Little girls, little girls, get ready. The musical Annie will be revived on Broadway in the fall of 2012 to mark the 35th anniversary of the original production, with Thomas Meehan, who wrote the shows book, on board to update the script for the first time, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday. The 1977 Tony Award winner for best musical, Annie ran for almost six years and has spawned countless tours and regional productions, but it has been revived on Broadway only once, in 1997, a production that drew negative reviews from critics and ran only seven months. Ms. Madover declined to offer a theory about why that revival failed, but said that hers would be different because Mr. Meehan would be working with the script and a new creative team will look to modernize the show. The story (as if anyone didnt know) of a little orphan girl who warms the hearts of Daddy Warbucks, Franklin D. Roosevelt and just about everyone except the mean orphanage manager Miss Hannigan, Annie will not be updated out of the Great Depression, Ms. Madover said. Rather, Mr. Meehan plans to look at the dialogue and the structure of the plot for ways to sharpen the storytelling. (Mr. Meehan won the 1977 Tony for best book, one of seven Tonys that the production received.)

title: Laurie Anderson Work a Hit With Dogs

The concert was performed for the first time outside the Sydney Opera House on Saturday as part of the Vivid Live arts festival that Ms. Anderson is organizing with her husband, Lou Reed. The 20-minute work consists of thumping beats, whistles and high-pitched electronic sounds that cannot be heard by human ears, The A.P. said, as well as whale sounds that worked some four-legged concertgoers into a frenzy. (Others, The A.P. said, simply stared at the stage with glazed eyes, which in our experience is not necessarily an indication of a bad show.) A Jack Russell terrier named Oliver made a break for the stage, The A.P. reported, dragging his owner along with him. But all in all, Ms. Anderson said: That was the most amazing concert Ive ever, ever gotten to give! Its really a dream. Above, a fan at the event.

Over the weekend the alternative-rock band the Pixies (right, Black Francis, the bands lead singer) withdrew from what would have been its first show in Israel, as part of the Pic.Nic music festival scheduled in Tel Aviv this week. Wed like to extend our deepest apologies to the fans, but events beyond all our control have conspired against us, the group said in a statement. The bands Gorillaz and the Klaxons have also withdrawn from the festival after the raid by Israeli commandos on a Gaza-bound flotilla. Last month Elvis Costello canceled two concerts in Israel this summer, citing the complexities of the continuing Israeli-Palestinian conflict. After the announcement of the Pixies cancellation, Shuki Weiss, the promoter of the Pic.Nic festival, said in a statement, I am full of both sorrow and pain in light of the fact that our repeated attempts to present quality acts and festivals in Israel have increasingly been falling victim to what I can only describe as a form of cultural terrorism which is targeting Israel and the arts worldwide.

title: Del Toros Sad Farewell

Tolkien Web site that explained his decisions for leaving the project in further  if not complete  detail. Last week Mr. del Toro said on TheOneRing.net that he was withdrawing as director of The Hobbit, which MGM is planning for release as two films in 2012 and 2013. In a message posted on Sunday on that same site, Mr. del Toro wrote that his commitment to the project demanded enormous sacrifices both in personal and professional terms, requiring him to relocate my entire life and family to New Zealand after he joined the project in 2008. Though he has made other films that required location shoots and took years to come together, Mr. del Toro wrote, rarely do you relocate for such massive amount of time specially when you have to do major ironclad agreements to put in deep freeze other contractual obligations with multiple studios. He added: So  while the cited delays, contractual complexities or obstacles, cannot be attributed to a single event or entity  you will simply have to believe that they were of sufficient complexity and severity to lead to the current situation. A new director has not been announced.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Bad Parenting
description: Once again Friday nights episode of Friday Night Lights, proved to be an evocative treatise on miserable parenting. Early on we see Vince scouring the empty fridge in his apartment right before the camera finds its way to the image of his mother sacked out on a bench outside. She didnt forget to pick up the milk because she is too harried; she is too strung out to remember to do it in the first place. The series checks off every category of bad mother or father: Vinces mom is an addict; Beckys mom is an obsessive too focused on the transgressions of Beckys dad to really be in the moment with her daughter. Did anybody else feel worse for Becky that her mom was screaming into the dads voice mail during the pageant than they did over the fact that he didnt bother to show up?And how about that pageant? (I loved Beckys correcting of the M.C.  Its just Wicked.') There is something so incongruous  in a good way  about Becky being on the beauty pageant circuit, since she is so not a Texas looker. The show hammered this home with its shots of her competitors. Her confidence  her aggressiveness with Riggins  is constantly at odds with her rebellious hair and unconventional prettiness, and Im finding myself really riveted by the tension. Becky is also the first central female character to be ordinary looking. (Tyra, Julie and Lyla  knockouts all.) And whats amazing is how self-assured she is in spite of her clearly bad family life. She knows how to perform: I like the way her confidence was contrasted with Vinces, when he is asked to deliver a speech at a pancake breakfast after a great turn in his football game. He is at a loss and further confused by J.D. McCoys Dale Carnegie-like ease in front of an audience.

title: More Ups and Downs at Aspen Music Festival
description: Is the altitude finally getting to everyone? The dizzying swings of fortune for Alan Fletcher, the president and chief executive of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, continue. Mr. Fletcher, who was fired by the executive committee of the festivals board of trustees last October, rehired by the full board in November and given a vote of no confidence by the festival corporation (including board members, faculty and others) in April, has now had his contract extended for two years, through September 2012. The decision was made at a special meeting of the board on Monday, at which Rob LeBuhn, its chairman for the last year, announced that he was stepping down, effective immediately, in response to a majority vote. Mike Murray, the vice chairman, has been named acting chairman. The board will elect a new chairman, possibly at its next scheduled meeting on June 29. The festival is also looking for a new music director to replace David Zinman, who resigned in April, strongly criticizing Mr. Fletcher. The festival season opens on July 1.

title: The Life Aquatic

But theres a fine line between indulging in a little naval gazing and looking like an extra on shore leave from On the Town. AANDD, a new line of three unisex bags from the architect/industrial designer Adam Davidson, gets the seafaring tone just right, with waxed rope handles and a predominantly navy color scheme. I wanted to get past the usual garment center sources for hardware, Davidson says. So I looked at marine hardware and just fell in love with it. The roomy Sea Bag is Davidsons take on the weekender, with large exterior pockets and a detachable leather shoulder strap; the Sea Duffle is a cross between a shoulder bag and a sailors duffle; and the Courier is a leather messenger bag with a two-tone reversible flap that zips on and off. Womens bags tend to be bling-heavy, while mens bags shy away from any risk-taking when it comes to details, adds the designer. The idea is to find the middle ground. Aandd bags are available at Maryam Nassir Zaddeh, 123 Norfolk Street, (212) 673-6405. Prices range from $425-$625.

The hypocrisy here is frankly hilarious, considering that the ABC program Greys Anatomy has used the word douche not in the medical sense, but as a pejorative put-down, and a character on the 1990s ABC program NYPD Blue routinely used the word with its popular pairing, bag. title: Ankle Injury Sidelines Italian Ballet Star
description: The Italian dance star Roberto Bolle, above, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has withdrawn from performances with the company because of an ankle injury, the company announced on Tuesday. He was scheduled to appear in Swan Lake on June 21 and Romeo and Juliet on July 8. Marcelo Gomes, another principal, will replace Mr. Bolle in both, dancing opposite Veronika Part as Odette/Odile in Swan Lake, and with Paloma Herrera in Romeo and Juliet. The companys spring season continues through July 10.

title: Filmmaker Wins Stay in Case Against Chevron
description: The director Joe Berlinger will not have to turn over more than 600 hours of unused footage from his documentary Crude to the Chevron oil company pending his appeal of a subpoena for the footage. A three-judge panel for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York decided on Tuesday to stay a subpoena order made last month by a lower court, pending its ruling on the appeal. In the documentary Mr. Berlinger, above, chronicles a group of Ecuadorians who are suing Chevron (which now owns Texaco, the original target of the suit), saying that the companys oil-field operations polluted their drinking and bathing water. A federal district court sided on May 6 with Chevron, which said Mr. Berlingers raw footage could be helpful as it seeks to have the lawsuit dismissed and pursues arbitration. The panel on Tuesday also granted a request by both sides for an expedited appeal. A date for arguments was not immediately set, but arguments were expected to take place by mid-July.

title: Reruns Beat Reality
description: CBS reruns eked out a victory in the ratings on Monday while ABCs Bachelorette saw slight improvement from a week ago. According to Nielsens estimates, 7.9 million viewers tuned in to watch ABCs reality series The Bachelorette from 8 to 10 p.m., up from 7.6 million last week. That audience helped ABC finish in second place on the night, but it wasnt enough to outperform CBSs lineup, which included high-rated comedy repeats of Two and a Half Men (9.7 million) and The Big Bang Theory (9.1 million). At 10, ABCs True Beauty delivered a modest 5 million viewers, lagging behind CBSs rerun of CSI: Miami (8 million), but finishing ahead of NBCs debut of Persons Unknown (4.3 million). Fox was third on the night, while NBC ranked fourth.

title: Funny Girl Needs a Streisand
description: Funny Girl, the hit 1964 musical about Fanny Brice that helped cement Barbra Streisand as a star, is expected to have its first Broadway revival in the spring of 2012 under the direction of Bartlett Sher (South Pacific), the producer Bob Boyett said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. Mr. Boyett, who holds the rights to Funny Girl, described the challenge of finding the right actress to play Fanny as formidable, partly because so many people associate the role  and signature songs like People and Dont Rain on My Parade  with Ms. Streisand, who was only 21 when she took the part. With music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill and a book by Isobel Lennart, Funny Girl ran on Broadway from 1964 to 1967. Asked whether he had interest in casting Lea Michele, above, the 23-year-old Spring Awakening veteran who memorably performed Dont Rain on My Parade this season on her television series Glee, Mr. Boyett said: I think Lea is wonderful, shes great, and she would certainly be on anybodys list. Shes also got a pretty good gig going now on Glee. There have been a few Hollywood types who have expressed interest, Mr. Boyett added, declining to name names, but were also open to going with an unknown actress.

title: Sheen Plea Deal Delayed
description: A Colorado prosecutor told a judge on Monday that he had been unable to come to an agreement with lawyers representing Charlie Sheen, and the judge rescheduled the planned hearing until next month, Reuters reported. Mr. Sheen, a star of the CBS comedy Two and a Half Men, appeared in an Aspen court on charges stemming from a Christmas Day argument with his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, who called 911. Mr. Sheen was expected to plead guilty to a charge of misdemeanor assault against his wife and be sentenced to 30 days in jail, with permission to coach actors at a local theater as part of his plea bargain. Arnold Mordkin, the chief deputy district attorney of Pitkin County, told Reuters that the case had hit a snag, declining to give further details. Yale Galanter, a lawyer for Ms. Sheen, told The Associated Press that a disagreement over the terms of Mr. Sheens work release had held up the deal. The hearing on Mr. Sheens plea bargain was postponed until July 12.

title: Singing Spider-Man Needs a Love Interest
description: Three months after losing the film actress Evan Rachel Wood because of long production delays, the coming Broadway megamusical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark has a new choice for love interest Mary Jane Watson: Jennifer Damiano, left, the 19-year-old actress who plays the testy teenage daughter in the Broadway musical Next to Normal. Ms. Damiano, whose performance as Natalie earned her a 2009 Tony Award nomination, is leaving Next to Normal on July 18, a spokesman for the show said on Tuesday. Neither the spokesman nor other executives involved with Next to Normal would say what she would be doing next. But two theater executives with knowledge of the Spider-Man casting said on Tuesday that Ms. Damiano had recently signed a contract to play Mary Jane in the musical, to be directed by Julie Taymor and begin performances later this year at the Hilton Theater.

title: Clinton Woos a Leftist President
description: QUITO, Ecuador  Venturing into one of Latin Americas less friendly capitals, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton declared on Tuesday that the Obama administration was intent on having better relationships in this region, even with leftist governments like Ecuadors, which became stridently anti-American during the Bush administration.

title: Democrat in Chief?
description: A year and a half after they sat, shivering and awestruck, on a January morning and listened to the sounds of a million cheers careering off the marble walls of the Capitol, the Democrats who work under the dome can feel those same walls closing in fast. Throughout the dismal spring, it seemed as if every visiting delegation that drove up in a coach bus  Main Street merchants, family farmers, Rotarians and Elks  arrived with tales of angst and unrest back home. Every well-paid pollster who came through the door brought with him a stack of surveys and focus-group memos, each more dispiriting than the last, numbers portending an emphatic rejection of the majority in this falls elections. Every new thickly bound jobs report landed with a sickening thud on the desks of committee chairmen  a reminder that, despite modest improvements, time was running out to change peoples minds about the direction of the economy.

title: The Musical Has Lost Its Voice
description: ON Sunday night Broadway will stage its annual festival of self-promotion, the Tony Awards, which have increasingly become less a chance to honor excellence and more a splashy three-hour television commercial for the brand.

title: Perfectly Unfair
description: As I write this, Detroit Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga is preparing to make his first appearance on the mound since last Wednesday, when he was famously denied a perfect game by an umpires botched call on what should have been the final out of the ninth inning.

title: Frankies Spuntinos Chefs Have a New Cookbook
description: You might find a shelf of books bound in leather, stamped and edged with gold leaf in a wood-paneled library. The Frankies Spuntino Kitchen Companion and Cooking Manual, by Frank Falcinelli, Frank Castronovo and Peter Meehan (Artisan, $24.95), brings a hint of that elegance to the kitchen. But like everything Mr. Falcinelli and Mr. Castronovo do in their Brooklyn and Manhattan restaurants, it is also down to earth.

title: Table for 2? Get Ready to Wait in Line
description: RESERVATIONS? Not accepted.

title: Whither Wall Street? Pick Your Indicator
description: Everyone on Wall Street watches the Dow. Guy LeBas watches the Cow.

title: Calling All Readers: Tips on No-Reservation Restaurants
description: We want to hear from you on no-reservations restaurants. Which ones have the fastest lines? The nicest areas to wait? Where is it always slow? What are the best times to go? What are the worst? Please write your recommendations (or your complaints) in the comments below.

title: Nocciolata, a Different Version of Nutella
description: Nutella may seem synonymous with chocolate-hazelnut spreads, but there are other brands. Nocciolata, an Italian import that is new to New York, makes a creamier version with a consistency a little closer to a sauce than a spread. The flavor of toasted hazelnuts is somewhat more pronounced than that of Nutella, and it has a slightly higher proportion of nuts. Warm it and put it over ice cream, and you just might retire the jar of hot fudge for the summer.

title: Radish, a New Food Shop in Brooklyn
description: At the rate things are going, Brooklyn will soon have more charming country stores than Woodstock, Vt. The latest is Radish, a prepared-food shop in Williamsburg with adequate shelf space to display products made by bakers, artisan pickle-makers and chocolatiers from the borough. Amy Marks (at right) and Laura Migliozzi, former techies who own the place, had the good sense to bring in Katy Sparks, a local professional, to work with their chef, Mike Ciardi. On any given day, youll find several casseroles of hot dishes like macaroni and cheese, curried chicken or shepherds pie. You could easily anchor dinner with choices from an appealing and frequently changing assortment of salads and cold dishes, like asparagus with pistachios and Manchego; orzo with sugar snap peas; roasted carrots; roasted fingerling potatoes scored so that they look like gnocchi; savory tartlets; and a few meat dishes, including lamb burgers and steak. There are also sandwiches ready to go.

title: In New York, Local Meat Is Easier to Find
description: SO what does a cook have to do to get a Scottish Highland certified organic grass-fed steak in this town?

title: Dining Calendar
description: Herein, Herring

title: Ancient Manna on Modern Menus
description: AFTER several weeks of wandering the desert after their escape from Egypt, the Israelites were hungry, the Bible says, and started grumbling.

title: Buy a Platter, Help a Fish
description: Finding a house gift for a summer weekend, some beachside serving dishes or a wedding present that represents more than just a pretty plate can make the giving or owning more satisfying. Annie Morhauser, who has been hand-crafting glass tableware in Watsonville, Calif., for 27 years, has introduced sea-themed swimming-pool-blue plates that benefit the Seafood Watch program of the Monterey Bay Aquarium, which distributes buying guides for sustainable seafood. There are several sizes, each with shells, starfish and other creatures in relief.

title: Otarian
description: 947 Eighth Avenue (West 56th Street), Midtown, (212) 489-3270; 154 Bleecker Street (Thompson Street), Greenwich Village, (212) 614-6834, otarian.com.

title: Whitman and Fiorina Win in Calif.; Lincoln Prevails in Ark.
description: WASHINGTON  Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman, who ascended to the top of the business world before turning to politics, prevailed on Tuesday in their respective battles for the Republican nominations for the United States Senate and governor in California, setting the stage for costly general election fights this fall.

title: Strasburg Takes Mound With Style
description: 9:25 p.m. | Updated with Strasburg pitching seven inningsWASHINGTON  Stephen Strasburg started his major league career with a flourish Tuesday, retiring the side in the top of the first inning, then striking out three in the second.

description: Openings

description: 339A Second Street (Fifth Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-7040.

description: A house in a quiet residential neighborhood five minutes from the Baltic Sea.

title: On the Cusp of Nobility After a Life of Obscurity
description: MARBELLA, Spain  Jos Collado was 49 years old when he finally met his mother, and it took some coaxing before she would tell him who his father was. The answer stunned him.

title: Pearl Buck in China
description: Chapter 1 :Family of Ghosts

title: The Meteoric Rise, and Decline, of a Talented Young Writer
description: When Pearl Bucks second novel, The Good Earth, was named a Book-of-the-Month Club selection in 1931, its author was so innocent about the New York literary world that she shyly asked her publisher, Do they know that I am not a member of their club?

title: Popular New Drinking Game Raises Question, Whos Icing Whom?
description: NO sooner had Alex Rospos arrived from Los Angeles for a Memorial Day weekend on the Jersey Shore than he witnessed, and fell victim to, his first prolonged session playing what has become the nations biggest viral drinking game, otherwise known as icing.

title: South African Team Unites Under Pressure
description: Johannesburg

title: Israel Makes Case to China for Iran Sanctions
description: JERUSALEM  During the many months China has wavered over whether to join the American-led effort to impose sanctions on Iran, Israeli officials have been waging their own quiet campaign to convince the Chinese that Iran should be punished for its renegade nuclear program.

title: Even More Twists and Turns for Aspen Festival
description: When the corporation of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, made up mostly of the board of trustees and the faculty, rendered a vote of no confidence in the festivals president and chief executive, Alan Fletcher, in April, Rob LeBuhn, then the board chairman, said, We will only know what the practical effects are later.

title: Switzerland Rejects Deal to Share Banking Data
description: Swiss lawmakers on Tuesday rejected a deal to hand over to United States authorities data on more than 4,000 wealthy Americans suspected of evading taxes with the help of the Swiss bank UBS, a move that could bring the bank a step closer to indictment, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Justices Block Matching Funds for Candidates in Arizona
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday barred officials in Arizona from providing matching funds to candidates for state office who accept public financing, a program meant to help them keep pace with the unlimited spending of candidates who do not take public financing.

title: Marian Hossa Hopes to Win the Cup on His Third Try
description: PHILADELPHIA  For the third straight year, with his third different team, Marian Hossa is playing for the Stanley Cup. Maybe Wednesday night, he will finally win it.

title: With Every Step, Seemingly, a Story
description: Is the choreographer Christopher Williams trying to tell us stories without having the storytellers gift? Or is he trying to weave in and out of stories we dont know as if they mattered to him but not enough to tell them onstage? The questions arise because the two new works hes presenting this week at Dance New Amsterdam,  Gobbledygook (a work in progress) and Hens Teeth, show how deep his mind is mired in stories, stories, stories.

title: A Few Steps Short on Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  One of the political mysteries of the last year is why the White House and Congress have not been even more aggressive about trying to put people back to work.

title: Tomlinson Relishes New Home, and New Opportunity
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J.  LaDainian Tomlinson counted down his final days in San Diego: three nights left in the house he built, two meals remaining at his favorite restaurant, one last goodbye to the city that embraced him.

title: Together More Than 70 Years, Friends Reunite
description: The moment they spied one another, the needling began, the way it always did.

title: European Leaders Back Stricter Oversight of National Budgets
description: LUXEMBOURG  European Union finance ministers agreed Tuesday on far-reaching steps to tighten oversight of national governments budgets and crack down on falsification of economic data.

title: China: Irans President to Visit Pavilion at Shanghai Expo
description: Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, plans to attend the World Expo in Shanghai on Friday to take part in celebrating the Iranian pavilion there, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, said Tuesday at a news conference in Beijing. Irans pavilion is next to the North Korean pavilion, and Mr. Qin said it was unclear whether Mr. Ahmadinejad would meet with the Chinese president, Hu Jintao, because Mr. Hus schedule had not yet been fixed yet. Mr. Ahmadinejads visit comes as the United States and other Western countries are seeking to impose new sanctions on Iran for continuing with its nuclear program, which Western officials say is aimed at making a nuclear weapon. Iran denies the accusations. China and Russia have said they are willing to discuss the option of sanctions.

title: Obama Lobbies Elderly on Benefits of Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama dipped back into the volatile politics of health care on Tuesday, using a televised question-and-answer session to attack his Republican critics and remind retirees that the check  a new $250 rebate to help them pay for prescription drugs  is about to go in the mail.

title: Stylistically Omnivorous and Erasing Boundaries
description: The League of Composers/International Society for Contemporary Music has long presented chamber concerts devoted to recent scores, but last year the organization expanded its purview by assembling a chamber orchestra. It was a sensible idea: new-music chamber groups are thick on the ground in New York, but only a handful of orchestras specialize in contemporary works.

title: Photo Replay: June 8
description: A view of the day in sports across the world, from soccer to truck pulls.

title: Italian Works Lead an American Debut
description: The Orchestra Sinfonica di Roma, a youthful ensemble founded in 2002 and privately financed, made its American debut at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, starting a seven-city tour. Francesco La Vecchia conducted it in works mostly by neglected Italian composers.

title: Unpublished Sci-Fi Manuscripts by Stieg Larsson
description: Before you become a posthumous worldwide literary sensation you may want to reread the work you wrote as a teenager and make sure that it too is ready for posterity. Case in point: The national library of Sweden said that it had recently acquired several unpublished manuscripts by Stieg Larsson, right, the author of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, Agence France-Presse reported. They were written by Mr. Larsson at around age 17, long before he became a journalist and novelist, when he was hoping to break in as a writer of genre fiction. We have received material from a small archive from a periodical called the Jules Verne Magazine, and in that small archive there were some manuscripts by the author Stieg Larsson that were never published, Magdalena Gram, the deputy national librarian of Sweden, told Agence France-Presse. These were works in the science-fiction genre, she said. Mr. Larsson died at 50 in 2004, before publication of his three Millennium novels.

title: Guatemala: Frustrated, Chief of Corruption Panel Resigns
description: Carlos Castresana, the Spanish judge leading a United Nations commission charged with fighting Guatemalas corruption and impunity, has given up in frustration. After two and a half years at the head of the commission, known as Cicig, Mr. Castresana, above, resigned on Monday, saying that Guatemala had failed to keep promises to follow the panels recommendations. The catalyst for his resignation was the appointment of Guatemalas new attorney general, Conrado Reyes. Mr. Castresana accused Mr. Reyes of having ties to illegal adoption rings and drug traffickers.

title: Lester Johnsons Paintings
description: A selection of paintings by the figurative expressionist Lester Johnson, who died on May 30.

title: Lester Johnson, Expressionist Painter, Dies at 91
description: Lester Johnson, an admired artist whose expressionist brushwork lent vigor and force to the human figure  isolated and embattled, or alive with the joy of movement in crowds  died on May 30. He was 91 and lived in Southampton on Long Island.

title: Pierce, the Voice of the Celtics, Asserts Himself
description: In the thrust and parry of a championship series, the Los Angeles Lakers can deploy vast resources to deter Paul Pierce. If Pierce shoots, Ron Artest contests. If Pierce drives, Andrew Bynum and Pau Gasol meet him in the lane.

title: Strasburg Strikes Out 14 in Majors Debut
description: WASHINGTON

title: Turkey Goes From Pliable Ally to Thorn for U.S.
description: ANKARA, Turkey  For decades, Turkey was one of the United States most pliable allies, a strategic border state on the edge of the Middle East that reliably followed American policy. But recently, it has asserted a new approach in the region, its words and methods as likely to provoke Washington as to advance its own interests.

title: Legacy for One Billionaire: Death, but No Taxes
description: A Texas pipeline tycoon who died two months ago may become the first American billionaire allowed to pass his fortune to his children and grandchildren tax-free.

title: Live Analysis: Game 3 of the N.B.A. Finals
description: After two games, both teams in the finals had a victory and something to complain about  primarily the officiating.

title: The Human Phenome Project
description: In 1884, a man called Francis Galton opened the doors of his Anthropometric Laboratory. This was for the use of those who desire to be accurately measured in many ways, either to obtain timely warning of remediable faults in development, or to learn their powers. The many ways included height, hand strength, acuity of sight and hearing, lung capacity and the power of a blow with the fist.

title: 155 Workers, 6 Young Men, 1 Fiscal Mess
description: Every day brings dreadful news of some worthy cause that is going to be cut because government budgets are being hit with cannonballs.

title: 6 Die in Attack on Supply Rigs in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  About 30 NATO trailers carrying oil and other supplies from Pakistan to Afghanistan were burned late Tuesday night while stopped at a depot on the outskirts of Islamabad, killing at least six people, the police and local television reported.

title: Stimulus Talk Yields to Calls to Cut Deficits
description: WASHINGTON  At a moment when many economists warn that the American economic recovery is likely to be imperiled by prolonged high unemployment and slow growth, President Obama is discovering that the tools available to him last year  a big economic stimulus and action by the Federal Reserve  are both now politically untenable.

title: Keeping Politics Safe for the Rich
description: In a burst of judicial activism, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upended the gubernatorial race in Arizona, cutting off matching funds to candidates participating in the states public campaign finance system. Suddenly, three candidates, including Gov. Jan Brewer, can no longer receive public funds they had counted on to run against a free-spending wealthy opponent.

title: Amish Farming Draws Rare Government Scrutiny
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  With simplicity as their credo, Amish farmers consume so little that some might consider them model environmental citizens.

title: Fed Finding Status Quo in Bank Pay
description: Federal regulators reviewing the compensation policies of major banks are finding that the industry has not adequately adjusted its pay practices to reduce risk-taking.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,080 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Behind a Military Chill: A More Forceful China
description: BEIJING  If anyone ever doubted it, a testy exchange at a Singapore conference last weekend made it clear: Relations between the American and Chinese militaries are in a very deep freeze.

title: Albanys So-Called Governing
description: New York States budget is 10 weeks late, Albanys legislators are still trying to dodge any tough decisions and Gov. David Paterson has finally gotten fed up. He is pressing legislators to add parts of the annual budget to the weekly emergency spending bills that are keeping the state running. Legislators have a choice: They can pass the short-term budget bills with the extras attached or they can shut down the government.

title: Still No Shelter
description: The only thing that seems to be moving relentlessly ahead in Haiti is the weather, with punishing heat and near-daily thunderstorms settling in for the summer  and the hurricane season that just begun. Meanwhile, more than a million people are still displaced, many in tent cities with little protection from the storms. And Haitis government has no clear strategy to get them out of the camps and into more secure shelter any time soon.

title: Yankees Hope First-Round Pick Is Jeters Successor
description: BALTIMORE  In four or five years, Derek Jeter may be ready to finish his Hall of Fame career with the Yankees. In four or five years, Cito Culver may be ready to replace Jeter, his favorite player, at shortstop.

title: City Services for Families in Trouble Could Be Cut
description: The beating death of a 7-year-old, Nixzmary Brown, at the hands of her stepfather in 2006 helped prompt a series of reforms in New Yorks child protection services, including a greater emphasis on providing intensive services to families with problems, from domestic abuse to mental illness, that put children in danger.

title: The Romance of Jack the Ripper
description: SOME girls will buy a cheap leather jacket and run it through the Maytag, or take a Brillo to a pristine pair of combat boots, roughing them up for that Ive seen action at Glastonbury feel. Those girls are apt to be found haunting AllSaints Spitalfields, the British retail chain and purveyor of a romantically pre-aged look  all dun-colored bustle skirts, fatigued leather satchels and battered canvas boots that conjure a sepia-tone universe straight out of the gaslight era.

title: The Digital Pulse
description: Just how adaptable are humans? That is the question underlying pervasive worries about the impact of modern technology, especially the boom in the use of personal laptops and hand-held devices, like the iPad and smartphones. Are we becoming skilled multitaskers? Or are we sacrificing our attention to long-term goals for the more primitive gratification of skimming tweets and e-mail messages? There are indeed some gloomy answers to these questions, the kind described in Matt Richtels article about the Campbell family in The Times on Monday.

title: Abortion Drugs Given in Iowa via Video Link
description: DES MOINES  The situation has played out hundreds of times. From his office here, a doctor asks a woman on the computer screen before him one final question: Are you ready to take your pill?

title: Carriers Criticize German Air Fare Tax
description: BERLIN  Germanys plan to introduce an environmental tax of 1 billion euros a year on air travel tickets met with fierce resistance on Tuesday from airlines, which accused Berlin of making a shortsighted cash grab at the expense of an industry still struggling to return to profitability.

title: More Evidence of Drop in Donations
description: Charitable giving fell again last year, reflecting the continued impact of the economic downturn on donations. The Giving USA Foundation, a research organization governed by fund-raising professionals, estimates that individuals and institutions gave away $303.75 billion in 2009, a decrease of 3.2 percent on an inflation-adjusted basis. Other surveys have reported steeper declines, and charities anecdotally report that fund-raising was more difficult last year than in 2008 when the crisis began. For instance, a survey by Target Analytics of direct-mail fund-raising by 79 organizations found those revenues had fallen by a median 4.8 percent, with fewer than one-third of the participants reporting increases. A recent survey released by the Association of Fundraising Professionals found that individual giving had declined 4.9 percent last year to $217.3 billion, while the Giving USA survey found such giving to be virtually flat.

title: Texas Instruments Bolsters Forecast
description: Texas Instruments said on Tuesday that its sales and profit would be at the upper end of earlier forecasts, buoyed by demand for industrial machinery.

title: Blagojevich Was Led Astray, Lawyer Tells Jurors
description: CHICAGO  A lawyer for Rod R. Blagojevich offered jurors here a first impression of his client on Tuesday, and the portrait was, by design, rather dim: the former governor of Illinois, the lawyer said, is an insecure man, a serial telephone dialer (of friends who often stop answering), and a C student who surrounded himself with people he should not have trusted and is now nearly broke (because he never stole a thing).

title: Convictions for Former Duane Reade Executives
description: The former chief executive of Duane Reade, Anthony Cuti, was convicted on Tuesday of conspiracy and securities fraud for misleading investors in the drugstore chain.

title: Drawing Fire: Stay With Us
description: This is the third installment of a five-part series. To read from the beginning, go to Drawing Fire: Into Ubaydi.

title: U.S. Delays Release of Report Tying Meth to Mexico
description: WASHINGTON  In an apparent effort to minimize diplomatic turbulence with the Mexican government, the Obama administration has been delaying for weeks the release of a Justice Department report that describes a high and increasing availability of methamphetamine mainly because of large-scale drug production in Mexico.

title: Times Picks Vogue Editor to Lead T Magazine
description: Sally Singer, the fashion news and features director at Vogue, has been named the editor of T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

title: Founder Puts Blackwater Security Firm Up for Sale
description: WASHINGTON  Burdened by lawsuits, criminal investigations and negative publicity stemming from its private security work in Iraq and Afghanistan, Blackwater Worldwide is being put up for sale, the company has announced.

title: From Career in Minors to a Night in the Majors
description: As reporters and television cameramen crowded around, Jesus Feliciano planted himself on a chair in front of his new locker in the Mets clubhouse Tuesday after batting practice. Then he reconsidered and stood up.

title: McDonalds Offers Cash in Recall of Shrek Glasses
description: McDonalds is taking the unusual step of paying customers a premium to return Shrek drinking glasses that it has recalled because of concerns that cadmium used in the paint on the glasses could come off on childrens hands.

title: Afghanistan Strategy Focuses on Civilian Effort
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The prospect of a robust military push in Kandahar Province, which had been widely expected to begin this month, has evolved into a strategy that puts civilian reconstruction efforts first and relegates military action to a supportive role.

title: Heart-Transplant Recipient Is in Open
description: After struggling on Sunday in the wind at the Memorial Tournament, Erik Compton, a two-time heart-transplant recipient from Miami, admitted he was thinking about withdrawing from the United States Open qualifier in Springfield, Ohio. He was worn out, and 36 holes of grinding it out on Monday was a little more than he felt he could do.

title: Report on Zimbabwe Diamond Trade Angers Rights Groups
description: JOHANNESBURG  A monitor for the United Nations-backed body charged with halting the illegal trade in diamonds that finance conflict has recommended that Zimbabwe be allowed to export the stones, prompting condemnations from human rights groups that say the countrys military is still deeply involved in smuggling and violence against local miners.

description: CHICAGO  A week after pitching a perfect game in what fate declared an imperfect game, Armando Galarraga was back on the mound for the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday at U.S. Cellular Field. But this time it was not an umpires blown call that cost Galarraga a perfect game.

title: Border Shooting Strains Tensions With Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexican authorities expressed fury at the shooting death of a Mexican teenager on Monday night by a Border Patrol agent, while the FBI, which is investigating the death, said the agent had been under attack by rock-throwing migrants attempting to cross into El Paso, Texas.

description: Facing questions about whether a high-ranking prosecutors actions during a murder investigation and trial constituted misconduct, the Brooklyn district attorneys office agreed on Tuesday to allow a man imprisoned in that case to have his murder conviction vacated and his record cleared with the assurance that he will not be retried.

title: A Gift for Grads: Start-Ups
description: If you have a son or daughter graduating from college this year, youve probably gotten the word. When meeting this years college grads its best not to ask: Hey, what are you doing next year? Too many recent graduates dont have an answer. They cant find jobs even remotely related to their fields.
