title: Jeff Beck Leads Les Paul Tribute at Iridium
description: Les Paul, the father of the electric guitar, often used to say that the favorite of his many disciples was Jeff Beck, a two-time inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame for his work as a member of the Yardbirds and as a solo artist. Mr. Beck, in turn, has always said that his interest in the instrument was born when he heard How High the Moon on the radio as a 6-year-old. So when Iridium, the New York City jazz club where Les Paul had a Monday-night residency until his death last year, was looking for someone to lead a tribute to Paul, Mr. Beck was the logical choice.

title: Berlin Rejects Aid for G.M.s Opel Unit
description: FRANKFURT  The German government rejected on Wednesday a request for 1.1 billion euros ($1.32 billion) in aid for the struggling Opel/Vauxhall unit of General Motors, a decision the company attributed to the climate of budget austerity that has gripped Berlin.

title: A Long Journey to Vietnam
description: Monday, June 7: Hue, Vietnam

title: Answers About Social Security: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Australian Firm Sues Goldman Over Timberwolf Deal
description: For Goldman Sachs, the legal hits keep coming.

title: A Weekend in Brussels
description: The Belgian capital gets its share of commuters pouring off the Eurostar. Luckily, the ties come off after work.

title: Retracing Jeffersons Steps in Burgundy
description: In 1787, Thomas Jefferson visited the vineyards of Burgundy to study a winemaking tradition that stretched back to the 11th century.

title: Finalists Named in Ogilvy Brick Contest
description: A contest sponsored by OgilvyOne Worldwide, to find the worlds greatest salesperson, has been narrowed to three finalists, all of whom will get trips to Cannes, France, to make their cases live on stage during an event at the Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival.

title: Maliki Says Iraq Needs Him as Leader
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, struggling for his political future in a snarled, months-long contest to form a new government here, warned Wednesday that failure to return him to power would lead to Iraqs descent into the violence and sectarian strife that dominated the country when he took over in 2006.

title: Inside the Wizarding World of Harry Potter
description: The amusement park at the Universal Orlando Resort was made for Pottermaniacs who have more or less memorized J. K. Rowlings books.

title: Cassandra Redeemed
description: First came the Nouriel Roubinis, the Dean Bakers and the Robert Shillers of the profession: the few economists whose warnings about the impending financial crisis were ignored during the housing boom. Then came Edward Hugh.

title: A Cult Denim Line Goes Mass
description: When the designer Anne Johnston Albert shut down her East Village label and shop, Martin, in 2005 to move to Great Barrington, Massachusetts, cult-like fans of her jeans were, to put it mildly, dismayed. Martin resurfaced online, but the experience wasnt quite the same. In the store, you can tell whats going to work on someone the minute she walks in, she says. But when youre answering questions via e-mail, youre working in the dark. I missed having the interaction with customers. You can now have that personal experience again, but you will have to travel to Great Barrington. Germain, the clothing and home dcor shop Alberts opened with the interior designer Elena Litteron, features a carefully edited collection of jeans, tanks and easy dresses as well as mid-century furniture, pillows made from Swiss army blankets and other vintage fabrics, and pottery and photography by local artists. Though the new digs are decidedly more bucolic, Martin fans are essentially the same. In the East Village, I had young rocker chicks, Albert says. This is a wider clientele. But no matter their age, everyone wants cool clothes that look good. And the allure of perfectly fitting jeans remains as strong as ever. I wasnt familiar with Annes line before we opened the store, says Litteron. But Im a convert. Theyre the only jeans I wear now.

title: Mayor Sprinkles Wisdom Here and There
description: You can learn a lot about Michael R. Bloomberg, it turns out, from what he says at graduation ceremonies. He claims to have never had a bad day. He hates legalese. And he tries to call his mother every day.

title: TimesCast: Incumbents and Red Ink
description: On todays TimesCast, Jeff Zeleny talks about the results of Tuesday nights primaries, which didnt turn out to to be as bad for sitting lawmakers as Washington had feared. But they can hardly be carefree. With the economy still sluggish and the chairman of the Federal Reserve saying today that debts are unsustainable, Graham Bowley looks at an alternative to stimulus.

title: Obama Pledges New Aid to Palestinians
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged the Israeli government to loosen its blockade of Gaza on Wednesday, as the United States continued to scramble to find a way out of the stalemate in the Middle East and address the outcry over Israels deadly raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla last week.

title: A BP Parody Is Asked (by BP) to Declare That Its Not Real
description: The operator of a Twitter feed that exists to mock BP and its response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was asked by the oil company this week to specify that the feed was just a fake.

title: Life as a Runway | Curiosities, in the Arts and Sciences
description: The Karole Armitage dance companys benefit gala and auction in Chelsea drew artists, dancers and Salman Rushdie.

title: Climate in an Impolitic World
description: The public radio program Marketplace is hosting an all-day conference and webcast, Moving by Degrees, examining various aspects of the interlaced climate and energy challenges.

title: Caitlin Flanagans 1970s Nostalgia
description: Caitlin Flanagan has an essay in the June Atlantic that returns to one of her recurring themes: The coarseness of contemporary sexual culture and its impact on the souls of teenage girls. Along the way, she portrays her own 1970s teenage-hood as a more idealistic time, and posits that her own mother and women like her  liberals and feminists who believed in doing away with sexual double standards and helping their daughters incorporate sexual lives within a normal teenage girlhood  would react to the kinds of sexual experiences that so many American girls are now having  [with] horror and indignation.

title: Artest, Inelegant but Effective, Adds Muscle for Lakers
description: BOSTON  Ray Allens jump shot is the essence of basketball grace. Ron Artests game brings to mind the grinding of beef. After the two players collided early in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals on Tuesday night, Allen was on the floor and suddenly the stunning form that had lifted him to a record eight 3-pointers in Game 2 vanished along with Paul Pierces fantasy of having seen the last of Los Angeles.

title: Where Did All the Angry Voters Go?
description: Gail Collins: David, Im shocked by the lack of team spirit shown by Arkansas Democrats in their Senate primary. Here we had a perfectly good scenario going about angry voters and doomed incumbents and the end of political moderation. Then they go and renominate Blanche Lincoln. Who is not only an incumbent but an incumbent wishy-washy moderate. Whose re-election campaign has basically been: Im head of the Agriculture Committee. Let me stay in Washington and continue to get you stuff.

title: Oh, to Be Young and a Star
description: IN the final minutes before the fashion industrys big awards night on June 7, the lobby of Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center reflected the broad spectrum of ages, backgrounds and experience of the talents who make up the American design community. There was a curious mix of the old guard (Carolina Herrera, Donna Karan, Betsey Johnson) and the new (Alexander Wang, Joseph Altuzarra, Jason Wu), and you could listen in as one neophyte designer reflected on her recent work:

title: Resort Report | DVFs Gallant Era
description: Diane Von Furstenberg used an Ara Gallant photo of herself circa 1983 to set the tone for her 2010/2011 Resort show. The feeling of the collection was a modern womans boudoir, with models standing in front of a mirrored bedroom-like setup before they took to the runway in clothes that were graphic, simple and sporty. You can envision a modern sexy woman mixing the swimsuits with high-waisted shorts and mens silk shirts.

title: Behind the Set of Buddy Cop 2
description: Buddy Cop 2, a new play by the Brooklyn troupe Debate Society, takes place in the 1980s inside a temporary police station built on the basketball court of a small-town recreation center. Adjacent to the station is a racquetball court.

title: How Much Would You Spend on a Sick Pet?
description: How much is your pets health worth to you?

title: Taliban Aim at Officials in a Wave of Killings
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have been stepping up a campaign of assassinations in recent months against officials and anyone else associated with local government in an attempt to undermine counterinsurgency operations in the south.

title: Line-Item Veto Alternative Offered
description: Taking their lead from President Obamas recent proposal, a bipartisan group of senators on Wednesday introduced a bill to empower him and future presidents to get a quick vote in Congress on deleting spending items from annual appropriations measures soon after they have been signed into law.

title: Overbooking Gifted Programs at P.S. 163
description: The main office of Public School 163 on West 97th Street in Manhattan was filled with parents Wednesday who had been through the wringer of the kindergarten admissions process and were hoping they were near its end.

title: Simple Subtraction Leads to Confusion Over Saving of G.M. Dealerships
description: The Detroit Free Press reported on Wednesday morning that General Motors would be saving 900 more dealerships than planned.

title: Greater New Yorkers | Ei Arakawa
description: The Moment homes in on five artists from Greater New York, an exhibition that runs through Oct. 18 at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

title: Curtain Times for El Bullis Last Act May Change
description: At the end of his forthcoming biography of the chef Ferran Adri, Colman Andrews has a scoop on the last days of El Bulli (or at least, El Bulli as the world now knows it).

title: New Rankings in Midterm Contests
description: The latest ranking of House, Senate and governors contests by The New York Times finds that Senator Harry Reids race in Nevada is now a Tossup.

title: A Clash in Texas Over Air Pollution
description: HOUSTON  For 16 years, a showdown has been brewing between Texas and federal environmental officials over the states unique way of regulating industrial air pollution, which many critics complain is lax and has led to some of the dirtiest air in the country.

title: Jack Johnson Takes To the Sea to Top of Charts
description: The latest laid-back album from Jack Johnson ran away with the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. To the Sea (Brushfire), Mr. Johnsons fifth studio album, sold 243,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) came in a distant second, with 52,000 in sales, while Glee: The Music, Volume 3  Showstoppers (Columbia), came in third after two weeks as No. 1, with 45,000.

title: The Strange Case of Station 01
description: When the government and university researchers confirmed the existence of underwater plumes, or layers of dispersed oil in the Gulf of Mexico, on Tuesday, their report included a puzzling piece of information.

title: Answers From a Brooklyn Blogger
description: Following is the first set of responses from Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest.

title: For True World Cup Flavor, Visit an Ethnic Joint
description: The search for ethnic soccer joints continues.

title: Berlin Rejects Aid for G.M.s Opel Unit
description: 1:13 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Jack Ewing has more.

title: Seth Kugel: The New Frugal Traveler
description: This summer, Seth Kugel is taking the long and frugal way home -- from So Paulo back to New York City -- on less than $500 a week.

title: On Dance: A New Direction for the Martha Graham Dance Company
description: This week the Martha Graham Dance Company debuts a new approach to its overall mission. The company, which has been the dance-world guinea pig when it comes to grappling with the challenges of maintaining a company after a founding choreographers death, now wants audiences to see the troupe as a living museum, keeping the classics alive while also offering new works inspired by them.

title: How to Spot an A.T.M. Skimming Device
description: Thieves used fake debit cards to steal more than $200,000 from four Bank of America branches on Long Island this year, according to reports this week in The Wall Street Journal, Newsday and other news media outlets.

title: Following World Cup, Phone in Hand
description: When the World Cup opens this week, numerous apps will be able to help fans to keep track of the action on the field. And while watching live on a smartphone will be possible for some users, the options can be confusing, and they are not all free.

title: Makeup to Help Flaws Disappear
description: ONE day life was good. All it took was concealer for my under-eye circles, a swoosh of bronzer, and I was out the door. I wore no foundation, and I had no qualms.

title: Israel Widens Supplies Allowed Into Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israel has broadened the variety of foods allowed through its land crossings into Gaza, officials on both sides said on Wednesday, but Israel denied that this signaled any change in policy toward the Hamas-run enclave as a result of international pressure.

title: The Right Kind of Bar Food for the World Cup
description: South Africa, where the World Cup soccer tournament begins Friday, has a global reputation for wine, but its food  like that of most of Africa  is little known here.

title: 2nd Fire at Apartment Building Draws Scrutiny
description: When a fire broke out atop a Gilded Age apartment house at 72nd Street and Columbus Avenue late one April night, the fire trucks swarmed. From a bar across the street, the crowd watched the firefighters clamber up the building. Once upstairs, they hosed down a blaze on the roof deck outside a duplex.

title: Wall Street Pay Plunged in 2009
description: From Patrick McGeehan on City Room:

title: Chart: Big Bois General Patton
description: The artist Andrew Kuo charts the new song from the Outkast rapper. His solo debut album will be released on July 6.

title: Ristretto | Strada
description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

title: Tips for Applying Foundation
description: Applying foundation can be hard to get right, but makeup professionals say that a little practice pays off. A few tips:

title: Googles AdMob Fears Being Excluded From iPhone
description: The war of words between Google and Apple over mobile ads sharpened on Wednesday.

title: Does Tourettes Run in Families?
description: Dozens of readers had questions about Tourette syndrome, the odd and poorly understood disorder that causes uncontrollable tics and vocalizations, after the disorder was profiled in a recent Patient Voices series. Here, Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine respond to readers wondering whether Tourettes is inherited and how common the disorder is.

title: The New Face of Hip-Hop
description: LOS ANGELES

title: New Video on Spill, and Growing Concern on BP Leadership
description: As CNN explains, BP has released high-quality video images of oil flowing from its damaged well, after pressure from Democratic Senators Barbara Boxer and Bill Nelson, who demanded full access to all video to allow independent experts to make a better estimate of just how much oil is flowing into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Jazz, Featuring Chopin and Bach
description: You might not think of Le Poisson Rouge as the ideal place for an organ recital: for one thing, it lacks an organ. But an organist can bring a portable one, and that is what Cameron Carpenter did on Tuesday evening, though not without some backstage drama.

title: Studies Show Jews Genetic Similarity
description: Jewish communities in Europe and the Middle East share many genes inherited from the ancestral Jewish population that lived in the Middle East some 3,000 years ago, even though each community also carries genes from other sources  usually the country in which it lives.

title: Clover Club to Open for Lunch
description: When it first opened in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, in 2008, Julie Reiners Clover Club became one of the first high-end cocktail bars in New York to explore the world of daylight hours, serving brunch, with brunch-oriented libations ranging far beyond the Bloody Mary and mimosa.

title: At the Reisinger, the Defense Knew Just What to Discard
description: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a weeklong event starting on Memorial Day. Recently, though, the number of entries has plunged. This year eight strong teams competed over four days, the winners being Christal Henner-Welland, Uday Ivatury and Roy Welland of New York and Jaggy Shivdasani of Pleasantville, N.Y. In the final, at the Manhattan Bridge Club, they defeated Margie Gwozdzinsky, David Gurvich, Ira Herman and Michael Lipkin of New York and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.

title: Europe Refuses to Be Rushed on Regulation
description: The European Commission on Wednesday rebuffed claims from Germany and France that it was moving too slowly to regulate risky financial practices and said that a consensus was needed among all members of the 27-nation bloc before a decision was made, The New York Timess James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Brooklyn Goes to the Movies
description: A look at some of the films appearing in BAMcinemaFEST.

title: Fashion Statements of All Types
description: YOU have to go through the propaganda to get to the ice cream, said Long Nguyen, the editor of Flaunt magazine, in the narrow garden outside of Gavin Browns art gallery on Greenwich Street in the West Village.

title: Student Accused of Lying to Harvard Was Admitted to Stanford, Too
description: Adam Wheeler, the Delaware man charged with lying about his credentials to get into Harvard and to secure nearly $50,000 in financial aid and prizes, was later admitted to Stanford as a transfer student, Massachusetts prosecutors said in court documents released Wednesday.

title: Obama to Write Foreword for Mandela Book
description: President Obama is making a brief return to friendly territory: the book industry.

title: Sole Female Candidate for Oxfords Poetry Professor Withdraws
description: At a time when Oxford University would surely like to move beyond the unpleasant memories of last years disputed election for its professor of poetry position, a new controversy has opened up around that chair.

title: Resort Report | Max Azria, Out of Africa
description: Maybe Max Azria was getting excited about the World Cup when he decided to base his eponymous Resort collection on Peter Beards portraits of Lauren Hutton in Africa. The collection uses airy fabrics and a neutral palette. Im looking forward to wearing the simple long T-shirt dresses in half jersey/half silk walking down the beach on a far flung island. A girl can dream, right?

title: Chinatown Buses Unveiling New Routes
Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Militants attacked dozens of trucks ferrying vehicles for Western troops in Afghanistan early Wednesday near the Pakistani capital, The Associated Press reported, a bold assault that killed seven people and illustrated the vulnerability of a crucial United States supply line. Militants and ordinary criminals have often attacked NATO and American supply convoys over the past two years, but Wednesdays strike was the first so close to the well-protected capital, something likely to cause particular unease. Much of the fuel and supplies for Western troops in Afghanistan travels through Pakistan after arriving in the port city of Karachi.

title: Stand-Up Comics Sit Down Together
description: Paul Provenza reprises the role of social director on the stand-up comedy cruise ship in The Green Room With Paul Provenza, a six-week comics roundtable that begins Thursday night on Showtime. As he did nearly 20 years ago on Comics Only, his Comedy Central talk show, and again in the 2005 documentary The Aristocrats, Mr. Provenza promises to take viewers behind the scenes  Youre not supposed to be here, but if youre cool, you can come and hang, he says at the beginning of each half-hour episode  while providing exposure for as many of his compatriots as possible.

title: Developer Accused of Looting Downtown Buildings Reserve Fund
description: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, is suing the developer of a troubled downtown luxury building, saying he stole $7.4 million from its reserve fund and demanding he compensate buyers of apartments there.

title: When to Buy Your Child a Cellphone
description: David Poger had planned to buy his daughter Maya a cellphone when she was 15 and in high school, but last year he and his wife caved when she was 11.

title: Mets Draft Mostly College Players
description: 10:14 p.m. | Updated

title: Stiglitz Calls for Goldman Sachs Amendment
description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, wants the financial regulatory bill to bar financial firms that give up their government-backed bank charters from ever being able to seek government assistance again.

title: A Race Against Time for Gulf Fishermen
description: Insular by custom and geography, the fishermen of Delacroix Island in Louisiana have even less time now for outsiders  especially outsiders with Canons hanging from their shoulders  as they race to catch what blue crabs they can before the oil leaking from the Deepwater Horizon well closes their fishery entirely.

title: The Nobodies Album
description: Chapter 1

title: After a Picture From the Gulf, Thousands of Words
description: In Wednesdays TimesCast video, my colleague Brian Stelter suggested that the photos of birds mired in oil had supercharged public interest in the coverage of the Gulf oil spill nearly seven weeks into the slow-moving disaster.

title: In Search of Lonely Diners and Unbought Bloggers
description: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | Few scenes of New York City are as iconic the one depicted in Edward Hoppers painting Nighthawks. Based, as The Times, among many others, has noted, on a restaurant on Greenwich Avenue, a street that runs at a sharp Hopperesque angle to several Village streets, Hoppers long-demolished diner offered the painter, as it does the viewer, a noirish window onto the penetrating loneliness that lies at the heart of modern urban life.

title: You Cant Run From Past, but You Can Rewrite It
description: Carolyn Parkhursts third novel is about Octavia Frost, a woman who is famous for her best-selling novels. Octavia deserves to be equally famous for being unpleasant. And Ms. Parkhurst deserves credit for twisting her characters sourness into an unlikely selling point for The Nobodies Album, just as she made human-canine communication a boon for her first book, The Dogs of Babel.

title: Upfronts: And Then There Was One
description: ABC has become of the fourth of the five big English-language television broadcasters to finish the sale of commercial time before the start of the coming season.

title: Iran Halts Production of Neda Figures
description: TEHRAN  A factory in Iran has been closed down after trying to mass-produce statuettes of people who were killed in the protests that followed last years disputed presidential election, among them Neda Agha-Soltan, the 26-year-old who became an icon of the opposition when a video of her shooting was broadcast around the world.

title: Vintage Filings LLC
description: Shai Stern, the C.E.O. of Vintage Filings LLC, explains how he saved his company after the market collapsed.

title: Resort Report | Derek Lam, Childs Play
description: Showing at his Crosby Street store for the first time, Derek Lam described his collection for Resort as possessing a certain naivet not to mention an affinity for childrens craft paper. Indeed, he wanted his skirts and dresses  with their delicate laser cut-out patterns  to look like they were made with paper and scissors. A white cropped sweater bearing the midriff and high-waisted fit and flared skirt looked positively fresh. As my mind drifted from children to women to womens abs, I wondered who will choose to bare all in these teeny new knits.

title: Tight Credit Is Turning Franchisers Into Lenders
description: When Remi Tessier recently decided to open a pizza franchise, he got a big surprise: it was not going to be easy to get financing from a bank.

title: Energy, Climate Change, but No Cap and Trade
description: The latest proposal to deal with energy and climate change came on Wednesday from Senator Richard Lugar, a moderate Republican from Indiana. His plan seeks to cut energy usage and greenhouse gas emissions without creating a new market in carbon credits or taking a big bite out of the economy.

title: Makeshift Duos Honor a Real One
description: Art Garfunkel, slouchy in a Phillies cap, addressed the audience at SummerStage on Tuesday night. He was introducing 90 minutes worth of other singers vocal-duet tributes to Simon and Garfunkel. You should know that our versions  of The Sound of Silence or The Only Living Boy in New York  were not necessarily the definitive versions, he reasoned. We just did the first versions.

title: If You Own a Franchise, Are You an Entrepreneur?
description: Today, we published an article about how hard it can be to get financing to buy a franchise. One of the franchise owners featured is Remi Tessier, who obtained financing from his franchiser, Marcos Pizza.

title: Shopping With Jamie Durie
description: The landscape designer and host of the HGTV series The Outdoor Room with Jamie Durie, shopped for decorative garden items.

title: Hair to Close on June 27
description: The current Broadway production of Hair, which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, will close on June 27, its producers said on Wednesday. Hair began turning a profit in August, after recouping its capitalization costs of $5.76 million, but has performed unevenly at the box office this year. When it closes, it will have played 519 regular performances and 29 previews.

title: Resort Report | Chloe Sevigny for Opening Ceremony
description: Lately Ive had the Nineties on the brain, so when I discovered that Chloe Sevigny had tapped the footwear brand NaNa (one of my only style signifiers in the formative years of wearing a uniform) to create some styles with her for Opening Ceremony, my heart skipped a beat. To anchor the kitschy accessories and cool cropped knits, Sevigny offered a core collection of five dresses in five prints. It will be easy for a girl to buy a few and wear them as a uniform. And shell have more opportunities to change up her footwear, which to me is what the Nineties were all about.

title: Photo Replay: June 9
description: A view of the day in sports as South Africans and international soccer teams prepare for the start of the World Cup and hockey fans prepare for Game 6.

title: Why Caseys General Stores Loves Iowa
description: Alimentation Couche-Tards hostile offer for Caseys General Stores, a rival convenience store operator, would appear at first glance to be a plain vanilla hostile offer. Caseys does not have a staggered board, so all of its directors are up for election this year. This provides Couche-Tard with a standard route for any hostile bid: it can begin a tender offer and combine it with the nomination of a slate of directors to bring the target to the table.

title: United States vs. England
description: Duncan Irving argues for England.

title: United States vs. England
description: George Vecsey argues for the United States.

title: 100 Acres to Roam, No Restrictions
description: WHEN 100 Acres: The Virginia B. Fairbanks Art & Nature Park opens to the public next weekend in the backyard of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, there will be no signs or guards admonishing visitors not to touch the art. Quite the contrary.

title: Kevin Costner Does a Star Turn on the Hill
description: Tucked at the end of a witness list otherwise filled with doctors, engineers, scientists, and disaster-response specialists testifying before a House committee today about the Gulf oil spill, one name stood out: Kevin Costner.

title: How I Saved My Company: Vintage Filings
description: Shai Stern, co-founder and chief executive of Vintage Filings, thought he had built the fastest growing financial printing service in the business. Then the market tanked and the recession hit.

title: Little Bethenny, Positioning Herself to Be Happy at Last
description: Who is Bethenny Frankel?

title: From Poland, Doughnuts Filled With Plum Jam
description: My iron-clad view on the Best Doughnut in the World actually varies with the last excellent doughnut I ate or thought about. It can be any one of several varieties from New Yorks Doughnut Plant; it can be the elusive Carnival fritter from Venice  elusive because it is available for only a few weeks a year in the run-up to Lent; it can be the apricot-jam-filled doughnut sold (also on a maddening timetable somehow linked to the ecclesiastical calendar) at outlets of the Kurt Gutenbrunner group such as Caf Sabarsky.

title: Warren Buffetts Lunch Tab: $700,100 and Climbing
description: Someone has bid $700,100 to dine with the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett in an annual charity auction, pushing the bidding at this point far ahead of last years level, Reuters reports.

title: Resort Report | Oscar de la Renta, Dress Success
description: Oscar de la Renta knows how to make a summer dress! His resort collection was full of color, prints and very feminine frocks. There was also a nautical theme, a vague 40s vibe and a very modern iPad clutch!My favorite looks were the easy day dresses. No one does it better.

title: The Blogroll is Back
description: A brief housekeeping note, as they say at board meetings: Merging the blogrolls from the old Diners Journal and Pour blogs took a while, but at last were done. Look down the page for some blogs and sites that our reporters and editors regularly cruise.

title: A Debut, an Anniversary and a Springboard for Young Players
description: An exuberant cacophony greeted audience members entering Riverside Church before a concert by the St. Louis Symphony Youth Orchestra on Tuesday evening, as ensemble members sat onstage energetically rehearsing. Significant collective and individual preparation had clearly gone into their terrific concert, the orchestras New York debut appearance, celebrating the 40th anniversary of its founding by Leonard Slatkin, the former music director and now conductor laureate of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

title: Robbing Peter to Pay Paul (and Con Ed)
description: So Gov. David A. Paterson has been keeping New York States government going week to week, with the Legislature providing the cash by approving one emergency extender bill after another.

title: Beyond Flat Panels: A New Generation of TV Sets
description: CERTAIN products herald the arrival of The Future. Think about the first time you saw someone using a laptop on an airplane. The first time you bought a song over the Internet. And the first flat-screen TV you saw: after decades of promises, a TV you could hang on a wall. It was like having a Worlds Fair in your living room.

title: Unlikely Fan of Afrobeat Pulled Fela! to Broadway
description: As a student at Phillips Exeter Academy in the mid-1960s Stephen Hendel found comfort in his old turntable, the kind that could stack six records at a time, his Paul Butterfields and Sonny Boy Williamsons. Out on campus you endured bullies by keeping your emotions in check, he believed. But lying on his bed, listening to blues and jazz and soul for hours on end, the teenager felt his first stirrings of excitement and rich imagination.

title: Mormon Church Agrees to Pay Campaign Finance Fine
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Mormon Church has agreed to pay a fine of slightly more than $5,000 for failing to report some campaign staff contributions it made in support of Proposition 8, the 2008 ballot measure that outlawed same-sex marriage.

title: Where Bands Jam, but Traffic Flows
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  In a warehouse next to his home, David Pennington, the mayor of Coffee County, stores enough pop-culture memorabilia to make a lesser collector gasp. There are entire walls of Gene Autry items, faded Coca-Cola signs hanging from the ceilings and rare baseball cards in a glass display case. Stashed throughout are reams of posters, tickets and magazine clippings for the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival, which begins its ninth season on Thursday and is the pride of this bucolic small city in central Tennessee.

title: The Bambino, and Other Curses of the Red Sox
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Babe Ruth shows up to throw a bit of grit into the polished blandness of Johnny Baseball, a well-mannered musical about a rudeness-provoking sport, now at the American Repertory Theater here. Of course any show about the curse of the Boston Red Sox would have to include George Herman Ruth Jr., who, according to baseball mythology, was the curses cause. After they sold him to the Yankees, in 1920, the Sox didnt win a World Series for more than eight decades.

title: HelloWallet Attacks Mint.com
description: When HelloWallet had its debut in March, it characterized itself as an independent alternative to Mint.com that could perform more functions.

title: Midsummer Arrives Early, Ashtons Dreams in Tow
description: Surely no performance in ballet today is more definitive that that given by Herman Cornejo as Puck. title: Canada: Police Search for Suspicious Fertilizer
description: The Canadian police are searching for 3,582 pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, which can also be used to make explosives, sold to man who purchased it under false pretenses two weeks ago. The sale was made at a farm supply store about an hours drive from the Toronto convention center that will host the Group of 20 summit meeting this month. The man did not provide identification, as required by Canadian law, after convincing clerks that he was a regular customer. The clerks then helped him load the 65 bags of fertilizer onto a flatbed trailer pulled by a minivan. The store later realized that the man was not who he claimed, and contacted the police. The police say they have no evidence linking the purchase either to the summit or to bomb-making and acknowledge that the purchaser, described as a middle-aged man with a heavy accent and missing two fingers, may simply be fertilizing fruit trees.

Mr. Tan, 56, was sentenced by a lower court in February.

title: Mexico: Tense Moment on Border

It pretty quickly got very intense over on the Mexican side, an F.B.I. spokeswoman, Andrea Simmons, told The Associated Press. Mexican officials, including President Felipe Caldern, have condemned the shooting, which the Border Patrol said was in self-defense after rock-throwing migrants confronted agents during an arrest. The teenager, Sergio Adrin Hernndez, 15, was shot beside a railroad bridge connecting Ciudad Jurez with El Paso. Amnesty International said the shooting appears to have been a grossly disproportionate response and flies in the face of international standards that compel police to use firearms only as a last resort.

Aleksandr Bortnikov, the director of the Federal Security Service, said Mr. Taziyev helped organize the suicide bombing of a Nazran police station that killed 24 people and an attempt on the life of Ingushetias president, Yunus-Bek Yevkurov.

Defense Minister Herv Morin had filed a complaint against Mr. Siramy, whose real name is Maurice Dufresne, accusing him of violating secrecy rules and divulging the identities of operatives.

description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Mike Nothnagel is known for his very tough Friday and Saturday puzzles, but today he proves he can do a simpler Thursday-style crossword as well. As Thursdays go, this one isnt as wild and crazy as some, but its clever and interesting, and the way everything cross-connects can make your head spin. If youre not careful, you can get a false sense of dj vu when clues that seem to be familiar turn out to be different.

title: The Sounds and Songs of Stanley Cup Rivals

title: So Many Phone Add-ons, Youll Need More Pockets
description: THE problem with shopping for phone gadgeteers who have everything is obvious: they have everything. But there are a few categories of gifts suitable for even the most acquisitive fans: functional items that they dont know about, that they may not realize they need or that are just too modest to make it onto the wish list. Then there are items that seem too extravagant for people to buy for themselves.

title: A Call to Triple U.S. Spending on Energy Research

description: The Mets and the Padres were rained out on Wednesday night and will make up the game on Thursday as part of a day-night doubleheader. Johan Santana will face Mat Latos in the regularly scheduled game beginning at 1:10 p.m. Fans who held tickets to Wednesdays game can use them to attend the second game of the doubleheader, which will start at 7:10 p.m. Jon Niese will pitch for the Mets.

Its a reminder that America relies on imports anyway and it wont make any real difference to ban difficult drilling until oil companies prove it is safe.

description: Few early matches in the World Cup have brought the anticipation of the United States-England game on June 12 in Rustenburg. A number of Americans play club soccer in England and will not lack for familiarity with their opponents when they take the field. The teams have met only once in the World Cup, when the United States defeated England, 1-0, in Brazil in one of the tournaments most storied upsets.

But a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the month indicated by the figures published Thursday was also likely to re-ignite pressure on Beijing to let its currency appreciate against the U.S. dollar.

description: The N.F.L. reached a licensing deal with the online game company Quick Hit, bolstering a rival to Electronic Artss Madden NFL. The deal is the N.F.L.s first licensing arrangement for an online game, a league spokesman said. Its exclusivity arrangement with E.A.  struck in 2004 and extended in 2008  is for a console-based action simulation, the league said. Quick Hits product is played through an Internet browser. The game, QUICKHIT Football, is free to play and generates revenue when users buy add-on features.

title: Jack Johnson Takes Top Spot on Chart
description: The latest laid-back album from Jack Johnson, below, ran away with the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. To the Sea (Brushfire), Mr. Johnsons fifth studio album, sold 243,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) came in a distant second, with 52,000 in sales, while Glee: The Music, Volume 3  Showstoppers (Columbia) came in third after two weeks as No. 1, with 45,000. The fourth and fifth spots are the same as the previous week, as Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), the best-selling album of the year, is No. 4, with sales of 41,000. Ushers Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive) followed, with 35,000. JOSEPH PLAMBECK

title: Broadway Is Losing Its Hair
description: The current Broadway production of Hair, which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, will close on June 27, its producers said on Wednesday. Hair began turning a profit in August, after recouping its capitalization costs of $5.76 million but has performed unevenly at the box office this year. The announcement comes two weeks after the producers of the London production of Hair said the West End show would close when the current cast departs in September; tickets had been on sale through January 2011. A national American tour of Hair is scheduled to begin in October in New Haven and continue to 20 cities. On Friday, to mark the 500th performance of Hair on Broadway, free tickets will be given to the first 500 people in line when the box office opens at 10 a.m. at the Al Hirschfeld Theater, the producers said. Directed by Diane Paulus, this Hair began as a free show in the summer of 2008 at the Public Theaters Delacorte Theater in Central Park, before moving to Broadway in March 2009. When the Broadway production closes, it will have played 519 regular performances and 29 previews. PATRICK HEALY

title: Strong Finish for Glee
description: Foxs Glee ended its first full season on Tuesday on a high note, attracting 10.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, the seriess largest audience without the benefit of following an episode of American Idol. Fox placed third for the night over all. ABC was No. 1 for the night with its coverage of Game 3 of the N.B.A. Finals. CBS was second with repeats of its crime shows. NBC was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

title: BP Concerns Drag Down Other Stocks
description: Investors were shaken Wednesday by the prospect that BP might cut its dividend, pulling down the broader market, Susanna G. Kim writes in The New York Times. In the last hour of trading, the major indexes on Wall Street  led by energy shares  turned lower, erasing gains of more than 120 points on the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Martin and Roger Join Evita Revival
description: The pop singer Ricky Martin will play Che and the Argentine actress Elena Roger will reprise her acclaimed West End performance as Eva Pern in Broadways first revival of the musical Evita, which is expected to begin performances in spring 2012, the producers of the show announced on Wednesday. The show remains one of the most popular of the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the book writer and lyricist Tim Rice; the original Broadway production ran from 1979 to 1983 and won seven Tony Awards. Mr. Martin, 38, above left, has one previous stint on Broadway, as the besotted French student Marius in Les Misrables in 1996. Ms. Roger, 35, above right, drew rapturous critical notices as Evita in the 2006 revival of the show in London. Performance dates were not announced beyond spring 2012, and additional casting and creative team members will be announced later. PATRICK HEALY

title: Daniel Lanois Injured in Motorcycle Crash
description: The singer-songwriter and producer Daniel Lanois was in intensive care after he was injured in a motorcycle accident over the weekend, The Guardian reported. Mr. Lanois, a Quebec-born musician who has worked as a producer on albums including Bob Dylans Time Out of Mind, Willie Nelsons Teatro and U2s No Line on the Horizon, crashed his motorcycle in Los Angeles on Saturday. A statement from his label, Jive Records, did not specify his injuries but said that because of their severity, Mr. Lanois, above, had canceled his summer tour and all other promotional activity for the next two months.

title: Another Bail Payment Prevents Lohans Arrest
description: Lindsay Lohan avoided arrest Tuesday after a judge said she had violated her probation and her lawyer said a monitoring device Ms. Lohan wears detected the presence of alcohol. After a meeting on Tuesday with prosecutors and Ms. Lohans lawyer, Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court said Ms. Lohan, above, had violated the terms of her release, based on results from a court-ordered alcohol monitor, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the  Mean Girls  and Parent Trap star, was ordered to wear the monitoring device in May after missing a probation hearing stemming from her 2007 arrests on drunken-driving and misdemeanor drug charges. At that time an arrest warrant had been issued for Ms. Lohan and revoked when she posted $100,000 bail. On Tuesday another warrant was issued for Ms. Lohan, and bail was doubled to $200,000  this one revoked when she paid up. Ms. Lohan wrote on her Twitter account that her monitoring device wasnt set off, adding that it was physically impossible because she had done nothing for it to go off. But Ms. Lohans lawyer, Shawn Chapman Holley, said in a statement that the device indicated the presence of a small amount of alcohol after she attended the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night, according to The A.P.

title: Barbara Kingsolver Wins Orange Prize
description: Barbara Kingsolver has won the Orange Prize for Fiction for The Lacuna, her tale of a young man growing up in the political turmoil of Mexico and the United States in the mid-20th century. The British prize, decided by a panel of five judges, is given annually for the best novel written by a woman in English. It comes with an award of about $47,000. Daisy Goodwin, the chairwoman of the judges, said in a statement, We chose The Lacuna because it is a book of breathtaking scale and shattering moments of poignancy. Among the other finalists was Hilary Mantel, who was seen by many as the favorite for her Wolf Hall, which won the Booker Prize, Britains most prestigious literary award. Ms. Kingsolvers other books include The Poisonwood Bible, Prodigal Summer and Pigs in Heaven. JULIE BOSMAN

Now Reading | A Warhol Tell-All
description: Christopher Trela first discovered John Wilcocks long out-of-print The Autobiography and Sex Life of Andy Warhol while browsing a rare-book stall at a Fifth Avenue street fair in 1991. Wilcock, who was a travel reporter for The New York Times before becoming a founding editor of both The Village Voice and Interview magazine, visited the Factory for seven years, up to five times a week. Casual conversations with the likes of Leo Castelli, Ultra Violet, Charles Henri Ford and Lou Reed, culled at the height of Warhols fame, eventually culminated in this oral history, which Wilcock self-published.

title: Boyle in Discussions to Sing for Pope

A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle, the homegrown singing sensation who was discovered last year on the reality competition Britains Got Talent, was likely to perform for Pope Benedict XVI during a papal tour this fall. While negotiations are still taking place, The A.P. said, Ms. Boyle is expected to sing during an open-air papal Mass at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Sept. 16. The event is part of a four-day trip by Benedict, during which he will also address Parliament and beatify John Henry Newman, a cardinal who converted to Catholicism in the 19th century. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Ms. Boyle told Reuters: Susans management are currently looking at the possibility of this happening.

A broken wrist sent him on a circuitous route, 1,200 miles south from Paris to take the mineral waters at Aix-en-Provence, and on the way he planned to fulfill his professional obligations as Americas top envoy to France, researching French architecture, agriculture and engineering projects.

Beneath the buttoned-down facade is a lively capital that follows its own sartorial trends, indulges in decadent flavors (especially when it involves beer) and exhibits a witty, even wacky sense of humor. What other city would erect an entire museum to a single comic book series? Or to an artist famous for painting faceless men in gray suits?

But in the years since, they have gradually meshed with the city, transforming from an almost overlooked urban footnote into a network of recreation and possibility.

It also revives provisions in the stimulus bill that have bolstered Small Business Administration lending by increasing loan guarantees and eliminating borrower fees. Several times those measures have expired before winning short-term extensions from Congress, but they have not yet been renewed after running out of money and legal authority at the end of May. Szabo, a photographer for the MTI Hungarian News Agency, has been taking the long view of the flooding in his country that has displaced about 4,000 people. Far removed from the misery on the ground, he has created canvases that would not be out of place in a gallery of modern art. They are well worth examining in Full Screen mode.

Among the offerings: a personal video system that allows you to aim wireless cameras at say, your cats food bowl and view it real time on the Web; a battery-run charger for mobile devices; and goggles with a built-in monitor that for the viewer is the equivalent of an 80-inch screen. Seriously. Our former Frugal Traveler compiled a list of gadgets last year, and so have Time and Travel and Leisure. But a narrow poll of In Transit editors  who are partial to smartphones and travel guides  indicates that we could still use some suggestions. Got any favorite devices that you just cant leave home without?

title: Martyrs: Roasted, Beheaded or Maimed

Feigen Collection, a high-quality exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery here. One, by Orazio Gentileschi from around 1628, is a run-of-the-mill depiction of the penitent Mary Magdalene, half reclining on her side on the cold floor of a shadowy cave. A dark orange blanket covers her legs and lower torso, leaving her breasts and shoulders exposed. Leaning with one elbow on a large, open book, her long hair flowing over its pages and a skull nestled under her arm, she gazes heavenward with a pious, melancholy expression.

title: On the Horns of Abundance: Jazz Festivals Resound

title: Turning Points
description: In 2007, the anthropologist Mary Douglas published a groundbreaking, if little-noticed, book, Thinking in Circles, which argued that many seemingly disjointed, chaotic or arbitrarily organized ancient narratives  for example, the Book of Numbers in the Hebrew Bible  are carefully designed to be read in a circular, rather than linear, form. A circular or ring narrative is one in which events come to a decisive point in the middle and then lead back, in parallel fashion, to the point of entry: ABCBA. Unlike a conventional (we might say ABCDE) narrative, which builds to a world-altering climax near the end, a ring narrative appears symmetrical and exhaustively coherent, like a snowflake. When every element in the composition interacts with all the others, Douglas writes, and nothing is extraneous or unnecessary, everything contributes to embellish the pattern.

description: JOHANNESBURG  Of all the opponents that South Africa could have faced Friday in the first World Cup match on African soil, none will probably be better prepared for the noise and emotion and altitude than Mexico.

title: Heated Opposition to a Proposed Mosque
description: A church may be a church, and a temple a temple, but through the prism of emotion that still grips many New Yorkers almost a decade after 9/11, a mosque can apparently represent a lot of things.

title: Guilds Said to Tell Disney of Concerns on Miramax Talks
description: LOS ANGELES  Representatives of Hollywoods principal guilds have told the Walt Disney Company that they have serious concerns about the possible sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group organized by David Bergstein.

title: Phillies Are Swatting and Flailing
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Drawing Fire: Remains of the Day
description: This is the last in a five-part series. To read from the beginning, go to Drawing Fire: Into Ubaydi.

title: A Basic Civil Right
description: After a nearly three-week trial in January, and a lengthy hiatus while lawyers fought over documents, closing arguments are scheduled for Wednesday in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Drug Maker Seen as Uncooperative on Inquiry
description: A Congressional investigation into a recent recall of childrens Tylenol and other pediatric medicines has been stymied by the manufacturer, Johnson & Johnson, investigators say, raising the prospect that new measures  like issuing of subpoenas to compel cooperation  could be invoked.

title: Beyond Iran Sanctions, Plans B, C, D and ...
description: WASHINGTON  No one in the Obama White House believes that, by themselves, the newest rounds of sanctions against Irans military-run businesses, its shipping lines and its financial institutions will force Tehran to halt its 20-year-long drive for a nuclear capability.

title: The Message From Arkansas
description: They may not have won, but discontented Democrats sent an important message to the Obama administration on Tuesday by mounting an unexpectedly strong primary challenge to Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas. For the White House to minimize the efforts of unions and others who helped support that challenge suggests a tone-deafness to the growing restlessness in the Democratic Party.

title: A Potato Remade for Industry Has Some Swedes Frowning
description: SKARA, Sweden  Johan Bergstrom, a blond and boyish man of 31, who farms here with his father, reached into the dark, soft soil and extricated a tennis-ball-size potato, holding it gently so as not to snap off any of a half-dozen white shoots that were growing out of the potatos eyes. He advised against tasting the potato, whose dulcet name Amflora belies its harsh flavor, a result of genetic jiggling that has made it almost pure starch.

title: Real Justice for Juveniles
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York has sent the Legislature a juvenile justice bill that would achieve two urgently important goals. It would improve the quality of the leadership and care in the states often dangerous and inhumane juvenile facilities. And it would ensure that only children who need to be institutionalized  because they present a risk to the public  end up in the facilities.

title: Deal for Ground Zero Workers
description: After the World Trade Center attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, thousands of people worked heroically, searching for remains and clearing the rubble. Too many later paid a price for not having adequate respirators or other equipment. They grew sick, many with respiratory illnesses. Or they grew increasingly anxious about how the stew of noxious chemicals would affect their health in the years to come.

title: Gay Couples Gain Under Violence Against Women Act
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has decided that federal prosecutors should enforce criminal provisions in the Violence Against Women Act in cases involving gay and lesbian relationships, a newly disclosed memorandum shows.

title: Iran Defends Rights Record as Opposition Cancels Rally
description: UNITED NATIONS  As Iran defended its record before the United Nations Human Rights Council, calling itself a model of Middle East democracy, opposition leaders in Tehran on Thursday canceled a weekend rally marking one year since the countrys disputed presidential election because the government did not give them a permit.

title: Plan Would Allow Abortions at Military Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON  The fight to allow gay and bisexual people to serve openly in the military is already drawing political blood in Washington, but tucked into the same 852-page Pentagon policy bill as the repeal of dont ask, dont tell is a little-noticed amendment that takes on another emotionally charged issue: making abortion easier for military women in war zones.

title: Scoring Low, More Pupils Face School This Summer
description: An estimated 21,000 elementary and middle school students scored at the lowest levels on state math and reading exams, New York City education officials said Thursday, meaning that twice as many students in those schools as last year will be required to enroll in summer school.

title: Contractors Told to Prepare for Moon Programs End
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has greatly scaled back the work it will do in the coming months on its program to return astronauts to the moon, telling companies working on the program to set aside money to cover its potential cancellation.

title: In Louisville, View of Banks Role in the Everyday
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  A $238 million basketball arena is rising on Main Street, financed through a bond deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs.

Heres to Jacques-Yves Cousteau
description: Friday marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Jacques-Yves Cousteau, who is an absolute hero of mine (and thats not a word I toss around much).

title: Surprising Immigration Crackdown Advances
description: BOSTON  Lawmakers were tangled in budget talks inside the Massachusetts Statehouse this week, but a 19-year-old college student spent even more time at the gold-domed building on Beacon Hill.

title: General Forecasts Slower Pace in Afghan War
description: BRUSSELS  The top United States and NATO commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, acknowledged Thursday that efforts in Kandahar to drive back Taliban insurgents were likely to take significantly longer than planned, raising new questions about what can be achieved in southern Afghanistan before the end of the year.

title: Bitterness Follows End of a School
description: After more than a century on the West Side of Manhattan, St. Michael Academy had assumed the traits of some of its best students: cash poor, underestimated by peers, capable of defying expectations with breathtaking regularity.

title: Congressional Negotiators Start Effort to Merge Versions of Financial Reform Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Negotiators from the House and Senate gathered on Thursday to merge two bills representing the most comprehensive changes to financial regulation since the Depression, but the script they acted out was largely being written elsewhere.

title: How Failure Became an Option
description: Needing a break from the omnipresent BP oil cam, I went back and watched the spirit-resuscitating Apollo 13.Oh, to revel in the days when we could fix anything with duct tape and American self-confidence! Sad to say, it looks like a time capsule.

title: South Africas Hopes Extend Beyond Field
description: JOHANNESBURG  The World Cup begins here on Friday with excitement at so elevated a level that even many of the unhappy are happy.

title: A Place to Kick Back
description: Freddie LjungbergAge: 33Occupation: Soccer playerComing Project: Kicking off his instructional camp, Freddie Ljungbergs Advanced Soccer Clinic at Suncadia, in Cle Elum, Wash., Aug. 20-22

title: An Early Campaign Gaffe Makes a Non-Issue Big
description: You can parse a voting record. Flip-flops  political ones  are fair game. But dont talk about a womans hair.

title: Uncertainty Marks Start of Expansion
description: One of the most chaotic off-season days in the recent history of college sports left the Pacific-10s signature member, Southern California, bludgeoned by a landmark N.C.A.A. ruling. Although the penalties included a two-year postseason ban and the loss of 30 scholarships, the most significant development Thursday was the major restructuring of the landscape of collegiate athletics.

title: Prune and Grow
description: Sixteen months ago, Congress passed a stimulus package that will end up costing each average taxpayer $7,798. Economists were divided then about whether this spending was worth it, and they are just as divided now.

title: Hundreds Held in Drug Raids in 16 States
description: WASHINGTON  A coordinated series of law enforcement raids across 16 states this week resulted in the arrests of 429 people accused of participating in smuggling and transportation networks for Mexican drug cartels, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced Thursday.

title: Judge Denies Bail for Men in Terror Case
description: NEWARK  A federal judge denied bail on Thursday to two New Jersey men accused of trying to fly to Somalia to join an Islamist insurgent group.

title: Senate Rejects Republican Effort to Thwart Carbon Limits
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday defeated a Republican-led effort to prevent the Environmental Protection Agency from curbing greenhouse gases as lawmakers road-tested arguments for a future fight over climate change legislation.

title: Explorer Born June 11, 1910
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Having tribute puzzles appear on significant birthdays is a crossword tradition, and Birthday Number 100 seems significant enough. Were looking for an explorer born a century ago today. Since the anniversary falls on a Friday, we end up with a very open themeless-style grid (only 26 blocks) thats light on the number of theme entries but fills the Friday requirements for fans of late-week puzzles.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: A.S.P.C.A.s Veterinary Forensics
description: A.S.P.C.A.s senior director of veterinary forensics is the captain of a new canine C.S.I. unit.

title: At Jacksons Side, And Patiently Waiting His Turn
description: BOSTON  In a pivotal moment of the Los Angeles Lakers 2009 title run, Brian Shaw drew a blank, literally and deliberately, with a hint of creative mischief.

title: Red Bulls Grab the Back Page
description: In the annals of New York sports, one of the goals is to garner the back page of the citys tabloid newspapers (which in actuality, are the front pages of the sports sections of The New York Post and The Daily News).

title: A.I.G. Needs A.I.A. Deal Soon
Vija Celmins:  New Paintings, Objects and Prints
description: Starting in 1977 the artist Vija Celmins devoted a lot of energy to 11 small stones. First she made sure they were fabulously (really) diverse: tiny and darkly smooth as opposed to larger and delicately mottled or glassily angular and crystalline. The largest was brown with white flecks and a white Saturn-like ring. Next Ms. Celmins cast the stones in bronze and over the next five years painted each cast until it was absolutely identical to the original. The piece, To Fix the Image in Memory, is a mind-bending, eye-stretching poetic wonder: a universe of visible and invisible differences, a solar system in which each surface presents a galaxy of details. Each stone is a world unto itself  except for its twin.

title: West Bank: Local Elections Put Off
description: The Palestinian Authority decided Thursday to postpone local elections that had been scheduled for July 17 in the West Bank. A spokesman said the balloting had been put off until further notice. No official reason was given for the delay.

title: Barbados: Clinton Pledges Aid
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged $124 million in American aid to the Caribbean region over the next two years to combat a surge in drug-related violence. Meeting with Caribbean leaders in Barbados, Mrs. Clinton said the region needed American help to crack down on the highest rate of interpersonal violence in the world. Responding to concern among the leaders that oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico could reach their shores, she said, We earnestly hope that does not happen.

title: Rodriguez Exits Game in First Inning
description: BALTIMORE  Alex Rodriguez played third base and batted cleanup on opening night, and he has started all but two games since. That spell of durability has reinforced his value to the Yankees.

title: Adolf Dietrich and Richard Phillips: Painting and Misappropriation
description: The Swiss wildlife and landscape painter Adolf Dietrich (1877-1957) has an unlikely ally in Richard Phillips, a contemporary artist given to large canvases and confrontational imagery. Mr. Phillips has been borrowing themes from Dietrich for years and now makes good on his debts in a stirring show at the Swiss Institute.

title: Op Out of Ohio: Anonima Group, Richard Anuszkiewicz and Julian Stanczak in the 1960s
description: Op Art never gets old. Op Out of Ohio presents about 30 eye-dazzling optical works from the 60s by five painters who did time as students or teachers at Oberlin College or the Cleveland Institute of Art. All were also included in The Responsive Eye, the landmark 1965 exhibition of perceptual abstraction at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and went on to exhibit internationally. Richard Anuszkiewicz and Julian Stanczak remain the best known. The others  Ernst Benkert, Francis Hewitt and Ed Mieczkowski  formed a collaborative called Anonima. Working in studios side by side, they investigated problems in perception and design with quasi-scientific zeal.

title: Virginia: Diocese Wins a Battle Over Property
description: The State Supreme Court ruled Thursday against nine conservative congregations that split from the Episcopal Church and tried to take their church properties with them. The Episcopal Church and the Episcopal Diocese of Virginia fought hard in court to retain the properties, worth tens of millions of dollars, in part to deter other breakaway parishes from running off with their assets. The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the ruling of a lower court that had sided with the conservatives in applying a law on how to divide church property when congregations fracture. But the battle is not over. The Supreme Court sent the case back to a lower court to decide a different legal question: whether the denomination or the parish actually owns the properties.

title: Rousting Africas Sleeping Giant
description: Soweto, South Africa

title: Population Shows a Racial Shift
description: Two large suburban counties flipped from having white majorities to having white minorities last year. Gwinnett County, outside Atlanta, and Contra Costa County, near San Francisco, showed the change as minorities edged closer to becoming a majority of the nation's youngest children. More than 500 of the nation's more than 3,000 now fall in that category. The census estimates released Thursday also quantified the impact of the recession on former population magnets. California recorded the largest net loss of population to other states, 98,000, followed by New York and Michigan. As of July 1, 2009, racial and ethnic groups other than non-Hispanic whites accounted for 48.6 percent of all births and 48.3 percent of children younger than 5.

title: As Crime Rate Drops, New Yorks Jail Population Falls to Lowest Level in 24 Years
description: Fewer inmates are behind bars in New York on any given day than at any time in the past 24 years, and the number admitted to the citys jail system has fallen below 100,000 for the first time since 1987.

title: Izzo Meets With Cavaliers
description: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met with the Cleveland Cavaliers about their coaching vacancy on Thursday, confirming that the interest between the parties is mutual.

title: While Waiting on James, Cavaliers Meet With Izzo
description: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met with the Cleveland Cavaliers about their coaching vacancy on Thursday, validating speculation that the interest between the parties was mutual.

title: Photo Replay: June 10
description: Soccer madness takes over on the eve of the start of the World Cup.

title: Ratings Boost for Game 6
description: The Chicago Blackhawks Game 6 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers attracted 8.28 million viewers on NBC, the most since 8.29 million watched Game 3 of the 1974 finals. The viewership for Wednesday nights overtime game was 43 percent better than the 5.8 million who watched last years Game 6, and 4 percent higher than last years Game 7. Guy Boucher was hired as the coach of the Tampa Bay Lightning. Boucher, 38, the former coach of the American Hockey Leagues Hamilton Bulldogs, becomes the youngest coach in the N.H.L. boucher (AP)

title: In These Difficult Times, New York States Motto Could Be: Will Tattoo for Food
description: Week to week. Thats how the great state of New York is making do during these sorry days of fiscal ridiculousness. Since the state has seen fit to get along without an annual budget, an emergency spending bill gets approved every week authorizing just enough money to enable New York to squeeze through the next seven days.

title: Students to Protest Possible End of Free Rides
description: Students are planning to walk out of 23 high schools to demonstrate outside City Hall against the threatened end of free bus and subway rides to and from school, protest organizers said Thursday.

title: Empire of the Summer Moon
description: Chapter 1: A New Kind of War

title: Men on Horseback
description: Why does Custer persist? Nearly 134 years after his last stand, a military debacle that cost the lives of all 210 men under his immediate command, George Armstrong Custer remains such an iconic figure in the American pageant that mere mention of his name evokes an entirely overromanticized era in the American West. By all rights he should be a footnote. That he enjoys the glory of single-name recognition is a testament to the power of personality, show business and savvy public relations. Custer wasnt just an Indian fighter. He was one of the first self-made American celebrities.

title: Russo Finding His Way in Outfield
description: BALTIMORE  The Hall of Fame pitcher Jim Palmer was about to walk out of the Yankees clubhouse when he stopped the defensive star of Wednesdays game. Nice play, Palmer told Kevin Russo, pumping his hand. You can play defense.

title: Italy: Wiretapping Bill Advances
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis conservative government won a vote in the Senate on Thursday on a bill that restricts wiretaps and fines media organizations that report information derived from wiretaps used in criminal investigations before the case goes to trial. The bill, which now goes to the lower house for final approval, would require a three-judge panel, instead of a single judge, to approve a wiretap; limit the number of days for a wiretap; and require special authorization to listen in on priests.

title: Recovering the Dead in Haiti
description: On a trip to Haiti in April, Angel Franco, a staff photographer at The Times, met a man called Sony, who had given himself the task of recovering the bodies of his neighbors in the devastated Fort National neighborhood of Port-au-Prince; bodies that were still buried under rubble three months after the earthquake. In this conversation with James Estrin, Mr. Franco recalled what led up to their meeting and how both men memorialized their encounter. Its been edited for brevity and clarity.

description: diadem \di--dem, -dm\ noun

title: Billions of Dollars Ride on Teams Maneuvers for New Stadiums
description: Jed York, the 29-year-old president of the 49ers, made his way to the American Legion hall in Santa Clara on Tuesday night.

title: A Violent Incident Leaves Scars, and Perhaps a Tough New Law
description: Every fire begins with a spark. For San Franciscos controversial proposed sit/lie law, the inciting incident happened on a Wednesday night in early December in the Haight  an act of violence so brutal it inspired a grass-roots movement.

title: Alameda Stirred Up on Tax Plan
description: For years, it was the eclectic Eastern European goods that enticed shoppers into Jenny Turcinovics store in Alameda: gummy candy from Serbia, fine Croatian chocolates and bottles of mineral water from Romania and Turkey.

title: Moving Gay Films Into the Mainstream
description: The Womens Basketball Coaches Association declined to screen Training Rules, a groundbreaking documentary about a homophobic college basketball coach, at a coaches conference in San Antonio during the womens Final Four tournament in April. But Kathy Wolfe was not deterred.
