description: Mexico vs. South Africa

title: Judge Provides Impetus for Cook County Jails Virtual School
description: Long before he was assigned to the Cook County Courts criminal division six years ago, Judge John Kirby was all too familiar with the logjam of nonviolent drug cases on the courts docket  14,000 annually according to a Justice Department study released last month.

title: Redemption for Hawks and Kane
description: Theyre calling it the most dramatic goal in franchise history, the one Patrick Kane scored against the Philadelphia Flyers four minutes into overtime Wednesday night, enabling his Blackhawks to hoist the Stanley Cup for the first time in 49 years.

title: New Leader of DDB Must Bring Luster Back
description: In February 2008, 40-year-old Paul Tilley, head of the creative department at DDB Chicago, one of the citys largest and most prominent advertising agencies, checked into the Fairmont Hotel just steps from the agencys offices and, soon after, leaped to his death from an upper floor.

title: A Lament for the Blues in Their Backyard
description: Buddy Guy said he was worried about the blues.

title: Keeping Score: One Game Says Little About Strasburg
description: It did not take long for declarations of greatness to start after Stephen Strasburgs debut for the Washington Nationals on Tuesday.

title: Bench Lifts Celtics to Tie Series
description: BOSTON  The fashionable Beat L.A. chants had all but faded from TD Garden, the oxygen bled from the building by Ray Allens misfires, Kobe Bryants impossible jumpers and Derek Fishers intensity. An anxious air hung over the Boston Celtics on Thursday as they teetered on the edge of a heavy series deficit.

title: Former Greys Anatomy Star Turns To a Life In the Theater
description: Based on the 2009 that T. R. Knight had, it can be safely said that he knows a thing or two about life (and death) in the television industry. What does he know about A Life in the Theater? Enough to be cast as the co-star in the coming revival of that David Mamet play, its producers said on Thursday. Mr. Knight, left, who last year left his role on Greys Anatomy, will portray John, a young actor, in the 1977 Mamet work, which will be on Broadway for the first time. He appeared on Broadway in the 2001 revival of Noises Off and in Tartuffe in 2003. Appearing opposite him in the role of Robert, the mentor, will be the Broadway veteran Patrick Stewart.  A Life in the Theater will be directed by Neil Pepe and presented at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. Preview performances are scheduled to begin on Sept. 23.

title: Boyle And the Pope?
description: Its not a done deal, but Susan Boyle, right, may soon be singing for an authority figure who perhaps wont prejudge her the way Simon Cowell did. A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle, the homegrown singing sensation who was discovered last year on Britains Got Talent, was likely to perform for Pope Benedict XVI, right, during a papal tour this fall. While negotiations were still taking place, The A.P. said, Ms. Boyle is expected to sing during an open-air papal Mass at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Sept. 16. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Ms. Boyle told Reuters Susans management are currently looking at the possibility of this happening.

title: Lone Female Candidate Quits Oxford Poetry Race
description: At a time when Oxford University would surely like to move beyond last years disputed election for its professor of poetry position, a new controversy has opened up around that post. The Guardian reported that Paula Claire, the only woman in the running for the position, withdrew from consideration, saying the election process was seriously flawed and favored another contender, Geoffrey Hill. Last year the Nobel Prize-winning poet Derek Walcott withdrew from the election after Oxford academics were sent anonymous packages containing pages from a book describing a decades-old act of sexual harassment that he was accused of having committed. Ruth Padel, the first woman in more than 300 years to win the seat, resigned after it was learned that she had sent e-mail messages alerting reporters to that book. Ms. Claire, a poet in Oxford, told The Guardian she was frustrated that the universitys official announcement of candidates described her as a performer and artist but not as a poet, and that a flier in Oxfords Gazette, the official journal of the university, said Mr. Hill was quite simply a giant and the finest living poet in English today. Ms. Claire said: That is grossly over the top. They shouldnt allow it ahead of the election. A representative of Oxford told The Guardian, No special arrangements have been made for this election that are inconsistent with normal university operations in this respect.

title: China Inflation Rises to a 19-Month High
description: New data from China on Friday cemented the view that the countrys giant economy powered ahead in May  though a marked rise in inflation also raised the pressure on Beijing to slow the booming pace of growth.

title: Kid Rock, as Comedian, at Country Music Awards
description: If neither Betty White nor Neil Patrick Harris is available to preside over your awards ceremony, might we suggest you consider Kid Rock? On Wednesdays broadcast of the CMT Music Awards in Nashville, Kid Rock, above, the rap-rock-country crossover star, proved to be quite the kidder, describing Lady Antebellum as the hillbilly Fleetwood Mac, except I suspect they dont do drugs or sleep with each other, and asking , Will you just have my baby and lets get it over? (She replied, If its a girl, maybe.) Carrie Underwood won video of the year for Cowboy Casanova and performance of the year for Temporary Home. Lady Antebellum won group video of the year for Need You Now, and Miranda Lambert earned her first CMT award, winning female video of the year for White Liar. Keith Urban won male video of the year for Til Summer Comes Around.

title: Arizona Tonys Party Canceled
description: A Tony Awards viewing party that was to take place Sunday in Tempe, Ariz., has been canceled. The event, which was to include a telecast of the ceremony prior to its being broadcast on the local CBS affiliate, was to be held at A.S.U. Gammage, an Arizona State University theater that presents touring productions of Broadway shows. We didnt get the turnout we wanted, said Colleen Jennings-Roggensack, the executive director of the theater and a member of the board of governors of the Broadway League, which administers the Tonys with the American Theater Wing. Despite a news media blitz, only about 300 tickets were sold for the event at the theater, which seats 3,000.

title: $25 Million, and a New Name, For Arts Center Near Seattle
description: The Performing Arts Center Eastside in Bellevue, Wash., has received a $25 million gift  said to be the third largest donation in the United States to a single arts institution since 2007  from the Tateuchi Foundation to help build a performing arts hall in the suburbs of Seattle, the center announced on Wednesday. The new five-story, 135,000-square-foot building in downtown Bellevue  designed by the architect Norman Pfeiffer  will include a 2,000-seat concert hall and a 250-seat cabaret-style space. Groundbreaking is scheduled to start in fall 2011 with an opening planned for 2013. In recognition of the grant, the institution will be renamed the Tateuchi Center, a tribute to the Japanese-American humanitarian, entrepreneur and business leader Atsuhiko Tateuchi, who died in 2007.

title: Flash Crash: The New Normal?
description: The flash crash in United States stock markets that shook investors on May 6 may be the first of many as the markets herd mentality is exacerbated by ultrafast trading strategies that are rapidly spreading around the world and across asset classes, experts said Thursday.

title: Horror and Injustice Play Starring Roles
description: It is one of the most stunning moments in Enemies of the People, a documentary that revisits the Cambodian killing fields of the late 1970s, and a high point of the Human Rights Watch Film Festival opening on Friday at Lincoln Center. Thet Sambath, a Cambodian journalist whose father and older brother were among the two million slaughtered by the Khmer Rouge, coaxes a Cambodian farmer who carried out its lethal orders to describe his method of execution.

title: Vladimir Arnold Dies at 72; Pioneering Mathematician
description: Vladimir I. Arnold, a Russian mathematician who discovered important theorems that found application in astronomy, mechanics and even weather forecasting, died June 3 in Paris. He was 72 and had homes in Paris and Moscow.

title: Peter Keefe, Creator of Cartoon Voltron, Dies at 57
description: Peter Keefe, the creator and executive producer of Voltron: Defender of the Universe, a hugely popular 1980s cartoon series that helped prepare the way for other Japanese-style animation in the United States, died on May 27 in Rochester. He was 57.

title: Crispian St. Peters, Singer of the Hit Pied Piper, Dies at 71
description: Crispian St. Peters, a British pop singer of the 60s best known for his buoyant hit Pied Piper and his soulful version of You Were on My Mind, died on Tuesday at his home in Swanley, Kent, England. He was 71.

title: News Quiz | June 11, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: S.E.C. Approves Circuit Breaker; Urges New Rules
description: Last months market volatility and concerns over unfair trading may require new controls on electronic trading systems, Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said on Thursday, even as the agency approved circuit breakers for the exchanges.

title: In Louisville, a View of Big Banks Everyday Role
description: A $238 million basketball arena is rising on Main Street, financed through a bond deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs. At the corner of Main and Fourth sits a branch of UBS Financial Services, the brokerage arm of the giant Swiss bank. Once known as Whiskey Row, Main Street and the surrounding blocks are now lined with bank towers: BB&T, PNC, National City and Your Community Bank.

title: E.C.B. Extends Cash Lifeline and Gives Pep Talk
description: The European Central Bank extended its cash lifeline for banks on Thursday, while its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, urged national euro zone regulators to take steps to resuscitate confidence in the health of their financial institutions, Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier write in The New York Times.

description: One of the best ways to get inside the head of British private equity boss Guy Hands is to study what gift he gives for Christmas. For years, Mr. Hands has sent friends and business associates a book he has recently read along with a letter discussing the work. The gift is designed to be both thoughtful and thought-provoking, Reuters reports.

description: JOHANNESBURG  Heartbreak intruded on the opening day of the World Cup soccer games when Nelson Mandelas 13-year-old great-granddaughter Zenani was killed in an auto accident early on Friday.

title: Fujitsu and Toshiba Said to Mull Mobile Deal
description: Fujitsu and Toshiba are in talks to merge their mobile phone businesses, two sources told Reuters, in a move that would create Japans No. 2 cellphone maker in a rapidly shrinking market.

title: U.S. Fury at BP Stirs Backlash Among British
description: Spewing oil and alienating Americans with its chief executives impolitic remarks, BP may be Public Enemy No. 1 in the United States. But in Britain, where the company is a mainstay of the stock market and a favorite of pension funds, investors and politicians are becoming increasingly angry at the blistering attacks from across the Atlantic, The New York Timess Sarah Lyall and Julia Werdigier write.

title: Congress Starts to Merge Financial Reform Bills
description: Negotiators from the House and Senate gathered on Thursday to merge two bills representing the most comprehensive changes to financial regulation since the Depression, but the script they acted out was largely being written elsewhere, The New York Timess Sewell Chan writes.

title: Are Your Teachers Under Too Much Pressure?
description: An article today reports on an increase in teachers caught tampering with their students standardized tests and scores. Because those scores now often determine which teachers get bonuses and tenure, some say the higher the stakes are, the more teachers will cheat. Do you agree? Do you think this shows that changes in education, including the testing required under No Child Left Behind, are putting too much pressure on your teachers? Or do you think there are just a few bad apples who cheat, and that public school teachers are no more pressured than they ever were? She hopped out, ran past idle onlookers and managed to put out the flames with her sweater. The dog, subsequently named Phoenix, survived for four days with burns over 95 percent of her body, but soon began to succumb to kidney failure and had to be euthanized.

But Leo Castelli, who opened a gallery in New York in 1957 and became the leading dealer of Pop Art and early Minimalism, deserves to be remembered in full-size type. A trim, courtly migr who had worked as a banker in prewar Europe, he was fluent in at least five languages and able to extol a Warhol soup can or a Richard Serra lead-pipe sculpture even in Romanian, which had tangible benefits. His achievement was to globalize American art in an age when Europeans still thought that made in the U.S.A. was a label best reserved for washing machines.

title: Manila Vice

Its colonial Spanish rulers brought with them the Roman Catholic Church, making the archipelago the largest Christian state in Asia. Adherence to church doctrine has given the country one of the worlds higher birth rates, but the churchs moral teachings havent made much of an impact. Having a mistress is de rigueur for political figures. Young prostitutes ply their trade in Manilas strip clubs, then go to Mass on Sunday. After the Spanish departed, the Americans left their mark. We will become American, says Cristo, one of the characters in Miguel Syjucos ambitious new novel about the Philippines. Our children will learn to speak American. description: Ariel Pinks Haunted Graffiti

title: Disease Threatens Japans Beef Trade
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan  It is a calamity for this quiet cattle community. A prized black calf born last fall will soon be killed, part of the mass destruction of livestock in Japans battle against its worst foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in at least a century.

title: A Laboratory for Violence
description: There are many ghosts in Beiruts Martyrs Square, among them numerous courageous and outspoken Lebanese journalists. Samir Kassir, a political commentator and opponent of Syrian meddling in Lebanon, was murdered by car bomb in June 2005. A year earlier, he had summed up the Lebanese paradox in a conversation with Michael Young: Yes, we were a laboratory for violence, but we were also, before that, a laboratory for modernity, and in some ways we still are.

title: Tug of War Over Izzo Continues
description: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo took a short plane ride from Lansing, Mich. to Cleveland Thursday, something hes done many times.

title: Musical Version of Elf Heading to Broadway
description: A musical adaptation of the 2003 film Elf, which starred Will Ferrell as a human raised among Santas little helpers, will help kick off the holiday season on Broadway in November with a limited run at the Al Hirschfeld Theater through Christmas and New Years Day, according to three people with knowledge of the plans.

title: Kitchen Comfort
description: What do you say about a novel in which the most interesting character is a glacier? Hold on, dont flip to the best-seller lists quite yet. This isnt the damning judgment it might seem, because this is no ordinary glacier: its the Siachen, the largest in Asia and, dare I say it, the most human chunk of flowing ice on earth. From the helicopter it looked like a giant mans tongue outside his mouth, licking a womans belly. Thats how Kirpal (Kip) Singh, the chef who narrates this novel by the Indian-Canadian writer Jaspreet Singh, describes it. Siachen was a big tattoo on a pregnant belly.

title: Bars Turn to Texting to Warn of Rowdy Patrons
description: PORTLAND, Me.  As patrons at Bull Feeneys danced to a 90s cover band and sipped from cans of Pabst Blue Ribbon, Eric Coulombe, the manager, fiddled with what he says is the latest weapon against the rowdiness and fighting that has long plagued the bar scene in this seaside city  an iPod Touch.

title: The Force Behind HBOs Documentaries
description: ONE recent midday eight producers, editors and researchers of an HBO documentary on postwar traumatic stress, Traumatology: The Art of Coming Home, were gathered in Sheila Nevinss documentary clubhouse  a pale turquoise, art-filled 12th-floor apartment on East 86th Street in Manhattan, downstairs from her home, that serves as an editing room. They were there to view work in progress, but Ms. Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, wanted to talk about one producers unusual medical condition.

title: Kagan Expressed Broad View of Religious Freedom
description: WASHINGTON  As a young White House lawyer, Elena Kagan waded deeply into politically volatile issues like abortion, immigration and religious freedom that may eventually come before her if she is confirmed to the Supreme Court, according to documents released Friday.

title: A High-Five for the Invisible Hand
description: The word market tends to set off a religious war. Opponents accuse proponents of blind faith in the Miracle of the Market. The proponents too often seem to confirm this accusation by overpromising and underproving what the market can do. (Opponents are often guilty of equally unthinking belief in the Immaculate Government Intervention.) Each side recites its creeds, giving heart to the faithful but making no converts.

title: Teaching a Reluctant Hound to Hunt
Competing in My Own Reality Show
description: A STUDENT in my summer writing class announced one day that he was going to star in a new reality show. Professional matchmakers were combing the globe to find him a wife.

title: Control Issues Shake College Sports
description: By some sort of cosmic coincidence, one of the biggest spectacles in international sport, the World Cup, kicked off on Friday, fresh on the heels of a day when the purely American spectacle of college sports erupted in one big messy fireball.

title: Proud, Painful Art on Baghdads Blast Walls
description: BAGHDAD Baghdads blast walls are a blank canvas. They reflect Iraqis shared history both proud and painful facts of life here in the capital.

title: Life Costs More Here, Unless Youre Hiring
description: New York City may be the most expensive place to live in America, but it is not the most costly place to employ people.

title: In Our Image
description: For all their daily efforts to disembowel one another, American foreign policy experts agree on one thing: the United States needs a new, coherent and practical strategy for the 21st century. Peter Beinarts Icarus Syndrome: A History of American Hubris doesnt attain this policy nirvana. Still, its a highly readable and useful hundred-year account of American ventures abroad that can serve as a path to understanding past failures and uncovering why policy renewal is now proving so elusive.

title: Letterman: Separate Oil From Seawater
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Yesterday, British Petroleum stock dropped $17 billion in value. And the executives at British Petroleum say they have no idea what happened. I kind of have an idea. I kind of think maybe I got a hunch.

title: What Were Reading: Goldman Still More Disliked than BP
Obama Takes a Hard Line Against Leaks to Press
description: WASHINGTON  Hired in 2001 by the National Security Agency to help it catch up with the e-mail and cellphone revolution, Thomas A. Drake became convinced that the governments eavesdroppers were squandering hundreds of millions of dollars on failed programs while ignoring a promising alternative.

title: Five Questions for Sean Hayes
description: Its been a newsworthy few months for the actor Sean Hayes. He came out of the closet in the national gay magazine The Advocate. He was the subject of a widely-discussed Newsweek essay that questioned his ability as an openly gay man to play straight in the Broadway revival of Promises, Promises. On Sunday, hell host the live broadcast of the Tony Awards at Radio City Music Hall. Next week the sitcom Hot in Cleveland, which hes producing, will begin airing on TV Land with a cast that includes Betty White.Mr. Hayes, who is nominated for a Tony for his performance in Promises, Promises, took a break during a rehearsal Thursday to talk with ArtsBeat about his full plates. Following are excerpts from his conversation.

title: Leno: A Cheap, Effective Solution
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: BP, which of course stands for Born Polluted, is spending $50 million on a p.r. campaign to make themselves look good. In fact, they said they would burn the midnight oil if they hadnt spilled it.

title: Fallon: Snooki Never Got the Message
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: You guys heard about Al Gore and Tipper splitting up? Everybody is talking about it. Everyones blogging about this, and now there are reports online that his daughter and her husband are splitting up. I bet this is the one week where Al Gore wishes he didnt invent the Internet.

title: Leave No War Behind
description: Probably no group of intellectuals has had a greater impact on American politics over the last four decades than the neoconservatives. The Rolling Stones even sang a song about them. Yet who or what exactly is a neoconservative? Over the years the meaning of the word has changed. Initially it referred to a coterie of liberals and leftists, absorbed in domestic policy issues, who raised questions about the efficacy of Lyndon Johnsons Great Society programs in the mid-1960s. Today, neoconservatives seem restricted for the most part to the Republican Party and are advocates of a muscular foreign policy. Irving Kristol, who once described himself as a liberal mugged by reality, was one kind of neoconservative. His son, William, a lifelong Republican, is an entirely different kind.

title: The Doubleheader Hits High Gear
description: It may be a down day on the track in Le Mans, but the drivers who will compete in the 24-hour race are on parade, and there is a buzz in the air. The grid is set for the worlds greatest endurance race: The former Formula One driver and hometown boy Sbastien Bourdais placed a Peugeot on the pole position Thursday night.

title: Weekend Competition: As I Always Say
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are posed a simple task.

title: TimesCast | June 11, 2010
description: Today, the oil spill takes a toll on jobs in the Gulf, negotiations heat up over financial reform on Capitol Hill, and South Africa plays Mexico to open the 2010 World Cup.

title: Student Crossword | The World Cup
description: Get ready for the 2010 World Cup with our Student Crossword. You can find the answers here.

title: My Nanny, Myself
description: In response to my post about the new domestic workers law on Wednesday, a reader, J., left a lengthy comment (No. 18) questioning the combative lens that some put on the subject.

title: Valiant Effort by S. Africa in Opener
description: JOHANNESBURG  The World Cup came to Africa on Friday for the first time, and South Africa proved to be an eager and proud host, if not a completely satisfied participant.

title: The Oil Spills Spillovers
description: In watching coverage of the crisis in the Gulf of Mexico, I  like many others  have been wondering what kind of effects it might have on alternative energy development in the United States. Are venture capitalists, expecting a tipping point, scrambling to invest in new technologies? Can we expect a flurry of new research and development spending in as-yet untried fuel sources?

title: My Backlogged Pages
description: In this age of Amazon recommendations and Kindle downloads, I still rely on the old-fashioned services of a book buyer. My personal book buyer has an uncanny ability to anticipate my tastes. He has introduced me to out-of-print novelists, obscure playwrights and classic philosophy tracts. Ive enjoyed nearly all of his choices, though quite a few remain stacked in my bookshelf, still unread.

title: Company Involved in G.M. Recall Said the Problem Runs Deeper
description: When General Motors recalled almost 1.4 million 2006-9 vehicles this week, the company said a system that heated the windshield-washer fluid could cause fires, even in vehicles that were turned off. As part of the recall, G.M. said it would remove the system.

title: On Stage With Marian Seldes
description: A looks at the actresss 60-year career in the theater.

title: The 60-Year Stage Life of Marian Seldes
description: On the day last January when Marian Seldes was planning to see her friend Angela Lansbury in the Broadway revival of  A Little Night Music,  she fell in her apartment, injuring her shoulder. Since the show must go on, even when its not hers, she sat through the three-hour musical, went backstage to say congratulations (Angela was wonderful, of course), then had dinner with friends. The consummate actress, Seldes did an expert job of hiding her pain, but by meals end the friends insisted on taking her to the emergency room. Her shoulder was so badly broken that it was replaced with a titanium model. She spent six weeks in rehab and is still undergoing physical therapy.

title: Bunch Muncherasi MD
description: I was vacuuming the bedroom one afternoon some months back when I moved a few books aside and spotted a dusty old scrap of paper. I recognized it instantly, and all at once realized my adult life had become a series of wrong turns.

title: Americas Next Top Kill
description: Youre a veteran of the Iraq war and a former Navy submarine officer whos now a scholar of nuclear policy at Columbia University. Youre also among the newly emergent big-bang crowd that wants to blow up the leaking well in the Gulf of Mexico.  I advocate the demolition of the well. Its feasible to use nuclear explosives. The Russians did it four times with a 100-percent success rate. But I fear the mere mention of the nuclear option has only given opponents and unnamed oil engineers a straw man to attack.

title: Lifelong Earning
description: Think of a person wearing an identity-related symbol and you probably think of logos. But wearable symbols dont have to be connected to brands. Noncorporate examples range from military patches to motorcycle-gang emblems, but one of the most appealing is the merit badge. While the classic form is associated with youthful scouts, in recent years the merit badge has crossed over into the adult world and is lately getting a digital twist.

title: Pop-Up Stars
description: In earlier times, major-league baseball players held regular jobs in the off-season. They managed bowling alleys, drove trucks, raised hogs.

title: Unedited Video of Israeli Raid Posted Online
description: Iara Lee, a Brazilian-American filmmaker and activist who was shooting a documentary on the flotilla of ships that was intercepted last week on its way to Gaza, has posted one hour of unedited video online that shows the early stages of the Israeli commando raid.

title: The Value of Losing a Business Competition
description: In business competitions, as in business, the odds of winning are stacked against entrepreneurs. Of course, the chance to meet investors and partners and to get expert feedback  along with the possibility of scoring prize money  are chief among the reasons students tend to compete. But why would companies that are already up and running, and in some cases venture backed, risk it? And when they lose, is it worth it?

title: A Lack of Oxygen
description: I am a physician. Near the end of a flight, the elderly man beside me said he did not feel well and mentioned a history of heart disease. As we landed, he slumped forward in his seat. I thought it urgent to give him oxygen. The flight attendant brought it but refused to allow me to administer it without permission from a supervisor, which we awaited in vain. He was helped off the plane in a wheelchair, placed on a stretcher and taken to a hospital. Promptly giving him oxygen could have lessened the damage from a heart attack and eased his pain. Should I have administered it without permission? LAWRENCE S. SCHIFFMAN,LEEDS, MASS.

title: Playing at Sexy
description: Last month, over the course of one workday, six friends sent me a link to the same video along with messages that said, Have you seen this? I had, but I clicked it each time anyway. I just couldnt stop myself. The clip showed a troupe of 8- and 9-year-old Los Angeles girls in a national dance contest. Wearing outfits that would make a stripper blush, they pumped it and bumped it to the Beyonc hit Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It). The girls were spectacular dancers, able to twirl on one foot while extending the other into a perfect standing split. But I doubt that two million people had tuned in simply to admire their arabesques. As with TV phenomena like Toddlers and Tiaras, the compulsion to watch was like the impulse to rubberneck at an accident, but in this case the scene was a 12-car pileup of early sexualization.

title: Pebble Beachs Water Hazard Is a Doozy
description: The layout and location of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, site of this weeks United States Open, can bring about some unusual rules situations, specifically because the course has holes that abut what is arguably the largest lateral water hazard in the world (i.e., the Pacific Ocean). For example, this week players may choose to drop a ball in a dropping zone outside of a bunker instead of in a bunker when taking relief under the water hazard Rule (Rule 26). The long bunker to the left of the 18th fairway at Pebble Beach is immediately adjacent to the ocean.

title: The Defense of Computers, the Internet and Our Brains
description: If youre reading this blog post on a computer, mobile phone or e-reader, please stop what youre doing immediately. You could be making yourself stupid. And whatever you do, dont click on the links in this post. They could distract you from the flow of my beautiful prose and narrative.

description: Viktor & Rolf create white blouses that are basic but not boring, a bag that combines beauty and function, and more items.

title: BP Directors to Discuss Suspension of Dividends
description: HOUSTON  BP said Friday that its board of directors would meet Monday to discuss whether to suspend the companys dividend to pay spill-related claims.

description: Who: Jack Black

title: Counting Feathered Folk in the Bronx
description: Usually when people get this worked up over Baltimore Orioles arriving in the Bronx, they are New York Yankee fans. But John Delaney is a Mets fan. He is also a publicity man for the Wildlife Conservation Society and an avid bird-watcher.

title: Rehnquist Was Asked to Review Wiretapping Program
description: WASHINGTON  The legal battle over the Bush administrations program of eavesdropping without warrants has never reached the Supreme Court. But it may have come closer than previously known, as a result of an approach to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist prompted by National Security Agency employees who believed the program violated the law.

title: Across Iran, Anger Lies Behind Face of Calm
description: TEHRAN  One year after Irans disputed presidential election, the familiar rhythms of life have returned here. Through a widespread, sustained and at times brutal crackdown, the government has succeeded in suppressing a protest movement that shook the nation for months after the re-election of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, which the opposition said was fraudulent.

title: Reliance Industries to Buy Indian Broadband Company
description: NEW DELHI  Indias bitterest family feud got down to business on Friday.

title: Gunmen Kill 19 at Drug Rehab Center in Northern Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Getting treatment for drug addiction has become a dangerous activity in the northern state of Chihuahua, where gunmen allied with drug cartels have staged numerous attacks on rehabilitation centers, including a particularly vicious massacre on Thursday night that left 19 men dead, the authorities said Friday.

title: The Governments Elite and Regulatory Capture
description: The fate and scope of financial reform is now left to the Senate and House conference committee, which is putting together the final bill. It is an unsettling time as the struggle over derivatives reform, the Volcker Rule and untold nuances and seemingly minor provisions are left to jockeying among elected representatives. Yet, while there are many good things in the bill that should form the core of any financial reform and subsequent acts by Congress, there is one area  perhaps the key one  that this bill fails to address.

title: When a Playwright and His Play Are Separated
description: Michael Golamco is a young West Coast playwright whose Year Zero has received praise during its run at Second Stage Uptown. ArtsBeat asked him to write about what its like to drop in from one coast, work with new collaborators, and then leave the play (which closes on Sunday) behind. Heres what he had to say:

title: Letter: M.I.A.s Agitprop Pop
description: A cover story on M.I.A.? Why? What has she ever done that is truly substantive or important? Media folks love talking about her because she merits all the right buzzwords: multicultural, cutting-edge, globalized hip-hop, etc. And it is all true.

title: Letters: The Why-Worry Generation
Letter: What Happened to Valor?
description: In her article, Katherine Zoepf purports to show that since 9/11, the military has awarded remarkably few Medals of Honor. That conclusion follows from the comparison of medals awarded per serving service member and thus will be higher in times of heavy fighting and lower when only a small part of the military is engaged. A far better measure is the ratio of awards to combat deaths. For the span from 9/11 to now, there have been six medal awards and 4,279 combat deaths, for a ratio of about 1 to 713. In World War II there were 292,131 combat deaths and 464 medals, a ratio of 1 to 629: in the 94th Infantry Division, we had 1,200 combat deaths and one Medal of Honor.

title: Letters: The Teachers Unions Last Stand
description: As the superintendent of a small, rural school district in northwestern Pennsylvania, I read Steven Brills article (May 23) with interest. I recently testified before the House Committee on Education and Labor concerning problems with the presidents reform framework. Our district did not participate in our states Race to the Top application for one very simple reason: The four reform frameworks would be impossible to implement. Small, rural school districts are often isolated, and finding teachers to fill openings caused by the reform frameworks would be impossible.

title: Iterate
description: If you use Facebook much, you know the drill. You log on for your social-networking fix, and the site looks different from how you remembered it, either subtly or radically so. An endless stream of design changes can leave users feeling unsettled  or even irate, as has been the case with the latest uproar over Facebooks privacy settings. Why all the behind-the-scenes tinkering? Its the way of the Web these days: everything is iterating.

title: The Electric Smart: A Car That Seems to Demand Batteries
description: The battery-powered Smart car is based on the 1-liter, 3-cylinder gas version introduced to the United States in 2008, but it sure doesnt drive like one.

title: Life Costs More in N.Y.C., Unless Youre Hiring
description: New York City may be the most expensive place to live in America, but it is not the most costly place to employ people, Patrick McGeehan writes on the City Room blog.

title: Ruling in Bonds Case Sets Back Prosecutors
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled on Friday that prosecutors would be barred from using what they say are positive drug tests and doping calendars in the perjury case against Barry Bonds, significantly hurting the governments case.

title: Inside the Circus of Oxfords Poetry Professor Election
description: World Cup, shmorld cup  if youre not following the heated election for the professor of poetry at Oxford University, youre missing out on some intense and cutthroat competition.

title: Google News Gives News Organizations a Chance to Stand Out
description: Many mainstream news organizations have long viewed Google News as a threat to their interests.

title: The Glee Generation
description: THERES a scene in the 1985 college comedy The Sure Thing in which John Cusack, then as now an avatar of insouciant hipster cool, climbs into a car thats supposed to take him cross-country to Los Angeles. He doesnt know the student couple hes riding with; he merely answered the ad they posted on the campus ride board. They turn out to be his worst nightmare.

title: The View From Inside
description: An hours drive northwest from Baton Rouge sits the Louisiana State Penitentiary, known as Angola, the largest maximum security prison in the United States. On the site of a former slave plantation, it currently houses close to 5,000 inmates and covers more ground, at 18,000 acres, than the island of Manhattan. Surrounded on three sides by the Mississippi River, its stunning physical isolation and distinctive antebellum feel have provided the backdrop for numerous feature films and documentaries, including  Dead Man Walking,   Monsters Ball  and  The Farm.  For Southerners, especially African-Americans, Angola is both a prison and a state of mind, a relic from before the civil rights era, when white supremacy was the custom and racial segregation was the law.

title: Two Wheels, High Drama and an App
description: You dont have to like bicycling to love Lance Armstrong, but you do have to like drama. And with one month until this years Tour de France, you can follow Mr. Armstrongs story on your iPhone with a new, free Team RadioShack app.

title: Reviewing Glenn Beck
description: Media Matters for America has an early look at Glenn Becks novel, The Overton Window.

title: Capello, Super Cool
description: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  In a terse, nine-minute news conference after Englands final training session before its Group C opener, Manager Fabio Capello failed to mention the United States team or a single American player. Not in English and not in Italian.

title: Random Acts of Science
description: Quantum mechanics is the most revolutionary scientific theory to appear in the past 150 years. In the atomic domain, it superseded laws first set out by Isaac Newton a quarter of a millennium earlier and has since had an unbroken string of successes. Today, it continues to give an utterly reliable account of the behavior of the subatomic world, yet there are nagging doubts that there is something rotten at its core.

title: Answers From a Brooklyn Blogger, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest.

title: Final: Uruguay 0, France 0
description: After the first day of the 2010 World Cup and all the pomp and circumstance, there was nothing that sorted out the direction that Group A will take with both games ending in draws. Uruguay, an underdog like South Africa was when it faced Mexico, is no doubt feeling better after playing to a scoreless draw with France.

title: Notes on a Scandal
description: Enter the New Zealander Eleanor Catton, stage left, delivering a wildly brilliant and precocious first novel (shes in her mid-20s) thats not easy to describe. Nonlinear and occasionally tricky to follow, its a series of plays within plays; and as in a piece of experimental theater, its characters often break mid-dialogue to confess in startlingly honest asides or snatch at one anothers thoughts, with lighting and music added during moments of high drama or hushed intimacy. The plays not just the thing, its everything. If Catton seems to be getting up in your face with high art, thats because she knows her tale has been told before and she wants to make it new.

title: So an Herb Walks Into a Bar ...
description: IN an enclave better known for bodacious beach bodies, pumping dance clubs and misbehaving reality TV stars, theres a mixology movement afoot in Miami, led by the cocktail gurus at the Living Room, the bar and lounge of the W South Beach hotel and residences.

title: The High Cost of Loving Your Phone
description: OUR cellphones have become love objects. We take them everywhere and stare at them constantly. We panic when they are lost and grieve when they die. We even clothe them.

title: Hope for America
description: A new exhibition at the Library of Congress surveys the political humor of Bob Hope and others.

title: Tribe of One
description: More than 800 pages long and the result of nine years labor, Joshua Cohens third novel, Witz, is a deliberate act of excess thats also an exercise in omission  the product of a negative aesthetic that emphasizes what isnt there. In telling the story of the last Jew alive, for example, Cohen omits the word Jew. And within the loose skeleton of a coming-of-age story, he negates the premise of growth through experience by having his central character be born full size, at full intelligence . . . with glasses and hairy.

title: TV Gives Dance a Boost, and Thats Good, Right?
description: IN the 1990s the British producer Nigel Lythgoe confronted an unanticipated and unsettling side effect to the popularity of his television series Gladiators: children were emulating the shows cast members, slamming into one another on playgrounds without helmets and hurting themselves.

title: U.S. vs. England: A Divide as Wide as an Ocean
description: The United States opens its 2010 World Cup against England on Saturday in a match that has generated more than a few chest-poking arguments in bars and pubs on both sides of the pond. David Hirshey and Roger Bennett, authors of The ESPN World Cup Companion, come to the game from opposite ends of the field. One is from New York and came of age watching Brazils mind-blowing World Cup champion of 1970. The other, born in Liverpool, suffered as England found increasingly theatrical ways to shatter the hearts of a nation in the late 80s and early 90s.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

description: FEW things are more alarming to the modern hyperparent than a silent teenager. And for good reason: The quiet ones usually have something to hide.

title: Resort Report | Louis Vuitton, Still Sweet on the 50s
description: In keeping with Marc Jacobss fall collection for Louis Vuitton, the theme for Resort was 50s. This time around it translated into sweet colors, full skirts and, yes, great accessories, from straw fedoras to eyeglass chains, and my favorite resort shoe so far: a strappy-brown leather sandal with a floral-print insole.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The virtual postman delivered a lot of birthday-dinner questions this week, and the usual run of putatively food-loving people who dont eat meat. There were questions about brunch, about tasting menus and about much more. Herewith four good people with four good queries, along with my answers.

title: For Better, for Worse, for B.M.I.
description: BLAME the pizza. Thats what Jennifer Deans does. She blames the pizza she and her husband devoured on a regular basis for the combined 95 pounds they gained in the four years that they have been married.

title: Sara Manning, Carter Griffin

Griffin and Haynes G. Griffin of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Ronald T. Evans, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Figure Eight Island Yacht Club in Wilmington, N.C.

title: Cooking Tools: Barbecue Gadgets
description: No one epitomizes the pursuit of barbecue like my father-in-law. Johns DVR is half-full of barbecue-related cooking shows, and he spends hours reading online commentary on proper smoking techniques. He uses natural gas when hes in a hurry, and charcoal when hes got all day, and can discuss the benefits of each. His esteem for the Weber brand is akin to another demographics feelings for Apple  that is, he believes its not just the best, but that it has no credible competition.

title: The Tony Is Given a Mini-Makeover
description: For the first time in 43 years, Tony is growing up. The Tony Award statuette  a medallion mounted on a black pedestal with a curved armature  has gotten taller and heavier in advance of Sunday nights ceremony at Radio City Music Hall. It now stands five inches tall, up from three and a quarter inches, and weighs 3 1/2 pounds, a two-pound gain. (The new model is above left, next to the old.) Howard Sherman, the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which administers the Tonys in partnership with the Broadway League, said the previous one felt light in the hand, and the change was meant to make it feel more substantial. We know the physical scale of the Oscars, Emmys and Grammys, he said. While were not attempting to keep up with the Joneses, we felt this is a significant award, and it could feel and look a bit more significant. When the first Tonys were given in 1947, winners received scrolls and a money clip, for the men, or a compact, for the women. In 1949, the award was turned into a medallion inside a presentation case. In 1967, the year the awards were first televised, the medallion was mounted onto a base.

title: N.B.A. Championships Score Big Points for ABC

Although Nielsens final results were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary numbers showed Game 4, broadcast on ABC, drew slightly better ratings than Game 3 on Tuesday, which was watched by nearly 16 million people. ABC was the nights top-rated network while CBS ranked second with repeats of its crime shows CSI and The Mentalist. Fox was third, garnering 6.6 million viewers for So You Think You Can Dance. NBC placed fourth with comedy repeats and its new show 100 Questions (2.3 million).

title: Musical Version of Elf Heading to Broadway
description: A musical adaptation of the 2003 film Elf, which starred Will Ferrell as a human raised among Santas little helpers, will help kick off the holiday season on Broadway in November with a limited run at the Al Hirschfeld Theater through Christmas and New Years Day, according to three people with knowledge of the plans. Thomas Meehan (Annie, The Producers), who is writing the shows book with Bob Martin (The Drowsy Chaperone), said in a telephone interview that Elf the Musical was in very good shape, very fun shape and was set to arrive at the Hirschfeld some time in November. The music is by Matthew Sklar and the lyrics by Chad Beguelin, who collaborated on the musical adaptation of the movie The Wedding Singer. Two theater executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity in order to discuss the show ahead of its official announcement, said that the director and choreographer Casey Nicholaw (Drowsy Chaperone, All About Me) would direct Elf and that the run was expected at this point to be limited, similar to recent holiday-timed shows on Broadway like Irving Berlins White Christmas and Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The current tenant at the Hirschfeld, the musical revival of Hair, has announced that it will close on June 27.

title: Final Twilight Movie to Be Split in Two
description: Even if youve never read a Twilight book in your whole undead existence, youre probably aware that Breaking Dawn, the fourth and final entry in Stephenie Meyers novels about a young vampire and the human woman who loves him, is possibly the strangest in that series. (Among other plot twists, the human Bella gives birth to the vampire Edwards baby, and the werewolf Jacob becomes romantically bonded to that baby.) So whats the best way to handle the cinematic adaptation of such a weird work? Break it into two movies, of course. Summit Entertainment, the movie studio behind the Twilight films, will release the film version of Breaking Dawn as two separate movies, The Hollywood Reporter said. Both will be directed by Bill Condon (Gods and Monsters, Dreamgirls), above, with the first part to be released on Nov. 18, 2011, and the second planned for the following year. The third, less strange movie in the cycle, The Twilight Saga: Eclipse will be released on June 30. The breaking up of Breaking Dawn follows other cinematic literary adaptations that have been divided into two films, including Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (which will be released in two parts in 2010 and 2011) and The Hobbit (planned as two films for 2011 and 2012).

title: Brooklyn Party Space To Return In a Flash
description: The party will go on. A week after the Bklyn Yard, the popular performance space on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, announced that it was closing, Justin Carter, a D. J. and promoter who has produced weekly events there, said his party, Sunday Best, would continue. Weve worked it out so were going to be able to have a shot at it, Mr. Carter said in an interview. The response that got poured out when people saw the space was shut down was really intense, and we think that people really want to see something happen here. Before the shutdown, Sunday Best had already booked D. J.s for this summer, starting with Dam-Funk this Sunday, who will appear as planned. (Above, the D. J. Michael Mayer at a Sunday Best engagement.) The space, now to be known simply by its address, 400 Carroll Street, has drawn thousands of people over the last four summers for a mix of outdoor dance parties, concerts, fashion and food events, serving as a destination in a developing neighborhood. Mr. Carter would not specify what deal he and his fellow party promoters  the D. J.s Eamon Harkin and Doug Singer  struck with the landlord, but some changes will be made. The space, already sparsely decorated, will be bare bones, Mr. Carter said, though a spinning disco ball will remain. For now, liquor will not be permitted on the premises, though Mr. Carter said he and his partners would pursue the proper licensing to allow for that as soon as possible.

title: Book Planned About Raid On Gaza-Bound Flotilla

The publisher, OR Books, specializes in books that are based on current events and rushed to publication quickly. Paperback and digital copies of the new book, Murder on the Mavi Marmara, are expected to be available on July 28. It will be edited by Moustafa Bayoumi, a professor of English at Brooklyn College and the author of How Does It Feel to Be a Problem?, and contain a retelling of the attack by eyewitnesses, and analysis of the blockade and the conflict in the region.

title: Afghanistan: Violence Claims 14
description: Eleven Afghans and three NATO soldiers were killed in violence Friday in Afghanistan. A suicide bomber wearing a burqa walked into a bazaar in Zabul Province, as a foot patrol of NATO soldiers walked through the same area. The bombers explosion killed two NATO soldiers and two Afghans, according to a NATO spokesman and a spokesman for the Zabul governor. In a rural area of Kandahar Province, a roadside bomb exploded as a minivan passed, killing nine civilian passengers, three children, the Kandahar governor said, and a NATO soldier was killed in eastern Afghanistan.

Young newlyweds from Long Island, still recovering from their reception for 600 guests the previous weekend, faltered as their lawyer quizzed them on the details of their City Hall ceremony four months before. A Manhattan woman bickered with her Turkish spouse about the kinds of questions they had been warned to expect.

title: France: Russia Stresses Iran Pledge
description: Russias prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, told French President Nicolas Sarkozy that Moscow would continue to freeze delivery of S-300 missiles to Iran after the United Nations Security Council passed further sanctions against Tehran, Mr. Sarkozys office said Friday. The sanctions do not specifically cover the missiles, but Mr. Putin apparently underlined Russias commitment, made privately to Washington and to Israel as well, not to destabilize the region through arms sales  especially of the S-300, a mobile, long-range air defense system. In Paris, Mr. Putin also agreed with the French to speed up talks on the possible sale of four French-made transport ships that can carry helicopters and tanks. France wants to sell the ships, known as the Mistral, without sophisticated guidance and weapons systems; Mr. Putin wants the ships fully equipped.

So its owners are going after different customers, with the help of a roadside sign: Disaster Catering Available! Lets Talk.

description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazils Senate has approved a bill that would divide billions of dollars in oil royalties equally among the countrys states, threatening the countrys largest oil producing state, Rio de Janeiro, with the loss of up to $4 billion in revenue.

title: The Latest Work Dodge: A Shutdown
description: Once again, Albanys lawmakers are disgracing the state. In this case, the $135 billion state budget is more than 70 days late and around $9.2 billion short. An annoyed governor, David Paterson, has begun adding sections of the 2010-11 budget every week to emergency budget extenders. If lawmakers refuse, they will shut down the entire state government.

description: Since the Texas Rangers agreed to a sale to a group led by Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan for $575 million earlier this year, creditors of the teams parent company have insisted that other bidders would have paid more.

title: BPs Responsibility
description: The Times reported on Friday that investors and politicians in Britain are increasingly upset at Americas criticisms of BP. This isnt an issue of American pique or British patriotism. Americans are rightly angry at BPs inability to stop a disastrous leak for which it was wholly unprepared and its failure to tell the truth about the extent of the damage.

My 17-year-old son, Alex, was more generous. I think I should give the king my bed, he said, wondering aloud if the king, who had been living in a Tibetan refugee settlement in India, would require security.

They spend weekends there with their son, Harry, 5.

He pointed  not at a mugger running away, not at a bleeding bullet hole, but at a map. Specifically, the part marked Rockefeller Center.

title: An Esoteric Menu for an Eclectic Crowd
description: True to its name, the Gilt restaurant on Madison Avenue is carved out of the study of the 19th-century Villard Mansion at the Palace Hotel, seats 55 and oozes opulence. With cathedral ceilings, sparkling mosaic tile floors and elaborately carved moldings and paneling, the restaurant pays homage to the Gilded Age. The $89 prix fixe menu, known for skilled combinations of esoteric ingredients, plus a 2,100-bottle wine list, with 50 offerings by the glass, attracts an eclectic crowd. On Tuesday night, it was an elegantly appointed mix of serious-looking men in gray (not flannel) suits, couples, ladies who might be lunching if the place were open for lunch, and close friends out for a laugh-filled night on the town.

title: Mindful of TV Blackouts, Jets Slash Their Seat Fees
description: With the first regular-season game in their new stadium three months away, the Jets again slashed the price of thousands of personal seat licenses Friday in a bid to ensure that their home games are broadcast on television.

title: The Courage to Leave
description: There is no good news coming out of the depressing and endless war in Afghanistan. There once was merit to our incursion there, but that was long ago. Now were just going through the tragic motions, flailing at this and that, with no real strategy or decent end in sight.

title: Bad News: They Only Think Theyre Happy
description: Imagine a golden summer. You and your spouse are cooking, drinking wine, nuzzling and getting ready to watch the sunset from your house on Marthas Vineyard. There you are with your best friends, who will soon marry and have two children roughly the same age as yours. Imagine that the summer lasts 12 years. And that one night, over lemon almond polenta cake, it ends.

title: Trying to Make History, With 6 Votes Per Person
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y.  There is little in this Westchester County village to suggest that one of the most important elections in its history is under way. Demure campaign signs punctuate lawns here and there. Even more rarely, residents may run across a candidate shaking hands at the mall.

title: Down to the River to Play, and Sing and Dance
description: LAST year, when Jeff Rumpf was planning the 32nd annual Great Hudson River Revival  some version of the event, widely known as the Clearwater Festival, has been held since the mid-1960s  he made what he now calls a big mistake.

title: Arabic Class Becomes a Popular Choice
description: Luke Smith-Stevens was 9 when he heard a roar and looked up to see one of the two planes that would hit the twin towers flying directly over his classrooms skylight. In the subsequent months, he tried to make sense of the conversations he overheard and half-understood, the ubiquitous feelings of rage.

title: A String Quartet in Tangles
description: Dissonance is the name by which a popular Mozart string quartet is known; it is also the name of Damian Lanigans prickly play about a group of musicians practicing the piece for an important Carnegie Hall concert. Their relationships are full of conflict and power plays.

title: On the Stage, Reviving a 300-Year-Old Patient
description: It might be nice to report that the Schoolhouse Theater has mounted Molires classic French comedy The Imaginary Invalid in order to add its two cents to the nations health care discussion. But for better or worse, and I suspect its for better, Pamela Moller Karemans production seems to have been intended just for the fun of it. To the extent that theres commentary, its all Molires, as the much-abused intimates of Monsieur Argan  and in particular, his marriageable daughter  cope with his all-consuming hypochondria.

The view from Pier Restaurant, however, is wider, virtually uninterrupted, and can be enjoyed from under the cool thatch of the tiki bar or from a table on the adjoining breezy patio, a haven on a sultry summers day.

title: Clams With the Crowds
description: We really are a barometer of summer, said Mace Colodny, 49, of Centerport, whose family has owned and operated the Shack, an open-air clam bar and restaurant there, since 1980. When people see the crowds, they know summer is here.

title: Breeders Cup to Return to Kentucky
description: The Breeders Cup awarded Churchill Downs its featured event, one of the richest in racing, for a second consecutive year. After a two-year run at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif., Churchill Downs was picked as the host for the 2011 Breeders Cup. This years two-day event was already set for Nov. 5-6 at the track, home of the Kentucky Derby. Churchill seemed the logical choice for 2011 because of several factors: in California, a lease dispute and drainage issues at Santa Anita; in New York, finances and politics. cup (AP)

title: War Insight, Beyond Bang-Bang

title: Repayments Top Loans Outstanding in Bailout

TARP repayments have continued to exceed expectations, substantially reducing the projected cost of this program to taxpayers, Herbert Allison, the Treasurys assistant secretary for financial stability, said in a statement.

title: Sigmar Polke, Whose Sly Works Shaped Contemporary Painting, Dies at 69
description: Sigmar Polke, an artist of infinite, often ravishing pictorial jest, whose sarcastic and vibrant layering of found images and maverick painting processes left an indelible mark on the last four decades of contemporary painting, died Thursday in Cologne, Germany. He was 69.

title: Groupe Danone Agrees to Buy Medical Nutrition
description: Groupe Danone, the yogurt maker, agreed to buy Medical Nutrition USA for about $62.3 million, adding protein supplements for the elderly to its medical-nutrition business in the United States. Danone will pay $4 a share, 44 percent more than the closing price Thursday for Medical Nutrition, which makes Pro-Stat proteins, Danone said. The purchase would bolster Danones medical nutrition unit, which increased sales 8.3 percent last year to 925 million euros ($1.1 billion), accounting for 6 percent of total revenue. Medical Nutrition USA makes liquid proteins that are predigested by fruit enzymes, helping people with protein deficiencies and accelerating tissue healing in patients with ulcers, according to its Web site.

title: For Hartford Stage, Facelift at the Theater

Theyll be about five miles away, in the Roberts Theater at the Kingswood-Oxford School in West Hartford, while Hartford Stages 33-year-old theater gets a $4 million makeover. The renovation is the first phase of a two-part project expected to be completed by 2013, before the celebration of the theaters 50th anniversary.

Four years ago, a collection of the most insightful lessons culled from the magazine through the decades was published. title: Floodwaters Recede, Leaving Death and Debris
description: LANGLEY, Ark.  In the steamy heat of an Arkansas summer, more than 200 rescue workers spread across the banks of the Little Missouri River on Saturday to search for victims and survivors of a devastating flash flood that killed at least 18 people who were caught unaware in the dark of a secluded campground. They found two more bodies, after locating 16 on Friday, but were worried that perhaps dozens more might be hidden in the thick brush of a craggy gorge.

title: Rap Invites the Party Onstage
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  Who are the real communal utopians at Bonnaroo? Sometimes it seemed to be the rappers. Wale, late on Thursday night, and Jay Electronica, on Friday afternoon, both invited the audience to dance onstage during their sets and were soon surrounded by flailing arms and grinning facesso many that Jay Electronicas security ended up clearing the stage again during the set. Meanwhile, the proudly disorganized neo-hippie band Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeroswho play an amiably ramshackle blend of 1960s skittle rock and soul, with singalong lyrics about sunshine, love and other, as one song puts it, sentimental liesrambled loosely around the stage themselves, but left the audience offstage.

title: Florida Skips Offshore Oil Binge but Still Pays
description: KEY LARGO, Fla.  When rigs first started drilling for oil off Louisianas coast in the 1940s, Floridians scanned their shoreline, with its resorts and talcum-white beaches, and said, No thanks. Go ahead and drill, they told other Gulf Coast states; well stick with tourism.

title: Rodriguez Discusses His Injury
description: Alex Rodriguez learned Friday that tendinitis in his right hip flexor had been the source of the tightness near his groin area. Rodriguez, who left after the first inning of Thursdays loss in Baltimore, did not play in the Yankees win over the Houston Astros on Friday and is considered day to day. The following is a transcript of Rodriguezs meeting with reporters after Fridays game.

title: Cover Songs Set Free at Bonnaroo
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  Its not a Bonnaroo set without a wild-card cover version. The Flaming Lips and an allied group, Stardeath and White Dwarfs, played the entirety of Pink Floyds Dark Side of the Moon with no deference at all. With fuzztone bass and wah-wah guitars, a garage-rock kick and non-portentous vocals, it went lurching toward Flaming Lipsdisheveled version of madness rather than Pink Floyds majestic one.

title: A Decade Later, Genetic Map Yields Few New Cures
description: Ten years after President Bill Clinton announced that the first draft of the human genome was complete, medicine has yet to see any large part of the promised benefits.

title: At Bonnaroo, Looking Inward
description: The big party that is Bonnaroo teetered on an uncharacteristic mood on Friday: introspection. The headliner, Kings of Leon, has taken some of Southern rocks basic tensionsbetween faith and hell-raising, gospel and blues, pride and guilt, lust and repentanceinto songs that wrestle private demons but ring like arena-rock. And the more pensive side of Kings of Leon rippled down through the rest of the days bill. The National brooded cryptically over smoldering crescendos and U2 guitar chords. Dr. Dog pondered mortality, even as its songs bounded forward with cascading guitars and casual vocal harmonies.

title: Offensive Equivalent of the Perfect Game
description: A display case in the press box at Nationals Park shows a scorecard from Don Larsens perfect game in the 1956 World Series. It belonged to Shirley Povich, a longtime Washington Post sportswriter, and in its margins is a reference to Charlie Robertson and the year 1922.

title: Gardner Hopes to Return to Lineup
description: Brett Gardner, who has been relegated to pinch-running situations because of a mild sprain in his left thumb, took about 30 swings in batting practice Saturday and said he hoped to return to the Yankees lineup on Sunday.Gardner said after batting practice his thumb felt good and that he would be available to play Saturday against the Houston Astros.I feel like I could hit today or play the field today or whatever they need me to do, Gardner said before the game.Gardner said he would continue to heavily tape the thumb, which he did before taking batting practice.Gardner felt discomfort in the thumb Tuesday after a check-swing groundout in the sixth inning against Baltimore and then he jammed it during an at-bat in the eighth. He missed 40 games last year with a fracture in the same thumb.

title: Expectations Have Fallen as Woods Flounders
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  As Tiger Woods returns to the United States Open this week at Pebble Beach, the site of his still-stunning victory in 2000, he is facing some uncomfortable truths and difficult barriers. Four days before the tournament begins, Woods is trying to find a game that will hold up under major championship pressure.

title: Breaking Gender Barriers in the Negro Leagues
description: WASHINGTON  Mamie Johnson feels a kinship with Eri Yoshida, the Japanese female knuckleballer who recently became one of the few women ever to pitch in professional baseball. She nods knowingly at suspicions that Yoshida, the 18-year-old so-called Knuckle Princess, pitches for the far-flung Chico (Calif.) Outlaws less as a competitor than as a curiosity.

title: Rodriguez Unavailable Again
description: For a second straight game, Alex Rodriguez was not in the Yankees lineup because oftendinitis in his right hip flexor. His availability to pinch hit againstthe Houston Astros was not known.Rodriguez is considered day to day with the tendinitis, which is not believed to be related to the hip surgery he had in 2009. Manager Joe Girardi did not know if Rodriguez would be available as a pinch-hitter Saturday because Rodriguez did not meet with the training staff before Girardi briefed reporters.Hes not ready to go and well continue to evaluate him every day and see what availability we have of him every day, Girardi said before the game. Hes not a starter for us. I came to the ballpark not planning on starting him. Ill keep talking to our doctors.Rodriguez was not available to reporters before the game.Rodriguez did not play on Friday. He had complained of tightness in his groin area and exited after the first inning of Thursdays loss at Baltimore. Rodriguez also exited early in a Yankees win over Toronto last Sunday, a day after a 14-inning loss to the Blue Jays.Asked if Rodriguezs workout regimen to warm up his surgically repaired hip might have caused the tendinitis, Girarid said: He didnt have a problem until we played that 14-inning game on the turf. So is it more of his workload or was it more the 14 innings on the turf, a day game after night game? If I was a guessing man, Id guess it was the latter.Girardi said he did not know whether Rodriguez might be used as a designated hitter when he returns.Kevin Russo was listed as the Yankees starting third baseman on Saturday. Ramiro Pena started at third base Friday and went 0 for 3.

title: Kodak Gives Worlds Largest Photographs to Museum

Coloramas, towering backlighted transparencies that were 18 feet high and 60 feet wide, were promoted by Kodak as the worlds largest photographs. More than 500 were publicly displayed, for runs of three weeks each. (Above, Family in Convertible, Texas.) They often contained idealized depictions of American daily life, usually showing a Kodak camera being used to photograph a family, activity or beautiful scene. The archive gift includes display images of all Coloramas, including those that were never displayed, along with research documents, negatives and other prints and files. An exhibition of 36 Coloramas, focusing on the 1960s, will be on view at the Eastman House from Saturday through Oct. 17.

title: Smithsonian Gets Itself a Lifeboat
description: No, its not a federal bailout, but an actual lifeboat: the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company has donated a 100-year-old boat, used on two early attempted crossings of the Atlantic by airships, to the Smithsonians National Air and Space Museum. The lifeboat, above, was first used by the journalist Walter Wellman and his crew in their attempt at the first powered flight across the Atlantic in 1910. They flew for 38 hours before being forced down by engine problems near Bermuda and rescued by a steamer. The boats next mission ended less happily. In 1912 Wellmans chief engineer, Melvin Vaniman, tried to cross the Atlantic on the Akron, the first Goodyear airship. It had barely gotten over water when it exploded, sending the crew members to their deaths. The lifeboat, however, was saved and has been kept in storage by Goodyear since then. After being cleaned, it will go on display at the museum near two historic aircraft that succeeded in crossing the Atlantic: the gondola of the first balloon to do so, and the Concorde.

On Friday he filed papers arguing that prosecutors were simply taking the same motion before a different judge, without any changed circumstances, The Associated Press reported. A previous judge in the case, Keith Schwartz, prohibited Dr. Murray, above, from administering anesthetics but did not suspend his license. The case has now been taken over by Judge Michael Pastor.
