title: Obama, Visiting Gulf, Tries to Lift Economy and Mood
description: THEODORE, Ala.  President Obama on Monday stepped up his efforts to limit the economic fallout from the oil spill, announcing steps to assure consumers that seafood from the Gulf of Mexico is safe and promoting tourism in the region as BP, under pressure from the White House, agreed to accelerate the cleanup.

title: Japan Eases Past Cameroon
description: In a turgid affair in Bloemfontein, South Africa, Japan beat Cameroon, 1-0, on Monday.

title: A Boy and His Kalashnikov
description: 2:32 p.m. | Updated As Jeffrey Gettleman reports in The Times today, American money is helping the Transitional Federal Government in Somalia recruit an army that includes heavily armed boys. Welcome to Planet Teen, where the fate of children  particularly the worlds billion-plus teenagers  will substantially shape the quality of life in developing countries for decades to come.

title: Skilling Behind Bars: Enrons Ex-Chief Speaks
description: While he awaits word from the Supreme Court over the appeal of his Enron conviction, Jeffrey K. Skilling has decided to open up.

title: Terrazzo, Terrazzo! And Inadvertent Verity
description: You can gaze at its constellation-filled ceiling, or admire those sky-high Corinthian columns, but there is one way to appreciate the neo-Classical splendor of Grand Central Terminal that does not require a craned neck: stare at the floor.

title: For Salon Reporter, a Long Commitment to Arlington Burial Story
description: For most reporters, there is nothing less interesting that the last story they did. They report something, write it up and then it is on to next. But investigative reporters are autodidacts, grabbing a single subject by the throat and hanging on, like a dog on a soup bone.

title: The Life, Death and Rebirth of Big Bad John
description: You may remember Jimmy Dean, the country music star and entrepreneur who, The Associated Press reported, died Sunday at age 81, as a Tonight Show guest host, a purveyor of sausage products, or as Willard Whyte, the eccentric Las Vegas billionaire from the James Bond movie Diamonds Are Forever.

title: Caregiving and Alzheimers: A Road Map
description: What I like about the new guide for those caring for people with Alzheimers disease, published by the National Institute on Aging, is that its:a) simply written;b) comprehensive, covering issues from medical conditions and legal documents to why you shouldnt try to take your relatives temperature with a glass thermometer;c) free.

title: Brief Paddock News From Montreal
description: Over the last four and a half years of blogging I have occasionally shared short news briefs from the paddock from my friend and journalist colleague Agns Carlier. Agns has just sent me a load of fresh gossipy items from the Canadian Grand Prix:

title: Researchers Sail to the Spill Site
description: One journey Ill be following closely over the next week is the voyage of the Cape Hatteras, a 135-foot research vessel operated by the Duke/University of North Carolina Oceanographic Consortium. As we reported here last week, scientists from these and other universities are sailing into the heart of the oil spill to study its environmental impact. After a stop in Gulfport, Miss., the crew departed Saturday for the spill site in the Gulf of Mexico and is blogging from the boat.

title: Brooklyn Heights, 6:45 A.M.
Indictment Over Bloomberg Campaign Funds
description: Updated, 1:29 p.m. | A top Republican political operative was charged on Monday by the Manhattan district attorneys office with grand larceny, money laundering and three other counts in connection with accusations that he stole $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during last years campaign.

title: 24 Hours of Le Mans From the Best Seat in the House, Literally
description: When I covered my first 24 Hours of Le Mans, in 1976, I wrote my story on a yellow legal pad as I sat in the shade of a small tree on a cinder block patio behind the pit area. I passed the handwritten copy to a Telex operator in a small press office next to the patio, and she typed it for my editors in New York. Then I walked right out onto pit lane for the victory celebration.

title: A Quiet Victory for the Netherlands
description: JOHANNESBURG  Simon Poulsen can almost be excused for falling asleep on the job. Poulsen, a Danish defender, nodded a harmless Robin van Persie cross into his own goal just after halftime of a slow, droll affair Monday between the Netherlands and Denmark at Soccer City.

title: Monday Reading: Getting Paid to Take Medicine
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that hits your wallet.

title: Cysts, Pancreatic Disease and Cancer
description: Can diseases of the pancreas like cysts or pancreatitis progress to cancer? Are melanoma or colon cancer related to pancreatic cancer? Those are among the questions recently posted to the Consults blog. Dr. Eileen OReilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds.

title: Skadden Hires Brussels Lawyer From Clifford Chance
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the giant American law firm, said Monday that it had hired Simon Baxter, a partner at Clifford Chance, for its Brussels office.

title: Final Scenes From Bonnaroo
description: The ninth annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival wrapped up on Sunday in Manchester, Tenn., after four days of performances by more than 100 acts.

title: What Were Reading: Investing in the Companies You Regulate
See You in the Funny Pages: Little Orphan Annie Says Goodbye
description: The lizards have ceased leaping, and the sun isnt coming out tomorrow or even today: on Sunday, after an 86-year run as the pluckiest pupil-free young adventurer in the funny pages, Little Orphan Annie appeared in her last newspaper comic strip.

title: Numberplay: Trapped in the Fourth Dimension?
description: We have not received this weeks dispatch from Pradeep Mutalik, the Numberplay author. As you all know, he was intent on acting on the e-mail he received from the mysterious Dr. I. J. Matrix last week.

title: Resort Report | Jenni Kayne, Smooth Sailing
description: Jenni Kayne knows a thing or two about what to wear on a spectacular cruise during the winter months. Her presentation was held on her familys personal yacht  upon which Kayne has traveled to far-flung places like Corsica and Tahiti. The clothes were simple and easy to mix and match, including Kaynes signature leather shorts and T-shirts. The navy cotton cape will come in handy should it start to drizzle on deck.

title: A Blogger Taps Out; Combatants Want In
description: In a city marked by constant change, some find that its transformations come too quickly, while others complain that the status quo is not upended  and slammed down against the boxing mat  fast enough.

title: A History of Luxury
description: A new tome includes the history of the Goyard family and the object is nothing less than a bible of luxury.

title: Picking the Best Cash-Back Credit Cards
description: In the market for a cash-back rewards card and wondering which one to get? Heres some advice to help you decide.

title: On Our Radar: Whaling Payoffs?
description: Assertions that cash in envelopes was exchanged for pro-whaling votes on the International Whaling Commission.

title: Easy Dishes With Exotic Grains
description: Whenever I go to an ethnic grocery, I wind up buying items that are not on my shopping list. I cant help myself. Sometimes I am intrigued by something Ive never tried before, like the buckwheat flour and cornmeal polenta mixture I bought several months ago at an Italian deli. (I wasnt crazy about the polenta I eventually made with it.) Other times an item will spark memories of a dish Ive eaten in my travels or havent made in a while.

title: Chickpea Flour Crpes With Roasted Pepper, Tomato and Goat Cheese Filling
description: Chickpea flour crpes make great wrappers for all sorts of fillings. This savory combination of tomato sauce with roasted pepper and goat cheese is easy to make with ingredients you can keep on hand in the refrigerator and pantry.

title: Indian Semolina Pilaf
description: I know of some great polenta dishes, but they usually require a lot of butter and cheese. So to find a recipe for a bag of Italian semolina polenta that had been languishing in my pantry, I turned to the cuisines of Southern India. Upma is a favorite breakfast dish in Southern India, although youre more likely to want it for dinner. This version is simplified; I made it with the ingredients I had on hand. Traditional ingredients in upma include curry leaves, cashews, hulled chickpeas (chana dal) and white split gram bean (urad dal). You can add other vegetables of your choice.

title: Democrats Add to List of Campaign Challengers
description: In the midst of what looks to be a difficult election cycle, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is adding 11 candidates to a program that mainly looks to capture Republican-held seats.

title: Agency Sues City Over Foster Care Contract
description: A longtime New York City foster care provider is suing the city and its child welfare agency in an effort to halt the severing of its contracts, which would transfer the cases of about 1,400 foster children to other agencies.

title: New President at National Trust for Historic Preservation
description: Stephanie Meeks, president and chief executive of the development organization Counterpart International, has been named the eighth president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced Monday.

title: Indian Semolina Pilaf With Tomatoes
description: This version of upma, an Indian semolina pilaf, is inspired by a recipe in Julie Sahnis wonderful book, Classic Indian Vegetarian and Grain Cooking.

title: Bulgur and Cherry Pilaf
description: Cherries have arrived in Southern California, so Im inspired to make a Turkish pilaf that I love. It is traditionally made with sour cherries and bulgur or rice, but Ive also added dried cherries or cranberries (two other ingredients I found in my pantry) to the mix. Ground fennel contributes to the sweetness.

title: Last Body Missing  in Ark. Flood Found
description: LANGLEY, Ark.  Crews searching dozens of square miles of riverbank and muddy, rugged vegetation in steamy heat and humidity on Monday found a 20th victim of the deadly flash floods that swept through a cherished family campground area early on Friday.

title: Resort Report | Chris Benz, Dreaming of Pat Nixon
description: Chris Benz has an eBay obsession. Thats where he discovered the midcentury California sculptor Sascha Brastoff  the inspiration for his resort collection. Brastoff made beautiful tabletop pieces in pastel and metallic finishes, a palette befitting the modern day Pat Nixon whom Benz had in mind when designing his tweed jackets, cropped pantsuits and long, slinky dresses.

title: F.B.I. Releases Files on Edward M. Kennedy
description: After two brothers fell to assassins bullets, Senator Edward M. Kennedy received repeated threats that he, too, would meet the same fate, according to thousands of pages of documents released Monday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BP Provides Plan to Speed Up Siphoning
description: Responding to a request by the Obama administration over the weekend that BP collect more oil sooner, the company on Monday announced a plan to siphon off 40,000 barrels to 53,000 barrels of oil a day from its leaking well by the end of June, up from the current 15,000 barrels a day.

title: Readers React to News of Afghan Minerals
description: 1:12 p.m. | Updated The New York Times article reporting that Afghanistan lies atop nearly $1 trillion in untapped minerals has become one of the most commented nytimes.com pieces of the year, with more than 900 published comments and still counting. The discovery, which could make Afghanistan the Saudi Arabia of lithium, according to an internal Pentagon memo, aroused considerable suspicion from Times readers. For most who commented on the article, trust for American motives in the Middle East appears frayed by the Iraq war and mixed results in Afghanistan.

title: Update: Apple Rethinks Its Ulysses Ban
description: Score one for Ulysses  Apple has decided that it is not obscene after all.

title: Some Fans Stranded After Netherlands-Denmark Game
description: JOHANNESBURG  According to radio reports here, hundreds of soccer fans were stranded at Soccer City after Bus Rapid Transit bus drivers started striking. Fans letting out of the Netherlands-Denmark game were being advised to take rail lines to get out of Soccer City. Rush hour is approaching here and traffic will snarl around the city.

title: Do Kids Still Matter to Marriage?
description: One of the more surprising trends in marriage during the past 20 years is the fact that most couples no longer view children as essential to a happy relationship.

title: Spirit Airlines Cancels Flights Through Wednesday
description: Spirit Airlines has announced on its Web site that it is canceling flights through Wednesday in the wake of a strike by its pilots late last week. Spirit is offering stranded travelers credit for the full amount of the unflown portion of the trip and a $100 credit. Though the carrier had pledged last week that service would continue in the event of a strike, Spirit started canceling flights on Saturday, disrupting plans for thousands of travelers, the Associated Press reported. Spirit, according to the A.P., operates 150 flights daily and is Fort Lauderdales sole carrier to 14 international and five domestic destinations. Whether the strike will be resolved soon remains unclear. Spirit and its pilots have been in talks for more than three years. The pilots had been seeking pay raises and the airline said it had offered to raise pay by 29 percent over five years.9:53 a.m. | Updated  An earlier version of this post inaccurately described the amount of compensation that Spirit is offering its stranded passengers.

title: James N. Wood, President of Getty Trust, Dies
description: James N. Wood, who served as director of the Art Institute of Chicago for 25 years and took over as president and chief executive of the Getty Trust in Los Angeles in 2006, helping to steer the institution through a turbulent period in its history, died Friday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles, the trust announced. Mr. Wood was 69. A statement by the trust said that Mr. Wood had died unexpectedly, of natural causes, but that no exact cause of death was announced.

description: British actor Bill Nighy advises readers of The Telegraph to never trust a man in a linen suit. Good thing hes not in charge of the fashion police.

title: William J. Mitchell, Vanguard of Urban Transportation and Planning, Dies at 65
description: William J. Mitchell, a noted theorist and planner on urban and transportation issues, died on June 11 after a long battle with cancer, according to the Massachusetts Institute of Technologys news office. He was 65.

title: Afghan Media Criticize Security Officials Resignations
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The recent resignations of Afghanistans interior minister and intelligence chief have been covered extensively in the Afghan papers.

title: Ailing Levine Withdraws From Tanglewood
description: Health problems have taken yet another toll on the schedule of the conductor James Levine. He has pulled out of all appearances at the Tanglewood Music Festival this summer because he needs more time to recover from the back surgery he underwent in April, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which runs the festival, announced on Monday. Mr. Levine was to have conducted six Boston Symphony Concerts and three by the Tanglewood Music Center orchestra, which is made up of young musicians. Michael Tilson Thomas, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Hans Graf and Johannes Debus, music director of the Canadian Opera Company, will substitute for Mr. Levine, the Boston Symphony said.

title: Patterns: Uninsured More at Risk Even in Hospitals
description: Uninsured Americans often have difficulty getting care and paying for medications. But what happens once they are admitted to a hospital with a life-threatening illness?

title: TimesCast | June 14, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, Obama presses BP for cleanup funds and reports on the crisis in Kyrgyzstan, child soldiers in Somalia and the resurgence of coca in Peru.

title: Song of the Vuvuzela: Can You Stand It?
description: Just five days into the World Cup, and the No. 1 topic of conversation around the world isnt about results or tactics, but rather the vuvuzela  the $2.50 plastic horn that, blown nonstop by the thousands, has provided a bleating soundtrack to every match at South Africa 2010.

title: Europes New Wind Power Rivals Gas
description: The amount of power generated by new wind turbines in the European Union this year will be about the same as the amount from new gas plants, according to the European Wind Energy Association, an industry group.

title: Cirque du Soleils Banana Shpeel Will Split at Months End
description: There will be no more terrible banana-related puns around these quarters, and no more reminders of how a long-running rock n roll tradition was pushed aside to make room for an ultimately ill-fated Cirque du Soleil show. On Monday the circus company from Montreal said Banana Shpeel, its current production at the Beacon Theater, would play its final performance there on June 27.

title: Buffalo Developer Wants to Turn Albany Upside Down
description: ALBANY  Carl Paladino, the 63-year-old Buffalo developer and candidate for governor, has been an outspoken presence on the campaign trail  outspoken being an understatement for a man whose campaign slogan is Im mad as hell.

title: U.S. Keepers Ribs Bruised, Not Broken
description: JOHANNESBURG  Goalkeeper Tim Howard does not have broken ribs and is expected to be available to play Friday against Slovenia in the World Cup, the United States Soccer Federation said Monday.

title: Vindication for the Buying Spree?
description: Private equity has been criticized for its seemingly profligate acquisition history during the boom times, paying huge premiums with billions of dollars in borrowed cash. But the industry may be vindicated as a number of its portfolio companies are getting ready to hit the market and appear likely to produce decent returns for their investors.

title: Dont Bother Following Me on Twitter
description: O.K., heres my deal with Twitter. Personally, I have a hard time doing anything in 140 characters or less. Maybe its a difference of the sexes thing. Research tells us more men than women are on Twitter while the Facebook community (which offers free-flowing prose if you choose) is heavier in estrogen. No surprise there really. Men tend to be bottom-liners and women seem to enjoy talking about their experiences more.

title: For News Corporation, Significant Online Investments
description: Reflecting Rupert Murdochs belief that consumers should pay for more content online, the News Corporation said Monday that it had acquired an e-reading platform called Skiff and had made an investment in a company that manages pay models for newspapers and magazines.

title: Ireland, Ulster and the Flotilla Inquiry
description: As my colleague Isabel Kershner reports, Israels cabinet on Monday unanimously approved a government-appointed commission with foreign participation to investigate the circumstances surrounding its deadly commando raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May.

title: An Apartment Building Where Babies Reign
description: New York City apartment buildings are often a menagerie of types, including old-timers who remember precisely who lived in each apartment 25 years ago, midlifers preoccupied with their families, and residents so new that they still find the clanging radiators and groaning midcentury elevators charming.

title: Alas, Afghanistan
description: While Marc Ambinder and Blake Hounshell, among others, wonder if the weekends big news about Afghanistans enormous lithium deposits is really all that new, I wonder how long it will take some inventive Afghani politician to come up with a lithium-appropriate equivalent to the devils excrement, which is how a farsighted Venezuelan oil minister described his countrys enormous  and eventually enormously destructive  petroleum resources 30 years ago. Its possible, I suppose, that lithium could be a game changer that redounds to the benefit of Afghanis and their American occupiers alike, but the history of these kind of things suggests otherwise, and strongly. Its very hard to imagine that a country as misgoverned as Afghanistan will be an exception to the rule that whom the gods destroy, they first make rich in natural resources.

title: Bonnaroo: Stevie Wonder and Jay-Z
description: Stevie Wonder came to Bonnaroo prepared, though its impossible to say if it was by disposition or research. Jam-band fans? His second song was Master Blaster, about jammin until the break of dawn(something the Disco Biscuits were scheduled to do until 5:15 a.m. on Sunday).

description: What do you get when you cross Green Acres with Queer Eye for the Straight Guy, then subtract Eddie Albert, Eva Gabor and most of the straight guys? A campaign for a new weekly television series seeks to provide a humorous answer to that quirky question.

description: ZHONGSHAN, China  Workers who returned to their jobs on Sunday and Monday at a Honda auto parts factory here in southern China were threatening to go back on strike this week if the company did not improve its offer of a wage increase.

title: World Cups Incessant Drone Will Stay for Now
description: JOHANNESBURG  The loud trumpets called vuvuzelas will continue to be allowed for the time being at the World Cup, despite complaints from some international broadcasters, players and fans, the tournaments organizing committee said Monday.

title: Fair Warning | Design Miami/Basel: The Blog
description: This is the week the design world heads to Basel, Switzerland for Design Miami/Basel which opens to the public on Tuesday, a day ahead of Art Basel. But if you cant go to the design fair, the design fair will come to you: This year marks the debut of its blog, the aptly-titled Design Miami/Basel Blog (http://designmiamibaselblog.com/). It will afford journalists and design fans access to breaking news, quotes, images, and updates from participants in the fair like designers and gallery owners, as well as the option to sign up for an RSS feed that sends alerts in real time  in case you cant wait until your first cup of morning coffee in New York to find out which celebrities bought what before dashing off to lunch at Chez Donati.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Lars Bastholm, chief digital creative officer at Ogilvy & Mather North America, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide division of WPP, is taking the added post of chief creative officer for the Ogilvy New York headquarters. The post had been filled on an interim basis by Steve Hayden, vice chairman at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. Also, Dan Burrier, chief creative officer at Ogilvy & Mather West, Los Angeles, becomes chief innovation officer for Ogilvy North America, a new post, and Lauren Crampsie, director for business development at Ogilvy North America, becomes chief marketing officer there, also a new post.

description: If you can remember MTV 1.0 personalities like Mark Goodman, Martha Quinn, Nina Blackwood and J. J. Jackson, you may already be too old to contend for a new hybrid on-air and online position that the cable network is creating.

description: WASHINGTON  Ronald Kempfert was a young boy in 1975 when his father was sent to prison for murder, and they had no contact for 28 years.

title: Italy Salvages a Draw Against Paraguay in the Group F Opener
description: Italy and Paraguay scrapped to a 1-1 draw Monday night in a match subdued as much by the near-constant downpour in Cape Town as the knowledge that the next two games, for both squads, will be considerably easier than this one. Group F is the World Cups weakest division, and both teams will now try to gather the points necessary to advance from this stage in their upcoming matches against Slovakia and New Zealand.

title: Tom Watson, Ever Young at 60, Prepares for Pebble Beach
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  How can Tom Watson be 60? He still looks much the way he did in 1982, boyishly romping around the 17th green at Pebble Beach, the cliffside par 3, after holing what is commonly regarded as one of the greatest shots in golf history: a 16-foot pitch from the left rough that landed softly and darted into the cup, securing his first and only United States Open championship and closing out his rival Jack Nicklaus.

title: Fashion Report | Guinness Buys Blow Collection
description: Daphne Guinness, the art and fashion collector, has bought the entire Isabella Blow wardrobe, including seminal pieces by the late designer Alexander McQueen, which was to have been sold by Christies in the fall.

description: Some prominent names turn up in Ensemble Studio Theaters Series B group of one-acts, part of the companys annual marathon of short plays, but it is a couple of lesser names that deserve the most attention: Rachel Bonds, whose lovely Anniversary concludes the program, and Julie Fitzpatrick, the actress who brings that play to life.

title: Despite Flirtations, Texas Agrees to Stay in Big 12 and Save It

title: For BP, Toll Likely to Extend Past Cleanup
description: On the face of it, BP can easily afford to pay the short-term costs of the oil well that is leaking millions of gallons into the Gulf of Mexico. Last year, the company earned $17 billion, and it ended the year with more than $8 billion in cash.

description: Thousands of Uzbeks were reported to be flooding into Uzbekistan and thousands more  were massed at the border as they fled violence in the southern Kyrgyz cities of Osh and Jalalabad.

title: Afghan Officials Elated by Minerals Report
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Government officials sounded headily optimistic Monday as they fielded questions from local and international reporters about a new report on the extent of Afghanistans mineral wealth that suggests considerable potential for products other than opium, which until now has been the countrys most lucrative export.

title: Therapies for Cancer Bring Hope and Failure
description: CHICAGO  The experimental drug PLX4032, which reverses the effects of a mutation found in certain tumors, is considered a prime example of the targeted cancer therapies of the future. The drug  the subject of a three-part series in The New York Times in February  produced seemingly miraculous results in some patients with melanoma.

title: A Church Rite Shrouded in Haitis Loss
description: When they filled the church a few days after the earthquake, they were still in shock, swathed in coats and hats, faces illuminated by orange candlelight in the darkness. Now, five months later, the women were in flowered dresses, little girls wearing white first-communion frocks and flowers in their hair, and the sanctuary white-bright from the summery glare.

title: Aiming at Rivals, Starbucks Will Offer Free Wi-Fi
description: Many coffee shops try to discourage people from buying a cup of coffee and then lingering for hours to use the free Internet access. Starbucks will soon encourage them to stay as long as they want.

title: Artifacts | Broadcast Blues
description: Like many other people in the New York art world, I watched the Wednesday night premiere of Bravos Work of Art: The Next Great Artist with zero expectations of either art or greatness. I didnt think the artificial conditions of a gladiatorial competition between untried talents could create a realistic or even a very entertaining picture of what it means to make art. In fact, I slept through some of it. If the contestants had been seasoned professionals and we got to watch them work under pressure, it might have been a juicier proposition  a clash of titans, or something like Iron Chef.

title: Pipe Organ Returns to Alice Tully Hall
description: Skepticism stirred when Lincoln Center spirited the pipe organ out of Alice Tully Hall before the buildings renovation in 2006, promising its eventual return. The skepticism only grew when the renovated hall reopened in early 2009 with no sign of the organ.

title: Israeli Policeman Killed in West Bank Shooting
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli police officer was shot dead in the West Bank on Monday and two more were wounded in the first fatal shooting attack on Israeli security personnel in the area in more than a year.

title: A Near-Zero Fed Funds Rate Until 2012?
description: Observers of the Federal Reserve have been speculating for months about when the central bank might start lifting the benchmark short-term interest rate from near-zero, where it has been since December 2008.

title: Cause of Mystery Ills Splits Indonesian Fishing Village
description: BUYAT BAY BEACH, Indonesia - This is a simple village where the fishermen's families live on the sea in wooden shacks lighted by oil lamps and most everyone knows one another. But the people are divided by more than just the sandy track that passes for Main Street.

title: Tangled Strands in Fight Over Peru Gold Mine
description: SAN CERILLO, Peru - The Rev. Marco Arana drove his beige pickup over the curves of a dirt road 13,000 feet high in the Andes. Spread out below lay the Yanacocha gold mine, an American-run operation of mammoth open pits and towering heaps of cyanide-laced ore. Ahead loomed the pristine green of untouched hills.

Here are three recent ones, starting with a popular subject: health insurance exchanges, the online marketplaces, to be available starting in 2014, where individuals and small businesses will be able to compare plans and buy coverage.

title: Two Brothers Keep Connected as Volunteers at the U.S. Open
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The two men walking down the lonely road in the early-morning fog Monday looked as if they were either really lost or needed a ride. But it was clear moments after Carmen Battista and his brother Paul hopped in the backseat of a reporters car that they knew just where they were going.

description: In todays Science Times, the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody writes about the challenges of juggling yard work, finances and home repairs after the death of her husband Richard in March. She writes:

title: Getting on With Life After a Partner Dies
description: Mickey Martinez was the kind of husband many women dream about. He loved grocery shopping and did it weekly at a nearby supermarket, took care of household repairs, washed dishes, and was always ready with a broom or vacuum when needed.

title: Natural Winemaking Stirs Debate
description: THE world of wine is full of hornets nests. The minute you step on one, whether you nudge it accidentally or boot it with malice aforethought, the angry buzzing begins, rising to a high-pitched howl that would send anybody in search of shelter and a beer.

title: Ranting About Shopping Before Its Time
description: Hearing Jingle Bells piped through a retail stores speakers at Halloween just doesnt sound right. But to some, its even more frustrating to search for a plastic beach pail at a Wal-Mart in July  prime beach season  only to find that only a few are left, and all of the summer item shelves have been cleared to make way for back-to-school pens and pencils for September.

title: The Rich on Trial at a Private School
description: Seymour Herson is a sorry prospect. He lacks athletic, academic, social and grooming skills, relegating him to the third table in the cafeteria of a second-rate private school, where, solo, he strives to drink as many chocolate milks as possible. Seymour seems at peace with his station, even the regular beatings, his only worry being that one of the popular eighth graders has called him Chunk-Style, a sobriquet that, if repeated a couple more times, may stick.

This was after two million fans turned out for the Stanley Cup parade, and it demonstrates that those who dismiss hockeys impact in the United States can be out of step.

description: Councilman Charles Barron provided detailsMonday of his plans to begin a protest bid for governor, and blasted Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and the Democratic Party for putting together an all-white statewide ticket.

title: On Natural Wines
description: My column is about the seemingly emotional, threatening issue of natural wines. I use the term natural wines throughout the column, but its a measure of how nebulous the issue is to say that many people disagree on the use of that phrase. Some prefer other terms, like real wine, or natural winemaking.

title: Departing President of United Autoworkers Tells Union to Fight On
description: DETROIT  Ron Gettelfinger, whose tumultuous eight-year tenure as president of the United Automobile Workers union ends this week, encouraged workers on Monday to keep fighting the antiunion forces that want to kill off the U.A.W.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
description: Our show opens amid the grim violence of Kyrgyzstan in central Asia. Several days of chaos have started reshaping the ethnic landscape there, with more than 70,000 ethnic Uzbeks reported to be flooding into Uzbekistan and thousands more at the border (Slides 1, 2 and 3). For something considerably lighter, check out the waterfront image from Mumbai (Slide 10) or the picture of a soccer fan playing his vuvuzela at a World Cup game (Slide 11).

title: The Cavalacanga Ate My Cellphone
description: At around 2 p.m. on Thursday, I arrived in Atins via slow boat from Barreirinhas. But my destination was still about 90 minutes away: the home and restaurant of Luzia Diniz Santos and family in Canto de Atins, a little settlement of 30-odd people on a strip of sandy prairie between the ocean and the dunes of Lenis Maranhenses National Park in northeastern Brazil. Luzias grilled shrimp is famous, at least locally, and her place receives a steady stream of lunchtime guests. Her four simple guest rooms (for 20 reais,about $11, a night) are far less known. I found out only from a fellow boat passenger heading home to Atins, and changed my lodging plans accordingly.

title: Despite Killing, Mexican Backs Drug Policy
description: MEXICO CITY  Faced with a surge in drug-related killings in recent days, President Felipe Caldern on Monday offered a spirited defense of his governments antidrug offensive.

The legislation, already approved by the House, is a little vague beyond directing researchers and heads of academic departments to participate in activities that increase the awareness of the existence of gender bias.

You also most likely know that there is one important component missing from the game: the feeling of a real tennis racket.

title: Bathed in the Limelight, but Quietly Taking Leave
description: After the bouquets and flowers from his colleagues, the laughter and hugging and joking, Philip Neal stood alone on the stage, his final performance as a principal dancer with New York City Ballet over. His bearing was that of the danseur noble  upright, shoulders back, head high, one hand placed flat against his heart. As those in the audience rose to their feet, Mr. Neal slowly opened out his arms, his face grave, acknowledging the wave of love and appreciation that flowed over him as tangibly as the confetti that rained from above and the flowers that flew onto the stage.

title: Brooklyn Museums Populism Hasnt Lured Crowds

It had stopped worrying about competing with Manhattan museums or about its image  despite its world-class collections  as a poor mans Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Just How British Is BP?
description: In a story in The Times on Sunday, our colleague Sheryl Gay Stolberg wrote of growing displeasure in Britain over the use of the name British Petroleum by top federal officials in the United States in referring to the party responsible for the gulf spill. The company officially changed its name to BP several years ago, and to some on the other side of the pond, invoking the old name is a backhanded slap at Britain and even a threat to the special relationship our two nations share.

title: Early-Season African Wave Getting Better Organized
description: Back on June 9, an African easterly wave exited the western coast of Africa and has gradually gotten better organized as it trekked westward. Its presently located near 10N 41W, or about 1400 miles east of the Windward Islands. Its moving WNW at 12-13kts and that motion is expected to continue for the next several days. There is a 1010mb surface Low associated with the disturbance.

title: In the Hunt for Planets, Who Owns the Data?
description: We are about to find out just how generous nature really is.

title: Dry Rub and Wet Sidewalks
description: Last weekend, the eighth annual Big Apple Barbecue Block Party was held in and around Madison Square Park. Rain that fell for at least half of Sunday did not tame the flames. This years event included food from 18 of the countrys best pit masters, 5 of them from New York City. Barbecue lovers were able to get their hands dirty with food from as far away as Las Vegas and Driftwood, Tex.

title: Kyrgyz Tensions Rooted in Class, Not Ethnicity, Experts Say
description: MOSCOW  The violence that has claimed scores of lives in Kyrgyzstan is frequently ascribed to ethnic tensions, but regional experts say the causes are more complex.

title: Glimmerglass Changes Name and Broadens Agenda
description: Francesca Zambello, the new general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., has put an immediate stamp on the institution, changing its name to the Glimmerglass Festival and adding a regular piece of musical theater to the agenda. Starting next summer future festivals will also include lectures, symposiums, cabarets and concerts for the public. Such activities have already been offered on a limited scale to donors, a spokeswoman said. Ms. Zambello takes over on Sept. 1. Her first season, the summer of 2011, will include new productions of Bizets Carmen and Cherubinis Medea. The festival will also present a double bill of new works: A Blizzard in Marblehead Neck, by the composer Jeanine Tesori and the playwright Tony Kushner and commissioned by Glimmerglass, and Later the Same Evening, by John Musto and Mark Campbell, based on five Edward Hopper paintings. The musical will be Irving Berlins Annie Get Your Gun. While Glimmerglass put on Kiss Me, Kate in 2008, musicals will now become a regular feature, to be performed with a full orchestra and without amplification.

title: Little Orphan Annie Says Goodbye For Now
description: The lizards have ceased leaping. On Sunday, after an 86-year run as the pluckiest pupil-free young adventurer in the funny pages, Little Orphan Annie (above with her dog, Sandy) appeared in her last newspaper comic strip. In May, Tribune Media Services announced that it was ending the syndication of Annie, the comic strip chronicling that red-headed ragamuffin created by the cartoonist Harold Gray in 1924. But fans hoping for some narrative closure may have had better luck with the Lost finale. The last Annie comic concluded with its title character missing in Guatemala, and, according to a caption, Daddy Warbucks resigning himself to Miss Annies being lost forever. A final panel bore the legend, And this is where we leave our Annie. For now   But Steve Tippie, vice president of marketing and licensing at Tribune Media Services, said, Annie is not dying, shes moving into new channels, according to an interview with BBC News (which also looks at one of Annies earliest comic adventures). He said the character would continue to appear in graphic novels, games and in online and mobile projects.

title: A Movable Feast of a Festival
description: The best way to fight a pervasive assumption is to pretend it doesnt exist. The organizers of the first Undead Jazzfest, which ran Saturday and Sunday night at three clubs in the center of the West Village  Le Poisson Rouge, Sullivan Hall, and Kennys Castaways  are not necessarily hostile to the idea that jazz audiences like to sit and stay in one place and enjoy a set from beginning to end in silence and then go home. Theyre just not interested in it.

title: Preservation Trust Has a New President
description: Stephanie Meeks, president and chief executive of the development organization Counterpart International, has been named president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced Monday. Ms. Meeks, 45, who also spent 18 years at the Nature Conservancy, will succeed Richard Moe, who retired this month after 17 years. Ms. Meeks, who has been a member of the trust for many years, plans to begin in her new position in July. At the Nature Conservancy she held a number of positions including chief operating officer and, for nearly a year, acting president and chief executive. The trust, a nonprofit that supports the preservation of historic buildings and neighborhoods, issues an annual list of Americas 11 most endangered historic places.

title: Awaiting the Genome Payoff
description: NORTH WALES, Pa.  At Mercks automated biotechnology facility here, robot arms adapted from automobile factories deftly shuttle plates containing human cells.

title: Levine Withdraws From Tanglewood
description: Health problems have taken yet another toll on the schedule of the conductor James Levine, right. He has pulled out of all appearances at the Tanglewood Music Festival this summer because he needs more time to recover from the back surgery he underwent in April, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which runs the festival, said on Monday. Mr. Levine was to have conducted six Boston Symphony Concerts and three by the Tanglewood Music Center orchestra, which is made up of young musicians. Michael Tilson Thomas, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Hans Graf and Johannes Debus, music director of the Canadian Opera Company, will replace Mr. Levine, the Boston Symphony said. Mr. Levine has canceled many performances at the orchestra and at the Metropolitan Opera, where he is also music director, in recent years because of various ailments. They include a torn rotator cuff from a fall onstage in 2006, kidney surgery in 2008, surgery for a herniated disk last year and, most recently, lower-back surgery.

title: Killer Art
description: Examples of viruses and bacteria rendered in blown glass from Luke Jerrams Infectious Beauty exhibition.

title: Cirque Du Soleils Banana Shpeel to Close
description: There will be no more terrible banana-related puns around these quarters, and no more reminders of how a long-running rock n roll tradition was pushed aside to make room for an ultimately ill-fated Cirque du Soleil show. On Monday the circus company from Montreal said Banana Shpeel, its current production at the Beacon Theater, would play its final performance there on June 27. The show, a mix of broad vaudeville comedy, dance and acrobatics, was presented in Chicago last year, where it was flogged by critics. A Beacon Theater transfer was originally planned to start performances on Feb. 4 and run through June at least, bringing an end to the 20-year Beacon residency of the Allman Brothers Band. But the first preview date for Banana Shpeel was pushed back several times, to Feb. 25, then to March 17 and finally to April 29. It had its official opening on May 19. In a news release its producers said the show would begin a tour of North America in the fall.

title: Are Killer Viruses, Rendered in Glass, Also Things of Beauty?
description: In a gallery in Manhattans meatpacking district, balanced delicately on mirrored surfaces and quivering slightly with each passing truck, is a lineup of historys greatest killers: smallpox, influenza, H.I.V.

title: Bombing in Kenya Recalls 2008 Election Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The hospital floors on Monday morning were littered with bloody bandages. Young men writhed in bed, their hands in mittens of gauze, their faces studies in pain. Scrums of Kenyan politicians cruised the corridors, flanked by the victims relatives, who spoke darkly of a political conspiracy.

Midway through, the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival has addressed the 100th anniversary of the Mexican Revolution, shamanism in Korea, the Indian goddess Parvathi, an initiation ceremony in the voodoo tradition, a bridal preparation in the Northern Philippines, and the Hawaiian deity Hiiakas preparation for battles with dragons and demons. Roberts declaration (at his own hearing) that judges are like umpires; umpires dont make the rules, they apply them. Kagan will probably be asked to pledge allegiance to this account of judging and repudiate its disreputable alternative  judges who make law, legislate from the bench and import their politics into precincts where they dont belong.

title: A Good Day for Judicial Discretion
description: Equity is an elusive legal concept that occasionally allows some leeway in applying the rules of the law and is often unappreciated by judges who insist the law means only what it says. That was clear in 2008 when the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit refused to allow federal courts to consider a death-penalty conviction of Albert Holland because his lawyer had inexcusably let the filing deadline pass. Fortunately, seven members of the Supreme Court proved less rigid in their thinking on Monday and reversed that blinkered decision.

title: The Dictator and the Unesco Prize

title: In Pictures | The Great American Road Trip

So she bought a cargo van retrofitted with a bed and took to the road for a two-month solo road trip, photographing her way up the coast of California, to Oregon and the Olympic Peninsula of Washington, then through Idaho, Montana, Utah and Nevada. I didnt have a definite plan and I didnt want one, OKeeffe says. I love maps and navigation, but I wanted this trip to have a different sort of pattern  one that came from directions scribbled on the back of napkins, questionable decisions and wrong turns. Besides her camera, her other constant companion was a copy of Steinbecks Travels With Charley, which helped OKeeffe put her experiences of everyday American life in a larger context: a young woman in 2009 comparing her observations with those of a man at the end of his life in 1960. He was witnessing a new era of modernity in full swing, and I was looking at a lot of the broken pieces. OKeeffe made a selection of her images from the trip available to T; the full portfolio is on her Web site.

description: The new Food Lovers Guide to Brooklyn by Sherri Eisenberg (Globe Pequot Press, $14.95) is reasonably up-to-date for a borough where new food places open their doors by the minute.

title: When in Doubt, Insure
description: ITS only June, and already what a year its been for travelers: volcanic ash clouds shutting down dozens of European airports; unrest in Thailand, Jamaica and Greece; an oil spill undermining the plans of vacationers bound for the Gulf of Mexico coast. The summer  with its risk of hurricanes and the threat of airline strikes  promises little respite.

title: Removing Mysterious Sell-By Date From Milk Cartons
description: For decades, containers of milk sold in New York City have been stamped with two expiration dates: one carrying the dairy industrys recommended sell by date and an earlier one  sometimes nearly a week earlier  mandated by the city.

title: A Credit Union Pushing Overdraft
description: It is not just banks that are putting pressure on customers to sign up for overdraft protection.

title: June 28, 1969: Turning Point in Gay Rights History
description: The average homosexual, if there be such, is promiscuous. He is not interested in, nor capable of, a lasting relationship like that of a heterosexual marriage.

title: A Charger You Cant Lose
description: The other day I opened up a storage box I had placed on a basement shelf about six months ago. It was full of AC adapters. About 20 of them. I could identify four.

title: Law School Deans Back Kagan Nomination
description: Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court has received the backing of dozens of law school deans from across the country.

title: A Gotham Bloomsday
description: Bloomsday, or June 16, is the day on which fans of James Joyces Ulysses gather to hear the novel read aloud in a long list of European and American cities.

title: Somali Insurgents Detain Soccer Fans
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  As South Africa proudly held the continents first World Cup, a Somali insurgent group, Hizbul Islam, detained dozens of fans for watching the tournament in recent days south of Somalias capital, residents said.

title: Watchdog Group Files Complaints Over South Carolina Primary
description: The unemployed South Carolina man whose surprise victory in last weeks Democratic primary race for a Senate seat has drawn intense scrutiny now faces another obstacle. A watchdog group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, on Tuesday filed formal complaints with federal and state election officials (pdf) asserting that he and three other candidates violated election law.

title: Resort Report | Lanvin
description: At his recent resort presentation, Alber Elbaz explained that his collection was all about finding solutions. Most of these solutions were of the two-in-one variety. He interpreted fashions current minimal mood in what he called a Lanvin way: sleeveless black T-shirt dresses, when turned inside out, transformed into feminine tulle confections. These were very charming (albeit a bit scratchy) when worn in the minimal way. The swimwear was divine; when each suit was paired with its appropriate cover-up, the combo took the shape of a cocktail dress or beach-appropriate gown.

title: Disturbance Struggling in Poor Environment
description: A combination of marginal vertical shear and decreased low-mid-level relative humidity seems to have taken a toll on the developing vortex. Deep convection associated with the disturbance has diminished, and its now an exposed swirl of clouds centered near 13N 46W and tracking WNW at 13kts. It is not expected to regenerate. See http://einstein.atmos.colostate.edu/~mcnoldy/tropics/atcf/latestATL.png for the current location and prior track.

title: The New Shaved Ice
description: The Day-Glo aesthetic and fake flavors of snow cones have been replaced the true colors of summer fruit.

title: Mickelson Feels at Home at Pebble Beach
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Phil Mickelson turns 40 years old Wednesday. How will he celebrate?

title: Taking Orders From the Hive
description: For some reason, in the relatively short history of the Internet, people regularly return to the idea of submitting themselves to every whim and gaze of the collective mind. A non-exhaustive list would include local examples like We Live in Public and a random college graduate who, unemployed, decided to do whatever the Internet told him to do last year.

title: Lawrence ODonnell Gets His Own MSNBC Show
description: The longtime MSNBC commentator Lawrence ODonnell is getting promoted to anchor.

title: Bank of America Said to Rein In Oil Trades With BP
description: The bad news just keeps coming for BP  this time from Bank of America. A high-level executive at the bank has ordered its traders not to enter into oil trades with BP that extend beyond a year from now, Reuters reports, citing an unidentified market source familiar with the order.

Dining Calendar

title: Hecho en Dumbo
description: HUITLACOCHE, a corn fungus thats a delicacy in Mexican cuisine, doesnt always fulfill its funky potential. Too often its bland and mushy, a bit of name-dropping on the menu that doesnt do much on the plate.

title: Caf con Leche Syrup
description: Adapted from Daniel Holzman, The Meatball Shop, Manhattan

title: A New Tool to Start Those Coals
description: If Dad wields a spatula at a grill fueled by charcoal, heres a gift for him. It looks like a giant curling iron, but plug it in, hold it at the bottom of a nice pyramid of chunks or briquettes in the grill, and within a minute, thanks to a heating element and a blower, you have fire enough to get the coals going. You can apply it to a couple of more spots to speed things up. Within about 20 minutes your coals will be glowing and hot enough for cooking. It heats up only when the button is depressed and cools down instantly. It is clean and has a long cord, and when outdoor grilling season is over, it can be used in a fireplace.

title: Bucket Grills for Portable Cooking
description: Grilling at the beach or on a picnic will be easier with the new little bucket grills that are showing up this season. This one, fire-engine red like an official sand bucket, has a 10.2-inch grate and a liner that holds the charcoal and lets the ash drop to the bottom of the pail. Fill it with coals, perhaps with some newspaper underneath to speed up ignition, before heading out, so its ready to get to work on the hot dogs or burgers.

title: Hummus Catches On in America (as Long as Its Flavored)
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: A New Chocolate Cake in New York
description: To New Yorkers, chocolate cake might mean crumb-dusted blackout, not layers of chocolate meringue and chocolate mousse with a thin glaze of ganache. But that is the signature dessert at the Best Chocolate Cake in the World. A restaurateur in Lisbon, Carlos Lopes, with his Manhattan partner, Adriano Lucas, created a version of a dacquoise he saw at Fauchon in Paris. Now Mr. Lopess shops sell his creamy confection in Portugal, Spain and Brazil, with a factory turning out 150,000 a year just in Portugal.

title: Putting the Fresh in Refreshment
description: FIVE THOUSAND pounds of ice: as heavy as a young elephant, or five wading pools filled to the brim. Dylan Williams, the owner of Beaucoup Nola Juice in New Orleans, hauled it all in a refrigerated truck from New Orleans to Manchester, Tenn., last week, to supply his snow cone stand at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival.

title: In Albuquerque, French-Style Wines That Sparkle
description: ALBUQUERQUE

title: Design Your Own Shaved Ice
description: The Dining section of The Times has an article this week on shaved ice. Diners Journal is asking readers to post their ideas for a new shaved-ice recipe. Fany Gerson, a pastry chef in New York and the author of the forthcoming My Sweet Mexico: Recipes for Authentic Pastries, Breads, Candies, Beverages, and Frozen Treats (to be published by Ten Speed Press in September) will pick a suggestion from the comments and create a recipe for it. Write your ideas in the comments below. Be creative and have fun.

title: Takashi
description: A LOBE of sea urchin sits on a small tile of raw, red, marbled steak placed on top of a single shiso leaf, the shape of the ace of clubs, and a rectangle of nori slightly larger than the meat. The package is meant to be folded onto itself, then touched to a low bowl of soy sauce and eaten in perhaps two bites: a raw surf-and-turf canap, elegant and spare.

title: N. Korea Warns of Response to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  North Koreas ambassador to the United Nations said Tuesday that his countrys military would respond forcefully to any Security Council condemnation over the sinking of a South Korean warship, warning that our people and army will smash our aggressors.

title: Animal Husbandry, SoHo Style
description: The premise of The Fabulous Beekman Boys  a couple, uptight Brent and laid-back Josh, give up the Manhattan media world to become gentlemen organic farmers in upstate New York  inspires hopes of a gay Green Acres. The chores! The culture wars!

title: Dodging Bill Collectors, Plotting for a Crown
description: When the doorbell rings, nobody answers it. The same goes for the telephone. It could be a collection agent from Sears or the modeling school or the bank.

title: Stay. Eat. Make Yourself at Home. Maybe Find a Man.
description: In an episode from the first season of 30 Rock, Tina Feys schlumpy character, Liz Lemon, is delighted to discover that in Cleveland, she passes for a model. Youre so skinny, a complete stranger tells her. You really should eat something.

title: A Reconsideration for Online Ulysses
description: Score one for Ulysses: Apple has decided that it is not obscene after all. After the makers of a Web comic version of the epic James Joyce novel said last week that Apple had rejected several images containing nudity, Apple reversed its decision on Monday and asked that the panels be resubmitted, said Chad Rutkowski, the business manager for Throwaway Horse, the publisher of the comic Ulysses Seen. They basically apologized, Mr. Rutkowski said. They said they gave it a second look and realized that it wasnt obscene or anything like that. Theyre clearly drawing a distinction now and they understand what were doing. The initial installments of Ulysses Seen are available in the App Store and on the Web site ulyssesseen.com.

title: Curses, Fairies and Fantasies for This Beauty
description: The Sleeping Beauty is the grandest of all of the 19th-century classical ballets, the most complex in detail, the most fairy-tale-like of the fairy tales we believe, sometimes, onstage. Its vision of social order is also that of the world in which ballet originated. And the collaboration between its choreographer, Marius Petipa, and its composer, Tchaikovsky, is the idealized prototype for the relationship between great music and great dance.

title: Obama Party-Crasher Makes Housewives Cut
description: To the cynics who said theres no way that Bravo would cut the White House party-crashers out of The Real Housewives of D.C.: You were right.

title: Romance Grounded With a Bit of Gravity
description: The jazz singer and pianist Patti Wicks is all about rhythmic deconstruction. Like the much-missed Carmen McRae, Ms. Wicks, who appeared at the Metropolitan Room on Monday evening with the bassist Linc Milliman, scrutinizes songs with a raised eyebrow. Words and phrases are dismantled with a wry deliberation and an improvisatory boldness that put a question mark at the end of songs, especially when the lyrics are sentimental. Her attitude suggests a certain disbelief: Oh, really? she seems to imply.

title: Expanding N.Y.U. Sets Sights on Ground Zero
description: New York University has already proposed to expand from its Greenwich Village home into Brooklyn, Manhattans East Side and Governors Island. Now it has another idea: ground zero.

title: Visit Florida Ad
description: Florida's tourism office is running television spots to protect the state's tourism industry from the oil spill.

title: In Israel, From Storage Unit to Loft
description: JAFFO, ISRAEL  As a refugee from the former Yugoslavia, Nesh Bruic knew how to build homes. He arrived here in this Bible-era port town, now a part of Tel Aviv, in the 1990s, descended from a long line of builders. We always constructed our own homes back in Croatia, said Mr. Bruic, 41, who has designed restaurants and bars both in Tel Aviv and Belgrade. So when I first saw the place, he said, referring to his 700-square-foot studio that he restored, it felt like a pearl I had to rescue from destruction.

title: Bachelorette Lifts ABC
description: The Bachelorette, with Ali Fedotowsky, above, lifted ABC in the ratings on Monday night, with 8.3 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. ABC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for first place, even though CBS broadcast a lineup of repeats. Sitcom reruns on CBS averaged 7.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 while the networks repeat of CSI: Miami led the 10 p.m. hour with 7.6 million viewers, outperforming ABCs True Beauty (5.4 million) and NBCs Persons Unknown (3.4 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with back-to-back episodes of Last Comic Standing, a rerun at 8 (3.5 million) and a new installment at 9 (4.8 million). Fox placed third, with 6.5 million for Lie to Me at 8 but only 4.4 million for The Good Guys at 9. On Sunday, HBOs third-season premiere of True Blood attracted an audience of 5.1 million viewers, up from the 3.7 million who tuned in to the season opener a year ago.

title: When Titans Clash: Comic-book Edition
description: Comic-book creators are generally better known for imagining and illustrating the larger-than-life conflicts of fearsome opponents, not for engaging in them themselves. So it was somewhat unusual to find Neil Gaiman, the best-selling writer, in a Wisconsin court on Monday, where he is suing his onetime colleague Todd McFarlane over royalties that Mr. Gaiman says he is owed from Mr. McFarlanes Spawn comics series. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Gaiman and Mr. McFarlane testified in United States District Court in Madison. Mr. Gaiman said that a character called Dark Ages Spawn was essentially a copy of Medieval Spawn, which he had created for Spawn issue No. 9 in 1993, and that angel characters called Domina and Tiffany were copies of Angela, who also first appeared in that issue. A jury found in 2002 that Mr. Gaiman was a co-copyright holder for the Medieval Spawn and Angela characters, as well as a third named Cogliostro, and was owed royalties. They have yet to come to an agreement on payment.

title: Road Kill in the Serengeti?
description: Imagine. You are lying in the grass in the east African savannah, watching wildebeest fording a shallow river. You can hear the funny grunting noises they make, and as they pass by, you can feel the impact of their hooves on the ground and smell their rich animal smell. You see their kicking heels, their beautiful sleek bodies. Then you look up, and you realize that the herd stretches as far as you can see, that the plain is dark with wildebeest. If you were to wait for them all to pass, you would be there for days.

title: World Cup Replay: Day 5, June 15
description: A view of the tournament as Brazil beat North Korea and the other teams tied  with bright, sunny skies at some matches and winter coats at others.

title: Helen Hunt to Play our Town Stage Manager
description: A great many secrets are revealed about the characters in Thornton Wilders Our Town with one exception, the Stage Manager, who narrates the three-act play without saying much of anything about himself. Or herself, in the case of the acclaimed Off Broadway production at the Barrow Street Theater. The Academy Award-winning actress Helen Hunt (As Good as It Gets), left, will join the cast as the Stage Manager for a limited run, July 6-Aug. 1, the producers said on Tuesday. She will succeed Michael McKean, becoming the sixth actor to assume the role in this long-running production, directed by David Cromer, who played the Stage Manager in the first several months of the run of the play, which opened in February 2009. Ms. Hunt is no stranger to Our Town, having played the role of the young Emily Webb in the 1988-89 Lincoln Center Theater production. Ms. Hunts last major stage production in New York was Yasmina Rezas play Life x 3 at Circle in the Square on Broadway in 2003.

title: Successfully Surrendering It All to Crack
description: There are two kinds of crack addicts, those who cook their own  a complicated business that involves cocaine, baking soda, water and a flame  and those who grab the stuff to go, in ready-made chunks called rocks. Most people go for the rocks. Even when it comes to killing yourself, slowly and gruesomely, who has time to cook anymore?

title: Star Ballerina Attacked Near Lincoln Center
description: Two muggers attacked Natalia Osipova, right, a major international ballet star, as she left an American Ballet Theater performance early Tuesday morning, striking her in the nose and stealing her bag, her agent said. Ms. Osipova had attended a performance of Ballet Theaters Sleeping Beauty, in which she is scheduled to dance on Saturday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House and was crossing Amsterdam Avenue on her way home when she was mugged, said the agent, Sergei Danilian. Two guys just came from her back and they hit her and they took her bag, he said. She was so brave and so smart  she didnt scream, he said of the 5-foot-4 ballerina. Ms. Osipova had left her money at home and her computer at the Met, but the muggers got away with her point shoes and a small hammer used to shape them. The Met doctor was to examine her on Tuesday, Mr. Danilian said, and would determine whether she could dance full-out during an afternoon rehearsal or would just walk through it. She will absolutely, no doubt, perform on Saturday, he said. The police also interviewed her at the Met, he said. Ms. Osipova, who is Russian, is a star of the Bolshoi Ballet and in her second season as a guest artist with Ballet Theater.

title: When Titans Clash: Poets Edition
description: The carnival that is the election for Oxford Universitys professor of poetry post added another ring this week when one of the 10 remaining candidates, the Beat poet Michael Horovitz, criticized another, the biographer Roger Lewis. The Guardian reported that the dispute was touched off by an essay in The Telegraph written by Mr. Lewis. The essay, titled Now heres what I call poetry, listed details like the color of Elizabeth Taylors eyes, the tilt of Garbos face in profile and the bend of Chaplins cane. In a letter to The Telegraph, Mr. Horovitz wrote that Mr. Lewiss list was at first sight quite intriguing, but contained few allusions to actual poetry. He added: Mr. Lewis could presumably spout the hind legs off a donkey about these subjects, but how does this qualify him to follow Masefield, Auden, Graves and Heaney as the next Professor of Poetry? Mr. Lewis did not immediately respond to Mr. Horovitz. Last week Paula Claire, the only woman in the running this year, withdrew from the race, saying it unfairly favored the poet Geoffrey Hill. Another candidate, Michael George Gibson, questioned Ms. Claires decision, saying last week that she has rather flown off the handle with this one and calling the election a circus. Oxford is to announce the election results on Friday.

title: Breaking Bad Versus Mad Men
description: I had early doubts about Mad Men, but eventually I gave myself over to its charms, and after three excellent seasons I took it for granted that the saga of Don Draper was the best show on TV  the rightful heir, insofar as one could possibly exist, to The Sopranos and The Wire. But after working my way through AMCs other drama, Breaking Bad, which had its season finale Sunday night, I find that Ive changed my mind. And not only because Breaking Bad is brilliant though it is, it is  but because its dramatic strengths expose some of the weaknesses of Mad Men, and puncture, ever-so-gently, the mystique thats built up around Matthew Weiners show.

title: U.S. Team Focusing on Starting Strong
description: JOHANNESBURG  If a Slovenia player slips through the defense on Friday to score as easily against the United States as Steven Gerrard of England did when he side-footed a shot into the back of the net in the opening minutes of the World Cup opener, the Americans could find it hard to recover.

title: Embracing a Tragic Masculinity
description: SINCE he first gained attention on a New York stage 10 years ago, as a neo-Nazi on death row in "Coyote on a Fence," Paul Sparks has played manic addicts, antisocial misfits, bitter philanderers and other casualties of mismanaged existence.

title: Face Paint and (Playful) Fistfighting for This Tribe in Brooklyn
description: By the time the Kansas City rapper Tech N9ne closed his Monday night concert with Im a Playa, a song that rips off Falcos Rock Me Amadeus wholesale, there was no room left for shock, or awe, or revulsion, or thrill.

description: ALBANY  The State Senate on Tuesday, clearing aside decades of opposition, put New York on a course to adopt no-fault divorce  the last state to do so. It approved legislation that would permit couples to separate by mutual consent, a major shift with sweeping implications for families and lawyers.

description: Way back when, during the final decades of the last century, if a woman had a hard time conceiving, she saved her dollars by the tens of thousands and passed them over to a clinic specializing in assisted reproductive technology.

title: Said the Playwright to the Young Actor...
description: IN The Grand Manner, at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, Bobby Steggert plays Pete, a stand-in for the playwright A. R. Gurney during a galvanizing moment in his life. In 1948 Mr. Gurney traveled from his boarding school in New Hampshire to Manhattan, where he had a brief, nervous backstage exchange with the celebrated actress Katharine Cornell after a performance of Shakespeares "Antony and Cleopatra," an exchange that he uses as a jumping-off point in the comic drama.

stables, is on the market for 370,000 pounds, or about $550,000.

title: Portrait of an Addict as a Young Man
description: The first time he smokes crack. He never tells this story. Instead he usually says he tried it at a party, that he was pulled into a bedroom by someone he knew, a couple, a friend, someone he didn't know. It's someone different every time. The phony story always sounds less shameful to him, less weird, more normal, even glamorous. But that's not how it happens.

His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Is New York Ready for No-Fault Divorce?
description: In 1969, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California signed the nations first no-fault divorce law. He later called it the worst mistake of his life. But other states eventually followed Californias lead, and no-fault  under which one spouse can end a marriage, with no proof required of wrongdoing by either party  more or less became law of the land. New York State was the longtime holdout, since South Dakota passed its law in 1985.

Bromwich, the Washington lawyer President Obama has picked to revamp the troubled Minerals Management Service, has limited experience with the oil and gas industry. description: ATHENS  Newly elected and facing a huge budget deficit, Prime Minister George Papandreou arrived in Brussels for his first meeting with European leaders last December with few cards to play.

Medrek also accused the government of using food aid and other resources provided by the United States, the World Bank, and European donors as a political tool during the campaign. title: Feeling for  the Kerchief
description: In my continuing quest for alternatives to wearing a necktie during the hazy days of summer, I recently rediscovered the neckerchief. I was going to a theater opening on a recent evening and just didnt feel like sporting my usual tie slightly undone/white shirt open at the neck/sport jacket combo. I rummaged through my bureau looking for who knows what, when I came across a stack of faded-print cotton bandannas (the nostalgic cowboy kind). Perfect! If the Parisians can pull off their origami-like mastery of the scarf, why cant I give it a try? I first folded it in half to make a triangle, then rolled it up tightly,  la Fruit Roll-Up. I wrapped it snugly around my neck and tied a small, tight knot in front, tucking the ends into my shirt. I instantly felt dressier, more suitable for the special evening I had in store. Any slight apprehension I had about winning a Charles Nelson Reilly look-alike contest was quickly assuaged when I received some very nice, unexpected compliments. Since then, Ive been on the hunt for vintage bandannas so I can give my well-worn neckties a break.
