And was BP right to give in?

title: The Whitney Expansion
description: Many proposals by celebrated architects for the museums expansion were rejected before Renzo Pianos plan for a downtown location was approved.

title: All Green: Peas and Pasta
description: My favorite first-peas-of-the-year dish is prepared with lettuce, bacon and onion. For the remainder of the shelling pea season, it is succeeded by a raft of other dishes, many of them involving rice or pasta.

title: Stanford Cart
description: Mans Moravec added a slider to his Stanford Cart to move the television camera from side to side.

title: Glee Tops Vampires on Charts
description: The Billboard album chart this week answered one burning question: which is more powerful, vampires or a high school glee club?

title: Looking for Love, a Pint and a Soccer Match
description: IN the two months that the BP oil spill has befouled the Gulf of Mexico, an American stain has besmirched the British national character. That is the charge of some Britons in high places and high dudgeon. Last week, Lord Tebbit, the one-time Conservative Party chairman, accused President Obama of a xenophobic display of partisan political presidential petulance, while Londons mayor, Boris Johnson, complained that the United States was unleashing a wave of anti-British rhetoric.

title: Along the Waterfront in Lerici, Italy
description: The beautiful seaside town on the Italian Riviera has evaded the radar of foreign tourists.

title: An Italian Beauty Without Foreign Suitors
description: HOW is it that Lerici, an undeniably beautiful seaside town just minutes from the Cinque Terre on the Italian Riviera, has largely evaded the radar of foreign tourists?

title: 22 Percent of Internet Time Is Social, Nielsen Says
description: Messaging, commenting, blogging, sharing and liking now fill up 22 percent of all time spent online each month, according to Nielsen, a market research firm.

title: Travel Planning? Ask Your Friends.
description: TripAdvisor has introduced a new feature that allows its readers to combine advice from their Facebook friends with the reader reviews that the site is known for.

title: Never Reading Enough: A New York Affliction?
description: Even Internet strivers get the blues. Theres just so much stuff out there to be informed about, you know, and in a city of striving media and young Internet elites, for whom being in the know is among the highest forms of cultural capital, the abundance of text is apparently an increasingly debilitating fact of life.

title: Documents Can Be Summoned at a Touch With 2 iPad Apps
description: When the iPad arrived, I considered it a great tool for nonworking hours, mostly because my job revolves around Microsoft Office and Adobe PDF files. Apples iWork software for the iPad did not work seamlessly enough with those files, and nothing else had yet reached the App Store.

title: Last Generation?': A Response
description: The role of philosophers  and I take it, of The Stone  is to stimulate people to think about questions that they might not think about otherwise. That so many people were roused to comment on my piece, Should This Be the Last Generation?  despite comments being closed at one point  suggests that it achieved this aim. That said, it would have been good if some of those commenting had read the piece with a little more care, and all the way through.The comments show two common misunderstandings of what I was trying to do. As an example of the first, Rob Cook of New York writes that this piece frames overpopulation and environmental destruction in the wrong terms. It assumes that developed countries cannot cut down on consumption. But Last Generation? isnt a piece about overpopulation or environmental destruction, and it makes no assumptions about whether developed countries can cut down on consumption. It just isnt about that question at all. It asks a deeper question, one not dependent on the environmental constraints on our planet, nor on the number of people now on Earth. Even if there were only 1 million humans on this planet, all living at the level of an average citizen of, say, Switzerland, we could still ask whether it would be a good thing to have children in order to continue the species.

title: Maradona Keeps It Lively With Pel and the Koreans
description: The best came last. A relatively bland first week of the World Cup was salvaged on Wednesday by the last opening match, Switzerlands shocking 1-0 upset of Spain. It was the first time the Swiss had ever beaten the Spaniards (a streak covering 18 previous games over the course of 85 years); it was only the second loss in 46 games for Spain (whose previous defeat came last year, also in South Africa, to the Americans); and most important, it finally got people to stop talking about vuvuzelas.

title: Japan Resists Dolphin Documentary
description: Not surprisingly, a fight is under way in Japan over efforts to screen The Cove, the Oscar-winning documentary chronicling the annual slaughter of hundreds of dolphins in a town there.

title: Celebrating Horses, Humans and Their Bond
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  What would you call a show that brashly proclaims none of its 60 stars are female? Sexist, right? Definitely. Except that 34 of those main attractions are neutered.

title: A Juggernaut Rolls Into Carnegie, Chorus in Tow
description: You felt a buzz of electric anticipation in the air at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night long before a single note had sounded. The event at hand was mounted by Distinguished Concerts International New York, a producing organization that regularly presents choral extravaganzas with participants from around the world. Thunderous applause and illicit camera flashes greeted a 425-member choir as it efficiently crowded onto the stage.

title: The Media Response to Obama's Speech
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the media response to President Obama's Oval Office address on June 15, 2010.

title: The New Tiger, Practicing in Solitude
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Among the strange sites on the Pebble Beach practice putting green Wednesday morning was Tiger Woods completely alone. No caddie, no coach, no agent or press attache. It has been a long time since the worlds No. 1 golfer could be found alone at any tournament. Normally, he would be surrounded by a doting entourage that including security. Here, it was just Woods with his putter and four golf balls, working on his game.

title: How I Saved My Company
description: How raising prices and increasing a marketing budget helped Gnosis Arts survive.

title: Media Decoded: They Report, You Decide
description: A review looks at the rugged coverage of President Obamas address from the Oval Office about the Gulf oil spill. Is the media holding the president to account or piling on? Weigh in with an opinion in comments, and Brian Stelter and David Carr will join the frolic.

title: A Bluetooth for the Stylish, Not the Chatty
description: In time for release of the new iPhone, Jabra is putting out its high-style Bluetooth earpiece, the Stone, in white. Now fashionistas can match either black or white handsets.

title: Gran Turismo 5 Gets November Release
description: Yes, theres another Gran Turismo 5 trailer. But the good news this time is that it also comes with a firm release date.

title: Rodriguez Back in Lineup, as D.H.
description: As expected, Alex Rodriguez was back in the lineup for Wednesday nights game between the Yankees and the Phillies, but as the designated hitter, not the third baseman.

title: Model Boys From Brazil
description: Things just got a little easier for modelizers, who have exhausted Google, YouTube, The Fashionisto, Hero, et al. Made in Brazil is the latest guilty pleasure for dedicated fans of the male modeling industry. This shrine to Brazilian beefcake, which was previously only available online, now comes in oversize print form, and features 96 uninterrupted pages of runway regulars and new editorial faces. Evandro Soldati graces the cover; inside, fellow veteran Romulo Pires  a modeling Methuselah at 27  wrestles with pups, while up-and-comers Francisco Lachowski and Max Motta play demon and angel  scantily-clad, of course.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Man After Traffic Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Bridges and Tunnels division shot a man during a traffic dispute in the South Bronx early Wednesday, according to the police.

title: Pictures of the Day: Southeast France and Elsewhere
description: Flash floods caused by torrential rain killed 18 people and left about 10 missing near Frances Mediterranean coast, Reuters reported on Wednesday, after the worst downpours the region has seen since 1827. Residents were surprised by the speed at which the waters rose, turning streets into torrents and carrying away cars as if they were toys. It was dramatic, said Max Piselli, the mayor of Draguignan (pictured in Slide 1). The town is in a terrible state, with rocks, stones, mud and cars blocking the roads.

title: From Oprah Winfrey, Generous Gifts for Her Magazine Staff
description: Youll be forgiven if the following news makes you wonder why your boss hasnt lavished gifts on you lately.

title: American Airlines Lets You Board Early, for a Fee
description: If youre one of those passengers who hates waiting around until they call your seat zone number to board your flight, American Airlines has a solution for you: pay up. The carrier is offering its customers a chance to board earlier than everyone else (except priority customers) for an introductory rate of $10 each way. The perk can be purchased alone but is also also part of a broader bundling of benefits that the carrier is calling its Boarding and Flexibility package. In addition to getting you on the plane a little earlier, the package offers a $75 discount off of flight changes and allows you to fly standby on an earlier flight on your day of departure at no extra charge. That package starts at an introductory rate of $9. The airline said in a release that this is the first of many customized perks that it plans to offer to travelers. Our vote for the perk we wouldnt mind paying for: flight attendants who can help land planes.

title: Unclogging Sewer Lines, One Alligator at a Time (Not Really)
description: Strange things can be found on New York Citys streets. Even stranger things turn up below, in the sewer system.

title: Council Hears From Vendors and Residents on Proposed Food Truck Restrictions
description: The truck stops here.

title: Nisipeanu, Gelfand Lead Kings Tournament
WCBS-FM Regains Top Spot in New York
description: For the first time in 16 years, the oldies station WCBS-FM is the overall most popular radio station in New York City, according to the latest monthly ratings from Arbitron, capping a quick rise to the top after an equally sharp downfall.

title: 2 New York Lawmakers Back Wall St. on Derivatives
description: Two Democratic representatives from New York City, Gary L. Ackerman and Michael E. McMahon, are coming to the defense of Wall Street, urging members of the House-Senate conference committee on the financial regulatory bill to reject provisions that would force banks to spin off their lucrative derivatives trading units.

title: Fitzgerald Case, Just as Curious When Its Sung
description: The composer John Eatons concept of chamber opera has always been so quirky that he long ago coined the term pocket opera. Of his 20 operatic works, 12 are of the pocket variety, scored for a small cast and a small instrumental ensemble. Typically the singers play instruments, and the players do some singing and acting. Mr. Eaton, 75, a winner of a MacArthur Foundation grant, has an intriguing compositional voice that blends a microtonal harmonic idiom, elements of pastiche and quotations from popular songs, dances, marches and whatnot.

title: City Alleges Theft by School Contractor
description: A Queens electrical contractor bilked the Department of Education of more than $1 million by submitting fraudulent invoices, falsifying payrolls and charging for work that was never completed, according to allegations released Wednesday by Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools.

title: The Real Marshall Mathers
description: On your new album, Recovery, which comes out on Monday, you assume a confessional tone and back off from the misogyny and demented violence you pushed in your earlier work. Would you agree? I think Id have to go back and listen to it. Did I?

title: Making Video Files Compatible, and Paying for Texts
description: Q. Im using iMovie to make a DVD for my wifes 50th birthday and want to include video greetings from her friends in far-flung places. I imagine theyll use anything from DV to an iPhone to film the greetings. Do you have any suggestions for how they should send the files, and in a way that I can import and edit them?

title: Add Government to the List of Fat Cats
description: WASHINGTON  The thrashing of BP this week, in private meetings at the White House and in public hearings on Capitol Hill, was perhaps the most direct confrontation to date between governing Democrats and a corporate behemoth, but it was hardly the first.

title: BP: We Care About the Small People
description: My friend Jacob Weisberg at Slate did well with a line of novelty books of Bushisms.

title: How I Saved My Company: Gnosis Arts
description: Like a lot of business owners, Eric Bryant of Gnosis Arts, an Internet marketing firm started in 2007, found himself struggling during the recession. He thinks his company survived only because of two counterintuitive decisions he made. To hear his story, please watch the video below.

title: Artifacts | Art Unlimited
description: Art Basel in Switzerland is not like Art Basel in Miami. For one thing, there are twice as many people in town for the fair (more than 60,000), and few of them are American. There is way too much art that looks like other art. And the Swiss maintain a level of decorum that would seem foreign at the beach.

title: For Whitney, Downtown Is Its Crucible
description: As expansion efforts go, the Whitney Museum of American Arts record of futility is hard to match. Over 25 years it commissioned six expansion designs for its Upper East Side site, each of which, good or bad, ran up against a similar fate: killed in infancy by the neighborhoods notoriously conservative community board or subjected to a drawn-out death by the boards indecisiveness.

title: A Best Friend? You Must Be Kidding
description: FROM the time they met in kindergarten until they were 15, Robin Shreeves and her friend Penny were inseparable. They rode bikes, played kickball in the street, swam all summer long and listened to Andy Gibb, the Bay City Rollers and Shaun Cassidy on the stereo. When they were little, they liked Barbies; when they were bigger, they hung out at the roller rink on Friday nights. They told each other secrets like which boys they thought were cute, as best friends always do.

title: Innocence and Nerve Wrapped Into One
description: The radiance of Julia Roberts and the zany spunk of Holly Golightly: that only begins to describe the seductive charms of Sutton Foster in her irresistible cabaret show, An Evening With Sutton Foster, at the Caf Carlyle. Directed by Mark Waldrop, it might be described as a successful Moon shot in which it discovered that the orb is really made of green cheese; thats one small step for cosmic dairy products.

title: A Fathers Role?
description: What makes a father? That is the question I asked in a post earlier today, and it is one that Douglas L., a management consultant in Pennsylvania, has been asking for several months now. He is a father. He became one last October when his daughter was born. The babys mother was a woman with whom he had what he describes as a casual relationship.

title: What Were Reading: Editing Out Vuvuzelas
description: Here are the articles that caused the New York Times tech editors and reporters to pause as they browsed the Web on Wednesday:

title: Whitneys That Never Were
description: As Renzo Piano works to finalize his design for a new Whitney museum building in downtown Manhattan over the next several months, its a good moment to look back at a quarter century of efforts to expand the original museum uptown.

title: YouTube News Feed Shows Kyrgyz Violence, French Floods and Touchdown Jesus Ablaze
description: On Monday, Google announced a new initiative to help users, and news organizations, make better use of the 24 hours of video uploaded to YouTube every minute: the YouTube News Feed.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Star Trek and Critical Thinking
description: In this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer talks to Nancy Hill of the University of Texas at El Paso about lessons from Star Trek. Ms. Hills course for incoming freshmen  Thinking Boldly With Star Trek  aims to teach critical thinking, while exploring classic themes of science fiction. She says students respond to the course because the Star Trek theme is familiar and makes them feel comfortable.

title: FedEx Posts $419 Million in Profit for Quarter
description: FedEx, the package delivery company, swung to a fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday and offered a conservative outlook that relied on international sales, an area that also led growth in the last three months.

title: Nine to Know: Hard to Figure
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: When Wayward Ball Meets an Unyielding Defense
description: Adidas has heard much mockery of its latest, most troublesome child. The Jabulani football has attracted all manner of critics, who decry its tendency to move mysteriously in midflight. Goalkeepers have complained in training that it is a difficult customer, a diva even. As far as all members of the anti-Jabulani crowd are concerned, footballs, like children, should be as unobtrusive as possible; they must be seen and not swerved. That may be true. Whats probable, though, is that the Jabulani just wants to be loved.

title: Goose Shot Through Neck in Prospect Park
description: The drama never ends at Prospect Park lake. Wednesday afternoon, there was a Canada goose running around with an arrow or dart through its neck, the parks department said.

title: A Pair of Durable Troubadours, Contrasting and Complementing
description: They were a strange pair, actually: dry and wet. He, 62, with the guarded, narrow excellence of his fingerpicking, putting his voice through a heavy soul-compressor, like Marvin Gaye in a telephone booth; she, 68, practicing generosity, singing as loudly as possible and straining at the high edges, coming down hard on her songs pivot-point chord changes.

title: Shopping With Ron Gilad
description: The Brooklyn-based product designer found pieces created by New Yorkers that suited his taste for pared-down but playful products.

title: Spies of the Balkans
description: Dying in Byzantium

title: Cloaks and Daggers and Boudoirs in War
description: The man around whom Alan Fursts new spy novel revolves is Constantine Zannis, a highly placed police official in Salonika, Greece. In late 1940, as Spies of the Balkans begins, Zanniss specialty is discretion. He heads a new department charged with handling delicate situations. Is a politician being blackmailed by a prostitute? Call Zannis. Has a woman of some importance killed her husband and then insisted shes glad hes dead? Naughty girl, Zannis says, giving the Furst heros characteristic knowing shrug.

title: Investors Worry That BP May Default on Debt
description: Credit-market investors are pricing in a 36 percent chance that BP will default on its debt within five years as it deals with the cleanup costs and damage claims from the enormous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Bloomberg News reports.

title: A Bold Phone Fades a Bit in the Details
description: Fine print, baby. Its all about the fine print.

title: Murkowski Rival Grabs Tea Party Support
description: Joe Miller, who is trying to knock off Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska in a Republican primary, has won the backing of the Tea Party Express, giving him a second major endorsement this month.

title: A Faculty Recital, With Lectures, Too
description: Like New Yorks other conservatories, Mannes College the New School for Music presents performances throughout the school year. But Manness concert life blossoms most fully in the summer, when it offers several tightly focused festivals associated with training sessions and master classes. The one now occupying the schools auditorium  with a couple of concerts at Le Poisson Rouge as well  is the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance, a celebration of new music that opened on Tuesday evening.

title: Between Brilliance and Rage
description: Dr. Amy Bishop had shown evidence through the years that a small slight could set off a disproportionate reaction.

title: Catio Enclosures Protect Cats Outside
description: New Yorkers who would never let their cats roam free outside have created special outdoor spaces at home.

title: For the Vanderbilts Founders, a Rather Unlikely Grand Slam
description: Frank and Diana Schuld, who founded the Vanderbilt Bridge Club 35 years ago on Long Island, played several memorable deals together, but only one where they jumped to a grand slam with a void in the trump suit.

title: WNET Unit Gives Up Grants to Settle Lawsuit
description: A subsidiary of the New York public broadcaster WNET.org has settled a lawsuit by agreeing to repay the United States government $950,000 and to forgo about $1 million in federal grant money that it had been awarded but not yet received. The suit, filed by the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, asserted that the subsidiary, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, failed to adequately track the spending of grant money from the National Science Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Endowment for the Arts. It also said that in some cases the Educational Broadcasting Corporation used money for expenses that were not allowed under terms of the grants. The grants were for the production of programs including American Masters and Great Performances. As part of the settlement, reached on Tuesday, WNET.org and the Educational Broadcasting Corporation agreed to adopt a plan to ensure compliance with federal grant requirements.

title: Another Slam Dunk in TV Ratings Game
description: Professional basketball again boosted ABC in the ratings on Tuesday night as the Los Angeles Lakers forced the N.B.A. Finals to Game 7. Nielsens preliminary overnight estimates show Tuesdays Game 6 easily topped the night as the most-watched programming in prime time, but the numbers were down slightly compared to Sundays broadcast of Game 5, which attracted an impressive 18.7 million viewers according to the final ratings. CBS ranked second on the night with reruns of its crime shows, while NBC was third despite gaining an audience of 10.3 million viewers at 9 p.m. for Americas Got Talent. Fox finished fourth.

title: Stars Future a Factor in Bloody Bloody Move
description: It has been an open secret that the Public Theater is eyeing a transfer to Broadway for its critically acclaimed musical Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson. But the timing, if it happens, remains up in the air. The Shubert Organization has offered the Jacobs Theater, a prime piece of real estate, for the show in the fall, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the conversations. But one wrinkle is that Benjamin Walker, above, the star of the show, has been offered an enviable role in a coming X-Men movie, said the executives, who would speak only anonymously because they were not authorized to announce the information. It was not clear whether Mr. Walker was taking the film role, or when shooting might begin.

title: Search for Tony Home Reaches Far Uptown
description: Where would you hold next years Tony Awards show? The ceremonys usual home, Radio City Music Hall, has a sustained booking for June 2011, so the Tonys are in the hunt for a new space for the 65th-annual awards next season. There are not many places in Manhattan with Radio Citys seating capacity (roughly 6,000) and acoustics, not to mention its prime Midtown location. Sites being assessed by Tonys officials include the Beacon Theater (3,000 seats) on the Upper West Side and the Apollo Theater (1,500 seats) in Harlem. Word on the Rialto was that the Broadway Theater and the Marriott Marquis Theater have also been discussed. Also under consideration is the United Palace, a 3,000-seat theater at 175th Street and Broadway in Washington Heights. The Tonys have been held at Radio City since 1997, except for 1999, when they were at the Gershwin Theater, the current home of the musical Wicked.

title: Researchers Identify Bones as Caravaggios
description: The remains of Caravaggio, the Baroque artist, have almost certainly been found in a Tuscan ossuary, lifting a centuries-old mystery over his burial, Reuters reported. Researchers for the National Committee for Historical, Cultural and Environmental Heritage in Italy said on Wednesday that they were confident that the bones found in the ossuary, shown above by Silvano Vicenti, president of the committee, matched those of Michelangelo Merisi, the artist known as Caravaggio. We have carried out DNA testing on these remains and looked at the results alongside presumed relatives of Caravaggio, people with the same family name, Giorgio Gruppioni, a physical anthropologist, told Reuters television. We have compatibility with these genetic strands. Theories about the artists death have had him succumbing to syphilis or being murdered. Caravaggio, who was 38 when he died on a beach north of Rome in 1610, pioneered chiaroscuro, the painting technique of contrasting light and dark. He was also a rogue given to brawls, chasing men and women, and even murdering a tennis foe.

title: Talks Over Authors Profits Break Down
description: Talks over a financial settlement between Stieg Larssons companion and his family have broken down, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Larsson, the author of the hugely successful Millennium thrillers died suddenly in 2004 at 50, leaving behind the manuscripts that became the trilogy. Though they were a couple for 32 years, Mr. Larsson and his companion, Eva Gabrielsson, right, never married, and because Sweden does not recognize common-law marriage Ms. Gabrielsson was not legally entitled to profits from Mr. Larssons books, which have sold more than 35 million copies worldwide. The discussions which have been going on for six months between Stieg Larssons heirs and his former partner Eva Gabrielsson have ended, Mr. Larssons father and brother said in a statement released on Tuesday. Unfortunately she did not want to accept all or part of our proposal. Mr. Larssons family has said that it offered to share with her some proceeds from the novels, which have touched off a race to find the next great Scandinavian noir writer, but that she declined. Ms. Gabrielsson does have a crucial piece of the Larsson legacy: a laptop computer containing roughly three-quarters of a fourth novel.

title: Glee Takes Biggest Bite of Album Sales
description: The Billboard album chart this week answered one burning question: Which are more powerful, vampires or members of a high school glee club? Turns out its the gleeks. Glee: The Music, Journey to Regionals (Columbia), a new six-song collection that is the shows fifth release in its first season  and its third to reach No. 1  sold 152,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is about 8,000 more sales than the soundtrack to The Twilight Saga: Eclipse (Chop Shop/Atlantic), also released last week. Also on this weeks album chart: Christina Aguileras new Bionic (RCA) is No. 3 with 110,000 sales; Jack Johnsons To the Sea (Brushfire) fell three spots to No. 4, with 89,000 sales; and the Florida rapper Plies new album, Goon Affiliated (Slip-N-Slide/Atlantic), is No. 5 with 56,000.

title: President Obamas Gulf Speech Drew Fewer Viewers Than Other Recent Addresses
description: One in five households with television sets watched President Obamas Oval Office address about the gulf oil spill on Tuesday night, according to the Nielsen Company. An average of 24 million households and 32 million people tuned in to the almost 20-minute address, according to Nielsen, which counts only at-home viewing.

title: A Midcentury Tree House
description: A California home in the redwoods where each room is designed to face the view.

title: Kurdistan Is Urged to Ban Genital Cutting
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  Human Rights Watch urged Kurdistans government on Wednesday to ban genital cutting of women and girls, a practice the organization said is widespread and dangerous there, but which they said Kurdish officials had failed to move aggressively to stop.

title: Police Look Into Security After Melee at Concert
description: The police are looking into the causes of the rowdy scene at South Street Seaport in Manhattan on Tuesday night when a way-overcapacity crowd turned out for a free concert by the rapper Drake and the pop band Hanson.

title: Pulling Museum Mile Uptown
description: SHE was sometimes by his side when William C. Thompson Jr. worked the rubber-chicken circuit last year, a poised, attractive woman in no rush to pose for the cameras, confident that her husband, the New York City comptroller, could make his own case for why he deserved to be mayor.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Add a few more volumes to the bookshelf that holds the expanding literature of the Great Recession. This months protagonists watch as jobs, homes, boyfriends and opportunities disappear  and those are in the comic novels. Meanwhile, Glenn Beck delivers a conspiracy thriller with a P.R. executive as its villain.

title: Reclaiming Causes of a Filmmaking Rebel
description: When Nicholas Ray, the pathbreaking filmmaker and director of Rebel Without a Cause, died from lung cancer in 1979, he left behind a substantial collection of artifacts that had never, or rarely, been seen. There is, for instance, the original typed treatment for Rebel with a bizarre twist that had Plato (played by Sal Mineo in the 1955 film) shoot Jim (James Dean) and commit suicide by falling on a live grenade, as well as an unfinished experimental movie, We Cant Go Home Again, to which Ray devoted the last years of his life.

title: Searching the Globe for Authentic Materials
description: Contractors and designers like Fernando Sanchez travel the world to find rare and beautiful building materials for their clients.

title: France and Spain Act to Rein In Budgets
description: PARIS  Under pressure from anxious lenders, the French government took steps on Wednesday to help reassure markets about its creditworthiness, announcing that it would raise the retirement age and increase income taxes on the rich to help rein in its budget deficit.

title: Tiny Moments That Tell One Small Towns Story
description: A beguiling slice of Midwestern impressionism, 45365 drops in on the residents of Sidney, Ohio, to observe their lunches and haircuts, trials and transgressions. Filmed over nine months in 2007, this remarkable patchwork of unremarkable lives was assembled by Bill and Turner Ross, brothers, native sons and natural filmmakers. Alighting on county fair and high school football game, retirement home and voting booth, their detached, glancing gaze requires neither narration nor intertitles: the images  and the chatter of local radio  say it all.

title: Democrats Trim Back Spending Bill
description: Hoping to break a stubborn impasse over a major spending and tax package, Senate Democrats late Wednesday unveiled a trimmed-back measure they said was paid for except for emergency unemployment compensation and state aid money.

title: The Shadow of BPs Stock on Capitol Hill
description: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the Republican leader, bought stock in BP and other oil companies last year while other lawmakers were a little more fortunate, getting rid of BP stock before the enormous oil spill caused the environmental disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, The Associated Press reports.

title: A.I.G. Executive Wont Be Sued
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will not sue Joseph J. Cassano, the former head of the Financial Products unit at the American International Group, a lawyer representing him said on Wednesday.

title: Britain Moves to Revamp Financial Regulation
description: LONDON  Britain will abolish its main financial regulator and consolidate its authority in the Bank of England, the chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, said Wednesday night.

title: U.S. and Europe Press Tighter Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  A day after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on more than a dozen Iranian companies and individuals with links to the countrys nuclear and missile programs, the European Union followed suit on Thursday with what it called inevitable new measures against Tehran.

title: S.E.C. Drops Case Against Former A.I.G. Executive
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will not sue Joseph J. Cassano, the head of the Financial Products unit at the American International Group before the giant insurer nearly collapsed, a lawyer representing him said Wednesday, Gretchen Morgenson of The New York Times reports.

title: Trade Tensions With China Shadow G-20 Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Anger toward Chinas currency, trade and industrial policies has been steadily mounting in Congress, adding pressure on President Obama to take a tough stance with his Chinese counterparts at the Group of 20 leaders meeting next week in Toronto.

title: Spider-Man Is Among the Most Wanted
description: MEXICO CITY  Spider-Man has successfully taken on the Green Goblin, Doctor Octopus and Venom, to name just a few of his foes over the years, but the web-spinning superhero was no match for Mexicos federal police, who recently manhandled him and easily took him into custody.

title: In Illinois Race, a Teaching Career Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Mark S. Kirk of Illinois, a Republican candidate for the United States Senate, has often reminisced about his time as a teacher.

title: Bernhardt Designs Pillar Chair
description: Many ultra-modern chairs look sharp but, unfortunately, they can also feel sharp. Brad Ascalon, a New York designer, addressed this by creating the Pillar chair for Bernhardt Design.

title: Sales at ABC Carpet & Home and Others
description: During ABC Carpet & Homes summer sale, through July 18, nearly everything in stock will be up to 75 percent off (the Hampton sofa, originally $1,895, is $1,395; the Louis console by Reeves Design, regularly $1,095, is $769; and the Tom Dixon Cage light, originally $215, is $129); 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000 or abchome.com.

title: Road Test: Stain Removers

The sparkling pool has new tiles that replicate the originals, the camellias are blooming and Antonio Canovas marble sculptures of scantily clad nymphs rise from pedestals in the pool.

title: Talking With a Cooper-Hewitt Design Award Winner
description: Today, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum announces the winners of its National Design Awards, its own Oscars. William Sofield (above right), the Princeton-educated designer who created sleek containers for Tom Fords Gucci juggernaut, will take the prize for interior design. Mr. Sofields work ranges from the thunderously sensual  like Mr. Fords post-Gucci emporia, which telegraph an  Eyes Wide Shut  mens-club naughtiness  to a quieter, more intense exposition of luxury, as in the between-the-wars finishes on a Fifth Avenue penthouse once owned by Jackie Onassis, the dining room of which Mr. Sofield veneered with eggshell marquetry. Mr. Sofield, who has also designed retail boutiques for Bottega Veneta and Yves Saint Laurent, David Barton gyms and the SoHo Grand hotel, was asked to submit 10 projects to the Design Awards jury. He included the Studio at Laurel Canyon (above left), a Craftsman bungalow in Los Angeles he owned and restored over 10 years, which once belonged to Douglas Fairbanks.

title: Trophy Hunters With Their Eye on Interiors
description: BRAGGING rights for homeowners are fleeting, hard to hold as a fistful of fog. You think your home is special because your backsplash is covered in tile imported from Mexico? There are those who think nothing of dispatching their architects and builders to the ends of the earth to personally scope out far more exotic goods  to the Middle East for the perfect limestone, even as bombs are going off, or to Indonesia for centuries-old reclaimed teak.

title: At World Cup, Little Faith in France
description: DURBAN, South Africa  It never seems easy for the French at major soccer championships. Even when they won their lone World Cup  at home in 1998  they did it with a coach, Aime Jacquet, who was heavily criticized much of the way for his supposed tactical and leadership deficiencies.

Weve been working with Puma on recreating iconic elements of after-hours sports, said Rinat Aruh, a founder of Aruliden. Everyone always does things for basketball and baseball, but theres so much love for Ping-Pong.

He was 71 and lived nearby in Farmingville, N.Y.

It has been a long time since Woods, the worlds No 1. golfer, has been found alone at any tournament. Once he would have been surrounded by a doting entourage that included security. On Wednesday, it was just Woods working on his game for the United States Open with a putter and four balls.

The oil pours out nearly every week, and some swamps are long since lifeless.

In Fremont County, Wyo., where the Popo Agie and Little Wind Rivers are flooding, volunteers are using white irrigation pipe, the kind you see tracing the high contours in pastures and hayfields across the state.

A murderer named Gary Mark Gilmore, famous even before the books about him, died before a five-man firing squad, ending a national moratorium on capital punishment. In the worst-hit town, Draguignan, between Marseille and Cannes, some districts were under more than six feet of water and hundreds of vehicles had been swept away. Local officials said more than 1,200 people took refuge in schools and other government buildings, while the police evacuated more than 400 prisoners from a flooded jail.

title: Freshman Enrollment Climbed in 2008
description: Freshman enrollment at the nation's colleges and trade schools set records in 2008, the first year of the recession, and almost three-quarters of the increase came from minority high school graduates, especially Hispanics, seeking higher education, according to a Pew Research Center report released Wednesday. Enrollment of Hispanic freshmen at four-year and community colleges and trade schools increased 15 percent, compared with 8 percent among blacks, 6 percent among Asians and 3 percent among whites. The data was the most recent available from the Department of Education, but other government statistics suggested the trend had continued into 2009, the report said.

title: British Directors Will Oversee Ceremonies for 2012 London Olympics
description: Short of a feel-good movie about young Scottish heroin addicts who aspire to become ballet dancers, the 2012 Summer Olympics have found a more constructive way to bring the filmmakers Danny Boyle and Stephen Daldry together. Mr. Boyle, the Trainspotting director (who also won an Academy Award for Slumdog Millionaire), and Mr. Daldry, whose films include Billy Elliot, will be the creative heads of the London games, The Guardian reported. At an official announcement ceremony on Thursday, the 2012 Olympic Organizing Committee said that Mr. Daldry would serve as the overall creative director of ceremonies while Mr. Boyle would be the artistic director of the opening ceremony, which is scheduled for July 27. The Guardian said that the two directors would have a budget of 40 million (about $59 million) for a total of four ceremonies during the 2012 games, presumably a little more than Mr. Daldry had to play with as director of Billy Elliot: The Musical. In addition to that hit production, Mr. Daldry is also developing a stage version of Dumbo for Disney Theatrical Productions, while Mr. Boyle is directing Frankenstein for Britains National Theater.

title: Its All Tutu Much: McCartney Writing Ballet Music
description: Sorry, Sting, but it sounds like Paul McCartney has just lapped you in the race to be the pop musician with the most classical bona fides. Mr. McCartney, the former Beatle and Wings man whose orchestral works include Standing Stone and Ecce Cor Meum, told BBC News that he has agreed to write the music for a ballet and has already started work on the project. Im interested in doing things I havent done before, Mr. McCartney said to the BBC. That offer came up and I love writing music, the two went together and I said, Yeah, so I just accept things before I even know what Im doing. Mr. McCartney did not say who the music was being written for or when it might be performed, but he acknowledged that it was an unusual excursion, even for someone who has ridden shotgun in a yellow submarine, designed his own postage stamps and been recorded eating vegetables by both the Beach Boys and Super Furry Animals. I dont really know that much about it yet, Mr. McCartney said. Im just writing music for it, but its a switch.

title: Voyage to the Bottom of the Day Care Center
description: Toy Story 3 begins with a rattling, exuberant set piece that has nothing to do with the tale that follows but that nonetheless sums up the ingenuity, and some of the paradoxes, that have made this Pixar franchise so marvelous and so successful. The major toys  Woody (Tom Hanks), Buzz (Tim Allen), the Potato Heads (Don Rickles and Estelle Harris), Hamm (John Ratzenberger), Jessie (Joan Cusack), Rex (Wallace Shawn) and the others  are in a setting at once wholly unfamiliar and instantly recognizable. Theyre in a western, albeit one made in the amped-up modern action style, rather than the more stately idiom of old-time oaters. A train is hurtling down the tracks; a bridge explodes; stuff is falling out of the sky. There are force fields and laser beams and a big noisy surprise every time you blink.

title: Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?
description: As longtime readers know, I think the cellphone industry is one step away from a big-city mugger. Some of their practices are outrageous ripoffs-like how they charge so much for text messages (both the sender and the receiver), even though text messages cost them nothing. Or how the purpose of two-year contract is to sell you an expensive phone cheaply, on the premise that you'll pay it off over the next 24 months -- but once you've paid off the phone, your monthly bill doesn't go down. (Except at T-Mobile.)

title: What Were Reading: Free Checking
Two Favorites Are Tied for Lead of Dutch Championship
Obscure But Powerful Agency Gets New Leader
description: Its an obscure city agency with a big stick. And now it has a new leader.

title: Resort Report | Marc Jacobs
description: Marc Jacobs went to St. Tropez for resort. Instead of the modern-day decadence and nearly naked look typical of this locale, these clothes were more innocent. There was a playful 60s feel with youthful silhouettes in sweet pastels and prints featuring scalloped edges. Polka dots popped up often for a chic and upbeat mood. Feminine short dresses had nipped waists with fuller skirts  some with a volume of peplum in the back. There was still plenty of skin, with most hemlines landing well above the knee, and bandeau tops galore. These wraparound tops  done in most of the collections fabrics  could be paired with matching briefs at the pool or under a little tweed suit.

title: Justices Allow Search of Work-Issued Pager
description: WASHINGTON  A California police department did not violate the constitutional privacy rights of an employee when it audited the text messages on a pager the city had issued him, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Thursday.

title: The Growing Push to Impose a Transaction Tax
description: Among the hot button issues that Wall Street will be following closely next week at the Group of 20 economic summit meeting in Toronto is the idea of imposing a worldwide tax on financial transactions. The move, championed by the Europeans, is aimed at curbing excess speculation and building revenue.

title: Sexsomnia
description: A sleep disorder which apparently causes sufferers to engage in sexual activities while sleeping.

title: Jobs Growth Continues in May, as Unemployment Rate Falls
description: New York Citys unemployment rate fell again in May, remaining below the national unemployment rate for the second month in a row, according to data released on Thursday by the State Labor Department.

title: On a Wing and a Prayer: Chevrons Deep Well
description: One of the deepest offshore oil fields in the Gulf of Mexico lies beneath 7,000 feet of water and under more than 20,000 feet of rock and sand. Estimated to hold as much as 100 million barrels of crude, the field was discovered by Chevron in 2001, and production began in 2008. It is less than 20 miles west of the Deepwater Horizon blowout.

title: Resort Report | Givenchy
description: A modern-day Frido Kahlo was the muse for Givenchy. Riccardo Tisci spoke of a lightness and sensuality in the clothing, with a mixture of masculine and feminine and a larger focus on cocktail and evening looks. Lace was worked into more tailored pieces in blocks of black, white and red, while a new leopard print felt cool. The more feminine pieces were grounded with a sturdy shoe done with a new shorter heel.

title: Apps to Make Your Guitar Gently Weep
description: Electric guitarists can get a little carried away with their gear  especially effects pedals (a k a stompboxes), amps and cabinets.

title: Sarbanes-Oxley Gains Some Acceptance, Survey Finds
description: It has been nearly eight years since the Sarbanes-Oxley Act was signed into law. And ever since, its worth has been the subject of hot debate by the chattering classes.

title: The Earrings? Not for Sale. Nor the Comb.
description: Theres a pair of rhinestone and silver chandelier earrings resting on a shelf amid hundreds of other baubles, bangles, pins and pendants in Alfred Albrizios jewelry store in Greenwich Village. But if a customer asks to see them, Mr. Albrizio mumbles a demurral: Why not choose something else? Just not that trinket carved from fossilized ivory; oh, and not that necklace of amethyst tiles.

title: Status of Written Confirmations From Comcast
description: In a January Bucks post, Why You Can Get Written Confirmation From Comcast, we described the crusade of Marc Pachtman, a lawyer in Boothwyn, Pa., to get Comcast to provide written confirmations of what was agreed to on customer service calls.

title: F.C.C. Moves to Expand Role in Broadband
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission voted 3 to 2 on Thursday to move toward giving itself the authority to regulate the transmission component of broadband Internet service, a power the commissions majority believes is central to expanding the availability of broadband.

title: Afghanistan Moves Quickly to Tap Newfound Mineral Reserves
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Ministry of Mines announced Thursday that it would take the first steps toward opening the countrys reserves to international investors at a meeting next week in London even as Afghans expressed a mixture of hope and doubt about the governments commitment to develop the countrys newly documented mineral wealth.

title: The Morning Skate: Devils Name MacLean Coach, Trade Rumors Fly
description: Hockey really doesnt have an off-season. Its just that games are not played. But the news never stops.

description: Art Basel isnt just an international marketplace for modern and contemporary art. Its a mindset for both creative types and wealthy spark plugs seeking intellectual stimulation, visual pleasure and fellowship. Especially fellowship.

title: Fashion Spawn for Sale
description: In the late 1990s, Cecilia Pagkalinawan had a business advising fashion labels about selling their stuff online. There were actually some people who knew what she was talking about, although there wasnt really a market. Then came the dot-com bust, and Ms. Pagkalinawan closed her business and went to work for Burberry in London and later Frette and La Perla, developing e-commerce.

title: Who Needs a Mirror When You Have a Cellphone?
description: The mobile phone, the Swiss Army knife of the digital generation, has already left a trail of lifeless gadgetry in its path. Many phone owners no longer carry around point-and-shoot cameras, video cameras, music players, notepads or their old sturdy Filofax. Instead, they choose a single-serving device: the smartphone.

title: Higher Prices = Less Soda Drinking
description: The American Journal of Public Health released a study this afternoon finding that when the price of soda goes up, consumption goes down. From the news release:

title: U.S. and Europe Press Tighter Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  A day after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on more than a dozen Iranian companies and individuals with links to the countrys nuclear and missile programs, the European Union followed suit on Thursday with what it called inevitable new measures against Tehran.

title: Appeals Court Judge Is Sworn In
description: Judge Denny Chin was sworn in to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Wednesday, becoming the only Asian-American to fill an active judgeship on a United States Court of Appeals.

title: Little Slovenia Is Ready for the U.S.
description: What has 305 million people fewer people than the United States but could still knock the Americans out of the World Cup?

title: Pictures of the Day: Capitol Hill and Elsewhere
description: Lawmakers grilling Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, grew frustrated on Thursday when he repeatedly sidestepped their questions, saying he was unaware of engineering decisions before the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico and refusing to speculate about what investigators would discover about its causes. John M. Broder and Liz Robbins report that even as Mr. Hayward apologized for a catastrophe that never should have happened, he offered few specifics about why.

title: Along Lafayette Street, Some Very Odd Lots
description: THE three blocks of Lafayette Street from Houston to Great Jones are mostly an ugly scar, still raw from the ruthless clear-cutting that created it a century ago. As the most recent surge of development sweeps over NoHo, Lafayettes ragged edges are softening, but this unusual strip will always have an awkward limp.

title: Starbucks Hopes There Is No Java Jive From Contest Results
description: The next time you visit your local Starbucks and there is a big crowd keeping you from ordering a cup of coffee as fast as you would like, consider this: someone in that crowd may have contributed an idea to cutting down on cup waste.

title: Bronx Up, Battery Down; Its Your Sense of Direction
description: Midtown is a grid and its easy to figure out where you are, but Wall Streets a different story, and so is the West Village. It helps to have a sense of direction in the city. But are we born with that sense, or do enough visits to the corner of Stone and Broad Streets teach us?

title: Theater Listings: June 18  24
description: Theater

title: Helping Dads Become More Fatherly
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday announced a broad initiative to help fathers become more active and productive members of their families.

title: Not So Sinister in Stockholm
description: THERES nothing particularly remarkable about the mustard-colored building at Bellmansgatan 1, in Stockholms Sodermalm neighborhood. But that doesnt stop tourists from taking photos of the place.

title: The Sprint Evo 4G Phone
description: The Evo 4G seems wonderful at first, but it has some significant drawbacks.

title: A Culinary Tour Through Monrovia
description: In the Liberian capital, Southern cooking takes on a coastal African twist.

title: A Liberian Tour With Fork (and Fingers)
description: I KNEW my plan to spend my recent trip home eating my way around Monrovia was off to a good start when my sister showed up at the airport to greet me accompanied by a pot of bitterleaf over doughy fufu.

title: Tips for June Gardens
description: How to help annuals and perennials thrive through summer.

description: The latest news in Vienna

title: A Musical Battle Flag, Waved by All Sides
description: For generations Beethovens Ninth Symphony, with its choral finale espousing universal brotherhood, has been the work of choice to solemnize a peace treaty, open a new concert hall or foster communal bonding. Leonard Bernstein conducted the Ninth at an indoor concert in Berlin to celebrate the fall of the Berlin Wall. Then again it was conducted profoundly by the great Wilhelm Furtwngler in Nazi Germany, leading orchestras and choruses purged of Jews.

title: S.&P. Cuts BP Ratings, Citing Liabilities and Politics
description: Standard & Poors cut its credit ratings for BP on Thursday afternoon and warned that it might downgrade its ratings again because of the growing liabilities from the enormous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. It also said that BP faced intense political pressure in the United States.

title: Deep in the Carpathians, Painted Parables
description: WHEN the Moldavian prince Stephen the Great won his first decisive victory against the Turks five and a quarter centuries ago, he decided to mark the occasion with a grand monastery and adorn its walls with the colorful work of artisans of the day. With his second victory came another monastery. With the third, yet another.

title: Avant-Gardist in Retreat
description: PHILADELPHIA  What to think of the art of Pierre-Auguste Renoir?

title: Late Renoir
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Miami Art Museum Names New Director
description: The Miami Art Museum has named Thomas Collins, currently the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., as its new director, effective Aug. 16, the museum said on Thursday. The Miami museum has been without a permanent director since Terence Riley, the former chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, resigned abruptly in October after less than four years in the post. The museum is planning to break ground later this year on a new $131 million building designed by the firm Herzog & de Meuron, which is scheduled to open in 2013.

title: Keeping the June Garden Colorful
description: This is another in a series of articles on the maintenance and development of a flower garden. Previous articles can be found here and here.

title: Barton: What I Really Meant to Say
description: Representative Joe L. Barton on Thursday quickly backpedaled, and then recanted, the remarks he made about BPs liability fund that had caused an immediate uproar from Democrats and Republicans alike. At last count, Mr. Barton,Republican of Texas, retracted the apology he gave the energy giant during the House hearing earlier in the day, where he criticized the $20 billion fund created to help those affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: The Food of I Am Love
description: A look at some of the dishes that appear in the film.

title: Beyond Masks of Human Multiplicity
description: In program notes for Cloak, which had its premiere Wednesday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the Montreal choreographer George Stamos invokes Oscar Wilde and Leigh Bowery. Both men had marvelously intense, complicated identities, so it makes sense that they would be named in a work inspired by the multiplicity of self that is in all of us.

title: Andy Warhol, Outside His Comfort Zones
description: In the 10 years before his sudden death at 58 in 1987 Andy Warhol had more new, good ideas about making paintings than he knew what to do with. But he rarely let on.

title: MySpace Co-President Leaving Company
description: Updated: 5:28 p.m.: Barely four months after becoming a co-president of MySpace, Jason Hirschhorn is leaving the company.

title: Where Families Learn Sailing  Basics
description: THE sun cast a dreamy orange glow as it settled toward the horizon, and a parade of pristine sailboats began slipping back into the marina at Liberty State Park after a spin around New York Harbor. The Gonzalez family of Chatham, N.J., was on one of those boats, and Tony and Maryury Gonzalez and their three children were more than just passengers.

title: Canadiens Trade Halak to St. Louis
description: One of the big stars of the just concluded Stanley Cup playoffs has been traded.

title: The Buzz in Basel: Art, Alive and Well and Selling Briskly
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Minutes after a limestone head by Modigliani sold for $52.6 million at a Christies auction in Paris on Monday, word spread to the collectors arriving here for the annual art fair. And everyone wanted the details.

title: Coming-Out Conversations, Moderated With Pride
description: SAME-SEX marriage, religion, sex toys, Botox: no topic is taboo at Qtalk. Fitting for a live talk show that boldly embraces complex subjects, the Gay Pride Month edition, on Saturday night at 9:45 at the Metropolitan Room, will tackle an issue that is central to gays and lesbians: coming out.

title: Federal Officials Continue AT&T iPad Investigation
description: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Adding more about the controversy over the threat posed by exposed ICC-ID numbers. 10:45pm | Updated Amendedstatement from AT&T.

title: Resort Report | Proenza Schouler
description: A few weeks in India was all it took for the Proenza Schouler designers to add some glint to their chic-beach-bum-in-the-city resort hits. The puckered, gold-flecked fabrics looked rich and cool when mixed with their signature tie-dyes and relaxed cottons. The combination of day and evening fabrics felt easy and fresh. Baby-doll tops, dresses and skirts wrapped and tied in front like a sari. They introduced adorable Baja ponchos in orange and green stripes, and also used the fabric for shorts and relaxed pants that girls will want to live in when on holiday.

title: Suspect in Failed Times Square Car Bombing Is Indicted
description: Updated 5:46 p.m. | Faisal Shahzad, the Pakistani immigrant charged in the failed Times Square bombing plot, was indicted on Thursday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan, prosecutors said.
