title: Authors Brooklyn Town House Gets a Price Trim
Magical Thinking at the ECB
description: And the march to a lost decade continues. In its latest Monthly Bulletin (pdf) , the European Central Bank goes all in for immediate fiscal austerity. It justifies this by buying in, wholeheartedly, to the notion that fiscal contraction is actually expansionary. As evidence, it points to  well, things Ive already debunked: the allegedly expansionary Irish fiscal contraction of the 1980s that was probably largely about devaluation and falling interest rates, the Alesina-Ardagna study that makes no effort to distinguish between liquidity-trap and non-trap episodes (and whose method for identifying fiscal stimulus doesnt seem to capture actual policy.)

title: Deal Near on Student Transit Fares
description: Students will likely keep the discounted transit fares they pay to ride New York Citys buses and subways, as state legislators neared an agreement on Thursday to save a service that had been threatened by budget woes.

title: Bowling Ball, Shoes and Wig
description: Sitting on a musty couch in an East Village karaoke bar recently, I was fully aware I should have been home writing, but I blame my bowling team for the transgression. It may sound old-fashioned, but this league is more like a weekly party and it is sometimes hard to let the party end.

title: A Weekend in Bordeaux, France
description: Bordeaux sparkles with the addition of stellar restaurants and innovative wine bars.

title: A Survey of Italy in a Hurry: 8 Cities, 2 Centuries, 1 Show
description: The title suggests a leisurely Grand Tour, but An Italian Journey: Drawings From the Tobey Collection, Correggio to Tiepolo, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is more of a whirlwind trip. A couple of lines from Vasari, a map of Italy and youre off, dashing through two centuries and at least eight cities in fewer than 100 works.

title: Mid-50s Melodrama, via Antonioni
description: Le Amiche  it translates as The Girlfriends but sounds so much better in Italian  is about a group of women negotiating the complicated demands of work, love and looking fabulous in a bustling modern city. The city, to dispel any confusion, is Turin, and the sex, since this movie was made in 1955 in a country still ruled by traditional mores, is off-screen and unspoken. And the film, which American audiences may have encountered in revivals and retrospectives but never in theatrical release, was directed by Michelangelo Antonioni. (It opens on Friday for a weeklong run at the Film Forum.)

title: Irreverent Bingo, a Virtual Subway Series and a Chinatown Arcade
description: They say this city is a playground, so this week the Miser found some excellent ways to play without having to pay ... much.

title: Griffin Dunne and Wife Buy a Condo
description: EARLIER this year, this column reported that the actor and director Griffin Dunne, who starred in the cult classic American Werewolf in London, had transformed to an apartment seller from an apartment owner.

title: 36 Hours in Bordeaux, France
description: TASTING notes for the 2004 Bordeaux  the stony French city, not its famous wine  might have read something like this: lifeless and bland; aromas of dirt and dust; a once majestic city well past its prime. But recent years have shown real progress. Todays Bordeaux is smooth and elegant, thanks to reclaimed docklands and a beautification effort that is removing centuries of soot from its venerable squares and medieval churches. Theres also a new liveliness, including avant-garde art spaces and fledgling concept stores. Throw in some stellar upstart restaurants and innovative wine bars, and Bordeaux sparkles once again.

title: Connoisseurs of Tragedy Disperse Relics of Wrecks
Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?
description: 11:38 p.m. | Updated Clarifying the difference in wording noted by many readers  between what the whistleblower said and what the Verizon Wireless spokeswoman said about firing reps.

title: Talent Takes Wednesday
description: Americas Got Talent topped the ratings race on Wednesday night as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to that NBC reality show at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. NBC was first over all; Fox placed second on the night with So You Think You Can Dance (6.5 million). CBS was a close third, with the Paley Center for Medias special, TVs Greatest Surprises (6.6 million). ABC was fourth.

title: Magnums Treasures, Open to the Public
description: I think theres something quite magical about holding the stuff of history in your hands, said David Coleman, the curator of photography at the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Its All Tutu Much: McCartney Writing Ballet Music
description: Sorry, Sting, but it sounds like Paul McCartney has just lapped you in the race to be the pop musician with the most classical bona fides. Mr. McCartney, the former Beatle and Wings man whose orchestral works include Standing Stone and Ecce Cor Meum, told BBC News that he has agreed to write the music for a ballet and has already started on the project. Im interested in doing things I havent done before, Mr. McCartney said to the BBC. That offer came up and I love writing music, the two went together and I said, Yeah, so I just accept things before I even know what Im doing. Mr. McCartney did not say who the music was being written for or when it might be performed, but he acknowledged that it was an unusual excursion, even for someone who has ridden shotgun in a yellow submarine, designed his own postage stamps and been recorded eating vegetables by both the Beach Boys and Super Furry Animals. I dont really know that much about it yet, Mr. McCartney said. Im just writing music for it, but its a switch.

title: Putting Sandra Lees Lasagna to the Test
description: On Tuesday, the Food Network star Sandra Lees cooking  specifically her lasagna  took a public knock from her possible future mother-in-law, Matilda Cuomo, mother of the New York State attorney general and Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Cuomo.

title: A Realist Among Fans of South Africa
description: Alexandra, South Africa

title: Selling Paradise to the People
description: Want to get away? No problem. Take a plane, train, bus or car to some distant place and youll find the serenity that eludes you in daily life. Or so the tourist industry would have you believe.

title: Gay, Female and Overworked Like Everyone Else
description: The old joke surfaces early on The Real L Word. What does a lesbian bring on a second date? The punch line: A U-Haul. The L Word, which has inspired this new series, spent its five-year tenure on Showtime tirelessly working to upend the perceptions that underlie such bons mots: that lesbians mate like penguins, for life, with comparatively less vigorous libidos and healthier bean dishes.

title: Rachel Comey Buys SoHo Loft
description: FOR certain hip young things, the name Rachel Comey might evoke images of a fabulous pair of boots or a chic librarian. For those of us who frequent the Gap, she may be unfamiliar. But we can learn!

title: Readers Photos: Space Shuttle Launchings
description: A selection of photos submitted by readers and chosen by Times Travel editors.

title: Budget Boutiques in New York City
description: Six highly designed hotels, many rolled out by chains, offer wallet-friendly rates.

title: Affordable Boutique Hotels in New York City
description: FINDING a decent place to sleep in New York City has never been easy. Traditionally, you either had to spend a ton of money (the Ty Warner Penthouse at the Four Seasons for $35,000 a night, anyone?) or scrimp and hope for the best (warning: a recent search for bed bugs on TripAdvisor found 877 mentions for city hotels).

title: British Directors Will Oversee 2012 Olympics Ceremonies
description: Short of a feel-good movie about young Scottish heroin addicts who aspire to become ballet dancers, the 2012 Summer Olympics have found a more constructive way to bring the filmmakers Danny Boyle and Stephen Daldry together. Mr. Boyle, the Trainspotting director (who also won an Academy Award for Slumdog Millionaire), and Mr. Daldry, whose films include Billy Elliot, will be the creative heads of the London games, The Guardian reported. At an announcement ceremony on Thursday, the 2012 Olympic Organizing Committee said that Mr. Daldry would be the overall creative director of ceremonies while Mr. Boyle would be the artistic director of the opening ceremony, which is scheduled for July 27, 2012. The Guardian said that the directors would have a total of 40 million (about $59 million) to present four ceremonies during the 2012 games, presumably a little more than Mr. Daldry had to play with as director of Billy Elliot: The Musical.

title: N.Y.U. Shows Plan For Tower
description: The controversial 38-story tower that New York University seeks to add to its University Village complex in Greenwich Village would be made of concrete with floor-to-ceiling windows on the Bleecker Street side, according to plans, above, made public Thursday by the university. The design by Grimshaw Architects, published in The Wall Street Journal, calls for a 240-room hotel in the bottom 15 floors for visiting professors and university guests that would also be available to the public. The top floors would be for faculty housing. Opponents of the tower, show above in a rendering as seen from Houston and Greene Streets, have objected to adding a fourth building to the original three-tower modernist design by the architect I. M. Pei. The University Village site received landmark status in 2008. As a result, the universitys plans must be approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. On Monday the university is scheduled to make a preliminary presentation to the local community board. The building is part of a plan to add six million square feet of classrooms, dormitories and offices over the next 20 years on the core campus and at locations like Governors Island, downtown Brooklyn and the East Side of Manhattan.

title: The Octoroon Director Withdraws
description: The director Gavin Quinn, a founder of the Irish theater troupe Pan Pan, has withdrawn from the coming Off Broadway production of The Octoroon: An Adaptation of The Octoroon Based on The Octoroon after creative disagreements with the plays author, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins. Vallejo Gantner, the artistic director of the New York theater company Performance Space 122, which is producing the show, said in an interview on Thursday that the two artists agreed that Mr. Quinn would withdraw from the project because each of them had different visions. Sometimes collaborations dont work out, and this is one of those times, Mr. Gantner said. Mr. Quinns production of The Crumb Trail at P.S. 122 drew acclaim last year. Neither he nor Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins could immediately be reached for comment. Mr. Jacobs-Jenkinss most recent production was Neighbors, which drew attention for its use of blackface and minstrelsy when the work was presented this winter in the Public Theater Lab series. He will now direct The Octoroon, which is described by P.S. 122 as a bombastic, supertheatrical, full-scale investigation of the intersection of theater and identity politics involving The Octoroon, a 19th-century melodrama by the Irish playwright Dion Boucicault about the residents of a Louisiana plantation and a mixed-race romance. Performances are to begin on Saturday, three days later than originally planned, to give the cast more time to work on the production. The play is scheduled to run through July 3.

title: Mommy Dearest, Youre Mine Forever
description: In Cyrus, a creepy-funny comedy about man and boy love  not for each other  the actor Jonah Hill enters with a polite smile that is likely to send a chill straight up your neck, leaving your little hairs aflutter. As the title character, a 21-year-old man-child with a manic stare, an endless supply of neatly laundered button-down shirts and a seriously unhealthy attachment to his mother, he looks like the kind of guy who has been setting fire to the neighborhood cats, the one everyone says seemed so nice after the cops dig up the bodies. Best known for playing testy smart alecks in comedies like Superbad, Mr. Hill taps the spirit of Norman Bates so well he quickly pushes this comedy into horror.

title: Rethinking the Whiteboard
description: WhiteyBoard  maker of stick-on-the-wall whiteboards  has obtained approximately $500,000 in seed funding, the companys founders announced today. Bill Liao, who is best known as a founder of Xing.com, the dominant social network for business professionals in Europe, led the investment. He has taken eight companies public and is the author of Stone Soup: The Secret Recipe for Making Something From Nothing.

title: Resort Report | Reed Krakoff
description: For pre-spring, Reed Krakoff showed muted colors, architectural shapes and a great pair of riding boots with a mesh top half  perfect for warmer weather! His silhouette reflects the new minimalism with looser, sometimes boxy shapes, sports references and an art-gallery-cool sophistication. There was a surprising apron dress in tan leather that was so simple yet so flattering. His first eponymous store will open this August in New York and then Tokyo in the fall, so these clothes will be some of the first to hit the streets. They will look right at home in those cities.

title: A Clear Day Is Born Again in New Concert Production
description: Brian dArcy James and Anika Noni Rose will be among the stars of a reimagined  or should we say reincarnated?  version of On a Clear Day You Can See Forever that Michael Mayer will direct this summer at Powerhouse Theater, the Poughkeepsie collaboration between Vassar College and New York Stage and Film. The concert workshop of that Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, whose cast will also include David Turner, Kerry OMalley, Colin Hanlon and Sarah Stiles, will feature many changes from its stage and film versions. But what kind, exactly? Mr. Mayer isnt ready to say. Im really not trying to be coy, but I dont want to overexplain it, said Mr. Mayer, the Tony Award-winning director of Spring Awakening, in a telephone interview. He added: By playing a little bit with gender, I thought I could make a different kind of love triangle at the center of it. Thats the goal. The Powerhouse Theater production of On a Clear Day will run from July 29 through Aug. 1.

title: Race For Oxford Poetry Position Now Brings Out the Verse
description: Taking a page from barb-tossing rhymers like Eminem, Lil Wayne and M.I.A.  not to mention the original diss track artist, M.C. Geoffrey Chaucer  the standing candidates for Oxford Universitys professor of poetry have begun to malign one another in verse. The mudslinging started earlier this week when Michael Horovitz, the Beat poet and one of 10 remaining contenders for the Oxford post, criticized an essay by a fellow candidate, Roger Lewis, that was published in The Telegraph newspaper. Perhaps sensing an opportunity for a bit of mischief  and to promote his own candidacy for the Oxford position  Michael George Gibson has insinuated himself into the debate with a letter to The Telegraph, a copy of which was also sent to The New York Times. With a poem of his own, Mr. Gibson writes of Mr. Lewis:That Ox.Prof.Po.Candidate, Roger,Is a diss-all-his-rivals old codgerWhose Telegraph prose-hymnProsodically shows himA My Favo rite-Things silly splodger. Mr. Lewis has not responded to either of his rivals. Oxford is to announce the election results on Friday.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Shangri-La in Santa Monica, Calif.
description: THE BASICS

title: To Stage a Spoof Is Human. To Run and Run? Divine.
description: WHEN the musical Nunsense, about the singing, dancing, double-entendre-wielding Little Sisters of Hoboken, opened Off Broadway at the Cherry Lane Theater in 1985, it was a somewhat risky venture. When the curtain goes up on Sunday  same show, same theater  it arrives as the flagship of a comic mini-empire that shows little sign of slowing down.

title: Rodriguez Is D.H.; Posada Sits
description: The rules say you can only have one designated hitter in your lineup. So Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had to make a choice between Alex Rodriguez and Jorge Posada, his two aching veterans, for Thursday nights game against Philadelphia.

title: Metropolitan Opera Says Assets Fell 38% Last Year
description: The Metropolitan Operas net assets declined 38 percent in the last fiscal year, according to its most recent financial statements, largely because of stock market losses and a decline in new donations. But officials said they were encouraged by rising attendance figures at performances.

title: Alicia Keys Selling Long Island House
description: THE musician and actress Alicia Keys has accumulated a few awards in her 29 years. Actually, shes got a ton of them, including 12 Grammy awards, 11 Billboard Music awards, 3 BET awards and 3 MTV Video Music awards. (Who else feels unaccomplished today?)

title: Worlds of Movement Collide in One Space
description: WASHINGTON  The audiences thronging the Opera House at the Kennedy Center this week for the return of Ballet Across America (the first was in 2008) include a high number of dance practitioners. With nine companies participating, those not dancing tend to watch one anothers performances. Meanwhile the Dance USA conference has brought more leading figures. Intermissions are thoroughly buzzy.

title: Adoring Throngs for 80s Rock Revival
description: Matt Berninger, the lead singer of the National, got to play rock star at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. He shook outstretched hands and repeatedly walked into the audience as he sang  even, for one encore, ascending the halls catwalk into the balcony  while the obliging fans held up the long, long cord on his old-fashioned, nonwireless microphone. It was a show of closeness and confidence that nicely contradicted what he sang: thoughts of isolation and estrangement, of fear and anxiety: I dont know what to do/in my best clothes. Often the crowd was singing along.

title: Israels Ultra-Orthodox Protest Schools Ruling
description: JERUSALEM  Tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews took to the streets of this city on Thursday to accompany dozens of Hasidic parents who were on their way to prison for two weeks after refusing to comply with a Supreme Court ruling against ethnic segregation in their childrens school.

title: Where Composers Lend Their Voices
description: The American Composers Alliance, founded in 1937 by Aaron Copland and others, publishes new scores, maintains an important archive of American music and provides other forms of support for composers and new music. But its public face is the annual festival it has presented at Symphony Space since 2000: a lively, dogma-free celebration of mostly recent work by composers old and young.

title: Should Parents Be Jailed When Kids Drink?
description: Its graduation party season, which means social host laws that hold parents responsible for teenage drinking are back in the news. Last week, two Harvard Medical School professors were arrested because teenagers were found drinking at their daughters graduation party, though they said they did not see the alcohol.

title: A Determined Ballerina, Propelled to the Top
description: THE Bolshoi ballerina Natalia Osipova smiled brightly, theatrically, projecting outward as she danced the solo that Princess Aurora performs moments after arriving on stage in Act I of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: 2011 Infiniti M37 and M56
description: The new Ms solid foundation in chassis, engines and handling comes into sharper focus.

title: Marching in the War on Gay Marriage
description: Reed Cowans polemical film 8: The Mormon Proposition examines the successful campaign against gay marriage in California that was heavily financed by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which is implacably opposed to homosexuality. The highly emotional documentary is narrated by Dustin Lance Black, the screenwriter for Milk, who, like Mr. Cowan, is gay and grew up in a Mormon household.

title: Goalkeeping Is Not Only Question for Embattled England Coach
description: Whether to start the gaffe-prone goalkeeper Robert Green is only one of the questions facing Manager Fabio Capello ahead of Englands match against Algeria in Cape Town on Friday. In his final day of preparations, Capello faced a storm of criticism at home, questions over an injury-depleted defense and even some crafty psychological warfare from the Algerians.

title: Panel Demands NASA Documents to Support Budget
description: Annoyed that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been slow to explain how it plans to overhaul the human space-flight program, a Congressional committee is demanding that the agency provide a host of records related to its budget request for 2011.

title: Your Fathers Keeper
description: I spend time with my parents in social situations that include people outside our family. My mother, who has been married to my father for over 40 years, has a habit of subtly maligning him with every sentence: Sorry were out of mustard. Someone forgot to go to the market  again. (It gets much worse.) Its painful to watch her cut my lovely father down, but I doubt shell change her ways. Is there anything I can say, in the moment, to bring a temporary stop to it?

title: From Tapestried Villa to Sylvan Glade, Aristocratic Women in Love
description: Amid all the luxuries on display in the Italian film I Am Love  the chandeliers, tapestries and paneled walls, the paintings, statuary and white-gloved servants  nothing holds your gaze as forcefully as Tilda Swintons alabaster face. The first time you see that vision, her character, Emma Recchi, a Russian whos married into a wealthy Milanese family, is stage-managing the lavish birthday party that opens the film. By the end of this often soaringly beautiful melodrama, which closes with a funeral, Emmas face will have crumpled into a ruin. But it will also be fully alive, having been granted, like Pygmalions statue, the breath of life.

title: World Cup Replay: Day 7, June 17
description: Argentina had reason to celebrate after a 4-1 victory over South Korea, while Greece defeated Nigeria, 2-1.

title: Media Decoder: MySpace Co-President Leaving Company
description: Barely four months after becoming a co-president of MySpace, Jason Hirschhorn is leaving the company, writes Brian Stelter on Media Decoder.

title: Is Technology Unhinging Our Brains?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Summer Tour for Simon and Garfunkel
description: Simon and Garfunkels summer tour of the United States and Canada, already postponed once because of Art Garfunkels vocal strain, has now been put off indefinitely. A statement posted on the groups Web site says Mr. Garfunkel is recovering from vocal paresis. That condition inhibits the duo from performing shows at the highest possible level, the statement says, and it is for that reason and out of respect for their fans that Paul and Art have decided to put the tour on hold.

title: Assessing Who Should Pay for the Oil Spill Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: Surfin Safari
description: A nomadic Californian surfer once took a wrong turn somewhere in Europe and ended up at the Berlin Wall. His faithful board still slung across his back like a guitar, he gazed up at one of the border guards, ensconced in a tower behind a machine gun and miles of barbed wire, and yelled out, Man, you are bummed, because you will never know what true surfing really is! That ringing indictment of totalitarianism  reported in a 1980s issue of Surfer magazine  turns out to be wrong. In Michael Scott Moores clued-in and far-flung Sweetness and Blood, the border guard, so to speak, exchanges his military uniform for baggy shorts and a rash vest. The surfer who came in from the cold. Trabants out, woodies in.

title: The Pulp Inside Him as It Turns to Rot
description: Around here, if youre not a man and a gentleman, youre nothing, says Lou Ford, the protagonist of The Killer Inside Me. A murderous sociopath, cowardly and cold and particularly brutal toward women, Lou is in effect introducing the tale of his own self-annihilation. On the surface a polite, upstanding fellow  a sheriffs deputy with fine manners and a clean white shirt  Lou guides us on a grisly tour of the abyss that is his soul.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Pop

title: Rodriguez Is Installed as D.H., Leaving Posada as the Odd Man Out
description: The Yankees have two ailing sluggers whose bats Manager Joe Girardi would surely like to keep in the lineup. Unfortunately for him, he only has one place to put them.

title: Day 58: The Latest on the Oil Spill
description: BP Chief Testifies Before Congress

title: Colombian Coal Mine Blast Kills at Least 18
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  An explosion at a coal mine in northwest Colombia killed at least 18 miners, and dozens more trapped inside were feared dead, Colombian rescue officials said Thursday. The officials said the death toll could reach more than 70 when all the bodies were recovered.

title: Former Phenom Hopes to Repair His Career
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Eight years after making his first million, the golfer Ty Tryon got his first regular job.

title: Womens Rights, Then
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Recommends Approval of After-Sex Pill to Prevent Pregnancy
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  A federal advisory panel voted unanimously Thursday that federal drug regulators should approve a medicine that could help prevent pregnancy if taken as late as five days after unprotected sex.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: You Have Issues? So Does Everybody
description: The personal is political in the films of Agns Jaoui, a sort of Gallic Woody Allen whose comedies of manners reveal a sensibility acutely attuned to the tiniest nuances of the mind games people play. Ms. Jaouis films may lack Mr. Allens comic shtick, quotable one-liners and showy metaphysical angst, but they are precisely calibrated dissections of the pretensions and insecurities of the French chattering class. As critical as she can be of her characters, Ms. Jaoui portrays them with the evenhanded sympathy of a wise therapist who likes her clients despite their annoying foibles.

title: Tale of a Bounty Hunter
description: Jonah Hex, the titular tough guy of the enjoyable neo-B-movie of the same title, is so unforgiving that he doesnt kill a man once  he brings one unlucky victim back from the dead just so he can kill him again.

title: Lockheed in Talks to Reduce Price of F-35 Planes by 20%
description: WASHINGTON  Lockheed Martin is negotiating to cut the price for the next group of its new F-35 fighter planes to at least 20 percent less than Pentagon officials projected last fall, Robert J. Stevens, the chief executive, said Thursday.

title: Slovenes Hold U.S. in High Regard
description: Slovenia has never played the United States in soccer, but that does not mean there is no mutual awareness heading into their game Friday.

title: Seeking Excitement in Jamaica
description: Horizons are expanded and exoticism explored in Wah Do Dem, a shaggy road movie about relinquishing your comforts to find your bliss. Our halfhearted traveler is Max (Sean Bones, drifting rather than acting), a Brooklyn musician reconciling two tickets for a Caribbean cruise and a last-minute kiss-off from his unrepentant girlfriend (a minuscule cameo by Norah Jones).

title: Students Gain After Strike in Puerto Rico
description: MIAMI  Thousands of students at the University of Puerto Rico who went on strike two months ago to oppose severe budget cuts declared victory on Thursday after reaching an agreement with administrators.

title: Letter: Questions for Christopher Hitchens
description: Not that a man as intelligent, worldly, honest and entertaining as Hitchens needs the likes of me to defend him  he has made a career out of giving as good as he gets  but the tone that Deborah Solomon took in her interview with him was churlish and disrespectful.

title: Up Front: Jennifer Senior
description: In her cover review of Christopher Hitchenss memoir, Hitch-22, Jennifer Senior admits she was hoping for more self-disclosure from the author.

title: Do I Contradict Myself?
description: If anyone in this world is positioned to write a toothsome memoir, its Christopher Hitchens. Hes gone from international socialist to Iraq war enthusiast; he has a moving personal story and is a pasha of vice. His present solar system of intimates includes James Fenton and Salman Rushdie and Ian McEwan; his past included Susan Sontag and Edward Said (both deceased) and Gore Vidal (still alive, but banished to a growing Kuiper belt of discards and debris). Hes gone to a New York brothel with Martin Amis and delivered bluejeans to Polish dissidents; hes gotten smacked on the tush by Margaret Thatcher and beaten up by thugs in Beirut. He argues ruthlessly and writes like a drunken angel, making targets of subjects as various as Mother Teresa, Henry Kissinger, the Clintons and God. (In 2007, he published the best seller God Is Not Great  a title Rushdie ruefully deemed one word too long.)

title: In Kyrgyzstan, Failure to Act Adds to Crisis
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyzstan, an obscure country with a coveted location in Central Asia, is in serious danger of fragmenting. The crisis here, ebbing for now after days of ethnic violence and military atrocities, could have ramifications all the way to Washington.

title: A Second Chance for Joshua
description: Two Republican senators find the memos that Elena Kagan wrote as a Supreme Court law clerk to be mysteriously troubling. Truth be told, reporters on the Kagan beat have found the memos troubling as well, due to an almost complete absence of news value that has left journalists scrambling to construct articles from the thousands of pages of Kagan-related documents pouring forth in the run-up to the Senate confirmation hearing that begins a week from Monday.

title: Court Grants Bail and Frees American Lawyer in Rwanda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Peter Erlinder, the American lawyer jailed in Rwanda after being accused of denying the countrys genocide, was released Thursday on bail amid growing international pressure, allowing him to leave Rwanda, possibly for good.

title: As Strikeouts Go Down, Wrights R.B.I. Go Up
description: CLEVELAND  There was a time this season when David Wright was leading the league in one category he did not care to be involved in at all, and was nowhere near the top in a category that is very important to him.

title: Asking Big Questions
description: Roger Nygards documentary The Nature of Existence is an extreme example of ADD filmmaking. Religious leaders, gurus, shamans, scientists, philosophers, waitresses and cab drivers flash by, giving quotable answers to Mr. Nygards big questions: Why do we exist? Is there a God? Is masturbation a sin?

title: Lakers Defeat Celtics in Game 7
description: After playing from behind for most of Game 7, the Los Angeles Lakers surged past the Boston Celtics in the final minutes to capture their 16th N.B.A. Championship.

title: Justices Debate Issues in an Oceanfront Case
description: WASHINGTON  A project to restore eroded beaches in the Florida Panhandle did not violate the Constitutions takings clause even though the state claimed ownership of the strip of land the project created next to the ocean, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.

title: Hijacking Their Way Out of Tyranny
description: LATE one summer night 40 years ago this month, Yosef Mendelevich, a young Soviet Jew, camped with a group of friends outside the Smolny airport near Leningrad. The next morning, they planned to commandeer a 12-seat airplane, fly it to Sweden and, once there, declare their purpose: to move to Israel, a dream they had long been denied.

title: Doctors Group Fights a Bill That Would Ease Restrictions on Midwives
description: Amy Paulin, now a New York State assemblywoman pushing for more independence for midwives, was 27 when she became pregnant with her first child and started doctor-shopping in New York City.

title: Known Faces Are Displacing the Amateurs in Online Videos
description: Just as the unknowns who showed up on screen in the early days of television gave way to radio and movie stars like Jack Benny and Bob Hope, more famous faces are supplanting everyday people in Web series, particularly when the video clips are sponsored by advertisers.

title: Feinberg to Visit 2 Gulf Governors  on Friday
description: Two days after President Obama put him in charge of a $20 billion fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill, Kenneth R. Feinberg will fly on Friday to meet with the governors of Mississippi and Louisiana.

title: Spill May Have Taken Its Largest Victim Yet
description: Over the last weeks, the carcasses of oily pelicans, turtles and other animals have washed to shore in the Gulf of Mexico. Now the first dead whale has been found  a juvenile sperm whale floating 77 miles from the leaking oil well.

title: An Indian Epic With Bollywood Glamour
description: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: He Shoots, He Scores. Why Quibble?
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Republican Backpedals From Apology to BP
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Joe L. Barton had to be truly sorry by the time he apologized for his apology on Thursday.

title: Worlds Mining Companies Covet Afghan Riches
description: WASHINGTON  Mining companies around the world are eager to exploit Afghanistans newly discovered mineral wealth, but executives of Western firms caution that war, corruption and lack of roads and other infrastructure are likely to delay exploration for years.

title: Making Their Own National Noise, but Losing Anyway
description: Much has been made of the vuvuzelas, whose buzzy drone has been the soundtrack of the World Cup games being played in South Africas stadiums.

title: Staten Island Church Reconsiders Deal to Sell Vacant Convent for Use as a Mosque
description: A plan to sell a Roman Catholic convent on Staten Island to a Muslim group for use as a mosque is faltering in the face of community opposition.

title: Trim the Experts, Trust the Locals
description: On Tuesday, The Times ran a front-page article on the chaotic efforts to clean up the oil washing around the Gulf of Mexico. Campbell Robertson reported on an incident in which boats that were supposed to be laying boom were, in fact, anchored on the wrong side of a bay in Louisiana. They were helpless as oil oozed in from the gulf, and BP had no way of contacting the workers to get the boats moving.

title: Deal to Save Student Transit Discounts Is Near
description: Students are likely to keep the discounted fares they pay to ride New York Citys buses and subways, with legislators and transit officials close to an agreement on Thursday to save the service.

title: Cooper Becomes Loud Voice for Gulf Residents
description: There arent any small people here, the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper said from Louisiana on his prime-time program Wednesday night, emphatically rejecting the remarks by BPs chairman that the oil company cares about the small people.

title: Dusting Off a 150-Year-Old Ode to the Citys Favorite Samurai
description: From an ornate balcony above a ballroom on the East Side of Manhattan, a nine-piece string ensemble played a sprightly number Wednesday evening for the benefit of several dozen people who stood below. None had heard the two-minute piece before. How could they have? Tommy Polka, as it was called, had not been played in public for 150 years.

title: Federal Judge Rejects Terrorism Suspects Plea to Halt His Strip-Searches
description: A federal judge has refused to order the Bureau of Prisons to stop conducting strip-searches of a former detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who is now jailed in Manhattan awaiting trial in a terrorism case.

title: That 30s Feeling
description: BERLIN

title: Seventy Years Later, Churchills Finest Hour Yields Insights
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  Historians have called it one of the greatest speeches ever delivered in English, and surely one of the greatest ever delivered by an Englishman, at a moment of national peril unparalleled in modern times.

title: Man Accused of Stealing Sewer Firm From Widow
description: A Queens man was charged on Thursday with fraudulently taking over a sewer-cleaning company from a widow while she was in Israel burying her husband and son.

title: Canada: Inquiry Into 1985 Attack Cites Flaws in Antiterror Preparedness
description: A commission that investigated a 1985 airplane bombing that killed 329 people criticized the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the government and the intelligence service on Thursday for failing to prevent the attack. John C. Major, the former Supreme Court justice who headed the investigation of the Air India bombing, Canadas deadliest terrorist attack, said that the series of failures was inexcusable and suggested that the episode could have been prevented with better coordination between agencies. Justice Major said that Canadas air security and intelligence systems were still flawed with regard to handling terrorism.

title: Iceland: Bobby Fischers Estate Dispute
description: The Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered that the body of the former American chess champion Bobby Fischer be exhumed so that a paternity test could be performed to see if he is the father of a 9-year-old Filipino girl. The order is part of a fight over his estate, which is reportedly worth about $2 million. Mr. Fischer died in Iceland in 2008. Other claims have been filed on the estate by Miyoko Watai, a Japanese chess official, who said she is Mr. Fischers wife, two nephews of Mr. Fischers and the United States, which says he owed back taxes.

title: For Finalists, Tough Calls the Morning After
description: LOS ANGELES  After the Champagne celebration comes the hangover, a blurry, throbbing aftermath of doubt and reflection.

title: Afghan Mineral Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Somalia: U.S. Military Aid Denounced
description: A second United States senator complained Thursday about American military assistance to Somalias government, which the United Nations considers one of the most flagrant users of child soldiers in the world. Senator Russ Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in a letter to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton that the American government should press the Somali military to halt any use of child soldiers and until we have that confirmation, I believe it is inappropriate to continue providing the T.F.G. with security assistance. American officials said they have urged the Somali military not to recruit children but that with few American personnel in Somalia, it is impossible to guarantee this does not happen.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Business School Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonprofit Advocate Carves Out a For-Profit Niche
description: Speaking on behalf of the Center for Consumer Freedom, Richard B. Berman takes no prisoners.

title: In Coney Island, Where Old and New and Weird Rub Elbows
description: About noon on Surf Avenue in Coney Island on Thursday, three hot dogs walked down the street.

title: 14 Stores Accused of Selling Illegal Knives
description: At least 14 retail stores in Manhattan  including major retailers like the Home Depot, Eastern Mountain Sports and Paragon Sports  have been selling illegal knives, District Attorney Cyrus R. Vance Jr. said on Thursday.

title: State Party in S. Carolina Rejects Bid for New Vote
description: In this age of candidate Twitter accounts and robocalls, the surprising victory in a South Carolina Democratic primary by Alvin M. Greene, 32, an unknown candidate without so much as a Web site, harks back to another era.

title: No Stranger to the Devils, MacLean Is Hired as Coach
description: NEWARK  Two bald men in navy suits and blue ties, one old enough to be the others father, strode to a podium together Thursday at Prudential Center and sat at a table. The older man, Lou Lamoriello, the Devils general manager, had another new coach to introduce.

title: Turks Put Twist in Racy Soaps
description: ISTANBUL  A topless hunk lights candles in the bedroom.

title: Common Sense and Private Property
description: Not a single Supreme Court justice agreed with the harebrained notion that some Florida property owners were entitled to the extra land created when the state widened the beach in front of their houses.

title: Loopholes Grow in Bill to Offset Ruling on Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats are pushing hard for legislation to rein in the power of special interests by requiring more disclosure of their roles in paying for campaign advertising  but as they struggle to find the votes they need to pass it they are carving out loopholes for, yes, special interests.

title: Finish the Job, Albany
description: Hard as it may be to imagine, New York legislators have actually managed to agree to about half of the states $135 billion annual budget through Gov. David Patersons tactic of attaching parts of it to the weekly emergency-spending measures that are keeping the state government from shutting down.

title: Two Children Are Killed in a Queens House Fire
description: A fire that started in a rear bedroom and engulfed a two-story house in Queens killed two young brothers on Thursday morning, officials said.

title: A Bad Day for BP and Mr. Barton
description: Its hard to imagine anyone having a worse day than Tony Hayward, BPs embattled chief executive, who spent Thursday in the cross hairs of an angry Congressional committee and turned in a mind-bogglingly vapid performance. But he got a run for his money from Representative Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, who inexplicably decided to call the escrow account agreed to by BP and the White House a $20 billion shakedown.

title: Vogues Publisher Is Leaving Cond Nast
description: The publisher who oversaw Vogue through some of its most robust times  and issues  said Thursday that he was leaving Cond Nast after nearly 25 years.

title: That Cheats the Kids
description: The parents of children attending George Washington Elementary School in Baltimore were understandably outraged when they learned last month that someone at the school had altered thousands of answers on students 2008 state math and reading tests to raise their scores. Following a lengthy investigation, state education officials did exactly the right thing. They revoked the principals state teaching license and made clear that educators elsewhere could expect the same if they tampered with test results.

title: Senate Stalemate Persists on Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats failed Thursday night to break a partisan impasse over a major package of tax changes and safety-net spending, leaving the future of added unemployment benefits and a series of business tax breaks up in the air.

title: Twisting Arms at BP, Obama Sets Off a Debate on Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  First there was General Motors, whose chief executive was summarily dismissed by the White House shortly before the government became the companys majority shareholder. Chrysler was forced into a merger. At the banks that received government bailouts, executive pay was curbed; at insurance companies seeking to jack up premiums, scathing criticism led to rollbacks.

title: Torn by Violence, Vendors Unite to Rebuild Market
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  For some visitors, it was the rainbow of fruits and vegetables or the aroma of spices that drew them to the big bazaar in Osh. Kanyshai Jusupova came for the fresh-baked flatbread. And she said it did not matter who was behind the counter.

title: Mexico Court Clears Officials in 2009 Fire at Care Center
description: MEXICO CITY  For more than a year, the parents of 49 children killed in a fire at a day care center have managed to keep public attention on the case. The case was back in the news on Thursday, after a Supreme Court ruling that was a blow to many of the parents.

title: Bloggingheads: America's Soccer Problem
description: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Daily Beast and Stephen Spruiell of National Review debate why Americans haven't embraced soccer.

title: For U.S., Slovenia Stands in Way of Bigger Things
description: JOHANNESBURG  At least four American cities have larger populations than the nation of Slovenia, the United States opponent Friday in the teams second match in the group stage of the World Cup.

title: Sale of Property Positioned Queens Pastor to Gain
description: For 25 years, the Rev. Floyd H. Flakes Greater Allen African Methodist Episcopal Cathedral of New York successfully ran a 300-unit apartment complex for the elderly in southeastern Queens.

title: More New Jersey Towns Force Big School Cuts
description: About 17 percent of the New Jersey school districts that had budgets rejected by voters this spring have been ordered by town councils to make cuts to lower their proposed school taxes by at least 3 percent, according to an analysis by The New York Times of state education data released on Thursday.

title: The Deal to Buy a Queens Housing Project
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake and his partners used public money to buy control of a lucrative Queens housing project in 2006.

title: Judge Rejects Many Claims in 9/11 Cases
description: A federal judge in Manhattan who was criticized by families of victims of 9/11 for taking too long to decide motions in lawsuits they had filed has handed down a ruling dismissing claims made against many of the defendants.

title: Robert B. Radnitz, Producer of Sounder, Dies at 85
description: Robert B. Radnitz, a producer of family moviesincluding Sounder and Where the Lilies Bloom and who was praised for not playing down to his audience or filling the screen with violence, died on June 6 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 85.

title: Suspect in Times Sq. Bomb Attempt Is Indicted
description: Faisal Shahzad, the Pakistani immigrant charged in the failed Times Square bombing plot, was indicted on Thursday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan, the government said.

title: Master of the Mets Domain
description: Every Fathers Day, dads get barbecues, neckties and golf tchotchkes. Then there is the gift Jerry Seinfeld will get this year.

title: Rapper/Actor Woolard
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  My solve got off to an inauspicious start today. Wading in at the end of the Down clues and then working my way up, my first thought was, Oh no, a puzzle with a lot of stuff I dont know!

title: Inquiry Aimed at Transfer of Aqueduct Bid Papers
description: The state inspector general is investigating whether a senator or Senate staff member gave internal documents regarding the competition for a slot-machine franchise at Aqueduct Racetrack to a lobbyist for one of the bidders, an official with knowledge of the investigation said Thursday.

title: Mind and Matter: Alternative Abstractions, 1940s to Now
description: Museum of Modern Art

title: Jim Nutt: Trim and Other Works: 1967-2010
description: David Nolan Gallery

title: Kelli Williams: Scala Naturae
description: Leo Koenig

title: Richard Wilson and the British Arcadia
Amy Gartrell: Whatever and Ever
description: Daniel Reich Gallery

title: Drill Ban Means Hard Times for Rig Workers
description: In addition to the fishermen and hoteliers whose livelihoods have been devastated by BPs hemorrhaging undersea oil well, another group of Gulf Coast residents is beginning to suffer: the tens of thousands of workers like Ronald Brown who run the equipment or serve in support roles on deepwater oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Looking for Answers, Finding One
description: WASHINGTON  On the 58th day, an outraged nation summoned the man it holds responsible for one of the worst environmental disasters in American history. He walked through the oversize wooden doors, shed the protective cocoon of his dark-suited entourage and took his place at a long table.

title: Elzbieta Czyzewska, Polish Actress Unwelcome in Her Own Country, Dies at 72
description: Elzbieta Czyzewska, a star of Polish movies and television in the 1960s whose marriage to the American journalist David Halberstam made her an outcast in her home country, and whose career frustrations in the United States became a cautionary tale for immigrant artists, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 72.

title: Keeping Score: Luck Is Likely to Catch Up to Jimenez
description: When Ubaldo Jimenez allowed three earned runs in a rain-shortened, six-inning victory against the Blue Jays last Friday, it was by far his worst outing of the season. Once upon a time, a pitcher would have considered himself fortunate to escape Coors Field with a performance like that, but for Jimenez, the Rockies 26-year-old ace, it was a blemish that raised his earned run average above 1.00 for the first time in nearly two months.

title: Nonprofits Paying a For-Profit Firm
description: Six nonprofits provide as much as 70 percent of revenues for Berman and Company. Many of the groups board members are current and former employees of the company.

title: Former Police Commander Denies Abuse
description: CHICAGO  For almost three decades, allegations of brutality have swirled around Jon Burge, dogging him through his last years as a police commander all the way to his retirement in a beach town near Tampa, Fla. For all that time, some here have called for Mr. Burge to publicly answer, under oath, charges that he routinely tortured confessions out of suspects who were largely poor black men from the South Side.

title: Heads Found in 3 Boxes Set for Flight
description: A Southwest Airlines cargo worker last week opened three suspicious boxes at Little Rock National Airport and found 45 human heads, bound for a medical laboratory in Fort Worth. The heads were to be used to help train neurosurgeons.

title: After Round 1, a Big Crowd in the Mid-70s
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Sometimes its hard to tell what a good score is during the first round of the United States Open, although anything close to par usually qualifies. But Thursday, more than a third of the field posted scores from two-over 73 to four-over 75.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Toyotas Image Falls in J.D. Power Survey
description: A new consumer survey shows that Toyota has paid dearly among car owners for its recalls over accelerator pedal problems.

title: 2010 Mets Are Starting to Resemble 2005 Yanks
description: The Mets never work in a vacuum. Everything they do is measured against the Yankees, fairly or not. Sometimes the comparisons are unflattering.

title: Nuclear Agency Weighs a Plan to Dilute Waste
description: BETHESDA, Md.  A competition between nuclear waste dumps has pulled the Nuclear Regulatory Commission into an unusual reconsideration of its rules to allow moderately radioactive materials to be diluted into a milder category that is easier to bury.

title: Against the Phillies, the Yankees Offensive Spigot Is Quickly Shut Off
description: The Yankees have feasted in recent weeks on some of the leagues worst pitching staffs. Then the Philadelphia Phillies came to town, and with them came an offensive famine for the home team.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: SUMMER SOLSTICE CELEBRATION June 22, 1633, did not go well for Galileo Galilei. On that day, the summer solstice, the Inquisition forced him to renounce his theories of a Sun-centered planetary system. What a difference a few centuries make. Galileo would no doubt be gratified that on June 20, 2010, in honor of the solstice, a major scientific institution is offering a festival that builds on his work. Thats the American Museum of Natural History, whose Summer Solstice Celebration (the actual solstice is Monday) promises to bring light to any benighted minds  particularly childrens  who might underestimate the Suns importance. Youd be surprised at how many people think the Sun is moving around the Earth, said Suzanne Morris, the museums associate manager of public programs. Theres no chance of making that mistake at the festival, which will include an inflatable planetarium in which museum educators will hold demonstrations illustrating the Earths motion and explaining the summer solstice, which occurs when the tilt of the Earths axis maximizes the hours of daylight. Families can look at the Sun safely through a solar telescope and examine it indirectly (above, right) with a device to observe sunspots. It reflects an image of the Sun onto a piece of paper, so you can see the contrast, Ms. Morris said. In a nod to the Suns cultural importance, the Rose Center for Earth and Space will host an ancient solstice ceremony by members of the Kichwa Nation, a group representing the Andean peoples. Activity stations will demonstrate the Suns power. In what might be called cool chemical reactions, children can make solar prints (images created with chemically treated paper and sunlight) and UV bead bracelets, which turn from white to colored in sunshine. To emphasize that energy is possible without batteries and electric cords, Ms. Morris said, the Arthur Ross Terrace will become a mini Indy 500 for racing solar-powered model cars. She acknowledged that the Sun can be a temperamental guest of honor. Indoor activities, like making Sun models from clay, will take place regardless of weather. And young visitors should come away knowing that whether or not it shows its face, the Sun is undeniably a star. (Sunday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., Rose Center, 81st Street and Central Park West, 212-769-5200, amnh.org. Free with suggested museum admission: $16; $12 for ages 62+ and students; $9 for 2 to 12; free for under 2 and members.) LAUREL GRAEBER

Her white hair was gathered at the nape of her neck, and her voice was low. Please help me get Jeffs pacemaker turned off, she said, using my fathers first name. I nodded, and my heart knocked.
