description: The gulf oil fiasco is just the latest instance in which a lack of regulation  or dysfunctional system of regulation  has led to a major American disaster. After the failure of the levees during Hurricane Katrina, the Wall Street meltdown of 2008, the collapse of the housing market and now the BP spill,we have come to what feels like a moment of reckoning, with some tentative signs that our countrys decades-long love affair with deregulation is starting to chill.

title: King of His Multigenerational Castle?
description: There is a trend, the Internet tells me, of grown adults, sometimes even married and with kids of their own, moving back in with their parents. As much as I try to steer clear of trends, I have recently been considering this possibility, but in reverse. I grew up outside Miami, and when my youngest brother and I first moved to Brooklyn, my parents used to visit pretty often. When I married, the visits fell off. I think they were happy that I was taken care of: good job, good wife, good riddance. When I had kids, the visits started to pick up again. I didnt take it personally. They are now those kinds of parents, meaning that they are now grandparents. Last year my parents rented for a few months in the neighborhood. Then about a month ago, on the phone, my mother told me that they were thinking of coming to Brooklyn.

title: Jil Sander: Detox
description: Though it was dusk and apparently damp when theJil Sander mens show started in Florence  I watched the Web stream  the colors cleared the head. Intense yet cheerful, the blues, greens, yellows, pinks and oranges could have been taken from nature or a Warhol or a Koons canvas. Anyway, they were distinctive colors without navel-gazing and they worked best in assemble. Raf Simons seemed energized by this collection, which included belted jackets, quite a number of boyish shorts, and T-shirts in solid colors as well as grid patterns and deep-hued, splashy prints.

title: Honda Reveals New 2011 Odyssey
description: Honda revealed its fourth-generation Odyssey minivan Thursday in an online news conference from its research and development center in Ohio.

title: You Make the Call
description: Every Tiger out there was telling me that I had kicked the call because theyd seen the replay. . . .So I told Tim our clubhouse guy to cue it up, and  I missed it. I missed it. This isnt a big call. This is a history call.

title: Bromance? Renaissance Boston Suggests Brewmance.
description: Bonding over brews  that is what the Renaissance Boston Waterfront Hotel has in mind with a new beer-themed special available this Fathers Day through Labor Day.

title: The Recycling Thief
description: We put our paper, plastic and other recyclables in city-issued containers in  our backyard and move them to the curb for weekly pickup through our  towns recycling program. A scavenger regularly removes cans and bottles,  presumably to redeem for cash. I say that by depriving the city of these  items, he adds to our recycling costs. I want to ask the police to apprehend  the thief. My wife says I lack compassion. You? J.M., BURLINGAME, CALIF.

title: Implacability
description: In my recent column on cool, I wrote, "From Old English to the ages of Chaucer and Shakespeare all the way to the present, cool has been able to mean 'dispassionate, calm, self-composed.' Some of our latter-day cool expressions  'stay cool,' 'play it cool,' 'cool as a cucumber,' 'cool customer'  play off this ancient connotation of implacability." Catherine Harris e-mails: "I believe you meant to use imperturbability rather than implacability, describing the calm sense of cool. Someone who is implacable is relentless and unappeasable, not necessarily perpetually unruffled."   If there's one lesson I learned from many years of reading my illustrious predecessor William Safire, it's to show humility when called out by the Gotcha Gang. In a 1984 column, he introduced the Gotcha Gang as "that shock troop of Lexicographic Irregulars who specialize in correcting other language mavens." Safire later revealed the hidden benefit of publicizing Gotchas: "By ostentatiously wolfing down one slim slice of humble pie, I buy the license to take pops at everybody else for months without appearing to be a wiseguy."  Let this be my first On Language mea culpa: Harris (along with fellow Gotcha-ers Brian Hoffman, Peter Glasgow and Wade Richardson) rightly questions my use of implacability, which does not quite fit in the context of cool. Imperturbability would indeed have been a better choice, as would the more modern unflappability.  I cop to the malaprop, though my mix-up was not as blatant or farcical as the eponymous Mrs. Malaprop's constant misuse of language in Richard Brinsley Sheridan's 1775 play "The Rivals" (e.g., "He is the very pineapple of politeness," with pineapple standing in for pinnacle). I might have been influenced in my word choice by such cool words as placid and placate, but of course, implacability tends to imply just the opposite, an inability to be made calm.  In my modest defense, the "relentless, steadfast" shade of implacability can intersect with the unruffled nature of imperturbability, and in fact the adjectives implacable and imperturbable often appear side by side - or as linguists would say, they can easily "collocate" with each other. For instance, the newly published translation of Simone de Beauvoir's "Second Sex" by Constance Borde and Sheila Malovany-Chevallier contains a line about "precise, imperturbable, implacable logic."  The overlap in usage between the two words doesn't absolve the linguistic error, however. In a vicious dissection of James Fenimore Cooper's many "literary offenses," Mark Twain offered some simple rules for writing as an antidote. My favorite is: "Use the right word, not its second cousin." This advice hits close to home, since I work as executive producer of the Visual Thesaurus, which essentially creates interactive family trees of words with similar meanings. Implacability and imperturbability might have a passing family resemblance, but it's best not to treat them as blood brothers.

title: Bryant Sets Narrative for Next Season
description: A popular story line for next season was crafted Thursday night when Kobe Bryant won his fifth championship ring, putting him one behind Michael Jordan, the player he seems to mimic in so many ways, including celebratory post-title moments.

title: Long Live the King
description: In addition to the legacy that is Michael Jacksons discography, the King of Pop also left behind a trove of collectibles  from his bedazzled gloves and rhinestone-covered military garb to the countless tacky tchotchkes that filled his Neverland compound. Though many of the clothes and objects have been sold at auction, the museum-worthy collection has been preserved by the Swiss-born photographer Henry Leutwyler in a new book, Neverland Lost: A Portrait of Michael Jackson (Steidl 2010; $45). Mr. Leutwyler photographed the items prior to Mr. Jacksons death in 2009, forgoing visual trickery and relying instead on a plain black background. Many of the images point to the otherwordly realm the star inhabited; others, such as an ordinary tube sock studded with rhinestones, bring him heartbreakingly down to earth.

title: Complaint Box | Abusive Customers
description: Lets face it, folks. The customer is not always right. In fact, some are just plain old abusive, cheap and crass. I say this not as a salesman but as a dyed-in-the-wool middle-class consumer.

title: From Alfa to Omega
description: At its best, Alfa Romeo combined striking design with driving joy.

title: A Reason for Optimism
description: The latest economic data has not been very good. Yet Robert Barbera  an economist at ITG, whos been more right than most over the last couple of years  says he isnt especially worried.

title: Zen and the Art of Image Maintenance
description: IF luxury brands have identities, Infinitis has too often seemed a secret one.

title: Lead Actor Withdraws from Bollywood Hitler Film
description: A plan for the Bollywood film industrys first feature about Hitler has already drawn an outcry from Indian moviegoers and historians, and now the project has lost the actor who was to play the lead character, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Small People
description: BP chairman Carl-Henric Svanbergs controversial description of those affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: Flight Training: Building an Army of Billy Elliots
description: A BOY in a tutu. This was the image Lee Hall saw in his minds eye when he began the original screenplay for Billy Elliot, the tale of a striking coal miners son who crashes the gates of the Royal Ballet School in London. We thought it would be impossible to find one kid for the movie, Mr. Hall said on a recent visit to New York. Doing the show live, with singing, is so much harder.

title: Classical Music, Plugging In
description: THOUGH the electric guitar was introduced in the early 1930s, its adoption into classical music came decades later. Composers like Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tippett used the instrument chiefly for its vernacular allusions. Later Rhys Chatham, Glenn Branca and Lois V. Vierk tapped into its capacity for producing complex overtones and, yes, punishing volume.

title: Twilight of the Gods
description: Electronic samples from the Klez Dispensers; Ray Marchica and Sons of Sound; Thomas Buckner and Ellen Band, vocalists. Tzadik TZ 8069; CD.

title: Aftercare Tips for Patients Checking Out of the Hospital
description: IN mid-March my 85-year-old father checked into a prominent New York City hospital for a scheduled operation. The procedure, to remove a cancerous tumor from his thigh, went well, and soon he was sent home.

title: Preparing to Leave the Hospital
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman looks at ways to prepare patients to leave the hospital  and minimize the chances of returning.

title: Inside the List
description: BECK BUMP: Swedish socialism may still rule the hardcover fiction list, via Stieg Larssons megahit The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest. But Larsson, who died in 2004, was recently given a run for his money by the free-market Austrian economist Friedrich von Hayek (who died in 1992), thanks to a mighty fist-bump from Glenn Beck. Hayeks classic treatise The Road to Serfdom, first published in the United States in 1944, shot to the No. 1 spot at both Amazon and Barnesandnoble.com after Beck devoted the entire June 8 episode of his television show to the book. A perennial seller for the University of Chicago Press, Hayeks libertarian cri de coeur had already received a big boost from Barack Obama, who has been cited by conservative pundits as the embodiment of the kind of creeping government tyranny that Hayek warned of. After Obamas election, sales went from about 7,000 copies a year to almost 30,000, according to Garrett Kiely, director of the press. After Becks program, the book sold about 60,000 to 70,000 copies in one week. This surge came too late to push the book onto this weeks paperback nonfiction list, which records sales until June 12. But stay tuned.

title: Cocktail Recipe: Bourbon Sidecar for Two
description: Forgive me, but Im about to go pedantic for a minute. Im always disturbed by the scene in which the beleaguered spouse  alright, the beleaguered guy  arrives home after a hard day, flops down on the chair and announces, I need a drink.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LAST STAND: Custer, Sitting Bull, and the Battle of the Little Bighorn,  by Nathaniel Philbrick (Viking, $30.) The author of Mayflower gives appropriate space to Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse and others who fought that day, but Custer steals the show.

title: Paperback Row
description: MY FATHERS TEARS: And Other Stories,  by John Updike (Ballantine, $16.) All but one of the 18 stories in Updikes final collection (he died in January 2009) were published in the last decade. Their protagonists are elderly gents who share biographical details and concerns with Updike himself. Updike once described himself as a literary spy within average, public-school, supermarket America,  our reviewer, T. Coraghessan Boyle, recalled. These are his last smuggled dispatches, made all the more poignant for their finality.

title: Execution by a Hail of Bullets  and a Message on Twitter
description: Politics Daily is reporting that Utahs attorney general, Mark Shurtleff, used his Twitter account to update citizens on the execution of the convicted killer Ronnie Lee Gardner by firing squad, including the moment when he gave the green light to proceed.

title: Letter: From Boys to Pros
description: Congratulations to Michael Sokolove for his thoroughly researched article on the Ajax youth academy. It was also very informative about U.S. youth soccer. As a professional polo player and father of three soccer-crazed boys, the implications of Sokoloves accurate assertions about international youth development in the sport are very personal. The U.S. system does not fit either a Dutch skills-based teaching method or the just play method of the kind my kids have experienced in South America. The U.S. method is probably a detriment to many because of its focus on winning even with very young players. Where is Johann Cruyff when we need him?

title: Letter: The Corporate Challenge
description: While its obvious from Frank Brunis profile that Carly Fiorinas personal experience informs her position on abortion, her experience has done nothing for her opinion on health care reform. She obviously cannot imagine what it is like for uninsured women with breast cancer who have limited access to timely and quality health care.

title: Letters: The Freegan Establishment
description: In Jake Halperns recent article about freegans in Buffalo, Kit is definitely onto something when he says: Just be nice to people. Just make connections. Its all about connections. Indeed, not only can people live on what we throw away in this country; childrens lives around the world can also be saved by it.

title: Casualties of War
description: Ive read somewhere that in the approximately 5,000 years of recorded history, there have been a little more than 200 years of recorded peace. No wonder so many writers have something to say about what weve done for the other 4,800, which is to slaughter one another. Imagine a tower built of all the war novels, memoirs, poetry, histories and commentaries written since the Iliad. Now imagine yourself standing on the roof. You would probably need an oxygen tank.

title: Geoffrey Hill Is Oxfords Next Professor of Poetry
description: The 2010 race for Oxford Universitys professor of poetry had it all: newfangled rules to allow online voting, an 11th-hour withdrawal by its only female candidate, a furious final round of campaigning by its 10 remaining contenders and plenty of name-calling. And in the end, the front-runner won, anyway.

title: Geopolitical Cycles
description: O to be young and biking in America at the close of the 19th century and have nothing to worry about, except perhaps the roads (which were an issue only if they were good: on the big-wheeled boneshaker bikes, as one cycling reporter put it, the element of safety is rather distasteful to a good many riders who prefer to run some risk, as it gives zest to the sport)! O to ride when cyclists were called wheelmen, Bicycling World covered bike races as if they were moon launches and spectators cheered on men in short-legged pants and caps that  wait!  looked a lot like what that guy on the G train in Brooklyn was wearing the other day! O to ride between bicycling meccas like Pittsburgh and Buffalo, at a time when America was embracing travel and just setting out, like bicyclists, into the wide world!

title: What Were Reading: Beard Ban
Inside the Box
description: Video games have created what must be the biggest generation gap since rock n roll. Sure, a generational rift of sorts emerged when the World Wide Web showed up near the end of the last century, but in the case of the Web, the older cohort admired and tried to emulate the younger crowd, rather than looking down on them with befuddlement or disdain. With games, a more traditional Get off my lawn panic has reared its head.

title: Name That Stimulus Proponent
description: The raging debate over what to do about the deficit is now getting its own lingo.

title: Sharp Images, Bright Screen on New Samsung Phone
description: Samsung has announced the release of the Captivate, the first in a new line of Galaxy S smartphones with startlingly bright and detailed screens.

title: Preparing Women to Build Growing Businesses
description: Gail Warrior understands the real issues faced by small-business owners. Depending on how you define small, she is one herself. In 1997 she founded Warrior Group, which specializes in permanent, modular construction, and is today chief executive and president of the 50-plus-employee company, which had 2009 revenue of $124 million. Based in DeSoto, Tex., Warrior Group handles projects in 30 states.

title: 10 Ways to Celebrate Fathers Day
description: How are you celebrating Fathers Day? Here are some creative things to do with your favorite dad, all of them inspired by pages in The Times.

title: S.E.C.s Revolving Door Draws More Scrutiny
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: A Close-Knit Team on a Plus-Size Show
description: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.

title: Pharma Drama
description: Lauren Belfers death-haunted medical thriller begins in December 1941, just three days after the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor. Claire Shipley, a photojournalist working for the phenomenally successful Life magazine, has come to the Rockefeller Institute in New York to record one of the earliest trials of a new medication called penicillin. Highly effective in experiments involving bacterial infections in mice, this substance is about to be tried on a human. Will the drug work? Or will it have serious, potentially lethal, side effects? For the patient and the doctors, theres no real choice: this experiment is a desperate last chance for a 37-year-old man who had been robustly healthy until a seemingly harmless scratch, acquired during a game of tennis, rapidly developed into a life-threatening infection.

title: Should Your Neighbor Be Banned From Smoking?
description: Many of us work in smoke-free offices, eat in smoke-free restaurants, even drink in smoke-free bars or outdoor cafes. But if we live in an apartment, should the whole building also be smoke free?

title: The Luck (or Misfortune) of the Draw
description: WIMBLEDON, England - Just below the spotlights aimed at Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Serena and Venus Williams, some of the worlds top unseeded tennis players got a glimpse of the road ahead at The Championships on Friday.

title: One World, One Voice
description: I found it a pleasure to read Robert McCrum on the English languages development in, for instance, the 14th century: After centuries of repression, the recognition of Everyman and the true commons was . . . expressed in the simple English words that hold good still. By the time he reaches the 21st century, however, our connection is shakier.

title: The Love Not Taken
description: Last summer, at a beach house in the Hamptons, a weekend guest arrived carrying a novel shed picked up abroad and was loath to put down. Called One Day, it was written by David Nicholls, whom some of us recognized as the author of another novel, Starter for Ten, a coming-of-age story about a working-class boy who goes to an elite university, falls in love with a girl whos out of his league (and not nearly as nice as he is) and enters an intercollegiate quiz contest. Those of us susceptible to nostalgic reveries of youthful heartache and self-invention (which is to say, all of us) longed to get our hands on Nichollss new novel, once our friend revealed its premise:

title: Where the Times Square Suspect Is Just a Client
description: When the suspect in the Times Square bombing plot appeared in a packed courtroom last month, the governments table was full: three prosecutors and an F.B.I. agent sat side by side. At the defense table, the suspect, Faisal Shahzad, sat next to a single federal public defender, Julia L. Gatto. They seemed badly outnumbered.

title: The Kagan Family: Left-Leaning and Outspoken
description: ON a crowded train somewhere in Pennsylvania in the aftermath of World War II, Robert Kagan gave up his seat to Gloria Gittelman, a fellow student from Pennsylvania State University, on a trip home during a school holiday. He was bound for Brooklyn, she for South Philadelphia.

title: McDowell Leads; Mickelson Charges at U.S. Open
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The alarm went off at 4:20 on Friday morning, awakening Graeme McDowell, the man from Portrush, Northern Ireland, and setting in motion a most remarkable chain of events in the second round of the United States Open at the Pebble Beach Golf Links.

title: Samurai Shopper | Here Comes the Sunblock
description: Please tell me youve received at least one of the 10,000 memos detailing with grisly relish the terrible effects of sunlight on skin. Then again, if youve missed the memos, good for you! Hiding under a rock where the sun dont shine has definite advantages.

title: Giving the Crowd What It May Not Crave
description: A LATTER-DAY Mark Twain may eventually coin the perfect name for the current era of failing institutions and diminished expectations. Until then there is the summation of recent history that Louis C. K. provided in an interview with Conan OBrien.

title: Counterfeit Condoms and a New Arrangement
description: New Yorkers long ago stopped being fooled by the luxury knockoffs peddled from sidewalk card tables at prices too good to be true. Not that they always keep their wallet in check  as a close inspection of many a supposedly pedigreed Louis Vuitton handbag might reveal, if the penny-pinching owner would allow it.

title: War and Peace: The Fact-Check
description: Dominic Lieven, a professor of history at the London School of Economics, is a distinguished scholar of the czarist empire, and in this superb book he has written his masterpiece. The story he tells  Russias gargantuan struggle with Napoleon  will be known to most people through Tolstoys  War and Peace,  and it takes a brave man to challenge the great novelist. But that indeed is Lievens goal, and for the most persuasive of reasons. He believes that Tolstoys account is badly misleading (Lieven has a historians natural concern for the facts) and perhaps more important has skewed our view of Russia and contributed to our tendency to misunderstand and belittle its role in international affairs.

title: In 90 Seconds, Germany Falls Back Into the Pack
description: A week ago, Germany was the power of this World Cup, having pounded Australia into submission, 4-0. Serbia was nobodys favorite to advance out of the group stage after losing in a most uninspired way to Ghana.

title: Goose Search Is Postponed Pending Feather Loss
description: Rangers in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, have called off efforts to apprehend an elusive goose with an arrow through its neck until it gets easier to catch. That should happen soon, when the Canada goose, variously known as Sticky or Target, begins molting.

title: Bairs Next Target: Fannie and Freddie
description: Sheila C. Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said Friday that overhauling the nations mortgage-finance system should rise to the top of the agenda as soon as Congress completes its sweeping financial regulatory bill, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Maiko Matsushima and David Brick
description: IT was just another intense artistic collaboration, or so Maiko Matsushima, a costume designer, and David Brick, a choreographer, thought during an April 2008 production in Princeton, N.J.

title: Combing Cambodia for Missing Friends
description: PKHAR DOUNG, Cambodia

title: Torture and the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Smarter
description: To the Editor:

title: Dangerous Zeal
description: Young people have doubtless heard the trash talk about President Obamas being un-American, but they probably have no idea that similar charges against ordinary citizens nearly brought the government to a standstill during the height of the Red scare in the 1950s. Exposure of real spies after World War II and fears of Stalins Russia had created a tense mood in Washington. So when a junior Republican senator from Wisconsin, Joseph R. McCarthy, began accusing the State Department of harboring card-carrying members of the Communist Party, for a time he tapped into a popular cause. But as chairman of the Senates Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, McCarthy would pursue his anti-Communist crusade with a zeal that would ensnare and wrong many innocent people.

title: Drawn and Courted
description: The idea of a collaboration between Lois Lowry and Jules Feiffer is exciting news. Lowry, twice winner of the Newbery Medal, is the author of dozens of much-loved works for children and young adults, from the popular Anastasia Krupnik series to the Giver trilogy, while Feiffer is a prize-winning cartoonist and playwright who has also written and illustrated numerous picture books and childrens novels. With The Birthday Ball, this illustrious pair tries something new for both: the comic fairy tale.

title: Under the Spotlight
description: Dance: 10. Looks: 3. What is adolescence but a long, grueling theatrical audition? The cruel spotlight and the snickering from the darkness might as well describe the morning walk to the locker through a gantlet of rich kids, bullies and fabulous, distant beauties. This is one reason the authors of two new gay-themed young adult books center their plots on the production of a high school musical. The other is that gay and musical tend to exert a world-bending magnetic force on each other.

title: A Decent Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: GOAL!  By Mina Javaherbin.Illustrated by A. G. Ford.  Candlewick. $16.99. (Ages 6 to 10)

title: In Evils Clutches
description: A bleeding-heart sensibility isnt the first thing you expect from a thriller. Unless, of course, the author happens to be John Harvey, whose boundless empathy imparts a grave and tender tone to his bleak crime novels. In FAR CRY (Otto Penzler/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26), that compassion is aroused by Ruth Pierce, a London schoolteacher whose husband sweet-talks her into letting their preadolescent daughter, Heather, join a classmates family on a camping trip to Cornwall. Under this permissive clans slapdash care, the girls become lost in a treacherous coastal fog, and Heathers battered body turns up on a cliff ledge near the crumbling remains of an old mine shaft.

title: Changing the Rules
description: This weeks column is by Capt. Joseph Himpelmann, who has recently returned to the United States after serving as a Battery Commander in a heavy brigade combat team based in Mosul. The name of the base has been withheld to avoid jeopardizing service members still operating in that area. The views expressed in this blog are those of the author and do not reflect the official policy or position of the Department of the Army, Department of Defense or the United States government. If you are an active-duty service member and would like to submit a post, please e-mail us at AtWar@nytimes.com.

title: Week in Pictures, June 18
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Prairie Haute Companion
description: The look is cozy and homespun. Basket weaving class behind the barn.

title: His Cross to Bear: Heartthrob Vampire
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Special Edition of Kimmels Show Friday Night  With the Lakers
description: Jimmy Kimmel and ABC will get an unexpected gift Friday night: a new show when a repeat had been scheduled. And the show will include about the most prominent guests a talk show could land this week: Kobe Bryant and other members of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: TimesCast | June 18, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, reports on the refugee crisis in Kyrgyzstan, Mississippi governor Haley Barbour, casting the next Billy Elliot and an interview with author Christopher Hitchens .

title: End Times, Perhaps, for Late-Night Annoyances
description: What constitutes an urban nuisance is often in the eye  or ear  of the beholder.

title: Senate Leader Says He Leaked Memo to Aqueduct Bidder
description: ALBANYThe messy bidding process overa casino at Aqueduct got even messier on Friday.

title: World Cup Replay: Day 8, June 18
description: Serbia upset Germany, which played much of the game short-handed and could not convert a penalty kick.

title: While Oil Gushes, Invisible Ocean Impacts Build
description: One reason the public, and politicians, have been so focused on the unchecked environmental disaster unfolding in the Gulf of Mexico is the vivid nature of the assault from gushing oil. We have a much harder time with less visible, and more incremental, environmental disruptions. The carbon dioxide being added to the atmosphere at a rate of about 1,000 tons a second is invisible and will have impacts that are spread in time and space and often are a matter of shifted odds of adverse events, not direct harm. The same is true for changes in the oceans driven by human activity, including the CO2 buildup.

title: Lighten Up
description: The Takeaway Yes, were painfully aware of how important it is to maintain structure in our lives, especially these days. But what about the boredom that comes with it? Fortunately, loosening up doesnt mean you have to look like a slob; this springs tailoring is refreshingly, well, untailored.

title: Fallon: Lost in Transition
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Yesterday during a press conference, B.P. chairman Carl-Henric Svanberg caused some controversy when he said B.P. cares about the small people. Part of his new strategy  plug the hole by digging himself into a deeper one.

title: Ferguson: The Power to Shut Off the Internet
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: There is a new bill in the Senate that is upsetting a lot of people. This bill would give the President the power to shut off the Internet. Al Gore is strongly opposed to it. Not because he invented the Internet. Because he did. But because he just signed up for Match.com.

title: Letterman: Hes Dying His Hair
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Have you seen President Obama lately? People are saying hes dying his hair. Right there, thats a good use for the oil.

title: Snoop Dogg Is Astonished by Dutch Festival Ban
description: Earlier Friday, ArtsBeat reported that Snoop Dogg was dropped from the lineup of a coming festival in The Hague, where authorities said they wanted to ensure the open and friendly character of that concert.

title: Around the World With Exotic Grains
description: If youre like most adventurous cooks, your pantry probably contains at least one or two bags or canisters of unusual grains that looked enticing at the exotic food store but which youre not quite sure what to do with. In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five delicious ways to cook with chickpea flour, a staple of Indian cooking, Italian semolina, the flour traditionally used to make pasta, and bulgur, a Middle Eastern favorite. Even if you dont have these ingredients on hand, it may well be worth a trip to the market to get them.

title: Jumble Fever
description: Matchy-matchy is so last decade.

title: Leno: A Little Weasel Guy
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, the big story, President Obama will set aside $20 billion to pay the victims of the oil spill in the Gulf. Well, that is good news. The bad news  it still comes out to less than, like, a dollar a gallon.

title: Obama: Ten Thousand Points of Infrastructure
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  With the unemployment rate still stuck close to 10 percent, President Obama flew to this political swing state on Friday to promote his economic stimulus program, which he credited with its 10,000th road project.

title: Is It Illegal to Lie About Your Pay in a Job Interview?
description: When the DailyWorth retracted its recent post about a woman who had inflated her current salary during a job interview, the sites editor wrote that a number of human resources personnel had said that even slight salary history inflations are illegal and could jeopardize your job application.

title: Congrats, Michigan
description: For the first time in four years, Michigan did not have the highest monthly state unemployment rate, according to a new Labor Department report for May.

title: Weekend Competition: Voulez-vous Vuvuzela?
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to dally with sounds, descriptions of sound, and onomatopoeia.

title: Across the Threshold of Fatherhood
description: IN early 2006 I was coming out of an extended trip through what I can now only call a spiritual wasteland. The first line from Dantes Inferno had been rattling around inside me  I, too, had come to the middle of my life and found myself in a dark wood, having lost my way.

title: Vain Glorious | Grooming Rx
description: The world doesnt need more products, just better ones, says Chad Murawczyk, who opened MiN New York, an old-style apothecary, on one of SoHos few remaining gritty stretches six months ago. To this end, Murawczyk has stocked the shops dark-wood shelves with exclusive and hard-to-find fragrances like Linaris Notte Bianca (a favorite of David Bowie; $195) and Arabian Nights from Kilian Perfume as an Art ($395), as well as grooming products from Taylor of Old Bond Street and handmade straight razors from the French firm Thiers-Issard ($200-500). More a cabinet of curiosities than a drugstore, its as if Zitomer had been transported to Savile Row.

title: Balancing Levity and Heft in an Exploration of Desire
description: IN Alain Resnaiss splendid and elliptical 1977 film, Providence, the narrator  a dying writer played with dyspeptic gusto by John Gielgud  explains that its been said his search for style has often come at the expense of feeling. I put it another way, he says, that style is feeling in its most elegant and economic expression. Its a wittily self-reflexive moment from a director who for much of his long, astonishing career has been accused of creating mere exercises in style, films without the requisite drama and empathetic characters with obvious motivations, a cinema (or should we say sin?) of the brain instead of the heart.

It was really hard picking one so I went with one that had to do with Mexico and the seasons, something I craved, she wrote in an e-mail.

title: For Want of a Goal
description: I am not a soccer fan, particularly. I hated playing the game as a kid, Im easily exasperated by the ties and the low scoring and the penalty-kick finales, and I loathe what Jonathan Last calls the ritual attack of the soccer scolds every World Cup season. (Also, I had college roommates  and dear friends  who insisted on referring to the game as football, even though they were Americans going to college in America, for crying out loud.) But todays United States-Slovenia match was a beautiful, remarkable, riveting thing to watch and a game seemingly perfectly engineered, in its stakes and scoring and sudden reversals, to hoist me on my own soccer-hating petard.

description: Last week I enlisted my father-in-law John, a devoted barbecue enthusiast, to help test grill gadgets of dubious value: thermometer tongs, a water-filled grill brush and wire skewers. Though they all seemed like gimmicks, each one held up surprisingly well under testing. Perhaps pressing our luck, I ordered a barbecue-based cast-iron crme brle set. What better way to make burnt cream than with a scorching hot cast-iron salamander, right?

title: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
description: Even as some refugees who fled the brutal violence in Kyrgyzstan began returning home on Friday, tens of thousands remained in tent camps in neighboring Uzbekistan, Clifford J. Levy of The Times reported, and the United Nations said that one million people could be in need of food and other assistance. Although the bloodletting has ebbed, Kyrgyzstan, an obscure central Asian country that houses American and Russian military bases, remains in serious danger of fragmenting. The provisional Kyrgyz government has lost control of large areas in the southern part of the country because of its failure to quell attacks that have killed at least several hundred ethnic Uzbeks, and possibly many more. Uzbeks have set up de facto autonomous zones and are refusing to recognize the authorities in the Kyrgyz capital. The first two slides were shot for The Times by James Hill.

title: Shake-Up at BP as Hayward Steps Back From Spill

title: New Blood for Lineage of Desperate Housewives
description: To anyone who has noticed the alarming number of middle-aged women sublimating their erotic fantasies through the Twilight books, the arrival of  The Gates Sunday on ABC will come as no surprise. The series has the sensibility of something incubated in a focus group of 40-year-old women complaining of busyness and boredom  of demanding children, sexless marriages and the high prices at Restoration Hardware. In deciding what to call the show, the producers, one suspects, landed on and then rejected something like The Real and Desperate Vampire Housewives of Somewhere that Looks an Awful Lot Like The Truman Show.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Is there such a thing as a budget boutique hotel? Yes, at least in New York, where Stephen Heyman reports that such places have been cropping up over the past three years. He does a test run of rooms at six new hotels  Distrikt, Eventi, Fashion 26, Hotel Indigo, the MAve and the Strand  that are aiming to offer boutique frills at midrange prices.

title: Wanderlust | Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold
description: Now that theres a Red Wing concept store in Berlin, you can buy Filson in Paris, and scarves from Brooklyns Hill-Side have made it to Amsterdam and Trieste, its clear that the fetishization of American heritage style is no longer just for American men. And few shops in Europe are more faithfully dedicated to heirloom denim and classic work wear than the new Stockholm shop Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold. The name alone, taken from a Townes Van Zandt classic, is like Carhartts incarnate. The shop, in Sdermalm, the citys answer to Brooklyn and the only party of town that could be called gritty, is outfitted almost entirely in unfinished knotty pine boards; they line the walls and form blocky benches and tables for merchandise that includes Mr. Freedom work shirts, Quoddy moccasins, Pendleton blankets and Wesco motorcycle boots. And true to the cult of craftsmanship, the narrative behind every company the store does business with is highlighted on its Web site. The expertly focused selection of brands includes plenty of international origin  canvas satchels from Brady Bags of England, founded in 1877; Grunden rain gear (Sweden, 1926); jeans by The Real McCoys (Japan, 1990)  but the effect is nonetheless a mashup of styles that feels unmistakably American. Easy rider meets California gold miner meets New England stevedore, all crammed into your dads tool shed, circa 1976.

title: Letters to a Father
description: Clearing out my mothers house, preparing for a move, I found letters I sent home years ago from college. None of them said outright what I should have said  that I was grateful to my parents, for so many reasons, not least of all the fact of their reading and listening. But it was there between the lines.

Most of the biggest houses there are gone, and Crown Heights has had a busy history since that time. But if millionaires are scarcer today, the good news is that in much of the neighborhood the comfortable ambience they once prized is intact. And finding a place to live is less daunting than even a few years ago.

Growing up in the Washington housing project in East Harlem in the 1970s, the singer Marc Anthony came to realize early on that every familys identity was based on the music they were blaring out their windows toward the courtyard below. As he moved about, he recalled this week, he would hear Marvin Gaye coming from one apartment, Ray Barretto from another, the Bee Gees from a third.

description: The distant, legendary past and the complicated present are never far apart in the songs of Carmen Consoli, a Sicilian songwriter whos a superstar in Italy. On Thursday night she played to a club-sized crowd at Le Poisson Rouge. She sang about the myth of Narcissus and about plastic surgery. She also sang about politicians dallying with hookers and about being sexually abused by her uncle.

title: Lead Actor Withdraws From Hitler Film
description: A plan for the Bollywood film industrys first feature about Adolf Hitler has already drawn an outcry from Indian moviegoers and historians, and now the project has lost the actor who was to play the lead character, Agence France-Presse reported. Anupam Kher, who was to play Hitler in Dear Friend Hitler, said he was withdrawing because of the criticism of the production. On his Twitter account Mr. Kher wrote, Sometimes human emotions are more important than cinema. In a statement reported by Reuters, Mr. Kher, left, added: I have never been moved by commercial considerations, but I have always respected social opinions. In an earlier description of the film, which is to be directed by Rakesh Ranjan Kumar and will focus on Hitlers final days, its producers said Dear Friend Hitler would reveal the German dictators insecurities, his charisma, his paranoia and his sheer genius. The filmmakers said the project would not glorify Hitler, but the project, scheduled to begin filming in August, was widely condemned.

title: Larry King to Host Oil-Spill Telethon
description: Larry King will host a two-hour celebrity telethon on Monday night to raise funds for the response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, CNN said. The broadcast, Disaster in the Gulf: How You Can Help, will feature appearances by Justin Bieber, Deepak Chopra, Cameron Diaz, Kathy Griffin, Lenny Kravitz, Tim McGraw, Robert Redford and other celebrities, as well as a performance by Sting. Mr. Kings friend Ryan Seacrest will interact with online participants. CNN journalists will report live from the affected region during the telethon. CNN said the funds raised for people and wildlife affected by the oil spill would benefit three charities: the United Way, the National Wildlife Federation and the Nature Conservancy. In January, Mr. King held a similar telethon for victims of the Haiti earthquake.

title: Big Numbers for ABC
description: The Los Angeles Lakers Game 7 victory in the N.B.A. Finals on Thursday lifted ABC to No. 1 on the night by a wide margin. Preliminary overnight numbers for the broadcast were the highest for any N.B.A. Finals game on any network since 1998. Final audience figures were expected to easily surpass the sizable audience of 18.7 million viewers who tuned in to Game 5 on Sunday. CBS ranked second on the night with two repeats of The Mentalist at 8 (7.2 million) and 10 (8.2 million) and a rerun of CSI in between at 9 (8.3 million). Fox was third, earning 6.1 million viewers at 9 for the first results episode of So You Think You Can Dance. NBC finished a distant fourth.

title: After Rough Campaign, a New Professor of Poetry
description: The 2010 race for Oxford Universitys professor of poetry had it all: newfangled rules to allow online voting, an 11th-hour withdrawal by its only female candidate, a furious final round of campaigning by its 10 remaining contenders and plenty of name-calling. And in the end, the front-runner won, anyway. On Friday Oxford said that Geoffrey Hill, author of King Log, Mercian Hymns and Without Title, had won the election to become the universitys 44th professor of poetry. Mr. Hill claimed the victory with a commanding lead, winning 1,156 of more than 2,500 votes; the next closest candidate was Michael Horovitz, the Beat poet, who picked up 353 votes. The voting was open to Oxford alumni and academics. Paula Claire, who was the only woman vying for the position this year, predicted the outcome when she pulled out of the election earlier this month, saying it was seriously flawed and too heavily tilted in favor of Mr. Hill. Mr. Hill, an Oxford graduate, is to assume the mantle of poetry professor in the fall, succeeding Christopher Ricks. The post was left open last year after Ruth Padel, the first woman in more than 300 years to win the seat, resigned after it was learned she had alerted reporters to a book describing a decades-old act of sexual harassment that Derek Walcott, a 2009 candidate, was accused of having committed.

title: Snoop Dogg Astonished by Dutch Festival Ban
description: Having spent the better part of four years fighting for his right to travel to Britain, the hip-hop star Snoop Dogg, left, now finds himself a rapper non grata in The Hague, where the authorities had him scratched from the lineup of a free concert planned for later this month, BBC News reported. Snoop Dogg was scheduled to perform at the Parkpop festival in The Hague on June 27, but the mayor and law enforcement officials there asked its organizers to find another artist to replace him to ensure the open and friendly character of the festival. In a statement the rappers management wrote that Snoop Dogg was astonished by the decision of the Mayor of The Hague, and is a mainstay at music festivals all over the world and has performed at all of these without incident.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 18
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Simon and Garfunkel Suspend Tour
description: Simon and Garfunkels summer tour of the United States and Canada, already postponed once because of Art Garfunkels vocal strain, has now been put off indefinitely. A statement on the duos Web site, simonandgarfunkel.com, says Mr. Garfunkel is recovering from vocal paresis. That condition inhibits the duo from performing shows at the highest possible level, the statement says, and it is for that reason and out of respect for their fans that Paul and Art have decided to put the tour on hold. The tour was to have begun on July 3 in Vancouver, British Columbia, and included stops in Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., and Atlantic City. The two played the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival in April, where Mr. Garfunkel complained from the stage that his voice was a little elusive. That show was to have kicked off a tour, but within a few days it was postponed. Mr. Garfunkel has also canceled recent solo concerts, including one last month at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

title: A Church Sells Its Tiffany Window
description: Movers this week took out a Tiffany window, below, from the First Baptist Church in Brattleboro, Vt., after the church sold the century-old scene of St. John the Divine in a garden to an antiques collector. The collector, Cameel Halim, is building a stained glass museum in Illinois and paid $85,000 for the window. Mr. Halims only competition, from a group of philanthropists including Michael Eisner, the former chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, offered the church $47,500 to leave the window in the choir loft. The movers replaced the window with simple colored panes. It happened very quickly, said Karen Davis, a trustee of First Baptist. Its sad for the church for sure. The proceeds will pay for repairs to the Gothic brick building and to operate a homeless shelter. Mr. Halim is turning a Victorian house in Evanston, Ill., into a museum with an 8,000-square-foot gallery for his windows by designers including Louis Comfort Tiffany and his arch-rival, John La Farge.

title: Hamming It Up, With Pink Light, Flashes of Murakami and Flowered Bikinis
description: The title of John Jasperses recent full-length work is a long and unwieldy one. But its as perfect a description of theater as any youll come across. It is (drum roll): Truth, Revised Histories, Wishful Thinking and Flat Out Lies.

title: From the Street, but Domesticated
description: Once upon a time, you could glue a cigarette butt to a canvas or haul dirty tires into a gallery and upset peoples nervous systems. Now, art is so adept at absorbing any whiff of mischief that it is difficult to retain any meaningful vestige of the street. This is especially true in Keith Haring: A New Dimension and Chakaia Booker: Eminent Domain, on display in the Museum Building and the Domestic Arts Building at Grounds for Sculpture in Hamilton.

title: From Memphis to Arizona to Seattle, Navigating Dreams and Blues

They arose formally at the Kennedy Center Opera House on Thursday evening in a post-performance discussion after Ballet Memphis, Ballet Arizona and Pacific Northwest Ballet each presented a ballet as part of the Ballet Across America season.

title: Thieves Are in the House, and Theyre All Related

It starts out looking like one show, a sexy, light-hearted comedy about larceny, and ends up looking like another: a slightly more serious, and potentially irritatingly sentimental, dramedy about trying to go straight.

We are here today because another alleged victim of Roman Polanskis sexual predatory conduct has come forward, the lawyer explained, her face set in a familiar, concerned frown as the cameras whirred. The Writers Theater production of A Streetcar Named Desire directed by David Cromer takes you within a millimeter or two of this carnal knowledge. If you happen to be seated in the right spot  the easily unnerved might call it the wrong spot  you can practically see those colored lights going yourself when Stanley and Stella engage in a fraught bout of lovemaking after that poker game ends in violence and tears.

title: For a Young Parent, Lessons in Fatherhood
description: Like many young fathers, Leon Britton Jr. begins his day early, at 5 a.m. But not because of a crying baby. He lives two miles away from his daughter, Diamond, who is 2 1/2, and her mother, Rosa Colon, who is expecting their second child in August. Mr. Britton commutes from the Pelham Parkway neighborhood of the Bronx to Long Island City, Queens, where he works as an animal control technician. At 3 p.m., he heads for Ms. Colon's apartment in the Gun Hill section of the Bronx, where he hangs out with Diamond until about 9 p.m., then returns to his own place to sleep.

Midberry and the Rev. James H. Midberry of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. David H. Kim, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the German Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul in New York.

title: Clara Platter, Michael Alexander
description: Clara Sophia Platter and Michael Alexander were married Saturday in Pottersville, N.J. The Rev. James. M. Taylor, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of William Welch and Andrea Filippone, the brides aunt and uncle.

title: Privacy in the Cellular Age
description: Do people have a right to privacy in a closed telephone booth? In 1967, the Supreme Court said they do and prohibited government eavesdropping there without a warrant. But what about a cellphone with no booth? What about a phone that also sends messages, scours the Internet and records your exact location?

title: Cory Mescon, Benjamin Baumer
description: Cory Ellen Borfitz Mescon and Benjamin Strong Baumer were married Saturday at Smith College in Northampton, Mass. The Rev. Stephen Philbrick, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Caroline Mallone and Eric Huebner
description: Caroline Joanna Mallone and Eric Heinz Huebner were married Saturday in a Quaker ceremony at the Baltimore Monthly Meeting of Friends, Stony Run, a Quaker meetinghouse in Baltimore.

title: Elise de la Selle, Oliver Jones
description: Elise Catherine de la Selle, a daughter of Nancy and Sebastien de la Selle of Paris, was married Saturday to Oliver Holdship Jones, a son of Christina C. Evans and Peter D. Jones, both of New York. The Very Rev. Dr. Ernest E. Hunt III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at All Souls Church in Onteora Park, N.Y.

title: U.S. Cracks Down on Farmers Who Hire Children
description: WHITE LAKE, N.C.  The Obama administration has opened a broad campaign of enforcement against farmers who employ children and underpay workers, hiring hundreds of investigators and raising fines for labor and wage violators.

title: Stacey Paradise, Noah Kushlefsky
description: Stacey E. Paradise and Noah H. Kushlefsky were married Thursday at the Manhattan Penthouse in New York. Cantor Rebecca Garfein officiated.

title: Far Over the Line
description: Its no surprise to political realists that once Sharron Angle secured the Republican nomination for the United States Senate in Nevada as a Tea Party insurgent, she would soften some of her most pugnacious stances. Sure enough, she is toning down her calls for abolishing the energy and education departments, phasing out Social Security and repealing the income tax.

title: From Bomb Traces, Chile Terror Inquiry Builds
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Muhammad Saif ur Rehman Khan said he had traveled from his native Pakistan to Santiago to learn Spanish and work in a hotel. But five months after his arrival, Mr. Khan finds himself under investigation as a terrorism suspect, after traces of a rarely used explosive were discovered on his belongings when he visited the American Embassy.

title: New Yorks Moment for Divorce Reform
description: As a particularly dismal legislative session limps to a conclusion in Albany, lawmakers have a chance to do something right by ending the logjam over no-fault divorce. New York is the only state where a court must find fault before granting a divorce unless the spouses have lived apart for a full year under a formal separation agreement  a proven formula for inviting false testimony, endless litigation and generally making divorce far more painful than it needs to be.

title: Elena FitzPatrick and Justin Sifford-Angotti
description: Elena Maria FitzPatrick, the daughter of Verna and Richard FitzPatrick of Roosevelt Island, was married Saturday to Justin Dario Alexander Sifford-Angotti, the son of Belinda Sifford of Berkeley, Calif., and Thomas Angotti of Brooklyn. The Rev. Lewis C. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Tejas Gawade, James Bouklas
description: Tejas Ashok Gawade, a daughter of Vidya A. Gawade and Ashok S. Gawade of Livingston, N.J., is to marry James Brian Bouklas, a son of Naomi Bouklas and Dr. George J. Bouklas of East Setauket, N.Y., on Sunday. The Rev. Nicholas A. Montanino, a World Christian Ministry minister, is to officiate at a nondenominational ceremony at the Watermill, a catering hall in Smithtown, N.Y.

title: BP Fund Is a Magnet for Fraud, Experts Say
description: The $20 billion BP compensation fund announced by the Obama administration this week has those along the coast hoping that it will provide a more benevolent gusher than the one at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Holly Jackson, Sari Edelstein
description: Holly Jackson and Sari Lynn Edelstein were married Saturday at the Red Inn in Provincetown, Mass. Rabbi Howard A. Berman officiated, and James Mack, a chaplain with the Unitarian Universalist Meeting House of Provincetown, participated in the ceremony.

title: Canada: Thieves in Quebec Grab a Tiger by the Trailer
description: Thieves who made off with a truck and trailer outside a motel near Montreal early Friday morning may have been surprised to discover its cargo: a tiger and two camels. Quebec has recently experienced a rash of truck and trailer thefts. The police speculated that the thieves were probably unaware that they had also acquired the animals, which were traveling to a private zoo near Toronto from Nova Scotia when their two handlers stopped for the night. The handlers told the police that the trailer and the animals were gone when they woke up on Friday morning. The tiger, they said, had been caged within the trailer, which was designed to carry cattle.

title: Debbie Dao, Alexis Dang
description: Debbie Yen Dao and Alexis Bao-Chuyen Dang were married Saturday at St. Irenaeus Church in Cypress, Calif. The Rev. Brian Cool, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Illinois: School Scraps Plans for Sculpture
description: The University of Illinois, which is responding to a budget crisis by raising tuition and turning to short-term borrowing to meet its operating expenses, decided this week to drop its plans for a $98,000 sculpture honoring its president, Stanley O. Ikenberry, The Chicago Tribune reported. The paper said the plans for the sculpture were scrapped after the newspaper began inquiring about the artwork. University officials said Friday that no one was available to comment on the situation. The universitys new president, Michael Hogan, will start next month.

title: China: Tang Dynasty Coffin Returned by U.S. Businessman
description: A 27-ton imperial sarcophagus from the Tang Dynasty that was stolen by tomb raiders has been returned to China from the United States, according to a report in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. The coffin, which was stolen from the tomb of the Tang empress Wu Huifei, who died in 737, arrived at the Shaanxi History Museum on Thursday. Chinese police officers first discovered that the relic had been stolen in 2006. They traced it to a businessman in the United States, who had bought it for $1 million, China Daily reported. The businessman agreed to return the coffin unconditionally after three rounds of negotiations. The coffin was shipped from Virginia on March 16.

title: Making Sure the Check Is Not in the Mail
description: President Obama ordered federal agencies on Friday to create a uniform do not pay list to reduce some of the $110 billion in improper or erroneous payments made by the government last year. The list is intended to prevent benefit checks, grants or contract payments from being made to individuals or companies that are not qualified to receive them. A government-wide database would screen contractors, subcontractors, businesses and individuals who obtain federal contracts to see if they have been convicted of federal fraud, operate phony businesses, owe back taxes or otherwise would be ineligible for government payments or benefits.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE JUICE PRESS on East First Street is here to prove the unlikely hypothesis that the East Village needs another place to get a drink. Its cheerful storefront is next door to Juicy Lucy Juice Bar, the neighborhoods longtime go-to for fruity concoctions. But Marcus Antebi, the tattooed co-owner, said his is the only place around for people who want strictly organic ingredients and juice that is pressed according to every health code. There is a $60 eight-juices-in-a-day cleanse and alluring juice cocktails like the Pompeii ($8.75 for 16 ounces of tomato, green pepper, celery, carrot and homemade Tabasco) and the Ginger Fireball ($7 for 8 ounces of ginger, lemon, orange, colloidal silver, oregano and cayenne pepper.) Luna, the juice-jerk on duty at Juicy Lucy on Friday, seemed unmoved by the competition. People here really like juice, he shrugged. Plus, ours is cheaper.

title: Wishing Will Make It So
description: Americans have always raised their children to believe in the power of the dream. This is probably why hundreds of thousands of young people are certain they are destined to become the American Idol. Or Next Top Model. Or marry a Jonas Brother.

title: Florida: Senate Candidate Faces Foreclosure
description: A bank began foreclosure proceedings this week on a Tallahassee home co-owned by Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate for the Senate, after he failed to pay his mortgage for five months, according to court documents. Mr. Rubio, a former speaker of the Florida House, and State Representative David Rivera, who is running for Congress, bought the home in 2005 for $135,000 and lived there when they were in Tallahassee for legislative sessions. Alex Burgos, a spokesman for Mr. Rubios campaign, said Mr. Rubio and Mr. Rivera were selling the home and stopped paying the mortgage during a dispute with the bank. He said they made a final payment of $9,524 on Thursday. Marco and David resolved this, so this process wont go any further, Mr. Burgos said.

title: Dartmouth Atlas: A Response to Its Researchers
description: A front-page article in The New York Times on June 3 examined the Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care, a compendium of research on Medicare spending that has often been cited by the Obama administration in the debate over health care legislation.

title: Fuel Maker for Reactors Has China as Investor
description: HONG KONG  A company here that is partly owned by the Chinese government has quietly purchased a 5.1 percent stake in the only American-owned provider of enriched uranium for use in civilian nuclear reactors.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about the new TV Land sitcom, Hot in Cleveland, referred incorrectly to the audience laughter heard on the show. It was from a live audience at the taping, not from a laugh track.

title: For Neighbors, a Hospitals Demise Leaves a Hole
description: Until St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan officially shut its doors at the end of April, Eddie Najda ordered 20 dozen bagels a day for his deli down the street. He now orders four dozen. Henry Valerio parked 50 transient cars a day in his Quik-Park garage; he now gets 15. And, without doctors and patients, the flower shop on Greenwich Avenue is selling half the flowers it once did.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Senate Passes Plan to Stop Medicare Pay Cuts to Doctors
description: WASHINGTON  With lawmakers worried that older Americans relying on Medicare could begin losing access to health care, the Senate on Friday approved a six-month plan to prevent a steep cut in doctors fees paid by the federal health program.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: BP Ignored the Omens of Disaster
description: We have to get the priorities right, the chief executive of BP said. And Job 1 is to get to these things that have happened, get them fixed and get them sorted out. We dont just sort them out on the surface, we get them fixed deeply.

title: The Thrill Is Gone
description: President Obamas relationship with America, like many a young marriage, is growing sour.

title: Obama Hopes Recovery Summer Will Warm Voters to the Stimulus
description: The shovels are finally ready. But is anyone paying attention?

title: $3.4. Billion Guarantee for New Nuclear Plant
description: The Southern Company, the giant utility owner, agreed to a $3.4 billion federal loan guarantee to build the countrys first nuclear power plant in three decades. The guarantee covers up to 70 percent of Southerns eligible projected costs, the company said Friday. This is another step forward on the road to nuclear power playing a prominent role in Americas energy future, David Ratcliffe, the chief executive, said in a statement. Southern would be the first to receive federal aid under a five-year-old law aimed in part at helping add nuclear stations, which usually cost more and take longer to build than coal or natural-gas-fired generators. Southern plans to add two reactors to its Vogtle station near Waynesboro, Ga., in 2016 and 2017.

title: Companies Bet on Rise in Demand for Uranium
description: WASHINGTON  Uranium enrichment, the market that the Noble Group has entered with its purchase of USEC stock, is a globalized business fraught with uncertainty.

title: In California, Facing Illegal Immigration
description: In the closing days of the Republican primary in California, Meg Whitman vowed to get tough on illegal immigrants, and in a radio commercial even brought out a big gun, a former governor, Pete Wilson. He is known for his advocacy of Proposition 187, a 1994 initiative that sought to deny public services to illegal immigrants. It was blocked by a federal court, but remains a sore point with Latino voters. Now, after winning the primary, Ms. Whitman reveals her opposition to the proposal in new Spanish-language television commercials, and embraces concerns dear to Latinos.

title: Insider Leaks Tarnish Aqueduct Casino Plans
description: ALBANY  New revelations of insider leaks involving the proposal for a casino at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens have further marred a selection process that has attracted the attention of state and federal investigators.

title: Olympic Figure Skater Ilia
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  What more do I need to say about Samuel A. Donaldsons construction other than its terrific.

title: The Mets Foundation Is Not Cracked
description: How could you blame Mets fans for irrational theories? Three season-ending heartbreaks and the thorough embarrassment of 2009 could scramble the senses of even the wisest fans.

title: Bloggingheads: American War Crimes?
description: Matthew Yglesias of the Center for American Progress and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the drone strike program.

title: An Odd-Looking Hit, and an Even Stranger Path to a Penalty
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  There was a time when what happened to Shaun Micheel on the 10th hole of his round Friday at the 110th United States Open would have made him so mad he would have seethed all day.

title: City Opens East Sides First New Public School Building in 50 Years
description: With teenagers running through its shiny halls for only a few weeks, East Side Middle School still has that new-school smell.

title: Crowd Gathers to Watch Woods, but Warms to Els
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  They came in great numbers to see Tiger Woods tee off just past 8 a.m. on Friday. And within an hour, it seemed half the crowd tromping around the Pebble Beach Golf Links trailed the threesome of Woods, Ernie Els and Lee Westwood.

title: Keeping Children Out of the Fields
description: Facing new scrutiny by the Obama administration to detect underage-workers and wage violations on farms, blueberry growers in North Carolina are trying to clean up their act.

title: Turkeys Gain Is Irans Loss
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Jurors Watch Video of  Officer Hitting Man With a Baton
description: Surveillance video played before a Manhattan jury on Friday showed a police officer who is charged with assault repeatedly lashing a man with a baton even as the man lay on the floor, and again after he was handcuffed.

title: Is There a Nurse in the House?
description: Pittsburgh

title: Chamberlain Hits Another Bump in the Road
description: Tell Joba Chamberlain that it is raining, and he will be happy that the flowers will bloom. Negative thoughts never seem to leave his lips, and they did not on Friday, the day after all three batters he faced in the ninth inning scored in the Yankees 7-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Plea to Obama Led to an Immigrants Arrest
description: The letter appealing to President Obama was written in frustration in January, by a woman who saw her family reflected in his. She was a white United States citizen married to an African man, and the couple  college-educated professionals in Manhattan  were stymied in their long legal battle to keep him in the country.

title: Honda Strikers in China Offered Less Than Demanded
description: ZHONGSHAN, China  Wage negotiations between workers and managers at a Honda auto parts factory here ended on Friday night with the companys final offer of a pay increase that was substantially less than employees had been seeking, a worker involved in the discussions said.

title: Manuel Talks Softly Despite the Mets Recent Success
description: Considering the criticism he took in the first two months of the season, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel might have felt at liberty to boast about his teams recent accomplishments.

title: To Help the Little Guy, the Government Proposes New Rules for Big Meatpackers
description: The Obama administration proposed new rules on Friday seeking to increase competition and rein in potentially unfair practices by large meatpackers and poultry processors. The move is aimed at helping small livestock and poultry farmers survive in an industry dominated by corporate giants.

title: Kagans E-Mail at Clinton White House Reveals a Blunt, Savvy Legal Adviser
description: WASHINGTON  An enormous trove of e-mail messages from Elena Kagans years in the Clinton White House released late Friday afternoon offered glimpses of a savvy, sharp-elbowed and sometimes salty-tongued lawyer at ease with politics, policy and bureaucratic infighting.

title: For English Men, a Shutout in the Wimbledon Draw
description: LONDON  When Wimbledon released its draws Friday morning, attention here focused not on Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal or the Williams sisters. Instead, tennis fans here bemoaned the lack of an English mens singles player in the main draw, a first in the 133-year history of the tournament.

title: I.M.F. Backs Spains Austerity Measures
description: The International Monetary Fund gave its blessing on Friday to Spains efforts to bolster its banks and reduce its budget gap. But the fund also stressed that passage of a proposed loosening of labor market rules was crucial to stimulate flagging growth.

title: Machinery Sales Jump 11% at Caterpillar
description: Caterpillar, the worlds largest maker of construction equipment, said worldwide retail sales of machinery measured over three months rose for the first time in almost two years. Sales as reported by dealers climbed 11 percent in the period through May, the company reported Friday. The previous gain was posted in September 2008, said Jim Dugan, a spokesman. North American sales rose 15 percent in the period, the first improvement since August 2006.

title: Blumenthal Contradicts Past Remarks on the Draft
description: Recent remarks by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut recounting his enlistment in the Marine Corps Reserve did not only contradict historians accounts. They also contradicted his own previous statements on the subject.

title: Peddling Relief, Firms Put Debtors in Deeper Hole
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  For the companies that promise relief to Americans confronting swelling credit card balances, these are days of lucrative opportunity.

title: Park Domes Fenced Off to Protect Children
description: When three stainless-steel climbing domes were unveiled in Brooklyn Bridge Park in March, many parents praised their appearance. But almost right away, several reported that their childrens hands turned bright pink after touching the metal on sunny days  and word spread quickly on local blogs that the scorching-hot two-foot-high domes were to be avoided.

title: Plus-Size Revelation: Bigger Women Have Cash, Too
description: Corseted into a size 18 white denim dress, wearing heels that made her about 6-foot-2, Gwen DeVoe, a former model and fashion-show producer, stepped onto a runway in Manhattan this week and made a pitch to retailers for the plus-size woman.

title: Gay and Ready for Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Net Benefits of Biomass Power Under Scrutiny
description: GREENFIELD, Mass.  Matthew Wolfe, an energy developer with plans to turn tree branches and other woody debris into electric power, sees himself as a positive force in the effort to wean his state off of planet-warming fossil fuels.

title: Cuddling With a Child, and Listening to Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Ramirezs Return to Fenway Park Meets Everything but Indifference
description: BOSTON  Two years ago, Manny Ramirez seemed to do everything in his power to get away from Fenway Park. He slapped a teammate, shoved a team employee and took himself out of the lineup with a mysterious injury  all before the trading deadline.

title: For Some Subway Riders, an Abiding Appreciation of Rats
description: Early this week, after the city announced a new plan to combat rat infestations in subway stations, City Room asked readers to send in photographs of rats. They are still coming in, and we will publish them online early next week. But we also got something that surprised us: passionate e-mail messages defending, applauding, lauding and otherwise expressing affection for ... rats. Who knew so many New Yorkers, and others, loved their rats so much? We certainly didnt.

title: Peeking at the Negative Side of High School Popularity
description: PROM time has come and gone, and while it didnt affect me or my sons this year (Im too old, theyre too young), it still caused a reminiscent tightening in my stomach.

title: F.D.I.C. Closes Nevada Bank, 83rd Failure of Year
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Friday took over Nevada Security Bank, based in Reno, with $480.3 million in assets and $479.8 million in deposits. Umpqua Bank, of Roseburg, Ore., agreed to assume the assets and deposits. The failure is expected to cost the deposit insurance fund $80.9 million. It is the 83rd failure of the year, setting a pace more than double that of 2009.

title: Yankees Struggle as Magic Belongs to the Mets
description: There is not much of a precedent, but the Mets do not find Yankee Stadium hospitable. Their first game here last season ended with a dropped pop-up that symbolized both teams fortunes. The Mets were cursed, the Yankees charmed. The Mets would be delighted if their 4-0 victory Friday night was as prophetic. In extending their winning streak to eight games, the surging Mets stayed as sharp against one of baseballs best teams as they did against two of their worst.

title: Odd Delivery Aside, Outs Add Up for Takahashi
description: Hisanori Takahashi has his skeptics. Some say the best he can do is fool hitters who are not familiar with either his pitches or the odd hesitation in his windup.

title: Gen. Marcel Bigeard, French Hero of 3 Wars, Dies at 94
description: PARIS  Gen. Marcel Bigeard, one of Frances most decorated veterans, who led troops in the French Resistance in World War II and in wars in Algeria and Indochina, died Friday in Toul, France, where he lived. He was 94. His death was confirmed by his wife, Gabrielle Grandemange.

title: FIFA and the Drawing of Lots: A Brief History
description: If England and the United States tie their respective games next Wednesday, and the English score two more goals in their game than the Americans do in theirs, both teams will be dead even in the Group C table. According to FIFA regulations, the two will have to draw lots to see who advances and who goes home.

title: Mets Get the Jump in Subway Opener
description: Even when things seemed bleak for the Mets in the seasons first few weeks, the team saw encouraging signs. Infielder Alex Cora pointed out that the Mets were losing a lot of road games in their last at-bat, meaning they were in games until the end. Manager Jerry Manuel saw a lot of hits and figured the Mets would start making them timely.

description: Debt settlement companies offer help to individuals in financial turmoil. Peter S. Goodman reports on the growing criticism  the industry has inspired.

title: In Defense of Koman Coulibaly. Sort Of.
description: They say there is holding on every play in the N.F.L., but that the referees cant call it every time because no one would watch. The same goes for free kicks in soccer.

title: The Morning Skate: New Rule May Ban Intentional Head Shots
description: The movement to ban some checks to the head took a step forward on Friday when the N.H.L.-N.H.L.P.A. Competition Committee proposed a five-minute major penalty and a game misconduct for blindside hits to the head.

title: Celebrating the Short, Sweet Ride of Freedomland
description: Frank Adamo guided his Jeep down Bartow Avenue in the Bronx. To his left were the towers of Co-Op City. To his right, the Bay Plaza shopping center. But in his mind, he was someplace else entirely.

title: Violence Up Sharply in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With an average of an assassination a day and a suicide bombing every second or third day, insurgents have greatly increased the level of violence in Afghanistan, and have become by far the biggest killers of civilians here, the United Nations said in a report released publicly on Saturday.

title: Saturday Word: Politics of Jobless Claims and the Oil Spill
description: After a week in which Democrats failed to break a Republican filibuster on an extension of unemployment benefits  something that is usually noncontroversial in a troubled economy  both parties used their weekly national addresses to call for an end to the politicking.

title: Fan Busts In on England Dressing Room
description: Not content to boo Wayne Rooney and his England teammates after a poor 0-0 tie With Algeria on Friday, one fan barged into the locker room to give the players a dressing down while they were undressing.

title: Japans Hard Right Keeps Dolphin Film from Theaters
description: An article in The Times today shows how a small, but potent ultra-conservative faction in Japan has intimidated theater owners pondering showing The Cove, the Oscar-winning documentary that revealed in bloody detail the annual roundup of dolphins by a Japanese town and the slaughter of the animals that dont get auctioned to dolphin shows and aquariums.

description: Roger Federer may be the best mens tennis player in history. Or he may not be as good as his contemporary rival Rafael Nadal.
