description: Ive always had a passion for sales even though I really never had a sales background. When I redefined my role as chief executive last year, I made the decision that I could no longer be the only one responsible for sales if we were to start scaling this company aggressively. This meant that I needed to start relying on others to make these deals happen.

title: He Forgot to Leave Tickets for the Queen
description: At 96, Gardnar Mulloy recalled the most impressive incident of my life as if it were yesterday. It was on Centre Court at Wimbledon in 1957 as Mulloy was receiving the cup for the mens doubles title from Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Still a Fan, Just With a Shorter Favorite Player
description: I trained hard for the World Cup, and I like to think Im in better shape than I was for the 2006 tournament  as a fan, and as a father.

title: In the Arizona Desert, Promise Tumbles Away
description: Chase Field, the home of the Arizona Diamondbacks, feels like a giant airplane hangar and sits close to Sky Harbor International Airport in Phoenix. So General Manager Josh Byrnes picked an apt analogy to describe his once-promising team.

title: Al Kaline: A Star Who Knew to Hit the Cutoff
description: Al Kaline, a Hall of Fame outfielder for the Detroit Tigers, retired in 1974 with a career batting average of .297, 3,007 hits, 399 home runs and 1,583 runs batted in. Kaline, 75, now a special assistant to the Tigers president, Dave Dombrowski, was in Manhattan in May. He accepted the Vin Scully Lifetime Achievement Award in Sports Broadcasting on behalf of Ernie Harwell, the longtime Tigers broadcaster who died just before the presentation. The award is sponsored by WFUV, Fordham Universitys radio station.

title: No Pro Baseball in Montreal, and Little Hope of Any
description: MONTREAL  The game resembled baseball as best an 8-year-olds skirmish can. The Beloeil Braves and the Boucherville Seigneurs smacked grounders and attempted double plays in full uniform, with batting gloves dangling out of their back pockets. Just like the pros.

title: Legislative Hurdles in an Era of Conflict
description: WASHINGTON  It was a little-noted vote on an unremarkable bill, but it spoke volumes about the current state of Congress.

title: Kimmel: More Important Priorities
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Sarah Palin was on the Fox Business Network and surprised a lot of people by calling marijuana quote, a minimal problem in America. She said law enforcement has more important priorities than arresting people smoking pot in their homes and also admitted that she herself has tried pot, which could explain some of the things that shes said over the years. Its not Sarah, its old baked Alaska talking.

title: China Signals a Gradual Rise in Value of Its Currency
description: HONG KONG  China announced on Saturday evening that it would allow greater flexibility in the value of its currency, a move that could deflect growing international criticism of its economic policies and defuse one of the greatest sources of tension between Beijing and Washington.

title: Fallon: An Unprecedented Combination of Failures
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Tonight, Im not going to do any jokes about oil spill related news. I thought it might be nice to just pretend for a few minutes that the oil spill isnt happening. You know, kind of like B.P. does.

title: Ferguson: 100 Times More Water
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Did you know that NASA says theres 100 times more water on the moon than they first thought? In fact, there is so much water on the moon that B.P. is planning to go up there and ruin it.

title: Letterman: They Could Go Out of Business
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: There are rumors now that the C.E.O. of British Petroleum is saying they could go out of business. And I thought, well, yeah, great. But if they go out of business, who will be in charge of not stopping the leak?

title: Fighting Words
description: Representative Joe L. Barton, Republican of Texas, condemned a White House deal that requires BP to establish a $20 billion fund for victims of the oil spill.

title: Leno: They Cant Wait for the Oil
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Lets see whats going on with B.P. C.E.O. Tony Hayward, otherwise known as the lying king.

title: Prime Number
description: 62: The proposed new retirement age in France, as of 2018. Raising the age from 60 is essential to reduce the nations debt, the French government said. As onerous as it may seem to the French, 62 looks pretty good to other Europeans. In Britain, Spain and Italy, youve got to work until youre 65. Germany recently raised its retirement age by two years, to 67. The French Parliament must approve the change; a summer of demonstrations and strikes is likely.

title: E-Mail: Press Delete
description: Life without e-mail? The day may be coming, according to Sheryl Sandberg, Facebooks chief operating officer. Only 11 percent of teenagers use e-mail daily, Ms. Sandberg told Nielsens Consumer 360 conference last week. Teenagers increasingly use text messaging and social networking sites to communicate  a shift that Ms. Sandberg said pointed to what people like us will do tomorrow. That is good news for businesses, said Fast Company, which reported on the conference. Personal e-mail addresses are tough for businesses to get. Its easier for businesses to connect with consumers on services like Facebook, which has 400 million members and 100 million daily mobile users.

To even keep her safely in the hospital for a night  shes got to go on bed rest  is going to be a huge struggle for him financially. But Mindys stripper friends rally together to offer their services for free to raise money for her treatment. title: Rise in Value of Currency to Be Slow, China Insists
description: HONG KONG  A day after announcing that it would allow a more flexible currency, China said on Sunday that any appreciation in its value would be gradual, and it set the renminbis value in early trading on Monday at the same level as it traded on Friday.

title: The Fathers Day Balance Sheet
description: The meaning of Fathers Day has changed for me over the years. My father has been gone a couple of years now, and my kids are almost out of the house. Ive been a father for 28 years, an entrepreneur for 32. As with any demanding job, balancing the responsibilities of parenthood with the responsibilities of the business has been a challenge. My perspective has changed, and I write todays post for the benefit (I hope) of younger parents, fathers and mothers, who are dealing with this struggle.

The main thing that made the Canadian race so good was Bridgestones tire choice, which caused problems for the teams as they had a hard time putting heat into the tires in the lower-than-predicted temperatures and on the smooth track surface.

He will back up the referee Carlos Batres of Guatemala for the Group F encounter.

title: Lady Power
description: If you want to get a bead on the state of feminism these days, look no further than the ubiquitous pop star Lady Gaga. Last summer, after identifying herself as a representative for sexual, strong women who speak their mind, the 23-year-old Gaga seemed to embrace the old canard that a feminist is by definition a man-hater when she told a Norwegian journalist, Im not a feminist. I hail men! I love men! But by December she was praising the journalist Ann Powers, in a profile in The Los Angeles Times, for being a little bit of a feminist, like I am. She continued, When I say to you, there is nobody like me, and there never was, that is a statement I want every woman to feel and make about themselves. Apparently, even though she loves men  she hails them!  she is a little bit of a feminist because she exemplifies what it looks like for a woman to say, and to believe, that theres nobody like her.

title: Teixeiras Slam Gives Sabathia All He Needs

Winners of seven straight over all, they had beaten the Yankees on Friday night and had their two best pitchers, Mike Pelfrey and Johan Santana, ready to take the mound on the weekend.

title: Like a Tight Relay Team Handing Off the Baton
description: At several points during Fridays show at Symphony Space by an ad-hoc band called the Jazz Gallery All-Stars, an ancient ritual took place. Over a repeating cycle of chords, the saxophonist Miguel Zenn took a solo. Then the bassist Ben Williams took a solo, then the trumpeter Roy Hargrove, then the guitarist Lage Lund. It didnt always happen in that order, and others were sometimes involved. The pianist Gerald Clayton. The trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire. The hand-drums percussionist Pedro Martinez. The drummer Kendrick Scott. The singer Claudia Acua.

title: Veterans Finding Their Way
description: It took a while for Keith Jarrett to locate his muse at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. From his station at the piano he worked through familiar cycles of theme and variations with his longtime partners, the bassist Gary Peacock and the drummer Jack DeJohnette. The music in the concerts first half was sympathetic and duly elegant but also vaguely unsettled, even a bit labored. When intermission arrived  abruptly, after well under an hour  it registered as a relief. There was still time to regain the lead.

title: Carefully Constructed Program in a Floating Hall
description: Some performers try to dazzle you with their brilliance and charisma. Others, though just as accomplished, take a more self-effacing approach to making music. That group includes the superb violinist Miranda Cuckson and the exemplary pianist Steven Beck, two young performers who teamed up for a deeply satisfying recital at Bargemusic in Brooklyn on Friday night.

title: The Roommates: Updike and Christopher Lasch
description: John Updikes letters display youthful eruptions of self-doubt fed by his Harvard roommate, Christopher Lasch, an equally ambitious provincial (by way of Omaha and Chicago) who would go on to become a renowned historian and social critic. The two freshmen sized each other up instantly.

title: Literary Ore of Updike, Do-It-Yourself Man of Letters
description: In the mid-1960s, when John Updike began giving selected papers to the Houghton Library at Harvard University, they were cataloged and, for the most part, made available to researchers. But after an amendment to the tax law in 1969 eliminated the sizable deductions authors reaped from such donations, Updike, though he continued to deposit papers, did so only for warehousing purposes. He retained ownership of this material and let very few look at it. The calculation was proprietary. His literary cosmos was still expanding, and he was loath to expose its workings.

title: John Updikes Archive: A Great Writer at Work
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  When John Updike died of lung cancer in January 2009, at 76, there seemed little left to learn about him. Not only was he among the most prolific writers of his time, but he was also among the most autobiographical, recasting the details of his life in an outpouring of fiction, poetry, essays and criticism that appeared with metronomic regularity in the pages of The New Yorker and in books published at a rate of almost one a year for more than half a century.

description: The tens of thousands of engraved cream-colored diplomas that New York high school graduates will receive this week can trace their birth to an old-fashioned source: an ink-splattered, cluttered printing workshop in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: Time, Thrashing to Its Own Rock Beat
description: A music mogul named Lou is one of the many characters who drift through Jennifer Egans spiky, shape-shifting new book, A Visit From the Goon Squad. Whether this tough, uncategorizable work of fiction is a novel, a collection of carefully arranged interlocking stories or simply a display of Ms. Egans extreme virtuosity, the same characters pop up in different parts of it. Lou is a case in point. He appears early and then burns through a few of Ms. Egans adjacent (though not consecutive) chapters, ending up very much the worse for wear.

title: Litmus Test in Primary: Overhauled Drug Laws
description: For many Democrats in Albany, it was a landmark achievement: the long-sought overhaul of New Yorks strict Rockefeller-era drug laws, repealing mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenders that critics said disproportionately and unfairly fell on blacks and Latinos.

title: Ink Gushes in Japans Media Landscape
description: TOKYO  For years, the online newspaper JanJan News mounted a scrappy challenge to Japans blandly conformist press, offering articles written by readers who took on taboo subjects like whaling and the medias collusion with the government. But the site never attracted enough readers or advertising and was finally forced to shut down most of its operations three months ago.

title: Before Trial, Bush Reflects. Or Does He?
description: The problem with When We Go Upon the Sea is not that its yet another derisive play about George W. Bush. Nor is it that the playwright Lee Blessing (A Walk in the Woods, Cobb) offers a liberal fantasy of Mr. Bush on trial for war crimes. The real trouble, dramatically speaking, is that this Bush character (played by Conan McCarty, with perfect squinting eyes) doesnt do anything of interest. He doesnt engage in soul-searching or in an elaborate defense of his presidency  or anything else that might cause much conflict. He just generally acts smug.

title: Razing the City to Save the City
description: DETROIT  For generations, residents of this hollowed-out city hoped that somehow Detroit could be reborn  its population would return and its crumbling core would be rebuilt. No idea was more heretical than widespread demolition of thousands of derelict buildings.

title: Mejia Gets Good News: Hes Going to Minors
description: Rarely has a player been so upbeat about hearing that he would be sent down to the minor leagues. But Mets reliever Jenrry Mejia knows it is the best path for his long-term goal to be a starting pitcher.

title: A Day in the Life Lyrics Sell for $1.2. Million
description: Lyrics handwritten by John Lennon for a song on the Beatles Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band album sold for $1.2 million at Sothebys auction house in New York on Friday, The Associated Press reported, exceeding Sothebys presale estimate of $500,000 to $800,000. A scrawled version of A Day in the Life appears on one side of the single sheet of paper, with revisions, corrections and annotations; on the other side is a cleaner version in mostly all caps, above. The corrected version adds the phrase I love to turn you on, which helped to get the song banned in Britain by the BBC when the album was released in 1967 because of the lines implication of drug use. (The lyrics differ slightly in the finished recording.) The album won four Grammy Awards in 1968. Sothebys would not release the name of the purchaser, who made the winning bid by phone.

title: South African Artist to Receive Kyoto Prize
description: The South African visual artist William Kentridge will receive Japans Kyoto Prize in Arts and Philosophy, the Inamori Foundation announced on Friday. The foundation, in Kyoto, Japan, honors individuals who have made significant contributions to the betterment of society. Mr. Kentridge is best known for his animated films, which he calls drawings in motion, about the history and social circumstances of postcolonial South Africa, which he began sketching from charcoals and pastels in the 1980s. The foundation praised Mr. Kentridge, above, in a statement on its Web site for his originality as an artist whose wide-ranging activities encompass drawing, animation, stage direction and writing. It continued, His deep insights and profound reflections on the nature of human existence provide opportunities to consider fundamental issues that could face any individual in the world. Mr. Kentridge joins two other winners: Dr. Shinya Yamanaka, a Japanese medical scientist who will be awarded the prize for advanced technology, and the Hungarian mathematician Laszlo Lovasz, who will receive the award for basic sciences. Each recipient will be given a diploma, a gold medal and about $550,000 during a week of ceremonies in Kyoto, beginning on Nov. 9.

title: Debut Novel Wins Major Literary Award
description: The Twin, the debut novel of the Dutch author Gerbrand Bakker, has won the 2010 International Impac Dublin Literary Award, besting the well-published authors Marilynne Robinson (Home) and Joseph ONeill (Netherland). The Impac award, organized by Dublin City Public Libraries and chosen from submissions by libraries in 43 countries, will earn Mr. Bakker, a sometime gardener and skating instructor, more than $123,000, almost $31,000 of which will be given to the books translator, David Colmer. Its wonderful, Mr. Bakker told The Guardian while in Dublin on Thursday to receive his prize. But for me it was also wonderful to read the book in English. I said to David the translator, Who wrote this book? I didnt recognize it. I thought it was very good. It made me realize it really is a book, and I am a writer. The Twin is about a man who resigns himself to taking over his familys farm in the remote Dutch countryside after his twin brother dies in a car accident. It was first published by Uitgeverij Cossee in Amsterdam in 2006 and published in English in Britain two years later by Harvill Secker. This is the third year in a row that a debut novel has won.

title: Anything Goes Returns To Broadway
description: Reno Sweeney is steaming back to New York. Twenty-three years after its last Broadway revival, Anything Goes will return in February in a Roundabout Theater Company production starring the Tony Award winner Sutton Foster (Thoroughly Modern Millie), right, as Reno, the nightclub singer aboard an ocean liner of colorful characters created by Cole Porter (music and lyrics) and Guy Bolton, P. G. Wodehouse, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse (book). Kathleen Marshall will direct and choreograph the show, at a Broadway theater to be named later, Roundabout plans to announce on Monday. (Ms. Marshall won a Tony for choreography for her last outing for Roundabout, the 2006 revival of The Pajama Game, starring Harry Connick Jr.) The 1934 musical, which features songs like Youre the Top, I Get a Kick Out of You and the title number, starred Ethel Merman as Reno; its only previous Broadway revival, in 1987, starred Patti LuPone as Reno, Howard McGillin as the lovesick Billy Crocker, and Bill McCutcheon as the gangster Moonface Martin. The opening-night date and additional casting will be announced later. Todd Haimes, Roundabouts artistic director, said in a statement that this revival would not be in line with the current Broadway trend of scaled-down musical revivals, most recently La Cage aux Folles and A Little Night Music. Noting that the show is a big ensemble piece, he said, I dont think you can do Anything Goes properly without embracing its size.

title: Numberplay: Spooky Action at a Distance
description: After my whimsical travels of the last week, it is good to come back to Numberplay (incidentally, we finally have this convenient URL that you can bookmark to get access to all Numberplay posts). In todays post, I will leave all whimsy aside, and show you that the universe we inhabit is stranger that our fictitious imaginings. Today we will explore a fundamental and almost unbelievable result of Quantum Mechanics (QM) through a set of simple puzzles. This famous result is Bells Interconnectedness Theorem which was discovered by the physicist John Stewart Bell in 1964. Bells theorem has been called by physicist Henry Stapp the most profound discovery of Science. It is profound because it shows that the universe has the property of non-locality: two particles can be light years apart, yet they are linked to each other instantaneously. How instantaneously? Recent measurements have shown that this phenomenon occurs more than 10,000 times the speed of light! In order to show that the universe in non-local, Bell showed that a certain simple and obvious inequality  Bells inequality  is violated. Amazingly, the only math that you need to understand this profound inequality is contained in the following simple problem.

title: The Secret Frontrunner

Ariel Levys profile of Huckabee, in this weeks New Yorker, lines up plenty of reasons why this might be flat wrong, from Huckabees proven inability to raise money or organize a ground game, to his perpetually-simmering war with the conservative establishment, to his tendency to self-pigeonhole (his protests to the contrary notwithstanding) as the candidate of Southern evangelicals and only Southern evangelicals. (Theres also the fact that he might just be happier as a well-compensated entertainer than as a politician.) But Levy also captures many of the qualities that make Huckabee more formidable than many handicappers acknowledge: His immense charm and relentless niceness, his intense bond with one of the G.O.P.s largest constituencies, his high favorable numbers among Republican voters and his strength in early polls. title: Wanted: Ideas for a New Stop Sign
description: Two weeks ago, we wrote about Gary Lauder, a venture capitalist in California who had devised a new take on the stop sign, which he presented at a TED Talk in February.

title: Critics Picks Video: Dazed and Confused
description: Schools out, now what? Thats the central question asked by this weeks Critics Pick, Dazed and Confused, Richard Linklaters period look at high school life in 1976. Mr. Scott praises the films soundtrack and Mr. Linklaters attention to authenticity when recreating the looks, clothes and mood of the era. He also makes note of the films pacing, saying it has a meandering, almost haphazard structure. Youre not sure who youre going to run into next or where youre going to end up, which, of course, is what life is like when school is out. Have you seen Dazed and Confused? Please share your thoughts.

title: Disney Seeks to Take Its Phineas and Ferb Cartoon Hit to Next Level
description: LOS ANGELES  Picture the early days of SpongeBob SquarePants  before the theme park tie-ins, the movies and the merchandising blitz. Back when it was just a goofy animated show that somehow developed a loyal audience.

title: Seabrooks Lawyer Notes a Possible Conflict
description: The lawyer for City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook informed a federal judge on Monday that he might have a conflict of interest with a potential witness, which could further disrupt a case that has already been troubled by delays.

title: Forward March!
description: Q. A student of neurology told me that a child of 3 or 4 months has lower-limb muscles ready to walk, but cannot because the inner ear (the vestibular system) is not yet developed, and that it is only at 11 or 12 months that the child can stand and walk because the inner ear has developed sufficiently. Is this true?

title: Protests Over Power Shortages Force Iraqi Minister to Quit
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs electricity minister abruptly resigned Monday evening because of growing public outrage over the relentless power shortage crisis in the country, which exploded into violent weekend demonstrations that carried into the first day of summers 110-degree heat.

title: Bidding Farewell to Ghosts of Pain
description: Early each morning I deal myself a daily hand of pills: Wellbutrin (450 milligrams) and Zoloft (200 mg) to ply the capricious oceans of postcancer depression, Provigil (200 mg) to keep exhaustion at bay and a chewable orange baby aspirin (81 mg) as a sweet and modest hedge against a heart attack.

title: Rat Daddies
description: Just a quick note to say that since Nicks Thursday column, which proposed giant bomb-sniffing, Tuberculosis-detecting rats as alternatives to more traditional Fathers Day gifts, Apopo, the organization behind the so-called HeroRATS, has received more than $150,000 in donations. And according to Mari Kuraishi, president of GlobalGiving.org, an online donations company that sponsors projects around the world like Apopo, an additional $30,000 went to non-rat-related enterprises.

title: In Search of a Good Wine List
description: My column is on American gewrztraminer, a category that got me to wondering whether anybody drinks much gewrztraminer these days. I dont drink it too often myself, although I do love bringing a bottle of good gewrztraminer with me when I go to Phoenix Garden, one of my favorite places in New York for excellent Cantonese food.

title: The Fossil Record of Prehistoric Gnawing
description: Small mammals have been gnawing on bones for calcium and protein to supplement their diet for 75 million years, according to a report on the oldest known evidence of gnawing: on dinosaur bones.

title: Damselfish Cultivate Their Algae Gardens
description: Gardeners who are vigilant against weeds may have a newfound appreciation for damselfish, which, a  new study reports, are diligent weeders of algae gardens in coral reefs around the world.

title: Ancient Mesoamericas Rubber Industry
description: The Mesoamericans were robust users of rubber, according to historical and archaeological records. With it they made sandals, rubber bands and also balls, which they used to play a ceremonial game in stone-walled courts.

title: Resort Scorecard | Stella McCartney Wins!
description: When did resort become a fully fledged season (like those divisions of the year, spring and fall, that actually represent a change in weather)? About that, were not sure exactly. But as the fash pack has been busy since before Memorial Day taking in the 67 shows/presentations/European house reshowings/roving street-sides, Scorecard has, as ever, kept tabs on all the critic talk for you. One things for certain: when reviewing collections intended expressly to lure the dollars of women who winter in the urban jungle, qualities like prettiness, wearableness and merchiness are suddenly very good things.

title: Under Pressure, Commission Discusses Lifting Whaling Ban
description: The International Whaling Commission on Monday began what promises to be a contentious, high-stakes meeting in Morocco on whether to maintain a 24-year-old moratorium on commercial whaling in the face of pressure from Japan, Norway and Iceland to permit the hunt.

title: Updike Typewriter for Sale
description: John Updikes papers may have gone to Harvard, but his typewriter could be yours. Christies will auction off on Tuesday an Olympia electric 65c typewriter and metal typewriter cart that belonged to the late novelist. The estimate is $4,000-$6,000. The serial number indicates that Updike probably purchased the typewriter while his family lived in London, from 1968 to 1969, shortly after he wrote Couples. He gave it to one of his daughters about 15 years before his death in 2009. A member of the writers family is selling the typewriter now and will donate half the proceeds from the sale to the New York Public Library.

title: Pharaohs Are Given an Update
description: A new study provides detailed information about the timeline of ancient Egypts Old, Middle and New Kingdoms using radiocarbon dating.

title: English Man Who Killed as a Child Accused of Downloading Child Pornography
description: On Monday, a British court made public new charges against a man who had been convicted of killing a 2-year-old boy in 1993, when he was just 10 years old himself, and then released from prison in 2001 and given a new identity.

title: Dent Charges Into the Second Round
description: WIMBLEDON, England - Taylor Dent of the United States serves, rushes the net, and volleys winners with the abandon of a 20th century player who doesnt realize the 21st century game of tennis favors duels from the baseline.

title: Discovering the Wonders of Skin Cells
description: Q. OVER THE YEARS, WHAT HAS BEEN THE DISCOVERY YOU ARE MOST PROUD OF?

title: Nice View. How About a Game of Chess?
description: A bit late, but maybe worth the wait.

title: Hallucinations in the Hospital
description: Hospital stays can be disorienting for any patient, but for some elderly patients the experience is particularly risky, triggering an unusual phenomenon called hospital delirium. As New York Times reporter Pam Belluck explains, these frightening hallucinations can be triggered by medicine, infection, surgery or even simple medical procedures.

title: In Price War, E-Readers Go Below $200
description: A price war is brewing in the growing market for electronic reading devices.

title: I Love My Wife (Hmm, Now How Can I Kill Her?)
description: Adam Rosss Mr. Peanut is a dark, dazzling and deeply flawed novel that announces the debut of an enormously talented writer. An account of three troubled marriages, the book is a Rubiks cube of a story that reads like a postmodern mash-up of Tolstoys  Kreutzer Sonata,  Edward Albees "Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? and one of James M. Cains noirish mysteries.

title: The Best Games of E3: From New Halo to Epic Mickey Mouse
description: The new technologies from Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony provided the most important news from the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles last week, but there were plenty of exciting new games on display as well. No one person is able to see anything close to everything at E3  the show is just too big  but these are some of titles coming in the next year that appeared particularly interesting and impressive.

title: Labor Rule Changes Expected to Advance in Spain
description: MADRID  The Spanish government was expected to secure parliamentary approval Tuesday for its planned labor market overhaul despite concerns among economists that the changes would do little to alleviate Spains unemployment burden.

title: Now Screening | Gucci
description: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Spanish Press Blasts English Paper for Nonsense About Goalkeepers Girlfriend
description: Before Spains 2-0 victory over Honduras on Monday moved it back into contention for a spot in the final 16, the nations news media spilled a lot of ink, and pixels, defending the national teams captain and goalkeeper, Iker Casillas. As The Lede blog explained on Friday, last week Casillas was the victim of an apparently baseless rumor started by a report in The Times of London, which claimed that many in Spain said the team was in crisis because its keeper was too distracted by the beauty of his girlfriend, a sideline reporter for Spanish television, to do his job properly.

title: Ex-Citi Trader, Hall, Raises $1 Billion
description: Andrew J. Hall, the former Citigroup energy trader whose proposed $100 million bonus created an uproar about excessive Wall Street compensation, has raised $1.08 billion for an offshore version of his hedge fund, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Candidates for Attorney General Make Their Case
description: The five Democratic candidates vying to become New Yorks top prosecutor gathered together for the first time on Monday to make their cases.

title: I See England, I See France
description: The amateur pantomime that is Englands 2010 World Cup campaign took another theatrical turn on Monday, perhaps more entertaining in its way than the mercy flight of WAGs winging its way to South Africa in defiance of Coach Fabio Capellos ban on wives and girlfriends.

title: The World of Percy Jackson Lives On In The Lost Hero
description: Human children arent the only ones who enjoy summer camp: the offspring of the Greek gods have a getaway all their own, though nondivine readers will have to wait until the fall to catch up on their adventures there. The publisher Disney Hyperion said on Monday that it would release The Lost Hero, a new work by Rick Riordan, the author of the hit Percy Jackson & the Olympians adventure series, as well as The Red Pyramid, s childrens best seller. The new young-adult novel will be the first in a Heroes of Olympus series that will bring existing Percy Jackson heroes and new characters together at Camp Half-Blood, the training ground for demigods. Mr. Riordan said on Monday that he had been contemplating this series well before completing the previous one. I knew already that there was more to the story that I wouldnt be able to fit into the arc, Mr. Riordan said in a telephone interview. Really, its a balancing act between wanting Percy Jackson to have a strong ending and acknowledging that there are a lot of fans out there who werent ready to say to goodbye to that world. The Lost Hero will go on sale Oct. 12.

title: National Academy Museum To Renovate
description: The National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts will close its Beaux Arts museum building, on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, on Sunday to renovate its exhibition galleries and create a new visitor center and a school studio gallery. The project, to be announced on Tuesday, will modernize the galleries for the first time in more than 100 years, providing dedicated space for the semipermanent exhibition of works from the academys collection of more than 7,000 paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures by American artists and architects. The renovation is part of the academys larger effort to address some of the problems that forced it to sell two important Hudson River School paintings in 2008 to pay its bills. Because of its strict policies against deaccessioning art to pay operating costs, the Association of Art Museum Directors advised other museums to cut off all loans to the 184-year-old academy and forgo any collaborations. During the renovations  expected to be completed in September 2011  the academy will continue to host its evening roundtable discussion, The Review Panel, and the school will maintain a full class schedule, both on the premises.

title: For Next Season, American Idol Says the Kids Are All Right
description: The next season of American Idol isnt officially subtitled The Search for the Next Justin Bieber, but one wonders if that teenage pop sensation had any influence on a newly announced adjustment to the reality contests rules. On Monday the producers of American Idol announced that they would lower the minimum age of eligibility for the singing competition to 15, the Idol host Ryan Seacrest said on his Web site, ryanseacrest.com. In previous years the minimum age for Idol hopefuls was 16, but now performers like Aaron Kelly and Haeley Vaughn (who were well shy of voting age when they appeared on the shows ninth season) will look like seasoned war horses compared to the 10th seasons crop. Sorry, Larry Platt, but you still cant officially compete on the show: the maximum age remains 28. The Idol producers also said that the shows next round of auditions would begin on July 17 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Auditions will continue through the summer in Milwaukee; New Orleans; East Rutherford, N.J.; and Austin, Tex., before concluding in San Francisco on Aug. 19. And to answer your next question: No, a replacement for Simon Cowell, the outgoing American Idol judge, has not been announced.

title: Red Recovers Its Investment
description: Red, the 2010 Tony Award winner for best play, has recouped its $2.25 million production costs after 14 weeks of performances on Broadway, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday. That financial benchmark makes Red one of a handful of plays from the 2009-10 Broadway season that earned back their investors money, among them the revivals of Fences and A View From the Bridge and the new plays Race and A Steady Rain. Red, a two-character drama by John Logan about the artist Mark Rothko (played by Alfred Molina, right, standing), won six Tony Awards overall this month, including best director (Michael Grandage), best featured actor in a play (Eddie Redmayne, above, kneeling) and best set for a play (Christopher Oram). The production is to close on Sunday after 101 regular performances and 22 previews, an unusually short run for a best -lay Tony recipient. This was necessary, Ms. Madover has said, because the two stars had commitments, and she did not want to recast their roles.

title: Wnyc Hires a Vice President
description: The radio station WNYC  now officially known as New York Public Radio  has hired Graham Parker, the executive director of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, to run its classical music arm, WQXR-FM (105.9). Mr. Parker will have the title of vice president, a newly created job that more sharply defines the stations profile. WNYC, which acquired WQXR nine months ago in a deal with The New York Times, said WQXR would continue to operate Q2, an Internet stream where the station presents most of its contemporary music programming and broadcasts live concerts. Mr. Parker was hired even though New York Public Radio is still a bit more than two-thirds of the way toward raising $15 million for the acquisition and start-up costs. Laura R. Walker, the president and chief executive, said the appointment was not adding another layer but rather a move she had long envisioned. In fact, its a pretty lean staff, she said. The audience for the station is very high, and it deserves its own leader. Orpheus said that its general manager, Jim Bredeson, would be acting executive director while a replacement is sought.

title: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
description: If its Monday, Scorecard must be in Milan. Resort may have just wrapped for the ladies, but as our color-coded master fashion calendar reminds us, its time to get up to speed on the spring 2011 mens-wear shows, which is why weve pulled double duty reading all the reviews so you dont have to. Between John Varvatoss 10th-anniversary rocker-chic redux and Dolce & Gabbanas 20th-anniversary Sicilian sartorial extravaganza, this weekend designers were taking a long look back. Yet it was Raf Simonss Koonsian pastiche for Jil Sander, which was actually shown in Florence last Thursday as part of Pitti Uomo, that blew everyone else out of the water, reminding us that granddad-like isnt necessarily chic. Celebration, indeed.

title: At Ground Zero, a Step Forward On Performing Arts Center
description: At its board meeting on Tuesday the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve an agreement under which it will be reimbursed by the city for the cost of building infrastructure below the planned performing arts center at ground zero. The construction of footings and foundations for the arts center has been estimated at $44 million. The authority, which owns the World Trade Center site, and the city have said that they expect that money to come from a $50 million fund controlled by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The development corporation has been working toward an alternative plan: moving the arts center to the Deutsche Bank building site at 130 Liberty Street, which the corporation owns and where it believes that the arts center can be built much faster and more cheaply. The city has argued for the importance of honoring the original master plan for ground zero, which calls for a performing arts center in the area bounded by Fulton, Greenwich, Vesey and Washington Streets  the architect Frank Gehry was selected in 2004 to design the building for its anchor tenant, the Joyce Theater. The Port Authoritys plan to address the infrastructure issue is a tangible sign that the performing arts center is moving forward, Linda Shelton, executive director of the Joyce, said on Monday. There were a lot of skeptics that this wouldnt happen, but this is a great step forward. The Port Authority and the development corporation declined to comment on their expectations for Tuesdays meeting.

title: Carlyles Booz Allen Plans $300 Million I.P.O.
description: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm taken private less than two years ago by the Carlyle Group, is planning an initial public offering to raise as much as $300 million, Bloomberg News reports, providing another sign that the I.P.O. market appears to be thawing out from its chill earlier this year.

title: Answers From the Investigative Team
description: Following are responses from David Barstow, one of the reporters who examined the lax oversight of the oil rigs blowout preventer.

title: Maurice and Marlene: Love Story Retold
description: Dont assume from the title Dietrich & Chevalier: The Musical that youre going to get diamonds and white tie and old Euro-Hollywood glamour. You are, to some degree. But if you see the show, at St. Lukes Theater, youre also going to get Nazis: edicts from Hitler, cheery messages from Goebbels (reichsminister for enlightenment) and threats from French collaborators. And theyre a lot more interesting than the pallid little romance.

title: Joo Gilberto Concert at Carnegie Hall Canceled
description: Because of international travel restrictions, the Joo Gilberto concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as part of the CareFusion Jazz Festival has been canceled. George Wein, the producer of the festival, said in a statement: I am heartbroken over this unfortunate situation. Joao Gilberto is one of the most important musical artists of our generation, and it has always been a privilege to present him at Carnegie Hall. Tickets will be refunded where they were purchased.

title: Eminem Reasserts His Core Values
description: Maybe there should never have been room for Eminem in the first place.

title: Cold, Dark and Teeming With Life
description: The deep seabed was once considered a biological desert. Life, the logic went, was synonymous with light and photosynthesis. The sun powered the planets food chains, and only a few scavengers could ply the preternaturally dark abyss.

title: Take Your Time, Crime Will Wait
description: Slow Food, a movement that began in Italy in the 1980s as a protest against agribusiness and fast food, promotes organic farming and regional cooking. That cult of less-is-more parochialism spread to other fields, including tourism (Slow Travel) and investment (Slow Money).

title: Poll Finds Deep Concern About Energy and Economy
description: Overwhelmingly, Americans think the nation needs a fundamental overhaul of its energy policies, and most expect alternative forms to replace oil as a major source within 25 years. Yet a majority are unwilling to pay higher gasoline prices to help develop new fuel sources.

title: For Final Bow, a Shower of Flowers and Adoration
description: Its difficult to be phlegmatic when a packed theater is cheering for you, with dazzled fans calling out your name in rock-star fashion. But Albert Evans more than managed it Sunday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, when he danced the third (Phlegmatic) variation of The Four Temperaments for the final time as a New York City Ballet principal. They dont call them old pros for nothing.

title: A Box-Office Bump for Tony Winners
description: The Broadway productions Memphis and Red  the winners of the 2010 Tony Awards for best musical and best play, respectively  each enjoyed box-office bumps of about 20 percent last week in the immediate afterglow of the CBS telecast on June 13, according to Broadway box-office data released on Monday.

title: Back to the Cabaret, With Stories From a Long Career
description: At 76 Tammy Grimes has amassed a lifetime of stories and loves to tell them. She was discovered singing in a cabaret by Nol Coward, knew she would marry Christopher Plummer the first time she saw him onstage (and she did), was the first and in some peoples minds the only Unsinkable Molly Brown (sorry, Debbie Reynolds), and once showered with a young Marlon Brando.

title: The Love of a Father (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Reality TV Show Faces Ultimate Test
description: Reality TV has brought birth, dating, marriage, divorce, drinking, dieting, hiring, firing and old age into American homes. And now, death.

title: A Call for Preservation (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Work of Being First, Expectations Attached
description: It makes a kind of sense to take a didactic approach to a story about education. Thats what Charles Smith has done in Freed, his play about a former slave attending college in the 1820s. Some scenes take their cues from the Socratic method, others are point-counterpoint or stand and deliver, but almost all involve two people exchanging ideas or arguing. Thats the plays strength and its weakness.

title: Teens and Online Video (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Unions for All: Pentagon Federal
description: In response to my column about big credit unions with loosey-goosey membership rules, one reader wrote in to chastise me for not offering more details on which credit unions specifically tended to have the best deals.

title: Leave-Takings Above a Bar in Brooklyn
description: In his documentaries The Boys of 2nd Street Park, Ring of Fire and Crazy Love, Dan Klores established himself as a keen observer of specific New York stories, with a solid grasp of sociohistorical context. But specificity and context are two things missing from his first full-length play, Little Doc, which opened on Thursday night at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

title: Surviving a Spouse (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethnic Uzbeks Find Calm but Fear for Those Still Behind
description: KARASU, Uzbekistan  I have three children  9, 7 and 4 years old  and they are just in shock, a woman named Ursanoy Mamadaliyeva said on Monday. My youngest said to me, Mama, if we return to Kyrgyzstan, then you have to buy me an automatic weapon.

title: A Brazilian Makes Playful but Serious Art
description: At the New Museum last Friday the artist Rivane Neuenschwander was on her knees, slicing up the carpeting in a third-floor gallery as she searched energetically for microphones hidden in the floorboards and walls. A security and surveillance team had secreted the bugs there at her request, but without her knowing their locations; now the devices were recording her hunt in the otherwise silent room, in preparation for a fast-approaching show.

title: Academic Series in Jazzy Surroundings
description: Maybe location really is everything. When Mannes College the New School for Music presents its annual summer festival concerts in its auditorium on the Upper West Side, they seem low key and academic, no matter how vividly played and well attended they are. But following in the footsteps of the Keys to the Future festival, which was held at the similarly quaint Greenwich House Music School until this year, Mannes has moved a few of the concerts in its Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance to Le Poisson Rouge.

title: Improvisational and Atmospheric Dialogues: A Tribute to an Avant-Gardist
description: The avant-garde composer and multireedist Anthony Braxton had plenty of words for his admirers at Le Poisson Rouge on Friday night, when it was officially his turn to take the stage. He talked about the striving of noncommercial artists. He referred to geopolitical dynamics, adding that the world was still full of men and women of goodwill. He expressed appreciation for the costume splendor of Lady Gaga. And finally he struck a note of retirement-party humor: If you have to be 65, this is the best way to do it.

title: Outer Court Heaven, Away From Wimbledon Crowds
description: One of the joys of Wimbledon is finding a match on the outer courts and settling in to watch. Theres an intimacy to these matches, as you can sit in the first row and watch a match between two world class players who often battle through qualifying to earn a spot in the main draw.

title: Concern Over Foreign Trials for Drugs Sold in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Medical ethicists have worried for years about the growing share of new drugs whose human trials took place in foreign countries where federal auditors could not make sure patients were protected, but no one knew how big the potential problem was.

title: A Complex Food Chain
description: A cold-seep community in the Gulf of Mexico includes microbes that live on oil and gas seeping up from the seabed.

title: White House Seeing Hope in Illinois?
description: Is the White House suddenly doubling down to try and keep President Obamas old United States Senate seat in Democratic hands?

title: Battles in California Over Mortgages
description: As the housing market continues to sputter, the real estate industry is increasingly split on the responsibilities of overextended and foreclosed homeowners.

title: Next Worry for Wall Street: Basel Bank Rules
description: As the debate over the financial regulatory bill nears an end in Congress, many on Wall Street are shifting their attention to Switzerland to see what new regulations will come out of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the international banking watchdog.

title: Intel and F.T.C. Agree to Talk
description: Intel has reached a legal cease-fire with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Iran Bars Nuclear Inspectors In Response to Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  Iran on Monday barred two United Nations nuclear inspectors from returning to the country, apparently the first step in what Irans government has said will be a series of actions in response to the latest round of United Nations Security Council sanctions.

title: Drug Use Has Increased in Afghanistan, U.N. Report Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The last several years of poverty, conflict and widely available opium are taking a toll on the Afghan population, with roughly 800,000 Afghan adults now using opium, heroin and other illicit drugs, a jump from five years ago, according to a study by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.

title: Banker Is Said to Be Mayors Choice for Economic Development
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce Tuesday that he has selected a former Wall Street banker as the next deputy mayor for economic development, according to administration and business officials.

title: South Africa: 6 Arrested in Shooting of an Exiled Rwandan Army Chief
description: The South African police said Monday they had arrested six suspects in the Saturday shooting of the exiled Rwandan army chief Lt. Gen. Faustin Kayumba Nyamwasa, an attack his wife claims was an assassination attempt by the government of Rwandas president, Paul Kagame. The police withheld the nationalities of those arrested. General Nyamwasa, who is in stable condition, was shot in the stomach as he returned with his family to their suburban Johannesburg home. He left Rwanda this year after a falling out with Mr. Kagame, above. The Rwandan government called accusations of an assassination attempt preposterous.

description: To the Editor:

title: Feinberg Seeks Faster Payments of BP Claims
description: BP said Monday that it had so far spent about $2 billion in its response to the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, including containment efforts, economic and environmental claims, and state and federal costs, The New York Timess Liz Robbins reports.

title: Oil Spills in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: A Health Insurer Pays More to Save
description: Like a lot of doctors, Patrick Kilduff has too many patients and too little time. He and the five other physicians in Shavertown, Pa., oversee the care of about 12,000 people, and a typical office visit lasts just 15 minutes.

title: Excerpt: 'Memphis Beat'
description: The new TNT procedural stars Jason Lee as a Memphis detective who sings on the side.

title: Nets Look at Big Men While Pining for a Guard
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets continued their search for a complementary big forward to center Brook Lopez on Monday by working out the college freshmen DeMarcus Cousins of Kentucky and Derrick Favors of Georgia Tech.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Iraqi Danger Zone, Violence Resists a Timetable
description: MOSUL, Iraq  Staff Col. Ismail Khalif Jasim, the top intelligence officer in Nineveh Province, was scrutinizing faces last week as he walked through what the police say is the most dangerous neighborhood in Iraqs most violent city. The place is so risky that some of his colleagues apologetically offered reasons why they would be unable to accompany him there.

title: Chinas Currency Off the Table, G-20 Focuses on Europe
description: WASHINGTON  Chinas decision to allow its currency to rise gradually against the dollar has strengthened the Obama administrations hand going into a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries this weekend in Toronto. But other challenges, from Europes debt crisis to changes in banking regulation, could test the unity of the G-20 as it moves from crisis control to a more complicated agenda of economic coordination.

title: Taxing Investment Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Solar Power in Colorado
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigarette Tax Increased to Keep State Running
description: ALBANY  New Yorkers who like to smoke will have to dig a little deeper to light up next month, after the Legislature passed a bill on Monday that will give the state the highest cigarette taxes in the country.

title: Obama Says Fathers Just Need to Be There
description: In what has become his tradition within a tradition, President Obama for a third straight year seized on Junes celebration of fathers to promote a national conversation about responsible fatherhood, infused with his own experiences as an abandoned son and now as a busy parent.

title: Spain Impresses, but Knows It Has Work Still to Do
description: JOHANNESBURG  Spain played with urgency Monday night, to survive in the World Cup, to defeat one opponent in hopes of avoiding another.

title: Africa Hosts the Cup but Imports the Coaches
description: CAPE TOWN  This is supposed to be Africas World Cup, but Africas teams, many on the verge of elimination, are still not entirely Africas teams.

title: Ratner Content to Succeed in the Shadows
description: Unlike his outsize real estate undertaking in downtown Brooklyn, Bruce C. Ratner blends in. In the commercial heart of the neighborhood that he is reshaping and where many are said to resent him, Ratner walked the perimeter of the footprint for his $1 billion sports arena during a recent weekday lunch hour without drawing a glance.

title: Diamond Find Could Aid Zimbabwe, and Mugabe
description: JOHANNESBURG  New mining in Zimbabwe has quickly yielded millions of carats of diamonds and could help catapult the nation into the ranks of the worlds top diamond producers, according to the head of a group of experts for the United Nations-backed effort to stop the trade in conflict diamonds.

title: Let the Pill Go Free
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Leathery Veteran Faces the End of a Big Career
description: A weathered veteran, weakened and graying at the edges, is facing the end of its baseball career with the Mets. There are perhaps only one or two more starts in the coming week before a designated replacement is in the lineup.

title: Deep in the Heart of Texas
description: A number of responses to my column about the education I received at Classical High (a public school in Providence, RI) rehearsed a story of late-flowering gratitude after an earlier period of frustration and resentment. I had a high school (or a college) experience like yours, the poster typically said, and I hated it and complained all the time about the homework, the demands and the discipline; but now I am so pleased that I stayed the course and acquired skills that have served me well throughout my entire life.

title: Amid Controversy, Little Time for Feel-Good Questions
description: Johannesburg

title: U.S. Said to Fund Afghan Warlords to Protect Convoys
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American taxpayers have inadvertently created a network of warlords across Afghanistan who are making millions of dollars escorting NATO convoys and operating outside the control of either the Afghan government or the American and NATO militaries, according to the results of a Congressional investigation released Monday.

title: Blow Up the Well to Save the Gulf
description: TONY HAYWARD, the chief executive of BP, made an astounding admission before Congress last week: after nearly two months of failure, the company and the Coast Guard have no further plans to plug the Macondo oil well leaking into the Gulf. title: Sophie Hicks | Chlos Architect
description: If I were to put a dress on, I wouldnt look like a woman, says Sophie Hicks. Id look like a man in drag. The sternly chic British architect began wearing mannish suits as a fashion editor at glossies like Tatler and British Vogue. Then, in the late 1980s, she quit her editorial job and went to architecture school. Sure, high fashion frustrated her. (Madonna, at the very last moment, once bailed on a big photo shoot that Hicks had dreamed up with Azzedine Alaa.) But Hickss concerns about the industry went deeper. I was only 26, and I started seeing fashion go in circles, she says, noting that the legends she worked alongside  like Grace Coddington  must have seen the same things go around 12 dozen times. Hickss biography has fabulous footnotes: She appeared in a Fellini film (Intervista, in 1986), designed a Picasso exhibit for the Royal Academy of Arts, and made a perfume bottle for Paul Smith. Her most famous buildings are, perhaps predictably, fashion boutiques. She has designed shops for Yohji Yamamoto in Paris, Paul Smith in London and 100 or so Chlo stores, including flagships in Tokyo, New York and Hong Kong. Today, shes at work on a small home in South Kensington. For that building, shes invented a geometric building block with the British brick maker Ibstock. Its a bit like mesh, she says of the partially translucent brick. So youll get little glimpses of whats going on outside.

And when President Obama found out that Tony Hayward was on his yacht, he was so angry, he missed a putt.

But on a second go-round on Monday evening, Jay-Z was joined by Eminem for a three-song set that was performed on the theaters roof.

But Frances dream of a sanctioned stock-car racing series might not have made it without Raymond Parks.

title: Dealing With Momentum in Final Group Games
description: In the last games of the World Cup group phase, results are everything. Players will be willing to give all they have to secure a win. Much attention gets paid to the offense in those situations, but what about defending a lead? Certain teams, like Italy, are known to absorb pressure by defending compactly just outside the 18-yard box. Many teams in these last few group games will resort to this tactic. Sometimes it works, but quite often it does not. There are other options.

title: Tips for Using Your Cellphone Abroad
description: There are plenty of cheap ways to make calls when abroad, including a combination of local SIM cards and Skype. But setting up these methods can be complicated and time consuming, and its often more convenient just to use your cellphone. Its no wonder, then, that many people get hit with high roaming charges when they travel out of the country.

title: Census Reports It Has Reached Almost All Households
description: As of Tuesday, 98 percent of the 47 million households that had failed to return their census questionnaires had been contacted by a census worker.

description: The producers of this falls Off Broadway revival of Tony Kushners Angels in America announced the full cast on Tuesday, including the Tony Award winner Frank Wood (Side Man) as the closeted lawyer Roy Cohn; Bill Heck (the star of The Orphans Home Cycle) as the gay Mormon lawyer Joe Pitt; and Zoe Kazan (A Behanding in Spokane) as Joes Valium-addicted wife, Harper.

title: Consumer Advocates Critical of Annuity Proposal
description: The deceptive marketing tactics used to sell equity-indexed annuities have been well documented. In case you havent heard of these annuities, theyre a complex financial product that promises a guaranteed return. Salesmen often make house calls, and theyve been known to lure senior citizens to their so-called educational seminars by promising them a free meal. In many cases, elderly investors were sold products that were simply wrong for their circumstances, while the agent walked away with a hefty commission.

description: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Giorgio Armani at Milan Fashion Week.

description: Updated Wednesday, June 23 | A complete version of this story appeared in Wednesdays editions of The New York Times and can be read here.

title: World Cup Live: Mexico vs. Uruguay
description: Uruguay have won Group A by beating Mexico, who still qualify for the next round of the World Cup. The South Americans finish on 7 pts, while Mexico have 4 pts. As for the rest of the group, France go home, as do the South Africans, the first hosts to ever be knocked out in the group stages.

description: June 23, 2010, 9:50 a.m. | Updated June 25, 2010, marks the 60th anniversary of the start of the Korean War. Here are some New York Times resources for teaching and learning about the Forgotten War and looking at how The New York Times has reported on it, then and now.

title: Cause of Death Is Determined for Slipknot Bassist
description: An autopsy for the Slipknot bassist Paul Gray found that he died from an accidental overdose of morphine and fentanyl, a synthetic morphine substitute, Reuters reported. A statement released by the police department of Urbandale, Iowa, following the release of an autopsy report from the Polk County Medical Examiners Office, said that Mr. Gray also suffered from significant heart disease.

description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide has reached across the continent to fill a long-vacant post as the senior creative executive for its North American operations.

title: First Day of Polaroid Sale Breaks a Record
description: The first day of a forced sale of photographs owned by the Polaroid Company  a collection that includes work by dozens of well-known artists  brought in more than $7 million Monday at Sothebys, breaking a record for the highest price ever paid for an Ansel Adams picture.

title: Friends to Avoid, Hipsters to Embrace
description: With their dough-eyed optimism (har) and boundless faith in the goodness of others and the rightness of sharing personal details with the world, New Yorks nascent community of tech enthusiasts can sound a bit at odds with the citys historically rough demeanor.

title: TimesCast | June 22, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, President Obama summons General McChrystal to the White House, a World Cup update, a Massachusetts town bans bottled water and bringing farm fresh food to the Bronx.

title: Dust to Dustbuster?
description: Wieki Somerss In Progress, still-life vignettes made of human ashes.

title: Letter: Humanity and History
description: To the Editor: I had to tell you how moved I was by Steve Doughertys article In Germany, War and Reunion, (May 30) about the encounter between his father, Lt. Dick Dougherty, and Maj. Hannibal von Lttichau in Tegernsee, Germany, near the end of World War II. I read and reread the article, then e-mailed it to everyone I knew who would enjoy it. I visited this idyllic German village in 1984 and had no idea how close it had come to destruction. This wonderful story portrayed humanity and history at their finest moments.

title: Senate Democrats Call for House Support on Disclose Bill
description: Senior Democratic Senate leaders wrote a letter to their colleagues in the House on Tuesday urging support for legislation aimed at curtailing the power of special interest groups by requiring them to disclose more information about their role in purchasing campaign advertisements. And the senators promised to work aggressively to pass the bill in their own chamber.

title: Letter: Let Passengers Speak
description: To the Editor: Regarding the June 13 Practical Traveler (Air Travels Costly Future): Airline industry insiders believe that the path to restoring their sectors viability will be charted by their new Aviation Advisory Committee. Security issues and service cutbacks at all levels have taken all the joy out of flying. Inviting customers (the industry may have forgotten thats what passengers are) to be better represented on the committee would be a more effective first step to earning the publics interest to start flying again. George R. Horhota

title: One-Tank Trips
description: Are high gas prices keeping you homebound? Find more than 50 round-trip getaways you can take on one tank of gas.

title: Europe for Every Budget
description: The best of 10 European cities on a budget of either $250 or $1,000 a day.

title: Gourmet to Be Re-Invented as an iPad Application
description: On Tuesday, Conde Nast announced that it would resurrect Gourmet magazine, the celebrated food and travel publication the company discontinued last October, as an iPad application called Gourmet Live. Jenna Wortham has the story on our sister blog, Bits.

title: Did Jaws and Star Wars Ruin Hollywood?
description: On the 35th anniversary of the great white blockbuster, John Podhoretz has an essay blaming the unprecedented box-office success of Jaws for the rise of the lousy, disposable summer tent-pole movie. In his review of Toy Story 3, David Edelstein takes a different tack, arguing that if you want to trace Hollywoods decline into dreck like The A-Team and the umpteen Shrek sequels, the beginning of the end was Star Wars, synthetic then as now, clever but never exhilarating, infinitely merchandisable.

title: After Loss, Blake Questions Tennis Future
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated WIMBLEDON, England  James Blake of Tampa, Fla., took 10 months off the mens tennis tour to relieve a knee pain. But six days ago, at a warmup tournament in Eastborne, the feeling returned and on Tuesday it bedeviled him throughout a first-round loss at Wimbledon.

title: Obama Says Health Law Shouldnt Be Excuse to Raise Rates
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, whose vilification of insurers helped push a landmark health care overhaul through Congress, warned industry executives at the White House on Tuesday not to use the bill as an opportunity to enact unjustifiable rate increases that dont boost care and inflate their bottom line.

title: Celebrity Speakers, and Then a Woodsy Summer
description: In New York City, it is not just the colleges that can snag high-profile commencement speakers. High schools large and small are also celebrating their graduations with wit and wisdom from some major names.

title: This Year, the Fly Survives
description: He may be the commander in chief, but President Obama apparently has no power to control a lowly fly.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Knight and Day'
description: James Mangold, the director of Knight and Day, discusses a scene from the film, on DVD Nov. 30.

title: In Kosher Ice Cream, a Taste of Traditional Baking
description: Move over Soy Vay sauces. Chozen is a new kosher ice cream with mix-ins that would make Tevye happy. Rugelach, coconut-almond macaroon and chocolate matzo are the flavors, all swirled in a fine vanilla ice cream base with no gums or stabilizers. It started as a kitchen table concoction by Ronne Fisher and her daughters, Meredith Fisher and Isabelle Krishana, as they shared memories of traditional Jewish baked goods and ate homemade rugelach straight from the freezer. Nonetheless, one bite of the coconut-almond macaroon had me happily recalling a Good Humor toasted almond ice cream pop. Chocolate babka and honey-apple are future flavors. How about hamantaschen for Purim?

title: A Newsletter Is Revived, This Time as an E-Zine
description: David Rosengarten has started publishing his highly detailed, thoroughly researched food newsletter again after a two-year hiatus. The Rosengarten Report is now a monthly, available only online as an e-zine.

title: Uruguay Edges Mexico, but Both Teams Advance
description: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  Uruguay and Mexico did not have to try very hard. A tie in their final Group A match Tuesday would have sent both teams to the second round of the World Cup. Neither the overmatched host team, South Africa, nor hapless France, meeting at the same time in Bloemfontein, posed a viable threat in their group.

title: Q&A: Europe or Rio for a Wedding Anniversary?
description: Q.

title: Russian Envoys Back European Criticism of Kremlins Caucasus Policy
description: MOSCOW  To the surprise of human rights activists, Russian delegates to the Council of Europes Parliamentary Assembly on Tuesday approved a sharply critical draft resolution on Russias policy in the North Caucasus, which says human rights violations and the climate of complete impunity were bound to foster the rise of extremist movements.

title: Kagan Backed by Former Solicitors General
description: Former solicitors general from both sides of the political spectrum are backing the nomination of Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court.

title: Made in America: New Bacons Go to Market
description: La Quercia of Norwalk, Iowa, has made its name curing pork from heritage breeds for Italian-style meats like prosciutto. This spring, Herb Eckhouse, an owner, started making his first American-style dry-cured, applewood smoked bacon. Its quite smoky and very rich, thanks to a high proportion of fat to streaks of lean. Slices should be cooked over moderate heat because the fat has a fairly low smoke point.

title: Opposites Attract
description: Recently, I saw a charming little movie about two characters, opposites in temperament and outlook, hostile at the start, who gradually learned not only to find delight in each other, but also to appreciate how much they had in common. This film is whimsical, inventive, crammed with visual virtuosity and six minutes long. Its called Day and Night, and it can be seen when you purchase a ticket for Toy Story 3.

title: Astor Bake Shop Opens in Queens
description: After 22 years as a pastry chef at Regines, TriBaKery and more recently at Blue Fin, George McKirdy finally decided to go out on his own.

title: Beijing Prepares to Be Host
description: The city's hotels and dining scenes are getting ready for the moment when they will be beamed across the globe during the 2008 Summer Olympics.

title: Sleep-Away Separation Pains
description: Its the time of year for name tags on shorts and T-shirts, stamps on preaddressed postcards and lots of bug spray. Its also time to trawl a password-protected Web site, looking for glimpses of your children and their bunk mates in photographs, reading their expressions for clues because the no-cellphone rule means you cant talk to them every day.

title: Broadway Bares 20
description: Images from Strip-opoly, the 20th production of Broadway Bares.

title: The Sign That Marked Wall Street: Sold for $116,500
description: Its a simple street sign, made of iron, enamel and sheet metal. But its also an old marker of the intersection of Wall Street and Broad Street, an artifact of what once was the most powerful corner in finance.

title: Belarus Escalates Dispute With Russians Over Gas
description: MOSCOW  The president of Belarus ordered a halt to the transit of Russian natural gas to Europe on Tuesday, escalating an energy conflict with Moscow over unpaid debts that he said was turning into a gas war.

title: Words Woven, for the Price of a Donation
description: Robert Samuel Snyderman, a wild-haired 23-year-old who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, is one of the more visible of the seemingly ever-growing ranks of the citys street-poets-for-hire. Lately, hes been setting up shop outside the Brooklyn Flea in Fort Greene, accepting whatever price customers feel compelled to put on a work of art and pounding it out on his light blue typewriter. Read more on The Local, the Timess blog about Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: A Surging Kanepi Eliminates Stosur
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The Estonian Kaia Kanepi played superb tennis through the clay court season, and she has continued her good form on grass. She is the kind of player seeds hope not to play in the early rounds. Samantha Stosur drew that unlucky assignment, and lost, 6-4, 6-4, in a match that could have tipped Stosurs way but for some huge serving and steady nerves from Kanepi.

title: On Our Radar: Victory for Biotech Industry

title: Minnows Batter Reputations of Games Traditional Powers
description: This World Cup is not going according to plan. That much is obvious. If we look at the tournament results so far, we quickly become aghast at the vast number of bizarre results. Italy drawing with New Zealand? England drawing with Algeria? Spain losing to Switzerland? Uppity countries with meager FIFA rankings are queuing up to outthink and outplay their more distinguished opponents; and we cant remember the last time a World Cup saw so many anomalies.

title: Soderling Routs Ginepri to Reach Second Round

title: New Law Expands Rights of Some Loft Residents
description: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday night signed a hotly debated bill into law that expands protections for dwellers of lofts in industrial buildings throughout New York City.The sponsor, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, who said he had been working on the legislation for two decades, said the law would protect tenants who had been living in loft spaces for at least a year in 2008 and 2009. These tenants will have new protections, like the right to rent stabilization.

title: Manioc Showdown: Farofa v. Farinha
description: Manioc, the root vegetable more commonly known to Americans these days by the Spanish word yuca, makes it to the Brazilian table in infinite ways, from tapioca to chopped-and-fried mandioca frita to a dense but spongy cake. But it is most common in floury form, served as ever-present side dishes called farinha and farofa.

title: Quote Unquote | Roadkill By Any Other Name
description: Ke$ha explains her ridiculous wardrobe to Paper Magazine. Next time, please leave the feathered headdress where you found it. Thanks.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that the $25,000 campaign donation he made to Rod R. Blagojevich in 2006 was motivated by nothing more than their agreement on important issues.

description: Updated, June 23, 2:10 p.m. | President Obama has dismissed General McChrystal as commander of American forces in Afghanistan, and chosen Gen. David H. Petraeus, the architect of the 2007 surge in Iraq, to be his replacement.

title: Drilling Ban Blocked; U.S. Will Issue New Order
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in New Orleans on Tuesday blocked a six-month moratorium on deep-water drilling projects that the Obama administration imposed after the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The White House swiftly vowed to appeal the ruling.

title: Agency Works to Free Political Prisoners
description: The advertising agency JWT has teamed up with Human Rights Watch for an unusual display in Grand Central Terminal on Tuesday that seeks to generate support for freeing political prisoners in Myanmar (formerly Burma).

title: Most Americans Support Paid Sick Leave, Poll Finds
description: A bill in Congress that would require employers to offer workers seven paid sick days a year has fostered a classic debate between liberals who want government to protect workers, and conservatives who say the last thing business needs is another government-imposed mandate.

title: Algerian Federation Boss Gets Angry at His Players
description: Wednesdays United States-Algeria match for survival in Pretoria is our main concern today  but first, in honor of South Africas victory over France, lets take a moment to enjoy a musical interlude. Heres the South African pop group Four Jacks and a Jill playing their 1968 hit, Master Jack, and I hope you watch on full screen to see the lions and springbok:

title: Tsukin-ist
description: A portmanteau term describing bicycle commuters in Japan. (Tsukin [commuter] + cyclist)

title: A Look at Budget Boutique Swag
description: In this Sundays travel section, I wrote about budget boutiques, an emerging category of New York City hotels that offers hipper design and snappier service than your average tourist trap  all for the cheap-for-Manhattan price of about $250 a night. In May, I slept in six of them. Like any self-respecting guest, I swiped everything in my room that wouldnt result in a charge, either on my hotel bill or in court. That meant all those little bottles: shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, body balm, body milk, and so on.

title: Article Prompts Speculation About McChrystals Future
description: Updated | 4:47 p.m. Ahead of a meeting at the White House on Wednesday between Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and President Obama, speculation is rife in Washington and online about whether the general will remain Americas top commander in Afghanistan. As my colleague Dexter Filkins reports, Mr. Obama summoned the general to Washington after a magazine article portrayed the general and his staff as openly contemptuous of some senior members of the Obama administration.

title: Now Screening | Dsquared2
description: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Dsquared2 at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Excerpt: 'Jimmy Kimmel Live'
description: A power outage forced the host to shoot his show with his laptop. The episode will air on Tuesday night.

title: Annual Broadway Bares Fund-Raiser Surpasses $1 Million
