title: Trying Out Wi-Fi in the Sky
description: I WAS about halfway through a cross-country flight from San Francisco to New York when I made a Skype call to my wife, Karen.

title: The Usefulness of Anger: A Response
description: If I were angry, and someone came along and told me that I was not angry for the reason I thought I was, but for a completely different one, I would be furious. Although it was neither the intention nor argument of my June 13 essay for The Stone, The Very Angry Tea Party, to deny that Tea Party supporters had political reasons for their anger, it is probably not surprising that it was read by them as discounting those reasons altogether and putting an underlying set of commitments in their place.

title: Poll: Strong Support for Paid Sick Leave
description: A new poll by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago shows strong public support for legislation, currently in Congress, that would require employers to offer workers seven paid sick days a year. The bill has fostered a classic debate between liberals who want government to protect workers, and conservatives who say the last thing business needs is another government-imposed mandate. Read more on Economix.

title: Rocking Awake With the Octiv Mini Speaker
description: Most iPhone owners are familiar with the alarm clock feature, which can wake you with a number of sound effects like a marimba or barking dog. But what if you would like to be nudged to consciousness by the dulcet sound of, say, Green Day?

title: Rebound of the Rich: Wealth Rises to $39 Trillion
description: Great Recession? What recession? The worlds millionaires and billionaires  now totaling 10 million  saw their overall wealth jump 18.9 percent last year, to $39 trillion.

title: Parents in N.J. to Be Billed for Daughters City Schooling
description: It may not be surprising that the lure of fame and the promise of top-notch performance instruction is enough to tempt some parents to lie to get their children into the most coveted New York City schools. After all, students who enroll at the Fiorello H. La Guardia School of Music & Art and the Performing Arts - or simply La Guardia, as the school is more commonly known - have a chance to really make it.

title: Q. and A.: Woody Biomass, Pros and Cons
description: As I wrote in an article over the weekend, electricity derived from burning organic matter, particularly wood, has long enjoyed a reputation as a green alternative to coal-fired power  and why not? Trees and plants, renewable by definition, release planet-warming gases into the atmosphere when they burn, and absorb it again when they are growing.

title: Speculation About McChrystals Future Rampant
description: Updated | 4:59 p.m. Ahead of a meeting at the White House on Wednesday between Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and President Obama, speculation is rife in Washington and online on whether the general will remain Americas top commander in Afghanistan. As my colleague Dexter Filkins reports, Mr. Obama summoned the general to Washington after a magazine article portrayed the general and his staff as openly contemptuous of some senior members of the Obama administration.

title: Ask an Expert: Overcoming Insomnia
description: Falling asleep, or staying asleep, is a challenge for those with chronic insomnia. In addition to the anguish and fatigue that comes with lack of sleep, studies link sleep deprivation to a variety of health ills, from heart attacks to obesity.

title: France, Germany and U.K. Support Bank Tax
description: PARIS  The three largest European countries on Tuesday solidified their commitment to direct bank taxes as part of the build-up to a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries, where agreement on the matter is far from assured.

title: As Public Transit Shrinks, an Option Is Added
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a yearlong pilot program Tuesday that will allow commuter vans to pick up passengers in parts of Brooklyn and Queens with limited access to public transportation or where bus service cuts will take effect next week.

title: Watch This Space | MADE in Berlin
description: The conversion of unused office space into a gallery is nothing new in Berlins Mitte district. But MADE, a new art center opened by three of the citys creative ringleaders (and sleekly designed by the architect Alexis Dornier), is aiming to do something out of the ordinary. A collaboration between Philip Gaedicke, Nico Zeh, Tadi Rock and Luise Biesalski, MADE provides free studio space toemerging artists, pays for their materials and then puts on a show of new work  and it will even throw in some publicity. The only catch is that they have to try something new. In other words, a photographer cant just take pictures and a painter cant just paint.

title: World Cup Live: Greece vs. Argentina
description: Late goals from Martin Dimichelis and Martin Palermo preserved Argentinas perfect 3-0-0 record in Group B with a comfortable 2-0 win over Greece in Polokwane Tuesday night. Argentina won Group B with the maximum nine points and will face Mexico in the round of 16 on Sunday.

title: World Cup Live: Nigeria vs. South Korea
description: In a stirring match worthy of dredging tears from both sides by its conclusion, South Korea found its dream while Nigeria exited the World Cup with some fresh, near-miss nightmares.

title: No Power? No Problem: Jimmy Kimmel Live Relies on a Webcam
description: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their programs on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmels show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night.

title: Marketers Have Goals at World Cup, Too
description: The 2010 World Cup is the first to be played under the auspices, or maybe under the influence, of the social media. So companies that analyze data from Facebook, Twitter and other social media outlets are eagerly providing data on how advertisers  official and otherwise  are faring among soccer (or football) fans.

It was the sort of place serious couples went to for serious dinner dates, elegant without being fussy, adult. The dcor was beige and said little. The point was on the plate: food that was vaguely Asian and informed by classical French technique. This was still a novel conceit, then.

It demands our attention today not just for its age, but for its rebirth  an electrical fire in the kitchen during the summer of 2009 severely damaged the restaurant, and it reopened in April.

The occasion was a dinner for Edible Schoolyard New York, the latest branch of Waterss urban garden initiative now breaking ground  18,000 square feet of asphalt to be exact  at P.S. 216 in Brooklyn. A slab of wood festooned with local salumi wended its way through the crowd, followed by platters of Island Creek oysters and Maxwells Farm fava bean toast. Suddenly you are friends with a lot of people, Waters said.

title: Tunas End
description: In the international waters south of Malta, the Greenpeace vessels Rainbow Warrior and Arctic Sunrise deployed eight inflatable Zodiacs and skiffs into the azure surface of the Mediterranean. Protesters aboard donned helmets and took up DayGlo flags and plywood shields. With the organizations observation helicopter hovering above, the pilots of the tiny boats hit their throttles, hurtling the fleet forward to stop what they viewed as an egregious environmental crime. It was a high-octane updating of a familiar tableau, one that anyone who has followed Greenpeaces Save the Whales adventures of the last 35 years would have recognized. But in the waters off Malta there was not a whale to be seen.

They were artists, private collectors, consultants, artists, museum trustees and curators, historians and critics, and they looked at art in 300 galleries from 36 countries. These are the only solid statistics. No one tracks how much money changes hands at these assemblies of art and fraternity, but a conservative guess would be a few hundred million dollars. Jack Kerouacs last typewriter, a Hermes 3000 manual that he used from 1966 until his death in 1969, brought $22,500 at the auction, having been estimated at $20,000-$30,000. Meanwhile, a typewriter that belonged to John Updike from the late 1960s until 15 years before his death sold for $4,375, having been estimated at $4,000-$6,000. (Updike produced several major novels in this period, but Christies didnt determine whether he actually typed them on this machine.) Updikes typewriter was being sold by a member of his family; half the proceeds will go to the New York Public Library.

title: No Power? No Problem. Use Jimmy Kimmels Webcam
description: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their shows on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmels show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night. That episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live, which ABC was to show on Monday, was instead to be shown on Tuesday. And it still featured segments with Seth Rogen (who was on hand to introduce his new movie, The Green Hornet) and the comedian John Henson, as well as a performance by the country musician Dierks Bentley  only slightly more pixelated than home viewers are used to seeing. Mr. Kimmel, whose late-night talk show is produced at El Capitan Theater in Los Angeles, said his control room lost power just before taping was to start at 7 p.m. Pacific time. I blame BP for this, he said in a telephone interview. Im sure theyre responsible somehow.

title: Jay-Z and Eminem Go Outside for Letterman
description: After boasting on Empire State of Mind that he could make it anywhere, Jay-Z was denied a first attempt to play a surprise show at the Ed Sullivan Theater, which is home to Late Show With David Letterman. But on a second go-round on Monday evening, Jay-Z was joined by Eminem for a three-song set performed on the theaters roof. Last week word surfaced that Jay-Z was preparing a performance  meant to be unannounced  on the marquee of the theater. But with the city recovering from a free Drake concert last Tuesday that turned into a melee, Jay-Zs marquee moment was halted. The crucial distinction for Mondays team-up between Jay-Z and Eminem, which will be seen Friday on Late Show, was that it was staged on the roof of the theater, and not the marquee.

title: Fiction About Anne Frank Is Faulted Over Sex
description: The author of a coming young-adult novel about Anne Frank said in an interview that her book, which imagines a romantic relationship between Anne and a teenage boy who hid with her from the Nazis, was not exploiting the Holocaust or oversexualizing that famous young diarist. The novel, called Annexed, and written by Sharon Dogar, is told from the point of view of Peter van Pels, a teenage son of the Dutch family called the van Daans in Annes diaries. A report published Sunday in The Times of London said the novel included scenes of Peter yearning for and having a physically intimate relationship with Anne. But the books depiction of Anne and Peter was disputed by Buddy Elias, Annes only living relative. Anne was not the child she is in this book, Mr. Elias told The Times. I also do not think that their terrible destiny should be used to invent some fictitious story. In an interview with The Guardian, Ms. Dogar said she had corresponded with Mr. Elias about the project and said the novel did not overemphasize Annes sexuality. The sexual awakening of Anne plays more of a major part in her diary than this book, she said. The United States publication of Annexed is planned for Oct. 4 by Houghton Mifflin Books for Children.

title: First Day of Polaroid Sale Sets Ansel Adams Record
description: The first day of a forced sale of photographs owned by the Polaroid Company  a collection that includes work by dozens of well-known artists  brought in more than $7 million on Monday at Sothebys, and also broke a record for the highest price paid for an Ansel Adams picture. Clearing Winter Storm, Yosemite National Park, above, a large 1938 black-and-white landscape, went for $722,500, including a buyers commission to the auction house, topping the $609,000 that was paid for another Adams work in 2006. Polaroid, founded in 1937 by Edwin H. Land, fell victim to the digital revolution, going bust in 2001 and again in 2008. To pay off creditors, a bankruptcy court in Minnesota ordered the company to sell a portion of its collection, which includes 400 photographs by Adams alone, along with prints by Chuck Close, William Wegman, Robert Rauschenberg, David Hockney, Robert Frank, Robert Mapplethorpe, Andy Warhol and Lucas Samaras, whose photograph Ultra-Large (Hands) went for $194,500 on Monday, breaking a record for Mr. Samaras set in 1989. Sothebys said it expected the 1,200 pieces in the sale to fetch $7.5 million to $11.5 million. As of late afternoon on the sales second day, it had brought in $11.2 million so far.

title: Cast Is Announced for Angels in America
description: The producers of this falls Off Broadway revival of Tony Kushners Angels in America announced the full cast on Tuesday, including the Tony Award winner Frank Wood (Side Man), below, as the closeted lawyer Roy Cohn; Bill Heck (star of The Orphans Home Cycle) as the gay Mormon lawyer Joe Pitt; and Zoe Kazan (A Behanding in Spokane), also below, as Joes Valium-addicted wife, Harper. Casting for this Signature Theater Company revival  the first major New York production of Angels since its Tony-winning Broadway run ended in December 1994  also includes Robin Bartlett (the 2007 Broadway revival of Prelude to a Kiss) as Joes mother, Hannah, and Robin Weigert (the 2001 revival of Noises Off) as the Angel. The actor Christian Borle (the musical Legally Blonde) will play Prior Walter, Billy Porter (Smokey Joes Cafe) will play Belize and Zachary Quinto (Spock in the 2009 Star Trek movie) will play Louis. With performances set to begin Sept. 14 at its 160-seat theater on West 42nd Street, Signature also announced on Tuesday that opening night has been scheduled for Oct. 28. The two parts of Angels, Millennium Approaches and Perestroika, will alternate in repertory from the start of performances to closing night, scheduled for Dec. 19. The revival, to be directed by Michael Greif (Next to Normal, Rent), is part of Signatures yearlong season devoted to Mr. Kushners work.

Paterson whose domestic violence case prompted the governor to abandon his election bid, has invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself, refusing to answer questions in the investigation into the matter, according to a person with knowledge of his actions.

title: U.A.W. Chief Is Taking On Toyota Plants

title: In Istanbul, From Ransacked to Revived
description: ISTANBUL  A ransacked 19th-century town house in the quiet community of Kuzguncuk may seem an odd choice of residence for a worldly former diplomat like Stephen Kimmel. But for Mr. Kimmel  now an adviser to Koc Holding, the largest conglomerate in Turkey  the empty four-story brick structure came as a relief after previous remodeling projects.

description: An 83-year-old Roman Catholic nun was killed and four others were injured after a minivan racing to flee the police crashed into another car in Harlem on Tuesday, sending the minivan over a traffic island and into a group of pedestrians.

Stanley McChrystal, the top commander in Afghanistan, was called back to Washington to explain disparaging comments he and his aides made to a Rolling Stone reporter about senior administration officials. The generals ill-advised remarks, which have prompted him to prepare a letter of resignation, will only feed the general sense of despair and impatience that Americans seem to feel about our progress in Afghanistan.

title: Gone Fishing on Scholarship, With Hopes of Turning Pro
description: GIBSON COUNTY LAKE, Tenn.  The college freshmen Jake Lawrence and Jacob Hardy have two priorities: getting good grades and catching big fish. Standing on the deck of a 20-foot-long bass boat on a 560-acre lake in west Tennessee, they almost look like two tanned brothers. They wear the same uniform of flip-flops, wraparound polarized sunglasses, frayed Bethel University ball caps, and fishing shirts plastered with sponsor logos.

title: Chris Welles, Award-Winning Business Writer, Dies at 72
description: Chris Welles, an award-winning business reporter and former director of a prestigious fellowship program at Columbia for business reporters, died Saturday at a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 72 and lived in Brooklyn.

In Washington, officials applauded the siege as an important demonstration of Pakistans willingness to confront Islamist militants.

title: Adrift, Burnett Is Missing His Command and His Coach
description: PHOENIX  Since establishing himself as a premier pitcher in 2008, when he won 18 games for Toronto and led the American League in strikeouts, A. J. Burnett has endured rocky stretches that reinforced the reputation that trailed him for years: immensely talented but maddeningly inconsistent. Never during this period, though, has he lurched into the sort of rut he is now, with four straight poor starts that culminated Monday night in a 10-4 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: The Anosognosics Dilemma: Somethings Wrong but Youll Never Know What It Is (Part 3)
Spills Effects Trickle Down Into Everyday Life
description: ORANGE BEACH, Ala.  When the Deepwater Horizon exploded on April 20, Nadejda Damian had just arrived in Alabama from Moldova, the former Soviet Republic, to spend the summer cleaning beachfront condominiums. But with the spill, there are fewer tourists, which means fewer condominiums to clean  which, for Ms. Damian, 21, means a summer of losing money instead of amassing a nice sum to take home.

description: HONG KONG  The Chinese currency slipped Tuesday in its second day of trading since Beijing promised increased flexibility in the exchange rate.

title: Chess Hustling, a Look Back
description: Part of the fabric of night life in New York City, particularly during the summer, are the street chess games. Dozens of players in places like Washington Square Park, Union Square and St. Nicholas Avenue and 141st Street are up all night, taking on all comers, for a few dollars a game. The games are fast and gritty and often peppered with non-stop and colorful banter.

title: For Gulf Victims, Mediator With Deep Pockets and Broad Power
description: WASHINGTON  Kenneth R. Feinberg is the $20 billion man with an open-ended checkbook full of BPs money. Just as jaw-dropping as the sum is the power he has to spend it: Mr. Feinberg will not only decide who is paid for losses from the gulf oil spill, and how much, he also gets to pick the three judges to handle appeals of his decisions.

title: South Africa: Labor Leader Avoids Punishment by Governing Party
description: The governing African National Congress backed away Tuesday from disciplining Zwelinzima Vavi, leader of Cosatu, the powerful trade union federation, but scolded Mr. Vavi for alien behavior for publicly accusing two A.N.C. government ministers of corruption, saying he had unfairly dragged their names through the mud.

title: Peru: Report Shows Gains in Coca
description: Peru is poised to overtake Colombia as the worlds largest producer of coca, the plant used to produce cocaine, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime said in a report on Tuesday. The agency cited a 6.8 percent increase in areas under coca cultivation in 2009 compared with 2008, part of broader expansion of coca growing in Peru in recent years. There was a 16 percent decline in areas under coca cultivation in Colombia for the same time period, and an increase of 1 percent in Bolivia. About 55 percent more coca is grown in Peru now than a decade ago, the United Nations said. Colombian and Mexican trafficking groups, as well as small factions of the Shining Path rebel group, are feeding off the coca trade in Perus remote forest regions.

title: No Love Lost for Half-Brothers
description: The Germany-Ghana match set for Soccer City stadium in Johannesburg on Wednesday is not only a struggle for survival for both teams, it is also a clash of half-brothers, with a hint of revenge in the air.

title: Panel Named to Steer Course on Dealing With Sri Lanka
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appointed a three-member panel on Tuesday to advise him on how to proceed with accusations that war crimes may have occurred in the months leading up to the end of Sri Lankas civil war in May 2009. The Sri Lankan government has staunchly opposed any United Nations action, calling it an infringement on national sovereignty, particularly since it has formed its own commission to look into possible human rights violations as the war against the Tamil Tigers ended. Human Rights Watch issued a statement saying that the Sri Lankan government has repeatedly failed to undertake real investigations and urging Mr. Bans advisers to recommend a serious international inquiry.

title: Israel: Spy Satellite Is Launched
description: Israel launched a spy satellite into orbit Tuesday night from an air force base near the center of the country. The new satellite, known as Ofek-9, will help Israel more efficiently monitor the region, including Iran, said Chaim Eshed, the director of Israels military space program.

title: Canada: Missing Animals Found
description: A tiger and two camels that were thought to have been inadvertently stolen by truck thieves in Quebec last week were recovered unharmed and in good health on Monday night not far from where they had been taken. The animals were being moved from Nova Scotia to a private zoo near Toronto when the truck and trailer carrying them disappeared from a motel parking lot early Friday. The zoo offered a $20,000 reward, and police officers, acting on a phone tip, found the trailer containing the animals abandoned on a rural road not far from the motel. The animals were driven through the night and reached the zoo early Tuesday.

title: Cutting Off the Unemployed
description: It was bad enough when the Senate left town for a long Memorial Day break without passing a bill to extend expiring unemployment benefits. Its worse now.

title: About Those Premiums
description: President Obama told health insurers on Tuesday not to use health care reform as an excuse to raise the cost of premiums. The warning is timely. With critics still scare-mongering about the supposed cost of reform, insurers in several states have been seeking double-digit premium increases that look hard to justify as necessary to keep up with medical inflation.

title: Thrushs Song
description: In the woods the other day  redwoods and coastal oaks  I stopped to listen to a Swainsons thrush, a bird more often heard than seen. Usually its song is tempered by distance, its maker hidden in the understory. But this thrush was standing on a fallen limb right in front of me. The physical effort of its singing seemed so slight  head tilting, beak parting  compared with the quantity of its delicate, laddering song.

title: Fierce Recycling Effort in Fighting Oils Spread
description: VENICE, La.  Pete Parkers not-so-small frame radiates purpose. Striding around a dockside yard where his decontamination unit works, he keeps an eye on 11 workers who are stooped over drills, bolts and iron mallets to repair oil-containment booms damaged by waves and strong currents in the gulf.

title: Whats Second Prize?
description: Gen. Stanley McChrystals trashing of his civilian colleagues was unprofessional and may cost him his job. If so, it will be a sad end to a fine career. But no general is indispensable. What is indispensable is that when taking America surging deeper into war in Afghanistan, President Obama has to be able to answer the most simple questions at a gut level: Do our interests merit such an escalation and do I have the allies to achieve victory? President Obama never had good answers for these questions, but he went ahead anyway. The ugly truth is that no one in the Obama White House wanted this Afghan surge. The only reason they proceeded was because no one knew how to get out of it  or had the courage to pull the plug. That is not a sufficient reason to take the country deeper into war in the most inhospitable terrain in the world. You know youre in trouble when youre in a war in which the only party whose objectives are clear, whose rhetoric is consistent and whose will to fight never seems to diminish is your enemy: the Taliban.

description: The National Labor Relations Board has all five seats filled for the first time since December 2007 after the Senate confirmed two of President Obamas nominees for full terms: Brian Hayes, a Republican Senate aide, and Mark Pearce, a Democrat. The board, which remedies unfair labor practices and certifies union elections, traditionally requires a majority of three to act on divisive issues. The board has three Democrats and two Republicans.

title: Phys Ed: Do Sport Bars and Gels Provide the Energy of Sports Drinks?
description: According to a study published this spring in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, people who exercise for more than about two hours at a time can benefit from sports drinks. Most of us know that, of course. The carbohydrates in the drinks provide immediate fuel, which allows our bodies to avoid dipping into its own energy stores, meaning that, theoretically, you can exercise longer or more intensively before running out of fuel. But few people, in practice, can or will drink enough calories during a long workout to benefit significantly, the study authors suggest. The volume of fluid needed is, to say the least, daunting. Achieving the ideal carbohydrate-intake rates, the authors write, requires toting and stomaching about a half gallon of a typical sports drink every hour. Good luck with that.

title: New Test Approved for Swine Flu
description: A new and improved diagnostic test for the 2009 swine flu was approved Tuesday by the Food and Drug Administration. The new kit, developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has been shown to be 96 percent accurate on samples taken from nasal swabs, which can be done in a doctors office. It takes about four hours. The test replaces the one authorized for emergency use in April, 2009, when the flu pandemic was just beginning. That test was less accurate and worked more consistently on samples from the lungs, which are usually taken in hospitals.

title: What Would Get You to Move Your Checking Account?
description: In a Your Money column on Wednesday, I take a look at Perk Street, a company that offers a 2 percent rebate on every dollar its checking account customers spend when they sign for purchases using their debit cards. You have to have a $5,000 balance to qualify; otherwise, the reward is 1 percent instead of 2 percent, which is still far higher than what most banks pay in debit card rewards, if they offer them at all.

title: Sounds of the Past
description: The original cast recording of Gypsy, battle sounds from World War II, Patti Smiths debut album, and Tupac Shakurs single Dear Mama are among 25 recordings selected for the Library of Congresss National Recording Registry. The National Recording Preservation Act of 2000 directed the Librarian of Congress to select 25 recordings annually that are culturally, historically or aesthetically significant and at least 10 years old. Nominations are made online by the public and by a group of professionals in the fields of music, recorded sound and preservation. The recordings are preserved at a state-of-the-art facility in Virginia. The 25 additions also include a May 1941 radio broadcast featuring a debate between the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr and John Flynn, the New York chairman of the noninterventionist America First Committee, over whether the United States should aid Britain in the war; the blues singer Howlin Wolfs song Smokestack Lightning; Bill Cosbys comedy album I Started Out as a Child; Loretta Lynns Coal Miners Daughter; and Willie Nelsons Red Headed Stranger. The library is accepting nominations online for the next registry.

title: No Power? Jimmy Kimmels Webcam
description: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their shows on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmels show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night. That episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live, which ABC was to show on Monday, was instead to be shown on Tuesday. And it still featured segments with Seth Rogen (who was on hand to introduce his new movie, The Green Hornet) and the comedian John Henson, as well as a performance by the country musician Dierks Bentley  only slightly more pixelated than home viewers are used to seeing. Mr. Kimmel, whose late-night talk show is produced at El Capitan Theater in Los Angeles, said his control room lost power just before taping was to start at 7 p.m. Pacific time. I blame BP for this, he said in a telephone interview. Im sure theyre responsible somehow.

title: Imperial Bedrooms
description: They had made a movie about us. The movie was based on a book written by someone we knew. The book was a simple thing about four weeks in the city we grew up in and for the most part was an accurate portrayal. It was labeled fiction but only a few detailshad been altered and our names weren't changed and there was nothing in it that hadn't happened. For example, there actually had been a screening of a snuff film in that bedroom in Malibu on a January afternoon, and yes, I had walked out onto the deck overlooking the Pacific where the author tried to console me, assuring me that the screams of the children being tortured were faked, but he was smiling as he said this and I had to turn away. Other examples: my girlfriend had in fact run over a coyote in the canyons below Mulholland, and a Christmas Eve dinner at Chasen's with my family that I had casually complained about to the author was faithfully rendered. And a twelve-year-old girl really had been gang-raped  I was in that room in West Hollywood with the writer, who in the book noted just a vague reluctance on my part and failed to accurately describe how I had actually felt that night  the desire, the shock, how afraid I was of the writer, a blond and isolated boy whom the girl I was dating had halfway fallen in love with. But the writer would never fully return her love because he was too lost in his own passivity to make the connection she needed from him, and so she had turned to me, but by then it was too late, and because the writer resented that she had turned to me I becamethe handsome and dazed narrator, incapable of love or kindness. That's how I became the damaged party boy who wandered through the wreckage, blood streaming from his nose, asking questions that never required answers. That's how I became the boy who never understoodhow anything worked. That's how I became the boy who wouldn't save a friend. That's how I became the boy who couldn't love the girl.

title: Whats in a Name? Firm Will Find Out
description: The architecture firm Polshek Partnership, which is responsible for the renovations of Carnegie Hall, the Brooklyn Museum, City Center and the Public Theater, will from now on call itself Ennead, the firm is to announce on Thursday. The name, pronounced EN-ee-add, is a Greek term for a group of nine deities in Egyptian mythology and reflects the firms reconfiguration as a collective of nine partners. James Polshek, who has been at the firm for 55 years, said he was comfortable with the change. This is what has to happen if youre going to pass the torch in a creative way, he said in a telephone interview. Thats what I wanted to do. The firm also announced the creation of Ennead Lab, a private foundation dedicated to research, education and advocacy. Mr. Polshek, 80, left the partnership five years ago and became design counsel to the office, a title he will retain. I will continue working, he said. I have a lot of years left in me. What happens to the name if the number of partners grows or decreases? Its the name of the moment, Mr. Polshek said. Maybe theyll remove three gods or add two more gods, or whatever. He added, Certainly, my name is always going to be associated with this office. It will be whispered, not spoken out loud.

title: Drakes Debut Album Tops Charts
description: With impressive sales of his debut album, the rapper Drake, below, leads a wavelet of releases on the Billboard album chart. Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) sold 447,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the third biggest opening week of the year, after Sade (502,000) and Lady Antebellum (481,000). Mojo (Reprise), the first album in eight years by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, is No. 2 with 125,000, and Sarah McLachlans new Laws of Illusion (Arista) opened third with 94,000. The 34th volume of Now Thats What I Call Music! is No. 4 with 88,000 sold; Billboard reports that it is the first time in that series 12-year history in the United States that a new volume has opened with fewer than 100,000 in sales. Also on this weeks chart, Jack Johnsons To the Sea (Brushfire) falls one spot to No. 5 in its third week out, with 68,000 sold, and the soundtrack to The Twilight Saga: Eclipse (Chop Shop/Atlantic) fell four spots to No. 6, with 55,000.

title: Jackson Estate Sued Over Song Rights
description: A Broadway producer seeking to create a musical from Michael Jacksons songs is suing the singers estate in an effort to force the executors to provide the rights to Thriller, Beat It and other hit songs and also to bar the estate from licensing song rights to another party for use in a stage show. The lawsuit, filed by Nederlander Presentations last Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, came two months after the Jackson estate announced a deal with Cirque du Soleil, the acrobatic-theater company, to create two shows based on Jacksons music. Whether the lawsuit is a direct response to the Cirque deal is unclear: James Nederlander Jr., who is pursuing the court action, declined to comment through a spokesman. A lawyer for the Jackson estate, Howard Weitzman, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the Cirque deal had no bearing on the Nederlander musical project because Cirque shows are not musicals but rather big arena, circuslike spectaculars. In 2008 Nederlander Presentations signed a contract with a production company of Jacksons, obtaining exclusive rights through October 2011 to develop a musical based on selected Jackson songs, with an option to extend through October 2013. Mr. Nederlander is also seeking songs that Jackson may have written for the musical; the civil suit does not indicate whether he wrote any such compositions.

title: Wouldnt It Have Been Nice? No Reunion for Beach Boys
description: God only knows how the idea that Brian Wilson and Mike Love, founding members of the Beach Boys, might team up to commemorate the bands 50th anniversary, got out there. But the two surf-rock survivors wont be getting around to that reunion any time soon. After a report last week in The Las Vegas Sun said that Mr. Love and Mr. Wilson were considering writing and recording again, Mr. Love has quashed that possibility. In a statement, Mr. Love said: The Beach Boys continue to tour approximately 150 shows a year in multiple countries. At this time there are no plans for my cousin Brian to rejoin the tour. He has new solo projects on the horizon and I wish him love and success. Mr. Wilson, who with his brothers Carl and Dennis, Mr. Love and Al Jardine, formed the Beach Boys in 1961, stopped working with the band in the 1980s, and is currently working on new music based on unfinished compositions by George Gershwin.

title: Man of Steel Lands on the iPhone
description: DC Comics, the home of Superman, announced two digital publishing and distribution initiatives on Wednesday. The company has teamed up with comiXology to produce a DC Comics App and store for the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad devices. (Above is a frame from All-Star Superman.) Digital versions of DC Comics will also be available on the Sony PlayStation Network and the Comics by comiXology app and Web site (www.comixology.com). The PlayStation platform opens with more than 80 comics and will add more than 50 issues a month, while comiXology begins with more than 100 titles and will add another 100 a month. Despite industry concerns that digital comics could cannibalize sales of their print counterparts, DC will offer new issues of Justice League: Generation Lost, a biweekly series, at the same time (and at the same price) they are available in stores.

title: Office Mates To Publish a First Book
description: Fans of The Office know that childhood wasnt so great for Erin Hannon, the emotionally vulnerable Dunder Mifflin receptionist played by Ellie Kemper. But things worked out better for Ms. Kemper, who not only isnt an orphan and didnt grow up in a foster home, but also has a creative younger sister, Carrie, with whom she is about to write a comic novel planned for 2012. On Wednesday the Three Rivers Press imprint of Crown Publishing said it had acquired the book, tentatively titled Monday Sessions, in which Ellie and Carrie Kemper chronicle a fictitious Manhattan psychiatrist named Dr. Amy Rice through her diary entries and patient files. Asked in a telephone interview how long she and Carrie had this project up their sleeves, Ellie Kemper said: Oh my gosh. Well, were not sure. We hope that it ends up coming out of our sleeves. The Kemper siblings are already used to working together at The Office, where Carrie recently joined as a staff writer, and occasionally writes lines that emerge from her sisters mouth. Its a great sense of power over her, Carrie Kemper said. If she makes one false move, shes off the show.

title: Next Fall To Close On July 4
description: The little-show-that-could couldnt make it on Broadway after all. The producers of the play Next Fall said the production would close at the Helen Hayes Theater on July 4, after 26 previews and 132 regular performances. Next Fall cost about $2 million to mount, and one of its lead producers, Richard Willis, said the show would close at a total loss to its producers and investors. A comedy-drama by Geoffrey Nauffts about a gay couple starring Patrick Heusinger, above left, and Patrick Breen, right, wrestling with religious differences and interfering family and friends, Next Fall was something of a test case for new plays without well-known cast members trying to make a go of it on Broadway. The play received strong reviews from several theater critics, and enjoyed publicity when Elton John and his partner David Furnish signed on as producer-presenters. (Their names were splashed all over advertising materials.) But in the end the audience did not build. The producers had hoped for recognition at the Tony Awards on June 13, but Next Fall lost out to another new play, Red, for best play and best director of the play, the two categories in which it drew nominations.

title: A Death Wish?
description: Just a quick thought. Round 9 of the Kings Tournament in Romania is underway and Magnus Carlsen of Norway has White against Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania. The game, which is live, started 1 e4 e5 2 Nf3 Nc6 3 Bb5 and then Nisipeanu trotted out the Schliemann Defense with 3  f5. Now maybe Nisipeanu did not want to suffer several hours of the Spanish Torture, the nickname for the Ruy Lopez. But playing the Schliemann, which is a bit unsound to begin with, against Carlsen seems a bit like committing harakiri. Maybe he figured he has a punchers chance of winning if he just goes in and trades blows. Or maybe he is testing Carlsens knowledge. Well see.

title: World Cup Live: Slovakia vs. Italy
description: Slovakia bounced Italy out of the 2010 World Cup, by a 3-2 score, at Ellis Park in Johannesburg, the biggest shock of the tournament thus far. The Italians are the defending champions, and while its difficult to repeat (only Italy in 1934 and 1938 and Brazil in 1958 and 1962 have done so), its another thing to go out in the first round. It was a pulsating match, especially the second half. For Slovakia, which led 1-0 at halftime, Robert Vittek scored his second goal in the 73rd minute. The teams then traded goals in the 81st (Antonio DiNatale), 89th (Kamil Kopunek) and 92nd (Fabio Quagliarella). Paraguay and Slovakia qualify from Group F, and will meet their counterparts from Group G in the Round of 16. You can follow the Group E games, Denmark-Japan and Cameroon-Netherlands, here, at 2:30 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: YouTube and the Guggenheim
description: On this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein looks at a joint project of YouTube and the Guggenheim Museum to find and showcase the latest in video art. She talks to Nancy Spector, deputy director and chief curator of the Guggenheim Foundation, and Ed Sanders, senior marketing manager for YouTube, about how the project evolved and how it will work. Called YouTube Play: A Biennial of Creative Video, its open to anyone who submits a video by July 31. Up to 20 videos will be displayed at the Guggenheim Museum in New York on Oct. 21, with simultaneous showings at the museums other venues, in Bilbao, Berlin and Venice.

title: Off the Menu: Jezalins $39.95 Sandwich
description: Forget about those foie gras and truffle burgers. A ham sandwich has stepped up to the plate, promising to indulge your appetite while wrecking your budget. And it could not be simpler. The single ingredient is that most elite of Spanish hams, jamn Ibrico de bellota, from black-footed pigs that rummage in the woods for acorns. At Jezalins Gourmet Market, which recently opened in the Limelight Marketplace, at Sixth Avenue and West 20th Street, about a quarter-pound of the nearly mahogany slices, each well-marbled with creamy fat, come piled on a simple crusty baguette for a sandwich that the owner, Michael Tzetzailides, calls Conquistador and for which he charges $39.95. (This ham is priced anywhere from $150 to $250 a pound at various retail outlets.) And there is enough meat in the sandwich for two people to share.

Mr. Franco joined the Times as a staff photographer in 1985. Today, the Lens blog has a show of his early Bronx street work. Read more at Lens.

General McChrystal did an interview in Rolling Stone and he was talking about how much he didnt like Joe Biden. He was talking about the administration. He was trashing everybody. So President Obama calls the guy home from Afghanistan, and they had, like, a sit-down in the White House, in the Oval Office, today. It was very, very intimate. It was the president, it was General McChrystal, the Salahis, and thats it.

Theres not much there, but it is home to the Pakas Palafitas Lodge, a legit jungle getaway like the kind you find all around tourist-clogged Manaus but without the clog of tourists. In other words, it has the three elements that make higher-end lodging affordable for even frugal travelers: lack of location, lack of location, and lack of location.

title: Battle Company: Loving Life, Making War
description: Restrepo, a documentary that sticks close to a company of American soldiers during a grueling 14-month tour of duty in an especially dangerous part of Afghanistan, is an impressive, even heroic feat of journalism. Not that the filmmakers  Sebastian Junger, an adventurous reporter perhaps best known as the author of The Perfect Storm, and Tim Hetherington, a photographer with extensive experience in war zones  call attention to their own bravery. They stay behind the portable high- and standard-definition video cameras, nimble flies on a wall that is exposed to a steady barrage of bullets.

title: World Cup Live: Cameroon vs. Netherlands
description: The Netherlands wrapped up Group E play with a 2-1 win over Cameroon in Cape Town this afternoon. The victory gave the Dutch maximum points from its three group games, and sets them up for a round of 16 clash with surprise qualifier Slovakia on Monday.

title: A Coach and a Player, Reunited
description: There was a sweet moment early in the first set against the Williams sisters, when Julie Ditty huddled briefly with her partner Renata Yurocova. Down by 15-30, Ditty knew that an early break against the best doubles team in the world could spell disaster. She gathered herself, bounced the ball three times on the fresh grass at the baseline as part of her ritual, then hit a wicked lefty slice that Venus couldnt touch. Ace.

title: Cue the Choir: A High School Experience Ends With One Last Performance
description: I never imagined that my last lap of high school would be so rigorous, but that made graduating all the more rewarding.

title: Indians, Envious of U.S. Spill Response, Seethe Over Bhopal
description: NEW DELHI  The contrast between the disasters, more than a quarter-century and half a world apart, could not be starker.

title: Are Antarctic Crustaceans in Peril?
description: As I wrote in The Times on Wednesday, the Marine Stewardship Council has come under fire for certifying as sustainable the Antarctic krill of AkerBiomarine, a Norwegian company that turns the tiny crustaceans into omega-3 dietary supplements and feed for farmed fish such as salmon.

title: Now Opening | The Standards Stairway to Heaven
description: With rooftop bars popping up across the city skyline with dizzying frequency this summer, none has managed to stir up more getting-on-the-list finagling than Le Bain at the Standard Hotel, where the 18th floor lounge (informally known as the Boom Boom Room) was already considered the ultimate velvet rope to cross even before it had an open-air addition.

title: Hatch Says He Has Qualms About Kagan
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican, voiced a heavy dose of skepticism about Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court on Thursday, indicating that he had concerns she would take what he called an activist judicial philosophy to the court.

title: TimesCast: A New Leader in Afghanistan
description: On the latest edition of TimesCast, Helene Cooper, a White House reporter with The Times, discusses the political risks of President Obamas decision to fire Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as his top Afghanistan war commander

title: Henry James Walked Here
description: IT was love at first sight. Henry James was 26 when he crossed the border from Switzerland and made his way, on foot, down into Italy  warm & living & palpable, as he wrote ecstatically to his sister on Aug. 31, 1869. The romance kindled that day lasted nearly 40 years, and played a significant part in his career; he set some of his greatest works in Italy, including Daisy Miller, The Aspern Papers and The Wings of the Dove.

title: Tuscany and Umbria as Henry James Knew Them
description: An 1874 essay by the author Henry James can be used as a modern guide to Italy.

title: Trial of Irans Blogfather Begins in Tehran
description: More than a year and a half after he was arrested in Tehran, Hossein Derakhshan, an influential Iranian-Canadian blogger also known as Hoder, was put on trial on Wednesday, according to Iranian news reports and statements by his family posted online.

title: In Turkey, Sunlight and Enlightenment
description: TO find the Kabak Valley, drive east along Turkeys Mediterranean coast. Park your car when the pavement runs out, and walk (or hitch a ride on a truck) to a portal to another dimension.

title: On the Trail of Hansel and Gretel in Germany
description: ONCE upon a time  about 200 years ago to be more precise  there were two brothers, Wilhelm and Jacob Grimm, who lived in the Kingdom of Hesse, now part of Germany. They loved fairy tales and set about collecting and publishing them  to the delight of readers around the world, young and old, forever after.

title: Judge Wont Stay Drilling Decision
description: The Obama administrations efforts to suspend deepwater oil drilling were dealt another setback in court on Thursday when the federal judge who struck down the administrations six-month moratorium refused to delay the decisions effects. .

title: An All-Japanese Mash-Up
description: THOUGH the Japantown area of San Francisco has remained largely static since the 1970s  stretches of concrete, blocky mini-malls and lots of sushi restaurants  a new wave of Japanese popular culture, from monster movies to Lolita dresses, has hit the area, thanks to the recent arrival of New People, a five-level, glass-walled, 20,000-square-foot shrine to all things Japanese.

title: Hotel Review: The Louis Hotel in Munich
description: THE BASICS

title: Store Review: Azaad Bazaar in Mumbai, India
description: Nestled in the heart of a chic shopping district in Bandra, the Azaad Bazaar is part store and part clubhouse, just the place to pick up that handmade rainbow lampshade, check the bulletin board for coming parties and, if youre lucky, drink a cup of chai with the shops owners.

title: No Way Back
description: Mr. Marcopoulos's latest documentary features the tattoo artist Mark Mahoney.

title: Can You Die of Insomnia?
description: Lack of sleep can make getting through the day a challenge and is increasingly tied to a host of medical problems. But can insomnia actually prove fatal? That was among the hundreds of questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog at Ask an Expert: Overcoming Insomnia.

title: Edward Scissorhands Gets a Stage Debut but No Burton-Size Budget
description: As befits a fractured fairy tale about a man with blades for fingers, the stage version of Edward Scissorhands that will open on Friday at the Bayard Studio Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is going to be cut down a bit from the original film.

description: Elena Kagan will get a bipartisan introduction when she appears before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday for the start of her confirmation hearings.

description: June Havens, as portrayed by Cameron Diaz in the movie Knight and Day, is a tomboy tuner with a passion for Pontiacs. The character Ms. Diaz plays is also well-versed in the lore of Pontiac power plants, and apparently so too is the films director, James Mangold.

title: With iOS 4, New Features for Old iPhones
description: People purchasing the new iPhone 4 are not the only ones getting something new.

title: Young Writers Fill-In
When East 70th Street Was Horse Heaven
description: THE rich are different, said F. Scott Fitzgerald, but Ernest Hemingway could have told him that they, too, want a good parking spot. So although East 70th Street is known for its capacious mansions, one block has private stables to match.

title: Italy Coach Blames Himself for Early Exit
description: JOHANNESBURG  Like a car on a frigid morning, Italy always seemed to need time for its engine to turn over at the World Cup.

title: Creating Your Own Version of a 401(k)
description: As a freelancer, I no longer have an employer-sponsored 401(k) and the benefits attached to it, like automatic contributions and contribution matching.

description: Actress Tilda Swintons description of a lustful food scene in the movie I am Love.

description: Children play with bubbles at the Glastonbury Festival 2010, in England.

title: Just a Couple of Guys Grabbing Burgers
description: So what is it with Rays Hell Burger? Could it be winning the White House Burger Battle?

title: Nature, Up Close and Personal
description: Summer, which can be hard in the city, could be heaven to the painter Charles Burchfield, the 20th-century mystic of American light. Because he spent most of his time in a leafy suburb of Buffalo, to him the season meant trees aureoled in noonday sunshine, afterglow skies as cool as the song of a thrush and gardens pulsing with the music of crickets in moonlight.

title: The Paintings of Charles Burchfield
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: A Parade by Any Other Name Moves to the Sidewalks
description: Updated June 25 | There has been much talk and some consternation about the shortening of parades in New York this year, a product of the citys budget constraints.

title: The Morning Meeting
description: A peek inside the daily session in which leaders of the spill cleanup in Venice, La., develop a constantly evolving approach to fighting back the oil spreading along the Gulf Coast.

title: Someone to Watch Over Me
description: A few years ago after learning of the death of a favorite teacher, a friend from surgical training and I began exchanging e-mail messages reminiscing about the man we once alternately referred to as the Silver Fox because of his dapper looks and Chuckles because of his easygoing manner. Dr. M was well known in the hospital for his elegant surgical technique and deep respect for patients as individuals. But what my friend, Dennis, and I, and the other doctors-in-training cherished most was his uncanny ability to recognize exactly how much we residents could and couldnt do. Or, perhaps more aptly, how much he should and shouldnt do when teaching us.

title: New Supervision Rules for New Doctors
description: For nearly a decade now, the effort to reform doctors training has been focused almost exclusively on the number of hours spent at the hospital. But new rules released Wednesday go a step further, focusing on the supervision of doctors in training, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in the latest Doctor and Patient column.

title: Now Showing | The YSL Retrospective
description: I recently had a chance to catch the Yves Saint Laurent retrospective in Paris, a tour through over 40 years and 300 creations from one of the 20th centurys greatest designers. While certainly familiar with his groundbreaking Le Smoking, an alternative to the little black dress based on a mans tuxedo, I was struck by how consistently he drew from the world of mens wear.

title: Isner Wins Match That Wouldnt End
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The final tally looked impossible, like a misprint or a joke. The numbers sat there on the scoreboard  6-4, 3-6, 6-7 (9), 7-6 (3), 70-68  daring those gathered around Court 18 at Wimbledon to believe they were authentic.

title: Congress Fails to Pass an Extension of Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation to extend unemployment subsidies for hundreds of thousands of Americans who have exhausted their jobless benefits teetered on the edge of collapse on Thursday, as Senate Democrats and Republicans traded bitter accusations about who was to blame for an eight-week impasse.

title: No Break for Meek, or Actress on the Run
description: In March, Jonathan Reynolds took aim at abortion-rights politics in Girls in Trouble. Three months later Andrew Dinwiddie respectfully recreated a culture war sermon by Jimmy Swaggart in Get Mad at Sin! And to complete this unofficial conservative trilogy in small-scale theater, Americas Off Broadway presents the New York premiere of Ideal, a 1934 philosophical murder mystery by none other than Ayn Rand.

title: Climate 411
description: When I was starting out in science journalism in the early 1980s, a writer had three choices to begin reporting a story. You could go to your publications wall of dusty encyclopedias of professional and scientific associations, phone directories and other reference tomes lining the walls (in my case, at Science Digest magazine). You could raid a more experienced colleagues Rolodex. Or you could call the Scientists Institute for Public Information, S.I.P.I, a nonprofit group founded in 1963 and mainly paid for by media companies and foundations to provide, in essence, directory assistance for journalists seeking scientists.

title: Carlsen Secures at Least a Tie for First at Kings Tournament
Nature Had Other Plans at the Naumburg Bandshell
description: It takes more than a little rain to chase away an audience of tenacious New York classical music lovers, a point proved when the first drops started to fall just before a concert by the Knights, a stylish, adventurous young chamber orchestra, at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park on Tuesday evening. The concert, presented by Naumburg Orchestral Concerts as the first event of its 105th season, drew what appeared to be hundreds of aficionados and curiosity seekers.

title: Will Obamas Small-Business Agenda Survive Congress?
description: It was late October when President Obama first called for measures to stabilize struggling small businesses. Then, in his State of the Union address in January, he emphasized the role small business would play in healing the nations wounded economy. But it is only now, eight months after that speech, that Congress finally seems ready to act. And the House and Senate are so far apart that it is not clear that they will be able to agree on a bill that contains more than just a few of the presidents ideas.

title: Feliciano Steps In for Pagan
description: The Mets lineup for Thursdays series finale against the Tigers has been posted and, as expected, Angel Pagan is not in it.

title: Sometimes That Inner Demon Just Needs to Win
description: David Byrne in Psycho Killer could be speaking for Tom Blander when he sings, I hate people when theyre not polite. The lyric seems tailor-made for the ironically named philosopher-turned-cannibal in Order, Christopher Stetson Boals deliciously nasty little horror comedy, running at Theater Row.

title: In Whaling Wars, Resources vs. Beings
description: High-stakes international negotiations in Morocco over the future of whaling collapsed this week, with anti-whaling nations like Argentina unwilling to accept compromise proposals that Japan reduce, but not eliminate, its killing of whales in Antarctic and Pacific waters.

title: In Queens, Dismantling a Monument to Floral Excess
description: Residents of Forest Hills Gardens thought this day would never come.

description: R.A. Dickey continues to provide the Mets with one of the most delightful surprises of the season, extending his record to 6-0 after eight masterly innings against the Tigers in the Mets 5-0 victory at Citi Field on Wednesday night.

description: BUFFALO  The assistant to Anthony Galea, the Canadian doctor accused of smuggling human growth hormone and other banned substances into the United States, pleaded guilty in federal court Thursday to making false statements to border authorities.

title: May Orders in Durables Fell Slightly
description: New orders for durable goods fell slightly in May, but the overall trend shows that spending by consumers and businesses has improved from last year, according to government figures.

title: Popcast: The Roots, Nina Nastasia and More
description: The Roots, long one of the best  and only  live acts in hip-hop, have been the house band on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon for more than a year now. How has playing on television every night affected its music?

title: Local Stop: Brighton Beach
description: Known as Little Odessa, the neighborhood offers an urban seaside feel, with a Russian accent.

title: Resort Report | Akris in Capri
description: Albert Kriemler of Akris was yet another designer with Brigitte Bardot on the brain! He was inspired by her role in Jean Luc Godards 1963 film, Contempt, specifically the parts set in Capri. This translated into twin sets with clear crystals on the shoulders, wide leg pants in white but also in a strong shade of orange and a few different photo prints of cafe life and the boardwalk in Capri. No matter the season, its always very sophisticated at Akris, and this resort collection was definitely that.

title: Streetwise New Yorkers Caught in Their Unguarded Moments
description: If you wanted to assemble a compendium of street photography clichs, you could simplify the task by picking from Hipsters, Hustlers and Handball Players: Leon Levinsteins New York Photographs, 1950-80 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Punk Fans Find a Home in Brooklyn
description: IF there were such a thing as a punk-rock festival checklist, an event taking place in downtown Brooklyn this weekend would cross off all the items. Seminal band? Check. Accompanying skate park? Check. Vendors offering the latest gear? Check.

title: An Air of Russia and Ocean Breezes
description: What do travelers get for a subway swipe these days? At the end of the B and Q lines in Brighton Beach, they get ocean views and homemade pirozhki, a great toy store and hand-knit woolens sold on the street. And while the strip is famous for its post-Soviet explosion of cheap stuff, there is also quality amid the quantity, as well as friendly people chatting in Russian, and waves tickling the shore.

title: A Day Like Any Other
description: Images from the Rivane Neuenschwander exhibition at the New Museum.

title: Currys Option Now May Give Knicks Options Later
description: In a move that should come as a surprise to no one, Knicks center Eddy Curry has exercised his contract option for the 2010-11 season. Curry locks in $11,276,863 in guaranteed salary by electing to forgo free agency and remain with the Knicks for another year. He had until June 30 to decide whether to opt in or out.

title: Violence Expert Visits Her Dark Past
description: Jessica Stern is among the worlds experts on violence and evil, a woman who spends her time thinking about bad men and bad deeds. She has lectured at Harvard about terrorism and is the author of a respected book, Terror in the Name of God: Why Religious Militants Kill (2003). During the Clinton administration she was on the staff of the National Security Council. She presents herself as hard, no-nonsense, buttoned up. She is certainly possessed of the perfect surname. If the plane goes down, she writes in  Denial,  her new memoir, you want me at the controls.

title: Flirtatious Bunch, Instigating Playful Adventures
description: BECKET, Mass.  Prima ballerinas know how to work a crowd, sweeping their arms and eyes up and out as if to embrace the farthest reaches of cavernous theaters. So it was on Wednesday at the Ted Shawn Theater here, when Nina Ananiashvili warmly acknowledged her public on opening night at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival.

title: A Peek Into the World of Nadal and the Upset That Wasnt
description: Routine is a condition for survival, wrote Flannery OConnor, and Rafael Nadal would certainly agree. With a difficult second-round match looming against Robin Haase of the Netherlands, Nadal declined an invitation to meet the Queen of England. Asked why he passed up the chance to meet Her Majesty, who was making her first trip to Wimbledon since 1977, Nadal explained that Haase was a difficult opponent and, I have my routines.

title: South Street Seaport to Relocate Two Concerts
description: In response to reports that some concerts at South Street Seaport had been canceled as a result of the melee at a free Drake show there last week, the Seaport and Paper magazine, which presented the Drake event, say the concerts will still take place, but not at the Seaport.

title: Pulling Up a Chair With the Great Vin Scully
description: The other night, driving home on the Merritt Parkway after a game at Yankee Stadium, I listened to a tape of a 30-year-old World Series broadcast from CBS Radio. It was a one-run game in the bottom of the ninth inning, with two out and the bases loaded. The broadcaster cut through the tension with enthusiasm.

title: Italy Was the Old Man of Europe
description: Johannesburg

title: In Defense of Student Evaluations
description: Stanley Fish inveighs against the practice of asking students to assess the quality of their professors teaching:

title: Leader of the Opposition
description: The Israeli security cabinet just voted to ease the three-year blockade on Gaza, in the wake of the tragic naval attack on the Mavi Marmara by Israeli commandos. What does that mean in practical terms?  Ive heard that the cabinet changed the list to allow more goods to enter. There shouldnt be any limitations on food, but things that can be used for terror cannot be permitted. The reason for the blockade on Gaza was not to punish the Palestinians but to continue to delegitimize Hamas. There is no hope for peace with Hamas, and we need to continue the peace process with the legitimate Palestinian government.

title: Finding Marriage Without Losing a Self
description: WHEN I met Scott, I was somewhere between the before and after picture  in a no mans land called cosmetology school. We went on our first date on a balmy night in the early fall of 2003. I had met him the week before at a bowling party and hed asked me what I did.

title: Subprime Case Costs Morgan Stanley $102 Million
description: Morgan Stanley agreed Thursday to pay $102 million to end an investigation in Massachusetts into unfair lending practices, Reuters reports.

title: Art on Your Sleeve
description: Uniqlos UT project was conceived as a futuristic convenience store for T-shirts, with some 1,000 new styles added every year. But as the cast of contributors to the collection has grown  Nobuyoshi Araki, Terry Richardson and Peter Saville have all teed up  UT has come to seem more like Gagosian-to-Go than Kwik-E-Mart. The latest series, A Function of Forms, is curated by the photography writer Ken Miller along with Gallery Target in Tokyo and features black and white images by the likes of Daido Moriyama, Lee Friedlander, Linus Bill and Peter Sutherland.

title: Kids Books Today
description: From the perspective of one Christian reader, the trouble with young adult books is that theyre tawdry and dangerous:

title: From Pentagon, Messages of Dismay and Support
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Adm. Mike Mullen, who had sponsored Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as commander in Afghanistan, expressed profound disappointment in his judgment on Thursday  tempered with thanks for his years in combat  after he was fired from the post. The dismissal followed publication of a profile of the four-star general in Rolling Stone that quoted him and his aides disparaging other officials.

title: Advances in Oil Spill Cleanup Lag Since Valdez
description: Two decades after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, cleanup technology has progressed so little that the biggest advancement in the Gulf of Mexico disaster  at least in the publics mind  is an oil-water separator based on a 17-year-old patent and promoted by the movie star Kevin Costner.

title: Clear the Aisle
description: At our upcoming wedding, my fianc and I would like to honor our families by having our parents and siblings walk down the aisle before us. I have four siblings, and he has one, plus a cousin he considers a brother. So thats four for me and two for him. Hes been making a big fuss that things are not balanced. He wants me to eliminate two of my siblings, or add a couple of his friends. Im flabbergasted! The whole idea is to honor family. What am I missing here?

title: Brooklyn Diocese Seeks Sainthood for Priest Who Fought Bigotry
description: Brooklyn, the borough of churches and trees, Walt Whitman and Woody Allen, Barbra Streisand and Mike Tyson, has never lacked for people of distinction  except perhaps in one category.

title: Solemn, Strange and Demanding Sounds
description: In September Alan Gilbert made a statement about his artistic priorities by opening his first program as music director of the New York Philharmonic with the premiere of a work by the Finnish composer Magnus Lindberg, the orchestras newly appointed composer in residence. So it was fitting, and another indication of Mr. Gilberts vision, that on Wednesday night he began the final program of the season with another Lindberg premiere, the 25-minute single-movement Al largo, a lushly colorful, brilliantly orchestrated, teeming, intriguing yet baffling work.

title: Douglas Manor, Queens, 2:45 P.M.
description: Storms swept through northern Queens Thursday afternoon, knocking trees onto utility lines and cutting power to 2,300 Con Edison customers. I looked up and it was like a swirling water fountain, said Fred Ganzer, 71, above. All white, with branches and water just going around in a circle, upwards.

title: An Air of Russia Mixes With Ocean Breezes
description: What do travelers get for a subway swipe these days? At the end of the B and Q lines in Brighton Beach, they get ocean views and homemade pirozhki, a great toy store and hand-knit woolens sold on the street. And while the strip is famous for its post-Soviet explosion of cheap stuff, there is also quality amid the quantity, as well as friendly people chatting in Russian, and waves tickling the shore.

title: Officers Return Fire, Killing Man in the Bronx
description: Police officers killed a man who opened fire on them as they searched for drugs at a Hunts Point apartment in the Bronx on Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Supreme Court Rolls Back a Law Born of Enron
description: The timing is exquisite. First the Supreme Court of the United States provided a significant legal victory to the mastermind behind one of the greatest corporate frauds in American history. Next the court may throw out the law that Congress passed to reform corporate America  a law inspired by that very fraud.

title: A Different Horse Show in the Hamptons
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Equus rides again at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall here this summer. Clip-clip, clip-clop, whinny-whinny  oops! Be careful where you step in those Gucci flip-flops.

title: Conference Panel on Finance Makes Little Progress
description: WASHINGTON  Like procrastinating college students facing an approaching term-paper deadline, House and Senate negotiators on Thursday dawdled through much of what was supposed to be their final day of meetings trying to reconcile competing versions of a financial regulatory bill.

title: Phil Collins Returns to His Old Hometown, Motown-Upon-Thames
description: In its 1960s prime Motown Records rightfully called its hits the sound of young America. Nowadays those songs are the sound of aging British rockers nostalgia. Rod Stewart (last year, with the soulless Soulbook) and now Phil Collins have recorded album-length soul tributes, recreating old arrangements. The songs remain surefire, as perfectly wrought and indelible as anything in pop history. But the singer makes a crucial difference, and not always for the better.

title: Big Brother or Big Sister? This College May Discount Your Tuition
description: Participating in Big Brothers Big Sisters can be emotionally rewarding, but at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., that experience is about to become financially rewarding, too.

title: Murkiness of Youth, in Spotlight Once Again
description: The jazz guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel prizes ethereality and control in his music, but that doesnt mean he shies away from the unruly or the unknown. His career as a bandleader has involved searching as well as refinement, even when he worked within a tradition, as on Reflections (Word of Mouth), a standards album released last year. This week at the Village Vanguard hes applying the feathery grace of that recording to a murkier, more elusive batch of songs, some new and others dredged from history, including his own.

title: Star-Crossed, Tamed or Tragic: A Tour of Shakespeares Heroines
description: LENOX, Mass.  Because Shakespeares Juliet is so irresistibly star-crossed, love-drunk and young, people tend to forget just how intelligent she is. Not Tina Packer. Portraying the female half of tragedys most popular double-suicide act, at the Founders Theater of Shakespeare & Company here, Ms. Packer glows with the energy of a quick, bright mind discovering  and enjoying  itself.

title: On the Boards, Out of Town
description: Productions mentioned in the accompanying reviews:

title: An Ace on the Slopes Has an Ace on the Links
description: I cant think of any two athletic achievements that have less in common than a hole in one and an Olympic gold medal. One takes seconds, is launched on a whim and involves some luck, while the other usually represents a lifetime of hard work realized in a superior triumph under unrelenting pressure.

description: WHAT Three-bedroom, 2,000-square-foot house

title: Genre Fair
description: Images from movies in the New York Asian Film Festival.

title: Obama and Medvedev Talk Economics
description: WASHINGTON  With recent accords on national security behind them, President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia engaged in a bit of economic summitry on Thursday, with Mr. Obama pushing for more exports to Russia and Mr. Medvedev seeking more American business investment, especially in technology.

title: Festival Moves to Fancier Base but Keeps Its Genre-Bending Fare
description: The New York Asian Film Festival has been waving the fan-boy flag proudly since 2002. Glossy crime dramas and horror shows, martial-arts spectaculars, machine-gun-wielding schoolgirls  the kind of crazed, populist blockbusters that we were born to show, in the words of Grady Hendrix, one of the festivals founders  have led the way, as the series, which started with just 11 movies at the Anthology Film Archives, has grown to 45 films and moved to the uptown precincts of Lincoln Centers Walter Reade Theater.

title: Lawmakers Wrangle Over Derivatives Rules
description: House and Senate negotiators scrambled all day on Thursday to reach final agreement on how to regulate derivatives and whether to impose restrictions on the ability of banks to trade for their own benefit, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: Artist Lofts Hit the Market
description: In the Land of Lofts

title: A Garden Crawl Through the Garden State
description: NEW JERSEY is the Garden State, but that nickname wasnt always so secure. Unofficially, it dates to at least 1876, when Abraham Browning of Camden likened our Garden State to an immense barrel, filled with good things to eat and open at both ends, with Pennsylvanians grabbing from one end and New Yorkers from the other. But in 1954, when the State Legislature voted to add the moniker to license plates, Governor Robert B. Meyner vetoed the measure, saying, I do not believe that the average citizen of New Jersey regards his state as more peculiarly identifiable with gardening for farming than any of its other industries or occupations. He was overruled.

title: Inspired by Wishes, Memories, Dirty Shoes
description: What do you wish for? In Rivane Neuenschwanders first museum survey, you can write the wish on a piece of paper and perform a ritual to make it come true. You can also, if you like, work with a police sketch artist to recall the face of your first love. This is Ms. Neuenschwanders contribution to Conceptualism: art thats conciliatory, collaborative and amenable.

title: Big Names at Work at a London Gallery
Law to Require Landlords to Come Clean on Bedbugs
description: A bill passed by both houses of the state Legislature on Thursday requires New York City landlords to tell prospective tenants about a buildings recent bedbug history.

title: Scorecard | Ermenegildo Zegna Wins!
description: Today the mens-wear season gets underway in Paris, yet critics are somehow still filing their final reviews from Milan, so its back to Italy for The Moment. As Scorecard can tell you, between men in gray flannel suits, international men of mystery and American gigolos, there was nary a decade this side of Technicolor that wasnt mined for inspiration in the closing shows. Yet as Famiglia Zegna proved, theres not much competition in the sport of archive digging when youre celebrating the centennial of the wool mill that Granddad founded.

title: School Is Turned Around, but Cost Gives Pause
description: LOS ANGELES  As recently as 2008, Locke High School here was one of the nations worst failing schools, and drew national attention for its hallway beatings, bathroom rapes and rooftop parties held by gangs. For every student who graduated, four others dropped out.

description: David J. Barron, the acting head of the Justice Departments powerful Office of Legal Counsel, will step down next month and be replaced by one of his current deputies, Jonathan G. Cedarbaum, the department said Thursday.

description: THEATER

title: Lions Gate and MGM Hold Talks on Potential Deal
description: Lions Gate Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have been holding merger talks, but it is not clear that a deal will emerge, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

description: Around Town

title: Sci-Fi Summer Films, a Free Hip Hop Old School Party, and the UnFancy Food Show
description: Oh, the days of $3 drive-in movies, how our love lives (and wallets) miss them. Well, the Saturday night Sci-Fi Summer film series indoors at the Coney Island Museum can be the modern couples next-best alternative. This weekend the program presents Attack of the 50-Foot Woman (1958), and continues every Saturday at 8:30 p.m. through Sept. 18, with other classics like King Kong vs. Godzilla and the original 1968 Planet of the Apes. Doors open at 8, and the evening starts with vintage drive-in trailers, shorts and commercials at 8:15. Tickets are $5 each and include free popcorn. Food and soft drinks and alcoholic beverages beverages are sold at the Freak Bar. (1208 Surf Avenue, between Stillwell Avenue and West 12th Street, Brooklyn; 718-372-5159, www.coneyisland.com.)

title: From Greece, a Parable About ... Something

title: A Sanctuary and a Prison
description: Plenty of parents try to instill their values in their children and shield the little ones from the perils and temptations of the outside world. The mother and father in Dogtooth, a Greek festival-circuit conversation piece directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, present an extreme case of this kind of protectiveness. Their idea of home schooling is to provide their children with daily tape-recorded vocabulary lessons, which would not be unusual if the definitions were less idiosyncratic. The three kids  two daughters (Aggeliki Papoulia as the elder, Mary Tsoni as the younger) and a son (Hristos Passalis)  are taught that excursion refers to a kind of flooring material and that a sea is a kind of armchair.

title: Blatant Acts of Naked Regression
description: It doesnt get worse than Grown Ups, Adam Sandlers sloppy entry into this years man-child-comedy sweepstakes. Lazy, mean-spirited, incoherent, infantile and, above all, witless, the farce  which focuses on five 40-something guys in full regression  suggests a hangover from The Hangover. If squirting breast milk, simultaneous urination by slobs in a pool at a water park, and a repeatedly flatulent grandmother are your idea of fun, I say go for it.

title: Revenge on the Bully, Silently, in Japan

When you watch, say, Charlie Chaplins City Lights or The General by Buster Keaton, you are aware of such complete mastery of the emotional and narrative possibilities of cinema that color and sound seem like so much distraction and filigree. Everything you could possibly want is here, and indeed the addition of anything else would only subtract from the perfection of the art.
