title: NEA Will Honor 18 Artists
description: The National Endowment for the Arts will present 18 lifetime achievement awards on Friday in the fields of opera, jazz, and folk and traditional arts. The honorees include the composer Philip Glass, for opera, and five members of the Marsalis family, for jazz. Each award comes with $25,000. Besides Branford, Delfeayo, Ellis, Jr., Jason, and Wynton Marsalis, the other 2010 Jazz Masters are Orrin Keepnews, a writer and record producer; Hubert Laws, a flutist; David Liebman, a saxophonist and flutist; and Johnny Mandel, a composer-arranger. The honorees in folk and traditional arts are Yacub Addy, a Ghanaian drummer; Jim Texas Shorty Chancellor, a fiddler; Gladys Kukana Grace, a Lauhala weaver; Mary Jackson, a sweetgrass basketweaver; Delano Del Floyd McCoury, a bluegrass guitarist and singer; Judith McCulloh, a folklorist and editor; Kamala Lakshmi Narayanan, a Bharatanatyam Indian dancer; Mike Rafferty, an Irish flute player; and Ezequiel Torres, an Afro-Cuban drummer and drum builder. The opera honorees, besides Mr. Glass, are Martina Arroyo, a soprano; David DiChiera, a composer and the general director of the Michigan Opera Theatre; and Eve Queler, the music director of Opera Orchestra of New York.

title: China: Official Links 10 Detainees to 2008 Killings
description: A Chinese security official said Thursday that the police recently broke up a terrorist group that was involved in an attack in August 2008 in the western city of Kashgar that resulted in the deaths of 17 paramilitary officers. The official, Wu Heping, said the police had detained 10 members of the group, including two ringleaders, Abdurixit Ablet, 42, and Imin Semaier, 33, both natives of the restive western region of Xinjiang, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. Previously, Chinese officials had said they had arrested a taxi driver and a vegetable seller at the scene of the attack and charged them with the killings.

But theyre also exhausted and frustrated much of the time. And at these moments they cant help letting you know that things would be much better if only there werent so many morons all around.

title: Greece: Bomb Kills Cabinet Ministers Assistant
description: A powerful bomb sent in a package to the minister of public order exploded near his office in Athens on Thursday, killing his 52-year-old assistant, who opened the package. The minister, Michalis Chrysochoidis, left, who is in charge of the police and counterterrorism, was not in his office at the time. He described the attackers as cowards and said their actions would not divert his ministry from its counterterrorism drive. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: Turkey: 3 Suspects Arrested After Fatal Bombing
description: The police arrested three suspects in a bomb attack that killed five people in Istanbul on Monday, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. Officials did not identify the suspects, but attacks on military targets are generally ascribed to the rebel Kurdistan Workers Party. A new attack on Thursday in the eastern town of Elazig killed one civilian and two soldiers, Anatolian reported.

title: U.S. Calls for Indigenous Whaling Quotas
description: The American whaling commissioner said Thursday that the United States was trying to salvage some progress from an international conference on whaling by calling for a vote to set whaling quotas for indigenous peoples who depend on the animals for sustenance. These are people who actually need the whales to eat, the commissioner, Monica Medina, said in Morocco. But they end up begging for their quotas. Talks aimed at reducing the hunt globally, specifically hunting by Japan, Norway and Iceland, which circumvent an international moratorium on whaling, collapsed on Wednesday at a conference of the International Whaling Commission in Agadir, Morocco. A proposal put forward by the commissions top executives had sought to bridge the gap between pro-whaling and antiwhaling nations, calling for approval of the resumption of commercial whaling under strict supervision by the commission and at reduced levels.

Several days earlier, 5.2 million viewers tuned in for ESPNs broadcast of the United States-Slovenia game.

title: Massachusetts: Immigrant Crackdown Is Eased
description: A crackdown on illegal immigrants, passed by the State Senate last month, has been scaled back. The House and the Senate on Thursday approved a less stringent version of the contentious plan, which would have required the state attorney general to set up a hot line for residents to anonymously report businesses suspected of hiring illegal immigrants. The compromise plan, adopted as an amendment to the state budget, only codifies existing state policies. But as part of sweeping budget cuts, the legislature also eliminated health care coverage for thousands of legal immigrants.

title: Texas: Seven Officers Are Fired for Beating
description: The Houston police chief has fired seven officers involved in the beating of a 15-year-old suspected of burglary, a beating that was caught on videotape and outraged many black residents. Four of the officers also face misdemeanor charges for the pummeling of the youth, Chad Holley, who had been handcuffed and forced to the ground after a short chase on March 23. Some black leaders called the charges of official repression a slap on the wrist and questioned why prosecutors had not persuaded a grand jury to charge the officers with felony assault.

title: Hartford Stage Artistic Director to Depart
description: After 12 years as artistic director of Hartford Stage in Connecticut, Michael Wilson has announced he is stepping down in June 2011. Im looking forward to being more fully in the rehearsal hall, Mr. Wilson said in an interview. In January he is scheduled to direct Olympia Dukakis in a production of Tennessee Williamss Milk Train Doesnt Stop Here Anymore for Roundabout Theater Company, and he hopes to oversee a Broadway production of that playwrights Night of the Iguana in the next 18 months. From 1998 to 2008, Mr. Wilson, above right, presided over a Williams marathon at Hartford Stage that included premieres of three previously unpublished short plays. During Mr. Wilsons tenure, the theater also produced the acclaimed three-part, nine-hour production of Horton Footes Orphans Home Cycle, which later moved off Broadway. Paul Marte, a Hartford Stage spokesman, said a search committee would be convened next month, with a national search expected to take six to nine months. Mr. Wilson said he would be available past his planned departure to help with a transition if necessary.

title: South Street Seaport to Relocate Two Concerts
description: In response to reports that some concerts at South Street Seaport had been canceled because of the melee at a free Drake show there last week, the seaport and Paper magazine, which presented the event, said the concerts would still take place, but not at the seaport. Since it was demonstrated that the escalating popularity of the scheduled artists can result in crowds that exceed even the safe capacity of the Pier 17 concert stage, both Paper magazine and the South Street Seaport have decided that the remaining events of the Sounds Like Paper concert series will be relocated, a seaport spokesman said in a statement, which was confirmed by Paper. In a letter to Community Board No. 1 of Manhattan last week, General Growth Properties, which owns the seaport, had said the two remaining shows, by the pop singer Kesha, above right, and the band Ratatat, would be canceled. The Seaports outdoor concert space has a capacity of about 10,000, but according to some reports, as many as 25,000 people turned out for the Drake concert on June 15. It was not clear whether a new stage had been found, or whether the seaport would be involved. Kesha, whose song Tik Tok is one of the years biggest hits, had been booked for a free Seaport concert in August, but a spokeswoman at her record label, RCA, said Thursday that she had not yet been informed about a new date or location. BEN SISARIO

title: 80s Pop Stars Face Off in a SyFy TV Movie

Once again, Tiffany and Debbie Gibson are about to go head-to-head: the Syfy channel has cast the onetime pop rivals in a coming made-for-television film, The Hollywood Reporter said. The film, Mega Python vs. Gatoroid, will star Ms. Gibson, above right, as an advocate for animal rights who accidentally helps create supersize snakes, and Tiffany, above left, as a park ranger trying to save endangered alligators in the Everglades. In a statement, Tiffany said: Only in my dreams have I been able to have a catfight with Debbie Gibson ... until now! This is soo mega cool! Ms. Gibson added: I know that pop-culture fanatics have been dying for Tiffany and me to collaborate for the past 24 years! What better way to do it than by battling each other in a campy romp through the Everglades? The film is to be shown next year. An accompanying shopping mall tour was not immediately announced.

No other show came close to matching it in the ratings, and the network led the night over all. Fox was runner-up, averaging 6.3 million viewers for So You Think You Can Dance from 8 to 10, while CBS came in third with reruns. ABC was a distant fourth with comedy reruns followed by a special Jimmy Kimmel Live at 10 (3 million), featuring Robert Pattinson, Kristen Stewart and other cast members from The Twilight Saga: Eclipse.

title: Opera Orchestra of New York Returns
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York, a small but beloved institution for fans of offbeat repertory and big voices, is staging something of a comeback. The company said Thursday that it would end its financially induced hiatus and mount two concert productions next season: Meyerbeers Africaine and a double bill of Massenets Navarraise and Mascagnis  Cavalleria Rusticana.  The double bill, to be conducted at Carnegie Hall by Alberto Veronesi, who takes over as music director in 2011, will feature Roberto Alagna and Elina Garanca in the Massenet, and Mr. Alagna, Maria Guleghina, Krysty Swann and Mignon Dunn in Cavalleria, according to Opera Orchestra. Eve Queler, who founded the company in 1967 and is music director now, will conduct  LAfricaine,  with Marcello Giordani singing and Chiara Taigi in her United States debut, at Avery Fisher Hall. The organization suspended opera performances in 2008 and has been presenting only recitals. The board chairman, Norman Raben, said it is now debt-free and raising the $1.25 million to $1.5 million needed for next season. Its a big comeback, he said. The board stood up tall. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Goin Back With Neil Young
description: Neil Young makes his debut at No. 3 on the hardcover list this week with Neil Youngs Greendale, published by the Vertigo imprint of DC Comics. In it, Mr. Young, with the help of the writer Joshua Dysart and the artist Cliff Chiang, revisits the northern California town he first envisioned in his 2003 album of the same name. The graphic novel spotlights Sun Green, great-granddaughter of Jay Green, the man who founded Greendale, and her supernatural relationship with nature. (A preview of pages from the graphic novel can be found here.)

title: Student Challenge Favorite | A Teacher From Eritrea
description: Our Student Challenge will continue all summer long, and well regularly choose a favorite student comment to feature. You can still enter this weeks Challenge here.

title: High-Risk Insurance Pools to Begin Next Month
description: IF you have any kind of chronic medical condition and youve been shopping for health insurance, you know how insanely difficult it is to find an insurer that will cover you at all, let alone at an affordable rate.

title: Studio Ghibli to Make Games
description: TOKYO  Studio Ghibli, the Japanese animation studio that wowed American filmgoers with My Neighbor Totoro and the Oscar-winning Spirited Away, plans to bring its quirky sensibility and style to video games.

title: Friday Reading: Notification of a Buildings Bedbug History
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Obamas Remarks on the Financial Deal
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on Friday after Congressional negotiators reconciled competing versions of legislation that would transform financial regulation, as released by the White House:

title: Children Dying in Hot Cars
description: It is that time of year again when reports come in from around the country of children dying of hyperthermia, after being locked in sweltering cars.

title: The Dollar Menu, Bolivian Style
description: Everythings cheaper in Bolivia than in Brazil, and if you doubt it, just watch all the Brazilians crossing the Mamor River every day to buy electronics, colognes and stuffed animals here in Guayamern before they return home (to Guajar-Mirim).

title: 2010 Lilith Tour Cancels Dates, Report Says
description: 11 a.m. | Updated

title: Hong Kong: Plan to Expand Legislature Is Approved
description: The Legislative Council voted 46 to 12 on Friday to approve a plan to add 10 seats to the legislature in 2012. The public would elect lawmakers to fill five seats. Elected members of the citys 18 district councils would nominate candidates from their ranks to run for the other five seats, with the public voting on them. Eight lawmakers from the oldest pro-democracy political group, the Democratic Party, joined pro-Beijing parties to support the measure. A ninth, Andrew Cheng, resigned from the party this week in protest and joined lawmakers from the Civic Party and minor pro-democracy parties to oppose the measure as too small a step toward greater voting rights for Hong Kongs seven million people. The legislature approved a separate plan on Thursday to expand the committee that elects Hong Kongs chief executive, to 1,200 members in 2012 from 800 now.

title: The Next Crisis: Public Pension Funds
description: Ever since theWall Street crash, there has been a bull market in Google hits for public pensions and crisis. Horror stories abound, like the one in Yonkers, where policemen in their 40s are retiring on $100,000 pensions (more than their top salaries), or in California, where payments to Calpers, the biggest state pension fund, have soared while financing for higher education has been cut. Then there is New York City, where annual pension contributions (up sixfold in a decade) would be enough to finance entire new police and fire departments.

title: Is It Energys Turn Now?
description: With the overhaul of financial regulation nearing completion, some Democrats are hoping that Congress can turn to the next big legislative challenge  energy and climate change. There is no consensus yet what such legislation should include, but there is strong determination on the part of the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress to try to move something  anything  before Congress leaves town in August.

title: William S. Richardson, Ex-Chief Justice in Hawaii, Dies at 90
description: William S. Richardson, who as chief justice of the Hawaii Supreme Court for 16 years was a leading proponent of the rights of native Hawaiians, often relying on ancestral custom rather than Western common law in his decisions, died Monday in Honolulu. He was 90.

title: Cooking Tools: Induction Burners
description: Last Christmas, I received as a gift an induction burner, a square plastic machine with a glass top that uses electromagnetism to heat pots and pans instantly, with little wasted energy. (Kim Severson wrote about induction burners in April.) Before last year, I was aware of induction stove tops, but had no idea that the little portable cookers existed, certainly not ones that cost around $75, like my Max Burton 6000. As kitchen revelations go, this turned out to be a big one, for five reasons.

title: 2011 Toyota Sienna
description: The 2011 Sienna van has improved its ride and handling over the previous model.

title: How HDTV Scrambles Beauty Standards
description: Maybe human skinwasnt meant to be digitized. Maybe, to ensure that people keep being attracted to one another, we should refrain from representing our complexions in the points, dots and samples that make up a high-definition image. Sure, the sports fan loves HD, which displays life in staggeringly fine-grain resolution of up to 1,920 by 1,080 pixels. But other TV fans  those who like prettiness, say  sometimes find ourselves shuddering. Technologically, spots may be a gamechanger; dermatologically, they are too often vitiligic, psoriatic or bubonic.

title: After the Storm, a Calm Refuge
description: CLEVELAND

title: How Long Will My Family Be Covered Under Cobra?
description: Q.

title: Ghoti
A New Option for the Uninsured
description: Next month the federal government will begin providing relatively affordable coverage for uninsured people with pre-existing conditions, writes Walecia Konrad in this weeks Patient Money column.

title: Porn in the Office
description: Arriving at work, I often find that my boss, who owns the business, had been looking at pornography after-hours on the computer we sometimes share. (He has no private office, and this computer  is the most isolated.) Sometimes he leaves those pages open, so I cant help  see ing  them. I dont care what he does so long as its not in my work space. Asking him to stop might endanger my job. May I turn  on the parental controls and set a password? M.B., PHILADELPHIA

title: Isners Wimbledon Fairy Tale Ends
description: WIMBLEDON, England  One tennis match made John Isner famous. One long, tense, laugh-at-logic match that defied easy explanation. It lasted 11 hours and sprawled over three days, overshadowed the sports most famous tournament and catapulted this giant of a tennis player toward international acclaim.

title: Where Do Gadgets Really Come From?
description: Armed with our laptopsand smartphones, our apps and Twitter accounts, consumers enjoy previously unimaginable access to marketplace information and sometimes even power. The Web crackles with peer reviews; with the right mobile device we can scan a bar code of something at the mall and compare the price with far-flung retail rivals. And we can vent and maybe achieve some satisfaction. Remember the online video of the slumbering Comcast repairman? Remember when the consultant and writer Jeff Jarvis blogged his unhappy laptop experiences into what became the Dell Hell public-relations nightmare? Add it all up, and its a significant shift, a transparency triumph, as Trendwatching.com put it not long ago.

title: The Nicaraguan Coconut Salesman
description: The coconut salesman appears every morning in front of the tourist hotel in Jinotepe, Nicaragua. He stands there with his cart full of coconuts, his machete to hack the tops off and his bag of straws. He is in his 50s, with a pronounced belly that strains the fabric of the old T-shirts he wears, and dark, wet eyes.

title: Jamaicans Ponder Cross-Dressing Gangsters
description: On Thursday evening, Christopher Coke, the leader of Jamaicas powerful Shower Posse gang, was paraded before the cameras in handcuffs by federal agents in New York, after his long-delayed extradition on gun and drug charges.

title: German Court Liberalizes Rules for Right to Die Cases
description: BERLIN  In a landmark ruling that will make it easier for people to allow relatives and other loved ones to die, Germanys highest court ruled Friday that it was not a criminal offense to cut off life-sustaining treatment for a patient.

title: Inside the List
description: SWEDEN FREEZES OVER:The Overton Window, the new political thriller from Glenn Beck (inset), enters at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, displacing Stieg Larssons Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest after a mere three weeks. Weep not for Larsson, however:the first two installments of his Millennium trilogy are No. 1 and No. 2 on both the trade and mass-market paperback lists.

title: David Mitchell, the Experimentalist
description: As the Eyjafjallajokull Volcano was spewing plumes of ash into European airspace in April, shuttering airports and stranding millions, the British novelist David Mitchell, a tall, gracious, high-spirited man of 41, was marching me across a long, flat tidal beach near his home in Irelands West Cork. Along the way, he told me a story about the perils of humility. I had a short and rather valuable lesson, Mitchell said after a morning on the beach, one of these warnings that the universe gives you on a platter sometimes. Id done an event in New Zealand at a very large auditorium, hundreds of people, and I was kind of pleased with it; it had gone well. A woman came up to me afterwards, a medievalist at the university there, and she said, Have you heard of the humility topos? I said no. She explained that, in the medieval era, humility was seen as a great virtue. The humility topos was used for these abbots  you can think of a good one in Ecos Name of the Rose  who were actually monsters of arrogance, but were always banging on about how humble they were  Just like our lord Jesus Christ. We serve him in humility  when they were the least humble people you can find in history. Some even became pope. And the woman looked at me and said, Watch out for the humility topos. And then sort of disappeared in a puff of smoke.

title: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
description: Chapter Two: Captain Lacy's Cabin on the Shenandoah, Anchored in Nagasaki Harbor

title: Chris Carter, Ever the Animal
description: In his short time with the Mets, Chris Carter has impressed his teammates and coaches with his enthusiasm, hard work and good cheer. His nickname, the Animal, seems well deserved.

title: Got Talent! at the Staten Island Ferry
description: The shirt said Hard Rock, but the music was anything but. Hunched over a piano, his back to the Staten Island waterfront, Michael Mignemi swayed gently as he played Pachelbels Canon. As the sound filled the breezeway, people heading toward the ferry terminal veered off slowly to him.

title: Uruguay Finds Potential to Add to Legacy
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa  History is a source of pride for Uruguays soccer players, but it is also a burden. They are rather like modern-day Athenians and Romans: working, striving, dreaming but well aware that matching the luminous achievements of their ancestors is probably too much to ask.

title: Cheers at Europes Expense
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Letters: Democrat in Chief?
description: Regarding Matt Bais article on President Obama, I am thankful we have a president who realizes that robocalls and speaking at rubber-chicken fund-raisers are not consistent with the office of leader of the free world. Most politicians have feet of clay and compromise themselves for the wrong reasons. I am proud of President Obama, and I dont always vote for Democrats. I vote for whoever I think will do the best job for the country, state or municipality.

title: The Muslim Past
description: In the United States, a country saturated with instant punditry, serious scholars rarely attain celebrity as public intellectuals. Yet Bernard Lewis, a professor emeritus of Near Eastern studies at Princeton, has long radiated influence far beyond his specialization in Ottoman studies. A friend of Henry Kissinger and a mentor to subsequent cohorts of conservative policy makers, Lewis arguably has done more than any Mideast expert to mold American attitudes to the region.

title: A Jeep for High Rollers
description: Jonathan Ward has a passion for re-creating Army Jeeps with modern parts.

title: Letters: The Animal-Cruelty Syndrome
description: Charles Siebert discusses empathy and how childrens capacity for it can be impacted by their own maltreatment and by witnessing the abuse of animals. While it is critical to implement therapies toheal people who have been thus affected, prevention strategies, like educating children about the humane treatment of animals, can help protect even more people and animals from harm. Teaching empathy and nurturing that quality from an early age is invaluable in helping children develop into humane adults.

title: Reform Bill Includes Ban on Movie Futures
description: The prospect of trading futures contracts based on box-office revenue appears dim, as the financial overhaul bill approved early this morning includes language that bans the trading of those contracts.

title: The Week Ahead: June 27  July 3
description: Art

title: Old Friends
description: In a long literary career, the Chicago writer Richard Stern has published eight novels, several highly acclaimed. But he has also dabbled in a genre he calls orderly miscellany. Still on Call, his sixth such book, is a grab bag of essays, reflections, lectures, blog posts and assorted scribblings that has the fragmented, meandering structure from which such collections often suffer.

title: Letters: Questions for Christopher J. Brownfield
description: Christopher J. Brownfield should speak a little more carefully when discussing the idea of using nuclear weapons to stop the BP leak.Brownfield states that the Russians did it four times with 100-percent success rate. The Russians did not destroy oil wells in this way. Rather, they used nuclear explosives to seal runaway gas wells, but never an oil well on land or underwater. Brownfield also never mentions how difficult it would be to emplace a nuclear explosive a mile underwater, set it off and be assured that no other catastrophe would result.

title: What Price Perfection? The $80,000 Army Jeep
description: EVEN in Midtown Manhattan, where blocklong Hummer limos barely rate a second glance and six-figure supercars rarely draw more than a yawn, an Icon CJ3B attracts a knot of curious admirers. This, despite its no-gloss finish, bling-free wheels and an interior totally lacking in luxury appointments (a good thing, actually, as there is hardly a distinction between its interior and exterior).

title: Weird Science
description: As Justin Cronin clearly knows, if youre a writer seeking to slough off highbrow pretensions  to reject your early efforts at quiet fiction and write something with commercial appeal, something that will, if not conquer the critics, at least pay for your kids college education  youd be wise to opt for a vampire novel. The genre has proved so indomitable that its a wonder the Balkan underclass, whose age-old folk tales began it all, hasnt started to request royalties.

title: Bollywood Prepares Bin Laden Satire
description: After plans to make a movie about Adolf Hitler drew widespread protest and resulted in the withdrawal of the projects lead actor, the film industry in India is now set to produce a feature about another polarizing figure, Osama bin Laden.

title: Bank Stocks Remain Up After Finance Overhaul Deal
description: Shares in the nations biggest banks were still trading higher in midday trading on Friday, after Congressional negotiators hammered out a compromise on a proposed overhaul of financial regulation.

title: Speech Recognitions Early Days
description: In 1982, David Nahamoo had just received his Ph.D. from Purdue University and was headed to a prestigious institution, I.B.Ms Watson Laboratory. But his university peers, he recalls, sniffed at his chosen field  speech recognition  as more science fiction than computer engineering.

title: Weekend Competition: Are We There Yet?
description: This weekend, as the vacations inch closer, co-vocabularists are invited to share word-games suitable for long journeys by plane, train or automobile.

title: Racing Under a Watchful Eye Thats Thousands of Miles Away
description: STUDYING the stream of numbers flashing across his computer screen, Mark Williams checked the vital signs of Lewis Hamiltons McLaren MP4-25 racecar as it attacked a corner at the Australian Grand Prix in March. Hamilton pushed hard at the Albert Park circuit in Melbourne, working his way up to a sixth-place finish after starting 11th.

title: Financial Bill Includes Ban on Movie Futures
description: From Joseph Plambeck at Media Decoder:

title: Enemy of the Good? The Whaling Stalemate
description: Le mieux est lennemi du bien, Voltaire said. The perfect is the enemy of the good. That might have been the case this week in Agadir, Morocco, where the International Whaling Commission failed to make any progress on reducing the global whale catch.

title: Streaming the Data to Fans Homes
description: ITS not quite the same as driving the teams racecar on Sunday, but Formula One fans can feel some of the thrill virtually this year on Web sites that have been overhauled to provide real-time streaming on race weekends.

title: Bret Easton Ellis, Back to Zero
description: At first you think: Thats a nice conceit. They had made a movie about us, Bret Easton Elliss new book begins, and of course, they did, allowing us at least an early glimpse of the genius of Robert Downey Jr. The movie, it should go without saying, is the film version of Less Than Zero, Elliss headline-grabbing 1985 debut. Neither the book nor the movie is named, but titles arent necessary, for here are the old familiar names: Blair, Julian, Trent  and Clay, the narrator of that novel and this one, Imperial Bedrooms, which takes up their stories a quarter of a century on. So theres a neat, postmodern, self-referential beginning, with Clay, the cool observer of his own actions and feelings  or lack of them  observing himself being observed, an acknowledgment that his version of the story may be only one of many.

title: Crack Agent
description: Car crashes happen in different ways, but they all end the same, with the rest of us looking on in sympathy and prurience: I hope theyre O.K., but Id like to get a look if theyre not.

title: The Psychology of Bliss
description: In 2003, a German computer expert named Armin Meiwes advertised online for someone to kill and then eat. Incredibly, 200 people replied, and Meiwes chose a man named Bernd Brandes. One night, in Meiwess farmhouse, Brandes took some sleeping pills and drank some schnapps and was still awake when Meiwes cut off his penis, fried it in olive oil and offered him some to eat. Brandes then retreated to the bathtub, bleeding profusely. Meiwes stabbed him in the neck, chopped him up and stored him in the freezer. Over the next several weeks, he defrosted and sauted 44 pounds of Brandes, eating him by candlelight with his best cutlery.

title: Give Greed a Chance
description: The United States may be known as a place of self-invention and aspiration, but American literature is densely populated with characters who illustrate the perils of trying to change your station. From Lily Bart to Nick Carraway, the road to hell is paved with grand ambitions. And, more recently, with crazy mortgages. In Martha McPhees jaunty new novel, Dear Money, the spread of subprime mortgages and their frenzied trade on Wall Street forms the backdrop to a traditional story of an individual gradually succumbing to, and being corrupted by, the lure of wealth and all it promises.

title: The Age of Ambivalence
description: It may be that the hallmark of the modern moment is a certain demi-pleasurable drift  the timeless unspooling of information and entertainment on the Internet, Twittering, partial employment, life spans getting longer (even as the economy shrinks), no end to the reproductive years, midlife reinventions, TiVo-ing everything, four-day-week job furloughs  accompanied by a free-floating melancholy. If the last century crashed into the forces of urbanization, fragmentation and world war, this one seems to be on an endless, murmuring skid. Things are . . . O.K. You know. Theyre O.K. Click, click. Theres so much time, at least for some people, but its filled with doubts about what, exactly, to do. We can often be a bit frictionless, here at the end of the first decade of the new century. When were not feeling postapocalyptic, we hover, paralyzed by choice and what can seem a lack of final consequences.

title: What Were Reading: G.E.D.s vs. Diplomas
Resort Report | Brian Reyess Trip to the Island
description: Holiday hot spots like Capri or St. Barths have provided the inspiration for many a resort collection, but Brian Reyes found his inspiration looking at old photos from a rarely evoked destination island: Ellis Island. The palette is simple and soft with lilac, grays, black, and white, and the silhouettes are modern. Standouts include a great beige fur jacket, a black knit dress and a lot of culotte pants.

title: Borges on Pleasure Island
description: Little is quite as dull as literary worship; this essay on Borges is thus happily doomed. One finds oneself tempted toward learned-sounding inadequacies like: His work combines the elegance of mathematical proof with the emotionally profound wit of Dostoyevsky. Or: He courts paradox so primrosely, describing his Dupin-like detective character as having reckless perspicacity and the light in his infinite Library of Babel as being insufficient, and unceasing. But see, such worship is pale.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: IMPATIENT WITH DESIRE  By Gabrielle Burton.  Voice/Hyperion, $22.99.

title: Editors Choice
description: HITCH-22: A Memoir,  by Christopher Hitchens (Twelve, $26.99.) When the colorful, prolific journalist shares a tender memory, he quickly converts it into a larger observation about politics, always for him the most crucial sphere of moral and intellectual life.

title: Paperback Row
description: HALF THE SKY: Turning Oppression Into Opportunity for Women Worldwide,  by Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn (Vintage, $15.95.) The struggle for gender equality is the paramount moral challenge of our era, write Kristof and WuDunn, who won a Pulitzer Prize for their coverage of China in The New York Times, and their aim is to recruit the reader to join a worldwide movement against gendercide. Denouncing abuses and offering strategies, they tell stories of forced prostitution, honor killing and maternal mortality. In The Times, Martha Nussbaum called it a wonderful book.

title: Electronic Expressions in the Service of the Soul
description: LAURIE ANDERSON was home for a few hours last month  a rare occurrence. This musician and multi-media artist had returned from Poland, where she performed improvised music with the saxophonist and composer John Zorn and the bassist Bill Laswell. Soon she would be off to Iceland for a solo recital, and then to Australia, where she was a curator of the Vivid Live arts festival in Sydney with her husband, Lou Reed. In addition to retrospective and work-in-progress performances she would introduce a video installation and give a high-frequency outdoor concert composed primarily for an audience of dogs. (It was apparently a hit.)

title: Turn Right, My Love
description: I REMEMBER the first time I noticed. I was driving to Boston from my home in Brooklyn after an extended trip to California. In Los Angeles, the voice of my brand-new portable navigation device had guided me effortlessly through the maze of freeways and road rage like a graceful hostess  unflappable, efficient and with just enough sex appeal to give some sizzle to my protracted absence from my wife. Now, stuck on I-95 in Stamford, Conn., my charming companion had somehow been switched to a stern English schoolmarm.

title: Last Dance
description: DARCI KISTLER has a way of walking onto a stage and casting a spell. For years you could be sure that someone in the audience  in barely a whisper  would remind you that the woman with the honey blond hair, broad shoulders and killer legs was the last ballerina trained and hired by George Balanchine.

title: Doodle Jump Reaches Five Million Downloads
description: In early 2009, Igor and MarkoPusenjak, two brothersoriginallyfromCroatia, decided they wanted to build an application for the iPhone that would enable them to make extra money on the side.

title: How to Choose a Mover
description: How I chose movers in the past isnt anything Im proud of. The last time I picked a mover, I remember doing a quick search online and then signing up with the first mover I called.

title: Film Series and Movies Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Karzai Pressed to Move on Taliban Reintegration
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three weeks after a grand assembly recommended making peace with the Taliban and other armed groups, NATO and Afghan officials are pressing President Hamid Karzai to move more quickly to set up a council to oversee the process and to set in motion a plan to win over low-level Taliban fighters.

title: Congress Considers Funding for In-Car Alcohol Detection System
description: A government-auto industry program that is trying to develop a device to detect drunken drivers, which would be installed in all new vehicles, is on track to get a six-fold increase in funding.

title: Hedge Hogs
description: This is not an obvious time to be glorifying financial tycoons. Making enough money to buy your own private island might have earned you an airbrushed magazine cover a decade ago. Nowadays, though, the erstwhile Masters of the Universe are viewed with such opprobrium that one of their favorite lawyers told me recently he was advising his clients to soft-pedal their objections to financial reform legislation because the more Wall Street hates it, the better it plays on Main Street.

title: New Stephen Hawking Book Is Coming in a Finite Amount of Time
description: The latest book from Stephen Hawking, the British theoretical physicist and author of the runaway bestseller, A Brief History of Time, will be released Sept. 7, its publisher Bantam Dell said on Friday. The new book is called The Grand Design, and is written with Leonard Mlodinow, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Hawkings book will address worldly questions  Why do we exist? Did the universe need a creator?  and consider whether theres a single unifying theory that can explain all the forces of nature.

title: This Is How They Roll
description: ANYONE wondering which retro childhood pastime is poised for the kind of revival that roller derby and coed kickball enjoyed in recent years might look no further than Full Circle, a recently opened bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, devoted to Skee-Ball, the classic arcade game that involves rolling a wooden ball up a slightly inclined alley and trying to land it in a series of holes.

title: Subway Woes, Now and Then
description: Since 1904, there have been not two, but three certainties in life: death, taxes and dissatisfaction with the subway.

title: Aggression Shift: Mathieu Turns Tables on Youzhny
description: One of the quirks of the tennis scoring system is that a player can win more overall games but still lose the match. Mikhail Youzhny of Russia won one more game than Paul-Henri Mathieu of France, but the Frenchman prevailed in a fascinating five-set match on Court 18, 6-4, 2-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. It was a match that each player seemed in control of, with Youzhny storming back from a first-set loss to dominate Mathieu. But he played more conservatively when he had the lead, allowing Mathieu to seize the initiative with bold, aggressive play.

title: Prophet-Making
description: In late March, the former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan told Al Hunt of Bloomberg Television that the financial crisis had been a once in a century shocker. We all misjudged the risks involved, Greenspan said. Everybody missed it  academia, the Federal Reserve, all regulators.

title: Rare Haven of Stability in Somalia Faces a Test
description: BURAO, Somalia  The rallies usually start early in the morning, before the sunshine hurts.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 25
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Phantom Calls and Damp Sensors
description: CHRYSLER and Dodge minivans in need of new air-bag sensors and General Motors OnStar systems that make calls on their own are the subjects of some of the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Q. and A. With Fred Plotkin (Round 3)
description: Fred Plotkin, author of Italy for the Gourmet Traveler is answering reader questions. Questions were submitted by readers last week. (Answers to Round One and two.)

title: Risk Mismanagement
description: Wall Street is a place of big money and bigger egos. So its hardly surprising that vicious feuds will occasionally break out, especially when someones being blamed for the demise of a major investment bank, as James Cayne was when Bear Stearns collapsed in March 2008. Shortly after that historic event, Alan C. Greenberg, Caynes predecessor as the head of Bear Stearns, started working on his memoirs. It was reported that Cayne was wary of the coming Greenberg broadside.

title: The Minivan, Once a Star Player, Now Sits on Sidelines
description: MAYBE it was an image problem, or soccer-mom backlash. Or perhaps the minivan was a victim of bullying by those big bad S.U.V.s. But for whatever reason, the family-van market is a shadow of its former self.

title: London Underground | Time for Architecture
description: Architecture is very much on the agenda this month. The biennial London Festival of Architecture in full swing, with events and activities taking place across the city, and four major institutions have just opened must-see exhibitions that do their best to critique the personal and domestic spaces we inhabit.

title: Bookmark This: Resources for Oft-Taught Subjects All in One Place
description: Schools finally out for many, but we know that even teachers not staffing summer programs or working in year-round schools use this season to plan curriculum.

title: Legends of the Fall
description: The fall of Lehman Brothers, the 158-year-old firm bankrupted by its hubris and perilous mortgage bets, was one of the defining episodes of the 2008 financial crisis. Its chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., became overnight, in the words of Vicky Ward, a poster boy for the naked avarice of Wall Street.

title: TimesCast | June 25, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, reports on the new financial reform deal in Congress, a new job for the David Letterman extortionist and a World Cup update.

title: Policy Conflicts Seen as Obama Arrives in Toronto
description: TORONTO  President Obama arrived here Friday for back-to-back meetings of world leaders that will test international unity on how to restore global economic growth.

title: Court Upholds Landmark Status of City and Suburban First Avenue Estates
description: The New York Appellate Court on Thursday unanimously upheld the landmark status of the City and Suburban First Avenue Estates on Manhattans Upper East Side. In 2006, the two tan-brick apartment houses were designated a landmark, even though the owners had reclad them in reddish-pink stucco, drastically changing their appearance.

title: That On-Again Brooklyn Yard Party? Now at a New Location
description: Turns out the Gowanus canal is socially, not only environmentally, inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summers worth of programming there, Sunday Best, the weekly electronica party that tried to make a go of the outdoor space known as the Yard, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding as planned, there were unforeseen complications with the space, Justin Carter, a founder of Sunday Best, said in a phone interview. Rather than leave fans wondering whether the party would go on each week, they are moving to the courtyard of Brooklyn Fireproof, a warehouse space and caf in Bushwick, starting this Sunday, with Kenny Larkin, a Detroit D.J. on the decks, and no toxic odors in the air.

title: Snowe Urges Stand-Alone Extension of Jobless Benefits
description: 2:46 p.m. | Updated  After joining with her fellow Republicans to block a bill that would have extended unemployment insurance, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine urged Democrats on Friday to put forward a separate bill to help people who have exhausted their jobless benefits.

title: Vatican Criticizes Raid on Belgian Church Offices
description: ROME  The Vatican expressed shock on Friday at the raid on Thursday by the Belgian police of church offices in their search for hidden evidence of child sex abuse by priests. It also voiced its indignation at what it called the violation of two cardinals tombs in the search.

title: ReTweet | Louis Vuitton Tattoos
description: A tweetpic from T Magazines mens fashion director, Bruce Pask.

title: Now Screening | Rick Owens
description: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Rick Owens at Paris  Fashion Week.

If you havent seen Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe, add it to your Netflix queue pronto! Johansson riffed on Wagstaffs ability to morph from uptown art collector to downtown bohemian in a collection that includes slouchy masculine suits for above 57th Street and sexy, short leather dresses that are perfect for below 14th.

title: Rockaway Taco Sprouts a Farm Stand
description: Surfer dudes can always load up on veggies and fruit at some Greenmarket before they jumped on the A Train to Rockaway Beach in Queens. But its easier to do the shopping once they get there, at the new little market in the expanding, ramshackle complex anchored by Rockaway Taco. Elizabeth Gilchrist, a partner, said the produce was mainly local (much of it from Blooming Hill Farm in the Hudson Valley) and organic. Right now, greens, including callaloo, are in abundance, $3 a bag. There are also some tropical fruits because they are used by the smoothie stand that shares the premises. The market also sells bread from Robertas in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and some locally handmade odds and ends like glasses made from Red Stripe beer bottles, $10 each.

title: The Shame of JournoList
description: When the intra-liberal e-mail round-robin known as JournoList first attracted attention early last year, it seemed significant primarily as a milestone in the emergence of a kind of movement liberal mentality among certain media personalities  a team-player spirit, you might say, that imitated what liberals have long perceived as one of the strengths of movement conservatism. I suspect that some of the journalists who participated in the e-mail list (Im thinking of figures who write for mainstream outlets like Time and Newsweek and The New Yorker, in particular) would have never dreamed of joining a semi-secret liberal forum a decade ago: That would have seemed too partisan, too compromising, too biased. But now the world had changed, and they were happy to join a members-only political discussion group that deliberately excluded right-of-center writers and thinkers.

title: TD1 Forms in West-Central Caribbean

Based on those indicators plus and an aircraft reconnaissance flight into it, it was upgraded to Tropical Depression 1 at 22Z today (6pm EDT). description: On encountering the labels of Anthony Nappa Wines, one might speculate that the winemaker is playful, adventurous, provocative and young. Right on all counts.

title: Bracing for 35 Probable School Closings Next Year
description: If you thought this year was a dramatic one for school closings  with 19 city schools shut in January over the objections of thousands of parents and teachers before being given a temporary reprieve by a court  wait until next year.

title: Cambodian Dreams, Far From Home
description: The French-Cambodian choreographer Emmanule Phuon, fondly known as Manou during her time as a dancer with Mikhail Baryshnikovs White Oak Dance Project, digs into her past in Khmeropdies I & II. She began training at 5 at the Royal Ballet of Cambodia; in her new two-part work, which opened on Thursday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, she applies Western ideas to traditional Cambodian dance.

title: Now Frosting | The Cake Committee
description: And I thought strawberries were overrated. Who would have guessed that a cake, slathered in a heavy mask of pink frosting and garnished with tiny plastic clown heads, would prove me wrong?

title: Cabaret: Precarious but Resilient
description: Stability is a word not often used to describe New York Citys fragile cabaret world, where only a few can make a full-time living, and the clubs themselves ride an economic seesaw from week to week. But because Manhattans three major supper clubs  the Caf Carlyle, the Oak Room and Feinsteins at Loews Regency  are attached to hotels, their survival is not solely dependent on the box office.

title: New Hawking Book Is Out In a Finite Amount of Time
description: The latest book from Stephen Hawking, the British theoretical physicist and author of the bestseller A Brief History of Time, will be released Sept. 7, its publisher, Bantam Dell, said on Friday. The new book is titled The Grand Design and was written with Leonard Mlodinow, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Hawkings book will address worldly questions  Why do we exist? Did the universe need a creator?  and consider whether theres a single unifying theory that can explain all the forces of nature. Mr. Mlodinow is the author of The Drunkards Walk: How Randomness Rules Our Lives, about how mathematical laws affect seemingly simple events around us, and he collaborated with Mr. Hawking on A Briefer History of Time, published in 2005.

title: N.E.A. To Present Achievement Awards
description: The National Endowment for the Arts will announce lifetime achievement awards on Friday in the fields of opera, jazz, and folk and traditional arts. The honorees include the composer Philip Glass, right, for opera, and five members of the Marsalis family, for jazz. Besides Branford, Delfeayo, Ellis Jr., Jason and Wynton Marsalis, the other 2011 Jazz Masters are Orrin Keepnews, a writer and record producer; Hubert Laws, a flutist; David Liebman, a saxophonist and flutist; and Johnny Mandel, a composer-arranger. The honorees in folk and traditional arts are Yacub Addy, a Ghanaian drummer; Jim Chancellor, a fiddler; Gladys Kukana Grace, a Lauhala weaver; Mary Jackson, a sweetgrass basketweaver; Delano Floyd McCoury, a bluegrass guitarist and singer; Judith McCulloh, a folklorist and editor; Kamala Lakshmi Narayanan, a Bharatanatyam Indian dancer; Mike Rafferty, an Irish flute player; and Ezequiel Torres, an Afro-Cuban drummer and drum builder. The opera honorees, besides Mr. Glass, are Martina Arroyo, a soprano; David DiChiera, a composer and the general director of the Michigan Opera Theater; and Eve Queler, the music director of Opera Orchestra of New York. Each award comes with $25,000.

title: Lilith Tour Cancels Dates, Report Says
description: Just before the resurrected Lilith tour is scheduled to begin on Sunday in Calgary, Alberta, The Globe and Mail newspaper of Toronto reported that the concert series has been canceling dates because of poor ticket sales. The Lilith tour, which spotlights female artists and whose founders include Sarah McLachlan, is preparing for its first season since 1999, with a lineup that includes Mary J. Blige, Sheryl Crow, above, and Erykah Badu. But a manager for Norah Jones told The Globe and Mail that the dates Ms. Jones was scheduled to perform on, from Aug. 10 through Aug. 16 in West Palm Beach and Tampa, Fla.; Birmingham, Ala.; Houston; and Dallas had been dropped. Norah was prepared to do all the Lilith dates she was contracted for and then those dates were canceled, the manager, Sam Feldman, said. The Lilith tour had previously announced the cancellations of stops in Phoenix and Nashville. A press representative for the 2010 Lilith tour wrote in an e-mail message that there was nothing to confirm right now.

title: Bklyn Yard Party Now at a New Location
description: Turns out the Gowanus Canal is socially as well as environmentally inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summers worth of programming at the Bklyn Yard, an event space by the canal, Sunday Best, a weekly electronica party, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding as planned, there were unforeseen complications with the space, Justin Carter, a founder of Sunday Best, said in a telephone interview. Rather than leave fans wondering whether the party would go on each week, they are moving to the courtyard of Brooklyn Fireproof, a warehouse space and cafe in Bushwick, starting this Sunday, with Kenny Larkin, a Detroit D.J. on the decks, and no toxic odors in the air.

title: A Good Night for Rookies
description: Two premieres on ABC lifted the network in the ratings on Thursday, though crime show repeats on CBS led the night over all. According to Nielsens estimates, ABC garnered its best ratings of the night with Wipeout at 8 p.m., which attracted 7.8 million viewers. Following it, ABCs new police drama Rookie Blue made its debut at 9, drawing 7.3 million viewers, while at 10, the networks eight-part documentary series Boston Med got off to a decent start with 5.1 million viewers. Fox was third with So You Think You Can Dance (6.4 million) following a rerun of Glee (3.9 million). NBC placed a distant fourth with a line-up of mostly comedy repeats.

title: Bollywood Prepares a Bin Laden Satire
description: After plans to make a movie about Adolf Hitler drew widespread protest and resulted in the withdrawal of the projects lead actor, the film industry in India is now set to produce a feature about another polarizing figure, Osama bin Laden. But unlike Dear Friend Hitler, which will be a historical drama about that German dictators last days, the Bollywood movie Tere bin Laden (Without You, bin Laden) uses the Al Qaeda leader and the 9/11 attacks as a vehicle for satire, Agence France-Presse reported. In Tere bin Laden, a reporter played by the Pakistani actor and singer Ali Zafar is blocked from entering the United States after Sept. 11, 2001. The reporter becomes the subject of worldwide attention and a White House investigation when he begins producing fake news reports using a bin Laden impersonator. Mr. Zafar was quoted by Agence France-Presse as saying that the film is a satire and does not hurt anyones ideology. He added: The idea excited me and the script was hilarious. The films writer and director, Abhishek Sharma, told the wire service, People want new concepts, not commercial films.

title: Court Upholds Status of Manhattan Buildings
description: The New York Appellate Court on Thursday unanimously upheld the landmark status of the City and Suburban First Avenue Estates on the Upper East Side. In 2006, the two tan-brick apartment houses were designated a landmark, even though the owners had re-clad them in reddish-pink stucco, drastically changing their appearance. The two buildings clearly have a historical significance that justifies their designation as landmarks, the court said in its decision. City Councilwoman Jessica Lappin, who represents parts of the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island and was formerly chairwoman of the councils landmarks committee, said: I commend the court for making the right decision. Now the owner should restore these buildings to their former state and stop fighting a losing and wrongheaded battle with the community. The ugly pink stucco has to go. Brian Maddox, a spokesman for the Stahl York Avenue, which owns the property, said, We are weighing all legal options, including an appeal, which will permit us to pursue our interest in developing the property.

title: Taking It to the Banks?
description: So, one general is out, another is back and President Obama says its time to persist and we persevere. Well, House and Senate Democrats seemed to take the message to heart, and after what The Timess Edward Wyatt called a 20-hour marathon by members of a House-Senate conference committee on Thursday and Friday, the two chambers reconciled competing versions of legislation that would transform financial regulation. An impressive bit of legislative perseverance from the Democratic leadership, to be sure, but will the end product truly offer families the protections they deserve, help safeguard their financial security and give the businesses of America access to the credit they need to expand and innovate, as Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner promises? I suppose it depends on whom you ask.

Mr. Revels was elected to the Senate by Mississippi legislators in 1870 and ushered in a generation of 20 other black Republican congressmen, all from the South, in the two decades after the war.

Laura Robson of Britain, 16, who won the girls title in 2008 and played in the womens singles, doubles and mixed doubles fields this year, is a surprise wild card entry into the junior event.

On Tuesday morning at the original outpost of Mercadito, a tiny taqueria on Avenue B that attracts a young, hip crowd and feels like a resort cantina, a mellow version of this phenomenon played out as Mexico struggled against Uruguay. Even with a $25 all-you-can-eat tacos or wings special on offer during games, not everyone can show up at 10 a.m. for soccer. Those who did  a few couples up front, a group of men in back  sat transfixed, at times rising halfway out of their seats, calling out Vamos, or clasping their hands as if in prayer when either team came close to triumph or disaster. title: Jury Says Merck Must Pay $8 Million in Fosamax Case

The jury in New York set damages at $8 million in the case of Shirley Boles, 72, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., who said she developed osteonecrosis of the jaw by taking Fosamax. With osteonecrosis, a bone is no longer alive and cannot regenerate because of a lack of blood supply, according to the National Osteonecrosis Foundations Web site. The first Fosamax case resulted in a Merck victory in May. United States District Judge John F. Keenan, who is overseeing federal Fosamax litigation, scheduled three bellwether trials that might point the way to out-of-court settlements and show each side the others strategy. The third case is to be tried in November. We believe the jury verdict was a result of plaintiffs counsels inflammatory and prejudicial remarks, Paul F. Strain, a lawyer for Merck, said in a statement.

Cho Chang, not Hermione, was the girlfriend of Mr. Pattinsons character, Cedric Diggory. The article also omitted one of movies in which he appeared. Besides Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, he was in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the playwright A. R. Gurney erroneously included one of the actresses in Mr. Gurneys play The Grand Manner. While Boyd Gaines and Kate Burton were shown, Brenda Wehle was not.

title: Three Killed at Political Rally in Mexico
description: ZINACANTN, Mexico (AP)  A mob armed with clubs, stones and guns attacked a political rally in southern Mexico on Saturday, sparking hours of clashes that left three people dead and six more wounded.

title: U.S. Keeps Command of Military in Seoul
description: TORONTO  In its strongest move since the sinking of a South Korean warship, the Obama administration said Saturday that the United States would retain control of all military forces in the South during any conflict with North Korea, which has been widely blamed for the attack on the ship in March that killed 46 sailors.

title: Keeping the Africa in Africas World Cup
description: There were two teams in this compelling contest at Rustenburg. As difficult as it was for the United States to go out in such a fashion, the importance of Ghanas young, brave and ultimately undeniable victory has ramifications for the World Cup as a whole.

title: History Repeats Itself With Relievers Complete Game
description: Two words best describe what Michael Roth, a South Carolina sophomore left-hander, did at the College World Series on Friday night. Unexpected. Remarkable.

description: Americans celebrated across the country last Wednesday when the national team beat Algeria with a last-minute goal. But on Saturday it was the Ghanaians turn to celebrate, and they did, all around the world.

description: Sarah Mead and Reed Burgoyne met in San Francisco in 2002. Both artists, they teamed up in their art adventure and fell in love. Their current project is their handmade paper wedding.

title: A London Party for Your Inner Child
description: British high society in the 1920s saw a rise of decadent dress-up parties with absurd themes. One, called Come as You Were 20 Years Ago resulted in young socialites showing up in giant baby carriages pushed by their butler.

title: How to Turn an Old iPod Into Cash
description: Earlier this year, we started a recurring feature here at Bucks where we highlight others online who present novel cost-saving strategies we wish we had thought of. In our first installment, we detailed a creative tip for keeping thieves from trying to steal your important possessions. In this second installment, here are some tips weve found online for turning your possessions into cash and for saving on your commute that go beyond craigslist and public transportation.

title: New Czech Prime Minister Is Named
description: PRAGUE President Vaclav Klaus of the Czech Republic said Sunday he would appoint a center-right leader, Petr Necas, as the countrys new prime minister on Monday, clearing the way for a government that is both pro-American and focused on fiscal austerity.

description: ROME  In a sign of sharply rising tensions between the Vatican and Belgium, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday criticized as surprising and deplorable a raid on church property last week by Belgian police officers investigating sexual abuse by clerics.

description: Instant replay arrived in world soccer on Sunday. It became absolutely essential when the field officials totally missed the shot from Englands Frank Lampard that hit the crossbar and bounced fully two feet into the goal.

title: Kyrgyz Voting Calm After Violence
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyzstans interim leader, Roza Otunbayeva, declared victory on Sunday in a constitutional referendum that she hopes will legitimize her position as president and help stabilize the country, but in a sign of continuing disarray in her government, the director of the Central Election Committee said too few ballots had been counted to call the vote.

title: Family of Captured Israeli Soldier Press for Deal
description: TEL AVIV  The family of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, the Israeli soldier who has been held captive by Hamas in Gaza for four years, began a march to Jerusalem on Sunday aimed at pressing the government to make a deal for the soldiers release.

title: Pakistans Plan on Afghan Peace Leaves U.S. Wary
description: President Obama and the director of the Central Intelligence Agency both reacted with skepticism on Sunday about the prospects for an Afghanistan peace deal pushed by Pakistan between the Afghan government and some Taliban militants.

title: World Cup Live: Argentina vs. Mexico
description: Argentina stepped out of group play and into the knockout round, where if the pressure was supposed to be ramped up, it was never apparent.

description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For months, outfielder Carlos Beltran has pegged his comeback from off-season knee surgery to the Mets series against the Florida Marlins in Puerto Rico.

title: 40 Winks? Shed Even Settle for 30
description: Dressed optimistically in sweatpants and a starry Little Night Music T-shirt, Patricia Morrisroe reported for guinea-pig duty at a Manhattan clinic for sleep disorders. She was there for a $3,200 overnight stay during which her insomnia would be monitored. As a technician hooked her up to 25 electrodes and sensors, he reassured her that if any of these became disconnected while she slept, he would return and reattach them without disturbing her.

description: I watched Daniel Brandss tough first-round win over Igor Andreev in three sets and came away impressed. Andreev is a difficult opponent; recall that he had Roger Federer on the ropes in Melbourne earlier this year.

title: Strains of Klezmer and Bashevis Singer, and Then Mendelssohn, Too
description: Among the salient aspects of Mendelssohns life, that he was born a Jew could almost have seemed irrelevant had Wagner not seized on it to fuel a notorious aesthetic pogrom that wrecked Mendelssohns reputation for some time. Mendelssohn, only four years older than Wagner, was baptized as an infant; still, Wagner held up his former idols ethnicity as a sign of artistic blight.

title: A Haydn Sonata Accented With Ingenuity
description: On Saturday night, less than a month after winning first prize in the prestigious Queen Elisabeth Piano Competition in Brussels, the young Russian Denis Kozhukhin, born in 1986, played a recital at Zankel Hall presented by Monet MGM. Although the auditorium was not full, the audience was understandably enthusiastic. Mr. Kozhukhin gave formidable, freshly considered accounts of two challenging staples: Schumanns Symphonic tudes and Mussorgskys Pictures at an Exhibition.

title: World Leaders Agree on Timetable for Cutting Deficits
description: TORONTO  Leaders of the worlds biggest economies agreed Sunday on a timetable for cutting deficits and halting the growth of their debt, but also acknowledged the need to move carefully so that reductions in spending did not set back the fragile global recovery.
