description: THE-DREAM

title: Philosophy App
description: In his Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy, the science fiction writer Douglas Adams introduces Deep Thought  a computer the size of a small city, designed millions of years ago by a race of hyperintelligent pan-dimensional beings searching for the meaning of life. The super computer is described as a so amazingly intelligent that even before the data banks had been connected up it had started from I think therefore I am and got as far as the existence of rice pudding and income tax before anyone managed to turn it off

title: Box Office Measures Star Power
description: LOS ANGELES  The weekend box office delivered very different results for three A-list stars, as Adam Sandler hit another home run in Grown Ups, and Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz whiffed in Knight and Day.

title: Jazz Tradition and Whats Worth Keeping
description: Ambrose Akinmusires opening set at the Jazz Standard on Friday showed some excitement and unease: a young trumpeter and composer still looking for, or maybe still rejecting, a style. The music wasnt quite there yet, and it wasnt clear just where there was. But the irresolution felt good enough for now.

title: Police in Toronto Criticized for Treatment of Protesters, Many Peaceful
description: TORONTO  An escalation of aggressive police tactics toward even apparently peaceful protests at the Group of 20 summit meeting led to calls for a review of security activities.

title: Victory Means a Chance at the Bermuda Bowl
description: The 120-board final of the open trial to select the U.S.A.-1 team for next years Bermuda Bowl ended in Chicago late on Sunday. After 90 boards, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss led Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby, 185 international match points to 182.

title: The Seating Is the Stage for a Night
description: Jason Jordans dance career had humble beginnings: When he was 7, he was voted the best dancer at a Brooklyn house party. (His prize amounted to $5.) He went on to train and perform with Eliot Felds Ballet Tech, where he was a particularly luxuriant dancer  sinewy and nave, yet coolly confident. Now, as part of this years Vision Festival, Mr. Jordan presents his own company in a series of dance installations called Stations, in which he attempts to capture the essence of human development.

title: Sleek Playfulness and a Plea to the Heavens
description: Sense and sensuality: that was the credo for the R&B singers-songwriters Maxwell and Jill Scott at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Their double bill proposed a study in compatible contrasts, and, if you like, a treatise on the interplay of gender and power, seduction and surrender. But thats probably over-thinking the issue. Its certainly underplaying the pleasure of a surefooted, playfully intelligent, supremely satisfying show.

title: Shapes and Spaces for Peripheral Vision
description: Rob List is the sort of artist whose work transfixes, drawing you minute by minute through strange yet familiar terrain; the impulse is always to hold your breath.

title: No Trendy Bells and Whistles, Just Mozart on a Summer Eve
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Every summer festival has its own personality  a combination of atmosphere and sense of mission  and though that may evolve with audience demographics and tastes, most find ways to retain some of their original spirit. From 1929 to 1939, Lucie and Walter Rosen cobbled together a large country house at Caramoor, their 90-acre estate here, made up of rooms in disparate styles (from palaces and other buildings) that they acquired in Europe. When the house was finished, the Rosens began presenting concerts in their music room, and in 1946 they opened Caramoor to the public as a performing-arts center.

title: A Crusader for Boldness as the Arts Face Deficits
description: NEW HAVEN  Watching Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, speak to arts executives, as he did during two recent swings through New England, is like watching Jack Welch talk to business students.

title: McChrystals Quality Time With Rolling Stone: Impertinent? Check. Insubordinate? Maybe Not.
description: You could say General Stanley A. McChrystal was a victim of his own hubris  the archetypal field commander who got too intemperate with the suits back at headquarters.

title: Can Girls Be Overweight and Not Be Overwrought?
description: Gitbigger.com, a chronicle of a recent college graduate in Kentucky who is trying to get fat, is an example of one of the Internets proliferating gainer blogs. Writing this month, the blogger, who calls himself Stupidgit, told readers that although he had reached a point where he was consuming 3,000 calories a day, he was burning them off too easily, and that this deficit had become a problem. I simply need to set my bar higher, he announced, expressing the kind of resolve normally associated with people trying to look like Lance Armstrong.

title: Hacienda Material
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle will have you seeing double, with six gaga-like phrases making up the theme. The repeated syllables mostly all rhyme, with RARA AVIS being the biggest deviant (sounds sinister, doesnt it?). BABA WAWA finishes things up with a double dose of doubling.

title: Eric Claptons Crossroads Guitar Festival
description: BRIDGEVIEW, Ill.  Close-ups of strings, fretboards and guitarists callused fingers filled the video screens on Saturday at Toyota Park here, a stadium just outside Chicago, where Eric Claptons Crossroads Guitar Festival presented some two-dozen guitar-slingers during a sold-out, 11-hour concert.

title: Thom Browne: Party Line
description: The American designer Thom Browne, having his Paris debut, invited everyone this evening to the French Communist Party headquarters, in a handsome Oscar Niemeyer building. After a bit of a wait, we were shown into a sloped meeting room with rows of long tables and little French and American flags at each place. Presently four identical-looking models entered the room dressed in crested blue blazers, shorts, white shirts and ties, and wearing chic wire sunglasses. They sat at the head table and addressed the assembly  first in English, then in French  with a comic gravity.

title: Jackson Collectors Open Their Wallets at Auction
description: This years auction houses have seen no shortage of high-priced Michael Jackson memorabilia, and this weekend, on the anniversary of his death, collectors once again showed they were willing to pay tribute to the pop star. Among the 200 items being auctioned by Juliens Auctions at the Planet Hollywood in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported, were a Swarovski crystal-studded glove, above, he wore on his 1984 Victory Tour (estimated at $20,000 to $30,000) that sold for $192,000, including buyers premium, to Wanda Kelley of Los Angeles. Lets just say I wasnt walking out of here without that glove, Ms. Kelley, who also bought numerous albums at the auction, told The A.P. A similar glove sold for $350,000 in November at an auction by Juliens in New York. A pair of signed black loafers worn by Jackson on stage sold for $90,000, though they were listed at $2,000 to $3,000, and a custom jacket he wore during an interview with Barbara Walters, estimated at $6,000 to $8,000, went for $120,000. Perhaps one of the most poignant items was one of the last autographs signed by Jackson, dated June 24, 2009, which sold for $18,750.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Dreams Deferred
description: So we begin more or less with Tim Rigginss dream denied. Again! On last weeks episode of Friday Night Lights, there was a glimmer of hope for Rigginss  real estate. (And that says it all, doesnt it?) Hed fallen in love with 25 gorgeous, unusually lush acres of tree-lined Texas property, and he could picture a nice life for himself on it. When he inquires about the land, he learns that it costs $85,000. He quite obviously doesnt have the money, and lets not even bother to discuss post-recession financing. Riggins puts on a suit to go meet the Realtor  this is a grown-up appointment  but adult life just doesnt suit Riggins (or it just doesnt like him). He starts pulling at his tie as if its strangling him.

title: From Potter to Trenches
description: Daniel Radcliffe, below, having recently wrapped up filming on the last two Harry Potter movies, has signed on to play a more realistic warrior. Mr. Radcliffe will star in a new film version of All Quiet on the Western Front, based on the novel by Erich Maria Remarque, BBC News reported. The producer Ian Stokell said Mr. Radcliffe is expected to bring a vulnerability and innocence to the character of Paul Baumer, a young German infantryman fighting in the trenches during World War I. Production on the new film is expected to begin in spring 2012, following the completion of Mr. Radcliffes work in the Broadway musical How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. Rob Ashford (Promises, Promises) will direct Mr. Radcliffe in his Broadway debut in a musical, which is expected to open in spring 2011.

title: U.C.L.A. Live Cuts Its International Theater Festival
description: U.C.L.A. Live, the popular performance series that brings leading dance, music and theater companies to Los Angeles each year, has eliminated its prestigious international theater festival from the 2010-11 schedule because of budget cuts, The Los Angeles Times reported. The performance seriess annual budget, around $8 million, has been suffering in recent years because of falling attendance and reduced fund-raising, and the number of events this year has diminished to 47 from 85 in the 2009-10 season. David Sefton, U.C.L.A. Lives artistic director for almost a decade, resigned in May after learning about plans for a major rethinking and restructuring of the series. It was not going to be the program I was originally brought in to run, Mr. Sefton told The Times in May. Its not appropriate for me, and my response was to resign, he said. In past seasons the theater festival has presented innovative productions and acclaimed actors, including the theater and opera director Lenka Udovickis staging of Medea, starring Annette Bening; Ian McKellen in King Lear, directed by Trevor Nunn; and the National Theater of Scotlands widely praised Black Watch.

title: Strings and Songs
description: Photos from the Crossroads Guitar Festival just outside Chicago.

title: Oprah Shows Online Flap
description: A talent search by Oprah Winfrey has taken a confusing turn, thanks to online voting. Ms. Winfreys forthcoming cable channel, OWN, has been holding online and in-person casting calls for Your OWN Show: Oprahs Search for the Next TV Star, a reality show that will have its premiere next year. Last week the search was tainted by allegations from fans of the top two online candidates, Zach Anner and Phyllis Wick-Turner, that the other side had stuffed the online ballot box. Some even suggested that Ms. Winfrey was behind it. The allegations, picked up by the news media, prompted a channel spokesperson to say in a statement that no contestant has been favored in this competition, but that an investigation would be undertaken and that all votes would be verified twice. The five most popular online contestants will go before a casting director, but only one is guaranteed a spot on the reality show, though OWN could choose to add more than one. A total of 10 in-person and online contestants will vie for a spot; eventually the shows winner will be hired by OWN. By Sunday, Mr. Anner had accumulated two million more votes than Ms. Wick-Turner.

title: Footnote
description: The National Theater of London has announced a second season of National Theater Live, through which live performances will be broadcast to movie theaters worldwide. Screenings will begin Oct. 14 with the 2008 Olivier Award winner for best new play, A Disappearing Number, a collaborative work by the director Simon McBurneys Complicite theater group. Other screenings will include Fela!, Nicholas Hytners Hamlet and Danny Boyles Frankenstein. Times and locations will be announced later this summer.

title: A Family News Affair
description: Yahoo has announced that it has acquired a new online current-affairs show created by Ben Stiller and featuring his parents, the comedians and actors Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, above, The Guardian reported last week. Elisa Steele, Yahoos chief marketing officer, told The Guardian that the short Webisodes, probably less than 10 minutes each, would revolve around news items of the day, with Mr. Stiller and Ms. Meara providing commentary and the younger Mr. Stiller directing. Ben had a great idea, Ms. Steele said. He started to talk to us and it was a good fit with Yahoo. The show is expected to been seen exclusively online by years end.

title: Life Lessons, and Sweet Siren Song of The-a-tuh
description: The title is The Grand Manner, but the style of A. R. Gurneys latest play, which opened Sunday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, is definitely on the cozy side. A homey needlepoint embroidery on Mr. Gurneys encounter as a prep school student with the fabled American actress Katharine Cornell, this fantasy memoir allows the authors younger, provincial self a seductive first glimpse of a world where being merely life-size isnt enough.

title: The P.R. Blitz for the Presidency
description: In the campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, the two candidates  Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the incumbent, and Anatoly Karpov, the former champion  are each trying to portray themselves as front runners.

title: Tracking Gulf Oil and Storms
description: 7:43 p.m. | Updated There were a couple of days of breathless news stories playing up the threat to operations around the BP oil gusher posed by the brewing storm called Alex. But federal storm forecasters never saw much of a chance of this storm shifting northeast toward the region beset by slicks and oiled shores. As of Sunday night, the storm, still a tropical depression, had finished pummeling the Yucatan Peninsula and was projected to strengthen over warm Gulf of Mexico waters before making landfall on shores in the western gulf (although some models still calculate a possible risk to the oily east).

title: New Diploma Standard in New York Becomes a Multiple-Question Choice
description: When the State Education Department announced five years ago that all students would soon be required to pass five tests to earn high school diplomas in New York, officials applauded themselves for raising standards.

description: CONAKRY, Guinea  Long lines of voters snaked outside of polling places Sunday in what was widely hailed as this West African nations first free presidential election since independence 52 years ago.

Nearly six miles away, on the sixth floor of a nursing home in Brooklyn, the frail, white-haired woman in beige pajamas and brown slippers in Room 609 sat motionless at the edge of her bed, staring out her window.

title: Accident at Park Puts Focus on Trees
description: The accident occurred on a glorious, postcard-ready summer afternoon in New York, free of the usual culprits of lightning or snow. A large, healthy tree branch, 30 feet above a well-traveled path just outside the Central Park Zoo, snapped, fell and killed a 6-month-old girl as horrified visitors looked on.

description: JOHANNESBURG  It was forward Carlos Tvez who said the words no one else was willing to speak: the only satisfactory World Cup for Argentina would be to win it.

description: TORONTO  Giant banks, while bracing for a wave of tougher regulation in Washington, will not have to face a new set of global rules on capital and liquidity anytime soon.

description: The girls parents, wild with outrage and fear, showed the principal the text messages: a dozen shocking, sexually explicit threats, sent to their daughter the previous Saturday night from the cellphone of a 12-year-old boy. Both children were sixth graders at Benjamin Franklin Middle School in Ridgewood, N.J.

Pride Marches On
description: The 2010 Pride March celebrating the citys gay population filled the streets of Greenwich Village with thousands of spectators.

title: Puerto Ricos Pipeline Has Been Running Low
description: A decade ago, even a casual baseball fan could name an all-star teams worth of players from Puerto Rico: Carlos Delgado at first base; Roberto Alomar at second base; Juan Gonzalez, Ruben Sierra and Bernie Williams in the outfield; and Sandy Alomar Jr., Jorge Posada and Ivan Rodriguez behind the plate.

title: North Korea Rejects U.S. Proposal for Talks on Sinking of Warship
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Sunday rejected an invitation from the American-led United Nations Command to hold talks on the sinking of a South Korean warship three months ago, which a multinational investigation has attributed to the North Koreans.

title: BP Loses Trading-Floor Swagger in Energy Markets
description: It seems like Wall Street at its worst: a cowboy on the trading floor plots to corner a market, and gets caught.

title: Elena Kagans Moment
description: Elena Kagan has produced distinguished scholarship on the First Amendment, taking clear positions favoring a broad interpretation of free speech. She opposed bans on flag burning and hate speech, and tried to come up with a framework for deciding when laws unconstitutionally suppress protected speech. In the Clinton White House, as a domestic policy adviser, she was an advocate for responsible positions on campaign finance limits, tobacco regulation and gun restrictions.

title: U.S. Team Needs a Bradley or Two
description: Irene, South Africa

title: The Return of Superfund
description: Superfund  which cleans up abandoned hazardous waste sites  is one of the countrys most important environmental programs. It has been struggling since 1995, when a Republican Congress refused to renew the corporate taxes that gave it a steady source of financing. The pace of cleanups has dropped markedly.

title: Avatar Beats Hurt Locker Where It Counts: New Oscar Voters
description: Oscar night belonged to a drama, The Hurt Locker, but the path to membership in the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences ran through the science fiction genre this year.

title: Switzerland Starts to Come Clean
description: The United States Treasury forgoes about $100 billion a year in uncollected taxes from businesses and wealthy individuals that keep their money in offshore accounts, out of reach of the Internal Revenue Service. This is not only notoriously unfair; it is a crime. It has also proved notoriously difficult to stop because of the bank secrecy statutes in tax havens around the world.

title: Lush Land Winds Through a Ravaged Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  There is a certain spot in this war-ravaged city that is unusually quiet and profoundly lush, where the trees are older and dripping with vines and where the branches interlace over the road, creating a canopy that filters the usually harsh equatorial sun into something softer. The leaves here seem a brighter, glossier version of themselves. The grasses are long and thick, perfect to hide in.

title: Darci Kistler Stages Last New York City Ballet Show
description: Confetti rained from above, dozens of flowers were tossed at the stage and bouquets piled up at the feet of Darci Kistler as she took her bows at her final performance as a principal of New York City Ballet on Sunday afternoon.

title: Le Mondes Board to Choose Investors

title: Marzorati to Leave Magazine for New Post at The Times

In a memo to the staff on Monday, Bill Keller, the papers executive editor, announced that Gerry Marzorati will be taking on a new role overseeing new initiatives at The Times. Mr. Marzorati will continue to edit the magazine through the summer as the paper searches for his successor. Mr. Keller said he would consider both internal and external candidates for the position. His note to the staff is below.

title: Germany Goalkeeper Saw the Ball Go In [UPDATED]
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated  As reader gonzo points out in Comment #46 below, a more accurate translation of Neuers original quotation in German would be: I only watched the shot from Lampard, grabbed the ball quickly and continued to play. If I had looked to the right and left, maybe the referee would have thought about it. Maybe because of that I contributed to the fact that he didnt give the goal. His actual remarks, therefore, suggest that he was not completely certain that the ball had crossed the line  and only became convinced when he saw the replay in the doping control room after the match.

title: Numberplay: Maximum Protection on Board
description: Last week we discussed spooky action at a distance in Quantum Mechanics. This week we consider a game in which action at a distance is commonplace: chess. Actually, this puzzle is long overdue  it suffered a spooky displacement in time. I had meant to run it in late April or early May during the World Chess Championship in Sofia, Bulgaria, when challenger Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria took on reigning champion Vishwanathan (Vishy) Anand of India. Like boxing, the world chess championship is decided by a gladiatorial, head-to-head 12-round bout (over 18 days!) between the incumbent champion and a worthy challenger. Chess is a war-game after all!

title: Justices Extend Firearm Rights in 5-to-4 Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The Second Amendments guarantee of an individual right to bear arms applies to state and local gun control laws, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

title: A Classic French Sauce, Revisited
description: One of the mainstays of classic French cuisine is the white sauce called bchamel, a mother sauce from which many others are made, including the famously rich sauce mornay. Although bchamel is often referred to as a cream sauce, there is rarely any cream in it. What gives it a rich texture is the suspension of a paste called a roux, made with flour and fat, in a liquid  milk in a classic bchamel, or stock in another French cream sauce called velout.

title: Tour de France Q. and A. With Juliet Macur

The two-time winner Alberto Contador, last years winner, will again be the favorite. But this year he will no longer have as his Astana teammate Lance Armstrong, the seven-time winner who broke off and formed his own team last year.

title: Carrot Gratin With Bchamel

Squash will have to wait until the fall, but there are lots of carrots in farmers markets right now. title: A Long Goodbye From the Last of Balanchines Ballerinas
description: On Sunday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, the ballerina Darci Kistler made her farewell to dancing onstage, at 46. Some in the audience remembered how she first burst into their lives 30 years before, when she danced the Swan Queen with the School of American Ballet. I cannot forget that when she joined New York City Ballet that same year, she already danced not like a flower in bud but like a full-blown rose, in her first solo role as a professional dancer. The company danced in Paris in September 1980, and she performed the Scherzo in Balanchines Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3. To choreography that had seemed among the masters least distinguished she brought an easy hugeness of scale and a sparkling rapture that were intoxicating.

description: Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, also known as the Tall One from Tallinn, beat Klara Zakopalova, 6-2, 6-4, to continue her great run on grass and advance to the quarterfinals. She won despite serving at only 52 percent, stepping up her return game to beat the Czech, who looked tentative on big points. Kanepi, by contrast, won six of nine break points in a match that was a huge opportunity for both players.

title: Beaks, Bills and Climate
description: In the 1800s, an American zoologist named Joel Allen posited that animals in cold climates evolved to have shorter appendages (limbs, ears, and tails) than those in hot climates, in order to minimize surface area and thereby minimize heat loss. The theory, known as Allens rule, has long appeared in biology books, but scientific evidence for it has remained weak.

title: From M.S. Patients, Outcry for Unproved  Treatment
description: For her first appointment with Dr. Daniel Simon, Neelima Raval showed up with a rolling file cabinet full of documents. She had downloaded every word written by or about Dr. Paolo Zamboni, a vascular surgeon from Italy with a most unorthodox theory about multiple sclerosis.

description: Some people are usually cheerful. Others are more likely to have sad, depressing thoughts. Such traits help make up our personalities.

title: The Little Vampire That Could
description: If Stephenie Meyers slender new entry in her Twilight series somehow underperformed the runaway sales of the earlier books in that literary franchise, it would surely fill her rivals with vampiric schadenfreude and have industry observers declaring the craze for those pale-skinned bloodsuckers to be over, thus spawning a new wave of romantic novels about, we dont know, mummies or creatures from the Black Lagoon. But no. On Monday Little Brown Books for Young Readers, which published the Twilight novella, The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner, said the book had sold more than one million copies in the United States since it was released on June 5, The Associated Press reported. That would put the novella, which tells the story of a newborn vampire briefly mentioned in the Twilight novel Eclipse, on pace to be the best-selling book of the year. The film version of Eclipse opens on Wednesday.

title: A Final Turn for World at Daytime Emmys
description: With its cancellation looming, As the World Turns earned three of the top four acting awards at the 37th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards on Sunday night. Michael Park, left, who plays Jack on World, won in the lead drama actor category; Maura West, who plays Carly, won in the lead drama actress category; and Julie Pinson, who plays Janet, won in the supporting actress category. The award for supporting actor went to Billy Miller, who plays Billy on The Young and the Restless. Accepting his award, Mr. Park said, I cant think of a better way to say goodbye to a 13-year run on a 53-year-old show. He noted that taping of his soap opera wrapped last week, telling the audience, I pray that you never have to endure what we endured on Wednesday. The final episode is scheduled to be shown in September. As the World Turns was not nominated in the outstanding drama category; that award went to The Bold and the Beautiful for the second consecutive year.

title: Why Fish Came Ashore
description: About 365 million years ago, the fins of some fish evolved into limbs, creating a class of animals known as tetrapods that left the water to dwell on land, giving rise to amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals.

title: An Unproven Treatment for Multiple Sclerosis
description: An experimental treatment for multiple sclerosis is gaining interest on the Internet, inspiring hope among patients and scorn among skeptics, writes Denise Grady in todays Science Times.

title: Inmates, One Year Later, Are Still Smooth
description: On the first anniversary of Michael Jacksons death nearly everyone whose lives he had touched was heard from: his family and friends, his fellow musicians and even Bubbles the chimpanzee. But what about the convicts in the Philippine prison who became viral sensations for their video re-creation of the zombie dance from Thriller? Not to be omitted from the global Jackson remembrances, more than 900 prisoners at Cebu Provincial Detention and Rehabilitation Center assembled on Saturday to dance to Jacksons songs, including They Dont Really Care About Us, Billie Jean and, of course, Thriller, Agence France-Presse reported. Judge Geraldine Faith Econg, who led a delegation of jurists to the two-hour event, told Agence France-Presse: This will set an example to other rehabilitation centers in the country. It will also give people a different view of the inmates. Mils Bonnen, a teacher from Denmark who was among the 500 visitors who came to watch the performance by convicted murderers, rapists and drug dealers, told the news agency: It was a wonderful presentation. I was very impressed. Their concentration was really there, and they were really serious about their dance. The original Thriller Web video has been watched more than 42 million times on YouTube alone. A video from Saturdays performance is expected to be posted this week.

title: 60 Minutes Ticks at Top
description: On a low-rated Sunday night CBS earned the most viewers with its broadcast of the 37th annual Daytime Emmy Awards and 60 Minutes, the nights most-watched program. According to Nielsens estimates, 5.6 million viewers tuned in to CBS from 9 to 11 p.m. for the awards show. At 7 60 Minutes delivered 7.4 million viewers followed by a repeat of the celebrity special I Get That a Lot (4.4 million) at 8. NBC ranked second on the night, garnering 4.9 million viewers for Dateline from 7 to 9 followed by back-to-back reruns of Law & Order: Criminal Intent at 9 (5 million) and 10 (5.2 million). ABC placed third as its new dramas Scoundrels (3.6 million) and The Gates (3 million) struggled at 9 and 10. Fox finished fourth with reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

title: For Exchanges, Financial Bill Has Some Benefits
description: The sweeping financial regulatory bill does have some benefits for parts of Wall Street. While the banks will face more restrictions, the exchanges potentially stand to win big as a result of new rules on the trading of certain derivative contracts, gaining possibly billions of dollars in new revenue.

title: Chris Brown Enjoys His Second Chance
description: With fallen stars from Tiger Woods to Eliot Spitzer taking their turns on the comeback trail these days, could the moment be right for a second coming of Chris Brown? The BET Awards on Sunday night certainly gave Mr. Brown, above, the tarnished R&B singer, a prominent platform to demonstrate as emotionally  and, at times, theatrically  as possible that hes ready for the forgiveness of his audience. Last summer Mr. Brown was sentenced to six months of community labor and five years of probation after pleading guilty to felonious assault on the pop star Rihanna, an incident that seemed to leave his career in tatters. But at the BET Awards, which were held in Los Angeles, Mr. Brown took center stage as part of a tribute to Michael Jackson. During his performance of Man in the Mirror Mr. Brown frequently became choked up and at one point fell to his knees. Though many viewers accused Mr. Brown of usurping what was supposed to be an honor for Mr. Jackson, Mr. Brown had the last word when he was announced as the surprise winner of BETs Fandemonium award, a prize determined by fan votes. I let you all down before, but I wont do it again, Mr. Brown said in his acceptance speech. I promise you.

title: Introducing Living Rooms
description: Many animals build shelters, some of them dazzlingly efficient and complex, but only humans design homes that thoroughly reflect the architecture of their lives, families, work  even their thoughts. The home has been central to human existence since the Paleolithic age: recent archaeological work in Israel has found evidence of domestic order  food preparation here, beds over there  dating from around 100,000 B.C.E.

title: Near-Empty Tower Still Holds Hope
description: For those who follow real estate trends, One Madison Park, the new luxury residential tower at 23rd Street and Madison Avenue, is a choice example of the hubris that led to the financial crash. Earlier this year, just as workers were putting the final touches on its glittering facades, the building went into foreclosure, halting construction. The floors meant for a swimming pool, a spa and a wine bar remain cavernous concrete shells. The half dozen or so overly eager tenants who chose to move into the tower before its completion are still navigating through labyrinthine scaffolding, an unfinished lobby and ghostly corridors to get to their luxury apartments, without any idea when  or if  construction will begin again.

Still, the new play On the Levee, which opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street as part of Lincoln Center Theaters LCT3 series, manages to manufacture so little compelling drama from a historic natural disaster that neither the ecological scope nor the human cost comes through with much force or clarity.

One of these buildings, the Hopkins Center for the Arts from 1962, without breaking the idyllic tone, still looks relatively modern as architecture. The modernity continues indoors. The Hop has become one of the leaders in commissioning modern-dance works. In the last three years there have been world premieres by Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor and others.

title: They Pushed Back

The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, an arm of the Department of Homeland Security, has concluded that the workers, part of a group of 500 men recruited to work in Gulf Coast shipyards after Hurricane Katrina, had been subject to involuntary servitude and were entitled to visas set aside for victims of human trafficking.

title: Right-to-Know Law Gives Indias Poor a Lever
description: BANTA, India  Chanchala Devi always wanted a house. Not a mud-and-stick hut, like her current home in this desolate village in the mineral-rich, corruption-corroded state of Jharkhand, but a proper brick-and-mortar house. When she heard that a government program for the poor would give her about $700 to build that house, she applied immediately.

Mr. Rugambage, who was tried and acquitted of genocide crimes in 2006, was murdered while working on a report that linked the government to an assassination attempt against a dissident general in South Africa. Two of the men were charged with the murder of a Jewish taxi driver. The case had been under an order of silence. Six of the seven, all 19 to 27 years old, were from Nazareth, the largest Arab city in Israel, and the seventh was from a nearby village, the police said. Aviv Elgrisi, the police chief for the northern region, told Israeli Radio that the men had been inspired to act after watching speeches by Osama bin Laden and that two of them had tried unsuccessfully to go to Somalia to join the Islamic struggle there against the local Christian community.

But truly, theres no people like show people: Patrick Cassidy, above, who played Butler in the musicals last Broadway revival, will take over the role. He has also appeared on Broadway in Aida and 42nd Street and in the film Longtime Companion. The Ravinia production, which is to run Aug. 13 to 15, also stars George Hearn as Buffalo Bill, and will be directed by Lonny Price (110 in the Shade). title: Birthers, Polls and Public Ignorance
description: Theres a new poll out, from Vanity Fair and 60 Minutes, showing that 24 percent of Americans dont think that Barack Obama was born in the United States. On MSNBC last night, Chris Hayes asked me about it, and I tried to suggest that polls like this should be taken with a large grain of salt both because Americans will happily express all kinds of outlandish opinions to a pollster without necessarily meaning much by them (does almost half the public really believe in U.F.O.s, at least in any serious way? Im skeptical ), and because public ignorance is vast and deep enough to account for a good-sized chunk of any apparently-scary fringe opinion. For instance, I suggested that a lot of respondents probably dont know that birthright citizenship is a requirement for the presidency, and that some respondents may not even be aware that Obamas birthplace, Hawaii, is actually one of the 50 states.

title: Stolen Caravaggio Is Recovered
description: A Caravaggio painting considered to be the most valuable work of art in Ukraine was recovered in Germany, two years after it was stolen from a museum in Odessa, Reuters reported. The painting, called The Taking of Christ or The Kiss of Judas, was made by Caravaggio in the early 17th century, and depicts Jesus and his apostles John and Judas as they are being separated by soldiers. It had belonged to a Russian ambassador to France and a Russian prince before it was turned over to the Odessa museum, where it was stolen in 2008. On Tuesday Anatoly Mogylyov, the interior minister of Ukraine, said in a briefing that the Ukrainian and German police had recovered the painting and detained members of a gang that focuses on high-value thefts who had tried to sell the work in Berlin. A version of the painting is also in the National Gallery of Ireland in Dublin.

Mr. Eanet will spend next season with the quartet while a replacement is sought. Mr. Eanet had left a position as a concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera to join the Juilliard, which was founded in 1946. Bella is reciting Robert Frosts poem Fire and Ice, about competing notions of how the world will end. Supposedly its for an English paper, but who is Bella kidding? title: From Buildings to Baubles
description: At age 102, the renowned Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer is still working  and still inspiring. Specifically, he inspired one of his countrymen  Roberto Stern, the president and creative director of the jeweler H. Stern  to bring out a collection of jewelry that was inspired by the maestros sketches of buildings (including one of Brasilia, Niemeyers masterpiece), flowers and even the female form. The H. Stern Collection by Oscar Niemeyer, which was created in collaboration with the architect, captures the sketches light, flowing lines and their general joie de vivre. Niemeyers sketch for the exuberantly-curved roof of a church in Pampulha, Belo Horizonte, for example, was translated into a pair of white gold and diamond earrings. An almost childlike drawing of a flower became a graceful, delicate bracelet made of what seems like a single, slender ribbon of yellow gold. The jeweler is known for its creative collaborations, like those with Diane von Furstenberg, the Campana brothers and even Disney (on the surreal-luxe Alice in Wonderland collection). But was Niemeyer surprised by Roberto Sterns request to turn his architectural sketches into rings and necklaces? Not at all. Stern recalled that the architect said simply, I want to make beautiful things.

The designer recently showed his new Chanel resort collection there and used the town as the setting for his short film Remember Now. The shop, in an 18th-century mansion near the Place des Lices, is awash in a Coco-esque palette of black, white, red and beige (along with gorgeously stenciled walls) that match the clothing and accessories for sale. Never mind that the store stocks only the fall ready-to-wear collection; the tile floors and exotic flora in the garden lend plenty of beachy vibes.Chanel in St. Tropez, 25 rue Franois Sibilli; open from June 23 to Oct. 3, 2010.

title: BP Protesters Stage Mini-Spill at Tate Britain
description: Protesters took their dissatisfaction with BP to the steps of the Tate Britain museum in London, above, using the occasion of a summer party celebrating the oil companys 20-year sponsorship of the museum to call attention to its handling of the calamitous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday night, Bloomberg News reported, members of a protest group emptied BP-labeled cans containing a slick material in front of the partys entrance and covered the spillage with bird feathers. Other protesters poured out cans of the same material in the museums main hall while a separate group dressed in black picketed the event. BP, which spends more than $1.5 million a year to sponsor art institutions including the Tate Britain, the British Museum, the Royal Opera House and the National Portrait Gallery, told Bloomberg News that it would continue to finance those sponsorships.

title: Poof! Jeannie Memoir To Appear Next Year
description: For the five seasons that she starred on the classic television comedy I Dream of Jeannie, Barbara Eden could conjure up anything from valuable artwork to an elephant with a nod and a blink. So why did it take her four decades since the series ended its run to write a memoir about her life and career? Quite frankly, it scared the dickens out of me, Ms. Eden said in a telephone interview. I was quite frightened of doing this. Ive been asked several times, and its daunting to talk about yourself. It gets to the soft spots inside you. On Tuesday the Crown Archetype imprint of Random Houses Crown Publishing division said that it would release a memoir by Ms. Eden, called Jeannie Out of the Bottle, in the spring of 2011. As its title implies, the book will have its share to say about I Dream of Jeannie, in which Ms. Eden played the mystically empowered title character from 1965 to 1970. Shell have a big voice in this story, Ms. Eden said, but a lot went on before Jeannie. Ms. Eden, who is working with a collaborator, Wendy Leigh, on the memoir, said they had a few more soul-baring sessions planned before the manuscript is complete. Ill just hold my nose and jump in, Ms. Eden said.

title: Juilliard Quartet Violinist Steps Down; Health Cited
description: Nick Eanet, who joined the Juilliard String Quartet less than a year ago as first violinist, is resigning for health reasons, the group said on Tuesday. Mr. Eanet has an acute digestive ailment that makes it difficult for him to take part in the quartets extensive touring, according to a statement. The condition is not life-threatening, it said. Mr. Eanet will spend next season with the quartet while a replacement is sought. He left a post as a concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera to join the Juilliard, and replaced Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music.

title: Playboy Sues Drake
description: The rapper Drakes breakthrough single, Best I Ever Had, which went from a mixtape to a popular EP, didnt get to be the best all on its own, according to a copyright infringement suit filed by Playboy Enterprises. In the suit, which Playboy filed in federal court in California on Friday, the company says that Drake used material from the 1975 song Fallin in Love, by Hamilton, Joe Frank & Reynolds. Playboy owns the rights to that song. Cash Money Records, Universal Music Group and Universal Music Group Distribution are also named as defendants. Representatives for Playboy Enterprises, Drake and Universal said they had no comment. Drakes single peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100 and brought him a pair of 2010 Grammy nominations. The EP, So Far Gone, that includes the single has sold almost 500,000 copies.

title: Join the Glee Club

In a deal outlined on Tuesday, Oxygen will start a Glee casting-call reality show in June 2011 as part of a broader deal with Twentieth Television to show repeats of Glee in syndication beginning in 2013. The deal was reported by Deadline.com. Its an unusual cable extension of a broadcasters show, and it affirms the popularity of Glee, which recently wrapped up its first season. Fox mounted a nationwide call for new cast members earlier this year but last week scrapped its plans for a series of reality specials about the process. Published reports indicated that the Glee executive producer Ryan Murphy wanted to concentrate on the second season of the ensemble drama, which will start in the fall. In another deal for a freshman-year series this week, Twentieth Television sold repeats of the ABC sitcom Modern Family to the cable channel USA.

But she has taught about terrorism at Harvard and has served on the National Security Council, and she has spent a fair amount of time talking to terrorists themselves. Her 2003 book, Terror in the Name of God: Why Religious Militants Kill, consists largely of interviews with extremists of every stripe: Christian, Jewish, Muslim, anti-abortion militants, even followers of Timothy McVeigh.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Allison Amend
description: Allison Amend is the author of a story collection, Things That Pass for Love, and a novel, Stations West.Asking me to blog about music is like asking a parking meter about foreign policy: it may have an opinion, but it wont be worth much. You see, I dont listen to music. O.K., a little bit when jogging, but its the same 10 songs in the same order that Ive listened to on various machines (from yellow sports Walkman, to skipping CD-player, to minidisc player, to Zune  yes, Zune  to iPods) for years. At the gym I watch reality television (like every writer, I love Hoarders). At home, I listen to NPR. So theres no way I can impress with obscure Laplandic bands or neologistic sub-genres. Instead, Id like to share some songs I came across as I was doing research for Stations West, my novel about Jewish immigrants in Oklahoma in the 19th century. One of the subplots surrounds the construction and subsequent development of the intercontinental railroad. The railroad was the original information superhighway, bringing mail and newspapers, other cultures and foods to the remote West; railroad songs are the viral videos of the 19th century. Studying them I learned about attitudes and motivations particular to that time and place. If history is written by the winners, then songs are written by the disenfranchised, and literature is mostly about the latter.

title: A Filmmakers Muses

The afternoon sunlight streaming through the living room windows of her Park Avenue apartment, which is filled with works by artists like John Currin, Francesco Clemente and Cindy Sherman, illuminated her blond hair and pale green eyes. The overall effect seemed almost purposefully cinematic, but somehow there was not a trace of drama in the way she gestured toward the lilies and said matter-of-factly in her Greek-accented English, I cannot live without flowers or music.

Certainly, the movies that this 39-year-old director has made, from his breakthrough noir Memento to his billion-dollar Batman sequel The Dark Knight, have been some of the most influential and popular films of the last decade. title: Sun Screens
description: MOVE over, Kanye West. Bless, the avant-garde label in Berlin and Paris, has come out with shades that wouldnt look out of place in a Steven Klein video. Photoglasses ($240) are printed with a vacation photo and perforated like a colander. Duofringeglasses ($276) take a classic aviator frame and replace the  Top Gun  lenses with gold chains that dangle like beaded curtains. Available through Project No. 8 at 138 Division Street (Orchard Street); (212) 925-4271; projectno8.com or bless-service.de.

title: From Amsterdam to Cobble Hill by Bike
description: WHEN it comes to biking, New York is no Amsterdam. But that hasnt stopped Ad Hereijgers, an urban planner from the Netherlands, from opening a Euro-style bicycle store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that specializes in Dutch imports. That includes sturdy cargo and commuter bicycles by De Fietsfabriek (from $1,500) and Dutch ID (from $1,400), as well as hard-to-find accessories like a rubber bell ($2.50) and Bobike child seats ($215). The bike store is a spin-off of our urban planning activities, said Mr. Hereijgers, who divides his time between Amsterdam and Brooklyn. He plans to add film screenings, book readings and other bike-related events. Rolling Orange, 269 Baltic Street (Court Street), (718) 935-0695 or rollingorangebikes.com.

title: A Geek Never Looked So Good
description: TECHNO-LUST goes designer-chic at Dijital Fix, which opened a second store last month, on the Lower East Side. Dont expect iPod accessories here. Its all about glamorous gizmos, like the D.J.-tested, matte-black TMA-1 headphones from the Danish company AIAIAI (tma-1.com), which go on sale later this summer ($199), and Ceramic Speakers by the San Francisco designer Joey Roth ($499). Unlike its first store, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the Manhattan one has a gallery and tapas bar called Culture Fix. Shows feature photos taken with a Hipstamatic, a popular iPhone app. David Auerbach (above), the stores 25-year-old owner, said the idea for the multifunction store came from Japan. Our demographic appreciates good food, good wine, up-and-coming artists and electronics, he said. Dijital Fix, 9 Clinton Street (near East Houston Street), (877) 345-4349, dijitalfix.com.

He first spotted them on the artist Nate Lowman, before finding a pair of dead stock for himself. So when Opening Ceremony began collaborating with Timberland, Mr. Leon fished them out of the closet. The new Watershoe ($95) has a narrower shape and two new color schemes (orange and white, left, or classic aqua blue) but otherwise remains faithful to the original.

title: Counting the Years by Four
description: With the United States and three-fourths of the other teams having been sent packing many people of different nationalities are feeling a gaping hole. The institutions surrounding the teams have been working toward this tournament for four years if not longer. For them now, knocked out and discouraged, it is a process of regrouping and planning for four years down the road. For the players, however, it is not quite that simple.The U.S. team narrowly avoided heavy criticism by beating Algeria; a compliment can be given for advancing first in the group, and a tinge of pain for the missed opportunity to advance to the quarters can also be checked in with the coffers leaving Johannesburg. With these mixed emotions the players are heading home, neither a failure nor a huge success.

Instead, she is chief executive and president of the Warrior Group, a company with $124 million in revenue and 58 employees that is based in DeSoto, Tex., and handles modular construction projects in 30 states. Life happens, said Ms. Warrior, 42. She recently discussed the deal that almost put her out of business, the nuances of winning government contracts and the balancing act of being a newly divorced parent to a 10-year-old son. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: Old Media vs. New Media
description: David Brooks: Gail, lets give it up for Disney. Im down here at the Wide World of Sports complex in Orlando, Fla., watching a bunch of 11-year-old kids play baseball in 105 degree heat for seven hours a day, and I find that even out beyond the right-field fences, Disney provides high-speed Internet access for free. So I can watch my youngest pitch against 11-year-olds, who are shaving, and also monitor the Kagan hearings on my laptop. Astonishingly, most parents do not seem to be doing this.

title: Letter: Memories of the Bucovina

Readers who are intrigued by the article Deep in the Carpathians, Painted Parables (June 20) might be interested in Gregor von Rezzoris The Snows of Yesteryear and Memoirs of an Anti-Semite, both lovely descriptions of his growing up in this area. His description of the city of Czernowitz and its diverse population is moving, especially in light of what became of that diversity.

title: Letter: A Lerici Secret
description: To the Editor: Regarding An Italian Beauty Without Foreign Suitors (June 20) : Our long-kept secret is out! My husband and I discovered Lerici in 1989, while driving from Pisa to Santa Margherita. Eight years later, revisiting the region, we did some research to find this long-remembered, seemingly idyllic spot. In fact, we were not sure until we arrived that Lerici was the place. It was, and we have been back several times since.

title: Beauty Spots
description: FREEZING FAT? Lately, the prospect that cooling unwanted fat can make it disappear has been getting a lot of attention. One reason is that a growing number of doctors offer off-label treatments with Zeltiq, a cooling device that aims to make white fat cells die. (This despite the fact that the F.D.A. has not approved the marketing of Zeltiq for non-invasive fat reduction.) Results take roughly two months; each treatment area costs $500 to $1,000. A team of doctors first published on cryolipolysis, as this process is called, in 2008.

title: Walks With Men
description: In 1980, in New York, I met a man who promised me hed change my life, if only Id let him. The deal was this: hed tell me anything, anything, as long as the information went unattributed, as long as no one knew he and I had any real relationship. At first it didnt seem like much of a deal, but my intuition told me he knew something I didnt yet know about the way men thought - and back then, I thought understanding men would give me information about the way I could make a life for myself. I liked his idea that nobody would know we meant anything to each other: not the college where he taught, or the magazine where he was on staff. Not my boyfriend in Vermont.

title: Fte Accompli | Versailles Revived
description: Its easy to forget  given the cold war that sprung up between France and America during the Iraq invasion and all those hundreds of bottles of sublime French wine that were poured down the drain  about the Treaty of Alliance. This was the pact signed in 1778 by Benjamin Franklin, among others, that swore eternal friendship between the two countries and brought France into the Revolutionary War. The American Friends of Versailles was partly founded on these brotherly principles: the president, Catherine Hamilton, is a sworn Francophile who started the group in 1999 after wandering through Versailles (she is a member of the board of Les Amis de Versailles) and finding the Trois Fontaines Bosquet in utter disarray. There, the inspiration to help restore Louis XIVs seat of political power  piece by piece  was born.

description: Alcohol-induced blackouts have produced many unintended consequences, but pushing up the global price of oil and losing $10 million must rank among the most novel.

title: Looking Back, That Did Seem a Little Suspicious
description: They lived in suburban enclaves, they went to barbecues, they raised all-American kids. Now, they are accused of being Russian spies. (Maybe not particularly good ones, but spies nonetheless.) Yes, we are talking about the 11 illegals rounded up this week  some as nearby as Montclair, N.J., and Yonkers  and charged in the biggest international spy scandal in years.

title: Korean Tradition, Italian Style
description: An architect and his family live in a traditional Korean house, or hanok, that is anything but traditional on the inside.

title: Conductor as Guide on a Trip to Russia
description: The formal concert season has ended, but the New York Philharmonics musicians have a 52-week contract. So with the years subscription concerts behind them, the players have turned their attention to, well, more concerts: freebies (like the annual tour of the citys parks), out-of-town performances (the orchestras residency at the Vail Valley Music Festival in Colorado) and unusual projects (a Varse concert at this years Lincoln Center Festival). The postseason schedule also includes Summertime Classics, a series in which programs of favorites are made even more user-friendly, now in its seventh season.

title: 17 Arrests Shut Down Bronx Car Theft Ring
description: A transcontinental car theft ring based in the Bronx that stole hundreds of vehicles was broken up Wednesday, the police said, as 17 people were arrested in a series of early-morning raids.

title: New Faces Head Off to a Venerable Spot
description: At one time it would have been unthinkable that a hip Greenwich Village music club could host a send-off for young musicians heading to the formidable Darmstadt summer courses in Germany.

title: Nadal Rallies to Reach Semifinals
description: WIMBLEDON, England  In the first set of his Wimbledon quarterfinal against sixth-seeded Robin Soderling, Rafael Nadal said Soderling served big, hit hard and made basically no mistakes.

title: Beyond Larry King, Ratings Declines for CNN Programs
description: The announcement that Larry King is planning to leave his long-running CNN program in the fall  and the surge of speculation about who CNN can find to succeed the man who has been its signature prime-time star for 25 years  pushed the latest news about the channels ratings doldrums to the sideline for the moment.

title: Big Phone, Big Screen, Big Pleasure
description: You think technology moves too fast now? You think your camera, camcorder and computer become obsolete quickly?

title: How Mariano Rivera Dominates Hitters
description: The closer Mariano Rivera has confounded hitters with mostly one pitch: his signature cutter.

title: Ski on July 4 Weekend. Seriously.
description: When most skiers think of slopes to try come July, Chile and Argentina come to mind. But this year, a couple of ski resorts that dont require a passport are taking advantage of the buckets of snow that fell this winter to extend their seasons through July 4 weekend.

title: Railing at a Money-Mad World
description: At the end of the first of half of Daniel Sullivans marvelous new production of The Merchant of Venice, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, Shylock the moneylender can be found loudly lamenting his recent losses. These include a) a small fortune in cash and jewels, and b) his daughter, who has eloped with said valuables. As usual, Shylock, molten with sorrow and anger, cannot figure out which matters more.

title: Leading Only Winning Card Wins Team a Bermuda Berth
description: The U.S.A.-1 team in the 2011 Bermuda Bowl world team championship will be Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby. Seeded third in the trial that ended in Chicago on Sunday, they defeated the top seed led by Nick Nickell in the semifinals and the second seed, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss, in the final, 260 international match points to 218.

title: Louisiana Governor Seals Oil-Spill Records
description: For more than two months, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has made it clear that he considers the response of the federal government and BP to the gulf oil leak a failure on many fronts.

title: Scorecard | Thom Browne Wins!
description: Houston, we have liftoff! Today, Scorecard bids farewell to the Paris mens-wear shows  that weird and wonderful world where high concept is prized, and suits stay on the hanger. Leave it to an American making his Continental debut to pull the ultimate in-joke and suit his models up  for outerspace  before fashions General Assembly. Thats one way to score for Team U.S.A.

title: The Two Faces of the Tea Party
description: Last week, Matt Continetti published a long essay in The Weekly Standard arguing that we should understand the Tea Party as a movement thats torn between two competing political instincts  one reformist and one reactionary, one that wants to repair deformities in the American political structure and another thats ready to scrap the whole thing and restore a lost Eden. He associated these two impulses with CNBCs Rick Santelli and Fox News Glenn Beck, respectively, who are arguably the Tea Partys two founders  Santelli because of his famous on-air rant against the White Houses mortgage bailout, and Beck because of all his labors to promote the Tea Parties, and to supply their inchoate passion with a comprehensive intellectual foundation.

title: Rammellzee, Graffiti Artist, Dies at 49
description: Rammellzee, an early graffiti writer, hip-hop pioneer and performance artist whose style influenced the Beastie Boys and Cypress Hill, died Sunday in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he was raised. He lived in Battery Park City in Manhattan.

title: Museum Role Fits a Former Art Dealer
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Chancellor Donates Proceeds From Tobacco Stock
description: Updated: The chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, has donated $134,000 from the sale of her stock in the nations largest cigarette company to the universitys tobacco control center, officials said Wednesday.

title: Answers About Gay Youth in New York
description: Following is the first set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers questions about gay youth in New York City; the challenges they face; and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.

title: Food Brands Get Sociable on Facebook and Twitter
description: The number of advertisers with presences in the social media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube are increasing faster than the lines at the supermarket when the values of the cents-off coupons are being tripled.

title: With Purchase of Woot, a Daily Deal Site, Amazon Expands Its Inventory
description: Amazon.com, which sells millions of products, said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Woot, a site that sells one item at a time.

title: A Hoosier Haunting: Theres Something in the Water Thats Very Strange
description: So cold the river: thats the strange phrase uttered by a dying man in Michael Korytas calculatingly spooky new novel. The man is a 95-year-old Chicago millionaire called Campbell Bradford. And he is hardly the only person in this book to be rattled by unnaturally chilly fluids. The main character, a washed-up documentary filmmaker named Eric Shaw, spends most of Mr. Korytas 500-page story being tormented by haunted mineral water.

title: Why Nadal Is in and Federer Is Out
description: Who would have guessed that of the top four seeds at Wimbledon, only the six-time champion Roger Federer will miss the semifinals?

title: Date Is Set for Vote on Alcon Board Candidates
description: Alcon on Wednesday announced that it would hold a meeting on Aug. 16 for shareholders to vote on the appointment of five directors nominated by Novartis, which owns 25 percent of the Swiss eyecare-drug maker.

title: Welsh Rarebit, Repurposed
description: Welsh rarebit (aka Welsh rabbit) is basically a non-Swiss cheese fondue, generally enriched with egg, poured over toast and typically broiled until brown. There are dozens  hundreds  of recipes for Welsh rarebit kicking around, but here is how I made it a couple of weeks ago: two tablespoons each of flour and butter, made into a pale roux; just shy of 3/4 cup beer whisked in to form a sauce, which then simmered very gently for three or four minutes; six ounces roughly grated English cheddar (in this instance the so-called Borough Market cheddar from Whole Foods ); a tablespoon Dijon mustard; a teaspoon Worcestershire sauce; a scant 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper; and finally a beaten egg, warmed with some of the sauce then returned to the pan to enrich and slightly thicken the dish. To me, that tastes just exactly right, though a lot will depend on your cheese and your beer, of course.

title: Flash Crash a Wake-Up Call at Getco
description: The co-founders of Getco, a big market maker and high-frequency trader, are arguing that the flash crash on May 6 was a wake-up call for the entire securities industry to support stronger regulations to ensure adequate liquidity in the equity markets.

title: The Icelandic Post-crisis Miracle
description: Iceland is, of course, one of the great economic disaster stories of all time. An economy that produced a decent standard of living for its people was in effect hijacked by a combination of free-market ideology and crony capitalism; one of the papers (pdf) at the conference I just attended in Luxembourg shows that the benefits of the financial bubble went overwhelmingly to a small minority at the top of the income distribution:

title: For a Night, British Rule at the Ballet
description: Its amazing how much the whole climate of the Metropolitan Opera House improves once American Ballet Theater stops presenting its 19th-century classics. In the penultimate week of its season at the house, the company is shuffling seven one-act ballets and four pas de deux into different arrangements, and on Tuesday that meant All-Classic Masters.

title: Loan Giants Threaten Energy-Efficiency Programs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Obama administration is devoting $150 million in stimulus money for programs that help homeowners install solar panels and other energy improvements, which they pay for over time on their property tax bills.

title: Mastering the Elements
description: The Last Airbender? Lets hope so, though there is a scene at the very end that gestures toward a sequel. After 94 minutes  was that all? I could have sworn it was days  of muddy 3-D imagery and muddled storytelling, the idea that this is just the first Last Airbender seems either delusionally optimistic or downright cruel. An astute industry analyst of my acquaintance, who is 9 and an admirer of the Nickelodeon animated series on which the movie is based, offered a two-word diagnosis of its commercial prospects on the way out of the theater: Theyre screwed.

title: On Total Football, Joga Bonito and the Ultimate Goal
description: Is winning ugly better than not winning at all? Brazil and the Netherlands, which didnt always think so, have apparently come to the conclusion that it is. And while there has been some handwringing from their fans  and others  it is hard to argue that theyre wrong.

title: Cancer Causes Hitchens to Cancel Book Tour
description: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.

title: Christopher Hitchens to Begin Cancer Treatment
description: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Videos and Video Games
description: In this weeks New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Miguel Helft, who has followed Viacoms lawsuit against Google over copyright infringement of YouTube videos.

title: Curse of the Nike World Cup Commercial, Confirmed
description: A week a half ago we noted in this blog that there was something wrong with the Nike Write the Future ad, one of the signatures of this World Cup. My son, Asher Klein, a student at the University of Chicago, wrote in to say exactly what it was: the players in the ad were doing badly at South Africa 2010. Today he weighed in again to offer this update on the chilling phenomenon. (This is what you get when you bring up a child in a household where soccer is always on TV.)

title: Turmoil at School Where Principal and Parents Clashed
description: 5:31 p.m., July 2 | Updated  According to Department of Education employment records, Tomasz Grabski joined the Muscota School as principal on July 1, 2008. The school had received a B rating for the 2007-8 school year, following an F in the 2006-7 school year. Under Mr. Grabskis leadership, therefore, the schools performance grade rose from a B to an A, not from an F to an A, as a department spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

title: Accel Invests in ModCloth, a Social Shopping Site
description: ModCloth, a shopping Web site that sells flirty dresses and vintage blouses, has raised venture capital from Accel Partners, the Silicon Valley firm.

title: In Seoul, a Traditional House With Modern Style
description: SEOUL, South Korea

title: Ill Take a Scoop of Prosciutto, Please
description: The heavily tattooed woman walking the Shih Tzu ordered Secret Breakfast, the most popular ice cream flavor at Humphry Slocombe. The proprietor, Jake Godby  a man so shy and socially awkward that it never occurred to him when he opened an ice cream parlor that such an establishment might attract children  makes the ice cream with bourbon and toasted cornflakes, including so much Jim Beam that the scoops always run soft. The day was a sunny Friday, ice cream weather. Just before noon customers started lining up near the corner of Harrison and 24th Streets, an unrehabilitated crossroads in San Franciscos Mission district: first, a gold-chained Latino laborer who ordered Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt; then three 20-something guys  each part hipster, part geek  who stared anxiously at the flavor board, as if they had come in on a dare.

title: Lower Manhattan Cultural Council Picks Sam Miller as Its President
description: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has chosen Sam Miller, a veteran arts consultant and cultural policy expert, as its new president. The nonprofit council, formed in 1973 to support arts projects around the World Trade Center (which was then new) and the financial district, provides studio spaces and grants and has been best known in recent years for helping to rejuvenate the downtown arts scene after 9/11. Most recently he served as president of OAM Company, an arts consulting and producing organization he founded in 2009, working with the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation on strategies to help dance and theater programs.

title: Reyes Scratched With Stiff Back
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  After enjoying an injury-free spring, Jose Reyes was scratched from the Mets lineup Wednesday with a stiff lower back that he appeared to injure during batting practice.

title: Converting Pixels to Color Prints
description: Q. How can I move a picture that was e-mailed to me over to a photo Web site so that I can order copies?

title: Eminem Tops the Album Chart With Other Artists Far Behind
description: Much about the music industry has changed in recent years, but at least one thing remains the same: the role of Eminem, left, as a chart-topping star. His latest album, Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 741,000 copies in its opening week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, the most sales in a one week by any artist since AC/DCs Black Ice moved 784,000 copies in October 2008. Eminems sales easily exceeded those of other albums, including the new release from Miley Cyrus, Cant Be Tamed (Hollywood), which sold 102,000 copies, good enough for the third slot. The opening week of Ozzy Osbournes Scream (Epic) had sales of 81,000, putting it at No. 4. Last weeks top-seller, Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money), dropped to No. 2 with sales of 157,000, 65 percent fewer than the week before. Rounding out the Top 5 with 55,000 sales is the 34th volume of Now Thats What I Call Music!

title: Nunn and Mackintosh Duel Over Revival of Les Misrables
description: The battles in Les Misrables are supposed to be between the idealistic French revolutionaries and the army; between Valjean and Javert; and maybe between ponine and Cosette. But a dispute over the 25th-anniversary celebrations of that musical has pitted its original co-director Trevor Nunn against its producer Cameron Mackintosh, The Telegraph of London reported. In an interview with The Telegraph, Mr. Nunn, who with John Caird directed the original Royal Shakespeare Company production of Les Misrables, which opened at the Barbican Theater in London in 1985, said he and his original collaborators felt betrayed by Mr. Mackintoshs hiring of new directors for a revival of the show planned at the Barbican for September. We were not asked, said Mr. Nunn, whose Broadway credits include the current revival of A Little Night Music. In fact, we knew nothing of it. Mr. Mackintosh, who brought in the directors James Powell and Laurence Conner to handle the anniversary revival of Les Misrables, said in a statement that he was saddened by Nunns inaccurate and ungracious remarks. I believe that each new generation has to be able to put its own stamp on great material, Mr. Mackintosh said in the statement.

title: Talent Pays Off for NBC
description: Americas Got Talent topped the ratings on Tuesday night with 10.1 million viewers on NBC, according to Nielsens estimates, but crime show repeats helped CBS earn the nights most viewers on average. NBC would have led over all were it not for lower ratings for Losing It With Jillian (4.2 million) and Last Comic Standing (4.9 million). Fox ranked third with a two-hour Hells Kitchen from 8 to 10 (6.2 million). ABC finished in fourth place, with a World Cup theme episode of Wipeout (8.2 million).

title: David Duchovny to Appear in New Neil Labute Play
description: Over the course of David Duchovnys acting career his characters have gone to some unusual places, from the alien environs of The X-Files to many a Los Angeles bedroom on Californication. But there is one place Mr. Duchovny has never been: on the stage in a professional capacity. Thats about to change. On Wednesday MCC Theater said he would make his proper stage debut in its coming production of The Break of Noon, a new play by Neil LaBute. Mr. Duchovny, right, said in a phone interview he has previously acted Off, off, off, off  as many offs as you can put in front of Broadway. He added, Ive never done anything close to this scale. The Break of Noon is described in a news release as centering on a character called John Smith (Mr. Duchovny) who amidst the chaos and horror of the worst office shooting in American history, sees the face of God, setting off a maelstrom of disbelief among everyone he knows. The play, which will be directed by Jo Bonney, is to begin performances at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28. It is a co-production with the Geffen Playhouse, which will present it in Los Angeles next year.

title: Twilight Sequel Slays at Midnight
description: The Twilight Saga: Eclipse sunk its fangs into multiplexes on Wednesday morning, selling a record-setting $30 million in tickets for 12:01 a.m. shows. (Above, a famished fan.) Eclipse, the third entry in the phenomenally popular series, beat the industrys previous midnight record holder, The Twilight Saga: New Moon, which opened to $26.3 million in November. Eclipse also set an Imax record for midnight grosses, selling over $1 million and beating Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. At the very least the enormous opening puts Eclipse on track to match New Moon, which sold about $710 million at the global box office. While the studio behind the series, Summit Entertainment, has been cautious about predicting how Eclipse will perform, the hope is that its summer slot will generate repeat business dwarfing that of its predecessors. Filmed at a cost of $68 million, Eclipse will be shown in more than 4,400 theaters in North America. The next milestone to beat: New Moon holds the record for the biggest single-day gross in box office history with $72.7 million.

title: Inside Peter Buchanan-Smiths Design Studio
description: The designers TriBeCa studio is filled with axes, slings and objects of inspiration.

title: At Monticello, Jeffersons Methods Endure
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

title: Gardening the Jeffersonian Way
description: The art of saving seeds is alive at Monticello, Thomas Jeffersons home in Virginia, where gardeners are busy harvesting the pods of spent peas, beans and sea kale.

title: Thats a Nice Phone, but Hows the Network?
description: When cellphone shopping, many people start by looking for the perfect phone. All the carriers have good smartphones, so most of the time choosing one comes down to taste and budget constraints.
